https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/06/busin.print_headline: HOUSEWARE MAKER THRIVES AS FAMILIES STAY AT HOME A LOT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/06/busin.body_text: **********Although American families are reluctant to put money into new cars, houses, furniture and appliances, many are spending more time at home, entertaining and relaxing, and they are buying things for their kitchens, dens and bedrooms. **********If a company could take advantage of this demand for home accessories, therefore, it ought to do well despite the recession.  The General Housewares Corporation, a 15-year-old producer of cookware and table-top giftware, has done just that. By catering to the new interest in home entertaining, General Housewares has achieved one of the best earnings performances in the nonelectric segment of the housewares industry. **********''Consumers are spending more dollars in the home,'' observed John H. Muller Jr., chairman and president of General Housewares, which has its headquarters in Stamford, Conn. Company's Outlook for 1982 **********Since 1978 General Housewares has been exceeding its goal of a 20 percent annual rise in earnings and a 15 percent rise in sales. Last year, despite the nation's weak economy, the company had a 29 percent jump in net income, to $3.35 million, or $1.55 a share, from 1980's $2.58 million, or $1.20 a share. Its sales in 1981 rose 18 percent, to $73 million, from $62 million. **********Although the trend slowed in this year's first quarter, General Housewares still had a 14 percent profit gain on a 9 percent sales rise. In an interview, Mr. Muller said he believes that, despite a difficult second quarter, the company can do well enough in the last half to again reach its performance goal for the whole year. **********Jerome H. Kaplan, senior analyst for the Value Line Investment Survey, said that when big-ticket consumer items slow down, General Housewares' lines tend to perk up. ''During tough economic times,'' he said, ''people do more home entertaining, using lines like General Housewares' instead of spending for nights on the town. We expect the company to have another good performance in 1982.'' Pattern of Growth Is Seen **********''The company promises consistent growth in certain segments of the housewares industry,'' commented Henry L. Jicha Jr., vice president, research, for Bache Halsey Stuart Shields in New York. ''I see the possibility of a 10 percent decline in General Housewares' earnings in the second quarter because they are up against high increases last year, although I expect them to make it up in the third quarter.'' **********General Housewares was founded in 1967 when Mr. Muller, who had experience in both retailing and manufacturing, put $50,000 of his own money into a $1.5 million public stock offering. The new enterprise started out by buying a small Minnesota producer of ladders and ironing boards. **********After changing the name to General Housewares, the company eventually acquired nine other companies making complementary products, and it still owns five of them. The retained companies have been consolidated into General Housewares' two primary groups - cookware and tabletop giftware - operating a total of seven plants in Massachusetts, Connecticut, Ohio and Indiana. The cookware group is based in Terre Haute, Ind., and the table-top and giftware group is based in Hyannis, Mass. Some of Acquired Concerns **********The companies that were acquired included the Wagner Manufacturing Company, a cookware producer in Sidney, Ohio, and the Holt Howard Company, an importer of kitchen ceramics in Stamford. **********Three furniture companies, acquired along the way, were sold in 1980 so General Housewares could focus on its two major businesses.  The furniture concerns were Plantation Patterns, Birmingham; the Vogue Rattan Company, Lexington, Ky., and the Durham Manufacturing Company, Muncie, Ind. **********The aim of General Housewares, as Mr. Muller put it, has been to ''take fairly small businesses and, by providing professional management and the leverage of larger scale, make them more profitable.'' **********Upon each acquisition, the products and markets of the new business were closely studied to see if a new approach was necessary.  When the Colonial Candle Company was bought a decade ago, Mr.  Muller said, it was making a ''quality product sold primarily to candle and gift stores,'' and it was almost bankrupt. Product Changes Introduced **********''We exploded the color range and changed the colors every year, about one-third of the candle line annually,'' Mr. Muller said.  ''Bright shades have been replaced by muted or sherbet colors. We also shifted to a molded candle, which involves pouring wax into a mold rather than the usual way of hand-dipping.'' **********Colonial was in financial difficulties, Mr. Muller said, mainly because it had priced its products too low and aimed them at too narrow a market. The line has been widened, and department stores and retail chains are now major outlets. Candle sales, which were $6.5 million 10 years ago, have grown to more than $20 million, ''and Colonial is making money,'' Mr. Muller said. **********At the Columbian Enameling and Stamping Company, a Terre Haute concern acquired in 1968, heavier and smoother metals providing a more porcelain-like finish were introduced to replace the company's traditional enamel pots. New colors and a bulged shape were also added. **********Although his company has done well, Mr. Muller insists that acquisitions alone cannot assure success. ''You have to play all the keys,'' he said. ''Things are tougher today.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/10/world.print_headline: FOR RIGHTISTS IN LEBANON, THE P.L.O. IS A 'CANCER'
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/10/world.body_text: **********On the patio of his palace outside Aleih in the wealthy hill suburbs of Beirut, surrounded by retainers who are always at hand to light his cigarettes, Prince Feisal Majid Arslan, leader of the more conservative of Lebanon's two Druse factions, spoke approvingly of the Israeli invasion. **********''There is no other solution,'' said the Prince, who wore a pale pink suit over a bright pink shirt.  Asked for his views on the future, he replied: ''We will have to wait. We hope the Israelis won't do the same as the other armies who came to give us hope for peace. Our hopes were disappointed.'' His retainers nodded assent while clicking their worry beads. **********The Prince commands the loyalty of about half the Lebanese members of the Druse religion, an offshoot of Islam. He said that after the Israelis had driven the last of the Palestinians and Syrians from all of Lebanon, power should be given to a strong Lebanese military under the command of a strong president. **********''If all the foreigners are out of Lebanon, in less than a day, in two hours, the Lebanese will manage themselves,'' Prince Feisal said. ''Outsiders are Lebanon's disease.'' **********Israeli officers who took part in the leisurely discussion involving members of various rightist Lebanese factions kept smiling. But the Prince and his advisers said they did not know how long Israeli troops should stay to assure stability. ''That depends,'' he said. **********Asked why Lebanese who wanted the ouster of Palestinians and Syrians from their country were relying on the Israeli Army to do the work, the Prince shrugged. 'You Can't Imagine Our Shame' **********But the Rev. Joseph Touames, a prominent member of the Maronite Church, Lebanon's largest Christian group, responded vehemently, ''Because the Palestinians have robbed our army of its dignity.'' **********The bearded priest, who teaches anthropology at the Maronite University at Kaslik, added, ''You can't imagine our shame to have this Arab cancer imposed on us.'' **********Many Christian intellectuals differentiate between the Lebanese, Moslems as well as Christians, and the Arabs. None do so with more fervor than a group led by two widely published and resepected poets, Said Akl and May Murr, who consider the people of Lebanon descendants of the ancient Phoenicians. 4,000 Christian Fighters **********Their movement has an armed faction known as the Guards of the Cedars. Mr. Akl, the leader of the force, said he had 4,000 fighters under his command. **********The Guards have recently discovered a sense of kinship with Israel. Mrs. Murr was interviewed this morning just before she left for Israel. **********On her first visit to Israel last week, she met with Prime Minister Menachem Begin for 45 minutes. An informed Israeli source said the Begin Government would sponsor a tour of Europe by Mrs. Murr during which she will expound her views. **********''Israel and Lebanon are two twins of civilization, to which the world owes almost the entirety of its civilization,'' said the 52-year-old poet, who teaches history at Lebanese University and the Lebanese Military Academy. A 'Salvation Operation' **********She said she had told her cadet students that the coming of the Israeli Army was not an invasion but a ''salvation operation.'' The future officers aplauded, she said. **********Mr. Akl, a poet about whom almost as many books have been written as the large number that he has published himself, said, ''We are happy that the Israeli Army has come to do this heroic labor.'' He said the invaders were ''cleaning Lebanon of the Palestinian dirt.'' **********''There is a place for the Palestinians, not on our soil but under our soil,'' the 70-year-old poet declared. ''I kill him because I have to live.'' He said he had killed Palestinians as chief of the Guards of the Cedars ''and I will kill others until none are left.'' **********An Israeli colonel, who took part in the discussion with a submachine gun cradled in his lap, said later that he had felt so sick he had wanted to leave.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/10/world.body_text: **********The State Department says that because of what it sees as improvements in the human rights situation in Guatemala, it has recommended that the United States no longer block development bank loans to that country, according to Administration officials. **********On the basis of the State Department's recommendation, the Treasury Secretary, who directs the activities of the United States in the development banks, plans to support an $18 million loan request from Guatemala to the Inter-American Development Bank, according to a Treasury Department official. The loan is for a $30 million rural telephone project. **********Without opposition from the United States, which provides about $1.1 billion, or roughly 42 percent, of the Development Bank's current capital funds, the loan is expected to be approved this month. **********The Administration's action is part of a broader policy effort to aid Guatemala, which is locked in battle with leftist-led guerrillas. It has already received Congressional authorization for $10 million under the Carribean aid program. For next year, the Administration is asking for $15 million in economic and development assistance, $3.4 million for helicopters and spare parts and $250,000 for military training. Effects of Policy Change **********The Administration's proposed policy change will affect six loans, totaling some $170 million, requested by Guatemala from the Inter-American Development Bank and the World Bank, according to James Morrell of the Center for International Policy, a nonprofit research group concerned with American foreign policy and human rights. **********The proposed change in American policy brought strong protests from some Congressional Democrats. Representatives Tom Harkin of Iowa and Jerry M. Patterson of California said they were considering legislation or a lawsuit to block the loan. Mr. Patterson is chairman of the House subcommittee on Development Institutions and Finance, which oversees the activities of the United States in the development banks. Mr. Harkin was the sponsor of legislation enacted in 1977 that prohibits the United States from supporting development bank loans to governments that ''engage in a consistent pattern of gross violations of internationally recognized human rights.'' **********Under that law, the United States has withheld approval of 128 loans to 16 countries, according to Mr. Morrell.  Mr. Morrell said that most of the vetoes occurred during the Carter Administration, and that ''the main impact of the Reagan Administration has been to change the voting policy.'' Last year, the Administration reversed previous American opposition to loans to Argentina, Chile, Paraguay, Uruguay, the Philippines and South Korea, according to Jan Shinpock, staff director of the subcommittee on International Development Institutions. 'Human Rights Considerations' **********In the past, the Administration has opposed development bank loans to Guatemala ''on the basis of human rights considerations,'' the Treasury Department said recently in a letter to the subcommittee.  But the department is considering a change in its voting policy because of ''indications of improvements in the human rights situation in Guatemala,'' according to the letter, which was signed by W. Dennis Thomas, assistant Treasury Secretary for Legislative Affairs. **********Congressional aides and Administration officials who asked not to be identified said it was tantamount to a final change in policy, given the State Department's position. **********At hearings on the $18 million rural telecommunications loan, Stephen W. Bosworth, a Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, testified before the Development Institutions subcommittee that there had been a general improvment in human rights conditions in Guatemala since Gen. Efrain Rios Montt became President after a coup on March 23, 1982. **********While the record of the new Government is ''not perfect,'' Mr.  Bosworth said it had demonstrated ''a commitment to positive change and new opportunity in Guatemala.'' Repression in Rural Areas **********Representatives from church and human rights organizations testified, however, that since the coup there had been greater repression in rural areas and especially of the country's Indians, who make up about 60 percent of the population. **********''I am convinced that since the March 23, 1982, coup, the Guatemalan Government and Army continue to engage in widespread and systematic violations of basic human rights, in particular, the right to life,'' Angela Berryman, a representative for the American Friends Service Committee, told the subcommittee. She said her conclusions were based on discusssions in July with Guatemalans who had fled to Mexico. **********This week, Amnesty International said that Guatemalan forces had ''massacred more than 2,600 Indians and peasants'' since General Rios Montt came to power. **********Representative Patterson said last week that he was strongly opposed to the Administration's intention to support the loan to Guatemala because it was counter to ''documented Government atrocities against the Indian population of the very areas where this project will go.'' He added that he saw ''improving communications in areas where the Government is committing atrocities as a form of indirect military aid.'' **********Because of the country's human rights record, the United States has not provided military aid to Guatemala since 1977.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/06/world.body_text: **********The South African Air Force shot down an Angolan MIG after an encounter over southern Angola today, according to a brief announcement made in Pretoria. **********The clash was only the second known example in the last year of South African planes being challenged in the air on their regular incursions from bases in the northern reaches of South-West Africa, the disputed territory that is also known as Namibia. Last November a South African Mirage shot down a MIG-21 that had apparently sought to intercept it when it flew near an Angolan missile and radar site. It was said at the time that radio transmissions had indicated the MIG's pilot was a Cuban. **********This evening's announcement by Gen. Constand Viljoen, the chief of the Defense Force, did not say where in southern Angola the clash had occurred. In a virtually uninterrupted series of operations against insurgent organizations over the last 15 months, South African forces are believed to have cleared a swath at least 120 miles deep in which neither the insurgents nor Angolan forces are able to maintain any regular position. **********South African strikes in late July and early August are thought to have reached points at least 160 miles north of the border, farther than South African forces had been in four years. The Cuban forces, whose presence in Angola is now said by Western and South African diplomats to be the major factor holding up a Namibian cease-fire and settlement, have avoided contact with the South Africans and are reported to have withdrawn their southernmost units to defensive positions about 185 miles from the Namibian frontier. **********According to General Viljoen, the clash today occurred as a South African reconnaissance plane, accompanied by two fighters, was surveying what were described as missile ''concentrations.'' Four MIG's intercepted the South African aircraft, the announcement said, and one was then shot down. **********The announcement justified the reconnaissance mission by saying that the Soviet Union has been rearming the South-West Africa People's Organization after its recent losses; it contended that 600 tons of military equipment have been delivered to the Angolan port of Mocamedes in the last 10 days. Elections Termed Impossible **********Despite the extensive buffer zone that South African forces have created between the Cubans and Namibia, the Government of Prime Minister P.W. Botha maintains that ''free and fair elections'' under a United Nations plan nominally accepted more than four years ago would be impossible unless Cuban forces were pushed out of Angola. An American envoy, Frank G. Wisner, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Africa, was in the Angolan capital of Luanda last week for the second time in a month for discussions on the issue. **********Mr. Wisner said on his departure from Angola that he hoped to return soon for further talks, but on Monday at the United Nations, Foreign Minister Paulo Jorge of Angola again complained sharply about American efforts to link the question of Cuban troops in Angola to a Namibian settlement. **********Mr. Norge told the General Assembly that ''continued aggression'' by South Africa had delayed a gradual Cuban withdrawal. ''The United States has tried to accuse Angola of holding up the negotiations,'' he said, ''but in reality the United States representatives are responsible for the holdup.'' **********South Africa has agreed to withdraw all but 1,500 troops from Namibia after the territory is formally placed under United Nations supervision. In the view of some analysts, a Cuban withdrawal at the same time could imperil the Government in Luanda by bringing about a showdown with the Union for the Total Independence of Angola, known as Unita, the insurgent movement led by Jonas Savimbi.

Jerome H. Lemelson, president of the Licensing Management Corporation of New York, was granted patent 4,342,038 this week for the scale and other equipment. **********Destination information needed to calculate shipping costs can be obtained from manual input or a recording. https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/28/busin.body_text: **********J. Walter Thompson had serious worries about its syndication unit well before discovering what it has called ''fictitious entries'' in the unit's computer. In 1979, Stephen M. Salorio, then Thompson's assistant legal counsel and now general counsel, wrote a long report critical in several ways of the unit's management. **********''I wrote that the unit should not be permitted to grow at its current pace,'' Mr. Salorio said, ''that it was taking on more than it could digest. A decision was made to put a cap on the syndication inventory account, but false record-keeping circumvented the cap.'' **********According to Ivan S. Fisher, Marie Luisi's attorney, the report also raised ethical and possibly legal questions about the unit's conduct. Mr. Salorio said that in 1979 he met with several groups of Thompson time-buyers to tell them they were ''not permitted to promise to give a station a portion of time'' in exchange for accepting a syndicated program. **********A document shown to The New York Times by Mr. Fisher revealed that the problem was clearly not resolved by Mr. Salorio's lectures.  On Aug. 27, 1981, Mr. Salorio sent a memo to Robert E. Buchanan, executive vice president and United States media director, and Marie Luisi, senior vice president and director of communications service (with a copy to the chairman and chief executive, Don Johnston) about tie-in barter. **********It said: ''I have been told quite directly that, in effect, our conclusion on this score is flatly incorrect - that, in fact, our people engage in some pretty bald tie-in practices.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/01/world.body_text: **********The Supreme Court of Natal Province today nullified the white minority Government's seizure of black tribal land it intends to cede to neighboring Swaziland. **********The decision returned control of the Ingwavuma area in northeast South Africa to the government of KwaZulu, one of 10 so-called black homelands. **********KwaZulu had sought the emergency court hearing to challenge President Marais Viljoen's proclamation Monday removing the district from KwaZulu authority. **********The three-judge panel's ruling was a procedural blow to the Government's attempt to hand over 3,000 square miles of land and nearly one million black South Africans to the kingdom of Swaziland.  Government lawyers said they planned to appeal the decision. **********Blacks who would be affected by the transfer accused the Government of trying to get rid of blacks without asking whether they wanted to become Swazi citizens. **********The homelands policy, which is designed to give separate citizenship to most blacks in South Africa, is the basis of the nation's overall plan of apartheid, or racial segregation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/13/world.body_text: **********Reaction in the United States was generally mild to comments made by the Rev. Billy Graham at a Moscow news conference yesterday about the status of religion in the Soviet Union. **********Some American clerics felt the evangelist was being circumspect, but there was also some angry reaction.  A mild comment came from Dr. Charles Page, pastor of the First Baptist Church in Charlotte, N.C., the evangelist's hometown.  Mr. Graham had referred to Charlotte when he said he had seen three Moscow churches packed for worship on Saturday night. ''You would never get that in Charlotte,'' the evangelist said. **********Dr. Page said the three Sunday services at his church are full.  Asked about his reaction to Mr. Graham's comments about religious freedom in the Soviet Union, Dr. Page said, ''I find it hard to believe that they are not experiencing a great deal of suffering over there in order to worship.'' Interest in Returning to Soviet **********But the Charlotte minister's comments were typical of the opinions of those who respect Mr. Graham and believe that he was being circumspect. **********The Baptist minister said he believed the evangelist was being diplomatic by not being critical of the Soviet Union.  ''It has been circulated here that he wants the opportunity to go back to Moscow, and that he is trying to hold that possibility open,'' Dr. Page said in a telephone interview. **********But criticism of Mr. Graham's remarks came from Olga Hruby, an editor of the magazine Religion in Communist-Dominated Areas. Mrs.  Hruby called the evangelist's comments ''an insult to all Soviet believers.'' **********''We know many people who are being constantly harassed and persecuted,'' she said. ''If a church is full, it does not signify that religion is free. That may be the only church allowed to remain open.'' **********Mrs. Hruby said the Siberian Pentecostals who have taken refuge in the American Embassy in Moscow had written to Mr. Graham and asked him not to go to the Soviet conference of religious leaders. Observance of Laws Assailed **********Another critic of the evangelist's comments was Dr. Edmund Robb, a Methodist clergyman who heads the Institute on Religion and Democracy. **********''I am more than a little perplexed,'' said Dr. Robb, who considers himself a friend of Mr. Graham. ''His statement that he has not seen any evidence of religious persecution is just not believable. We all know of the plight of religious dissenters who are in prison this very day.'' **********The Methodist minister was also disturbed about comments Mr. Graham made in a sermon in Moscow when he said Soviet believers should obey the laws of their Government. **********''I think it is presumptious for an American living in a free society to go to a totalitarian society and exhort those people to respect their government and obey the laws,'' Dr. Robb said. **********He said the evangelist might have misinterpreted Chapter 13 of the Book of Romans in the New Testament, where Christians are told to obey secular authorities. **********A spokesman for the Southern Baptist Convention, the nation's largest conservative denomination, said there had been little reaction about Mr. Graham's comments in Moscow. **********''Usually if they have something bad to say, they let us know,'' W. C. Fields, the spokesman, said.

Previous methods have involved vocal characteristics or delivery of a test sentence. **********The inventors, who obtained patent 4,363,102, are John E. Holmgren, a Bell staff psychologist, and two speech scientists, Aaron E.  Rosenberg and John W. Upton. The procedure can also control access to secured premises.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/28/busin.main_headline: Personal Finance; TAXES: RANCHING, HOUSING, JOBS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/28/busin.print_headline: Personal Finance; TAXES: RANCHING, HOUSING, JOBS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/28/busin.body_text: **********THE following are answers to some recent questions from readers r egarding taxes.  Q: I'm looking for a job in the film industry, and wonder if n ewspapers and magazines specificially tailored to my chosen p rofession are deductible. Do I need receipts? And what about other e xpenses like telephone answering service? **********A: First, in order to be deductible, the expenses must be incurred while looking for a job in a field you're already in. If you are trying to enter an entirely new line of business, you must bear all the expenses. **********If you already have a job in the film industry, however, you can deduct the cost of specialized industry publications as a business expense, says Leon M. Nad, national tax partner with the accounting firm of Price Waterhouse. But the Internal Revenue Service might argue that the cost of general interest publications, such as a daily newspaper, were personal in nature and hence nondeductible.  Receipts are not required, but they help to substantiate a deduction if you are audited. The answering service would be deductible. **********Q: I'm a rancher, and I operate on a fiscal year that starts Nov.  1. I've been told that while the latest round of tax reductions took effect Jan. 1 for most individuals, they do not take effect for people on fiscal years until 12 months after the start of their 1981-82 fiscal years. Can I prorate the reduction? Otherwise, I won't profit at all this year from the tax cut since my fiscal year started so late in the calendar year. **********A: Normally, you, like any other self-employed individual, would have been able to prorate the cut, but Congress was very clear about not permitting individuals to prorate this time, says Mr. Nad. One possible solution: You could incorporate, since the tax bill provides for a modest tax reduction on the first $50,000 of taxable income of small corporations for 1982 and 1983. **********Q: I've been collecting Social Security since I retired as a bank officer last October and am now doing consulting work. I've been told that a contract can be drawn in such a way that my earnings would not be considered wages and that I would still be eligible for Social Security benefits even if the payments exceed the earnings test. Is this correct? **********A: Maybe, but you're in a very grey area. Generally, in order to be eligible for Social Security benefits, you cannot have a substantial amount of self-employment income - in 1982, for example you can generally earn only $6,000 before benefits begin to drop. **********The Social Security Administration uses the same definition of self-employment income as the Internal Revenue Code, which says it is income that was earned in connection with a person's trade or business. **********The crucial question is whether a person's self-employment activities constitute a trade or business. In three recent legal decisions, payments received by certain retired taxpayers were found to be exempt from self-employment tax because the individuals were not engaged in a trade or business, since they were not making themselves available to the general public. In two cases, the taxpayers served as consultants to the companies they formerly worked for, and agreed not work for any competitors. In the third case, a retired banker served as trustee for a particular trust. **********If your consulting earnings are not subject to self-employment tax, the argument goes, they also shouldn't count for purposes of the $6,000 Social Security $6,000 earnings test. The problem is that most of these cases have not dealt with the Social Security aspect. **********Furthermore, as reported by the Research Institute of America, a tax research organization, at least one court decision in New York last year denied Social Security benefits to a consultant in a similar position to yours. The Federal appeals court in New York said an earlier court decision, which exempted a consutant's income from self-employment tax, was ''unpalatable,'' and that the taxpayer was not entitled to Social Security benefits. Although that particular decision only affects taxpayers in the second circuit, comprising New York, Vermont and Connecticutt, it certainly dims the chances of such arrangements in other locals. **********Q: But wasn't there some recent change that liberalized the benefit eligibility rules for the self-employed? **********A: Yes, but it won't help you. In 1980, Congress said that some retirement payments resulting from self-employment activities before the person involved became entitled to Social Security benefits would no longer be treated as income for purposes of the Social Security earnings test. Previously, such payments were counted as income and the recipients - for example, retired partners of accounting or law firms - lost out on benefits. The change in the law was retroactive to Jan. 1, 1978, but you must have been self-employed - and earned the payments - before retirement in order to take advantage of this change. **********Q: Is it true that I must pay Social Security charges on sick pay? **********A: Yes, in most cases. Previously sick pay was exempt from the Social Security levy, although it has always been subject to income tax. But Congress has decreed that for 1982 and thereafter, the 13.4 percent F.I.C.A. (or Federal Insurance Contribution Act) tax should apply to sick pay received in the first six months of of an illness - if it is employer-financed sick pay. Payments received under employee-financed plans or workmen's compensation, on the other hand, are not taxable, nor are those received after the sixth month of one continuous illness. **********Q: We retired recently, and bought a home in Florida for the winter months. We also own the house in New Jersey where we have lived for 21 years, but plan to rent it several months a year to pay the bills. If we later sell our New Jersey home, will we still qualify for the $125,000 exclusion from capital gains tax? **********A: It depends which dwelling is considered your principal residence. Sidney Kess, director of tax policy for the accounting firm of Main Hurdman, notes that ''the mere fact that you have rented it doesn't automatically preclude'' you from claiming the house as your principal residence. But it could be a close call if you rent it out for more than six months a year, he adds. **********Q: My husband and I work for a hospital and and live across the street in an apartment building owned by the hospital. It is now restricting the building, allowing only doctors and nurses as tenants, and we must move out. I know that moving expenses are deductible if a move is made to be closer to work, but what happens when people are forced to move further from work by the employer? **********A: As far as the I.R.S. is concerned, you foot the bill. The tax code only allows people to deduct moving expenses if they change jobs, or their company moves them to a new location, and the new job is at least 35 miles farther from your former home than your old job. Since you are not moving because of a job change, but because you are, in effect, being evicted, the expense is all personal in nature and hence nondeductible.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/28/busin.body_text: **********The president of the Ford Motor Company, Donald E. Petersen, said that he expected a gradual recovery in auto sales during the second half of 1982. **********Speaking Monday, he said there was a pent-up demand for autos in the United States and he predicted that more consumers would come back into the market after the mid-year Federal tax cut. He predicted annual car sales could reach 9.5 million this year, but he said that much of the industry improvement that he expected hinged on resolving the budget dispute between President Reagan and Congress. https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/28/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Chart House: New Direction
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/28/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Chart House: New Direction
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/28/busin.body_text: **********DESPITE setbacks in certain of Chart House's restaurant properties, the company's shares have acted well. Perhaps the market is convinced this operator of Burger King restaurants is making a successful transition into other restaurant formats. **********What Chart House is attempting to do is reduce its dependence on Burger King and its Cork 'N Cleaver Steak House chain. If Chart House is successful, this consistently profitable concern may well experience its fastest growth since it became a major company. **********At least, that is Michael Culp's opinion. He follows the restaurant industry for E.F. Hutton & Company. ''Chart House,'' he said, ''is redeploying its capital into faster-growing, higher-margined and less-saturated segments of the restaurant industry.'' **********He said that, under the company's regional franchises with Burger King, Chart House's expansion potential was ''severely limited.'' But the 275 existing Burger King outlets throw off $25 million to $30 million a year, which can be used for expansion of the company's other chains. **********Mr. Culp noted that Chart House acquired the promising Luther's Bar-B-Que last September and he reported little chainwide competition for the barbeque concept. ''The typical Luther's can do $1.2 million in sales in the first year,'' Mr. Culp said. ''It only costs $800,000 to build a unit. By comparison, a typical Chart House Burger King does only $700,000 to $800,000 in sales and costs about $700,000 to put in service.'' **********Thus, the sales-to-capital ratio is 1.5 for Luther's and 1.1 for Burger King. Church's Fried Chicken and Chi-Chi's, the Mexican restaurant franchiser, can equal Luther's sales-to-capital ratio, but there are only a handful of companies in the industry with such high returns. **********Equally important, Mr. Culp said, is that Luther's turns Chart House into a franchiser for the first time. As the Value Line Investment Survey points out, franchising involves very little investment by the franchiser - ''a plus because finances are highly leveraged, with long-term debt and capitalized leases accounting for over half of total capital.'' Assuming a company uses debt prudently, it is able to earn a higher return on its equity with borrowed money. **********Mr. Culp used McDonald's as a proxy in explaining how lucrative a franchising operation can be. He said that McDonald's could typically flow 80 percent to 85 percent of its franchise income down to pretax profit. There is no guarantee, of course, that Chart House will do as well. **********While Chart House presses development of its Luther's chain, it is cutting back its unsuccessful Cork 'N Cleaver operations. The company had 60 of these units but has converted 15 of them into Cisco's Mexican restaurants it owns outright. **********This strategy, Mr. Culp said, has ''saved'' failing Cork 'N Cleaver stores, but he added that the ''jury is still out'' as to Cisco's long-term promise. **********Many of the Cork 'N Cleaver units are in the depressed Middle West. More than a third of the company's Burger King outlets are in Illinois, where results are reflecting the recession to some degree.  But the company's Burger King units in Texas, Louisiana and Virginia are offsetting the weakness in the Middle West. **********The Chart House Steak House division, he said, is the only successful high-priced steak chain in the United States. Chart House is pushing expansion to 15 percent to 20 percent annual rate from 10 percent and is depending heavily on Burger King's cash flow to finance it. The company has 48 Chart House Steak Houses and eight more under construction. These restaurants are found primarily along the West Coast and in Florida. **********Mr. Culp is recommending the shares as among the most promising in the restaurant industry. The industry, incidentally, has been depressed in part because of recession influences and last year's severe winter. He is estimating that Chart House will earn $2.30 a share in 1982, up from $2.03 in 1981. He expects $2.80 a share in 1983. The stock was quoted at 20 bid in over-the-counter trading yesterday, its highest close this year. **********William Trainer of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith said that his firm was neutral for the intermediate term on Chart House, adding that the shares were ''O.K. to buy.'' Mr. Trainer termed the Cork 'N Cleaver conversions ''modestly successful,'' adding that he was impressed with the company's ability to operate restaurants. **********To Mr. Trainer, Luther's is an ''interesting concept,'' but he said that ''they are not alone in developing the barbecue concept,'' with Tony Roma well along with an ''upscale barbecue restaurant'' and ''others entering the field.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/31/busin.body_text: **********Sales of new single-family houses fell 4.9 percent in July to the third-lowest rate in at least two decades, the Government reported today. Meanwhile, the median price of new houses rose to a record $73,600. **********New houses were sold at an annual rate of 353,000 last month, continuing a very slow year for the housing industry, according to the new report from the Commerce Department and the Department of Housing and Urban Development. **********However, the decline from June's level, the third drop in four months, came as home loan rates were rising again in July, according to other Government figures. **********Lenders say mortgage rates have been dropping along with other interest rates this month, and that could lead to better sales figures for August and September. **********Through July, just 226,000 new houses had been sold this year, down 22 percent from the same seven months of last year. And 1981 ended up with a total of only 436,000 sales, the lowest since the Government began keeping such figures in 1963. **********On a monthly basis, over those same 20 years, only the annual sales rates of 335,000 this April and last September were lower than the rate last month, the report indicated. **********It said the median price for new houses sold in July - $73,600 - surpassed the previous high of $72,800 in August 1981.  Analysts in the housing industry have said prices have been held down by slow sales and could rise rapidly if lower loan rates bring a rush of sales to Americans who have been putting off purchases.  According to that theory, unleashing such pent-up demand would allow builders to raise prices since available homes could be in relatively short supply. **********Michael Sumichrast, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders, said today that with interest rates declining ''our people are feeling a little bit better.'' **********''I have a distinct feeling that builders are at least looking to the future with some hope; some might even survive,'' he said.  The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said average home loan rates rose to 17.22 percent in early July, but Mr. Sumichrast said rates in various parts of the nation are now in the range of 14 percent to 16 percent. **********That decline ''is not enough to bring a major turnaround this year,'' he said. But he added, ''There's more optimism now that we at least are going to see some improvement next year in housing.'' **********The new figures, adjusted for normal seasonal variations in sales, are subject to later revision when more complete information is available. **********Today's report revised June's annual sales rate to 371,000 from the 343,000 originally estimated.  Before seasonal adjustment, about 31,000 new single-family houses were actually sold in July, down from 34,000 in June, the report said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/24/busin.main_headline: Market Place; A Slow Start For Cigna
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/24/busin.print_headline: Market Place; A Slow Start For Cigna
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/24/busin.body_text: **********ON March 31, amid considerable fanfare, the Connecticut General Corporation and the INA Corporation officially formed the nation's second-largest investor-owned insurance enterprise. Known as the Cigna Corporation, it ranks behind the Aetna Life and Casualty Company among publicly traded insurance giants. **********Initially, industry analysts viewed as particularly promising the twinning of INA's talents in commercial property and casualty coverage with Connecticut General's strengths in corporate employee benefit plans and marketing. **********On April 1, Cigna began trading on the New York Stock Exchange, finishing that day at 52 1/4. A week later, the stock reached a record high of 55 3/8. But after that, reflecting a series of disappointing developments, Cigna's stock traveled a bumpy downhill road. Meanwhile, institutional investors were holding an estimated 67 percent of the 74.6 million common shares outstanding. **********Two days ago Cigna traded at a new low of 31 1/2. It closed yesterday at 33 3/4, up 3/8. **********In a presentation made to securities analysts in April, management said that 1982 could be a ''tough year,'' particularly for Cigna's property-casualty operations as well as its group health-and-life and individual life coverage. In addition, according to Standard & Poor's, the company said it would incur ''substantial'' administrative costs related to the merger, including $12 million to $13 million in fees to investment bankers. **********On May 12, Cigna reported that, on a pro forma basis, profits in the 1982 opening quarter dropped sharply. The stock market's response that day was a decline of 2 3/8 points, to 45 3/4. The next day, as selling pressure intensified, the issue dropped 4 5/8 points, to 41 1/8. **********''The first-quarter earnings for Cigna were extremely disappointing,'' said Gerald E. Lewinsohn of Merrill Lynch in a comment to clients dated May 20. ''The company reported 79 cents a share versus a pro-forma of $1.57.'' **********''This was significantly below our revised estimate of $1.25 and far below our initial estimate of $1.60,'' he said. ''The release of earnings marked the completion of several weeks of uncertainty following a meeting for analysts on April 22 at which the company indicated that analysts' estimates were too high.'' **********In releasing its first quarterly earnings report as a merged company, Cigna cited the ''continuing down cycle'' in property and casualty underwriting, in addition to ''substantial catastrophe losses related to severe winter weather.'' **********Meanwhile, Wall Street analysts had gotten the message and were cutting their earnings estimates for Cigna. At Merrill Lynch, for example, the 1982 earnings projection was lowered last month to $7 a share, from $8.65. That followed an earlier reduction from $9.25 a share. Meanwhile, the brokerage firm estimates next year's profits at $8 a share. On a comparable basis, Cigna's 1981 profit is figured at $8.51 a share. **********Currently, Merrill Lynch rates Cigna's stock as ''neutral'' on an intermediate time frame of up to one year. The firm's long-term opinion on the stock is a ''buy.'' **********At Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., analysts are projecting 1982 earnings of $6.50 a share for the insurance company. ''This estimate assumes no improvement in the current economic environment in individual life, group health and property-liability areas,'' the analyst team said. ''At this point, we remain neutral on Cigna's equity.'' **********In the second week in May, Standard & Poor's was projecting Cigna's earnings at $8.25 a share for this year. Subsequently, the investment advisory service reduced its estimate to $6.75 a share. **********Cigna was not the only company in its industry to feel the chill of lower profits. John E. O'Neil of A.G. Becker Inc. noted earlier this month that earnings for the property-casualty group, ''reflecting several major catastrophes,'' plunged 46 percent in the first quarter of 1982. **********Commenting on the group in general, he said: ''We are looking for continuing erratic quarterly earnings and, in our opinion, there is no urgency to buy the stocks.'' **********Although Aetna Life and Casualty posted higher earnings in the year's opening quarter, this stock has also come under steady pressure. One reason, according to Herbert E. Goodfriend of Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc., is ''negative investor perceptions'' regarding Aetna's proposed acquisition of Geosource Inc., which supplies products and services to the energy industry. **********Drexel Burnham Lambert rates Aetna as a buy and has advised purchase of the stock on weakness.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/12/world.body_text: **********Following is the text of the Israeli Government statement today announcing a cease-fire in Lebanon, as translated from the Hebrew by United Press International: **********JERUSALEM, June 11 (UPI) - Following is the text of the Israeli Government statement today announcing a cease-fire in Lebanon, as translated from the Hebrew by United Press International: **********On Saturday, June 5, 1982, the Government decided to assign the Israel Defense Forces a mission to take all the Galilee settlements out of the firing range of the terrorists who are concentrated in their bases and headquarters in Lebanon. **********In the five days of fighting the I.D.F. carried out the mission assigned it in its entirety, with heroism, with sacrifice and with great resourcefulness. **********Happy is the nation whose warrior sons these are, the commanders of its army, its soldiers. The Government extends its respect to its holy and heroic sons, who gave their lives for peace in the Galilee and for all the citizens of Israel. **********Now is the time for extending condolences to all the families who lost their dear ones and the other bereaved families of Zion and fighters of Jerusalem. May they not experience any more sorrow. **********The Government sends wishes for a speedy and full recovery to all the wounded. Cease-Fire at Noon **********After completion of the mission assigned to the Israel Defense Forces the Government has ordered the army and all its branches to cease fire today beginning at 12 noon. **********Beginning at this time Israel's soldiers will no longer fire on all fronts in Lebanon unless they are fired upon.  Every attempt by the Syrians to try to move surface-to-air missiles into Lebanese territory in place of those destroyed by our pilots will be repulsed without delay and with all the means at the disposal of the air force. **********If the Syrian Army continues to shoot at I.D.F. soldiers and attack their positions, all the responsibility for the serious results of this agressive initiative will be borne by the Government of Syria. **********There is a basis for supposing that the residents of the Galilee will no longer live in fear.  We express our hope that the day is near when real peace will prevail between a free and independent Lebanon and the state of Israel.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/03/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene; The Search For Reality
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/03/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene; The Search For Reality
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/03/busin.body_text: **********THE philosopher Mortimer Adler has been explaining on television this week that truth is not a matter of belief but of objective reality that can be empirically tested, a reality that is the same for all people no matter what they think about it. **********Does economics confront an objective reality? If so, what is the truth about the current economic situation?  Now that the election is out of the way - and before the next election campaign gets rolling - this may be a good time to try to define that reality. **********The other day at the White House, the latest Nobel laureate in economics, Prof. George Stigler of the University of Chicago, told a news conference that the United States was in a depression. When the reporters gasped, Mr. Stigler said he could call it a recession if they preferred, but the press corps, eager for a story, shouted, ''No, no,'' and Mr. Stigler let ''depression'' stand, to the discomfiture of the White House, which had thought Mr. Stigler was on its side. **********He was, but he saw no reason to sugarcoat a bitter truth. **********Under similar circumstances, Prof. Alfred Kahn of Cornell University, when he was President Carter's chief inflation fighter, suggested calling a recession a ''banana.'' **********''What's in a name?'' asked Shakespeare, and Professor Adler agrees. You can label reality whatever you like - ''aaarghhh,'' he suggested -and it will not be affected in the slightest. **********So what is today's underlying economic reality? Economists and statisticians trot out these so-called facts: **********- The rate of increase in the hourly earnings of nonfarm production workers has slowed to 6 percent. **********- Rotary rigs operating in oilfields in the contiguous 48 states declined from almost 4,500 in mid-1981 to 2,466 in September. **********- Capacity utilization in manufacturing has fallen to 69.1 percent.  And so on and on. But what do all the signs mean? As another philosopher, Susanne Langer, said, all signs may be misunderstood.  Wet streets are not a reliable sign of recent rainfall if the sprinkler wagon has just passed by. A gunshot may mean the start of a race, the rise of the sun or the sighting of danger. ''Where we find the simplest form of error,'' Miss Langer said, ''we may expect to find also, as its correlate, the simplest form of knowledge.'' It is the kind of knowledge, she said, that we share with animals. **********The difference between economists and other animals, however, is that economists commonly have preconceptions about what things mean that grow out of the economic theories they learned as students.  They also have political ideologies, conscious or unconscious, that derive from their social values or the political or economic interests they choose to serve. **********Does this affect the underlying reality that economists are trying to observe and diagnose? It should not.  Economists seek to differentiate between ''positive economics'' (the description of reality, like it or not) and ''normative economics'' (the prescription of economic policies to achieve the values that particular economists or their masters favor). Positive economics says what is, presumably for everyone; normative economics says what ought to be, according to a particular viewpoint. **********But the analytically sharp line between positive and normative appears to vanish in the real world of political economy. Why can empirical evidence - the test of reality - not act as a checkrein on economists and politicians? **********One reason is that there are so many facts and so many opportunities for interrelating them in different ways that reality never assumes a firm and consistently clear shape. **********And what is often in dispute is not present or past reality but the future - and the future is not ''real.'' It does not yet exist. It cannot be described because it is still to be created by a multitude of decisions, big and small, and by accidents or discoveries that cannot be known in advance. **********Human beings cannot bear all that uncertainty. They feel they must know the future, or something about it, as a basis for rational actions - that is, actions designed to serve their self-interests. **********Does all this mean there is no economic reality? Not at all. It is an extremely complex reality, difficult to work out. But truth is there to be deciphered as a basis for intelligent action - whether in the interests of the individual, the business, the nation or the world. **********That is the creed of the economist as social scientist. Or, to be normative, it ought to be his creed - before, during and after election campaigns.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/20/busin.body_text: **********NINE months ago, some of the finest minds in business, law and realestate starte d working on a plan to sell the General Motors Building,a 50-story ma rble tower next to the Plaza and Pierre hotels on Fifth Avenue. What evolved is a rare and unconventional $500 million deal that has intr igued real estate experts, stirred endless questions about tax imp lications and prompted Mayor Koch to announce that the city would ta ke General Motors to court. **********In need of capital, General Motors announced last April that the building was for sale. Corporate Property Investors, a private real estate investment trust made up largely of pension funds, wanted to buy. Major real estate transactions are never simple, but this bargain does not even have a name that everyone agrees on. **********General Motors got what it needed, $500 million. Instead of selling the build outright, however, it borrowed the money from Corporate Property Investors at 10 percent interest and, in return, gave C.P.I. an option to buy the building in 1991. **********For the next decade, G.M. owns the building, earns rental income, takes the tax depreciation benefits and pays Corporate Property Investors $55 million in annual interest compounded quarterly. **********C.P.I. will manage the building through a newly created affiliate, Corporate Realty Consultants Inc., which will be paid a fee by G.M.  based on rentals in the building. At the end of 10 years, G.M. will hand C.P.I. a check for $500 million to repay the principal on the loan. C.P.I. can then give the $500 million back, and become owner of the building after paying the remaining unpaid principal on the building's existing mortgage. **********Why not just sell the building? Why would anyone lend money at just 10 percent interest? Would the building have sold for $500 million in a conventional deal today or is the building's value actually less, considering the low interest rate on the loan to G.M.? Is the purpose to postpone paying taxes? **********By the crudest calculations, Federal, state and local taxes on the sale of a $500 million building that cost about $100 million to build might work out to as much as $150 million or $200 million. The estimate includes a rough $40 million calculation for the city's new 10 percent capital gains tax. **********A conventional sale could have been a windfall for the city since the new tax, which took effect last October, was intended to raise a total of $30 million annually from all sales of million-dollar buildings in New York City. **********The questions abou nd. Those who know the an swers will talk about anything but taxes, primarily because Mayor K och said he will ask thecourt to decide if this deal is a sale requir ing the payment of city taxes now. **********G.M argues that there has been no sale yet, so no taxes are owed.  Robert O'Connell, G.M.'s treasurer, explained that the company's primary goal was to raise a large sum of money, but that this arrangement has added advantages. ''We could well remain as owner if C.P.I. does not exercise its option,'' he said. ''What we've given up is a 100 percent guarantee as to the benefits of depreciation and the increased value of the building over time.'' **********Asked for any possible scenarios in which C.P.I. might not want to exercise its option, Mr. O'Connell suggested that if rental incomes in Manhattan fell, the building might not be worth $500 million in 10 years. **********John White, chairman of Landauer Associates and one of the foremost strategists and matchmakers in the country for large real estate transactions, calls this a ''wonderful deal.'' Mr. White, who represented General Motors in the deal, also worked on the last major building sale in New York City, the $400 million Pan American Building transaction. **********In a deal similar to G.M.'s, Mr. White said, he helped arrange a mortgage six years ago from a British pension fund to the developer of a large complex, including a hotel and office buildings, in Washington. The pension fund also had an option to buy 50 percent of shares in the development company, which it exercised. **********''But this is different - here the G.M. notes are unsecured,'' Mr.  White said, referring to the loan. C.P.I. would have no claim in the event that G.M. defaulted, he said, adding, ''The option is a separate agreement.'' **********He explained that the 10 percent interest being received by C.P.I.  is not the discount it might seem. The initial return on the investment, at 10 percent, he said, is higher than C.P.I. would have received if it had simply bought the building this month. **********Comparing it with that in the Pan Am Building sale, Mr. White said that the ''initial equity rate of return - the cash on cash - after debt service on a $50 million mortgage was only 2.4 percent.'' **********In the Pan Am Building deal, he explained, many of the leases were due for renewal after three years, at which time the returns would behigher when r ents were raised. He estimated that the initial return on investment in the G.M. Building, if it had been purchased, might be 3.5 percen t, but most of the leases are locked in for eight more years.

A spokesman for the Valencia provincial governor said Mr. Besse had confessed to a million-dollar armed robbery at a jewelry store in the resort of Puerto Banus on the southern Costa del Sol. **********Mr. Besse was an associate of Jacques Mesrine, another notorious gangster, with whom he escaped from a Paris prison in May 1978. Mr.  Mesrine was shot and killed by the French police in November 1979.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/02/world.print_headline: Israel Opens New Hotel In Disputed Sinai Area
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/02/world.body_text: **********Israel defied Egyptian protests today and opened a luxury hotel in the disputed Taba border zone of Sinai.  The Avia Sonesta, a 10-story white structure just 200 yards from the present Egytian border, is expected to increase tourism to Taba and Israel's neighboring port, Eilat. **********Despite the opening, both Governments have assured each other that they expect to resolve the dispute peacefully. Israel and Egypt both claim sovereignty over the area and left the Taba question open when they fixed their borders. At stake is 600 yards of choice beachfront. **********A spokesman for the hotel, Anat Kozica, said the hotel's main opening ceremony was scheduled for Nov. 15. Fifty of the hotel's 327 rooms were booked on its first day, she said. **********Israel, in a message to Cairo on Sunday, said it was ready to tackle the issue in the framework of wider talks over strained relations with Egypt. It said it also expected Ambassador Saad Mortada, who was recalled to Cairo after the massacre in the Palestinian refugee camps in Beirut, to return before these talks began. ---- Special to the New York Times **********CAIRO, Nov. 1 - President Hosni Mubarak said today that he hoped for a ''peaceful solution'' to the dispute.  Egypt says Israel, by building commercial structures around the hotel, has violated an American-mediated agreement last April to halt all construction at Taba. **********Egypt hopes to resume negotiations on the dispute at the technical expert level next month and has called on the United States to press Israel to agree.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/15/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; British Archeologist Released by Afghans
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/15/world.body_text: **********A British archeologist, Ralph Pinder-Wilson, was released from jail in Afghanistan today after nearly four months. He was flown immediately to India. **********The frail, 63-year-old director of the British Institute for Afghan Studies was one of the few Westerners to remain in the country after the Soviet intervention began in December 1979. He was jailed on charges of trying to smuggle antique coins out of Afghanistan and helping Afghans leave. **********An expert on Islamic antiquity and for many years director of oriental antiquity for the British Museum, Mr. Pinder-Wilson had been in Afghanistan since 1977 as head of a British Institute team studying and cataloging architectural findings from the city of Kandahar. He was reportedly detained in Kabul on March 28.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/01/busin.body_text: **********Workers at Sabena Belgian World Airlines, the financially ailing national carrier, have accepted a series of austerity measures including wage cuts of up to 17 percent, the airline said today. https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/16/busin.print_headline: BEAR, STEARNS HEAD WINS GLOBAL SEAT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/16/busin.body_text: **********Global Natural Resources P.L.C. said yesterday that a group of dissident shareholders had unseated only one of seven directors in a proxy battle. But the dissidents vowed to continue their fight for control of the company. **********Global, an oil and gas exploration company based on Jersey, one of the Channel Islands between France and Britain, said the only member of the slate nominated by the dissident group to win a seat on its board was Alan C. Greenberg, chief executive officer of Bear, Stearns & Company, the New York brokerage. **********Bear, Stearns had led the dissident group, which announced several months before the board meeting that it intended to oust Global's board and sell off some or all of the company's assets. Although Mr.  Greenberg said he would attempt to reconcile himself with other Global directors, others in the dissident group said they would challenge the election results on legal grounds. Proxies for New Shares **********Global's annual meeting, conducted at a hotel on Jersey, began Monday, but the company said it was unable to complete its tally of proxies until yesterday because 12 million shares were represented, more than double the number voted in previous annual meetings. **********Members of the dissident group who were unsuccessful in gaining seats on the Global board included Marvin L. Warner, a prominent promotor of professional sports teams and a former United States Ambassador to Switzerland, and Jack W. Bertoglio, a major shareholder in Ennex Inc., an Oklahoma oil exploration company. **********The dissident group, in a formal statement yesterday, asserted that none of the incumbent board members would have been re-elected without the support of proxies representing 3.1 million new shares that Global issued earlier this month. The shares were issued when Global acquired the McFarlane Oil Company, a small oil and gas concern based in Houston. **********The dissidents have challenged the McFarlane acquisition in several court petitions, most recently in a Texas state court in Dallas. In its statement yesterday, the group said it would ''press on for an early trial attacking the McFarlane acquisition.'' Hope for End of Discord **********But in an interview, Mr. Greenberg said the position of the dissident group is no longer ''necessarily my own.'' He added that his ''first and only concern'' as a member of the Global board ''is the interests of all shareholders.'' **********Frank G. Beatty, Global's president and one of the incumbent board members, said the company ''deeply regrets the divisiveness'' caused by the proxy fight and the dissident group's promise of continued litigation. He added that Global hopes ''the election of Mr.  Greenberg will signal an end to the controversy and permit the company to get on with its business.'' **********Global, an 11-year-old concern with valuable oil leases in the Canadian Arctic, was formed as a consolidation of the Fund of Funds and Overseas Investors Services Ltd., two controversial international mutual funds that had been liquidated. The dissident group had been given the upper hand in the proxy battle because Global, which previously had not had more than 16 percent of its shares represented in proxy votes, cannot directly solicit proxies from most of its shareholders. The company's shares are issued in an unusual form known as ''bearer warrants,'' which allow their owners to remain anonymous.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/05/busin.body_text: **********IS Reaganomics a failure? Many conservatives as well as liberals share the belief that it is. Kevin Phillips, author of ''The New Conservative Majority,'' declares in an article in the current issue of The New York Review of Books: ''The question for the political analyst is no longer whether Ronald Reagan will succeed or fail. He is failing, and attention must now focus upon the ramifications and dimensions of that failure.'' **********''For the White House to assume that there exists a popular desire to embrace the conservative economics of Adam Smith, Andrew Mellon, Milton Friedman, Arthur Laffer and the Business Roundtable,'' Mr.  Phillips writes, ''says very little for the Reaganites' understanding of American electoral politics and of its own mandate.'' **********Mr. Phillips believes that the true mandate was populist - dedicated to anti-establishment cultural and social values and bent on getting more jobs and income for the working people, even if that involved a radical change in American economics and politics. And if Mr. Reagan fails, Mr. Phillips foresees a further swing to the right. **********The liberals also think the Reagan mixture of monetarism and supply-side economics is doomed to failure. A new Brookings study, ''Setting National Priorities: The 1983 Budget,'' concludes that fiscal and monetary policy will stay on a collision course during the years immediately ahead. The budget implies large and increasing deficits while the monetary authorities, who have the support of the Administration, are determined to slow inflation further by maintaining a policy of restraint. **********The clash between fiscal and monetary policy brought on the current recession, and, writes Joseph A. Pechman, the Brookings director of economic studies, ''the experience is likely to be repeated in the coming years unless the mix of fiscal and monetary policies is significantly altered.'' **********That now looks highly unlikely. Mr. Reagan remains the strongest defender of the mixture as before. He was reluctant to compromise over the budget and now seems unperturbed by the breakdown of the negotiations with the Democrats. Mr. Reagan clearly thinks he can handle the problem politically. He is determined to fix blame for the deficits - which Republican and Democratic negotiators agreed would total $182 billion in the fiscal year 1983, $216 billion in 1984 and $233 billion in 1985 - on the Democrats. **********Taking his campaign to the World's Fair in Knoxville, Tenn., and to the airwaves, the President has declared that the Democrats just want to ''spend and spend and spend.'' And he has announced his support for a constitutional amendment requiring balanced budgets. **********But for the time being, and presumably for a few years to come, the nation appears to be facing the biggest deficits in history.  Why is this development not producing greater shock in the financial markets? In fact, the markets have taken the breakdown of budget negotiations with remarkable calm. **********This could be a mistake; markets have missed the coming of disaster before, as they did in the period leading up to October 1929. Yet the markets have had plenty of bad news to adjust to in recent years, and they have done so. In inflation-adjusted terms, the markets have suffered a long, slow crash since the end of the 1960's. **********Today the markets remain wary but unpanicked. They brood about the huge deficits but are glad to know the facts to which they must adjust. Amid the gloom, there are some reasons for belief in stability rather than disaster. The steep recession at home and abroad has hit the prices of oil, food, steel and other goods, and brought down the rate of inflation. Rising unemployment has brought down wages, and may hold them in check for a few years. The slump has taken a heavy toll in bankruptcies and lost profits and income.  Whether this agony was the only way to stop the inflation or not is the issue, both politically and economically. **********Slow growth appears to lie ahead. But that growth should also be consistent with a lower level of interest rates. As Lawrence R.  Klein, a Nobel laureate in economics, observed this week at City University's Graduate Center, real interest rates (nominal rates adjusted for inflation) tend to be equal to the real rate of growth of the economy - a principle first enunciated by the late John von Neuman, the mathematician. **********Real rates today are much too high in relation both to economic growth and to the actual and potential rate of inflation.  The markets may be scenting the imminent decline of interest rates. Progress on the budgetary front would make that decline far more likely. But the markets seem prepared to keep a stiff upper lip even in the face of rising deficits, falling profits, and banking strains stemming from troubles in places as distant as Poland and the Falklands. **********The illusions that the Reagan revolution would work economic and political wonders are gone. But disillusion has not yet led to upheaval, either in politics or in economics. A failed recovery could change that and bring on the black mood and radical change of which Mr. Phillips warns.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/12/busin.body_text: **********WHEN THE INTERSTATE Stores Corporation emerged from bankruptcy proceedings in 1978 as T oys 'R' Us, the toy supermarket chain, Wall Street paid little a ttention. It should have. Shares of Toys 'R' Us common stock, which t raded at 1/8 in 1975 and 6 3/8 only two years ago, were fetching $ 50 last month, a return of some 40,000 percent in seven years. **********Toys 'R' Us is the textbook illustration of a strategy that has drawn increasing attention in the investment community, that is, speculation in the ''undervalued'' securities of companies in trouble, specifically, in companies reorganizing under the protection of Federal bankruptcy law. **********The newly popular angle certainly has its share of high risks.  Foremost, of course, is that of the company's going out of business - though some investors also may gamble on asset-backed securities in hopes that liquidation does occur. But traditional fears are giving way to visions of spectacular gains. And with the recession spurring corporate bankruptcies in this country to record levels - Chapter 11 filings have shot up 50 percent from last year, according to Dun & Bradstreet - there are more opportunities than ever to turn a profit on others' misfortune. **********''When a company files for Chapter 11, the immediate reaction of the average investor is to get out, without looking at the investment opportunities,'' said Arthur Zeikel, president of Merrill Lynch Asset Management. ''But the list of casualties has cut into companies that heretofore were regarded as high-quality investments.'' **********Mr. Zeikel directs Merrill's Phoenix Fund, the newest of at least four mutual funds concentrating assets in the securities of financially strained companies, including those in reorganization proceedings, that show potential for recovery. **********Such funds seek out companies that have been hurt less through their own fault than by the business environment governing their operations. Those with solid management, operating leverage and firmly entrenched product lines are likely to rebound when interest rates and other economic conditions improve. ''What you have,'' Mr.  Zeikel said, ''is the likelihood that those companies which have suffered most in the past five years should benefit from the new economic prospects.'' **********Recommended only for investors with at least $35,000, Merrill's fund and the others' offer the potential for high capital gains at considerably less risk. For those seeking aggressive capital growth, Mr. Zeikel calls an investment of 5 to 10 percent of a portfolio in undervalued securities a ''proper diversification.'' **********The Phoenix Fund currently invests about 75 percent of its holdings in stocks and the rest in bonds of strained companies. Others, like the four-year-old First Investors Bond Appreciation Fund, concentrate investments in deep-discount debt securities. The underlying profit motives are the same, but the risks different: in the event of liquidation, preferred and common stockholders are the last to get their money back. **********For the typical investor, such a fund may be the safest way to play the game. Indeed, most experts say choosing securities among hundreds of bankrupt companies is for experts only. **********''It requires an awful lot of expertise and time, and I think most small investors don't have any of that,'' said David Solomon, who manages the First Investors Fund. Keith Hammonds

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/02/busin.body_text: **********Gerald G. Probst has been named chief executive officer of the Sperry Corporation, succeeding J. Paul Lyet, and will also become chairman when Mr. Lyet retires from that post on June 1. **********In announcing the appointment, Mr. Lyet described his successor as ''a key member'' of the office of the chairman, which was established in 1979. Mr. Probst, who has been president, chief operating officer and a member of the board of directors of Sperry since 1980, has had ''direct responsibility for the corporation's five operating divisions and the Sperry Research Center,'' Mr. Lyet added. **********Sperry produces computers and other office machines, farm, industrial and hydraulic equipment and aviation guidance systems. **********An Air Force officer for nearly two decades, including a hitch as a bomber pilot during World War II, Mr. Probst, 58 years old, joined the Sperry Univac division in 1961 as director of advanced development. He subsequently served as general manager of the division's defense systems operations, and of the company's principal commercial computer manufacturing and marketing arm. He was president of Sperry Univac from 1971 to 1978. **********''Gerry Probst's principal experience at Sperry has been with Univac, and that's probably all to the good,'' said William Easterbrook, an analyst with Kidder, Peabody & Company, noting that the company now earns nearly half of its profits from its computer business. However, Sperry has been relatively unaggressive in introducing new products - both main-frame and minicomputers - in the past year, and it is also highly leveraged, Mr. Easterbrook added.  ''Those are two major problems that he absolutely has to address,'' he said. **********A native of Ogden, Utah, Mr. Probst received an undergraduate degree in electrical engineering from the University of Utah, and a master's degree from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/18/world.body_text: **********One official and one former official of a Jewish settlement in the West Bank have been charged with destroying possible clues to unsolved bombings that crippled two Palestinian Mayors in the occupied territory in June 1980. **********Zeev Friedman, former deputy chairman of the local Council in the urban settlement of Qiryat Arba, and Shalom Rosenthal, the township's security officer, were charged in Jerusalem District Court with unlawful possession of weapons and with knowingly destroying evidence that might be needed in a judicial process. **********Detained on Oct. 11, they were questioned and released 48 hours later. Their trial has been set for Dec. 9.  According to the charge sheet, a Jerusalem electrician, Moshe Julian, found an arms cache in March or April in the Qiryat Arba Council offices where he had been installing new electric lines. He was said to have found an explosive device in a niche in a thirdfloor wall after he had dismantled a fuse box. **********Wrapped in Hebrew newspapers and placed in a plastic shopping bag, the bomb was said to have consisted of a wooden frame, a magnetic device for attaching it to a target and two army-issue explosive bricks. Bomb Reportedly Destroyed **********Mr. Julian, who is listed as a prosecution witness in the trial, was said to have called the accused to see the find.  They took the bundle to Mr. Rosenthal's office and considered what to do about reporting it. During their discussion, the indictment said, ''they noticed the dates of the newspapers corresponded to the dates of the attacks on the lives of the Mayors of Ramallah and Nablus.'' **********In June 1980, booby-trapped devices rigged to car doors blew off both legs of Mayor Bassam al-Shaka of Nablus and a foot of Mayor Karim Khalef of Ramallah. Another bomb attached to the garage door of Mayor Ibrahim Tawil of Bireh blinded an Israeli bomb-disposal expert. **********''Owing to the fact the explosive bricks were of Israel Defense Forces make and since the charge was found concealed in the Council building,'' the indictment said, ''the accused concluded it was possible the charge had been assembled by Jews and may have been linked with the attacks on the Mayors.'' **********The indictment asserted that the accused accordingly decided not to tell anyone but to destroy the package.
