https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/06/world.main_headline: MUBARAK, IN WASHINGTON SPEECH, PLEDGES TO PURSUE TIES WITH ISRAEL
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/06/world.print_headline: MUBARAK, IN WASHINGTON SPEECH, PLEDGES TO PURSUE TIES WITH ISRAEL
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/06/world.body_text: **********President Hosni Mubarak promised today that even after Egypt regains all of Sinai from Israel on April 25, ''we will continue to build bridges of understanding and friendship with the Israeli people.'' **********''This policy is irreversible,'' Mr. Mubarak said in a speech to the National Press Club on the last of his three days in Washington.  ''It is the trend of the future. In fact, the completion of Israeli withdrawal from Sinai will open the door for more interaction between Egyptians and Israelis. It signals the removal of another psychological barrier on the road to full peace.'' **********Under the terms of the March 1979 peace treaty between Israel and Egypt, Israel is to return the final segment of Sinai, captured in the 1967 war, by April 25. There has been considerable concern expressed in Israel that once Egypt gets back its land, it will lose interest in keeping the treaty alive and will instead try to win favor among other Arabs. Pledges to Continue Talks **********Mr. Mubarak, in his speech as well as in private meetings with leading American Jews and members of Congress, has sought to ease any apprehension. He pledged today to continue negotiations for an agreement on Palestinian self-rule in the West Bank and Gaza Strip beyond April 25. **********But he warned that any accord on Palestinian autonomy must win the approval of ''moderate Palestinians.'' He said that ''a bad agreementis much worse than no agreement.'' **********In another development, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., in a news conference summarizing the visit of Mr. Mubarak, expressed concern about intelligence reports that Soviet artillery and rockets were being shipped through Lebanon to Palestinian forces in southern Lebanon. 'An Aggravation' **********He said this had ''the potential'' for upsetting the cease-fire between the Palestinians and the Israelis that the United States helped bring about last July. ''We view the provision of such armaments to Palestinian elements in southern Lebanon as an aggravation to the efforts we have been engaged in to prevent the outbreak of conflict,'' Mr. Haig said. ''It's true there have been reports of levels of artillery, rocketry, moving through Lebanon to the Palestinian forces.'' The Israelis have complained for some time about the reinforcement of the Palestinian forces, but this is the first time that a ranking American official has seemed to share their concern. At the urging of Washington, the Israelis have agreed not to launch a new attack against Palestinian positions in Lebanon unless fired on first. **********Mr. Haig said Mr. Mubarak's talks with President Reagan on Wednesday and Thursday had ''deepened and broadened relations between the United States and Egypt'' begun under Anwar el-Sadat. **********In his speech, Mr. Mubarak repeatedly stressed the importance of finding an autonomy agreement that would not be rejected by the Palestinians. The goal of the accord is to set the rules for election of a Palestinian self-governing authority in the West Bank and Gaza Strip to govern the region's pending negotiations on the final status of the lands. **********''In order to give this formula a chance of being implemented,'' he said, ''it must be acceptable to the Palestinians. They are the ones who will elect the self-governing authority.'' **********As he did earlier in the week, the Egyptian leader said that ''the core of the Middle East problem is the Palestinian question.'' After meeting privately with Mr. Mubarak, some leading American Jews said they were reassured by his commitment to the Camp David accords, which have provided the basis for the treaty with Israel and the autonomy talks. 'His Only Commitment' **********''He remains committed to Camp David, and it is his only commitment,'' said Howard M. Squadron, chairman of the Council of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations. Before the meeting, some Jewish organizations expressed concern about his statements calling for Palestinian ''self-determination'' and for a Palestinian ''national entity.'' **********During his visit, there was considerable discussion about Egypt's requests for additional economic and military assistance. American officials said Egypt would continue to receive about $1 billion in economic assistance, divided among food sold at concessional rates, development projects and other types of aid. Military aid to Egypt this fiscal year will amount to $900 milliion, of which $200 million does not have to be repaid. Tentative plans are for Egypt to get an extra $400 million in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. The terms are not known. Mr. Mubarak has been regarded as more strai ghtforward and less theatrical than Mr. Sadat, but at the press c lub Mr. Mubarak won applause for his quips. **********At one point, when asked about Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader whom Mr. Sadat repeatedly called ''a lunatic,'' Mr. Mubarak maintained his stance of not attacking anyone. ''He's your friend,'' Mr. Mubarak said. ''You sold him Boeings, C-130's.'' The Egyptian leader was referring to sales made before relations between the United States and Libya worsened several years ago.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/02/busin.main_headline: O.E.C.D. WARNS FRENCH POLICY MAY LEAD TO PROTECTIONISM
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/02/busin.print_headline: O.E.C.D. WARNS FRENCH POLICY MAY LEAD TO PROTECTIONISM
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/02/busin.body_text: **********France will face ''a great temptation'' to take protectionist measures because the Socialist Government's attempt to stimulate demand is likely to bring disappointing results, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development warned in its first report on President Francois Mitterrand's economic policies. **********Such protectionist backsliding would be ''very prejudicial both to the French economy and to the international community, by creating the risk of an escalation of protectionism,'' the group concluded in its annual report on France's economic prospects, published today.  The organization monitors the economic performance of 24 major industrial member countries. **********The organization's secretariat couched its report in diplomatic terms, acknowledging that ''the goals of the new policy do not appear out of reach.'' But the overall tone was cautious and skeptical, stressing the constraints placed on the Socialists' expansive economic strategy by the weakness of world demand, France's high inflation rate and its big balance-of-payments deficit. **********After warning that the Socialists' plan to revitalize the French economy by increasing demand and restructuring industry ''will take a few years to produce results,'' the organization said that ''there might thus be a great temptation to turn toward more or less disguised protectionist measures.'' Negative Effects Seen **********In its report, the group warned of a new inflationary spiral unless the Government's social reforms - including a 35-hour workweek by 1985, earlier retirement and work sharing - are accompanied by pay cuts and arrangements to promote efficiency. Such an inflationary spurt would have ''negative effects on external competitiveness and give rise to a further increase in unemployment,'' the organization said. **********The group's concerns about a surge in French protectionism coincide with those expressed privately by France's major trading partners, particularly since the Government introduced its plan to ''reconquer the domestic market'' by offering aid to industries that try to increase their share of the home demand at the expense of foreign suppliers in critical areas. **********The organization said it t hought higher pub lic spending and the strengthening in private demand resulting fro m last year's wage and pension increases would produce a moderate ac celeration in French economic growth this year to about 3 percent and ''stabilize'' unemployment, though at a higher level than i n 1981. Outlook on Inflation **********It said inflation may slow marginally from about 14 percent last year to 13 percent in the first half of 1982, partly because of new price controls and the linking of quarterly wage rises to the anticipated rate of inflation in the next three months. France's balance-of-payments deficit on current account is likely to remain ''substantial'' but stable at about $6.75 billion. **********But the organization warned that any deterioration in the world economy will undermine these limited achievements, breeding political frustration and intensifying the pressure for a ''siege economy.'' Moreover, the group's report emphasized that many of the economic and social reforms the Socialists are carrying out risk defeating their overriding aim of reviving industry and promoting employment unless carefully handled. **********Uncertainty about the Government's plans for a far-reaching reform of the tax laws is deterring new investment and hirings, the organization said

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/26/world.main_headline: CHINA SAYS IT AWAITS CONCESSIONS FROM THE NEW SOVIET LEADERSHIP
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/26/world.print_headline: CHINA SAYS IT AWAITS CONCESSIONS FROM THE NEW SOVIET LEADERSHIP
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/26/world.body_text: **********Having extended condolences to the Soviet Union on the death of Leonid I. Brezhnev, China is making clear that it expects his successors to come up with the concessions that will open the way to more normal relations. **********Mr. Brezhnev's death left Peking, like Washington, confronting the uncertainties of a new Soviet leadership. But the Chinese have the advantage of ongoing consultations with Moscow that could offer a logical channel for any moves toward reconciliation. **********In his final months, in speeches at Tashkent and Baku, Mr. Brezhnev made two public overtures to Peking. On Monday, Yuri V. Andropov extended yet another. The new Soviet party chief said in Moscow that the Kremlin wanted to ''improve relations with all Socialist nations,'' extending even to ''spheres where for various reasons we lack the necessary trust and understanding.'' Mr. Andropov made clear that ''this is also true of our great neighbor, the People's Republic of China.'' **********Today, the Chinese Foreign Ministry replied through its information department, saying: ''We have noted the statement by Yuri Andropov on Sino-Soviet relations. We hope to see the new Soviet leadership make a new effort in eliminating the obstacles hindering the normalization of relations between the two countries.'' **********This seemed only slightly more upbeat than Peking's earlier statements about attaching importance to Moscow's deeds and not its words. 'We Pay Great Attention' **********Mr. Andropov's overture was published inside the People's Daily newspaper. According to its New China News Agency dispatch from Moscow, Mr. Andropov mentioned ideas proposed by Mr. Brezhnev in Tashkent and Baku and said that ''we pay great attention to every positive response from the Chinese side.'' **********So far, the Chinese press has avoided commenting on the new Soviet leadership, though there has been an easing of anti-Soviet language, and even Chinese officials sound more cautious than usual. Some Western diplomats here believe the Chinese are waiting to see what happens at the next round of consultations in Moscow this winter. **********Before Mr. Brezhnev's death, China had agreed to consultations with the Soviet Union on their relationship, which has been chilled for more than two decades. The initial round of meetings took place in Peking last month, and the Chinese agreed to continue to Moscow for the second round. The Soviet 'Threat' **********But China's official position was summed up by Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang on Nov. 19 in a meeting with the Thai Prime Minister, Gen.  Prem Tinsulanonda. Mr. Zhao asserted that any improvement in Chinese-Soviet relations depended upon whether Moscow would act to remove its ''threat'' against China. **********Mr. Zhao defined this as the buildup of Soviet forces along China's border with the Soviet Union and Mongolia, Moscow's military intervention in Afghanistan and its support of Vietnam's invasion of Cambodia. The three issues all constitute a threat against China, Mr. Zhao said. **********The same complaints were raised before by other Chinese officials, including Deputy Foreign Minister Qian Qichen, who represents China in the new consultations. The message to Moscow is that Peking is not softening its conditions for better ties. **********A more conciliatory note was sounded by Foreign Minister Huang Hua before he led a Chinese delegation to Mr. Brezhnev's funeral. ''The Chinese people sincerely wish there will be a genuine improvement in the relations between the two countries,'' he said, ''and that these relations will return to normal step by step.'' Lavish Praise of Brezhnev **********Mr. Huang's allusion to a step-by-step approach, which would have been cleared with the leadership beforehand, indicated that Peking did not expect to get all the problems solved at once. But he also said he hoped that ''General Secretary Yuri Andropov and the Soviet party and Government make new efforts to promote the improvement of Sino-Soviet relations.'' **********His praise of Mr. Brezhnev as ''an outstanding statesman'' was the most lavish from Peking in years and was in sharp contrast to the vilification that once filled the Chinese press. **********The cordial welcome given Mr. Huang as the first senior Chinese official to visit Moscow in 18 years made clear that the new Soviet leadership was using the opportunity to press its case for reconciliation. Mr. Huang chatted nearly four minutes with Mr.  Andropov in a Kremlin reception line and later met for an hour and a half with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko. **********On his return last Thursday, Mr. Huang told reporters that he was ''optimistic'' about the next round of consultations.  When Mr. Huang was retired the next day, some Eastern European diplomats here saw it as a rebuke of his upbeat comments, though his retirement had long been expected because of ill health. But Chinese officials insisted that Mr. Huang's retirement had in fact been postponed to allow him to make his trip to Moscow. Mr. Huang remains active as a state councillor, and he would have logically briefed his successor, Wu Xueqian, and others in the leadership about his Moscow trip.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/26/busin.main_headline: Washington Watch; Rumania Loan Payment Claim
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/26/busin.print_headline: Washington Watch; Rumania Loan Payment Claim
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/26/busin.body_text: **********WASHINGTON A second Government agency, the Export-Import Bank, has been asked for reimbursement of federally guaranteed or insured loans to Eastern Europe. **********The Commodity Credit Corporation has thus far agreed to pay out $162 million on loans now overdue that it guaranteed for American banks financing grain sales to Poland. The bulk of that sum is going to the First National Bank of Chicago, the Bank of America, Marine Midland and the Girard Bank of Philadelphia. **********The Northern Trust Company of Chicago has now come to the Ex-Im Bank, which guarantees and insures credits for nonfarm exports, with a claim for $4,090,206. The claim relates to an overdue payment owed Northern Trust by the Rumanian Bank for Foreign Trade. The credit, which was insured by Ex-Im, financed a Rumanian purchase of sulfur from the International Commodities Export Corporation of New York.  The payment was due April 5, and the Chicago bank filed for reimbursement April 14. **********Ex-Im officials said it would take 30 to 90 days to process the claim, but they indicated that they expected to come up with the money, and then would attempt to recover the funds from Rumania.  ''This is the kind of claim that we would probably pay off on,'' one official said. **********Although Northern Trust has called for payment of its loan to Rumania, most analysts agreed that this should not lead all other banks and governments to write off their loans to Rumania. Northern Trust declined to comment. **********''There is so much at stake for the other commercial banks and governments involved,'' said Daniel L. Bond, director of the Centrally Planned Economies Project at Wharton Econometrics Forecasting. ''And with rescheduling, the prospects of Rumania's paying off its debts are good.'' **********Rumania's net hard-currency debt was placed at $10 billion at the end of 1981. Of that sum, Mr. Bond estimated that $304 million was owed to American banks. **********Rumania, which has a series of short-term debts due around this time, is trying to stretch out payments and to convince Western banks to enter into negotiations to reschedule the payments. It also is hoping that the International Monetary Fund will unfreeze the remaining portions of the $1.5 billion line of credit originally extended in spring 1981. **********The I.M.F. had cut off further borrowing by Rumania - and a host of other countries, including Zaire, Morocco, Bangladesh, Zambia, Costa Rica, Tanzania, Guyana, Madagascar, Senegal, Togo, Uganda, Honduras, the Solomon Islands and Grenada - because of their failure to meet economic performance targets. **********Rumania's debt situation is said to be far more manageable than that of Poland. Marc E. Leland, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for International Monetary Affairs, said that Poland needed more than $3 billion just to service its hard-currency debt this year. But he told Senator Robert W. Kasten Jr., Republican of Wisconsin, at a hearing last week that the Administration continued to oppose calling Poland in default because it believed such action would remove pressure on Poland to repay its debts to the United States. The Continental Divide **********Continental Air Lines has broken with other carriers, and the aircraft builders, on the issue of safe-harbor leasing, and has just told House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Daniel Rostenkowski, Democrat of Chicago, that the controversial provision of last year's Economic Recovery Act should be repealed. **********It's not that Continental hasn't made money from it. In fact, Continental has received more than $23 million through the sale of tax benefits, and expects to continue to participate in the plan if it remains on the books, according to George A. Warde, the airline's president. **********Mr. Warde said in a letter to Mr. Rostenkowski that his objection was that the leasing provision put at a ''serious competitive disadvantage'' those carriers that had decided not to place large equipment orders. **********''Safe-harbor leasing provides a Federal subsidy for those carriers that have ordered billions of dollars of equipment,'' Mr. Warde wrote. ''These orders were placed before safe-harbor leasing became law and therefore safe-harbor leasing simply provides windfall payments, not incentives, for previous captial investment decisions.'' Overseas Insurance Expansion **********Reagan Administration efforts, now supported in principle by the European Economic Community, to liberalize international trade in services such as banking and insurance, have prompted the American life insurance industry to gear up for foreign expansion. **********The American Council of Life Insurance, the industry's Washingtonbased trade association, says that more than 120 American life insurance companies either are operating overseas or are interested in doing so. Early in this century, the Guardian, the Equitable Society of the United States, New York Life and Mutual Life of New York all had extensive life insurance sales in Europe. For a variety of reasons they were forced out. The trade organization will hold a seminar on May 20 to discuss strategy for getting back in. High-Tech Trade Talks **********Clyde V. Prestowitz, deputy Assistant Secretary of Commerce and new co-chairman of the United States contingent of a joint working group in high-technology trade with Japan, went off with Vice President Bush to Tokyo yesterday to press the Japanese for greater trade liberalization. A new set of measures is expected to be announced by the Japanese at international economic meetings in Paris next month. Briefcases **********- The Administration has undertaken a jawboning campaign to induce corporate pension sponsors to invest more assets in residential mortgages. Housing and Urban Development Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. frets openly about a lack of adequate mortgage money even if interest rates are brought down. **********- Prospects brighten for Export Trading Company legislation this year. Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige strongly endorses efforts of House Banking Committee Chairman Fernand St Germain, Democrat of Rhode Island, to get the long-blocked House bill moving. A Senate version has already cleared.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/08/busin.main_headline: FOR NEW BUSINESS DURING RECESSION, START MUST BE LEAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/08/busin.print_headline: FOR NEW BUSINESS DURING RECESSION, START MUST BE LEAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/08/busin.body_text: **********A year ago, James C. Pearson had a retail furniture business with an extensive inventory. As interest rates rose, however, his profit margin fell. Last summer, amid an expanding recession, he cleaned house and started a new business, Susan James Associates. **********''We're a consulting firm now,'' said Mr. Pearson, the firm's president. ''We place bids, then buy only what we need for each job.  Somebody else has to keep the inventory.'' **********Michael R. Bloomberg was a partner at Salomon Brothers, the securities firm, until last September. His new company, Innovative Market Systems, which opened for business in February, is developing computer software systems for financial analysts. ''When we sold the company to Phibro last fall,'' Mr. Bloomberg said, ''I left to start a new business.'' **********Both companies were started during a recession, and both have endured a period of business failures unequaled since the 1940's. And while they may not be representative of all new businesses formed during the recession, they may share many of their characteristics.  Tight money and technological change, business people say, are key factors in the current wave of new companies. 'Interesting Time' **********''This is an interesting time,'' Mr. Bloomberg said. ''You can't go out and start a steel mill, but the position of the business cycle and the rate of technological change are such that people can go and start small companies when they have a few people with good ideas.'' **********Not surprisingly, the number of business starts during the first quarter of 1982 declined from the same period last year. According to preliminary figures supplied by the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, 9,094 new businesses were formed during the first three months of 1982, down 2.9 percent from the 9,366 last year. The biggest declines in business start rates were recorded in the region composed of Kentucky, Tennessee, Alabama and Mississippi, down 16.9 percent. **********Dun & Bradstreet said the rate of new incorporation declined in every region of the country except the Middle Atlantic area - New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania - which had an increase of 10.3 percent. **********The Small Business Administration, which also monitors new business, cautions that 1982 figures, though they may be down, are being compared with a record number of business starts last year. In 1981, 581,661 new businesses were incorporated, up more than 9 percent from 1980. Thomas A. Gray, chief economist for the agency, attributed last year's increase at least partially to the unemployment caused by the recession. **********''New business formation just seems to occur more frequently during a recession,'' Mr. Gray said. ''If you're suddenly unemployed and walking around in the street, you're more likely to say to yourself, 'Now is the time to try.' '' **********''The other question you have to ask is, 'What businesses are failing?' '' Mr. Bloomberg added. ''I think businesses that are already in existence -small, medium or large - tend to have greater problems during a recession, as people stop spending or change their buying habits. I'm not sure that has anything to do with new businesses.'' Borrowing Costs Key Factor **********Though other sources echoed Mr. Bloomberg's comments, most still say that starting up a business these days is no picnic. Undoubtedly, the primary problem is the cost of borrowing money. For a smallbusiness owner, who is generally forced to borrow at rates far above the prime interest rates charged to a bank's best customers, high capital costs may narrow his choices of business. **********''Without a doubt, it's the biggest problem a small-business man will face,'' said Gordon Bizar, president of the International Business Network, a political and economic organization for small businesses. ''On the other hand, if you can get the money, now is the time to be buying a business.'' **********Most people do it the other way around, Mr. Bizar said. ''They get in when the market is good and pay premium prices,'' he said. ''Those are the businesses that are failing today.'' **********Of course, not all new businesses are surviving, either. A small company founded in Chicago last year with the goal of buying X-ray negatives from hospitals and selling them for their silver content died when silver prices fell. Other businesses struggle on, hoping to last until consumer spending picks up. Some find their niche right away. 'Nothing to Get Excited About' **********Scott Sanders, an actor who co-founded Survival Techniques in his New York loft last December, said sales of his custom-painted decorated pillows, at $22.50 each, had been ''O.K., but nothing to get excited about.'' **********Mr. Sanders said the recession had definitely hurt his sales, but, because his costs are so low (he and several friends do all the work), the tiny company will probably stay in business. **********According to Malcolm N. Smith, senior lecturer in the School of Economic Policy at the University of Chicago's Graduate School of Business, high interest rates have done more to new business formation than simply restricting the choices involved. Mr. Smith said the recession had made certains kinds of businesses - specifically, consulting and service companies - more attractive aside from their low start-up costs. **********''In times like this, most companies would rather contract out than increase their employment,'' he said. ''If they need a computer programmer, they'll turn to an outside consultant before they'll actually hire anyone.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/07/world.main_headline: U.S. IS FASHIONING NEW MILITARY STRATEGY FOR ASIA
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/07/world.print_headline: U.S. IS FASHIONING NEW MILITARY STRATEGY FOR ASIA
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/07/world.body_text: **********The Reagan Administration has fashioned a new military strategy for Asia that emphasizes a shift in planning and forces from Northeast Asia to Southeast Asia and the Indian Ocean, according to Administration officials. **********While no American forces are to be withdrawn from Japan or Korea now, the officials say, plans are being made to send United States Navy, Marine, and Air Force units based in Japan and Okinawa to the Persian Gulf area in the event of hostilities there. **********Moreover, United States forces held in reserve, such as an Army division in Hawaii and a Marine division in California, could be deployed to the Persian Gulf rather than to Northeast Asia as reinforcements. **********To carry out that strategy, officials say, the Administration is insisting that Japan and South Korea increase their responsibilities for security in Northeast Asia. The Administration plans especially to turn the United States relationship with Japan into an active military partnership. **********Counter Vietnamese Policies **********The Administration is looking to Southeast Asian nations to counter what is seen as Vietnamese expansion and to support United States efforts to project military power into the Indian Ocean and the oilproducing regions around the Persian Gulf. **********The Administration plans to strengthen military ties with China.  But Taiwan is not included in the Administration's plans, leading Congressional conservatives to express fears that the Administration may abandon United States commitments there. **********The officials say that the Administration is trying to weave a loose coalition of Asian nations by dealing with each directly instead of trying to mold them into a formal group. **********The evolving strategy, the officials say, culminated in Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger's trip to Japan, Korea and the Philippines in March where he tried to persuade those nations to support it. Mr. Weinberger took a low posture in public, but officials say he was forceful in private. Worries Over Soviet Navy **********About the same time, Mr. Weinberger approved the Defense Department's classified strategic guidance for the next five years, in which the policy is outlined more explicitly than it is in those portions made public. It places East Asia behind Western Europe and Southwest Asia in priority for American military resources. **********''Our foremost objective in East Asia and the Pacific is, in conjunction with our regional friends and allies, to prevent the Soviet Union and Vietnam from expanding their influence in the region,'' the defense guidance says. **********Officials said the biggest danger in Asia is the Soviet naval threat to American sea and air lines of communication that run from the West Coast through Hawaii, Guam and the Philippines to Diego Garcia and the American fleet in the Indian Ocean. Vietnam adds to that threat, they said, by providing naval, air and communications bases to the Soviet Union. **********To permit American forces to shift their attention southward, the defense guidance says the United States must ''transform our relationship with Japan into an active defense partnership in which Japan significantly increases its defense capabilities.'' U.S. Commitment to Japan **********The present relationship is based on a security treaty under which the United States is committed to defend Japan while Japan has no obligations to the United States other than providing bases. Until now, Administration officials have only suggested that Japan acquire forces capable of defending Japan and the sea lanes out to 1,000 miles. The defense guidance makes that an explicit objective. **********The defense guidance continues the longstanding policy of assisting South Korea in the event of hostilities and calls for improvements in intelligence, command, firepower and antitank weapons for American forces there. **********In Southeast Asia, the guidance says the United States must ''foster the strength and cohesion of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations to counter Vietnamese expansionism while developing further the capacity of member countries to support the projection of United States power from the Western Pacific to the Indian Ocean and Persian Gulf.'' Members of that association are the Philippines, Thailand, Malaysia, Singapore and Indonesia. **********The strategic guidance says the United States must ''maintain the strategic value of our relationship with the People's Republic of China by supporting measured increases in its military capability.'' **********The plan says that ''encouragement and, if possible, logistic support will be provided to China's military initiatives that would fix Soviet ground, air, and naval forces in the U.S.S.R.'s Far Eastern territories.'' Lines of Communication **********In a war against the Soviet Union with conventional arms, the guidance says, deployments of American forces from East Asia ''will not be automatic and will be decided on a case-by-case basis.'' **********In the Pacific, the document says, ''first priority will be to defend Alaska, Hawaii, and connecting lines of communications with the continental United States.'' **********Next, the guidance directs, ''naval and air forces will control lines of communications to the Persian Gulf and control the East and South China Seas to interdict Soviet resupply or reinforcement of naval forces deployed in the area.'' **********Forces remaining in Japan and Korea, including the American infantry division in South Korea, would assist those nations, ''giving particular emphasis to protection of United States bases in the region.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/31/world.body_text: **********An Afghan diplomat who served as ambassador to London, New Delhi and delegate to the United Nations, declared himself today in support of the rebels in his country, which he fled a week ago. **********The diplomat, Abdul Rahman Pazhwak, who was president of the General Assembly during the Middle East crisis of 1967, said that while he was 63 years old and suffering from a stomach ulcer, he was eager to travel anywhere to foster unity among the competing guerrilla groups. **********Mr. Pazhwak had been recalled from his last post as Ambassador to London at the time of the coup that brought the first of three Marxist governments to power. He said he was kept under house arrest until Babrak Karmal was made President after the Soviet intervention 27 months ago. ''Since then I have been in retirement in Kabul,'' he said. **********Mr. Pazhwak said he had been invited several times by Mr. Karmal to participate in his Government but said that he has refused. He explained that he was able to obtain a visa to come to India for medical treatment but that he had no intention of returning home. **********Mr. Pazhwak, who is the most prominent former Afghan official to have made his support for the rebels public, said that while he belonged to no particular rebel group he had been in regular contact with guerrillas while in Kabul. **********Mr. Pazhwak said that a recent party conference was disrupted by rebel activity and by deep splits within the ruling party. He said that 18 delegates to the conference, including the president of Kabul University, its chief administrator and three professors, were killed by the Islamic rebels. **********Western diplomats here said that their sources in Kabul confirmed that four university staff members, including Azia Ur-Rahman Sayedi, the president of Kabul University, were killed in what appeared to have been political attacks, although it was unclear whether the assailants were members of another Marxist faction or Islamic guerrillas.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/14/world.main_headline: IRAQIS CONFRONTING IRANIANS IN THREE SECTORS ON FRONTIER
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/14/world.print_headline: IRAQIS CONFRONTING IRANIANS IN THREE SECTORS ON FRONTIER
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/14/world.body_text: **********Iraqi ground and air forces are putting up an active defense against Iranian attacks at three points along the border, according to Western diplomats here. **********The diplomats said Iraqi forces were relying on superiority in the air and in artillery to check Iranian probes toward Baghdad. Much of the defense is concentrated near the Tib River and near Basra, on the southern front, and around Mandali, northeast of Baghdad. **********The Iraqi advantage in modern weapons is offset to some extent, these sources said, by the problems inherent in covering a frontier that is 600 miles long. The diplomats say the Iraqis realize that their forces cannot be strong everywhere, but they have accepted a calculated risk that the Iranians cannot mount more than three offensives at any one time. **********Hussein Seems to Recognize Risk **********President Saddam Hussein appeared to recognize this risk in a speech to his Cabinet on Tuesday when he noted that ''our cities and villages lie within striking distance of troops crossing the frontier.'' He added that ''the longer the war drags on, the more impossible it would be to defend all the territories on the border.'' **********At the moment both foreign diplomats and Iraqi officials share the conviction that another major Iranian offensive is unlikely. The rationale for this is the high casualty figures of the last two years of war. **********One diplomat put Iranian dead at 150,000, which by rule of thumb would mean a total of 450,000 killed, missing wounded and prisoners of war. Other estimates put the dead at 60,000. Diplomatic estimates of Iraqi dead run from 36,000 to 44,000. **********The latest Iranian attack was launched in the area of the Tib River near Musian by a relatively small Iranian force. The sector is about 170 miles southeast of Baghdad and Iranian progress there would present no serious threat to the capital, diplomats say. Key Highway May Be Target **********However, Iranian forces might be able to cut the Tigris River highway, one of two roads linking Baghdad and Basra, by driving some 30 miles west from their present positions. **********The Iranian attack, which began Wednesday night against a single Iraqi brigade, appears to have been initially successful, according to diplomats. Iraqi fighter planes and French-built Gazelle helicopters armed with guided missiles and artillery finally checked the advance. **********Iraqi sources said the invaders had nowhere penetrated more than three miles, while the Iranians put their advance at twice that much.  The attack, which occurred in the Iraqis' IV Corps sector, ended by sundown on Thursday, the sources said.  The Mandali sector is reported relatively quiet after an initial Iranian penetration of two or three miles. According to an Iraqi communique, Iranian artillery has shelled Mandali intermittently since ground attacks ended. **********The third active front, east of Basra, is also quiet. There has been desultory shelling by Iranian artillery from positions about a mile and a half inside Iraqi territory. The Iraqis have replied with planes and helicopter gunships. **********Diplomats noted two significant aspects of the current fighting.  One is that the Iranians have discarded their mass tactics and assaulted with modest forces, no more than 20,000 around Mandali and fewer than that on the Tib River. The second is that the Iranians have not used the revolutionary guards, who customarily attack in waves of shouting infantry. Two Border Areas Are Disputed **********Iraq holds some disputed territory just over the frontier. One piece of land is around Qasr-i-Shirin and the other is farther south near Zaid Algawaz. Diplomats said Iraq considers that it gained these two areas under the Algiers Treaty of July 1975, which set the frontier between the two countries. The sources noted that markers had never been placed along the new frontier and therefore Iran had not recognized the demarcation. **********Casualties have had an impact on the Iraqi civilian population. One diplomat said there was hardly a family that had remained untouched.  As a result, the war's early popularity has waned.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/16/world.main_headline: NICARAGUAN TELLS U.N. THAT U.S. WANTS TO UNDERCUT SANDINIST RULE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/16/world.print_headline: NICARAGUAN TELLS U.N. THAT U.S. WANTS TO UNDERCUT SANDINIST RULE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/16/world.body_text: **********The Foreign Minister of Nicaragua told the General Assembly today that his country ''desired an understanding'' with the United States but that ''the response of the U.S. Government has been to attempt to impose on us its rigid East-West outlook.'' **********The Rev. Miguel D'Escoto Brockmann, the Foreign Minister, accused the Reagan Administration of ''financing covert destabilizing activities'' and ''the use of its territory for the training of counterrevolutionaries.'' **********Father d'Escoto described American nuclear strategy as ''reckless,'' ''denounced the campaign launched by the Reagan Administration to deprive Angola of its inalienable rights'' and condemned ''great power complicity'' in Israel's invasion of Lebanon.  Reply From U.S. **********Kenneth L. Adelman, the United States permanent representative, exercising the right of reply, said that the United States was being subjected ''to the same baseless allegations'' that it is an aggressor. **********Mr. Adelman said the charges made by the Nicaraguan Foreign Minister were ''no more than camouflage for the massive buildup of military force in his country and the simultaneous deterioration of the economy and basic human rights.'' **********Mr. Adelman added that in the first 18 months after the Sandanists came to power in Nicaragua, the United States provided them with more aid than was provided by any other government. He said the decision to maintain power through fear and false threats of American intervention was ''a cynical calculation of the Sandinista leadership.'' New Dominican Role **********The Dominican Republic, which is competing with Nicaragua for a seat on the Security Council, also addressed the General Assembly.  Stressing the Dominican Republic's growing political stability, Foreign Minister Jose Augusto Vega Imbert, said his country was now able ''to increase its effective participation in international events.'' **********Mr. Vega Imbert pointed to his country's willingness to support and participate actively with Mexico and Venezuela in their attempts to mediate the dispute between Nicaragua and Honduras. **********In other speeches today, the Foreign Minister of Colombia expressed his country's dismay at the unsettling situation in El Salvador, Nicaragua, and Honduras. Rodrigo Lloreda-Caicedo called for the removal of all military and security advisers from the area in accordance with the suggestions made at the recently concluded meeting of foreign ministers in Costa Rica. **********Mr. Lloreda-Caicedo said the Falkland Islands should immediately be made neutral and their administration entrusted to a multinational authority until Argentina's rights can be reconciled with the legitimate interests of the islands' inhabitants. **********In the wake of the recent violation of Sweden's territorial waters by an unidentified submarine, Foreign Minister Lennart Bodstrom said that ''Swedish territory will be protected from violations with all available means.'' **********Emphasizing Swedish neutrality, Mr. Bodstrom added that ''such violations will be treated with equal determination no matter from where they emanate.'' South Africa Is Assailed **********''Our policy of neutrality does not, however, condemn us to silence or passivity,'' he said.  Mr. Bodstrom also accused South Africa of trying ''to delay the United Nations plan for Namibia.'' ''This plan is the only course for achieving a peaceful and democratic solution,'' Mr. Bodstrom said.  Several speakers spoke against attempts to link the independence of South-West Africa, or Namibia, to the withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola. **********Patrick O. Bolokor, Foreign Minister of Nigeria, Thursday called the attempt to predicate Namibian independence on the withdrawal of Cuban troops as an ''unwarranted and arrogant demand.'' He suggested that if foreign troops had not been invited in, apartheid would have recolonized Angola. **********Last year, Mr. Bolokor said, the impression was given that a solution to the Namibia issue was near. He added, ''It is now crystal clear to all that a peaceful solution of the Namibian question is as far away as ever.''

After three and a half yearsi t is possible to draw up a balance sheet and judge promise against p erformance. The experiment has not worked. **********In 1979, Mrs. Thatcher promised a radical break with the postwar British consensus on economic management. Rejecting all direct responsibility for influencing output or employment, she undertook to control inflation by monetary policy alone and to ''galvanize the entrepreneur'' by cutting taxes and government spending so that the magic of the marketplace could insure that the private sector led the way to higher growth. **********After more than doubling the rate of inflation in her first year, she has held it for three months to just less than the level she inherited - but the recent fall in the pound points to rising inflation in the second half of next year. The price in output and employment has, however, been much higher than she reckoned. **********The national income has fallen 5 percent, despite a contribution of 2 percent from North Sea oil. Manufacturing output is at its lowest in 15 years, manufacturing investment has fallen 21 percent and, for the first time in recorded history, Britain is running a deficit on its trade in manufactured goods. **********Almost the whole burden of the experiment has fallen on the private sector. Retained profits have fallen from 9 percent of gross domestic product in 1977 to 6 percent in 1981. Meanwhile, taxation as a proportion of earnings has risen 10 percent and public spending is higher in real terms and higher still as a proportion of gross domestic product. **********Moreover, the Government has failed to achieve its monetary targets. Sterling M-3, its chosen measure, rose in its first two and a half years as much as in the whole five years when I was Chancellor of the Exchequer. This year, the Government may meet its monetary target, but only because it has raised the target to the average level set by Labor. **********Like President Reagan in the United States, Mrs. Thatcher has now abandoned the more bizarre features of her monetarist doctrine. But she still faces insoluble problems in reconciling what is left of her theories with a policy for recovery which will preserve the gains she has made on inflation. To understand her dilemma, it is necessary to explain why inflation has fallen recently in Britain, although monetarist theory would dictate a rise in inflation following the high monetary growth from 1979 to the end of 1981 - and why the fall in output has been so much higher than predicted. **********The immediate cause of the collapse in output and employment is that the Government set its monetary targets too low in relation to the expected growth of G.D.P., and that the high interest rates through which it hoped to achieve those targets cut output far more than they cut the supply of money. A firm - or a country - facing bankruptcy will pay any price for the money it needs to keep going.  So corporate borrowing has been reduced less, and more slowly than the theorists imagine. **********But the high interest rates have increased the cost of investment and inventories to an intolerable level. Moreover, interest rate differentials have been the most important influence on exchange rates for the last three years. The financial markets have been rewarding monetary vice rather than virtue. Countries which use high interest rates to fight high inflation have seen their currencies appreciate and their industries become less competitive.THE Government itself expects its balance of payments surplus to d isappear next year, although it can count on a net benefit of 8 b illion from North Sea oil. If the price of oil falls and the G overnment makes pre-election tax cuts in its spring budget, Britain w ill have a large deficit and the pound will be held firm only by bigi ncreases in interest rates. Yet the Government sees its hope of e conomic recovery depending exclusively on a continuing fall in i nterest rates. **********Although a further fall in interest rates is necessary to keep industry alive - real interest rates are still exceptionally high, as in the United States - there is little reason to believe that this alone will generate recovery. With exceptional margins of spare capacity, British firms will not invest in growth unless they see the prospect of higher demand. Any increase in demand through Government action will damage Mrs. Thatcher's financial objectives. But an increasing number of bankers as well as businessmen wold accept this as a small price for recovery. **********The real problem is to increase demand in ways which will generate more jobs and output rather than more imports, higher wage costs or higher savings. There is a growing consensus that the best way to start would be to increase public spending on the economic infrastructure -roads, railways and sewage, for example - since this would generate the fastest increase in jobs at the lowest price in imports. Any tax cuts should aim at increasing investment rather than consumption for the same reason. A lower pound is also a central element in most plans for recovery. **********But the recent experience of France, following that of Britain in 1974-75, illustrates the difficulty of unilateral reflation in a deflationary world. Though Britain, like other countries, will need some selective import controls and some depreciation to protect its balance of payments, the point may easily be reached at which this could start a chain reaction of beggar-my-neighbor policies in other countries. **********That is why there is growing interest in developing collective international action for recovery within a framework of more stable exchange rates than the world has recently enjoyed. Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan's recent speeches suggest that the United States might be less hostile to such ideas than in the past. For without such action, whatever first aid the International Monetary Fund and World Bank may offer, the risk of a collapse in the international banking system will remain acute.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/20/busin.main_headline: Allies Said to Urge U.S. to Lift Taxes
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/20/busin.print_headline: Allies Said to Urge U.S. to Lift Taxes
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/20/busin.body_text: **********The major allies of the United States urged the Reagan Administration at an unpublicized meeting to raise taxes as a means of reducing the United States budget deficit and thus the pressure on interest rates, authoritative sources said today. **********The finance ministers of France, West Germany, Britain and Japan argued their case at a meeting with Treasury Secretary Donald T.  Regan at the Palace of Versailles outside Paris on Sunday, these sources added. **********The meeting was one of the informal gatherings the finance ministers hold periodically to coordinate their viewpoints on major international economic questions. **********France's Finance Minister, Jacques Delors, who was the chairman of the Versailles meeting, said today that the present international monetary climate was not in ''the strategic, political or economic interests'' of the Reagan Administration or of its allies. **********However, he told a press luncheon that the Versailles meeting might lead to new steps that would be taken at the economic summit meeting in Paris next June to promote ''a better organization of the world economy.'' **********At Sunday's gathering, the sources said, the European and Japanese finance ministers told Mr. Regan that they feared interest rates would remain high in the United States and throughout the rest of the world during the remainder of this year, depressing growth and increasing unemployment, unless Washington cut the budget deficit by raising taxes. **********Recent Reagan Administration estimates have put the deficit at near $100 billion for the present fiscal year and at well over $100 billion in the 1983 and 1984 fiscal years. **********Implicit in the European and Japanese arguments, these sources said, was a growing skepticism about the merits of President Reagan's economic policies, which stress lower taxes for individuals and businesses to stimulate economic growth and spending cuts as the principal means of reducing the budget deficits. **********The allies believe that the Administration will be unable to reduce the deficit significantly and ease the upward pressure on interest rates simply by cutting Federal spending or stimulating economic growth. **********In addition, the finance ministers were reported to have urged that the Federal Reserve promote greater monetary stability by helping other countries support the value of their own currencies against the dollar, which has risen steadily in value in recent months. **********Another suggestion, the sources said, was for the Administration to publish a weekly ''commentary'' on the American money supply figures that explained any unusual movements. The aim would be to stop interest rates, currency trading and financial markets in general from ''overreacting'' to occasional ''blips'' in the money supply figures. Others Under Pressure This happen ed last Friday when a big increase in the United States money supply for the latest reporting week pushed the dollar up sharply in va lue because currency dealers thought the Federal Reservewould be forc ed to raise interest rates to restrain money supply growth. Highe r interest rates make dollar-denominated investments attractive an d other countries are under pressure to increase interest rate s to defend the value of their currencies. **********At today's press luncheon, Mr. Delors said that the weekly money supply figures were now becoming a serious source of monetary instability because the Federal Reserve just drops them onto the markets each Friday ''like Jupiter from heaven,'' without any attempt to explain their significance. **********During the Versailles meeting, the sources said, Mr. Regan refused to make any commitment on reducing the deficit or intervening more actively in foreign-exchange markets. 'Considering' New Steps **********The Treasury Secretary was quoted as saying only that the Administration was ''considering'' new steps to increase Federal revenues and that it remained committed to intervene in foreignexchange markets in ''a crisis.'' But as a senior European official said today: ''What is a crisis? It all depends on the definition.'' **********Mr. Delors was reported to have argued at Versailles that the Unite d States was straining the alliance and encouraging neutralism in Europe with its economic policies. In rece nt months, this has beena favorite French argument against President Reagan's economic policies and the high interest rates they hav e helped bring to the rest of the world. **********The tight monetary policy of the United States has been an acute embarrassment to France's new Socialist leaders because it forces them to keep domestic interest rates up to defend the franc at a time when they are trying to reduce unemployment by stimulating faster economic growth.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/03/world.print_headline: EXCERPTS FROM INTERVIEWS WITH MRS. THATCHER ABOUT THE FALKLAND; CRISIS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/03/world.body_text: **********Following are excerpts from interviews with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher tonight by correspondents of the BBC and Britain's commercial television service: **********Q. Prime Minister, we appear to be poised for the decisivebattle for Port Stanley. Can you see any way out of that, any way of avoiding that battle? **********A. Not unless Argentina decides to withdraw her troops. That would be marvelous if she did. After all, it's what Resolution 502 said.  But she hasn't done it in seven weeks, and I don't know whether she would be considering it now. I would only be too delighted if she did, it would save so many young lives. **********Q. Would you be prepared, even at this 11th hour, to let the Argentines off the hook if President Galtieri said, ''Right, we do want to pull out,'' or do you mean that they've got to surrender?  Would you give them an honorable way out, in other words? **********A. If they say ''Look, we're going to withdraw and we are going to withdraw within the next 10 to 14 days,'' then there would be no need for a battle. It's a possibility totally linked to a timed withdrawal. After the Fighting **********Q. I'm sure you've not contemplated anything but a victory if it does come to an all-out battle for Port Stanley, but what happens after that victory, what's the next step? **********A. It isn't that we talk so much in terms of victory or defeat, we talk in terms of repossessing the Falklands, which were invaded by the Argentine aggressor. So what we are really talking about is all the Argentine forces going back to the mainland so that we repossess the Falkland Islands, and then we have to start reconstruction and rehabilitation, and then we talk about a future. There are immense possibilities for development. Also, we'll have to talk to some other nations about having security for those islands. This mustn't happen again. We have to consider what kind of future the islanders want. It will take them some time to decide, and in part it will depend upon what we are prepared to do by way of development, what other countries are prepared to do to help us by way of security. But we are a democracy, they were born free and they must have a right to self-determination, so it will take quite a time to talk it through. **********Q. Do you see a role in the foreseeable future on the Falkland Islands for the Argentines?  A. I cannot, myself, see a role in anything relating to sovereignty for the Argentines on the Falkland Islands. You saw what happened in Goose Green and Darwin, how our people have been treated. They'd never wanted to go to Argentina before. They'll be even less likely to do so now. I think we are going to be there for some time, if not alone for a number of years, because I hope we can arrange some other people to help, to have a multinational force with us. You know, when the Americans asked us to join them in a multinational force in Sinai, I said yes, because it helped peace in that area. And I'm sure we'd have just exactly the same response from them. The Role of Diplomacy **********Q. Do you think diplomacy has got a part to play now?  A. I think a decision to withdraw troops on the part of the Argentines may have a part to play. They haven't withdrawn them for the last seven weeks. I always thought it would be difficult for a dictator to withdraw but it is always just possible that at the very last minute he might think that they have their backs to the sea and that he would quite like to avoid what could be a prolonged and difficult battle for all our people. Britain's Peace Terms **********Q. Is there anything you can do to encourage him?  A. I don't think there's anything more I can do. As you know, we made up our own terms and published them - they were quite clear - about how far we were prepared to go to avoid a conflict and avoid loss of life. Everything, but everything has been turned down. There is just a possibility, not but I don't rate it very highly. **********Q. You've been told to be magnanimous in any victory. Whatdoes ''magnanimous'' mean to you?  A. It is not a word I use in connection with the Falklands, in connection with a battle on the Falklands. Sometimes I think people are using it to say, all right, hand something to the Argentines.  Under these circumstances, to an invader and an aggressor and a military dictator, that would not be magnanimity. It would be treachery or betrayal of our own people. We couldn't betray our own people. **********Q. There is a view that one should not humiliate one's opponent, that merely makes life difficult for everyone.  A. I'm not trying to humiliate anyone, I'm just trying to repossess islands which are British sovereign territory for people who are British, to have British administration, to live their own way of life under a government of their own choice. That's not humiliation, that is liberty, justice and democracy. The Position of the U.S. **********Q. What to you think of the United States part in this crisis so far? Has America really been a good ally?  A. The United States is as staunch in the principles of liberty, justice and democracy as the United Kingdom, and in her heart of hearts she knew and always knew that there could never be any neutrality between the military junta and democracy. What she had hoped to do was to try to secure a peaceful settlement including the withdrawal of Argentine forces without a battle. We're very grateful to her for making that effort. It was not her fault that it did not succeed, it was the fault of the Argentines. She made the effort, and we tried too. The Secretary General of the United Nations made the effort but he could not succeed in getting the Argentines to withdraw in accordance with that resolution. The fault lies not with the United States, nor with the Secretary General. Their efforts were splendid. It lies with an invader who's determined to try to keep the fruits of invasion as a condition of withdrawal. That was and remains totally unacceptable to us.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/22/world.body_text: **********A leading Iranian dissident cleric, Kazem Shariat-Madari, has been placed under armed guard at his house ''so that people don't attack him,'' the Speaker of Parliament, Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, said today on the Teheran radio. **********Mr. Shariat-Madari, who is in his 80's and was stripped of his religious rank of ayatollah on Tuesday, is accused of supporting a plot by former Foreign Minister Sadegh Ghotbzadeh to overthrow Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the leader of the Iranian revolution. **********Last weekend, Mr. Shariat-Madari's house, library and theological seminary were ransacked. **********Mr. Ghotbzadeh, who was arrested two weeks ago, confessed in a televised interview Monday to plotting to kill Ayatollah Khomeini.  He said Mr. Shariat-Madari was ''frightened'' to join the ranks of the plotters but had pledged to support them if the Khomeini regime was overthrowwn.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/04/busin.main_headline: AT LICENSING SHOW, 'CUTENESS' IS A MUST
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/04/busin.print_headline: AT LICENSING SHOW, 'CUTENESS' IS A MUST
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/04/busin.body_text: **********''I'm looking specifically at cats,'' Dan Frantz said.  There were numerous cats, not to mention pandas, raccoons and other unendangered species at the second annual Licensing and Merchandising Show, which concluded a two-day run yesterday at the New York Hilton. **********More than 50 licensors and would-be licensors displayed their wares - characters and trademarks - for the consideration of licensees such as Mr. Frantz, the product manager of the C.A. Reed Company, which already stamps Donald Duck, Bugs Bunny and Pac-Man on the party favors it manufactures. **********''There are so many cat designs, it's kind of mind boggling,'' Mr.  Frantz said. ''Garfield has been taken. I've looked at Heathcliff, and he has some definite merit. He's got a lot of character, lots of accessories.'' **********In recent years, licensing - the practice of using someone's name or identity to promote someone else's products and services - has become a seemingly unstoppable marketing trend. The Licensing Letter, a monthly newsletter about the industry, estimates that licensed goods rang up $13 billion at retail worldwide last year. **********''Consumers are willing to pay more for a licensed product,'' said Jack Fox, director of marketing for Mattel Toys, which licenses its Barbie and Hot Wheels trademarks. ''That's the guts of the whole business.'' 'Created a Monster' **********''I have been in the licensing business for seven years, and I have seen it grow to unbelievable proportions,'' said Lester Borden, director of licensing for Columbia Pictures Merchandising, which is frantically licensing its new movie, ''Annie.'' ''I think we have created a monster here, and I'm a little concerned about it.'' **********Mr. Fox and Mr. Borden were among the speakers at seminars before the show, where licensees, along with manufacturers interested in becoming licensees, gathered in hopes of learning how to make the monster their own. **********''You got to think packaging, you got to think product and you got to think promotion,'' Mr. Borden advised.  ''You've got to specify the territory: Where do you want to market your product?'' Mr. Fox said. ''You want exclusivity on a category - not just five-inch dolls, but all dolls. With a nonexclusive license, you're cutting your own throat.'' **********There was recognition that licensing is a mine field. According to Mr. Fox, 75 percent of all licenses fail. ''There aren't that many 'Star Wars' out there,'' he said, referring to the movie that spawned an empire of successful licensed products. **********The timing has to be right. ''I had the Smurfs four years ago,'' Mr. Borden recalled. ''I couldn't give it away.'' Subsequently, after a design change and a Saturday morning television program, the Smurfs became hugely popular. ''I will go down in history as the man who couldn't give the Smurfs away,'' Mr. Borden said. **********''We were late with Mork,'' one licensee ruefully volunteered, referring to the ''Mork and Mindy'' television series, canceled this season. 'Cuteness' Important **********The product has to be right. The attributes of a successful adult property are ''pathos, comedy, drama,'' Mr. Borden said. ''But also cuteness. Snoopy is a perfect example of a character that goes both ways.'' **********There were bad-luck licensing stories. The movie ''Blade Runner,'' after selling a number of licenses, was rated R - a rating that will keep its products off the shelves of K Mart, a major retailer. **********There were ''can-you-top-this?'' licensing stories. Among the 50-odd products licensed for ''Annie'' is a vitamin-packed dog drink. ''Arf 'n' Arf'' is scheduled to be introduced next month. Concern About 'Schlock' **********And there were warnings that licensing could get out of hand through ill-conceived products, and the unlicensed use, or counterfeiting, of trademarks and characters. ''You need an aggressive licensing agent to control it, so schlock doesn't get out there,'' Mr. Fox said. **********At the trade show downstairs, there was licensed schlock aplenty.  There was an overfriendly raccoon, whose antics were largely ignored by the crowd, and an unobtrusive bear in a pink T-shirt. There was an exhibitor who darted into the aisles to stick embroidered appliques onto everybody's name tag. ''Give your products a little character,'' one booth bannered. Another urged, ''Character-ize your merchandise.'' **********Paramount Pictures ran taped excerpts of its new movie - and licensing opportunity - ''Star Trek II.'' Bally Midway Manufacturing, owners of Pac-Man, showed video games. **********Aardvark, a poster publishing company in Bensenville, Ill., tested the licensing market for its prints. ''That would make a nice shower curtain,'' said Gerald McGlothin, the company's owner, of a print of kittens in a teardrop. **********Jared Lee, an Ohio-based artist, urged would-be licensees to consider his humorous drawings of horses. ''The horse craze has been overlooked by most manufacturers,'' Mr. Lee observed in a brochure of his designs, which noted that there are approximately three million horse owners in the United States. **********Although some manufacturers had fretted earlier that the licensing bubble might burst - ''Retailers say, 'I'm being Smurfed to death,' '' one man reported - no one at the show seemed worried by that prospect. **********''We are getting into printed shoelaces, which are getting very big,'' said one licensee.  ''Printed shoelaces?'' his listener said incredulously. ''Is there room to print characters on shoelaces?'' ''A lot of room,'' said the man. ''A lot of room.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/10/world.body_text: **********An Egyptian delegation attending a conference in Kuwait of nations that identify themselves as nonaligned received a respectful hearing from Arab and other third-world delegates and was able to tone down but not eliminate criticism of past Egyptian policies, according to reports from the conference. **********The outcome of the meeting is regarded by officials here as a first indication of what is in store for Egypt's relationship with the rest of the Arab world after completion of Israel's withdrawal from Sinai. There will be a gradual normalization of relations between Egypt and the other Arab nations, the officials say, but there will also be misunderstandings, pressures and friction even with moderate Arab regimes. **********The Kuwait meeting, of a 21-member commission preparing for a full conference of nonaligned nations in September, was the first that a high-level Egyptian delegation has attended in an Arab capital in more than three years. Dr. Ahmed Esmat Abdel Meguid, the leader of the delegation, is a member of the Cabinet of President Hosni Mubarak and Egypt's chief delegate to the United Nations. He played an active part in all phases of the Kuwait meeting. **********It was on his insistence, according to news reports from Kuwait, that a blanket condemnation of the Camp David peace accords between Egypt and Israel was stricken from the final statement and replaced by a phrase expressing ''grave concern'' only over those provisions of the accords ''that purport to determine the future of the Palestinian people.'' Autonomy Talks Attacked **********The conference thereby condemned the Egyptian-Israeli-American talks on autonomy for Palestinians of the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip but refrained from attacking Egypt's peace treaty and diplomatic relations with Israel. **********This reflected a joint position that has recently emerged among the Governments of the Persian Gulf countries. Officials there now say it was Egypt's right to recover its territory, Sinai, by making peace with Israel. But they add, referring to Mr. Mubarak's predecessor, Anwar el-Sadat, that they expect that ''Mubarak unlike Sadat will not attempt to speak for the Palestinians.'' **********But Egypt, officials here keep repeating, is determined not only to respect the treaty with Israel but also to continue the talks on Palestinian autonomy no matter how difficult and frustrating they have proved to be. **********Thus a basic conflict remains between Egypt and other moderate Arab capitals on a crucial point.  Cairo officials argue that the autonomy talks are an essential part of the peace process and must be continued, if only to keep the process from grinding to a halt. Egypt reasons that as long as there are talks, Israel is less likely to annex the West Bank or attack Lebanon. While most other Arab capitals take it for granted that Israel will annex the West Bank, Cairo still hopes it will not. **********The Egyptians see continuation of the autonomy talks as a way of proving to the other Arabs that they did not intend simply to make a separate peace with Israel and that they are determined to push for an overall settlement in spite of all the obstacles. Talks Considered Dead **********This has been said publicly by Egyptian leaders and was repeated by Dr. Meguid in Kuwait. Nevertheless, most Arab regimes regard the autonomy talks as dead and expect them to be stopped. If the Egyptians renew them, criticism of Cairo may once again rise. **********In Kuwait, Dr. Meguid obtained a second change in the final statement. The first draft attacked the multinational police force in Sinai as an attempt by NATO ''to impose Camp David on the Middle East.'' The final version deplored the ''deployment of foreign forces on or near the territory of nonaligned countries in the Middle East.'' **********The final phrasing is interpreted here as a slap at the American Rapid Deployment Force and as a warning against any American attempt to extend this force into the Persian Gulf. **********Overall, the outcome of the Kuwait meeting is seen here as a first indication that the contacts between the Egyptians and the other Arabs will grow but that the reconciliation will be slow and difficult.
