https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/21/busin.body_text: **********American Airlines reported yesterday that it had net income of $17.8 million, or 45 cents a share, in the third quarter, down 50.7 percent from $36.1 million, or $1.13 a share, in the third quarter last year, when there was an extraordinary credit of $21.7 million. **********The company said that its third-quarter revenues were $1.13 billion, up 1.8 percent from $1.11 billion. Traffic increased by 4 percent, but yield -average revenue per seat per passenger mile - declined 2.6 percent. **********The extraordinary credit in 1981, it said, resulted from the tax benefit of a net operating loss carry-forward. Without the credit, the third-quarter net in 1981 was $14.4 million, or 39 cents a share. An spokesman said that the carrier's third-quarter net last year had been held down by the air traffic controllers' strike. **********In the third quarter this year, said Albert V. Casey, chairman and chief executive of the airline, ''both traffic and yield were disappointing.'' He added, ''Traffic was adversely impacted by the sluggish economy, and efforts to improve yield were frustrated by both the residual effect of tickets bought earlier in the year at lower prices and a plethora of new, unrestricted discount fares introduced by competitors.'' **********''On the other hand,'' he said, ''American's competitive performance continued to be excellent.'' The company's operating income was $47.9 million in the quarter, a decrease of 5.5 percent from $50.7 million in the third quarter of last year. USAir **********USAir Inc. said yesterday that it had record third-quarter earnings of $16.2 million, or 93 cents a share, up 128 percent from $7.1 million, or 40 cents a share, in the period in 1981. The company also said that its earnings had been held down by the air controllers' strike. **********The Washington-based carrier, once known as Allegheny Airlines, said its revenues for the quarter were $331.7 million, up 24 percent from $268.1 million. **********USAir's chairman and president, Edwin I. Colodny, said the results ''reflect our continuing efforts to reduce unit operating costs while maintaining adequate yields'' by what he called ''rational fare structures.'' **********The company reported that it would get delivery on six two-engine Boeing 737-200 jets this year and seven in 1983.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/30/busin.main_headline: AMERICAN CAN TO BUY THIRD INSURER
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/30/busin.print_headline: AMERICAN CAN TO BUY THIRD INSURER
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/30/busin.body_text: **********The American Can Company, continuing a shift away from the packaging businesses, said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire Penncorp Financial Inc., a general insurance company, for $295.4 million in cash, notes and cash. **********American Can also said it planned to take a $250 million pretax write-down of some of its holdings and eventually sell them. The after-tax write-down, to be charged against the current quarter's earnings, would be $175 million, or $9.50 a share. The company earned $19.7 million in its 1981 third quarter. **********Penncorp would be the third and largest insurance company acquired by American Can in six months as it strives for a role as a major factor in insurance and financial services. **********American Can, whose principal business is the manufacture of metal containers, said it would issue to holders of Penncorp's outstanding common stock a total of $264 million, or $13.75 a share, in preferred stock and principal amount of notes. In addition, American Can said it had obtained an option under which it could acquire, for $31.4 million in cash, Penncorp's outstanding warrants to purchase whatever common stock remained outstanding after the securities swap. **********Penncorp, based in Santa Monica, Calif., is a major underwriter, marketer and servicer of life and accident and health insurance. It had revenues last year of $330 million and earnings of $23.7 million, or $1.25 a share. **********News of the proposed transaction depressed the shares of both companies in trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.  Penncorp fell $1.125, to $11.25, while American Can lost 87 1/2 cents, to $30.625. **********Directors of both companies have approved the agreement in principle. Shareholders must also approve.  American Can said the holdings to be written down and eventually sold included its pulp mill in Marathon, Ontario; the Lignin chemical division in Rothschild, Wis.; the operations of its Dixie Cup division in Brazil, Japan, Canada and Venezuela; the U.S. Reduction Company, a processor of secondary aluminum metals, and 584,000 acres of woodlands in the Michigan area that the company values at more than $200 million. Motives for the Sales **********In an interview, William S. Woodside, chairman and chief executive officer of American Can, said the steps were designed to improve continuing operations and divest the company of businesses ''that are unprofitable, marginal or that do not fit our long-term strategy.'' **********American Can, which also has interests in consumer products, distribution and specialty retailing, entered the insurance business in April by acquiring the Associated Madison Companies, also a general insurance company, for $130 million in cash and stock. In July, it bought the Transport Life Insurance Company for $152 million, its only other acquisition so far under its restructuring program. **********Mr. Woodside said Penncorp would more than double the size of American Can's financial services sector, ranking it ''among the top 35 life insurance firms in the country.'' He also said that if the proposed acquisition were completed, the insurance sector would account for ''something more than 25 percent of our net income.'' **********''PennCorp's strategy of pursuing speciality niches in the insurance industry fits exceptionally well with the marketing and distribution emphasis of our existing insurance operation,'' Mr.  Woodside said. **********David Bell, an analyst with Herzfeld & Stern, said the restructuring program, by increasing revenues, should provide additional funds for American Can to expand into other financial fields and ''should cushion the company's recent earnings decline.'' **********In the first six months of this year, earnings at American Can dropped to $25 million from $43.1 million the year before, mostly because of the impact of the recession. Last year the company's net earnings fell to $77 million, or $3.77 a share, on sales of $4.83 billion, from $86 million, or $4.26, in 1980 on revenues of $4.81 billion. **********Since its restructuring program was announced last year, American Can has sold most of its domestic paper-and forest-based operations to the James River Corporation for $420 million. Included were the domestic operations of Dixie Cup and its towel, tissue and foldingcarton operations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/26/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS DIGEST; FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 26, 1982; The Economy
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/26/busin.body_text: **********A recovery in housing construction has begun and will continue into 1983, say industry analysts. But the rebound will be modest compared with the surge that followed the 1974-75 recession. (D1.) **********A battle is about to break out in the small-computer business as more sophisticated and easier-to-use machines are introduced. The contenders are Apple Computer Inc., which is expected to introduce its new ''Lisa'' machine in January, and Visicorp, which this week will introduce a software product that will expand the capabilities of the I.B.M. personal computer and other machines. (D1.) **********Women's apparel at leading department stores across the country is being marked down more sharply than at any Christmas season in recent years, and retailers of women's clothing say they fear what could be their bleakest holiday season in 25 years. (A1.) International **********Common Market representatives held firm against American demands for a phase-out of agricultural subsidies. An American official said the chances were only 50-50 that the conference of the General Agreement on Tarriffs and Trade in Geneva would end a success. (D1.) U.S. coal exports are expected to decline in the near term because of increased competition from other exporters, particularly Australia, South Africa and Poland. (D6.) **********Links between the Vatican and the collapsed Italian bank, Banco Ambrosiano, were discussed by the Sacred College of Cardinals in a session attended by the Pope. A communique did not disclose details of the talks, which came during the College of Cardinals' third day of meetings. (D2.) **********Mexican businesses in cities along the U.S. border report that a more flexible exchange policy adopted by the Mexican Government has improved their lot. Mexico has maintained the official rate of 70 pesos to the dollar elsewhere, but in border cities it has permitted the peso to float near the American banks' rate of 116. As a result, businesses are taking in some badly needed dollars. (D5.) Today's Columns **********The economy is likely to continue on its limping course because fiscal policy has been largely immobilized. Monetary policy has carried too large a part of the burden as fiscal policy has been bogged down by the outlook for built-in deficits of 4 percent to 5 percent of gross national product. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene.  (D2.) **********Steel companies face continued losses through 1983, even if a favorable labor settlement is reached and imports are further curtailed. Following a sustained economic recovery, however, there will be substantial improvement in steel industry earnings, according to an analyst for Oppenheimer & Company. Market Place. (D5.)

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/03/busin.main_headline: Pabst Bids Schmidt Increase Its Offer
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/03/busin.print_headline: Pabst Bids Schmidt Increase Its Offer
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/03/busin.body_text: **********The Pabst Brewing Company said yesterday that it had instructed management to make a counterproposal of $25 a share to C. Schmidt & Sons, which previously offered to acquire Pabst at $20.50 a share. **********However, Schmidt said that its $20.50 offer was its ''best and highest offer,'' and called the counterproposal ''tantamount to a rejection.'' Pabst refused to comment on Schmidt's reaction. **********Pabst, the Milwaukee-based brewer, last month rejected the unsolicited, $16-a-share offer by Schmidt, a privately held Philadelphia brewer. Last week, Schmidt raised its offer to $20.50. **********William F. Smith Jr., Pabst's chief executive officer, said that ''in light of recent developments, particularly Stroh's bid for Schlitz, it seems clear that a realignment of the brewing industry is under way, and we want to be sure that our shareholders get maximum value if the company is to be sold.'' Stroh Bid Rejected **********Last Thursday, the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company rejected a bid from the Stroh Brewery Company for two-thirds of its shares. However, Stroh said that it would proceed with the bid. **********With both Pabst and Schlitz, it is a case of large but declining brewers being pursued by brewers with far smaller sales. Pabst, which sold 13.5 million barrels nationally in 1981, according to Impact, a wine and spirits industry newsletter, slipped to fifth place from third last year among the nation's brewers. Schmidt, a regional brewer that ranks 11th, sold 3.3 million barrels. **********Pabst's board previously rejected an offer from its largest stockholder, Irwin Jacobs, a Minneapolis investor, to buy 2 million of Pabst's 8.18 million outstanding shares at $20 a share. Mr. Jacobs and six associates, with whom the company is engaged in a bitter proxy fight, already own 15.3 percent of the stock. **********The $20.50 Schmidt bid proves that Mr. Jacobs's offer ''is not beneficial to shareholders,'' Mr. Smith said. ''Obviously, if a price greater than $20 is available for all Pabst shares, a price of $20 for only a minority of the stock - as Jacobs is proposing - and using Pabst's money to boot, is hardly desirable.'' **********In a telephone interview, Mr. Jacobs noted that Pabst announced an agreement earlier this month to acquire the Pittsburgh Brewing Company, in an arrangement that would give Pabst stock to the Pittsburgh brewer at the price at which it was trading over-the-counter. Yesterday, Pabst closed unchanged, at 17 3/8. ''How can Smith say our price is too low when he's giving it away?'' Mr.  Jacobs said. Posted Loss in '81 **********Mr. Smith added that Pabst was profitable for the first quarter of 1982 and expected to be profitable for the year. In 1981 the company posted a net loss of $23.5 million, including a charge of $19.6 million from closing its Illinois brewery. **********Schmidt said yesterday that it was prepared to discuss the proposed acquisition ''within the context of'' its $20.50 offer, with a deadline of next Wednesday for a merger agreement. **********Pabst's annual shareholders' meeting is scheduled for April 13. Mr. Jacobs and his associates, who have accused the board of indecisiveness in the face of financial problems, plan a proxy vote at the meeting in an attempt to win control of the company. **********Mr. Jacobs, denouncing Pabst's board for ''negotiating the future of its shareholders through press releases,'' said that the Pabst announcement yesterday ''is final proof that the board shouldn't be entrusted with discussions concerning the future of the company.'' He added that his group's nominees should negotiate with Schmidt or any other interested company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/13/busin.main_headline: U.S. JUDGE REFUSES TO CLOSE BELL CASE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/13/busin.print_headline: U.S. JUDGE REFUSES TO CLOSE BELL CASE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/13/busin.body_text: **********Federal Judge Harold H. Greene refused today to dismiss out-of-hand the antitrust lawsuit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, but he said that he was ''delighted that a settlement has been reached.'' **********''I will not permit the case to b e dismissed without proper scrutiny'' of the settlement, Judge Greene announced. His decision raised the po ssibility that opponents of the settlement, including A.T.& T.'s co mpetitors as well as consumer groups concerned about higher phone rates, might be able to present to Judge Greene their objections to various terms of the settlement. That process could take 60 days. **********Judge Greene called the settlement a good one and said that it was preferable to continuing the yearlong trial of the antitrust suit in his District Court. But he chastised lawyers for both the Justice Department and A.T.& T. for failing to file their historic settlement with him, the presiding trial judge. He suggested that they may have been trying to circumvent public comment. **********The Justice Department and the phone company had expected Judge Greene to dismiss the seven-year-old antitrust case today on the ground that he had no legal right to continue the trial after both parties to the suit had come forth with a settlement. **********Quick dismissal would have permitted A.T.& T. to move ahead more rapidly with the key provision of the settlement: divestiture of the Bell System's 22 operating companies, which account for most of the nation's local telephone service. A.T.& T. will retain its longdistance network as well as its manufacturing subsidiary and its research arm, the most profitable parts of its business. **********Judge Greene ordered that documents related to the settlement be transferred to his court from the Federal District Court in Newark by next Monday. He said that if they were not transferred by then, he would seek to ''mandate'' the transfer. **********The latest legal developments were described by Brian C. Monahan, an A.T.& T. spokesman, as ''another thing we have to go through before all of this is behind us. We know the final route to the resolution of the case.'' The Ruling in Newark **********In Newark, District Judge Vincent P. Biunno, in a surprise ruling late Monday, approved the terms of the settlement. He also said that he had no objection to transferring the entire case to Judge Greene's jurisdiction, but he said he wanted to study the issues first. That raised the possibility that he might not meet Judge Greene's Monday deadline. **********Judge Biunno's court has had jurisdiction over a 1956 consent decree that has limited A.T.& T.'s activities to regulated telephone services. The settlement announced Friday would amend that decree, thus permitting the giant corporation to enter such unregulated and rapidly growing fields as data processing, computer-to-computer communication, distribution of information to homes, and the sale of a variety of terminal equipment. **********The ruling by Judge Greene surprised more than 100 Justice Department and phone company lawyers who had gathered in his courtroom. Nevertheless, there were no indications in today's proceedings that Judge Greene would reject the settlement after he has completed his review. **********Judge Greene said that by filing the proposed settlement in Newark as only an amendment to the 1956 consent decree, the two sides - intentionally or not - may have circumvented a Federal law that requires a 60-day period for public comment. ''I think that law applies,'' he said. He argued that the settlement should have been filed in his District Court as well as the Newark court. Public Hearing Possible **********In his ruling, Judge Greene instructed the lawyers to have the settlement transferred to him by next Monday so that he could study it and possibly allow the public to comment on it before deciding whether the settlement is in the public interest. **********The lead attorneys - George Saunders for A.T.& T. and Gerald Connell of the Justice Department's antitrust division - told Judge Greene that their plan was to have Judge Biun no approve the transfer of jurisdiction over the proposed settlement to Judge Greene's court so that he would be able to administer its te rms. **********Upon approval, the agreement gives A.T.& T. six months to develop a divestiture plan. The agreement gives the company 18 months - including the six months of planning - to carry out the divestiture. **********The ruling today, however, raised questions about when the 18 months would begin - from the day Judge Greene dismisses the case, or from Judge Biunno's approval yesterday of the settlement as an amendment to the 1956 consent decree. Provision for Hearing **********Judge Greene said he was convinced that the parties, contrary to their protestations that Judge Biunno's action surprised them, had framed the settlement as a technical amendment to the 1956 consent decree so it could be handled in Newark and remain free of the Tunney Act's provisions. **********The Tunney Act calls for hearings on such a settlement so that third parties can offer suggestions or objections and then allows a judge to acce pt or reject it in the public interest. **********In today's court session, the lawyers for both sides asserted that the judge's assignment was a simple one - just to drop the case, as agreed by the Government and Bell last Friday. Then Judge Greene called a recess ''for about 35 minutes so that I may prepare some thoughts.'' **********He returned in 40 minutes and read from a hand-written statement.  It seemed to be a valedictory, congratulating Mr. Saunders of A.T.& T. for his ''astounding'' performance, praising Mr. Connell of the Justice Department for ''fighting hard'' though outmanned by Bell, recounting statistics about the trial (such as its 350 witnesses and 25,000 pages of transcript) and calling the proposal ''a good settlement.'' The agreement ''solves the core of the complaint,'' Judge Greene added. Then his tone changed as he said he would not dismiss the case. Case 'Too Important' **********The judge said that to do so would be to circumvent the intention of Congress in passing the Tunney Act. He declared, ''This case is too important to the public interest to have it dropped in so haphazard a fashion.'' **********After the proceedings ended, Mr. Saunders said he was unsure what the next step should be. He said he would have to study Judge Greene's order closely and decide what was possible. ''How can we go to Judge Biunno and tell him to undecide the case that he handled just yesterday?'' Mr. Saunders said. ''We did in fact ask his opinion of the settlement.'' **********Repeatedly Judge Greene brought out the fact that Judge Biunno had not seen the huge volume of evidence about Bell and the Government's complaint that was presented before the Washington court during the trial. ''After all, what have we been doing here for the past 11 months?'' he asked the lawyers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/04/busin.print_headline: CRADLE TO GRAVE WITH PRENTICE-HALL; ENGLEWOOD CLIFFS, N.J.
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/04/busin.body_text: **********ALMOST from the cradle to the grave, Prentice-Hall Inc., the mammothp ublishing combine, pursues the literate, and even sometimes the a lmost-literate, consumer. **********It is not just that the 17 million tomes in the company's huge warehouse in West Nyack, N.Y., range from Frank Asch's ''Happy Birthday, Moon,'' a young-children's book, to J. Brooke Aker and Robert Schimer's unsentimental opus, ''Profitable Wills and Estates Practice Under the All-New Tax-Law Setup.'' **********For in-between markets, the company turns out books and other materials for the consumer as elementary school pupil, high schooler, college student and businessman or professional. It brightens his retirement with special-interest books on subjects like travel in Spain. It nourishes his spiritual life, along the way, with the works of Norman Vincent Peale. **********And it does all this on a scale that verges on the titanic, when compared to the will-'o-the wisp operations of, say, a regional poetry-publishing house. With revenues of $390.6 million last year, it boasts that it is the country's largest college textbook publisher and second-largest producer of loose-leaf information services dealing with taxation and regulation, one of the three largest publishers of professional books, and one of the dozen largest publishers of textbooks for elementary and secondary schools. THIS diversity makes good sense, in the view of the cautious m anagers who rule the company's destinies from its baronial h eadquarters campus here at Englewood Cliffs. They are aware of the s hifts in the country's population structure as the offspring of the p ostwar baby boom have grown older - and they're aware, too, of the u ncertain outlook for future college enrollments. **********''With diversification,'' says Prentice-Hall's dapper chairman, Frank J. Dunnigan, ''we tend to level out to some extent the ups and downs we would otherwise experience.'' **********Yet Prentice-Hall's brand of diversity has not been working as well as the company would like. Its compounded earnings growth has been 9 percent annually since 1977 - only a modest tally compared to the 18 percent logged by its rival McGraw-Hill, which has diversified more extensively into electronic information-purveying. **********As Rollins Maxwell of E. F. Hutton says: ''Prentice-Hall remains basically a publishing company; it hasn't participated in the sharp earnings growth that some other companies have had in recent years, resulting from applications of new technology to information.'' **********For his part, J. Kendrick Noble Jr., first vice president at Paine Webber Mitchell Hutchins, says Prentice-Hall is ''a company with a lot of potential, but for a long time it hasn't shown a great deal of success in putting it all together. Its core business - college textbooks - may not be a growth business, and it has to develop new ways of achieving growth.'' **********To be sure, Prentice-Hall has also made moves into nonprint modes of communication. It operates two small, specialized data banks, for instance, and late in 1979, for $35 million, it acquired Deltak Inc., a leading producer of multimedia training courses in data processing and other fields. **********But, considering the diversity of the company's existing operations, Mr. Noble says: ''I would expect to see somewhat more synergism and a somewhat more forward-looking strategy than I have seen so far.'' **********Prentice-Hall's president, Donald A. Schaefer, takes a rather different view. He cites the company's improved 1981 performance and contends: ''We had to get our ducks in a row, and the sort of thing we did last year was indicative of kind of getting our shop in order, I guess, to move from there.'' **********Last year's profits gained 10 percent to $33.8 million from $30.8 million in 1980. Revenues advanced to $390.6 million from $353.4 million in 1980. **********Diversity helped fatten Prentice-Hall's 1981 revenues, its executives say, with the company benefiting mainly from strong performances by its biggest operations: college textooks, loose-leaf materials and Deltak. Meanwhile, for an undisclosed total, top management was selling off three small book subsidiaries and restructuring some loose-leaf and business-books operations. These units, says Mr. Dunnigan, ''either weren't growing satisfactorily or weren't producing a satisfactory return on our investment.'' **********In comforting contrast, Prentice-Hall's college textbooks brought in revenues of $135 million, the company says, up about 10 percent from 1980. Mr. Schaefer says gratefully: ''We hate to use the term, but it's our cash cow.'' **********One reason the college books did well, he says, was that the company had a good 1981 crop of new titles and of revised editions of old ones. Revenues were buoyed by long-standing big sellers, such as ''Government by the People,'' an introductory Government textbook, which the company says is the country's most widely used work of its kind. About two million copies have been sold since the book first came out in 1952 through the good offices of a diplomatic Prentice-Hall editor, the late William Pullin. MR. PULLIN had learned that two scholars, James MacGregor Burns and J ack W. Peltason, were writing similar introductory Government t extbooks, and he persuaded them to pool their efforts. The r esulting product - with another co-author, Thomas E. Cronin - has p roven so durable that its 11th revised edition came out last year. **********''The beauty of revisions,'' Mr. Schaefer says, ''is that you know the books have already received acceptance in the marketplace.'' By contrast, he says, ''every new book is a gamble; you never know how it's going to be accepted.'' (And Prentice-Hall offerings have yet to surpass the durable fame of Paul A. Samuelson's introductory college economics textbook - published by McGraw-Hill.) **********Sometimes Prentice-Hall makes substantial revisions even before the first edition appears: Mr. Dunnigan says that if an author writes badly, the company is ready ''in effect to write the book for him, if the market is good enough.'' **********Another reason for Prentice-Hall's swelling college book sales, its executives say, is specialization among its sales people. They say that, as far as they know, theirs is the only textbook publishing company with a field staff calling exclusively on community colleges. The colleges which constitute a promising market, especially in recessionary times, when many people turn to vocational training after failing to land jobs. **********Still another reason, says the company's courtly, 69-year-old vice chairman, Howard M. Warrington, is the fact that ''enrollments have held up much better than most of the predictions.'' **********As for Prentice-Hall's sales of what it calls ''business and professional subscription products'' - a heading that includes its loose-leaf materials and Deltak - they rose to $143.3 million last year, up from $121.8 million in 1980. **********Increased loose-leaf sales, Mr. Dunnigan says, were in part a payoff on past efforts ''in the form of new product and improving our marketing efforts,'' as well as the demand for information to explain last year's new tax legislation. And he adds cheerfully: ''Loose-leaf services is a good cash generator, too; it doesn't even have inventory. You get the subscriptions in advance.'' **********Prentice-Hall put out new loose-leaf materials last August about the tax program, as did the Commerce Clearing House, the No. 1 company in that field. Mr. Schaefer says: ''We feel the quality of what we did - the editorial content - was more nearly complete.'' But Commerce Clearing House's view is that their offering was more to the point and that Prentice-Hall's was wordy. **********Deltak also fared well, Prentice-Hall executives report, accounting for 15 percent of total sales in 1981, up from about 13 percent in 1980. It is growing fast, they say, largely because its management has been capitalizing on the growing demand for the kinds of instruction it provides. **********For Prentice-Hall as for other textbook publishers, the year's first quarter is usually slow because campus bookstores have already bought the bulk of their textbooks for the academic year. But the company is predicting record sales and a record net for 1982, despite the lingering recession. **********Yet doubt hangs over the future of domestic college textbook sales, although Prentice-Hall executives say that foreign sales are a promising avenue for growth in that and other areas. SPEAKING of domestic sales, Paine Webber's Mr. Noble says: ''The college textbook market they're in now is a pretty good m arket in the short term, but there are questions about it over the l ife of the decade,'' with student bodies and curricula changing f ast. **********Drexel Burnham Lambert's John S. Reidy emphasizes that if Reagan Administration policies limit or reduce college enrollment, that could curb the growth of college textbook sales. And Mr. Schaefer concedes: ''We don't know what Congress will do as as far as student loan programs are concerned.'' **********The uncertainty about college text sales adds importance to Prentice-Hall's prospects for achieving growth in other fields or through skillful and lucrative interweaving of its existing operations. Synergism is the name of that game, and views differ as to whether Prentice-Hall is playing hard enough. **********Mr. Noble says: ''For example, Deltak uses computers and video cassettes for training purposes. I would think that some of that technology might be applicable to the college market. I would also expect to see Deltak being used, on a greater scale than has been done so far, for marketing materials produced by other Prentice hall units.'' **********For his part, Mr. Schaefer points out that authors of Prentice-Hall books have already been developing Deltak courses - and Deltak authors have written books for Prentice-Hall. He says the company is in fact investigating the possible use of Deltak courses, notably those in computer programming and data processing, in colleges, and particularly at community colleges. It is also looking into adapting and applying computerized instruction methods to professional training - outside the campus - in accounting, law and other areas. **********And it is pondering further acquisitions to accelerate growth. But Mr. Schaefer says: ''We have to get on with it now.''  THE POWER OFPEALE **********For three decades now, Prentice-Hall has been profiting from the power of the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale.  The company has sold 2.2 million hard-cover copies of the Manhattan Protestant clergyman's biggest best-seller, the inspirational self-help book ''The Power of Positive Thinking.'' It first came out in 1952 and it continues to sell more than 10,000 hardcover copies a year. **********Pondering the durability of ''Power,'' as it is sometimes known at company headquarters, Robert M. Shaw, a veteran Prentice-Hall executive, muses: ''People are trying to cope with change, that's why books of this type are popular - and who's to say it won't swing back'' into a new surge of popularity. **********The book emphasizes the importance of faith in oneself, and it has been followed by numerous works in similar veins by other authors.  All told, more than 18 million copies of it have been sold around the world, not counting sales of the two dozen other Peale works. **********''My books,'' Dr. Peale has noted cheerfully, ''have been published in 33 languages; on some copies the only thing I can recognize is my name.'' **********A perennial message in Dr. Peale's writing is that prayer, faith, and a hopeful attitude can resolve personal problems, and he was something of a trail-blazer in combining religion with psychiatric principles. **********The pull of his prose is such that Prentice-Hall also keeps three of his other inspirational works in print, including ''A Guide to Confident Living,'' another best-seller, which it first brought out in 1948. **********In an effort to capitalize further on the Peale appeal, the company is currently test-marketing editions of some Peale books in what the industry calls ''trade paperback'' format, which is larger than the usual paperback-book size, known as ''mass-market'' format. **********Meanwhile, a mass-market paperback edition of ''Power'' has been being put out by Fawcett Books, which was recently acquired by another paperback firm, Ballantine Books. **********Dr. Peale, now a spry 83 years old, continues as senior minister at Manhattan's Marble Collegiate Church, where he has preached for half a century -and where, in 1971, he spoke at the funeral of an admiring reader, Richard Prentice Ettinger, co-founder and long-time president of Prentice Hall.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/11/busin.body_text: **********BACK in 1972, Wall Street analysts hailed factory-built homes as one of the premier growth industries of the decade. Before 1973 ended, however, their market had collapsed. **********Now, after eight years of depressed conditions in the industry, things appear to be looking up. Though few persons on Wall Street have noticed, sales of factory-built homes are rising again -spurred by the high cost of site-built homes. **********Not only do site-built homes cost twice as much at the outset but also 16 to 18 percent mortgage money makes them unaffordable for many. **********The factory-built home could become a feasible alternative for many families. These units are no longer made of aluminum and put on wheels. They are built in factories using conventional housing materials such as wood framing. Boxlike in structure, they are relatively small. **********But they are comfortable and durable. More important, they cost about $20 a square foot plus $3 a square foot for foundation and setup - half as much as site-built homes' $40 to $45 a square foot. **********Richard Lilly, research director for Raymond James & Associates of St. Petersburg, Fla., said the average conventional home has three bedrooms and two baths and contains 1,600 square feet. At $40 a square foot, that is $64,000 plus about $10,000 for a quarter-acre lot, totaling $74,000. **********Factory-built homes, which must be trucked to the site, are smaller than conventional homes, partly from necessity. The typical multisection factory-built home would contain 1,100 square feet, including three small bedrooms and two small baths. To the $22,000 cost, add $3,000 for foundation and setting up as well as $8,000 more for a fifth of an acre. Total: $33,000. Mr. Lilly favors the Zimmer Corporation, a Florida company that builds such units. **********Noting that conventional housing starts have slumped to 1 million units from 1.5 million to 2.5 million in the 1970's, he said many families could no longer afford conventional housing. **********Factory-built housing peaked at 576,000 units in 1972, falling thereafter by more than half. Last year 240,000 units were sold, and this year's pace is similar. But Mr. Lilly, who is looking for a break in mortgage rates, expects demand to improve dramatically before the end of the year. **********He thinks 13 to 14 percent mortgage money is a ''strong probability'' for the second half, and those rates would bring heavy demand for factory-built units, he suggests. **********In New York, mortgage rates have dropped as much as one and a half percentage points over the last month. Starting today, Citibank is offering 15 1/2 percent money on six-month adjustable-rate mortgages. It had been getting 16 1/2 percent. **********Mr. Lilly noted that factory-home mortgage rates typically bear a 100 basis point premium, reflecting their origin as mobile homes.  Even so, he believes factory-built homes will experience their best years in the mid- to late 1980's. Zimmer, based in Pompano Beach with factories all over the nation, has more than doubled its homebuilding capacity in the last two years and has good distribution, he said. **********Mr. Lilly expects Zimmer to earn $1.15 a share this year and $1.80 a share in 1983. Ziller earned $1.11 a share in 1981.  He called Zimmer ''a capacity play.'' As Zimmer begins to utilize its production capacity, the company could earn $4 to $9 a share by the mid- to late 1980's, he said. At the current price, the shares are selling at 9 times his estimated 1982 earnings. In yesterday's trading on the American Stock Exchange, Zimmer closed at 10 3/8, down 1/8. **********The Value Line Investment Survey, which favors Zimmer, warns that the shares are volatile and notes that they are well above the year's low of 6 3/4 set in February. **********Mr. Lilly is not as impressed with other well-positioned companies that build factory homes. They include Fleetwood Enterprises, Liberty Homes, Champion Homebuilders, Oakwood Homes, Tidwell Industries and Ocilla Industries. **********David V. Jackson of Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards said that Fleetwood Enterprises was a pioneer in ''manufactured housing.'' He is neutral on Fleetwood and other companies in the industry but is inclined to take a more positive stance once interest rates show signs of dropping to 13 percent or less. This is necessary, in his view, to stimulate consumer demand.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/28/busin.body_text: **********Japanese computer manufacturers, with the aid of their Government, are moving ahead in an ambitious effort to surpass American companies in building high-speed computers vital to national security, according to officials, industry and university scientists in the United States. **********The rapid Japanese advance has raised the possibility that the United States could become dependent on a foreign supplier for socalled supercomputers, which are used in weapons development as well as many nonmilitary research applications. The situation is likely to spark renewed debate within the United States about the proper American response to Japanese industrial efforts. **********A panel of American computer scientists, in a report that will soon be made public, is urging that the Government undertake a national program to spur development of such supercomputers, which are the fastest calculating machines on earth. Such a program, if adopted, would be one of the first in which the Government, industry and universities collaborate to counter Japanese moves, which are seen as having been so successful in part because of close cooperation between business and Government there. **********Parallel to Semiconductors **********''The argument is that in absence of a coordinated Government effort, the Japanese will repeat in computer systems what they did in semiconductors,'' said Kent K. Curtis, head of the computer science section in the National Science Foundation's divison of mathematical sciences and computer sciences, in one of a dozen interviews in which officials discussed Japanese advances in making and marketing supercomputers. **********Mr. Curtis was referring to the success Japanese electronics companies have had in selling an important computer memory chip, the 64K random access memory. The Japanese have won more than half of that market, which is expected to grow to $1 billion in annual sales in a few years. **********Supercomputers are extremely expensive, selling for $5 million to $15 million each, and are designed for large scientific problems involving numerous calculations. They can perform, in some cases, more than 100 million arithmetic operations a second, making them 3 to 100 times faster than the largest general-purpose business computers made by companies such as the International Business Machines Corporation. **********There were 50 such supercomputers in use as of last June, largely in national laboratories and other Government facilities. They are used for nuclear weapons design, fusion energy research, weather forecasting and, it is believed, for intelligence and code-breaking by the National Security Agency. They are also employed increasingly in industry for tasks such as designing aircraft wings and simulating oil reservoirs. Many of the problems are so complex, involving billions of calculations, that they keep even a supercomputer busy for hours. Japanese Entry Into Market **********Virtually all supercomputers have been made by two American companies, Cray Research Inc. and the Control Data Corporation, both of Minneapolis. Recently, however, two Japanese companies, Hitachi Ltd. and Fujitsu Ltd., have introduced supercomputers that are roughly comparable in performance to the American models. **********Moreover, the Japanese Ministry of International Trade and Industry this year began a project to develop by the end of the decade a machine capable of performing 10 billion operations a second, 100 times faster than the Cray machine, according to American scientists who have visited Japan. **********The program, in which Japan's six largest computer companies are cooperating, involves financing of $100 million to $200 million a year for eight years, the scientists say. The Japanese also have a separate project to develop a so-called fifth-generation computer, which in addition to being fast would be capable of tasks such as understanding speech, making the machines extremely easy to use. **********The still unpublished report on the supercomputer situation has been prepared for the National Science Foundation and the Department of Defense by a group of 15 scientists and engineeers from universities and national laboratories headed by Peter D. Lax, a professor of mathematics at New York University's Courant Institute for Mathematical Sciences. **********The panel was established in part to explore how university researchers could get access to supercomputers, which are becoming vital for basic research.  The panel, which includes Kenneth G.  Wilson of Cornell University, who last week won the Nobel Prize in Physics, recommends that a program to provide such access be established. Keeping Pace With Japan **********But the panel also became concerned about development of future faster computers and questioned whether American manufacturers could keep pace with the Japanese. **********The report does not make specific recommendations other than calling for a national program involving Government agencies, the national laboratories, industry and universities, according to several members of the committee. However, an appendix suggests that five separate projects be set up to work on advanced computers, that each project involve a consortium of universities and computer companies and that each receive financing of $5 million a year for five years, Professor Lax said. **********Concern over Japanese inroads in supercomputers was spurred last spring when teams of scientists from Los Alamos, N.M., and Lawrence Livermore national laboratories visited Japanese computer centers.  The reports of the scientists suggested the Japanese could surpass the American companies and the labs, which design nuclear weapons, would have to buy from the Japanese. **********''That jolted a lot of people,'' said Jacob T. Schwartz, a professor at the Courant Institute and member of the Lax committee.  ''Historically Los Alamos has always gone for the biggest and fastest computers available,'' said Bill L. Buzbee, assistant director of the Los Alamos computer division. ''We would prefer to buy American, but if the biggest and fastest computers were foreign, we would certainly have to consider them.'' Worries About Competition **********Mr. Buzbee said the laboratory was concerned that if foreign companies assume leadership in supercomputers, they might not sell the newest computers to American customers for several years, for political or competitive reasons or because they had to satisfy their home market first. **********There is at least one precedent: In the late 1960's, the United States Government barred I.B.M. and Control Data from selling France large computers for nuclear weapons development. **********The call for a Government-sponsored effort rests on the assumption that industry will not be able to or will not care to take the risks involved to develop radical new approaches that some scientists say would be needed to achieve thousand-fold increases in computer speed. **********That recommendation is not likely to find favor in the Reagan Administration, which is emphasizing private enterprise and is trying to cut the Federal budget. **********''I have not seen any basis for justifying a massive Federal effort,'' said N. Douglas Pewitt, assistant director for general science in the White House Office of Science and Technology Policy, who said he is familiar with the Lax committee work but has not seen its final report. Mixed Feelings of Makers **********''The reaction that we have to counter the Japanese plan by becoming Japanese ourselves is not going to wash. That's not going to find much support in this Administration,'' Dr. Pewitt said. **********The supercomputer manufacturers, which have reviewed the Lax committee work, have mixed feelings, applauding the interest shown by the Government but questioning the specific approach. **********''It's about the first time the Government is beginning to focus on the supercomputer area,'' said Lloyd M. Thorndyke, senior vice president for technology at Control Data. ''Before that it's been almost benign neglect.'' He said the company thinks a Government effort is ''in the national good. Just how is the question.'' **********Mr. Thorndyke and Peter A. Gregory, vice president of planning and corporate development for Cray, said the Government should establish a market for supercomputers, either by promising to buy computers of certain specifications or by helping universities purchase supercomputers, and let the companies satisfy the market need. **********Both Mr. Thorndyke and Mr. Gregory said the Government should concentrate on sponsoring development of high speed micro-electronic circuits that would be the building blocks of future high-speed computers, while leaving the computer companies to design and build the computers. **********''I'm less anxious to have 10 universities working on design of computers. I don't think that will be that valuable,'' Mr. Gregory said. The computer makers also take issue with the technological approach to faster computing advocated by the Lax panel. **********The recommendations come at a time when American electronics companies themselves are banding together to share basic research and better compete with the Japanese. In the past year, two organizations have been formed by the companies to share research expenses, in part by funneling research money to the universities. But while cooperating among themselves, the companies have so far spurned direct Government involvement in their activities.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/02/busin.body_text: **********WASHINGTON THE Cetus Corporation in Berkeley, Calif., which describes itself as the oldest and largest biotechnology company, received a patent this week on a process for the production of valuable industrial materials. **********Patent 4,351,902 was granted William F. Amon Jr., vice president, and two staff scientists, Saul L. Neidleman and John Geigert, for a method of producing hydrogen peroxide, which has many commercial uses, and simultaneously an acid co-product that also has industrial applications. **********The process involves the use of enzymes obtained from microorganism fungal cells in chemical reactions that start with glucose. The 2-keto-D-gluconic acid produced is used in photography, the preparation of food preservatives and various chemical compounds. **********Another patent, obtained for Cetus this week by Chander P. Bahl, a staff scientist, pertains directly to genetic engineering. Patent 4,351,901 covers a method of altering a single nucleide, which is part of a chain forming a gene. Its general purpose is said to be to provide an improved method of making genes, which work in microorganisms to produce desirable proteins such as enzymes or hormones.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/30/world.main_headline: U.N. ASSEMBLY AGAIN BIDS SOVIET QUIT AFGHANISTAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/30/world.print_headline: U.N. ASSEMBLY AGAIN BIDS SOVIET QUIT AFGHANISTAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/30/world.body_text: **********The General Assembly, by a vote of 114 to 21, renewed its demand today that Soviet troops withdraw from Afghanistan. **********Despite the large majority, the outcome was a mild disappointment to Pakistan and other prime movers of the resolution because the number of nations in favor fell two below the total recorded last year. The Pakistanis had sought to increase the number to heighten the ''moral pressure'' for ''an early political settlement,'' in the words of Sahabzada Yaqub Khan, Pakistan's Foreign Minister. **********Even so, the Soviet Union could take little comfort from the result. The number of countries voting with Moscow also fell by two, perhaps reflecting the long holiday weekend and the absence of some small delegations. Most painful of all from Moscow's standpoint, 63 nations from those grouped as nonaligned voted with the majority and only 12 with the Soviet Union. Twelve others were among the 13 that abstained. **********This was the fourth time in three years that the Assembly had called for ''immediate withdrawal of foreign forces from Afghanistan'' and insisted on the right of Afghans ''to determine their own form of government.'' During this time, the Soviet Union has increased its troops to a total now estimated at 105,000 in a so far fruitless effort to subdue Afghan insurgents. Vote Dismissed by Soviet **********Oleg A. Troyanovsky, the Soviet delegate, dismissed the Assembly effort as an ''artificial hue and cry'' and a diversion from ''really burning issues.'' But despite the seemingly futile exercise here, United Nations officials and Asian diplomats believe they see signs that Moscow wants to find a graceful way out that would leave its interests in Afghanistan intact. **********At the Assembly's urging, an Under Secretary General, Diego Cordovez, has been mediating between Pakistan and the Soviet-backed Government in Afghanistan, seeking a political formula to end the conflict and enable the Soviet forces to leave. Mr. Troyanovsky had approving words for these talks. **********''We are pleased to note the preliminary outcome has, on the whole, been commended by the parties directly concerned,'' he said. ''It is important that the opportunity of making further progress and achieving mutually acceptable agreements is not missed.'' Pakistani Sees Progress **********For Pakistan, Foreign Minister Yaqub Khan echoed this theme. ''The indirect talks,'' he said, ''were of a constructive nature'' and ''represented some tentative progress, particularly in regard to the elements which should form the basis of a comprehensive settlement.'' **********The Pakistani minister said that the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan ''has damaged the process of detente and heightened global tension.'' Neither he nor the Assembly resolution mentioned the Soviet Union by name. **********Mr. Yaqub Khan asserted that the struggle against the Russians was being conducted by Afghans, not, as the Soviet Union charges, by American-supplied ''terrorists'' operating from bases in Pakistan.  ''Neither the coercive force of sophisticated weapons nor the might of a superpower has been able to extinguish the spirit of the Afghan people to assert their freedom,'' he said. **********Ending the debate, Tommy T.B. Koh of Singapore described the Soviet intervention as a ''litmus test of the foreign policy of the Soviet Union.'' Mr. Koh said it demonstrated Moscow's willingness to breach the United Nations Charter because ''force is being used to subjugate the people of Afghanistan.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/09/busin.print_headline: INSTALLMENT DEBT GREW BY $1.4 BILLION IN MAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/09/busin.body_text: **********Americans took on $1.4 billion more in installment debt than they paid off in May, with most of the increase in auto loans, the Government reported today. It was the largest increase in eight months, but still a modest gain in comparison with pre-recession figures. **********Robert Ortner, the Commerce Department's chief economist, called the report encouraging. He said that ''to the extent that it's a reflection of consumer confidence in the future, it could be very important.'' **********The report said the May increase in outstanding installment debt - a gain of 5 percent at an annual rate - was the largest since the $2.9 billion of last September. Gains of $2 billion and more had been common before the recession began last summer. **********The credit figures are important because greater sales of cars, furniture and other relatively expensive items - typically bought on credit - are considered necessary to pull the economy out of recession. **********In May, a jump of $959 million in outstanding auto loans - the biggest gain for that category since last October - led the overall increase. Outstanding auto loans had risen $233 million in April. **********In all, the report said, Americans took on $29.2 billion in new installment debt, up 1.7 percent from April, while paying off $27.8 billion in old debt, up 1.1 percent. The debt-liquidation total was a record, surpassing April's $27.5 billion. **********Besides car loans, ''revolving credit also grew more rapidly in May, posting a $537 million gain'' after rising $499 million in April, the report said. Revolving credit includes credit cards issued by commercial banks, retail stores and gasoline companies. All figures are seasonally adjusted.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/30/world.main_headline: BRITISH SAY TROOPS TOOK 900 CAPTIVES IN FALKLAND DRIVE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/30/world.print_headline: BRITISH SAY TROOPS TOOK 900 CAPTIVES IN FALKLAND DRIVE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/30/world.body_text: **********Britain took about 900 Argentine prisoners during its recapture of Darwin and Goose Green on the Falkland Islands, but the commander of a British parachute battalion was killed during the action, the Ministry of Defense announced tonight. **********British troops reportedly advanced on two fronts toward Stanley, the Argentine-held capital of the Falklands. The ministry announcement said that Lieut. Col. Herbert Jones, 42 years old, died in action around Goose Green. **********The large number of prisoners reported taken by the British Friday appeared to be a result of a twin-pronged offensive against Darwin and Goose Green that surprised and encircled the Argentine positions, in part with the assistance of landing craft, according to background accounts provided by British officials. The two settlements lie two miles apart along a narrow isthmus about 20 miles south of the British beachhead around San Carlos Bay. **********Radio Contact Reported Lost **********In a communique issued late tonight, the Argentine military command said that 800 Argentine troops resisted the attack ''in spite of being fully inferior in number'' and that at midday, ''radio contact with them was lost and has not been re-established.'' (Page 16.) **********According to reports in London tonight, Colonel Jones died when he led a small group of his men in an attack on an Argentine machine-gun nest. Also during the assault, according to the reports, some members of the Argentine garrison at Goose Green raised the white flag of surrender and then opened fire on paratroopers. **********Earlier, Darwin had been retaken with ''little trouble,'' according to the officials. All told, Friday's fighting -involving marines and the Second Battalion of the Parachute Regiment -lasted ''many hours'' and included bombardment by 105-millimeter howitzers of the Royal Artillery, military officials said. **********The reported British victory over the second largest concentration of Argentine troops in the Falklands appeared to have positioned British forces for a final assault on Stanley. **********As Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher remained at her country residence, Chequers, for the weekend, troops of the Royal Engineers were reported to be restoring the small grass airstrip at Goose Green, which will give Britain an important central operating base for its Harrier jumpjets. **********Royal Marines, moving across the marshy ground along a northern route toward Stanley, have reportedly attacked two other small communities, Douglas and Teal Inlet. There were unconfirmed reports that both had been captured. Teal Inlet is about halfway to Stanley. **********Publicly, the Ministry of Defense has released few details of Friday's battle and no casualty figures have been disclosed.''We do not have information yet about the extent of British or Argentine casualties,'' Ian McDonald, the Defense Ministry spokesman, said tonight. ''A detailed statement will be made about our own casualties when next of kin have been informed.'' **********A variety of tributes to Colonel Jones were offered tonight. Mrs.  Thatcher said she deeply regretted the loss of ''this truly valiant and courageous officer who was loved by his men.'' And a fellow parachute leader said, ''He was the sort of officer who believed in leading from the front.'' **********A spokesman said this morning that one Argentine Pucara airplane was shot down Friday near Goose Green. The downing of the plane brought Argentina's aircraft losses to 67, according to the British count. Britain has acknowledged losing 15 planes and helicopters and listed 115 men killed or missing before the latest ground action. British Warships Bombarded **********The Defense Ministry spokesman also said today that British warships bombarding Argentine military installations around Stanley Friday came under attack but were not hit. **********Today was also marked by a modest flurry of activity on the diplomatic front. Officials here said that a response had been sent to inquiries by Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations about terms for a cease-fire. The officials said that proposals for ''an honorable cease-fire'' would be considered but that the British insistance on unconditional Argentine withdrawal from the islands must come first. **********The official silence on the military action that began Thursday reflects a British strategy of trying to keep the Argentine forces off balance as to where and when the major British attack will occur. In addition, the British appear to be trying to lure at least some of the Argentine troops out of Stanley for a battle under circumstances more favorable to the British. **********The Darwin-Goose Green area is about 50 miles from Stanley across low-lying and open country. Most of the route, which would be the easiest way for the British forces to cover the distance to the capital, is just a track, but the last 13 miles are over an improved road with drainage ditches. British forces would have to contend with possible Argentine positions in the hills as they approached Stanley. **********Meanwhile, 3,000 soldiers who traveled to the South Atlantic aboard the Queen Elizabeth 2 have reportedly been transferred to military vessels - including the assult ships Intrepid and Fearless - in preparation for an amphibious landing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/23/world.body_text: **********The United States is sharply reducing the number of officials and dependents at the American Embassy in Buenos Aires because of tensions with Argentina over the Falkland Islands conflict, a State Department spokesman said today. **********The temporary removal of certain ''nonessential'' personnel began several weeks ago and more will leave in the next few days, said Rush Taylor, a department press officer. **********''All dependents have been asked to leave temporarily,'' Mr. Taylor said.As of May 4, there were 79 American staff members at the embassy and about 100 employees.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/26/busin.body_text: **********THE man who built the new condominium called the Viscaya on East 71st Street thinks there will never be another building like it on the Upper East Side, and it is hard to argue with him. **********Under the rules of the Upper East Side Historic District, no new building can be taller than six stories. The Viscaya is 21 stories tall. No doubt the project would not have been attempted at all if it had started after the historic district legislation went into effect in May 1981. **********But Harold Lynn bought the town house at 110 East 71st Street well before that, intending to plunge into his first new construction venture in Manhattan. With two investment partners and the Architects Design Group handling the design, he has produced one of the city's most unusual new condominiums, now on the market at prices ranging mostly between $587,000 and $675,000. **********Mr. Lynn, who is 45 years old, was an importer of women's clothing until five years ago. Then he sold his business and retired. For two years he traveled. Later he bought an apartment for himself in a building undergoing a renovation, and he found that the process fascinated him. **********So the idea of developing his own building was strongly in his mind when he bought the five-story building on 71st Street, just east of the cooperative at 733 Park Avenue, from the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children. As an admirer of the gracious character of the turn-of-the-century houses on the street, he also wanted to preserve that ambiance. He found a way. **********''One night I was having dinner and pondering how to get 17 stories to mesh with the old building,'' he said. ''I drew a picture on a napkin of a tower rising out of pillars, leaving a gap at the roof of the existing building for a roof garden.'' **********That is essentially what came about. The facade of the town house was left intact for the 30-foot frontage on the street back to a depth of 20 feet. The rest was sheared off to create the site for the new tower. Then the lower floors were built to meet the floors in the town houses, creating the floors for five apartments of 1,350 to 2,250 square feet. One duplex apartment has a private rear garden of 900 square feet. **********The town house was raised one floor, and on the reinforced roof the builder has produced an elaborately landscaped garden for the use of all the condominium owners. At this level as well, the Viscaya has a lobby for the tower portion of the building. The tower floors begin 30 feet above the roof level of the town house, set back 30 feet from the street, giving the impression from below that the two elements are barely connected. The tower seems almost to be floating on air. **********The tower floors total 1,500 gross square feet, and there is both a tenants' elevator and a service elevator. The two-bedroom, twobath apartments have about 1,200 square feet of living space.  There is one apartment per floor, with a continuous band of window around them. The selling prices average about $450 a square foot. **********''On a purely economic basis, nobody would build this building,'' said Mr. Lynn. ''It would be cheaper to knock down the old building and build new.'' **********Knocking down the town house would have cost less than $100,000.  Instead, Macar Contracting's workmen did the partial demolition by hand, using jackhammers and chisels to chip away walls two feet thick at the rear of the town house. **********The Buildings Department would not allow the use of a crane on the narrow residential midblock. So hoists had to be used by the men who poured the concrete floors. **********Mr. Lynn is a man with a taste for Renaissance painting as well as cooking and old automobiles. He once kept a collection of 19 antique cars at a home in Kings Point, L.I. His past experience in construction has been in homes for family use - a 200-year-old barn in Kings Point that was converted into a contemporary house and, earlier, a contemporary house in Roslyn, L.I. **********''Get your plans 100 percent set before you build,'' he said.  ''Don't make changes as you go along.'' **********This advice comes only after his experience at the Viscaya, however. He said he changed the layout of apartments in the tower significantly after construction started. When he saw how the apartment looked, for example, he didn't like the location of a bathroom. He changed it to provide direct access from the master bedroom. The room had basically been installed on all floors when he made the decision. As a result, plumbing lines and electrical fixtures had to be changed. He also decided belatedly to install washers and dryers. **********The building was given a 20 percent floor-area bonus - three floors - in exchange for a donation of $70,000 to a special parks improvement district, a device by which the city offered zoning bonuses to builders who contributed toward various public improvements. **********Mr. Lynn is already negotiating to buy another property. He wants to build again, but nothing run-of-the-mill. ''If it's creative and difficult,'' he said, ''I'm interested.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/24/world.main_headline: KIM DAE JUNG ARRIVES IN U.S. AFTER BEING FREED BY SOUTH KOREA
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/24/world.print_headline: KIM DAE JUNG ARRIVES IN U.S. AFTER BEING FREED BY SOUTH KOREA
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/24/world.body_text: **********Kim Dae Jung, South Korea's leading opposition figure, left Seoul today for the United States after serving two and a half years of a 20-year prison sentence for sedition. **********The 57-year-old Mr. Kim was expected to seek medical treatment in the United States for arthritis. Last week he was transferred from his prison cell in Chongju, 70 miles south of Seoul, to a heavily guarded room in the National University Hospital in the capital. **********The South Korean Government made no immediate announcement about Mr. Kim's departure, which was said to have taken place at 7:30 P.M.  Seoul time (5:30 A.M., New York time). Reporters were barred from the airport area just before Mr. Kim's flight left. **********(Mr. Kim arrived at National Airport in Washington Thursday night and demanded that ''all democratic patriots in prison'' in South Korea be released. It was not clear whether he was aware that during his flight to Washington the Seoul Government announced that more than 1,200 prisoners, including seven people convicted with Mr. Kim in 1980, had been freed under a Christmas amnesty. Page A4.) **********The decision to free Mr. Kim, which came as a surprise when reports of it first circulated last week, came after many months of quiet effort by the Reagan Administration to persuade President Chun Doo Hwan to act. Talks on the subject were conducted by the American Ambassador to South Korea, Richard L. Walker. Mr. Kim's wife, Lee Hee Ho, who is 60 years old, said in an interview last week that South Korean authorities were forcing her husband into political exile against his will. She said that arrangements for their departure had been made between the United States andSeoul and that the Kim family had not been told until the last moment. **********Officials and friends of the Kim family say that Mr. Chun has in effect banished Mr. Kim from South Korea, since the opposition figure has apparently received no guarantee that he can return to Seoul as long as Mr. Chun is President. Mr. Chun's first term is not up until 1988.Calmer Political Atmosphere **********United States officials had long favored Mr. Kim's release, believing him not guilty of the sedition charges, which grew out of a civil uprising that Mr. Kim was accused of ''masterminding'' in the southwest city of Kwangju in May 1980. He was sentenced to death in 1980, but that sentence was commuted to life imprisonment in January 1981, just before President Chun paid an official visit to the United States. Last March the sentence was reduced to 20 years. **********American officials here and in Seoul made it clear that President Chun's decision to free Mr. Kim could make for a calmer political atmosphere in South Korea, where about 40,000 United States troops are based. The Communist Government in North Korea found the Kim case of great propaganda value. **********By suddenly moving to free Mr. Kim - Mr. Chun is said to detest Mr. Kim personally - diplomats believe that the President has seized the initiative in South Korean politics and to have made a positive impression abroad. **********In return for freeing Mr. Kim, the Seoul authorities required that he go to the United States for medical treatment with his wife and two of their three sons. Otherwise, it was implied to the family, Mr. Kim would remain in detention, either in a hospital ward or in prison, serving out his 20-year sentence.To the Airport by Ambulance **********People close to the Kims say that the implicit threat may have been a bluff but that the Kims have been worn down by years of pressure.  Mr. Kim at first refused the offer, according to South Korean church officials close to him, because he preferred to stay in South Korea for an operation for arthritis, which is said to affect his legs. But under what people close to the family say was intense pressure, with Mr. Kim isolated in a hospital ward, he finallyagreed to the terms of his release. **********Kim Hong Il, Mr. Kim's oldest son, was quoted today as saying that his father and other family members went to the airport in an ambulance. He said he had been told he would be able to see his father at the airport but that he was unable to say farewell to him there. **********Mr. Chun, diplomats say, seems to have arrived at his decision by a gradual process of learning his way in office as leader of a nation of 38 million people. Mr. Chun moved brusquely and sometimes brutally when he seized power in May 1980, still then in uniform as a three-star general of military intelligence at the head of an army junta. **********He was surrounded by army officers, ruled South Korea under martial law and at once arrested his main rival, Mr. Kim. Before long Mr. Kim faced a death sentence for sedition, although the ground for conviction seemed slender to many South Koreans, and the court never published the record. The Chun Government has still not clarified in public the ground on which army courts sentenced Mr. Kim to death. **********United States pressure on Mr. Chun to commute the sentence and to consider releasing Mr. Kim began in the last months of the Carter Administration. Yet officials close to the case say that Mr. Chun reached his decision by taking advice not only from Americans but from his personal staff. **********Mr. Kim is likely to have to struggle in the United States. He has little money, few supporters and no grass-roots organization. He might languish in exile, like the Philippine opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr., who, once removed to the United States, proved an ineffective rival to President Ferdinand E. Marcos.----1,200 Others Freed **********SEOUL, South Korea, Friday, Dec. 24 (Reuters) - The South Korean Government today released more than 1,200 prisoners today in a Christmas amnesty, the Ministry of Information announced. **********The move followed the suspension of a 20-year sedition sentence on Kim Dae Jung, who was allowed to fly to the United States on Thursday. **********Information Minister Lee Jin Hie said the amnesty included seven people convicted with Mr. Kim in 1980.  Twelve people sentenced for their involvement in the civilian uprising in the southern city of Kwangju, in which 189 people died, were also released, the minister said. **********Fifteen prisoners interned for violating martial law, lifted in January 1981, were among those released. Six students imprisoned for anti-Government demonstrations and seven for membership in a leftwing organization were also freed. **********Apart from those imprisoned for political crimes, a further 1,158 common criminals benefited from the amnesty.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/12/world.print_headline: MUBARAK FLYING TO THE SUDAN TO SIGN PACT ON JOINT POLICIES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/12/world.body_text: **********President Hosni Mubarak will fly to Khartoum on Tuesday to sign an agreement to coordinate the political and economic policies of Egypt and the Sudan. **********The agreement, described by Cairo newspapers as a ''charter of integration,'' marks the latest and most formal stage in an eightyear-old policy of cooperation between Egypt and the Government of Gaafar al-Nimeiry, who has been the President of the Sudan since 1969. The Sudan was one of the few Arab countries to maintain relations with Cairo after it signed the peace treaty with Israel. **********Although the agreement envisions measures ranging from the gradual abolition of customs duties between the two Governments to an effort to coordinate foreign policy goals, Egyptian officials said it stops short of a formal political union between Cairo and Khartoum. **********Among Western diplomats, the new agreement, which must be ratified by the Parliaments of both nations, underscores the mutual security concerns of Egypt and the Sudan. Just as Cairo believes it imperative to have a friendly Government in Khartoum to secure Egypt's southern border and the sources of the Nile, Mr. Nimeiry is dependent on Egyptian military and economic aid for his political survival. **********The two nations signed a mutual defense treaty in 1976, and Egypt has sent troops or advisers to the Sudan several times to reinforce the Government. In the last decade, Mr. Nimeiry has survived several coup attempts that Egyptian officials attributed to the neighboring Government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader. **********Meanwhile, diplomats here say recurrent anti-Government demonstrations in Khartoum and other cities have been caused by acute shortages of food, gasoline and other goods. **********Egyptian officials said they hoped the coordination of investment policies would help bolster the economies of both nations. The agreement calls for the establishment of a joint fund of up to $200 million to be used to attract foreign donors and inevestors, including other Arab governments. **********In the past, there has been discussion of the possibility that the Sudan's expanses of fertile land and its abundant water could help supply food for much of the arid Arab world. But the Sudan, a vast area with a population half the size of Egypt's 44 million, has lacked both the manpower and the technical skills necessary to exploit its agricultural potential. **********In the past, Arab countries have embarked on a variety of political and economic unions that failed, such as the United Arab Republic that tied together Egypt, Syria and Libya. Egypt and the Sudan, however, have strong historical ties welded by a common border and a mutual dependence on the Nile. **********The agreement calls for the establishment of a joint Egyptian-Sudanese Parliament of 60 representatives to meet twice a year, alternating between Cairo and Khartoum. It is described as mainly symbolic and will have little if any authority. **********The two countries signed a similar though less ambitious agreement in 1974. It set up a zone of integration along either side of the border and outlined several ambitious joint ventures that were never built for lack of money.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/28/busin.body_text: **********Japanese auto makers enjoy a significant labor cost advantage over their rivals in the United States, and Douglas A. Fraser, president of the United Automobile Workers union, is trying to close the gap. Mr. Fraser is in Japan, urging Japanese auto workers to demand higher wages. **********''Industrial competition should not be based on who can pay the lowest wages,'' Mr. Fraser said today. **********''We should strive to eliminate all competition based on the lowest common denominator for the worker.'' **********Some Japanese auto executives think the American labor leader's message is apostasy. ''Our workers are paid less but they also have jobs,'' one executive said. ''I think our workers will have better sense than to listen to Mr. Fraser.'' **********Mr. Fraser is in Japan attending a four-day conference of union officials representing 3.9 million auto workers, mostly in the United States, Japan and Western Europe.
