https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/14/world.main_headline: U.N.-SOUTH AFRICA TALKS ON NAMIBIA CONTINUE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/14/world.print_headline: U.N.-SOUTH AFRICA TALKS ON NAMIBIA CONTINUE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/14/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister P.W.  Botha said today that South Africa was ready to move for a cease-fire and an internationally supervised election in South-West Africa as soon as Cuban soldiers withdrew from neighboring Angola. **********South African and United Nations officials met twice today at United Nations headquarters in New York to try to clarify outstanding political and military aspects of a Western plan for the independence of South-West Africa, also known as Namibia. **********Mr. Botha said it was ''ridiculous and terrible'' for critics to accuse South Africa of stalling negotiations for independence of the territory. **********He said South African soldiers were dying in the bush war against black nationalist guerrillas and that his white-minority Government had ''expected a cease-fire to come into force on July 15.'' **********''We put it quite clearly to the Americans that once clarity has been attained on the Cubans, South Africa stands ready to move to phase 3,'' he said. The third phase of the plan put forward by Western nations called for elections. **********He told the governing National Party's Transvaal provincial congress, ''There can be no talk of free and fair elections as long as the Cubans are in Angola because the South-West Africa People's Organization can hinder a fair and free election under the umbrella of Cuban troops.'' **********But Mr. Botha insisted that his Government would not pull out of negotiations, led by the United States, to end the 16-year-old war against guerrillas belonging to the South-West Africa People's Organization in the sparsely populated territory. **********The United States has said that the issue of the Cubans - there are an estimated 15,000 to 20,000 supporting the Marxist Government against pro-Western guerrillas - is separate from the independence question but that the Cubans must withdraw. **********There have been negotiations in the Angolan capital of Luanda in an effort by American diplomats to persuade the Government to ask the Cubans to leave, but there has been no indication that they would be pulling out. **********A brief United Nations announcement of the meetings said the talks today ''are a continuation of the meetings which started in July 1982, with a view to the clarification of outstanding points in respect to the implementation of Security Council Resolution 435.'' **********The 1978 resolution endorsed an independence plan devised by the United States, Britain, France, Canada and West Germany. It provides for a cease-fire between South Africa and guerrillas and the United Nations-supervised election of a constituent assembly leading to Namibian independence. **********Johann Eiselen, a spokesman for the South African Mission to the United Nations, said today's talks centered on ''logistic and practical matters'' related to the deployment of a planned 7,500-member United Nations truce supervisory group and to the electoral system to be used in creating the constituent assembly. **********Asked if talks on such details meant that an agreement was near, Mr. Eiselen stressed that they only dealt with portions of ''a whole spectrum'' of outstanding issues. Still to be finalized, he said, were such things as a package guaranteeing that the United Nations would act impartially in the territory.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/17/busin.body_text: **********The United States posted a $4.2 billion deficit in its balance of payments on the current account for the third quarter of this year, the Commerce Department reported yesterday; the nation appears headed for its first yearly deficit since 1979. **********Officials said next year would almost surely be worse. **********The main cause for the July-to-September shortfall was a jump in the deficit for trade in merchandise alone - from $5.7 billion in the second quarter to $12.5 billion in the third. **********As usual, there was a surplus in trade in services. That surplus rose about $200 million, to just under $10 billion for the quarter, the report indicated. **********There was a modest deficit for all other financial transactions.  The nation has had big deficits in merchandise trade every year since 1975. But those were outweighed by surpluses for services and other financial transactions in 1980 and 1981. **********Government and private analysts said services - transportation, banking and a wide variety of other business - would not be strong enough to balance the merchandise deficit, which may set a record of nearly $40 billion this year. **********The balance of payments on the current account includes not only trade in goods and services, but also investments and banking deals.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/17/busin.body_text: **********Debt-ridden MGM/UA, the entertainment conglomerate, yesterday executed a letter of intent to sell its music copyrights to CBS Inc.  for an estimated $70 million, according to a joint announcement by the two companies. **********The agreement apparently ends MGM/UA's effort to sell off at least part of its music interests, and could ease the company's problems in repaying its bank debt, now more than $650 million. **********Earlier this summer, MGM/ UA negotiations for the sale of its music company and a pre-1950 film library to Warner Communications for approximately $95 million fell through. **********In addition to acquiring MGM/UA's music catalogue, which includes more than 50,000 titles, CBS will enter into a co-publishing agreement with MGM/UA for the rights to music created for motion picture and audio visual productions over the next five years.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/29/busin.main_headline: Real Estate; Brooklyn Navy Yard Program
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/29/busin.print_headline: Real Estate; Brooklyn Navy Yard Program
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/29/busin.body_text: **********TWO months ago the Brooklyn Navy Yard Development Corporation, overseers of the sprawling industrial park on the East River, inaugurated its own steam production system, enabling it to provide steam to its tenants at rates below those of Consolidated Edison. **********On its agenda for 1983 are further development of plans for a permanent co-generation plant that will provide both steam and electricity, for the construction of a 176,000-square-foot industrial building within the old Navy Yard, and, aided by the state Department of Labor, for a major job development program. **********David Lenefsky, chairman of the quasi-public corporation set up in 1981, is confident that the 37-member board, appointed by Mayor Koch and Brooklyn community organizations, has begun a reversal of fortune for the two-century-old former naval installation that once seemed destined to become a monument to unrealistic expectations and bad management. **********The city's purchase of the Federal facility in 1968 prompted outsized predictions that the 265-acre installation containing 4.3 million square feet of indoor commercial space would soon bring 30,000 jobs to Brooklyn and new life to to the nearby Brooklyn neighborhoods of Fort Greene, Bedford-Stuyvesant and Williamsburg. **********The development dream, however, became mired in the factionalism that split the yard's former board and, according to an audit of the city Comptroller's Office, in the shoddy management practices of the nonprofit, community-based group that city officials had picked to run it, the Commerce, Labor, and Industry Corporation of Kings County, or Click. **********A spokesman for the Comptroller's Office said that a report last April found the Navy Yard's fiscal stability still precarious, though less so than before. **********Richard J. Aneiro, president of the development corporation, said it had lessened the yard's serious financial problems - it lost $1.2 million in the fiscal year 1981 - brought on by haphazard recordkeeping, a large indebtedness to Con Edison, and an unwillingness to do basic maintenance work. The facility will show a loss for the current fiscal year of less than half that amount, he said. The city receives 10 percent of the facility's rental income, which last year amounted to $4 million, but is also accountable for any losses. **********Mr. Lenefsky said that the yard was becoming financially healthy.  He added that it finally had the foundation to lure businesses by attending to ''years of neglect.'' **********The board has removed nearly 12 million pounds of garbage strewn about the yard, some of which apparently had been there since the Navy left in 1966. It has also repaired potholes, a pipe leak that allowed water to flow into the East River at the rate of 1.4 million gallons a year, and a dilapidated steam-distribution system. In addition, it has substantially renovated two of the site's four major buildings. **********Mr. Lenefsky said the cleanup had emphasized what he described as the yard's attractiveness for businesses: the steam generation system that will enable businesses to buy energy at reasonable rates, a completely fenced installation patrolled by a 24-hour private security force, and a location near major roads, public transit, and, of course, the water. **********Since November 1981, when the development corporation took over, the yard's tenancy has increased by 20 percent, to 45 businesses, and the work force has grown to 2,200 from 1,700. **********Tenants include a printing company, a maker of hand-made pewter, a vermouth bottler, and a forging company. The yard's largest employer is the Coastal Dry Dock and Repair Corporation, a ship repair company with 1,200 employees. **********About 4.1 million of the 4.3 million square feet of indoor space is now rented, and nearly half of the remaining space may be taken soon, Mr. Aneiro said. Rents at the yard are about $2.65 a square foot. **********That figure does not include utility costs. For those tenants who leased space during 1982, before the new steam plant went into operation, the development corporation set a flat fee of 65 cents a square foot for utility costs, which Mr. Lenefsky said was below that of other parks. Tenants who had been in the park were billed at rates 5 percent below the comparable Con Edison charge. New tenants will be metered. **********Not all of the board's plans for the yard have gone smoothly, however. Opposition from neighborhood groups and the Board of Estimate in October forced Mayor Koch to withdraw plans to build a steam plant that would burn 3,000 tons of garbage daily. **********And, although officials hope the yard will attract more businesses fleeing the high commercial rents in lower and midtown Manhattan, its lack of further rentable space - especially if plans for new construction collapse - could seriously hamper recovery plans. **********Mr. Lenefsky said, however, that with tenancy at more than 95 percent: ''We feel the potential of the yard is very strong. It can become the focus for economic and job development in Brooklyn, as it once was.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/26/busin.body_text: **********Tin prices plunged today to $14,100 a metric ton, the lowest level since last July, leaving dealers on the London Metal Exchange baffled about the cause of the collapse. **********Surprised tin traders said they were anxiously awaiting the next move by an unknown tin buyer who has kept the market guessing for months. **********Widely believed to be acting on behalf of tin producing countries, the buyer had sent prices soaring to a record high of $16,470 a ton only last week. **********Dealers believe the unknown buyer, who began his purchases last summer, now controls more than 50,000 tons of tin.  A metal market advisory firm, Hargreaves & Williamson, said in a report today that the cost of financing the tin stockpile, estimated at more than $1 billion, would force an end to the mystery purchases and send prices below $12,800 a ton this year. **********After the hectic morning trading session at the exchange, the main market for the world tin business, dealers said that pressure to find tin for immediate delivery evaporated.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/14/busin.main_headline: DOW RISES BY 11.13 ON RATE HOPES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/14/busin.print_headline: DOW RISES BY 11.13 ON RATE HOPES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/14/busin.body_text: **********The stock market broke its eight-session losing streak yesterday, as the Dow Jones industrial average surged 11.13 points, to 788.05, mostly on investors' hopes for lower interest rates. **********''The market was stimulated today by the sharp rally in bond prices, hopes that the discount rate would be lowered and by President Reagan's statement that the recession has bottomed,'' said Charles Jensen, chief technical analyst of the MKI Securities Corporation. **********After the close of trading, the Federal Reserve did cut its discount rate, the rate at which it lends to banks and other financial institutions, to 10 1/2 percent from 11 percent. Within minutes, several major banks lowered their prime rate too, to 14 1/2 percent from 15. **********Low interest rates benefit stock prices by lowering the cost of corporate borrowing, thus increasing profits. They also make the yields of equities more attractive with respect to money market funds and similar investments. Rally Expected **********Leonard Brooks Jr., investment strategist of Cowen & Company, said that a near-term recovery in the Dow to the 815-830 level ''now appears possible.'' He predicted that the upsurge would be led by the depressed quality and interest-sensitive issues.'' **********Yesterday's advance was broadly based, with advancing issues outnumbering stocks that declined by more than a 2-to-1 ratio.  Turnover on the Big Board was moderate, at 44.7 million shares, down from 50.1 million the day before as institutional interest slackened. **********The market's upsurge yesterday enabled the Dow to end the week with a gain of 3.71 points. In the previous two weeks the blue chip barometer had dropped 46 points, mainly because of the depressed economy, disappointing corporate profits and fears of huge budget deficits. **********Among the stronger blue-chip issues yesterday, American Telephone, the third most heavily traded stock, rose 1 3/4 points, to 52 7/8.  Some analysts expect the company to benefit from the decision this week by Federal Judge Harold H. Greene that basically approved the proposed antitrust settlement reached by the company and the Justice Department earlier this year, while calling for some modifications. Cities Service Gains **********Cities Service was ahead 1 3/4 points, to 33 1/4, when trading in the stock was halted. Also halted was Occidental Petroleum, up 1/4 point, to 17 1/2, at the time. After the market's close, Cities Service said that Occidental had made a $50-a-share offer for the company. Last week, Gulf Oil withrew its offer of $5 billion, or $63 a share, to acquire Cities Service. **********Other gainers in the blue-chip category included the Allied Corporation, which rose 1 1/4 points, to 32 1/4, and General Electric, up 1, to 64. General Motors, which is expanding its dealer incentive programs, advanced 7/8, to 40 3/4, and Procter & Gamble rose 7/8, to 84 3/4. **********The Chase Manhattan Bank rose 1 1/2, points to 34 1/4, in active trading, after losing 3 3/8 on Thursday following the disclosure it had a credit exposure of $45 million because of the failure of Lombard-Wall, a government securities trading house. **********Quaker Oats, which lost 2 7/8 on Thursday after reporting lower profits for the quarter ended June 30, gained 2, to 37 1/4. Denny's Inc., the fast-food chain, was up 1 1/4, to 24, after reporting an increase in its earnings for the quarter ended June 25. **********Metromedia, the highest-priced issue on the Big Board, fell 4 5/8 points, to 192. The stock fell 29 points for the week in response to a published report that questioned the ability of the television and radio complex to continue to post large earnings. **********On the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index rose 0.25, to 237.54. Scurry-Rainbow jumped 3 points, to 34, on the news it had higher profits for the nine months ended June 30. **********In over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index slipped 0.70, to 159.14. The big loser was the Navco Corporation, which dropped 6, to 9 3/4 bid, after it rejected a cash tender offer of $17.50 a share from an unnamed party.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/15/busin.main_headline: JOINT VENTURE IN COAST-TO-COAST PAGING PLANNED
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/15/busin.print_headline: JOINT VENTURE IN COAST-TO-COAST PAGING PLANNED
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/15/busin.body_text: **********National Public Radio and the nation's fourth-largest paging service operator announced a joint venture today to offer the first nationwide ''beeper'' service. **********Under the proposal made today by National Public Radio - which gets some of its funding from the Government - and the Mobile Communications Corporation of America, customers could be paged nearly anywhere in the United States using its existing satellite network. **********A fast-growing business, electronic paging has attracted about 1.5 million customers so far. The two organizations hope to create a national service by being among the first use new frequencies allocated by the Federal Communications Commission. **********Their enterprise, which will be called National Satellite Paging Inc., needs the approval of the F.C.C., but John N. Palmer, president of Mobile Communications, said the service should be available as early as next year at a cost of about $25 a month. **********The plan may mean millions of dollars in new income for public radio and be yet another step toward financial independence from the Government, following a recent entry into the data communications field. **********Profits, which are not expected for several years, will be split 60 percent to Mobil Communications and 40 percent to National Public Radio. **********''This will be a true network facility,'' Mr. Palmer said of the paging venture. ''Although some companies provide modest regional services, N.S.P. Inc. is the first system where any radio common carrier can be part of an integrated nationwide network.'' **********Under the system, paging calls would be sent to a satellite from Washington and then down to radio stations around the country. Those stations would relay the signal to local paging systems. Each call would be flashed to all points, but only the customer's beeper would pick up the call. **********Mr. Palmer's plan is to use his own paging services in 37 cities, as well as the facilities of other cooperating paging companies. He said the plan will offer just beeper service at first, and later offer an updated version where the customer gets a printout of the phone number he is to call. **********National Public Radio's president, Frank Mankiewicz, said that its 267 affiliated stations will also receive fees from the paging operations.

''The company's basic financial condition remains solid and we are continuing a program of major cost reductions.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/15/world.main_headline: HAIG, AT U.J.A., CRITICIZES REAGAN'S MIDEAST PLAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/15/world.print_headline: HAIG, AT U.J.A., CRITICIZES REAGAN'S MIDEAST PLAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/15/world.body_text: **********Former Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. attacked President Reagan's Middle East plan yesterday, describing the proposal for a freeze on Israeli settlements in the occupied West Bank as ''a very serious mistake.'' **********Mr. Haig also said the Administration's plan for autonomy for the Palestinians in association with Jordan threatened a ''gutting session'' between Israel and the United States. **********''The peace process will only move forward if there is a spirit of cooperation between Israel and the United States,'' Mr. Haig said.  ''That has been shaken in recent days. **********Address to Jewish Officials **********It was the first time Mr. Haig is known to have criticized the Administration in which he served until June. He spoke without a text to 300 officials of the United Jewish Appeal at the Hilton Hotel in Manhattan. **********Mr. Haig made no direct reference to Mr. Reagan's speech Sept. 1 in which he announced his Middle East plan or to his successor, George P. Shultz, who is regarded as the architect of that speech. When Mr.  Haig was asked to comment on the Reagan plan, he smiled and said it would be inappropriate to ''parse the pros and cons.'' But he added that his own remarks contained ''some pertinent observations.'' **********The United Jewish Appeal raises funds for needy Jews around the world. It has not taken a formal position on Mr. Reagan's peace plan, but the frequent applause yesterday indicated strong agreement with the Mr. Haig's criticism. Mr. Haig, who reportedly received $25,000 for his 45-minute appearance, serves as a consultant for United Technologies, a leading military contractor, and is a senior fellow at the Hudson Institute, a research center. A Standing Ovation **********Mr. Haig received a standing ovation by concluding, ''When we are true to Israel, we are true to ourselves.'' He had earlier said, ''When by our policies we can't deal effectively with our friends in Israel, we are undercutting our effectiveness throughout the Arab world.'' **********Mr. Haig also asserted that ''had the credibility'' of Israel's invasion of Lebanon ''been left undisturbed, the Palestine Liberation Organization would have left weeks earlier, and there would have been less bloodshed.'' **********That was apparently an allusion to President Reagan's repeated pleas to Israel for restraint, pleas that the Israeli Defense Minister, Ariel Sharon, has also said delayed the evacuation of the P.L.O. Reasons for Invasion Listed **********Mr. Haig said the invasion was an attempt by Israel to aid what he called ''the central Christian elements,'' the Christian Phalangist movement, as well as to protect Israeli planes flying over Lebanon from Syrian missiles and to prevent terrorist raids in northern Israel. **********The invasion began, Mr. Haig said, with ''two surgical strikes in the Beirut area'' that left ''no civilian casualties.'' Here, too, the former Secretary of State voiced arguments that have also been advanced by Mr. Sharon. **********Mr. Haig saved his heaviest criticism for Mr. Reagan's plan. He said he had explored the record of Camp David carefully and ''Israel never committed itself to terminate permanent settlements on the West Bank.'' **********The West Bank of the Jordan was taken by Israel in the 1967 war; Mr. Reagan has called for a halt to Israeli settlements there, where 25,000 Israelis now live. 'A Very Serious Mistake' **********''I think it's a very serious mistake'' to inject the settlements issue into the Camp David peace process,'' Mr. Haig said. ''You create an obstacle that puts all in jeopardy.'' **********But the most serious flaw, Mr. Haig said, was the President's proposal that Palestinian Arabs receive a full measure of selfgovernment in a West Bank entity linked to Jordan. **********''How important it is that the U.S. be an impartial catalyst in this process'' and avoid prescribing a ''bottom line,'' Mr. Haig said, seeming to imply that the President was attempting to fix the outcome of negotiations. **********Such a course, Mr. Haig said, could lead to ''a gutting session, one with the other.'' He suggested instead that Israel retain responsibility for West Bank security, with governing authority for both Arabs and Israelis there. Future of West Bank **********The West Bank's future, he said, ''is a thing for the local nations to decide, not the U.S. to dictate.'' But, he said, ''It is not in America's interest, or Israel's, to have an enclave established on the West Bank which is susceptible to manipulation by foreign powers.'' **********The former Secretary of State also cautioned against American interference in Israeli politics, hinting that the Reagan Administration preferred to deal with Israel's Labor Party rather than Prime Minister Menachem Begin and his Likud coalition.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/12/busin.body_text: **********Saudi Arabian light crude oil, used as the benchmark in setting world oil prices, has been sold at a slight discount recently, Petroleum Intelligence Weekly said today. **********The newsletter said that Caltex, which is owned by Texaco Inc. and the Standard Oil Company of California, offered to sell Saudi oil to Nippon Oil of Japan with payment due in 60 days, double the usual term. **********The longer payment time is equivalent to a discount of 35 cents a barrel. **********The newsletter, based in New York, said this represented the first break in Saudi prices below the $34 benchmark. https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/27/world.body_text: **********REAGAN PRESSES SOVIET ON AFGHAN ACCORD **********WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (Reuters) - President Reagan, marking the third anniversary of the Soviet military intervention in Afghanistan, said today that the occupation was not a success and urged Moscow's new leaders to work toward a peaceful solution. **********''The United States does not intend to forget these brave people and their struggle,'' Mr. Reagan said in a statement, adding that ''we hope that the new leadership of the Soviet Union will take advantage of the opportunities the new year will no doubt offer to achieve a solution for Afghanistan.'' **********Mr. Reagan said if Soviet aggression was allowed to succeed in Afghanistan ''it will have a dangerous impact on the safety of free men everywhere.'' **********''Afghanistan is important to the world because the Afghan people are resisting Soviet imperialism.'' Three years after the armed intervention, he said, the Soviet campaign ''is not a success.'' **********Spirit of the Mujahedeen **********The President said that even with forces of about 105,000, the Soviet Union had been unable to control the countryside or secure many cities and had failed to rebuild the Communist-controlled Afghan Army or create an effective government. **********''This is due to the spirit and will of the majority of the Afghan people and to the Mujahedeen, the freedom fighters, who continue to resist the Soviet invaders,'' Mr. Reagan said. **********The President said the human costs of the struggle were immense and repeated his Administration's charge that Moscow is engaging in chemical warfare in Afghanistan. **********''We have convincing proof chemical weapons have been used by the Soviets against the Afghans,'' he said in the statement, but he did not elaborate. **********The United States supports a negotiated settlement for Afghanistan predicated on the complete withdrawal of Soviet troops, he said. He added that he had discussed the need for a solution to the problem with President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan during his recent visit to Washington. **********''We are both committed to a negotiated settlement that will return Afghanistan to the ranks of independent, nonaligned nations,'' he said. **********Meanwhile, China said today that the Soviet actions in Afghanistan were aimed at world domination and the massing of Soviet troops along Afghanistan's border with China gravely threatened Chinese security. **********In an editorial, the official People's Daily said, ''The Soviet aggression against Afghanistan is a major step in the Soviet global strategy for world domination.'' **********The editorial, quoted by the New China News Agency in a dispatch received in Hong Kong, said Moscow intended Afghanistan to become ''a springboard for its southward drive. ---- Italy Adds Its Opposition By United Press International **********The Italian Government condemned the Soviet Union's ''continued occupation'' of Afghanistan in a statement issued in Rome yesterday.  ''The strong military repression continues to represent, for its grave violation of human rights, an element of tension in East-West relations,'' said the statement, issued by the Foreign Ministry. **********The statement underlined the need for a ''negotiated solution'' to the ''Afghan problem'' to end what it called ''the grave and numerous deprivations imposed on a people who ask nothing but to be able to determine freely their own destiny.'' **********In Bonn, the West German Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, also appealed yesterday to the Soviet Union to withdraw from Afghanistan. **********--- Guerrilla Gains Reported **********ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Dec. 26 (UPI) - The Afghan Islamic Press Agency said today that Afghan guerrillas penetrated Soviet defenses around a heavily defended airport, destroying two helicopters and four tanks. **********The agency, which is based in Peshawar, Pakistan, said that 40 Soviet and Afghan soldiers were killed in the attack, which it said took place last Tuesday at Jalalabad, a provincial capital 50 miles from the Pakistani border.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/18/world.main_headline: MARCOS DEFENDS HIS RIGHTS AND SPENDING RECORDS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/18/world.print_headline: MARCOS DEFENDS HIS RIGHTS AND SPENDING RECORDS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/18/world.body_text: **********President Ferdinand E. Marcos today defended his record on human rights in the Philippines and termed ''ridiculous'' reports that he was an authoritarian and that he and his wife, Imelda, spent public funds lavishly while other Filipinos suffered in poverty. **********In appearances before two Congressional committees and the National Press Club, Mr. Marcos began a public relations campaign to quiet the criticism that has dogged him since he declared martial law in the Philippines 10 years ago. In an effort to demonstrate the democratic principles of his rule, Mr. Marcos introduced at every stop three men whom he described as former political opponents who are now working in his Government. **********He identified the men as Luis Taruc, a former rebel leader; Jeremias Montemayor, a political opponent, and Nilo Tayag, who once led a leftist youth movement. None of the men spoke, but other members of Mr. Marcos's entourage busily distributed Government pamphlets that described progress under President Marcos. **********Mr. Marcos, who arrived two days ago for his first visit here in 16 years, was greeted warmly on Thursday by President Reagan. But his visit has been opposed by some senators and representatives, and demonstrators chanting anti-Marcos slogans have picketed his appearances. This afternoon a coalition of anti-Marcos groups held a ''counterforum'' to rebut statements by the Philippine President. Frmer Senator Speaks **********Benigno S. Aquino Jr., a former Philippines Senator who spent seven years as a political prisoner of the Marcos Government, described Mr. Marcos as ''a tyrant destroying the civil liberties of the people.'' Mr. Aquino said that the external debt of the Philippines was over $18 billion, of which at least 10 percent ''has gone to line the pockets of the Marcos family and their cronies.'' **********Mr. Aquino also criticized the cost of the Marcoses' visit to the United States, which has been estimated at more than $5 million. He said that more than 700 people, including 200 members of the Philippines press, made the trip at Government expense, and that the Marcos Government paid Cambodians as well as Filipino-Americans to fill out crowds of pro-Marcos demonstrators here. **********Other opposition speakers talked of continuing repression and human rights abuses by the Marcos Government. Bonifacio H. Gillego, representing the Movement for a Free Philippines, said that although Mr. Marcos lifted martial law last year, he continued to exercise the same broad authority as before. ''With or without martial law,'' he said, ''Marcos remains a dictator.'' **********Mr. Marcos addressed both martial law and human rights questions repeatedly in a day that included appearances at the Senate and House foreign affairs committees and a courtesy call on Senator Howard H.  Baker Jr., the majority leader. He was asked by Representative Stephen J. Solarz, Democrat of Brooklyn, to respond to a report coming soon from Amnesty International that cites widespread torture, political arrests and murders by agents of the Marcos Government. Martial Law Defended **********Mr. Marcos replied that ''Amnesty International is not exactly the most accurate judge'' because the group did not visit the Philippines before preparing the report. ''Tell our good friends at Amnesty to come to the Philippines and I will personally guide them,'' he said. **********An Amnesty spokesman said later that the report was based on a visit by its investigators to the Philippines for 17 days last November. **********In a 35-minute address to the House panel, Mr. Marcos said he imposed martial law in 1972 ''because there was anarchy in the country'' and added that he had done so only after consulting with the legislature. Mr. Marcos also denied charges of authoritarianism.  ''It's not true that I decide everything alone,'' he said. **********Accompanied by his wife, who wore the traditional full-length butterfly-sleeve Filipino dress, Mr. Marcos moved through the Capitol this morning in a flying wedge of Philippine Cabinet members and guards. Security was unusually tight, with metal detectors in use and 200 Capitol policemen standing guard. **********Later, at the National Press Club, Mr. Marcos said that some Americans misunderstood him, and he repeated his earlier descriptions of the Philippines as a constitutional democracy. **********''All these stories about our being repressive against our enemies and friends,'' he said. ''They've all joined the Government!'' Asked about reports of corruption, Mr. Marcos told the Press Club audience: ''You must mistake us for another nation. If any public official engages in corruption, he will land in jail.'' **********What of reports that Mrs. Marcos would succeed him as President?  Mr. Marcos replied that after his election his supporters urged him to appoint Mrs. Marcos Prime Minister. ''But the First Lady and I stood our ground,'' he said. ''Now is that the action of anyone who is preparing to create a dynasty?''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/23/world.body_text: **********IRAQ REPORTS EXPELLING IRANIANS IN ONE AREA **********NICOSIA, Cyprus, Nov. 22 (AP) - Iraq said today that its forces, attacking before dawn, had driven Iranian troops from recently captured positions on the central front. It said that at least 945 Iranians had been killed and that the Iraqis had pursued the fleeing troops and attacked ''enemy targets in his own territory.'' **********These statements, broadcast by the Baghdad radio, indicated that the predawn attack was begun in the enclave on the Iraqi side of the border that Iranian forces captured in a drive that began Nov. 1.  Iraq said the Iranians launched a counterattack ''soon after our forces had achieved their goals'' but were repulsed with more heavy losses. **********There was no immediate comment from Iran. A series of communiques reported clashes along the 300-mile front, with 80 Iraqis killed in artillery duels. But no major attack was mentioned. Kharg Island Attack Reported **********The central front attack was the second major success claimed by Iraq in as many days. On Sunday it reported that its air and naval forces sank five oil tankers waiting to take on crude oil at Kharg Island, Iran's main loading terminal in the Persian Gulf. **********(In Teheran, an Iranian Oil Ministry spokesman said in a telephone interview that the Iraqi statement was ''nothing but empty claims,'' Reuters reported. **********(In London, a Lloyds Shipping Agency spokesman said that two Iranian vessels - the 41,440-ton tanker Shirvan, owned by the National Iranian Tanker Company, and the 45,933-ton hotel ship Raffaelo, owned by the Government - were reported to be lying badly damaged in the Iranian port of Bushire, 40 miles southeast of Kharg Island. The spokesman said that he believed the damage was the result of fighting but that no firm details were available.) **********Iran made no comment in its broadcasts on the Iraqi claim of sinking tankers at Kharg Island. A spokesman for a Norwegian shipping company, Sig. Bergesen D.Y., said its Kharg Island agent had cabled that the Iraqi report was false. No Confirmation Available **********Iraq's statement that its forces had chased Iranian invaders from Iraqi soil could not be independently confirmed because no foreign correspondents were at the front at the time. **********In recent days, Iraq has allowed a group of American reporters to visit some Iraqi troops facing Iranians, but these areas have been mostly quiet. **********In its communique today, the Iraqi high command said: ''Fierce battles raged during which all enemy positions and fortifications collapsed.  ''The enemy was forced to retreat in a confused manner, leaving behind a large number of dead soldiers and quantities of weapons, some destroyed and some still usable.'' **********The communique added that scores of Iranians were wounded or captured by the Iraqi forces.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/30/busin.body_text: **********Having emerged from a deeply troubled past, Marine Midland Banks Inc. is trying to make up for lost time by creating a nationwide federation of commonly owned, but autonomous banks. **********Armed with capital from the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation, which now has a 51 percent interest in the New York bank, Marine is aggressively seeking to buy banks around the United States. Hongkong and Shanghai, one of the most powerful banks in Asia, operates more than 400 offices in 40 countries and is especially strong in the Far East, the Middle East and India. **********Because Federal law prohibits interstate banking, Marine's purchases cannot be consummated until the law changes, but the bank is confident that the change will come in the not-too-distant future. Until then, it is holding options to trade nonvoting preferred stock that it now owns in the out-of-state banks for common voting stock.  If the acquisitions do not go through, the preferred stock can be redeemed over a 20-year period. **********So far Marine has invested almost $100 million in two such arrangements, and it has eagerly been combing the Eastern section of the United States, particularly Florida, in search of additional candidates. It is unwilling to specifically say where it is looking and how much it expects to invest. **********''You've got to pick your partners,'' said Edward W. Duffy, chairman and chief executive officer of the bank holding company, the nation's 14th largest. **********''We want to be a leading nationwide bank during the 1990's,'' said John R. Petty, Marine's president, who earlier this month was named chief executive officer of the Marine Midland Bank, the holding company's primary subsidiary. The holding company is based in Buffalo, and the bank has two official headquarters, one in Buffalo and one in New York. **********For 50 years, Marine Midland was a Buffalo-based holding company with many affiliated banks throughout New York State. In 1976, however, these individual banks were merged into a single unit, today's Marine Midland Bank. Ranked 11th in Asset Return **********Since the capital infusion from Hongkong and Shanghai, Marine has been struggling to bring its earnings up to par with other banks of comparable size. Last year, it ranked only 11th out of the nation's 15 largest bank holding companies in terms of return on each $100 of total assets, a key indicator of a bank's basic profitability.  Marine's return was 47 cents, compared with an average of 53 cents. **********Marine's 1981 results represented a strong turnaround from 1976, for example, when its return on each $100 of assets was 8 cents, but still far from its goal of a 60-cent return by 1984. **********''You've got the momentum from the turnaround, but now they've got to get into the trenches and try to make it work - I don't know if it will fly for them,'' said James J. McDermott, vice president and analyst at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, a securities firm that specializes in bank stocks. **********Although it began to recuperate in 1977, Marine's process was agonizingly slow because the bank was caught in the vicious circle of needing capital to produce profits and needing profits to produce capital. ''We were coming back,'' Mr. Duffy said, ''but at a slow pace.'' **********For that reason it turned to Hongkong and Shanghai, which in return for a $236 million injection of capital, obtained control of Marine in 1980 but allowed Mr. Duffy and all senior officers and directors to keep their posts. **********Some analysts, however, are asking whether Marine is merely a tool being used by Hongkong and Shanghai to create a nationwide network in the United States, or whether Marine, indeed, is working on its own. **********Although Marine's management insists that it operates independently -Hongkong and Shanghai ''is aware of our general strategy,'' Mr. Petty said - Lawrence W. Cohn, vice president and bank-stock analyst of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said he recently was told by the Asian bank's chairman that Marine will be Hongkong and Shanghai's vehicle for expansion in the United States. **********But Mr. Duffy said Marine's current approach to forming an interstate unit is the product of the bank's past troubles. ''When, in the 70's, other banks were buying sales finance and mortgage banking companies across the country, we couldn't do that,'' Mr.  Duffy said. **********But, even then, Marine continued to have good relations with its correspondent banks in the United States, which has made the current program possible, he said. In fact, Marine calls its arrangements ''enriched correspondent relationships.'' Pennsylvania and Ohio Banks **********Marine's experience with Hongkong and Shanghai appears to have set the stage for the New York bank's investments in the Industrial Valley National Bank of Pennsylvania and in the Centran Corporation of Ohio. **********Industrial Valley is the 12th-largest banking company in Pennsylvania, with 48 offices throughout the southeastern part of the state. Centran, which has $3 billion in assets, owns the Central National Bank of Cleveland and five other Ohio banks. **********Like the Marine of the 1970's, both Industrial Valley and Centran were badly in need of additional capital and were anxious to avoid having to be merged into another organization, which could have jeopardized the jobs of their top managers and directors. **********In return for options to buy their stocks, if and when Federal law permits, the Philadelphia and Cleveland banks got badly needed capital and promises that their managements would be retained. **********Hongkong and Shanghai seems to be continuing to supply Marine with an abundant amount of long-term capital to finance additional acquisitions. Only last month, for example, the Asian bank lent Marine another $50 million for 10 years, even though the bank has not made full use of the previous injection of capital. ''It could be said that Marine is overcapitalized,'' said Mr. Cohn of Dean Witter. **********In addition to the similarity between the Hongkong-Marine deal and the agreements Marine has been striking with out-of-state banks, some analysts also see an uncanny similarity between the nationwide banking federation Marine is seeking to form and its own development from a group of commonly owned banks in New York State that merged into a single bank in 1976. Different Personalities **********Another similarity is the persistence of two distinct personality types among its senior management - the country-style banker, represented at the holding company level, and the more urbane executive found at Marine's New York City unit. Marine executives agree that big differences in style still exist among its top officers, but claim that they work smoothly as a team. **********Mr. Duffy, who is 55 years old, is basically a country boy who rose from the ranks of one of Marine's relatively small affiliates, in Watertown, N.Y. He lacks the image of a big-time banker, but officers say there is no doubt he is strongly in command, that he has been chiefly responsible for the comeback and that he is Marine's link with Hongkong and Shanghai. **********In contrast, Mr. Petty, 52, who joined Marine in 1976, had been a partner in Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb and before that had spent six years in the Treasury Department under Presidents Johnson and Nixon.  Between 1968 and 1972 he was Assistant Secretary for International Affairs. **********Another senior executive vice president, the 41-year-old W. James Tozer Jr., spent most of his careet at Citicorp, and has developed a highly sophisticated strategy for the bank, including its thrust beyond New York. **********Eugene T. Mann, 51, another senior executive vice president, falls among Marine's more earthy types and, in fact, has moved to Buffalo, to which he has developed a strong loyalty. He boasts of having ''repossessed cars in Flushing'' and of having ''opened a hot dog bar in the Rockaways,'' before he joined Marine. **********''We have had our dreamers who thought they could do exotic things,'' Mr. Mann said of Marine's former senior officers.  ''Today,'' he continued, ''we don't have dreamers, we have professional managers who want to get ahead.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/09/busin.body_text: **********An Interest Rate Window **********If the foreign-exchange and bond markets are to be believed, the prime interest rate - which for six months has remained remarkably steady - may be about to drop. The banks' cost of funds has edged down, and analysts say that in the short term, the current optimism over rates may be justified. **********Expectations of further declines in the money supply, a budget compromise, more good news on inflation and bad news on the economy have sent the dollar lower and bond prices higher in recent days.  And, with Treasury Department borrowings likely to remain relatively light this month and next, the prime rate could fall by as much as 1 1/2 percentage points, says William N. Griggs, a senior vice president at Schroder Bank. Given current conditions, one might expect even bigger declines, but short-term business borrowings remain very high. **********The interest rate dip is not likely to persist, Mr. Griggs predicts. Financing the July tax cuts and increases in Social Security payments should send Treasury borrowings up into the $100 billion range during the second half. In conjunction with a tepid recovery, those financings should move rates back up in the 16 to 18 percent range by year-end, he says. Producer Prices to Rise **********It's nice while it lasts. After two straight months of declines, analysts say, April's Producer Price Index, due to be released Friday, is likely to remain unchanged. The reason is that energy prices are inserted into the **********P.P.I. with a one-month lag, so the 4 percent energy price drop in March will show up in April to help offset a rise in food prices, according to Jason Benderly, an economist at the Washington Analysis Corporation, a Bache subsidiary. Again because of energy, Mr.Benderly says the May figures are likely to be flat. Starting in June, however, the picture is likely to change, as food, energy and manufacturing prices all begin to post increases of 6 to 8 percent.  For the third quarter, producer prices could show an increase of 7 percent on average, before easing in the fourth. An increase that large would be welcome for businesses, whose cash flow has been hurt by steady declines in producer prices. Labor Stays Weak **********In spite of an occasional double-digit settlement in industries like oil, the wage givebacks and salary freezes in autos, rubber and trucking have dominated the news, and experts say contracts are likely to remain modest for the rest of the year. Indeed, even at a healthy company like General Electric, which must reach a new pact with its 73,000 organized workers by July, the economy is likely to make the unions back off their goals of healthy salary increases. **********The recession and the shake-out in the electronics business should make workers at G.E. and Westinghouse (which follows G.E. in negotiating) more concerned about job security than wage hikes, says Russell Leavitt, an analyst at Smith Barney. **********To raise productivity, both companies are engaged in automating their plants, jeopardizing jobs. And, while G.E.'s first quarter earnings rose 5 percent, the recession has hurt demand for consumer, industrial and utility products. With that demand likely to remain limited, both companies are looking elsewhere for new profits centers. Any wage gains labor wins during these talks, Mr. Leavitt says, are likely to be modest. Export Credit War? **********With the Versailles summit talks a month or so away, a revolt of sorts against the United States' tough monetary policies is likely to occur this week, when members of the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development gather in Paris. **********The recession and much lower rates of inflation have failed to bring down interest rates in this country; as a result, international interest rate differentials remain wide. That could greatly complicate renewing an agreement on minimum interest rates governments may charge for export credit programs, says Harald B.  Malmgren, an independent trade consultant. **********Reflecting the high cost of money here, American officials are likely to urge that the floor on export credit rates be raised. With interest rates much lower elsewhere, the Europeans and Japanese may reject such a suggestion and keep rates low, Mr. Malmgren says. That might lead the Commerce Department to view government-backed export projects in the U.S. as subsidies, a violation of international trade regulations. **********Kenneth N. Gilpin

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/25/world.main_headline: MORALE OF ARGENTINE TROOPS APPEARS LOW, BRITISH REPORT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/25/world.print_headline: MORALE OF ARGENTINE TROOPS APPEARS LOW, BRITISH REPORT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/25/world.body_text: **********British correspondents in the South Atlantic reported today that the condition of Argentine troops defending the Falkland Islands seemed poor. **********At Port San Carlos, Gerald Dickinson, a 37-year-old sheep farmer, told the correspondents that he had watched as two 16-year-old conscripts were shot for desertion. He also reported seeing a large number of plastic shrouds containing the bodies ''of those who had died of the cold or of hunger.'' **********''The Argentine troops here used to drink tainted water,'' said Mr. Dickinson, ''and they lived mainly on mussels from the beach.  They were pitiful. They came to beg for bread but we wouldn't give them any.'' **********On board the troopship Canberra, Argentine prisoners recounted the moments that led to their capture. 'It Was All Too Quick' **********Agostino Akino, a 19-year-old private from Cobrache in northern Argentina, said he had looked up from his position on Fanning Head on Falkland Sound and seen an armada of British ships. **********''It was all too quick,'' he continued. ''The next thing I knew there were British troops surrounding me. I had lost my rifle, so I drew my pistol. A British officer spoke to us in English. I think he asked us to stop and surrender. Someone shot me inn the leg. I had to stop.'' **********The young soldier said that most of his patrol had fled at once, leaving him and two wounded comrades behind. He told the British reporters: ''We did not think we would have to fight when we went to the Malvinas, and I was given only a rifle and six bullets. I do not know why I was sent there. We were not told anything.'' **********Pvt. Miguel Garcia, from the northern village of Chaviria, said he and his comrades had not eaten for two days when the British attacked. Before that, he said, the troops had been given one can of meat a day, to be shared between two men.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/29/world.body_text: **********Latin American Foreign Ministers debated tonight an Argentine request that the United States stop supplying weapons to Britain in the Falkland Islands crisis. **********A strongly worded Argentine proposal was the focus of debate throughout the day in a special meeting of the Organization of American States called to deal with the Falkland crisis. Diplomatic sources said the United States, Colombia, Chile and Trinidad and Tobago sought to tone down the proposal's language during the closeddoor session. **********As in April, when the O.A.S. passed a mild resolution expressing its ''concern'' over the Falkland crisis, the English-speaking Caribbean nations voiced reluctance today over the bluntly worded proposal offered by Argentina and supported by such Latin American nations as Venezuela, diplomatic sources said. **********United States officials were especially concerned, however, that Argentina would succeed in gaining a tough condemnation of Britain and criticism of the United States in view of the intensified fighting in the South Atlantic in the last two weeks. Argentine Draft the Strongest **********Of the draft resolutions being prepared for the meeting of the 30-nation O.A.S., Argentina's was the strongest. It urged the Foreign Ministers to ''vigorously condemn the unjustifiable armed aggression perpetrated by the United Kingdom against the Argentine Republic and also its illegal decision, which is an attack against the security of the entire American hemisphere, of arbitrarily declaring an extensive area of up to 12 miles from the American coasts as a zone of hostilities.'' **********The proposal also urged the United States ''to order the immediate lifting of the sanctions applied against the Argentine Republic and to refrain from providing the United Kingdom with any material assistance.'' **********A third proposal offered by Argentina asked Latin American states ''to adopt those measures they deem appropriate to assist the Argentine Republic in combating the armed aggression perpetrated by the United Kingdom.'' U.S. Denounced Previously **********The meeting of the O.A.S. working committee followed an emotional public session Thursday during which the Argentine Foreign Minister, Nicanor Costa Mendez, strongly attacked the United States for its support of Britain in the Falkland crisis. **********Later in that session Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.  urged Latin American countries to support United Nations efforts to establish peace in the South Atlantic. He asked the Latin Foreign Ministers to avoid decisions that would increase tensions. **********Mr. Haig said the 1947 Rio Treaty, providing for common hemispheric defense against an outside aggressor, was not the right mechanism to apply to the conflict between Argentina and Britain.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/27/world.body_text: **********The West German Cabinet approved new guidelines for arms exports today amid controversy over the country's role as a supplier of arms to Argentina. **********A Government spokesman, Lothar Ruhl, who gave details of the decision, said Bonn did not intend to use the new guidelines as a way of easing approval for export deals. **********He quoted Chancellor Helmut Schmidt as having told ministers that West German policy on arms sales would remain restrictive. **********Under the new guidelines, which take effect immediately, Bonn will continue restrictions on the sale of arms to countries outside the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. But a key clause allows general exceptions for ''special political considerations'' and individual export decisions if ''vital interests of the Federal Republic of Germany call for an exceptional approval.'' **********The issue was highlighted last weekend when the Christian Democratic opposition said West Germany was now the main supplier of arms to Argentina. Last month West Germany banned arms deliveries to Argentina ''under the present circumstances.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/20/busin.body_text: **********The American Express Company said yesterday that its second-quarter profit climbed 7.5 percent from the previous year's level.  The company said that earnings totaled $144 million, or $1.48 a share, in the quarter, up from $134 million, or $1.42 a share, in the corresponding period of 1981. **********Consolidated revenues rose to $1.9 billion from $1.8 billion, for a gain of 5.6 percent.  American Express said that its biggest gains came from travelrelated services, which provided net income of $68 million, a 23 percent rise from the previous year, and from international banking services, whose net income rose 25 percent, to $14 million. **********Income from insurance services climbed 6.6 percent, to $61 million, while income from investment services declined by 21 percent, to $24 million. However, James D. Robinson 3d, chairman of American Express, said that ''both Fireman's Fund Insurance Companies and Shearson/ American Express have demonstrated earnings strength that is most impressive, compared with their respective industry trends.'' Paine Webber Inc. **********Paine Webber Inc., one of Wall Street's largest investment concerns, reported that it earned $4.5 million in the fiscal third quarter, up 36.4 percent from the period a year ago. **********Profit for the quarter ended June 30 amounted to 42 cents a share, up from earnings of $3.3 million, or 33 cents a share, in the 1981 third quarter. Revenues rose to $262.7 million from $257.9 million. **********However, profit for the first nine months of the fiscal year was off 21.2 percent. For that period, Paine Webber earned $15.2 million, or $1.44 a share, compared with a profit of $19.3 million, or $2.24 a share, for the same period in 1981. Revenues rose to $794 million from $780.2 million. **********Donald B. Marron, chairman and president of Paine Webber, said that the company resumed expansion of its nationwide branch office systems during the latest quarter. ''Our investment banking unit, Blyth Eastman Paine Webber, and our fixed income and government trading business contributed to Paine Webber's profit profile,'' he added. Mr. Marron said that earnings from principal transactions, of which fixed income is a major part, rose to $34 million from $16.1 million. **********Paine Webber is the parent company of Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis Inc., a securities firm; Paine, Webber, Mitchell Hutchins Inc., a research firm, and Blyth Eastman Paine Webber.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/03/busin.body_text: **********Unemployment remained at 9.5 percent in June, the highest level in 40 years. But the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported another decline in factory jobs last month and a continuing increase in unemployment among adult men, to 8.7 percent. (Page 1.) **********The basic measure of the nation's money supply fell within the Federal Reserve Board's annual target range for the first time this year, in the week ended June 23. The Fed said that M-1 fell $2.2 billion in that week, a steeper decline than anticipated. The Fed's target range calls for annual growth of 2 1/2 to 5 1/2 percent in M-1. (27.) **********Washington **********The $21 billion tax bill approved by the Senate Finance Committee reflects a growing Congressional desire to crack down on tax evasion and to move toward a simpler income tax with lower tax rates from top to bottom. It would impose a 10 percent withholding tax on dividends and interest, establish a variety of compliance devices for personal income and restrict individuals' deductions for medical expenses and casualty losses. (1.) **********The Finance Committee voted to allow tax leasing to continue through at least September 1985 but set new limits. Companies would not be allowed to offset more than half of their tax liabilities through leasing, nor claim refunds on past years' taxes. (33.) **********The Federal Trade Commission asked Gulf and Cities Service for more information on their proposed $5 billion merger. The request effectively freezes the transaction until 10 days after the commission is satisfied that it got adequate data to study antitrust implications. Analysts said they expect approval, as Gulf reported that 90 percent of Cities' stock had been tendered. (27.) Companies **********Shares of Holly Sugar tumbled 15 1/4 points, to 33 1/4, on the news that the General Electric Credit Corporation had withdrawn a previously announced offer to lend Holly $100 million for the company to go private by buying back its shares. (27.) **********New York Air's president, Neal F. Meehan, resigned. A spokesman said it had nothing to do with the carrier's mounting losses. (27.) **********International Telephone and Telegraph's Blackburn unit is the focus of a Treasury Department investigation into allegations that it circumvented the 1980 trade embargo against Iran by shipping electrical equipment to that country during the hostage crisis. (30.) **********World Airways said it had obtained some relief from lenders and lessors who agreed to defer about $14 million in payments to June 1983. But the airline, which lost $13 million in the first quarter of 1982, said it still may face problems in October when it could be forced to buy two aircraft for $18 million each. (29.) **********NLT said it is discussing a possible merger with American General as stock trading in the two big insurance companies was halted. The two dueled in April over which would acquire the other, and each holds almost 10 percent of the shares of the other. (29.) Markets **********Technology issues ran into renewed selling pressure as the general stock market continued to weaken. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 6.28 points, to 796.99, bringing its net loss for the week to 6.09 points. (31.) **********The dollar rose moderately against other major currencies in light trading. Gold prices rose in Europe and Hong Kong, but fell in New York. In Zurich, gold closed at $313.25 an ounce, up $3. (33.) Livestock and meat futures prices were lower. (33.) **********A bill to let companies transfer stock ownership by issuing computerized statements instead of certificates was passed by the New York Legislature and sent to Governor Carey. (34.) Today's Columns **********Insurers are selling short-term health insurance policies to cover periods of unemployment or other situations where people might temporarily lack coverage. Your Money (28.) **********A new method of preparing bacterial vaccines developed at Georgetown University weakens bacteria so they lose their ability to cause disease but retain their capacity to provide immunity. Clinical tests with humans are planned. Patents. (28.)

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/05/busin.body_text: **********Foote, Cone & Belding Communications will be acquiring Newsome & Company, the 37-year-old Boston public relations firm, and in the process they will be getting a new president, and, ultimately, a new chief executive, for its subsidiary Carl Byoir & Associates, the world's third-largest public relations company. **********The man is Peter G. Osgood, 41, with Newsome since 1965 and its chief executive since 1975. **********He becomes president Nov. 1 and chief executive officer March 1, replacing Robert J. Wood, 63, the chief since 1976. Mr. Wood will continue as chairman and will be active in management. **********The deal, which is for an undisclosed amount of stock, was put together by Abbott C. Jones, president of FCB/ Associated Communications Companies. **********Newsome will continue to operate under its own name, but its New York office will be moved in with Byoir before the new year. Newsome has $2.1 million in fee income, according to Mr. Osgood. The 52-year-Byoir organization on the other hand, generated $18.6 million in revenues last year with more than 200 clients in 10 domestic and 64 foreign offices and affiliates. **********Before going into public relations Mr. Wood and Mr. Osgood worked for competing Syracuse newspapers. At different times, of course.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/05/world.body_text: **********The Administration said today that it has suspended exports to an Italian firm that defied President Reagan's ban on exports of United States technology for use in the Siberian gas pipeline. **********Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said in announcing the action that similar sanctions against two French firms will be reduced to conform with the temporary order against the Italian firm, Novo Pignone. **********The firm defied Reagan's ban on supplying United States equipment and technology for the 3,500-mile pipeline project by loading two turbine compressors, built under license from the General Electric Company, aboard a Soviet freighter today in Livorno, Italy. https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/19/busin.body_text: **********Peter Bordeaux, 34, has been named president of the 132-year-old Sazerac Company of New Orleans.  Sazerac, along with marketing the Sazerac Cocktail, a drink associated with the city's French Quarter, makes and imports a variety of distilled spirits and is moving from a regional supplier to a national distributor. **********Mr. Bordeaux, who joined the company two years ago as executive vice president, succeeds Stephen Goldring in his new post and Mr.  Goldring continues as chairman of the private company. **********''My previous background was not in the liquor business so I have not been constrained by traditional marketing ideas,'' Mr. Bordeaux said. ''The largest group of consumers right now is the 18- through 35-year-olds. It's still really unclear on their interests in distilled spirits, and that group gives you a great opportunity.'' **********Sazerac is marketing a variety of liquors and liqueurs, including Aspen Glacial, which is blue and peppermint, and Mikha, a melon liqueur. Mr. Bordeaux has pushed Taaka, the company's vodka, from a regional brand to No.8 in the nation. In the works are plans for importing and marketing a Scotch called Auchentoshan and a Welsh whisky called Swn Y Mor. **********Mr. Bordeaux is a native New Yorker who was graduated from Cornell and the Tulane School of Law. He has worked as a financial consultant, as project manager in the New Orleans policy planning and analysis office and as special assistant to Tulane's president. **********Sazerac's strategy to become a national distributor has been dictated by patterns in the liquor industry. ''Thirty years ago there were hundreds of liquor distillers,'' Mr. Bordeaux said, ''but like the beer industry there has been a consolidation over time.'' One of the lessons has been to expand. ''We built a brand-new facility in 1979 and part of the game plan was to be in a position to produce nationally,'' Mr. Bordeaux said.  Daniel F. Cuff

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/16/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation yesterday merged the troubled Western New York Savings Bank into the Buffalo Savings Bank, creating the state's third-largest thrift institution, with assets of $5.5 billion. The merger became effective at 11:59 last night. **********All of Western's deposits and mortgages automatically were assumed by Buffalo Savings at the time of the merger.  Western had 220,000 depositors and held 18,576 mortgages, accordi ng to the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks. Western' s total assets amounted to $1 billion, and its deposits, $875 million . **********To help effect the merger, the F.D.I.C. injected $30 million into the capital structure of Buffalo Savings. The agency said that if instead it had allowed the bank to fail and then paid off its depositors, the total cost to the F.D.I.C. would have been about $210 million. **********As a result of the merger, Buffalo Savings now holds 32 percent of all deposits in the Buffalo metropolitan area. Five other banks, including two commercial banks, reportedly submitted bids to acquire Western. One of the commercial banks was identified as the Bank of New York. It appears that Buffalo Savings made the highest bid and thus required a smaller contribution from the F.D.I.C. Improved Service Seen **********Muriel Siebert, New York State Superintendent of Banks, said that the potential anticompetitive effects of the additional concentration of deposits in the Buffalo area was ''counterbalanced'' by improved service to the Buffalo community. ''In Buffalo, you've got Marine Midland, Chase and Citibank, and Manufacturers Hanover, among others.'' **********This was the fourth merger assisted by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation in the past two months. The F.D.I.C. is the Government agency that insures deposits in savings and commercial banks. **********Only a month earlier, Buffalo Savings acquired the Union Dime Savings Bank of New York, another institution that had been in danger of failing. Union Dime had assets of $1.4 billion. In other recent F.D.I.C.-assisted mergers of failing New York savings banks, the Metropolitan Savings Bank acquired the Greenwich, and the Harlem Savings Bank acquired the Central. **********Compared with the three other savings bank mergers, which together cost the F.D.I.C. almost $1 billion, the Western merger was relatively inexpensive. It was also simpler - the agency merely paid $30 million and walked away. In the other mergers, the F.D.I.C.  assumed long-term obligations in which it guaranteed the acquiring banks against any losses stemming from the acquisitions. **********Western, however, appears to have been in better shape. Some sources said that it was basically sound, but that for technical reasons it was about to default on $10.5 million in notes held in unit investment trusts operated by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith. One clause of the notes stipulated that they would be in default if Western's capital fell below $30 million. It dropped below that level in the fourth quarter, and therefore, the bank automatically defaulted. **********As part of the agreement, Merrill Lynch agreed to reduce the interest rate on the notes to about 4 1/2 percent. The original rates, according to a Merrill Lynch spokesman, ranged between 9 and 10 percent. Shares in the trusts were sold in increments of $1,000.  The Merrill Lynch spokesman said that the reduced yield on the Western New York notes would not significantly reduce the yield on the trusts. **********''Either you accept the lower rate or you lose everything,'' the F.D.I.C. negotiators told Merrill Lynch, according to the Merrill Lynch spokesman.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/26/world.print_headline: MOSCOW DISPUTES REAGAN ON THE MX
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/26/world.body_text: **********Pravda, the Soviet party newspaper, carried a detailed rebuttal today to President Reagan's arguments for deploying the new MX missile, charging that the plan would violate the accords limiting strategic arms. **********Western diplomats took the commentary in Pravda as an authoritative response to Mr. Reagan's speech on Monday announcing plans for deploying the missile, which he said was needed to modernize American nuclear forces. **********The commentary argued that the United States had started every escalation in the arms race, and that the Soviet buildup of the 1970's had only achieved a balance after the American expansion of the previous decade. It contended that the MX missiles and the Trident II missiles as well as new strategic bombers and long-range cruise missiles would expand the American military arsenal to 20,000 strategic charges by 1990. **********Previous Accords Invoked **********''Starting the implementation of the MX program,'' Pravda further asserted, ''Washington cannot but know that this runs counter to one of the central provisions of the SALT I and SALT II accords: an obligation not to create additional silos for intercontinental missiles. Just as Washington cannot but be aware that this step will not promote progress at negotiations in Geneva.'' **********The Carter and Reagan Administrations have both argued that the strategic arms accords ban new fixed launchers for intercontinental ballistic missiles and that this does not apply to the MX because the new rocket comes in a cannister complete with its own launching equipment. **********The first strategic arms accord expired in 1977 and the second was never ratified by the United States, but both sides have said they would abide by the accords if the other side did. **********Pravda did not develop the argument that the MX violates the strategic arms accords further. It focused, rather, on the fundamental disagreement between Moscow and Washington on whether there is a ''rough parity'' in strategic arms, as claimed by the Kremlin, or a Soviet superiority, as claimed by Washington. **********The Soviet article said the Soviet Union had no intention ''to chase the U.S.A. in the creation of each new system of weapons or to imitate the U.S.A.'' But the newspaper added, ''This does not mean at all that the Soviet Union will not find an effective reply to Washington if the U.S.A. starts realizing its plans.'' **********American analysts found the phrasing ambiguous and took it to mean that Moscow's repeated pledges to maintain an ample defense did not necessarily mean that it would produce weapons systems to match every new generation of American arms. **********The authoritative level of the Pravda article was underscored by the fact that the official Soviet press agency Tass transmitted it twice in English. Some analysts found the tone of the article less strident and aggressive than similar statements made under Leonid I.  Brezhnev, although specific arguments and claims were largely the same. On Building Confidence **********Pravda termed the confidence-building measures proposed by Mr.  Reagan in his speech as ''undoubtedly positive,'' but it went on to complain that the President had never responded to measures proposed by the Soviet Union. **********''There is no denying that not a single opportunity to come to terms on any steps of positive nature should be left without attention,'' Pravda said. ''Exchanging more information on the practice launchings of missiles, which the U.S. President suggests in particular, is useful. The main thing, however, is to prevent an operational launching of missiles. If 10 telephones directly linking Moscow and Washington, red or blue, are attached to a hundred MX missiles, will those missiles become less dangerous?'' **********One of Mr. Reagan's proposals was to improve the telex line linking Moscow and Washington.  Pravda contrasted Mr. Reagan's speech to one made on the same day by Yuri V. Andropov, the new Soviet party leader, in which he argued against making weapons a yardstick of the strength of the opposed social system and said the Soviet Union would refuse to make any ''preliminary consessions'' to bring normalization of relations. **********Mr. Reagan, Pravda said, also spoke of a ''desire for peace,'' but the article asserted that by this he signified a ''longing for the former comparative invulnerability of the United States, which encouraged it to various gambles.'' Arms Race Called American **********The paper reasserted the Soviet argument that the arms race ''has its roots in American soil,'' starting with development of new Minuteman, Polaris and Poseidon missiles, the cruise missiles and medium-range missiles with strategic potential.
