https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/19/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices rose moderately yesterday in slower trading following Wednesday's sharp rally. The best gains were posted by some of the special-situation issues that responded to specific news developments. **********At the final bell, the Dow Jones industrial average was ahead 4.60 points to 1,032.10. In the previous session, the blue-chip barometer soared 19.50 points on renewed expectations of a reduction in interest rates. **********In the overall market yesterday, stocks that rose on the New York Stock Exchange outscored declining issues by 944 to 649. Turnover on the exchange contracted to 77.6 million shares from 84.4 million the day before as institutional participation continued to ease. **********Leonard Siegel, vice president of investments at Josephthal & Company, said the market yesterday continued to be buoyed mainly by the belief that the Federal Reserve ''will shortly cut the discount rate.'' The rate, now at 9 1/2 percent, is what the Fed charges banks for loans. **********Mr. Siegel noted that if this occurred the Dow could surpass its high of 1,065.49 set on Nov. 3. He said that President Reagan's statement on Wednesday that he is considering a proposal to move up to January the 10 percent tax cut scheduled for July also helped stock prices. Schering-Plough Advance **********The big gainer yesterday was Schering-Plough, the second most active issue, which soared 5 3/8 points, to 42 1/4, on a turnover of 1.2 million shares. Several analysts yesterday recommended the stock following a meeting with executives of the company at which Schering's new product plans and recent financial results were discussed. **********James River climbed 3 3/8, to 31 1/2, in active trading. On Wednesday the special paper maker's stock rose 2 7/8 points after reporting that its per-share net in the quarter ended Oct. 24 advanced to $1.43 a share from 65 cents the year before. **********Emhart Corporation added 1 1/2 points, to 43, following the announcement that its directors had lifted the quarterly dividend to 65 cents a share from 60 cents. **********Medtronic Inc. tacked on 2 3/4, to 49 1/8, after gaining 3 7/8 points on Wednesday following introduction of a new pacemaker.  In the energy group, Texaco was up 3/4, to 31 5/8. On Wednesday, one of the oil company's units said results of a third well confirm a giant oil discovry in the Santa Maria Basin off southern California. Effect of Bell Ruling **********American Telephone and Telegraph, the volume leader, lost 1 point, to 60 5/8. The Federal Communications Commission yesterday rejected a proposal by the company to raise rates it charges its long-distance competitors for access to local Bell networks. The company also filed a public offering of 15 million common shares with the Securities and Exchange Commission. **********Several of the blue chips registered good gains yesterday. General Electric was up 1 5/8, to 90 5/8; American Express added 1 1/4, to 68 1/2, and General Foods rose 1 1/8, to 44. **********Prices on the American Stock Exchange mostly advanced, with the market value index ahead 2.33, to 335.55. Ply-Gem moved ahead 1, to 15 3/8, after directors voted a 2-for-1 stock split. **********In the over-the-counter market, the Nasdaq composite index rose 1.53, to 229.28.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/09/world.body_text: **********Concerned over deterioration in relations between Canada and the United States in recent months, three dozen businessmen, lawyers and former Government officials from both sides gathered here this week in an unusual three-day series of private meetings. **********The meetings were organized by the Columbia University Graduate School of Business and by Touche Ross & Company, an international federation of accountants and management consultants whose partners detected growing tensions between their American and Canadian clients recently. The co-c@hairmen of the meetings were Kingman Brewster Jr., former president of Yale and former Ambassador to Britain, and David Johnston, principal and vice rector of McGill University in Montreal. **********''We're neighbors and we're strangers,'' Mr. Brewster said. ''Both peoples have got to take a longer view of each other,'' Mr. Johnston added. **********The participants talked, at times heatedly, about American resentments over Canada's increasingly nationalist economic policies. They discussed Canada's belated but mounting efforts at cultural and economic nation-building, its preoccupation with the United States and its impatience with Washington's episodic interest in relations with Canada. 'Taking Friends for Granted' **********''The United States,'' Mr. Brewster said, ''got into the very bad habit of taking its friends for granted. I sensed it in Britain and I sense it here. But we tend to be more important to any one country than any one country is to us.'' **********''Canada is looming larger and larger in the American consciousness,'' said Allan E. Gotlieb, Canada's Ambassador in Washington, adding that this had yet to be translated into a generally well-informed public opinion. He saw ''the seeds of continued long-term friction between us because we are seeking greater economic control and that means less foreign control.'' **********''The United States is so massive an influence in Canada,'' said Abraham Rotstein, an economist at the University of Toronto, ''that anything we do domestically touches American interests immediately somehow.'' One major irritant, the discussions showed, is Canada's Foreign Investment Review Agency, which screens all foreign investments for ''significant'' benefit to Canada. **********Participants said that they generally accepted the agency's goals but that its operations were secretive, arbitrary and might better be aimed at specific key areas instead of every sector. The agency and Canada's National Energy Program, which discriminates against foreign oil companies to promote Canadian ownership, create an uncertainty and investment chill that threaten the kind of long-term foreign investments historically so vital to Canada's economy, participants said. Canadian Regionalism Is Strong **********''In the long run,'' said Lloyd N. Cutler, former White House counsel, ''freer trade and investment will benefit Canada's market of 25 million much more than its controlled approach. Canada will pay, and is paying, a horrible price for its policy that curbs competition. Almost any commodity you name costs more in Canada.'' **********Many of the Americans, who also included Elliot L. Richardson and Orville L. Freeman, former Cabinet members, said they learned some essential differences with Canada such as the strong pull of its disparate regions and the historically heavy economic intervention of Canada's federal government. **********''Canada seems so much like us,'' said Sol M. Linowitz, former United States delegate to the Organization of American States, ''that we expect Canada to be like us and do like us. And when Canada does differently by recognizing China or Cuba or struggling against us to maintain its independence, we are surprised and can overr@eact.'' **********There was a consensus that both sides, especially the Americans, should pay greater attention to the other, especially before adopting policies that could affect the other even inadvertently. William W.  Scranton, former Governor of Pennsylvania, urged support for upgrading the State Department's Canadian operations, now under European affairs. **********Mr. Scranton also suggested an annual Canadian-United States summit meeting as a regular culmination of each year's negotiations between the two countries to focus the attention of the American public and the Washington bureaucracy on the United States' often overlooked northern neighbor.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/25/busin.body_text: **********First came the rumors. Then, on Monday, the British Government confirmed that it would preserve Ravenscraig, the British Steel Corporation's only integrated steel mill in Scotland. **********The decision was contrary to the recommendation of Ian MacGregor, British Steel's hard-boiled chairman, and a challenge to Christmas spirit here in the south Wales city of 135,000 that is the home of the huge Llanwern works. No one here wants to see Scottish steelworkers lose their jobs, but fear is widespread that the successful defense of Ravenscraig means more job cuts at Llanwern next year and may in the long run undermine Llanwern's own struggle to survive. **********That struggle has produced dramatic productivity gains at the price of cutting the work force from a 1973 peak of 9,800 to 4,137, including a recently announced reduction of 350. 'People Are Frightened' **********''People are a lot quieter now, and frightened of what's coming in the future,'' said Reginald Russell, a seven-year Llanwern veteran who lost his job in 1980. **********''We're worried,'' agreed Alan Brittan, a 23-year-old employee in Llanwern's central engineering shop, as he sat in front of the Christmas tree in the card-bedecked, present-laden living room of his fiancee's parents. ''Sharon and I are getting married in March, we just bought a house, and I can't be sure that I won't be made redundant.'' **********It's not just the well-publicized woes of British Steel, which is losing between $12.8 million and $14.4 million a week. In pubs and in breaks from last-minute shopping, the Welsh quickly acknowledge that other Western steelmakers, and indeed many basic manufacturing sectors, are also being driven to the wall by worldwide economic recession and growing competition from abroad. **********''Llanwern has been cowed,'' said the Rev. Ray Taylor, an industrial chaplain who has been a familiar sight around the plant since it was built in the early 1960's. **********From all appearances, Newport and the towns in the county of Gwent for which it is the hub have taken advantage of Christmas to put aside such thoughts. Llanwern and smaller steel works in the area have shut down for the holidays in what Mr. Taylor called ''the bittersweet bonus'' that poor business pays to family life. Stores have been crowded with shoppers. Generous Payments **********Nevertheless, like the snowier Welsh town lovingly evoked in Dylan Thomas's ''A Child's Christmas in Wales,'' Newport could be described as ''bandaged.'' In Newport's case, the wounds have been salved with severance payments for Llanwern workers that are extremely generous by American standards - many receive 90 percent of a year's salary, and 80 percent for the next six months, and workers over 55 years old immediately receive pension money that would otherwise have been theirs at the age of 65. **********Many Newport merchants experienced a boom in business when 4,300 workers were laid off in 1980. Thanks to the generous severance payments, union leaders were able to fill most of the redundancy slots with workers willing to leave. For some, it was the once-in-alifetime opportunity to go into business for themselves. **********But there are signs the severance payment cushion is not quite as protective as generally healthy retail sales this month might indicate. **********''You won't see it much at Christmas - that's the very last thing the Welsh are going to pull back on - but it has had an impact,'' said Mr. Brittan, the steelworker. ''Not many people go on holidays now and you never find anybody in the clubs during the week.'' Unemployment at 15% **********Real estate brokers also report generally flat or depressed prices in many areas, particularly in new developments constructed in nearby towns to house the influx of workers attracted by Llanwern in happier times. **********A door-to-door study last year disclosed that unemployment had affected 45 percent of the households in some sections of Newport in the previous two years and concluded that numerous health problems could be attributed to the layoffs. **********''To say that all but a handful of the redundancies have been voluntary is not to say that there aren't a lot of people who are now sorry that they went,'' Mr. Taylor said. Unemployment in Newport is officially hovering around 15 percent and the level in some of the surrounding towns is much higher. **********''People don't say hello today,'' Charles Smith, a fitter at a smaller British Steel specialty steel plant here, said at the Royal Oak pub Wednesday night. ''They say, 'Are you still working?' '' **********None of this is lost on union leaders at Llanwern. Peter McKim, chairman of the trade union committee at the plant, described workers as ''punch drunk'' and expressed discouragement at the number of people who have ''come to accept unemployment as a way of life.'' Closure Politically Unwise **********Hope had risen last spring that the worst was over as British Steel cut its weekly losses to 500,000, regained domestic share and operated at more than 90 percent of its 14.4 million-ton basic steel capacity. But the bottom fell out of domestic and export markets this summer and imports rose, sending Mr. MacGregor to the Government with the advice to close another major facility. **********The possibility that it might be Llanwern appeared remote at first. Ravenscraig, near Glasgow, seemed the logical candidate because it was less efficient than either Llanwern or Port Talbot, another integrated Welsh plant that also makes strip steel. In addition, the closing of several large Scottish steel users had eroded local demand for Ravenscraig's output. **********But the three-month campaign by Scottish politicians, businessmen and clergy arguing that Ravenscraig was crucial to Scotland's industrial future convinced the Conservative Government that abandoning the plant was out of the question politically. Indeed, facing up to the likelihood of an election next fall, Patrick Jenkin, the Industry Secretary, announced that none of British Steel's integrated plants would be closed. Drive for Capital Investment **********The statement came in the form of a pledge for more Government financial support for British Steel. It extended British Steel's deadline to break even financially until March 1985. **********However, no one is assuming that the implicit promise to maintain all five plants for three years will be honored much past the election, unless business conditions improve. Llanwern union leaders, who joined in the campaign to keep Ravenscraig, are now lobbying more intensively than ever for a $100 million capital investment in a continuous caster for their plant. **********The energy-saving casters eliminate the need to make steel ingots prior to casting slabs. Energy now accounts for about 30 percent of Llanwern's costs, almost double the labor component, according to the unions. Port Talbot and Ravenscraig have continuous casters already, an advantage that looks ominous to Llanwern workers who want to hang on to their hard-won position as British Steel's most productive and lowest cost per-ton producers. **********''All I want for Christmas is the caster,'' said A.D.G. Williams, a union leader for process workers. ''We've made tremendous strides in manning levels, labor relations and practices. We haven't done all this to see it go down the drain.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/20/busin.body_text: **********With interest rates falling, the nation's builders started work on more new single-family houses in September than they did in any month for more than a year, the Commerce Department reported today. **********Overall housing starts jumped 14.4 percent, to an annual rate of 1.146 million. A flood of 30,000 federally subsidized housing units was responsible for most of the increase, reflected in the 73 percent increase in multifamily apartment construction. **********But starts for single-family houses alone rose 6.6 percent, to a rate of 663,000, the highest since July 1981.  President Reagan timed his signing of a National Housing Week proclamation to coincide with the housing report. ''These are the days of new hope for housing, hope for millions of families that dream of owning homes and hope for millions who make their livelihoods from building them,'' the President told those attending the White House ceremony. Aid to Builders and Buyers **********When bank lending rates drop, it makes it cheaper for builders to finance new construction. And when home loan rates decline, prospective buyers find it easier and cheaper to get mortgage loans. **********Government and housing industry economists said even better times seem to lie ahead for builders. ''Our feeling is that housing will continue to improve with interest rates declining,'' said Michael Sumichrast, chief economist with the National Association of Home Builders. **********Commerce Under Secretary Robert Dederick agreed, saying that, as a result of falling rates, ''growth in home-building appears likely to assume its customary leading role in the economic recovery'' of the nation. **********According to the Commerce Department report, in September overall housing starts rose to just below July's rate of 1.19 million and well above the level of under a million that has dominated the recession. **********The department also reported that starts for single-family houses hit the highest level since the 696,000 of July 1981; new multifamily units were started at an annual rate of 483,000, up 27.1 percent from August, and building permits for future construction rose 16.9 percent, to an annual rate of 1.038 million units, also only slightly below the July level. **********Mr. Sumichrast and Thomas Harter, chief economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, stressed that the big gain in multifamily building construction was mainly a result of an increase in Government-sponsored work. And Mr. Harter said there should be more of that subsidized housing started in the next few months. Highest Level Since April 1981 **********Mr. Harter added that, with interest rates continuing down this month, ''I wouldn't be surprised to see starts between 1.2 million and 1.25 million in October and then staying there in November or maybe even going higher.'' That would put starts at the highest level since the 1.3 million annual rate of April 1981. **********Mr. Sumichrast cautioned that housing starts tend to jump or fall quickly from month to month, and he said there may still be some declines ahead. ''But there's certainly a different kind of attitude among builders,'' he added. ''Some are starting model houses for next year,'' while this time a year ago many were going out of business. **********After declining to an annual rate of 931,000 units in April, housing starts have bounced up and down each month since. They rose 20.9 percent in May, dropped 14.8 percent in June, rebounded 31.4 percent in July to the year's high mark, then declined 16 percent in August before the new gain. **********Before adjustment for seasonal variations, the report said, about 107,600 new housing units were started in September, up from 93,200 in August.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/20/busin.body_text: **********Great Western Savings and Northern California Savings and Loan have agreed in principle to merge through an exchange of stock valued at $61.2 million, officials of both savings institutions said today. The new uni t would have $12.6 billion in assets and thus solidify its position as the nation's second-largest savings and loan association. **********The largest is the Home Savings and Loan Association of America, also of Los Angeles, with $15 billion in assets. **********Great Western Savings, with headquarters in Los Angeles, has assets of $10.6 billion and 123 offices and is one of the largest of the nation's nearly 5,000 savings and loan associations. Northern California Savings, based in Palo Alto, has assets of $2 billion and 60 offices. **********The merger is the latest in a series of thrift institution mergers brought about by the financial losses of many thrifts, which have been forced to pay high interest rates for their funds while earning lower yields from portfolios dominated by bonds and long-term mortgages. **********Under the agreement, Northern California Savings' stockholders would receive one share of Great Western Financial Corporation, the parent company of Great Western, for every share of Northern California Savings they hold. **********Shares of both companies, listed on the New York Stock Exchange, did not trade today. On Monday, Northern California Savings' common stock closed at $8.25 a share, up 75 cents, and Great Western's common finished unchanged at $12 a share. **********The companies said their directors had approved the merger proposal pending approval by both companies'shareholders and the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, as well as other conditions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/28/busin.body_text: **********ALGUR MEADOWS, founder of the General American Oil Company, used to call himself ''a man of three centuries.'' Born as the 19th century drew to a close, he was still healthy enough in 1978 to predict he would live until the year 2000. People who knew this tireless executive were almost convinced he would make it. But after playing golf one June day in 1978, Mr. Meadows was killed in an automobile accident. **********The takeover rumors that had swirled around General American Oil for many years became even more persistent.  Those rumors were stoked again last week after T. Boone Pickens Jr., chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company, said he was looking for an acquisition candidate to replace the Cities Service Company, which Mr. Pickens lost to the Gulf Oil Corporation. During Mesa's acquisition campaign, it was unclear for a time whether Mesa would take over Cities Service or vice versa. Cities Service abruptly ended the struggle when it chose a merger with Gulf. **********Since Mesa already owns 7.4 percent of General American, traders hopped aboard what appeared to be the next oil-powered takeover bandwagon. **********But Geoffrey Hertel of Rotan Mosle Inc. says the possibility of a takeover of General American by Mesa is ''less likely than it once was.'' Rotan is a Houston-based brokerage firm that specializes in oil stocks. **********Mr. Hertel comments that Mr. Pickens had obviously considered the idea of acquiring General American. But things are different today, even though he bought his General American shares at a relatively low price: $17.75 adjusted for splits, a bit over half of the present price. **********A major difference now, Mr. Hertel notes, is the ''questionable value'' to General American of its Canadian reserves. Mesa purchased its General American shares before the Canadian Goverment began its campaign to force American companies to sell their properties in Canada to Canadians. **********Roughly a third of General American's estimated 77.6 million barrels of oil reserves are under Canadian soil, and close to half the company's 561.2 billion cubic feet of gas are in Canada. **********Meanwhile, Mr. Hertel said, Mesa has been trying to sell its own Canadian reserves, suggesting that Mesa is not enthralled over General American's dependence on Canadian reserves. **********Regardless of Mesa's interest, there is a compelling reason to regard General American as a buyout candidate. Wall Street analysts note that the probate of Mr. Meadows's will is to be completed by mid-1982. After that, the Meadows Foundation, with 27 percent of General American's 24.6 million shares, will be free to sell them. **********The eventual recipient of the foundation interest is to be Southern Methodist University. Analysts believe that prudence will require selling the shares so the assets can be diversified. **********Mr. Meadows, whose first wife died before him, provided separately for his survivors, including his second wife and an adopted son. Mr.  Meadows's only direct heir is his brother's son, Curtis Meadows, president of the Meadows Foundation. **********According to one rumor, there was a meeting two months ago between foundation officials and a group of oil executives interested in acquiring General American. The rumor caused the stock to run to the mid-30's. No one could be reached at the foundation this weekend for comment. **********Joseph S. Clark Jr. of Wertheim & Company estimates General American to be worth at least $65 in break-up value. To him, Gulf's acquisition of Cities Service suggests that large companies are interested in buying independent producers. **********A third analyst, who asked not to be identified, put a minimum value on the shares of $50. He thinks that the Canadian Government under Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau is becoming less hostile to American companies and may allow them to hold their Canadian oil and gas.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/06/busin.snippet: AS Philadelphia celebrates its 300th anniversary this year, its s tock exchange is marking year 192, making it the nation's oldest s tock exchange. Despite such longevity - or perhaps because of it - t he Philadelphia Stock Exchange has made a nam...
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/06/busin.body_text: **********AS Philadelphia celebrates its 300th anniversary this year, its s tock exchange is marking year 192, making it the nation's oldest s tock exchange. Despite such longevity - or perhaps because of it - t he Philadelphia Stock Exchange has made a name as the most i nnovative of the six regional stock exchanges. It is now eagerly a waiting a go-ahead from the Securities and Exchange Commission for i ts latest innovation, trading in foreign currency options, which c ould go on stream as early as September. **********The move into currency options follows great success the exchange had in being the first regional exchange to trade in stock options, which it began in 1975. By last year, it had outgrown its building and had moved to a new, ultramodern, glass-paneled structure some four blocks away on March Street in downtown Philadelphia. **********The step into stock options was a $1 million risk, for an exchange whose trading in equities of small regional companies is about onefifth the size of the New York Stock Exchange's in terms to total transactions. But it proved worthwhile. Options currently account for more than 50 percent of the Philadelphia exchange's business.  Last year the Philadelphia just happened to be the sole trader in the options of Conoco, the target of a high-stakes takeover fight.  And currently it has Cities Service, another target of a takeover bid. **********Last year alone, the exchange sold 10 million options contracts, a number that reflects heavy trading in Conoco options during Du Pont's, Seagram's and Mobil's takeover battle for it. The exchange was trading up to 83,000 contracts daily in its 64 listed options, with Conoco accounting for most. Currently, it is handling a more realistic 45,000 daily contracts, including Cities Service stock options, which traded as many as 34,000 contracts last Wednesday.  Mesa Petroleum is in the midst of a takeover struggle with Cities Service. **********Though the Philadelphia exchange is the second smallest of the options traders - only the Pacific is smaller, and the two larger are the Chicago Board Options Exchange and the American Stock Exchange - it is gaining ground. Total volume for all four exchanges fell 3 percent in April from what it was a year ago, but at Philadelphia, volume rose more than 16 percent. **********If the move to new quarters and the frantic trading in Conoco options highlighted last summer's action, the beginning of trading in foreign currency options is expect to create a surge this year. **********As an indicator of how big the potential market in currency options might be, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported in June 1980 that gross foreign currency transactions by 90 banks totaled $23.4 billion for each business day in March of that year. Although Nicholas A. Giordano, the exchange's president and chief executive, says he has no way of knowing the size of the market, he speculates it could be hundreds of billions of dollars a year. **********''It's a question of how successful our marketing program is going to be in reaching the multinational corporations, import-exporters and speculators,'' Mr. Giordano said. But he predicts that the exchange could be trading 30,000 contracts a day within 18 months, which, at an average value of $30,000 a contract, would mean $230 billion a year in foreign currency options. **********For years, the Philadelphia Stock Exchange, formerly the Philadelphia, Baltimore, Washington Stock Exchange, had the image of a stodgy institution in a sleepy city. Mr. Giordano has pushed to project a spunkier image through new products. ''We've taken some risks that others didn't,'' he said. **********In addition to its options business and trading of multilisted stocks, the Philadelphia exchange has about 100 primary listings - stocks that do not appear on other exchanges - and about 30 regional stocks, those listed on other regional exchanges but not the New York Stock Exchange or American Stock Exchange. Among its 500 members, 104 deal exclusively with the Philadelphia exchange.TO be listed on the Philadelphia exchange, a company need have only $ 1 million in net assets, compared with $16 million on the Big Board.A s such, companies listed exclusively in Philadelphia are relatively s mall, and many of them are local, such as Morlan International Inc.,a Philadelphia-based maker of burial vaults, or the Horn & Hardart B aking Company, a local restaurant concern. Those primary stocks a ccount for only 10 percent of the exchange's equity business, h owever, while the bulk of the business come from such major, m ultilisted stocks as General Motors and Exxon. **********So far, the Philadelphia exchange has sold more than 300 seats to those hoping to trade in foreign currency options. Prices are $5,000 for members, $10,000 for nonmembers, and $8,000 for members who only trade in stocks on the exchange. **********To begin with, currency contracts will be offered in the five currencies most heavily traded against the dollar - the West German mark, the British pound, the Canadian dollar, the Japanese yen and the Swiss franc. **********An investor buying foreign currency options pays a fee, or premium, for the option to buy or sell a prescribed amount of that currency at a contracted ''strike'' price. Arnold F. Staloff, who will be responsible for the currency options, said the premiums would run between $300 and $1,500, depending on the length of the contract and the price. Regardless of how the currency moves, the option buyer can never lose more than the premium. **********Foreign currencies are generally traded in the form of futures contracts. As with any futures contract, buyers are locked into a predetermined price and they must pay up front a certain amount of money, called margin. If the value of the foreign currency declines in relation to the contracted price, the investor is required to put up more and more margin in order to cover the loss on his contract and hold onto it. **********With options, on the other hand, the investor can hold onto his option as long as he wants, no matter how steeply the currency moves in the wrong direction from the contracted price. And he does not ever have to exercise the option. He is not required to put up any more money and thus stands to lose only the initial amount, at worst. **********The Philadelphia exchange expects its proposed product to be greeted warmly by multinationals. Mr. Staloff cited the hypothetical case of a company planning to build a factory in West Germany. ''The company has a proposal out for 60 days,'' he said. ''The bid is for 10 million marks, or $4.2 million if they get the contract.'' **********He added, ''Today, they can finance the building by buying a futures contract for 10 million marks for delivery in two months. If the mark increases in value, they make money. But let's say the mark drops from 42 cents to 39 cents. That's a 3-cent loss per mark, or $300,000 whether they get the contract or not. If the company bought options for 10 million marks at 42 cents, their maximum loss would be the $48,000 premium it would cost them.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/29/world.body_text: **********The White House and State Department voiced strong regret today over the recent heavy civilian casualties in west Beirut, appealing for a new cease-fire. Israel, which had been bombing the city heavily for a week, said later that it had agreed to hold its fire against the Palestinians effective at 10:30 P.M. (4:30 P.M., Eastern daylight time). **********The developments came as the tempo of negotiations over the fate of 6,000 Palestinian guerrillas trapped in west Beirut appeared to be accelerating. State Department officials said the task of the special American envoy, Philip C. Habib, in negotiating the withdrawal of the Palestinians, would be eased if a cease-fire were restored. **********The White House deputy press secretary, Larry Speakes, said, ''It is the President's greatest desire that the killings stop.'' Mr.  Speakes said the United States was ''concerned over continuing violence in the Middle East and we urge all parties to observe the cease-fire.'' Observance of Truce Is Urged **********At the State Department, Dean Fischer, the spokesman, said Tuesday's bombing of west Beirut by Israeli planes was ''the source of the greatest possible regret to us.'' He said ''many innocent people have been killed and wounded as a result of the breakdown of the cease-fire,'' though he did not criticize Israel directly. **********Beirut police officials have said that 120 people were killed and 232 wounded on Tuesday.  ''Ambassador Habib is currently heavily engaged in trying to restore a cease-fire, which not only would spare lives and property damage but would also permit headway in political negotiations,'' Mr. Fischer said. **********'' We call on all combatants involved to reinstate the cease-fire in place. The bloodshed must stop.'' Asked what the Administration would do if it did not, Mr. Fischer replied, ''I don't know, quite frankly.'' State Department officials said later that Mr. Habib's mission to arrange a Palestinian withdrawal from west Beirut was hampered by the breakdown of the cease-fire. At a basic level, the officials said, the bombings made it ''physically difficult'' for Mr. Habib to negotiate with Lebanese officials seeking to work out an agreement. **********There was some initial confusion over Prime Minister Menachem Begin's comment in Jerusalem, after a meeting Mr. Habib, that the American ''will find out in the next two days'' whether the Palestine Liberation Organization will quit west Beirut. Mr. Begin said Mr.  Habib hoped to get what the Israeli leader termed an ''unequivocal commitment.'' **********A State Department official said Mr. Habib had apparently told Mr.  Begin that he hoped to get a commitment from the Palestinians. P.L.O. to Give an Answer **********''It was certainly not an ultimatum on the Israeli's part or a deadline,'' said the official. ''Phil said he needed to get an answer from the P.L.O. side.'' **********Meanwhile, Nicholas Veliotes, Assistant Secretary of State for Middle East Affairs, told a House Foreign Affairs subcommittee that the suspension of cluster bomb shipments to Israel was ''long-term, if not permanent.'' **********On Tuesday, the State Department announced an indefinite extension of the suspension of cluster bomb deliveries to Israel that President Reagan had ordered last week. The suspension was in part a response to Congressional criticism that the Administration had not taken a tough stand against Israel's use of the weapon, which sprays bomblets over an area several hundred feet in diameter. There were allegations on Capitol Hill that Israel had used the weapon against civilians.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/22/busin.print_headline: Bond Prices Advance Sharply; Drop in Key Rates Is Cited
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/22/busin.body_text: **********Bond prices soared and yields sank yesterday after an unexpected drop in key short-term money rates set off bursts of buying.  The buying caught many money managers off guard, particularly those who had sold Treasury issues short on Monday to square accounts for the holidays. Their efforts to cover their short positions helped to fuel the advance. **********At the close, gains of more than 2 points, or $20 for each $1,000 of face value, were common among the longer Government maturities, while intermediate issues rose half that much. But rates on shortterm Treasury bills were narrowly mixed. **********Initial Buying Burst **********Yesterday's initial burst of buying was led by ''retail,'' or institutional, money managers. It came at the market opening and reflected a drop in the Federal funds rate to 8.125 percent from 8.5 percent. That is the rate charged for overnight loans that banks make to each other. As William V. Sullivan Jr., senior vice president at the Bank of New York, noted: **********''The drop in the funds rate on a Tuesday was considered very bullish, a mood that was sustained by a strong Treasury bond futures market, which moved upward all day. As the cash and futures markets rose, the shorts were increasingly forced to buy out of their positions, thus causing prices in both markets to advance.'' **********In addition, he said, news that the Consumer Price Index for November was up only one-tenth of 1 percent, compared with the rise of eight-tenths of 1 percent in October, and the Government's ''flash'' report on fourth-quarter gross national product, which projected a 2.2 percent decline for the period, kept the rally going despite some scattered profit taking late in the day. Federal Funds Rate **********Most important, Mr. Sullivan noted, was the surprising drop in the Federal funds rate, because it occurred a day before the end of the bank statement week, when banks often scramble for overnight reserves to balance their accounts. **********Dealers had no explanation for the surprising drop in the Federal funds rate beyond noting the obvious: that banks seemed to be well suited with funds. **********A leading beneficiary of the buying was the Treasury, which auctioned $4.5 billion of seven-year notes, because it prompted bidders to revise their bids upward shortly before the 1:30 P.M.  auction deadline. At that time, the notes were being traded on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 10.60 percent, off 10 basis points on the bid side. Auction Results **********After the close, the Treasury announced that the auction produced an average price of 99.594, equivalent to a yield of 10.58 percent, down from the average yield of 11.94 percent for seven-year notes sold last September. The notes will carry a 10.5 percent coupon, down an eighth of a point from what had been expected before the sale. **********Today, the Treasury will auction $3 billion of 20-year and onemonth bonds, which traded yesterday on a when-issued yield basis of 10.65 percent bid, down 30 basis points. Tomorrow, the Treasury will complete its auctions this week with the sale of $7 billion of oneyear bills. **********In the secondary market for Treasury debt issues, 90-day bill rates rose to 7.92 percent from 7.85. But the rate on six-month bills slipped to 8 percent from 8.08, dealers said. Among the intermediate maturities, prices of the 9 3/8 percent notes of 1984 rose to 99.28 from 99.17; the 10.5's of 1992, to par from 98.28, and the bellwether long bond, the 10 3/8's of 2012, jumped slightly more than 2 points, to 98.28. Dealers' Financing Costs **********The drop in the Federal funds rate caused a similar decline in financing costs of Government securities dealers, some of whom had been somewhat concerned about the growth in their inventories. **********What also fed the price advance was that the Federal Reserve's only market move was to buy $700 million of Treasury paper for a foreign customer, which only slightly and indirectly increased banking reserves. **********Another bullish factor was the conviction of many buyers that the disarray among members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries portends weaker energy costs. Still another was the fact that few big corporate debt issues have been scheduled for sale until after Jan. 1. A major concern in the credit market is that the soaring Federal budget deficit will force the Government to borrow more, choking off funds needed to revive the economy. **********Edward E. Yardeni, senior vice president and chief economist at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., noted that the initial buying came from some retail buyers of this week's Treasury offerings on a whenissued basis. ''These buyers, and dealers, don't have to pay for these issues until Jan. 4, so even the more nervous money managers won't have to show their new purchases on the books for the fourth quarter and full year,'' he said. **********Following are the results of the Treasury's auction of $4.5 billion of seven-year notes: P.U. TABLULAR MATTER. https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/28/busin.body_text: **********Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that the Government might have to impose some controls over the trading of government securities as a result of the Drysdale affair. Drysdale Government Securities has been unable to pay almost $300 million that it owes to several banks that had been involved with the broker in securities trading. **********The problem involved repurchase agreements, or repos, in which market participants sell or lend a security and promise to buy it back at some point in the future. **********''Any incident of this sort raises some questions,'' Mr. Volcker said. But he indicated that the Fed was reluctant to interfere. He said that the market appeared to be instituting some reforms on its own, and that the Fed was ''interested in consulting with the participants'' on the matter. **********''I wouldn't prejudge an answer to the question'' of whether further control was required, he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/30/world.print_headline: U.N. CALLS ON ISRAEL TO LET FOOD INTO WEST BEIRUT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/30/world.body_text: **********The Security Council voted tonight to demand that Israel immediately lift its blockade of west Beirut to permit food and other supplies to reach the besieged area of the Lebanese capital. **********The vote was 14 to 0, with the United States refusing to participate. Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the American delegate, complained that the sudden introduction of the motion and the quick vote left her no time to consult with Washington. She warned that the Council could not function if delegates lacked time to check with their governments. **********The resolution was introduced unexpectedly by Spain in the middle of a debate on a French-Egyptian proposal designed to strengthen the Palestine Liberation Organization and its goal of a Palestinian nation. **********But Jaime de Pinies, the Spanish delegate, broke into the discussion to urge that the Council act to ease the suffering in west Beirut. Israel Said to Block Supplies **********He proposed a resolution demanding that Israel allow aid provided by United Nations agencies and the International Committee of the Red Cross into west Beirut. **********Earlier in the day, the Lebanese Government charged that Israeli soldiers were blocking supplies for west Beirut.  Mrs. Kirkpatrick said she had ''serious problems'' with the Spanish resolution because it was ''lacking in balance.'' The P.L.O., she said, is imposing itself on Beirut, but the relief resolution called only on Israel to act. 'A One-Sided Appeal' **********''A one-sided appeal in a two-sided conflict suggests purposes that are political as well as humanitarian,'' Mrs. Kirkpatrick said.  She tried to persuade the Council to delay its vote by two hours but her motion was defeated by a vote of 6 to 6 with 3 abstentions.  The 14 Council members who voted for the Spanish resolution were Britain, France, China, the Soviet Union, Poland, Ireland, Spain, Japan, Panama, Jordan, Zaire, Guyana, Uganda and Togo. **********After the vote, Yehuda Z. Blum, the Israeli delegate, said Israel ''fully supports any genuine humanitarian concern,'' but ''rejects and will resist any attempt to abuse humanitarian concerns for the purpose of obtaining political objectives.'' French-Egyptian Proposal **********The Council's 15 members spent most of the day discussing the French-Egyptian proposal, an ambitious attempt to pull back Israeli and P.L.O. forces from Beirut as well as to provide the framework for a permament settlement of the Palestinian issue. **********The P.L.O.'s observer at the United Nations, Zehdi Labib Terzi, said tonight that he welcomed the proposal, but he did not give any new sign that the guerrillas were ready to acknowledge Israel's existence. **********The French-Egyptian resolution, which was introduced in the Council today, affirms the right of all Middle Eastern nations to a secure life. This language, taken from Security Council Resolution 242, is regarded as assuring Israel's right to exist. **********The initiative is designed to give greater legitimacy to the P.L.O. and encourage the United States with an eye toward creating a Palestinian nation. 'A Positive Initiative' **********The Egyptian delegate, Esmat Abdel Meguid, told the Council that the P.L.O. leader, Yasir Arafat, had already taken ''a positive initiative'' by declaring on Sunday that he accepted all United Nations resolutions dealing with Palestine. Now, Mr. Meguid said, ''simultaneous and mutual recognition of the rights of both Israel and the Palestinians should be energetically promoted.'' **********''Such a step should be enhanced by a parallel, direct dialogue between the United States and the Palestinians,'' Mr. Meguid said.  He also made clear that the French-Egyptian call for ''selfdetermination'' meant the creation of a Palestinian state in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/27/busin.body_text: **********In its first formal trade-related sanction against Japan, the Reagan Administration today placed restrictions on Japanese fishing rights. **********The new rules, announced by the State and Commerce Departments, cut by 10 percent Japan's allowable catch from waters within 200 miles of Alaska, a favorite fishing ground, and will remain in force until American fish processors are allowed more access to Japanese markets. **********''The Japanese expected to get roughly 25 percent'' of their year's allocation, said the State Department's fishing policy formulator, Ray Arnaudo. ''We allocated the Japanese about 15 percent.'' **********The cutback for Japan was threatened earlier in the year, when instead of granting 100 percent of the year's fishing privileges all at once, as in previous years, the Reagan Administration angered the Japanese by announcing only half of the allocations. **********The balance was to be announced in April and July. The Japanese interpreted that to mean a straight 25-25 percent split of the remainder. **********The delay in announcements meant, for the first time, the Japanese ''literally have had to stop fishing on some specific species in some areas,'' a Commerce Department fisheries official said, as the original 50 percent allocation was used up before the next phase was announced.

The exact increases will depend on the product, alloy, form and geographic region, Kaiser said. ''Prices in many areas have become far too low, and we are not interested in participating in market areas where those low levels persist,'' Kaiser said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/08/world.main_headline: ISRAELI TROOPS KEEP SHELLING AS TALKS SEEM DEADLOCKED
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/08/world.print_headline: ISRAELI TROOPS KEEP SHELLING AS TALKS SEEM DEADLOCKED
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/08/world.body_text: **********Israel kept up its bombardment and blockade of the Palestine Liberation Organization in west Beirut today amid indications that negotiations for a settlement were still deadlocked over the basic details of when, how and where the P.L.O.would leave Lebanon. **********The negotiations have become a tangle of proposals from the Americans, the French, the Egyptians, the Palestinians, the Israelis and the Lebanese, which one Lebanese Cabinet minister described privately as a ''big salad, a big Caesar salad.'' **********The essential problem is that while all sides seem to agree that the P.L.O. should and will eventually transfer its headquarters and some fighters from Lebanon, there is still no firm agreement on how many fighters should leave, whether they should leave by land, sea or air, where they should go and what kind of military and political presence the P.L.O. should be permitted to leave behind in Lebanon to look after the interests of the 650,000 Palestinians still living here. Water and Electricity Go On **********The pace of the negotiations has clearly picked up, despite the Israeli blockade of west Beirut for the fifth straight day, which has prevented any food, fuel or medical supplies from entering the predominantly Moslem half of the capital still occupied by some 6,000 P.L.O. guerrillas and 500,000 Lebanese and Palestinian civilians.  Water and electricity, which were cut off Sunday, were turned back on by the Israelis today. **********The director general of Israel's Foreign Ministry, David Kimche, met this afternoon with Philip C. Habib, the special American envoy, at the American Ambassador's residence in the hills overlooking Israeli-occupied Christian east Beirut, apparently to discuss an American offer to send troops and Sixth Fleet vessels to protect the P.L.O. as it withdraws from west Beirut and to assess the short-term prospects for such an evacuation. **********This afternoon Mr. Habib telephoned Prime Minister Shafik al-Wazzan to brief him on the latest Israeli and American proposals, Government sources said. Mr. Wazzan has refused to drive through the Israeli checkpoints to meet Mr. Habib or President Elias Sarkis at the presidential palace in Baabda until the Israeli blockade is lifted. Meeting With Arafat **********Immediately after his telephone discussions with Mr. Habib, Mr.  Wazzan met with Yasir Arafat, head of the P.L.O., and former Prime Minister Saeb Salam to assess the P.L.O.'s reaction. After their onehour meeting at Mr. Salam's house, the Prime Minister told reporters: ''Each day there is progress, but each day there are new obstacles. We are still hoping to reach an honorable and favorable solution.'' **********Mr. Wazzan said his Government were still studying Mr. Reagan's offer of troops and naval vessels and hoped to have an answer in a day or two. Mr. Arafat has ruled out the idea of the P.L.O. leaving under American protection, although he is understood not to be opposed to American involvement in a multinational force to separate the Israeli and Palestinian armies around Beirut as the first step to a negotiated settlement. **********An official involved in this afternoon's talks between Mr. Arafat, Mr. Wazzan and Mr. Salam said, ''Many things are happening, but many things are not happening.'' **********What is not happening is that the basic differences between the Israeli and Palestinian proposals are not being bridged despite three weeks of negotiations. The P.L.O.'s Position **********Senior P.L.O. sources said today that the guerrilla group was still standing by a proposal it made to the Lebanese Government on June 24. That plan called for an Israeli withdrawal of 5 to 10 kilometers from Beirut and a P.L.O. withdrawal into its west Beirut refugee camps. A multinational force would then be deployed between the two armies and in west Beirut alongside the Lebanese Army. **********After this separation of forces, the P.L.O. would begin withdrawing from Lebanon with the understanding that its leaders would move the headquarters to another Arab capital - still to be selected - and some P.L.O. fighters would leave. **********The P.L.O. is still insisting, however, that some of its fighters be organized into two brigades as the Palestine Liberation Army and be permitted to stay in northern Lebanon and the Bekaa Valley under the command of the Lebanese Army. It is also demanding that a P.L.O.  diplomatic mission and information office be maintained in Beirut. U.S. and Israeli Stands **********The American position is understood to be that the P.L.O. leaders and all of its fighters should leave Lebanon, leaving only an information office in Beirut. **********The Israeli position, reaffirmed after a Cabinet meeting today, is very clear: the military, political and organizational presence of the P.L.O. should be removed from Lebanon in its entirety. **********Mr. Arafat apparently believes that the Israelis are unwilling to take on his forces in the streets of west Beirut and that if they do, the P.L.O. will be able to hold them off long enough for Arab and international pressure to force the Israelis to desist. Hence, his readiness to hold to his basic negotiating position despite the Israeli blockade and bombardments. **********Beginning late Tuesday afternoon and continuing through the night, Israeli artillery and warships blasted Palestinian neighborhoods on the southern outskirts of west Beirut, setting fires that blackened the dawn sky and causing ''many casualties,'' according to the state-run Beirut radio. Many Israeli shells fell in non-Palestinian residential areas of west Beirut as well. After a brief respite, Palestinian and Israeli gunners again began dueling today around sunset, with Israeli forces in Shuweifat and Khalde, overlooking west Beirut, trading artillery and rocket fire with the guerrillas dug into the Lailake and Hayy al Sollom neighborhoods. During each one of these artillery exchanges the Israelis have tried to move a few yards closer to the guerrilla outposts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/02/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; TREASURY YIELDS FALL SHARPLY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/02/busin.body_text: **********Amid widespread anticipation of lower interest rates in coming weeks, yields fell sharply yesterday for outstanding Treasury notes and bonds and for those scheduled to be sold this week and next. **********''The bullish outlook is so widespread that there are no sellers except for the Treasury,'' said Morgan Stark, senior vice president at the Chemical Bank. ''There has been persistent buying of long-term issues,'' he added, ''leaving prices nowhere to go but up.'' **********In advance of approaching Treasury note and bond sales totaling $13 billion, dealers in Government securities said presale orders from investors had not been heavy. But they predicted that the prospect of lower interest rates soon would be enough of an inducement to cause many firms to buy the new issues even though investors have not made definite commitments to buy. **********Demand for new corporate issues has been strong, but in the Treasury market the strongest presale activity has been for 30-year bonds scheduled for sale Nov. 9. Potential price gains are greater for long-term bonds than for the three-year notes scheduled for sale tomorrow or the 10-year notes on Thursday, analysts said. Lure for Speculators Seen **********The three-year notes were offered late yesterday on a when-issued basis to yield 9.81 percent, down from 10.02 percent late Friday. The 10-year issue was offered at 10.41 percent, down from 10.58 percent.  And the 30-year bonds were offered at 10.35 percent, down from 10.54 percent. **********Albert Gross, senior vice president at Refco Inc., a securities concern, said speculators could be attracted to the market because ''the most pronounced declines in interest rates will be in the period immediately ahead, not six months or more in the future.'' He added that ''the next problem is going to be pronounced weakness and actual declines in the money supply'' that would encourage the Fed to make long-awaited moves toward lowering short-term interest rates and cutting the discount rate, which the Fed charges for loans to financial institutions. **********Weakness in money supply growth, which often accompanies declines in short-term credit demand, was masked during October, said Mr.  Gross, because proceeds from maturing ''All Savers'' certificates were put into checking accounts. Outcome of Treasury Sale **********Dealers said the downward pressure on short-term interest rates yesterday was not so great as for longer-term issues because shortterm rates are lower than long-term rates and because the potential profits from a drop in interest rates are greater for long-term issues. **********At the regular Monday auction of new Treasury bills, rates fell slightly, with the three-month issue selling at an average rate of 7.813 percent, down from 8.031 percent last week, while the six-month issue averaged 8.231 percent, down from 8.472 percent. **********Based on the auction results, the maximum rate for new 91-day savings certificates is 7.813 percent for banks and thrift institutions alike, while the maximum rate for six-month certificates is 8.731 percent at thrift units and 8.481 percent at banks. **********In the market for tax-exempt issues, securities dealers said they were swamped with new issues, which has kept kept tax-exempt yields from declining as much as yields in the Treasury market. Corporations Enter Market **********In the corporate market, several high-quality industrial companies that borrow infrequently decided the time was ripe for new issues.  Dresser Industries' 25-year debentures, rated Aa2, were offered with an 11.8 percent yield, and the Mobil Corporation's Aa2-rated 10-year notes were offered to yield 10.9 percent, while Westavco's A1-rated 30-year debentures were offered to yield 12.125 percent. **********Other new corporate issues announced yesterday included the Ford Motor Credit Company's Baa2-rated five-year notes yielding 12.375 percent, Associated Dry Goods' A2-rated five year notes yielding 11.25 percent, Gerber Products' A2-rated 12-year notes yielding 11.75 percent and American Express Credit's Aa2-rated 30-year debentures yielding 11.99 percent. **********Following are results of yesterday's three- and six-month Treasury bill auctions: (000 omitted in dollar figures) 3-Mo. Bills 6-Mo. The three-month bills mature Feb. 3, 1983 and the six-month bills, May 5, 1983.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/30/busin.main_headline: A Key Economic Indicator Shows a Gain
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/30/busin.print_headline: THE WEEK IN BUSINESS; A Key Economic Indicator Shows a Gain
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/30/busin.body_text: **********The index of leading economic indicators rose eight-tenths of 1 percent last month, the Commerce Department said. It was the first gain since April 1981 and while the rise was a bit larger than expected, it was greeted with caution. Commerce Secretary Baldrige said it would be ''premature to draw any firm conclusions about the timing of a business upturn.'' **********Interest rates eased as Citibank dropped its prime rate to 16 percent from 16 1/2 percent, the first such reduction by a major bank since March. **********The Big Three auto makers reported that their mid-May sales rose 15.3 percent, the second consecutive period of new-car sales gains. **********The nation's foreign trade deficit dipped to $322 million in April, the closest it has come to balance since a one-month surplus more than six years ago, the Commerce Department reported. A drop in oil imports to a nine-year low was the main factor. **********Britain and Norway said they would raise the price of North Sea oil on June 1 by about $2.50 a barrel, to $33.50. Analysts say the increase was the latest sign that the oil glut is ending. **********Japan announced new tariff reductions on computers, machine tools and nuclear reactors in a second set of actions intended to lower trade barriers and reduce criticism by the United States and other countries of excessive Japanese market protectionism. **********Eight of 10 Common Market nations supported Britain in the Falklands crisis with an indefinite continuance of trade sanctions against Argentina. **********A Federal judge ordered all parties to the proposed antitrust settlement between the Justice Department and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to file new, clarifying comment and prepare for a public hearing on the plan by late June. **********United Airlines, the nation's largest domestic air carrier, said it was seeking to cancel or delay delivery of 20 Boeing 767's worth $1 billion. **********Firestone reported an 81.5 percent drop in second-quarter net income, while Deere posted a 96.7 percent decline. **********Disclosure that the Environmental Protection Agency has been advising oil companies since October 1980 that they could increase the lead content of regular gasoline 10 percent above the official limit of 0.5 of a gram per gallon spurred protests by environmental and consumer groups. **********The bankruptcy trustee for the Milwaukee Road told a Federal judge he had agreed to sell the railroad to the Grand Trunk Corporation, which would assume $253 million of its $500 million debts. **********The House rejected a Reagan-backed budget calling for a $103.5 billion deficit along with other proposals. The Senate rebuffed the Administration by approving a $5 billion program to aid the ailing housing industry through a mortgage subsidies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/06/world.main_headline: ACCORD ON TRADE SEEMS TO BE NEAR AT FRENCH PARLEY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/06/world.print_headline: ACCORD ON TRADE SEEMS TO BE NEAR AT FRENCH PARLEY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/06/world.body_text: **********The leaders of the major industrial democracies headed today toward an agreement to limit the use of cheap export credits in world trade, but without the sharp restrictions on credits to the Soviet Union that President Reagan has been seeking. **********A spokesman for the French Government said that Mr. Reagan had raised the issue ''with great intensity'' at today's luncheon meeting in the ornate Salon de la Paix at Versailles, but that he quickly found himself ''isolated'' from the six other leaders at the table. **********A senior Administration official, who asked not to be identified, said glumly this evening that ''we've got a long way to go if we're ever going to have an agreement'' on American proposals to curb government-subsidized credits to the Soviet Union as a means of limiting trade with that country. He said an accord acceptable to the United States had ''a one-in-five chance.'' **********Finance Ministers Confer **********While the leaders met to discuss broad economic and trade issues, their finance and foreign ministers conferred separately on a communique that would carefully bridge their differences, in some cases by employing highly generalized language. In addition, the finance ministers agreed that they would try to align their national economic policies more closely. (Page 16.) **********The conference participants were described as close to agreeing that all developed nations, including the Soviet Union, be permitted to receive export financing of no less than 12.5 percent for shortterm loans, and that there be no ceilings placed on the volume of such loans or credit in general to the Eastern bloc. **********The United States had originally sought a requirement that the Soviet Union pay market rates, or more than 16 percent, for their financing, and that there be a limit on the total volume of financing from the West. American officials said that if Mr. Reagan could not obtain all that he sought, then the United States would go along with ''the maximum we could get'' on the export credit issue while reserving the right to push for a more acceptable agreement later. **********Mr. Reagan, various officials said, contended today that stiff credit restrictions were needed to hamper the Soviet economy and make it more difficult for the Soviet Union to build its military strength. But these officials reported that his view was vigorously disputed by Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany and Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada. **********Mr. Schmidt and Mr. Trudeau were said to have argued that Soviet behavior would not be influenced by a cutback on exports, and they countered Mr. Reagan's statements by pointing out that his Administration continues to be willing to sell grain to Russia. **********The Reagan Administration has placed great importance on the credit issue. It indicated before the conference that the United States would be willing to make concessions on other economic matters if the leaders would agree to end low-interest credits to the Soviet Union.  For Europeans, however, the credits are deemed necessary to stimulate exports and produce jobs. **********In other developments, the conference participants reached a measure of agreement on new procedures to stabilize worldwide currency exchange rates. Reagan Administration officials maintained, however, that the United States would not drop its opposition to European requests that it intervene in the marketplace by buying and selling currencies to stablize exchange rates and prop up their sagging European currencies. **********As the leaders completed a day and a half of deliberations here, with one more day to go, much of their side discussions continued to be dominated by the situation in the Falkland Islands. Complaints About Interest Rates **********In addition, Mr. Reagan heard sharp complaints today about high American interest rates and large budget deficits from other conference participants. According to Treasury Secretary Donald T.  Regan, Chancellor Schmidt of West Germany turned to the President at one point and asked when he thought American budget deficits would be reduced. **********Mr. Regan said the President replied that he hoped the House of Representatives would succeed in approving a budget next week, and that soon thereafter there could be an agreement between the House and the Senate to reduce deficits in the next three years. European leaders have blamed huge projected deficits in the United States for high American interest rates. **********As expected, the participants were reportedly tough in their criticism of each other's trade practices.  Secretary Regan said the Europeans complained specifically about American efforts to block European steel imports. Both European and American officials also reportedly objected to each other's farm subsidies. Criticism of Japanese Cited **********Both the United States and its European allies were said to be critical of Japanese barriers to imports. Japanese officials said Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki said Japanese trade practices were no more restrictive than those of their nations. But the participants reportedly disagreed, although President Francois Mitterrand of France said this evening that Japan seemed ''to be settling more problems with the United States and North America'' than with Europe. **********Officials from West Germany, France and Britain said the most likely accord to be adopted at the conference would be a set of new limits on export credits for all countries - not simply the Soviet Union. Moscow would not be able to receive any credits greater than those given to countries in the West. **********This formula was worked out a few weeks ago by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, which is the Western economic alliance group. Secretary Regan said ''there are still some holdouts'' on accepting even this accord, and identified them as France and Britain. Other officials said the two countries were objecting to putting the formula into place too rapidly. **********Another American official said ''we want the O.E.C.D. agreement - plus,'' but that this looked increasingly unlikely. Specifically, he said the request for future limits on the volume of export credits and loans would be difficult to achieve. French Raise Subsidy Rate **********As recently as this spring, the French subsidized the financing of exports for the Soviet Union at 7.5 percent. Recently, they raised the level to 11.5 percent. The O.E.C.D. accord, if adopted, would raise the limit to the 12.5 percent level for short-term credits. **********An American official said it was incorrect that Mr. Reagan had taken one position on the issue and everybody else had taken another, as the French had said. He said Chancellor Schmidt had been supportive, and that Prime Minister Suzuki had also backed such an arrangement, provided everyone could agree on them together. **********It was unclear tonight whether the conference's potential failure to agree to Mr. Reagan's terms on credits meant that the United States would renew its efforts to impede European countries from helping the Soviet Union to build a natural gas pipeline from Siberia to Western Europe. **********Europeans want Mr. Reagan to let the pipeline proceed now, but the Administration says that Mr. Reagan wants to wait until after the credit issue is settled before making a final decision.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/14/world.print_headline: ISRAELIS' ATTACKS IN LEBANON BRING INCREASING CRITICISM IN WESTERN; EUROPE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/14/world.body_text: **********Western European nations, unhappy about the Israeli invasion of Lebanon almost from the start, have grown increasingly outspoken in their opposition as the military operation has continued. **********Today, in his first public comment in several weeks on the Israeli invasion, Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany suggested in a newspaper interview that Israel had killed civilians unnecessarily in the course of its bombardment of Beirut. **********Mr. Schmidt, speaking to the daily newspaper Die Welt, said, ''Here people are being killed indiscriminately -women and men who have nothing to do with the war, who bear no responsibility for this war.'' Schmidt Cites 'Human Dignity' **********He added that ''settling conflicting motives and interests with bombs and missiles cannot be reconciled with human dignity.'' On Wednesday a Minister of State at the British Foreign Office, Douglas Hurd, summoned the Israeli charge d'affaires, Yoav Biran, to express Britain's concern over the continued bombardment by Israeli forces. **********In a radio interview Wednesday night Mr. Hurd said that the Israelis were neglecting the effect on human beings of what they were doing. 'Thousands of Innocent Civilians' **********''There can be no doubt that thousands of innocent civilians, Lebanese and Palestinian, have been killed or wounded in Lebanon in pursuit of objectives which are very far from clear and probably not going to be realized,'' he said. **********To some extent European leaders, who have been concerned about the lack of forceful American action, have been encouraged by the tougher line taken toward Israel this week by President Reagan. But the Europeans are also concerned that the current Administration still rejects the principle of self-determination for the Palestinians. **********''The Americans do need to look again at their whole Middle East policy and in particular, at the way in which we can solve the Palestinian question, because until that is solved there will be further outbreaks of this kind and Israel will not have security,'' Mr. Hurd said. French Government Silent **********A silence was maintained today in France, as part of the effort by the Government of President Francois Mitterrand to ease tensions after the attack Monday on a Jewish restaurant in Paris in which 6 people were killed and 22 wounded by unidentified gunmen. Prime Minister Menachem Begin subsequently suggested that Mr. Mitterrand had, through a critical statement last month about the Israeli invasion, helped create the atmosphere that encouarged attacks on Jews. **********But French officials have made it clear that they are upset about both the continued Israeli offensive and the charges by Mr. Begin, who also said France was a land of rampant anti-Semitism and was acting like an enemy of Israel. **********''Begin is irresponsible,'' said Pierre Mendes-France, a former French Prime Minister, in a newspaper interview. ''I think that what he is doing is tragic for all the world, for his people and for the country.'' A More Difficult Step **********For West Germany, still sensitive because of the Nazi campaign of genocide against the Jews in World War II, taking such a firm stand against Israel was a far more difficult step. And Mr. Mitterrand made the first state visit to Israel by a French President as part of his effort to improve relations between the two countries. **********In 1980 the European Economic Community urged that the Palestine Liberation Organization be involved in any future talks on a settlement. The statement effectively eliminated any influence the Common Market might have had on Israel. Instead, the European nations now appear to be trying to influence Washington's position. **********The reaction today to the continuation of the Israeli offensive went beyond major European capitals. In Nicosia, President Spyros Kyprianou of Cyprus strongly condemned the Israeli attacks as ''a horrible crime of genocide against the Palestinians and the people of Lebanon, which is a stain on our civilization.'' 'Universal Indignation' **********He said in a statement that the continuing siege and the fierce Israeli bombardment was causing ''universal indignation and abhorrence.'' **********Strong words were also used in Vienna to describe the Israeli attack. Austria's Foreign Minister, Willibald Pahr, praised the United States for intervening to halt Thursday's assault on Beirut. **********''Only under hard pressure from the United States, for which we must be grateful, was this bombardment ended,'' he said at a news conference. **********The International Federation of Resistance Fighters also joined in the protests. A statement issued in Vienna by the group said that ''those who fought against Nazi barbarism and for the independence of their countries, relentlessly condemn indiscriminate use of violence by the Israeli Government, its disregard for human rights and democratic world opinion.'' **********And the Dutch Government appealed to Israel to lift its blockade of west Beirut, in keeping with a United Nations Security Council resolution adopted Thursday night. ---- Peres Defends Mitterrand **********Shimon Peres, chairman of Israel's opposition Labor Party, defended Mr. Mitterrand in New York on Friday, saying he was convinced the Frenc Prime Minister was a friend of Israel. He also urged that Israel encourage France's friendship, despite differences of opinion. **********''Among the French presidents,'' said Mr. Peres, ''and I happen to know quite a few of them, I believe that Mitterrand is the most knowledgeable on Jewish history. The cause of Israel is in his heart and mind more than anybody else that I can think of.'' **********''When the latest events took place in France,'' Mr. Peres said, alluding to the restaurant attack, Mr. Mitterrand ''was the first to come and see.'' Mr. Peres was speaking to the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations at 515 Park Avenue. ''I do not believe that he is indifferent to Jewish destiny or Jewish fate and I believe we must cultivate and respect France and its friendship.''
