https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/21/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; A 17th-Century Monk Becomes a Saint
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/21/world.body_text: **********Pope John Paul II canonized his first saint Sunday: he is Crispin of Viterbo, a 17th-century Italian shoemaker who became a monk. **********The Pope, who has traveled to Switzerland, Argentina and Britain in the last three weeks, told 20,000 people in St. Peter's Basilica that Crispin was an example of simple and wise happiness. **********''This is the first time during my pontificate that I have had the joyous job of canonizing a saint,'' the Pope said during the two-hour mass. **********Crispin, born in Viterbo, Italy, in 1668, was a shoemaker before he became a Capuchin brother. As a monk, he begged for the poor and worked as a cook, nurse, barber and gardener.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/05/world.print_headline: DOMINICAN LEADER DIES OF A GUNSHOT; SUICIDE IS REPORTED
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/05/world.body_text: **********President Antonio Guzman, who was scheduled to leave office next month, died today from a gunshot wound in the head. **********The Dominican Republic's Government said Mr. Guzman's pistol had accidentally discharged, fatally wounding him.  Privately, high Government officials said the 71-year-old President had committed suicide in the bathroom of his office, but they offered no explanation of why he might have killed himself. **********Vice President Sworn In **********Vice President Jacobo Majluta Azar was sworn into office as President by the Chief Justice shortly after dawn. He immediately issued a statement reaffirming that his Government will transfer power to President-elect Salvador Jorge Blanco, the winner of the May 16 elections, as scheduled on Aug. 16. **********On hand to back Mr. Majluta's statement were all the country's generals, who had assembled at the National Palace shortly after the shooting. **********Mr. Guzman, who was elected President in 1978, received a single shot in the head while he was in his office in the National Palace an hour before midnight. He was taken to a military hospital, where he died at about 5:30 A.M. **********When news of the President's death reached the palace, one of the generals asked Mr. Majluta to join them, and less than an hour later he was sworn into office while a dozen generals and journalists watched the ceremony. **********Mr. Majluta's first executive decree stated that he had taken charge in accordance with the Dominican Constitution and that a nineday mourning period was officially in effect. **********In a news conference after he was sworn in, the 48-year-old Mr.  Majluta said with a quavering voice that the armed forces would support the presidency and the transfer of power to Mr. Jorge Blanco, who like Mr. Guzman belongs to the Dominican Revolutionary Party, which is aligned with the Socialist International. Rumors of Coup Circulated **********Mr. Guzman's death was announced to this Caribbean country of 5.6 million people after several hours of rumors that a coup had taken place. **********Shortly after dawn a crowd of several hundred people stood silently outside the gates of the National Palace while a Roman Catholic mass for the President was being held inside. **********A closed coffin with Mr. Guzman's body had been placed in the chapel. Present at the mass there were the President's widow, Renee Klang Guzman, and one of his two daughters and her husband. To Be Taken to Santiago **********The coffin will remain at the National Palace until Monday, when it will be taken to Santiago, the country's second largest city, 100 miles northwest of here. **********A tense calm pervaded the capital's streets today. All radio and television stations repeatedly broadcast President Majluta's statement, and classical music was substituted for the popular merengue music. **********The Government is expected to stand by the official version of accidental death so Mr. Guzman can be buried in a Catholic cemetery.  Ninety-five percent of Dominicans profess Roman Catholicism, which is the official religion although religious freedom is guaranteed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/17/world.body_text: **********Following is the text of a statement on Lebanon issued by the White House and State Department today: **********It appears from press reports and eyewitness accounts that the Israelis have now moved into strategic positions throughout west Beirut and control much of that sector of the city. **********This is contrary to assurances given to us by the Israelis both in Washington and in Israel. **********We fully support the Lebanese Government's call for the withdrawal of Israeli forces, which are in clear violation of the cease-fire understanding to which Israel is a party. **********There is no justification in our view for Israel's continued military presence in west Beirut and we call for an immediate pullback.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/06/world.main_headline: BRITONS JAILED IN ARGENTINA SAW WAR FROM A CELL'S WINDOW
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/06/world.print_headline: BRITONS JAILED IN ARGENTINA SAW WAR FROM A CELL'S WINDOW
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/06/world.body_text: **********Simon Winchester, one of the three British journalists imprisoned for 77 days by Argentina on spying charges, reported this weekend that while in prison he kept records of the movements of military planes and ships ''which we could glimpse through the cell's grimy little window.'' **********Mr. Winchester, of The Sunday Times, was being held in Ushuaia, at the southern tip of Argentina, with two staff members of another Sunday newspaper, The Observer: Ian Mather, a reporter, and Tony Prime, a photographer. They were freed on bail last Tuesday and said on their arrival in Britain that they would return to stand trial. **********The jail, Mr. Winchester said in an article for his paper Sunday, provided a ''curious perspective on the war.'' It was from Ushuaia and ''while we were there,'' for example, that the Belgrano, Argentina's cruiser, left on her final voyage. She was sunk by the nuclear-powered submarine Conquerer. **********''Scores of destroyers, frigates and patrol boats scuttled into port once the vulnerability of the big ships was proven by her loss,'' he said, and ''we saw the Skyraiders and the Daggers,'' Argentine fighter planes, ''leave to attack the task force.'' War News From Argentines **********''It was terribly frustrating knowing all this and not being able to relate it,'' he wrote. The journalists were given additional information by the local police chief, who was also a naval captain and ''would come fresh from the war room to tell us things.'' **********On one occasion, according to Mr. Winchester, the official said that a British frigate, spotted near Cape Horn, ''had been ordered sunk by an Exocet,'' an air-to-surface missile that was to prove effective for Argentina, but ''last-minute orders from Buenos Aires called the attack plane home'' to Rio Gallegos, a nearby port, ''and the frigate was saved for later.'' **********Mr. Winchester wrote that he had been accused of using binoculars while waiting for a commercial flight at Rio Grande, also nearby, ''to observe Daggers, Aeromacchis and a solitary Neptune antisubmarine plane'' take off. ''I took notes,'' he acknowledged, and ''ventured to ask a waiting pilot to identify the passing hardware.'' **********He also said that after he had admitted meeting on three occasions with British military attaches an Argentine judge declared that the conversations ''were as among equals'' and that Mr. Winchester's notes were ''of a type and a caliber not usually available to an ordinary correspondent.'' First Days the Worst **********Mr. Mather, writing in The Observer, said the first days after their arrest April 13 had been the worst. But a medical examination that had terrifying implications turned out to be an inspection for possible earlier abuse and a portable electric generator that had been wheeled into a cell was used to weld a broken door. **********The three were permitted to share a cell, keep diaries, listen to the BBC World Service - and thus inform their captors of Argentine losses - read letters from Britain and consume books provided by an English resident of Ushuaia. They also argued over whether compliance or defiance was the best policy. **********Conditions improved as Argentina's military prospects declined, they wrote. Eventually they were moved to a ''suite'' of cells previously occupied by a prostitute and one night near the end of the war, Mr. Winchester wrote, ''I made so bold as to demand wine with our tripe and, astonishingly, I got it.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/08/world.main_headline: SEOUL ARRESTS PRIEST FOR AIDING A SUSPECT IN ANTI-U.S. INCIDENT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/08/world.print_headline: SEOUL ARRESTS PRIEST FOR AIDING A SUSPECT IN ANTI-U.S. INCIDENT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/08/world.body_text: **********A Roman Catholic priest and six lay associates were arrested in Seoul today after a nationwide investigation into the burning of the American Cultural Center in Pusan on March 18. **********The Rev. Choi Ki Shik, 41 years old, head of a Catholic educational center at Wonju, and his associates were charged with giving shelter to Kim Hyong Jang, a freelance writer and human rights activist, who has been arrested and charged with aiding in the planning of the incident. **********A student who was reading in the library of the center was killed when gasoline exploded in the building.  Moon Pu Shik, 23, is undergoing interrogation with eight other students, all from Pusan colleges, as the self-acknowledged organizer of the attack. **********Mr. Kim is said by the police to have counseled Mr. Moon and Kim Un Suk, 24, to carry out the arson attack. Mr. Kim had lived at Father Choi's Wonju center, 50 miles southeast of Seoul, for 22 months and Mr. Moon and Miss Kim fled to the center after the attack, the police said. **********Father Choi, to whom Mr. Moon confessed his part in the incident, urged the two fugitives to turn themselves in. They did so last Thursday after Father Choi, or other priests, notified the Agency for National Security Planning to make arrangements.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/09/world.main_headline: Bill Offered to Soften Seoul News Restrictions
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/09/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Bill Offered to Soften Seoul News Restrictions
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/09/world.body_text: **********The major opposition party submitted a bill to the National Assembly today proposing revisions to the law on journalism it says hampers press freedom. **********The bill submitted by the Democratic Korea Party seeks to make it tougher for authorities to cancel authorization for publication or seize published periodicals. It also aims to reduce criminal responsibility for editors. **********The existing law empowers the Government to seize published periodicals ''when there are due reasons for seizure.'' The bill would revise the provision to read ''when such publications upset the Constitution or destroy social peace and order.'' **********The revised language would subject editors to punishment only when they publish criminal material ''deliberately or by grave mistake.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/06/world.main_headline: ARGENTINE ACTIVISTS CALL A BRIEF TRUCE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/06/world.print_headline: ARGENTINE ACTIVISTS CALL A BRIEF TRUCE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/06/world.body_text: **********Opposition leaders say that although they support the military Government's seizure of the Falkland Islands, their discontent with the junta has not been reduced. **********Political and labor leaders opposed to the Government have said they are prepared to join in a war with Britain if necessary, but in interviews and public statements they have made clear that oppostion to military rule remains and pressure for elections will resume when the crisis over the Falklands ends. **********The military announced today that seven members of the British Royal Marines were captured Sunday on the Falklands. The statement said they escaped before the capture of their nearly 80 comrades in a battle Thursday. They had been hiding on a sheep ranch but surrendered peacefully after information on their whereabouts was revealed by an islander, the Government said. **********Preparing for Peace and War **********The Government said today that it was sending education, welfare and legal experts to begin adapting the islanders to Argentine systems. **********The military authorities said they were preparing on the islands for a possible attack by about 40 British ships that were leaving Britain and Gibraltar today. Argentine officials and many Argentines in the street said they found it hard to believe Britain would go to war over the islands. They said they expected a diplomatic solution. **********The country has not mobilized for war, although the military is on full alert and hospitals in the seaside resort of Mar del Plata, 300 miles south of here, are being prepared to take wounded. **********Foreign Ministry official said today that an edict issued Saturday night closing stores and requiring all people to stay indoors had been loosened, and islanders were going outdoors. The stiff penalties, such as 60 days in jail for an ''irreverent act'' against ''patriotic symbols,'' remained in force, however, the officials said. Roots of Opposition Remain **********Speaking of popular support for the seizure of the islands, former Foreign Minister Oscar Camilion said today in an interview, ''There are several levels of analysis, and from the point of view of discontent with the economy, the islands means nothing.'' **********Angel Robledo, the closest thing to a grand old man in the Peronist Party, the country's largest, said that ''undoubetedly the military is more stable than it was a week ago.'' **********''But,'' he added, ''I don't think this is sufficient to reverse the frustration and opposition that the majority of Argentines have felt.'' **********''Our limit for elections is 1984,'' he said, with or without the islands.  The seizure of the islands has struck a note of pride among Argentines when their country is in a frustrating political and economic situation. **********The military has been ruling for six years. The country is in a deep recession, unemployment is rising and inflation is about 150 percent a year, the highest rate in the world, according to the International Monetary Fund. One Official Appreciates Break **********Minister of Economics Roberto T. Alemann said in an interview today that the outpouring of support for the Government had bought him time for his economic policies to begin to have an effect. Those policies have focused on lowering inflation at the expense of unemployment and a declining standard of living. **********''As long as the crisis lasts, it helps me a lot,'' he said.  ''That's the way politics works around the world.'' One prominent human rights activist, Jose Federico Westerkamp, said in an interview that the military took the islands ''to divert public attention from the economic ills.'' He said, nonetheless, that he and most other rights activists supported Argentina's claim, although they were divided on the use of military force to take the islands.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/12/busin.body_text: **********Indonesia reduced the contract price of its top-selling Minas crude oil by 47 cents a barrel today and cut prices of other grades by as much as $1.30, the director of the state-owned Pertamina oil company said. The new Minas price is $34.53. **********The official, Judo Sumbono, said the reductions did not violate the price structure of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.  The average reduction was about a dollar a barrel for the 20 different grades of Indonesian oil. Indonesia's total oil production is estimated at about 1.3 million barrels a day, down from 1.6 million a year ago. **********The new Minas price represents a premium of 53 cents above the official OPEC benchmark of $34. The premium, which in the case of some OPEC members is as much as $1, reflects the higher value of different grades of oil.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/17/world.main_headline: BLACK HISTORY BEING REVISED IN ZIMBABWE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/17/world.print_headline: BLACK HISTORY BEING REVISED IN ZIMBABWE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/17/world.body_text: **********For decades, every schoolchild who grew up in this country, the former Rhodesia, learned that its history essentially began in 1855 when the Scottish explorer David Livingstone made his way to the great falls on the Zambezi River and named them after Queen Victoria. **********Now, as one of the first tangible fruits of its independence of only two and a half years, Zimbabwe is getting a new past. New history texts for primary schools are just off the presses and a hotly competitive race is on among several publishing houses, each with its own team of historians, to see who can be first with historical surveys for high school and university students. **********The new texts all seek to meet a deeply felt need: to show that the black people who live in the modern @Zimbabwe have been shapers of history and not just bystanders. **********Voyages of Discovery **********''I knew most intimately the history of Egypt,'' said Ngwabi Bhebe, a historian at the University of Zimbabwe, wryly recalling his own school days. ''We studied the Greeks and the Roman Empire, the Middle Ages and the Renaissance. Then we went over to the voyages of discovery. The voyages of discovery brought it near to us. **********''I was trained to believe that the history of the European in Africa was the only history,'' he said, ''that prior to that it was all darkness.'' **********Only when he started work on his doctorate at the University of London, where he first encountered the works of contemporary historians from West Africa, did Dr. Bhebe seriously start to question this approach. **********He has just finished writing one textbook and is about to start another, but he knows that the rewriting of history is only the start of a shift in historical perspective. All the teachers who have to work with the new texts, blacks as well as whites, were raised on the old ones, he points out, and will thus have to absorb what they now are expected to teach. Turning History on Its Head **********It is a history that dwells on the African kingdoms that rose and fell in the precolonial period in what is now Zimbabwe; particularly the one that flourished in the 14th century at Great Zimbabwe, an impressive set of ruins built of granite blocks, which the white settlers attributed to Phoenicians or Arabs on the racial assumption that the work was too sophisticated to have been done by local blacks. **********In fact, until independence, no textbooks were ever approved for use in schools in this country that mentioned, even as a possibility, the accepted archeological conclusion that the Shonaspeaking groups that are dominant in the present Zimbabwe are the direct descendants of Great Zimbabwe's builders. **********But it is in their interpretation of the colonial period and movements of resistance to white rule that the new texts turn the old history on its head. **********David Livingstone has just a minor walk-on part, and Cecil Rhodes, the empire-builder after whom Rhodesia was named, has become the personification of imperialism rather than the father of his country. The advent of white settlers is no longer presented as part of a tide of benevolence carrying technology, literacy and Christianity. Now issues such as labor exploitation, racial discrimination and the unequal division of the land are stressed. Comparing the Old and the New **********The difference is vividly illustrated by contrasting the treatment of an 1896 Shona uprising against the whites in an old text and the new ones. **********''The Africans were naturally disillusioned at the failure of the rebellion, which they thought had been at the bidding of the ancestral spirits,'' says a book that is now being withdrawn from the schools. So, this old text goes on, the blacks started to turn to Christianity. **********The new texts make heroes of two spirit mediums who inspired what is now called the ''first Chimurenga,'' or rising, and then were executed. ''The spirit of Kaguvi and Nehanda did not die,'' one of them declares. ''It continued to inspire freedom fighters, particularly during the second Chimurenga,'' meaning the independence struggle. **********The competing publishing houses are local subsidiaries of two British companies, Longman and Macmillan, and the recently established Zimbabwe publishing house run by two expatriate journalists, David Martin and Phyllis Johnson, who are co-authors of a study of the independence struggle. **********Mr. Martin and Miss Johnson, who are British and Canadian respectively, have produced with an American co-author the history text for primary students that does the most emphatic job of reinterpreting history in the light of current political values. **********But Zimbabwe does not lack for professional historians. In the Rhodesia of a generation ago, a black man with a history degree could aspire to become a headmaster of a school, which was about as high as a black man could hope to rise. As a result, Dr. Bhebe estimates, there are at least 20 black Zimbabweans with Ph.D. degrees in history, some of them now in high Government posts. **********That helps to explain, perhaps, the scholarly word of caution that can be found in the Ministry of Education's directive on the new history syllabus. ''A rejection of the old approach should not imply a narrowly nationalistic study of history,'' it says, ''as this would be a disservice to scholarship, Zimbabwe and Africa.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/09/busin.main_headline: A.T.&T. IN PACT ON CELLULAR UNITS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/09/busin.print_headline: A.T.&T. IN PACT ON CELLULAR UNITS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/09/busin.body_text: **********The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said today that it had reached joint agreements with 19 other telephone companies to develop cellular radio systems. **********One of the 19 is Cincinnati Bell, in which A.T.& T. holds a minority interest. Of the other 18 independent telephone companies involved, the largest players included the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation, United Telephone System Inc., Continental Telecom Inc. and the Mid-Continent Telephone Corporation. **********The agreements would leave A.T.& .'s cellular unit, Advanced Mobile Phone Service Inc., with a majority position and directly operating 23 of the systems in the nation's 30 largest cities, according to Pic Wagner, an A.T.& T. spokesman. The other seven would be controlled and operated by General Telephone. **********The Federal Communications Commission has allocated sufficient radio frequencies in each city for two cellular systems - a new kind of portable radio telephone service - but specified that one was reserved for application by local telephone companies. That licensing plan has been strongly opposed by other interested companies, which argue they will be locked in lengthy fights with competitors for the second license while the telephone companies corner the market. **********A.T.& T., however, faced the same prospect of lengthy comparative hearings at the commission in more than half of the 30 metropolitan areas for which applications were accepted yesterday. That is because independent telephone companies serve a portion of those metropolitan areas along with a Bell System company, providing the independent company the right to file a cellular application of its own. **********Yesterday, when the F.C.C. accepted the first cellular applications - a total of 193 - the bigger independent telephone companies filed separate applications to protect their interests. Today's announcement means they will withdraw those applications, however, providing clear sailing for their joint ventures with A.T.& T. and what is expected to be rapid F.C.C. approval. **********A.T.& T. declined to provide any details of its joint venture agreements, including the cities where it would control the system, and where the other independents would hold an interest.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/22/busin.main_headline: RATE DROP SENDS DOW UP BY 18.49
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/22/busin.print_headline: RATE DROP SENDS DOW UP BY 18.49
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/22/busin.body_text: **********A late buying surge sparked by falling interest rates sent the stock market ahead in a spirited advance yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 18.49 points, to 934.79, its highest closing in more than a year. Trading was heavy. **********The rally, which came after investor uncertainty had driven down the Dow average in the three previous sessions, was reminiscent of the thundering price gains posted during the second half of August.  Again, pension funds and other institutions were major buyers. **********''Earlier, there had been some concern about the success of today's auction of four-year notes by the Treasury,'' said Margo N.  Alexander, research director of Paine, Webber, Mitchell Hutchins Inc. ''But today's success in this note sale and the resulting strong rally in the bond market served as a signal for stock prices to move ahead.'' Short-Term Rates Drop **********Short-term rates, along with bond yields, showed dramatic declines in the fixed-income market. Three-month Treasury bills were offered to yield 7.35 percent. This represents a drop of 50 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, from the Monday bill auction that fetched an average rate of 7.849 percent. **********The Government's bellwether bond, the 14 percent maturity due in 2011, jumped nearly 3 points, or $30 for each $1,000 face value. It finished at 118 1/8, to yield 11.73 percent, the first time since January 1981 that the bond yielded below 12 percent. **********The Treasury auctioned four-year notes at an average yield of 12.3 percent. Demand for Treasury securities was so strong that by the end of the day this note was offered at a yield of 12.02 percent. Declining Money Fund Rates **********The bond market rally reflects a number of factors, including flight to what investors consider safe, quality issues and declining yields in money market mutual funds. The dropping yields have encouraged many investors to lock in higher rates in Treasury notes and bonds. **********When a price rally in the bond market produces lower yields on fixed-income securities, investors often decide to switch their funds to stocks. **********As the bond rally progressed, the Dow industrial average rose steadily during the afternoon from a level of 4.51 at 1:30 P.M. It was up 8.92 points at 2 P.M. and ahead 12.42 points by 3 P.M., as short-covering activity by traders added momentum to the broad advance. **********Volume expanded to 82.9 million shares from Monday's 58.5 million, the slowest trading in five weeks.  Indicative of the appetite of money managers and other institutional investors for blue-chip stocks, 28 of the 30 issues in the Dow industrials finished with gains. **********Alcoa was unchanged, at 27 3/8, while International Harvester, the only loser, dipped 1/2, to 3 1/2. Two days ago, Harvester fell 7/8 after the farm equipment company said it expected a loss of as high as $1.6 billion this year. **********Elsewhere, International Business Machines rose 2 points, to 76 3/4, its highest price in three years, on heavy volume.  Procter & Gamble sold at its highest price since 1975, climbing 1 3/8, to 99 5/8.  A total of 1,208 issues advanced on the New York Stock Exchange, while only 380 declined in price. As a result, virtually all stock groups finished with gains. **********The number of block trades of 10,000 or more shares, also denoting stepped-up trading by institutions, was 1,401. This was up from 932 big blocks on Monday. **********The Dow industrial average finished at its best level since 936.93 on Aug. 14, 1981. The current rally, one of the strongest sustained recoveries on record, began after the Dow closed at 776.92 on Aug. 12 of this year. **********The market's strongest sectors included energy, technology, transportation, precious metal, brokerage and drug issues. Utility issues also moved higher, inasmuch as they are beneficiaries of falling interest rates. **********Trading at record prices, Crum & Forster ran ahead 4 5/8 points, to 48 5/8, as the volume leader. Yesterday's announcement that Xerox had agreed to acquire the fire-and-casualty insurance company put an end to lingering Wall Street conjecture over the identity of the suitor striking a merger agreement for Crum & Forster. The stock did not trade on Monday, but it soared 17 1/2 points last week amid the swirling takeover talk. **********Xerox tumbled 3 1/8, to 31 1/2. Analysts said that in a takeover of this type arbitragers typically bought shares of the target company while they selling short the stock of the acquiring company. **********The American Stock Exchange's market-value index moved ahead 5.68, to 293.76. BDM International rose 2 1/4, to 29 1/2. This company, which performs technical services for the Government, was added Friday to Merrill's emerging growth list. **********In over-the-counter trading, Tony Lama rose 3 7/8, to 24 3/8, after the Triton Group agreed to acquire the boot manufacturer for $35 a share. The Nasdaq composite index gained 1.91, to 187.91.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/06/world.body_text: **********While they discuss world issues this weekend, the seven heads of government meeting here are also trying to keep track of whatever is going on back in their home capitals. **********But only one of them has a war.  Wherever Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher goes, the war in the Falkland Islands follows her. ''Just as it is her daily - indeed hourly - concern in Downing Street, so it must be here,'' an aide explained. **********It is also a central concern of the people with whom she is meeting, even though they ostensibly came here to discuss economic affairs. Last night at the opening dinner, for example, Mrs.  Thatcher, President Reagan and the others talked of little else but the Falklands. As a spokesman for another delegation explained: **********''When you sit down to dinner in a group that includes someone who is waging a war, it's a bit hard to ignore it.'' Mrs. Thatcher is not actually conducting the war, of course. In fact, the British say that all the political decisions have been made for the moment, and that - barring a sudden Argentine agreement to withdraw - the decision on when to move troops into Stanley, the capital, is in the hands of the military commanders on the scene. **********But still, Mrs. Thatcher must keep in touch. Just hours before leaving London on Friday, she conducted a meeting of her inner war Cabinet for a final review of the military situation in the South Atlantic. Clearly there was an understanding in the minds of everybody at that meeting that by the time she returns to London, the final, bloodiest battle of the war might very well be under way. **********The telephone in Mrs. Thatcher's suite in the ornate Grand Trianon Palace here in Versailles is said to be secure, so that she can keep in touch with Defense Secretary John Nott and other senior officials in London. But the British conceded that for a really important conversation, Mrs. Thatcher might well feel more comfortable using the secure line at the British Embassy in Paris. **********The Grand Trianon, where Prime Minister Thatcher, President Reagan and the other heads of government each have a suite, was built 300 years ago to be the private estate of Louis XIV, the legendary Sun King. **********Louis named the palace after the hamlet of Trianon, which was on this spot in the Middle Ages. He bought the land to enlarge his estate in 1670 and first built onto it a white and blue earthernware pavilion named ''Trianon de Porcelaine,'' which he surrounded with pleasant gardens. That pavilion, though lovely and delicate, was too fragile, and it was replaced later in the 17th century with the current sumptuous marble palace. **********To insure the privacy of the king and his family, courtiers were not permitted to enter the Grand Trianon. It is an appropriate heritage for the building that this weekend must be one of the most closely guarded overnight hostelries in Western Europe, with even antiaircraft guns installed on the grounds to protect President Francois Mitterrand's high-powered guests. **********Like the other leaders, who arrived in an elaborate procession of helicopters Friday afternoon, President Reagan has been staying in the Grand Trianon since Friday night. But his wife, Nancy, stayed an extra night in the American Ambassador's residence in Paris, moving into the Trianon only tonight. **********The youngest of the Reagans' neighbors this weekend in the Grand Trianon is Michel Trudeau, the 6-year-old son of Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada. **********Prime Minister Trudeau and his wife, Margaret, are separated, although she lives only a few blocks from the Prime Minister's residence in Ottawa. Michel and their two other children, who are 8 and 10, live with the Prime Minister. **********The three boys take turns accompanying their father on his various official trips around the world. Although no one in Versailles has solicited Michel's views on macroeconomics, he has been much in evidence at the ceremonial occasions of this conference, shaking hands gravely on Friday with President Mitterrand, and reacting to the soldiers and the helicopters and the bands with the awe that you might expect of a 6-year-old. **********But his eldest brother, Sacha, has become rather more worldly over the years. Accompanying his father on a Middle Eastern trip not long ago, Sacha wandered into the press section of the airplane, climbed up into the chair that the Prime Minister usually occupies, and asked the traveling Canadian correspondents: **********''Why don't you guys like my dad?'' **********Although the discussions at the Versailles conference have a good deal of substance - important issues such as East-West trade and what to do about foreign exchange rates - much of it is show, staged for still photographs and television. And the French have planned it carefully. **********''19:15 - the heads of delegations stroll through the park,'' the official schedule declares, and stroll they did. ''9:05 - arrival of President Mitterrand at the marble staircase.'' And so forth. **********But sometimes the unscheduled does happen. Today, for example, as the leaders gathered for lunch, an American press pool reporter who was ostensibly there just to observe the colorful occasion began asking questions, as reporters will do. **********President Reagan answered three questions about the vote on the Falklands Friday night in the United Nations Security Council, and then the reporter turned to Prime Minister Thatcher, who was seated on the President's right. Were the British angry, she was asked, about what appeared to be a weakening of the American support for Britain. The Prime Minister's icy reply, in its entirety: ''I don't do interviews at lunch time.''

The plan provides for a public guarantee on the loans, to be used to restructure the company before the end of 1983.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/25/busin.body_text: **********RESIDENTS here remember Sept. 29, 1980, as the most bitter of all days. At 9 A.M., the Atlantic Richfield Company held simultaneous meetings in Los Angeles, Washington and Helena, the state capital of Montana, to announce the permanent closing of the 75-year-old Anaconda copper smelter. The smelter's 1,000 employees, who were at home awaiting the end of a nationwide copper strike, heard the news over the radio. **********The next day, nearly 25 percent of the town's work force was out of a job, and Anaconda had lost the employer who for decades had maintained its parks, built its medical centers, treated its sewage and hauled in fertile black dirt so that residents could grow grass in yards that had been ruined by the smelter's fumes. **********''They cut off our primary reason for existence,'' said William N.  Callaghan, an optometrist in Anaconda, whose patients are now approaching him with great embarrassment about stretching out payments for their medical bills. ''We have been biting the bullet ever since.'' **********The closing of the smelter has, indeed, been a terrible blow for Anaconda and its residents, but they are by no means alone. The company town that loses its company has become an increasingly common experience - in many ways a reflection of the country's eroding industrial base - and is forcing executives to face a difficult question: What does a corporation owe a community that it created or the people who depended on that town for a livelihood? **********The issue of corporate responsibility has become critical now because, unlike the 1960's, when the economy was growing, employees who lose their jobs are less likely to find work in the plant next door. **********''The number of long-term layoffs and permanent plant closings increased dramatically during the 1970's, and it is catastrophic right now because it is much harder for the laid-off blue-collar worker to find other employment,'' said Bennett Harrison, a political economy professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. **********THOUGH corporate America seems more conscious of the need to assist those thrown out of work by plant closings, most employees - from the smelter workers in Anaconda to the steel workers in Youngstown, Ohio, where United States Steel closed three plants, some after as many as 75 years of operation - have been dissatisfied with the response of their employers. **********''In most cases, the treatment by management is very poor by comparison with companies in Europe, where there is usually a requirement to give six months' notice and a severance pay agreement,'' said Barry Bluestone, an economics professor at Boston College, who, along with Mr. Harrison, wrote a book entitled ''The Deindustrialization of America.'' ''In this country, there are no limitations on notifications and no requirements for severance pay except when a union has negotiated it.'' **********But Arco, which took over the smelter when it acquired the Anaconda Copper Company in 1977, insists that it has treated its workers justly, giving them far more help than required by union contracts.  ''In our view we put people in pretty good shape with almost a year of not having to work at all,'' said Ralph Cox, an executive vice president at Arco. **********But many government officials and social scientists would not agree that Arco, one of the nation's largest oil companies, did all it could for its workers. In fact, the manner in which many American companies have closed plants has so angered local officials that they have decided that, without legislated standards, corporations will do only what is required by union contracts or nothing at all. **********''No one helps voluntarily,'' said James Tierney, the Attorney General of Maine, one of the few states that has so-called plant closure legislation. The Maine law, passed in 1977 after several bad experiences with companies that left without helping their employees, requires employers of 100 or more workers to pay a week of severance pay for each year that an employee has worked. More than 15 states are considering some form of plant closure legislation, and in Montana a bill is expected to reach the state legislature this year. **********But if a plant closing is traumatic for workers and their towns, it can also be wrenching for the companies, which often react to crises in confusing and inconsistent ways and frequently take steps that are harmful to corporation and individual alike. **********''Under conditions of great personal stress, you don't imagine that a person will maintain his usual composure and in a crisis, a company will also do strange things,'' said Harvey Brenner, a professor of operations research and behavioral sciences at Johns Hopkins University. **********The residents of Anaconda cannot complain that they were left high and dry - Arco gave some financial help to both employees and the city - but they can question the effectiveness of the financial help and whether it was suited to the problems the community faced or just an effort to cover over an unfortunate occurrence. **********ARCO untangled itself from Anaconda in what might be called typical business fashion. The Anaconda smelter, which stands at the town's entrance like a concrete sentry, processed copper that Anaconda produced from the Berkeley open pit copper mine, about 27 miles from Anaconda in Butte. Facing a difficult copper market, Arco decided to close the smelter after finding that it would cost more than $400 million to bring it up to national and state clean air standards.  Arco believed that Anaconda's copper concentrates could be processed more cheaply in Japan, where there is less concern over environmental issues and refining operations are more efficient. **********Essentially, Arco's solution was to buy a year's time for each of its employees. Together with the $3,500 severance checks, weekly supplemental unemployment that ranged from $100 to $140 for a year, medical coverage for a year and state unemployment benefits, employees took home about what they had been earning. The town of Anaconda received $3 million - at that time equal to three-quarters of its annual tax receipts -for a fund for redevelopment and 57 acres for an industrial park. A team of personnel specialists also helped find jobs for some employees within the company or in other mining companies, according to Arco. Few workers, however, successfully founds jobs through this service. **********By most accounts from state and local officials, the help did not make much difference. Nearly two years later, the development fund has created about 30 jobs. A plastics company that got a $900,000 development loan fund has filed for bankruptcy and 14 other businesses have failed. The unemployment rate is 13.7 percent and the City Manager, Daniel Worsdell, claims that it is nearer 18 percent. The population has shrunk from 12,500 to 10,500, and by the end of the year the town's tax receipts will have decreased by one-third, to $3 million. **********''There certainly could have been a better transition,'' said Mr.  Worsdell. ''I think Arco believes that the $3 million would pacify us, but we knew from the beginning that it would not be enough.'' **********''I would say that Arco was very arrogant in their dealings with not only the state but the local people,'' said Timothy Gallegher, an aide to Governor Ted Schwinden. ''We didn't have any bargaining power. They could do as they pleased. They were sympathetic, but they were unable to strike that nerve that runs from the brain to the pocketbook.'' **********In fact, Arco felt it was giving more than adequate help. Under the union contract, the company was only required to give supplementary unemployment that ranged from $50 to $90 a week for a year and free medical coverage for one month. **********When asked what sort of methodology the company used, Arco's Mr.  Cox explained the company strategy. ''We have closed down a large number of operations and we look at each case individually. Where there is a lot of additional mining in the area, then I think the need for some additional help is a lot less or even minimal compared to the other end of the spectrum,'' such as Anaconda, ''where the local community is solely dependent on the local operation.'' **********MANY at Anaconda believe that what went wrong started with the timing of the closure announcement. In hindsight, local officials believe that retraining and job relocation would have been more helpful than a lump sum of money that employees spent as if they were still working. **********Arco's Mr. Cox says that as early as 1977 company officials started to warn the union that environmental laws had put the smelter's future in jeopardy. He acknowledged, however, that the company sent some mixed signals. As late as the fall of 1980, for example, Arco told the union that the closing of the smelter was one of several options that included building an entirely new smelter. **********''One mistake that we made,'' Mr. Cox added, ''is that during that time, we paved the parking lot and built a new medical center. I have since learned that these developments sent the signal to the community that we would be staying open.'' **********It is clear, however, that no warning would have been sufficient to prepare the community for the smelter's closing. ''The people here absolutely did not accept the fact that the plant was closed,'' said Eudora Fald, the county welfare director. ''Even after a year, people would believe that the plant was going to reopen and the actual impact of the plant closure has really come in January when all the benefits ran out.'' **********Social economists who have studied the cycles that follow a plant closing say that this is not uncommon. One of the most important things that an employer can do is to help its employees begin looking for new jobs, they say. Such aid helps convince the employees that they will not be needed in their present jobs and forces them to look ahead. **********''The research we have developed over the last 25 years indicates that in regard to a worker's mental and physical health, intervention has to come before he really loses his job,'' said Louis Ferman, a professor in the School of Social Work at the University of Michigan. ''Most companies only become engaged after the plant is shut down and for the most part, the community effort lasts only six weeks.'' **********Some companies - Warner Lambert, for example - have become involved before a plant closing and have found that such an approach actually saves the company money because it does away with the need for supplementary unemployment and medical benefits. **********As for Arco, Mr. Cox said that copper market pressures did not give the company time to give advance notice. The company feared that other smelters would soon be closed, and that if Arco slowly phased out its Anaconda operations it might not be able to contract refining capacity when the plant was fully shut. ''We didn't feel that we had the luxury to take two years,'' Mr. Cox said. '' **********In Anaconda, there is the feeling that the help Arco gave the city was in no way commensurate with the years of service that the city had given to the company. In addition to the recession, prospective investors were faced with a city that would have to spend heavily to maintain services that Anaconda had provided in the past. **********''I thought we would have a hell of a lot more money from Arco,'' said Kevin McNelis, director of the Anaconda Task Force. The city has only $100,000 left from the $3 million redevelopment fund, and still has to pay for a new sewage plant that will cost $3.3 million. The town hopes to get $2.5 million from a Federal grant but will still be short $800,000. **********What will eventually happen to Anaconda is unclear. Other old mining towns have been able to survive as tourist attractions. If it is a portent, the best-looking office in Anaconda is the one that offers a trolley tour of the town's mining operations. **********Arco has not closed the door on additional help, but the company has made it clear that it will not simply offer money at any request. ''Our continued response has been that anyone who has a specific need should outline that in detail and discuss it with local employees,'' said Mr. Cox. ''So far nothing has come along that we felt was significant enough.'' BUTTE'S BLACK HOLE **********She's battered, and she's beaten, She's ugly and she's torn, She's battle-scarred and gutted, From the copper she has borne. **********Still she is majestic, As she sits upon her throne, A mile high and beautiful, To those who call her home.  George T. Grose, 1957 **********BUTTE, Mont.  Dog-eared and scruffy, the city of Butte, once a bustling mining town that supplied Anaconda's smelter with copper ore, has not had much luck lately. Since January 1980, more than 1,000 copper miners have been laid off, and, in April, the Atlantic Richfield Company temporarily closed its operations at the main Berkeley pit, a hole 2,200 feet deep and a mile and a half wide that looks more like the eighth wonder of the world than a depleted copper mine. **********The miners in Butte are not quibbling about the amount of benefits that Arco gave them when the Berkeley pit was shut - they received none because Arco considers it a temporary shutdown. There are about 800 miners still working in the East Berkeley pit, which is about a half-mile away from the main mine. **********''We got nothing,'' said John Connors, president of the local Steel Workers Union, which represents the miners. Mr. Connors and others question Arco's definition of a temporary closing. They believe that since Arco has taken steps that will ultimately allow the Berkeley pit to fill with water, the cost of pumping the water out will make it a long time before the mine is reopened. **********Arco acknowledges that the cost would be steep, but said that it has done it before in other underground operations. ''We don't feel that we have closed it, just shifted our people to the other end,'' said Ralph Cox, an executive vice president of Arco. ''We look at this as an efficiency move, not a closure. I am well aware that the people in Butte feel that we need to do something for them.'' **********Residents of Butte are fairly resigned to the idea that Arco and Anaconda will someday leave town altogether. In the company's heyday at the turn of the century, 12,000 miners worked for Anaconda and the town's population swelled to more than 80,000. Since then it has slowly declined to 35,000. Robert Stodden, who grew up in Butte and returned recently on vacation, said that when he entered the city, ''It was like seeing someone I had known all my life die in front of my eyes.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/10/busin.body_text: **********Anheuser-Busch, the country's largest brewery, has given up hope of a settlement of the football strike, according to Thomas Sharbaugh, group marketing manager and a panelist today at the Association of National Advertisers meeting here at the Breakers Hotel. **********He made his remark as a session on commercials for cable TV broke up. He was asked if the maker of Budweiser and other brews is transferring some of the big bundle of dollars committed to National Football League telecasts to cable, where the company has been an early and active participant. **********But he would only say that there ''is clearly a possibility'' that cable will get some of the money. Very little of the money from football so far has gone into cable. **********But from what Mr. Sharbaugh was saying about cable and the cable commercials he showed, it would seem more probable than possible.  Few advertisers, and certainly no other brewer, know more about the cable medium than Anheuser-Busch. **********In its quest of the 18- to 49-year-old male, especially the drinker of two six-packs a week and more, the Bud boys have long been on the ESPN and USA cable networks and the superstations. It also uses cable to zero in on black consumers on Black Entertainment Television and to reach the 18- to 24-year-olds who watch Music Television Network.  The young people are not only forming brand loyalties but are heavy consumers. **********Music Television provides an audience of young rock fans, an elusive population segment since they are light readers and equally light television viewers. **********And as Anheuser does with most of its promotions, it tailors its advertising to the rockers.  ''The beauty of MTV,'' Mr. Sharbaugh said after showing a far-out example of its commercials, ''is that there's nobody tuned in that doesn't understand it.'' **********Nodding in agreement was a fellow panelist, James R. Blocki, vice president and director of advertising and creative services of Kraft's Retail Food Group. His company, producers for generations of those wholesome Ed Herlihy food-filled spots, has done a couple of avant-garde ads for the MTV set. **********The Anheuser-Busch and Kraft representatives showed the most polished creative work of the four panelists on ''Cable Commercial Showcase.'' The other speakers were Robert (Buck) Buchanan, executive vice president and domestic media director of J. Walter Thompson, and Malcolm D. Gray, director of advertising services of Scott Paper. **********Mr. Buchanan, as a matter of fact, was proud of the low cost of making the commercials he showed - 12 minutes for some $60,000. But his spots were not for the larger audiences available on cable networks, but rather for Thompson's own experimental system in Massachusetts, the Cable Shop, or for the Westminster Kennel Club show that marked the first electronic advertising for Ken-L-Ration Biskits. **********Robert Alter, president of the Cable Advertising Bureau, indicated that the bureau has a library of commercials made for cable and is happy to make them available to advertisers and agencies. **********The cable panel was one of four concurrent sessions that kept people out of the newly arrived hot sun. Another was on the provocative subject of greater advertising productivity. The six-man panel was composed of two teams, each made up of a consultant, an agency man and a client. Dart & Kraft and Richardson-Vicks were the clients. **********Vicks and its agency, Benton & Bowles, using a system devised by Thomas K. Myers, a consultant, studied the productivity of the people working on the Clearasil account. Here, according to Roy J. Bostock, executive vice president of the agency, are the four main problem areas, which probably can be found throughout adland: **********- Too much time was spent collecting competitive data - 20 percent of the product manager's time and 40 percent of the account executive's -mainly because of ''organizational inertia.'' **********- Too many media plan revisions were required ''in an overzealous drive'' by the agency ''for perfection every time a budget number changed.'' **********- ''An arduous, almost tortuous legal aproval process at Richardson-Vicks for copy.'' This ''bottom-up'' study also found that too few key decision makers attended the meetings they needed to attend. You know how they are.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/20/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; N.A.B. Campaign Focuses on Productivity
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/20/busin.body_text: **********The Japanese will be the role models in a new public service advertising campaign aimed at increasing productivity of American workers. The campaign, being sponsored by the National Association of Broadcasters and scheduled to begin running on Christmas Day, was prepared by Trout & Ries. **********Howard K. Smith, the former ABC-News anchorman, will serve as spokesman in the 30- and 60-second TV and radio commercials.  Through research, the agency has pinpointed the nation's productivity problem areas as ineffective management; adversarial relationships among management, labor and Government, and functional illiteracy. **********In one spot, Mr. Smith compares the size and resources of the United States and Japan and notes that Japan has been ''out-competing us.'' **********''Why?,'' he asks. ''What is the secret of Japan's success? One reason is the way they work together. If we've one thing to learn from the Japanese, it's the importance of working as a team. And as any coach will tell you, a team will beat a group of individual players. No matter how skilled. We too must learn to work as a team.  Government, management and employees have to pull together if we're to stay compeatitive.'' **********He ends up with, ''Let's work together'' after promising future commercials that will give examples of teamwork in action.  Never in the 50-year history of the N.A.B. has it involved itself in a public service campaign. This one is the result of a lobbying effort begun two years ago by Jerry Lee, president of WEAZ-FM, Philadelphia, and a member of the N.A.B. board. **********Can advertising help the situation? In 1973, the Advertising Council introduced a public service effort done by McCann-Erickson for the National Commission on Productivity. That effort suggested that workers think of their output as being ''signed works,'' and produce accordingly. The theme was ''America. It only works as well as we do.'' But if the program improved things, it really hasn't been noticeable. **********The Ad Council is going to try it again in the coming year, this time for the American Productivity Center with advertising by Compton Communications. If at first you don't succeed ...

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/12/world.main_headline: REAGAN PLEDGES AN EFFORT TO IMPROVE TIES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/12/world.print_headline: BREZHNEV DEAD AT 75, NO SUCCESSOR NAMED; REAGAN PLEDGES AN EFFORT TO IMPROVE TIES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/12/world.body_text: **********Leonid I. Brezhnev, who died suddenly on Wednesday at the age of 75, will be buried in Red Square, the Soviet leadership announced today. A four-day mourning period was declared, indicating that the funeral would be Monday. **********Although the exact cause of Mr. Brezhnev's death was not announced, it Message to Soviet people, page A12. was revealed for the first time that he had suffered from chronic heart and circulatory ailments. **********Official bulletins made public at intervals throughout the day suggested that the Kremlin was preparing for the largest funeral Moscow has seen since Stalin's death in 1953. No Word Yet on a Successor **********There was no announcement of any decision on a successor to Mr.  Brezhnev, who had held the post of general secretary of the Communist Party's Central Committee for 18 years, a term exceeded only by Stalin. His death also opens up the less important post of President of the Soviet Union, a position he had held since 1977. **********In an announcement, the leadership warned of a ''crushing retaliatory strike'' against any attempts by ''aggressors'' who might wish to take advantage of the loss. The statement said the Soviet Union would continue to try to eliminate the threat of nuclear war and insure detente and disarmament. **********Speculation on a new party leader focused on two of the 11 remaining full members of the Politburo, the Central Committee's inner cabinet. Andropov Heads Funeral Group **********One, Yuri V. Andropov, 68 years old, is a party bureaucrat and former head of the K.G.B, the internal security and intelligence agency, a post he vacated only six months ago to return to the party hierarchy. The other potential candidate, Konstantin U. Chernenko, 71, is also a career party official who was Mr. Brezhnev's chief of staff for more than two decades. **********Some Western diplomats believed that the leadership had given a hint of its choice with the announcement that Mr. Andropov would be the chairman of the funeral commission, a 25-member body that will oversee arrangements. The diplomats recalled that the chairman of the commission for Stalin's funeral in 1953 was Nikita S. Khrushchev, who later emerged as the party leader. **********Mr. Chernenko was made one of the members of the funeral commission, in a listing that placed the eight Politburo members who live in Moscow in alphabetical order after Mr. Andropov. Also on the commission is Viktor V. Grishin, 68, the Moscow city party leader, considered a possible compromise choice if neither Mr. Andropov nor Mr. Chernenko can gain a majority in the Politburo. The Politburo has the effective power to make the selection, which must be ratified by the Central Committee, a body of some 300 members. **********Other Politburo members on the commission who might have an outside chance at the top job are Mikhail S. Gorbachev, a 51-year-old agricultural expert; Andrei A. Gromyko, 73, the Foreign Minister; Arvid Y. Pelshe, 83; Nikolai A. Tikhonov, 77, the Prime Minister, and Marshal Dmitri F. Ustinov, 74, the Defense Minister. **********News of Mr. Brezhnev's death came at 11 A.M. in a two-paragraph announcement read on radio and television. The announcement followed 14 hours of uncertainty prompted by a sudden change of broadcast programming on Wednesday evening. The national television channel canceled a Police Day program for an early Bolshevik film, and radio stations dropped popular programs for broadcasts of serious music. Flags Not Immediately Lowered **********Although the announcement said that Mr. Brezhnev had died a ''sudden death'' at 8:30 A.M. on Wednesday, there was little in the 24 hours before the announcement to indicate that it was he who had died. Flags atop the Kremlin were not immediately lowered to halfstaff, and no unusual activity was visible in the Kremlin or at party headquarters. **********But several hours before the announcement, the official press agency, Tass, distributed the text of a message of greetings to Angola on its national day. The message, signed in previous years by Mr. Brezhnev, was sent in the name of the Central Committee. **********There had been speculation that the unusual goings-on heralded the death of Andrei P. Kirilenko, 76, who has been in ill health and whose resignation from the Politburo has been reported informally by Soviet officials, but the message to Angola suggested that it was Mr. Brezhnev himself who was dead. **********Eight hours after the announcement of Mr. Brezhnev's death, Tass made public a summary of the findings of the medical team.  It said that Mr. Brezhnev had ''suffered from arteriosclerosis of the aorta with the development of an aneurysm in its abdominal portion, constricting arteriosclerosis of coronary arteries, ischemic heart disease with heart rhythm trouble, cicatricial changes of the myocardium after infarctions.'' **********One Soviet source with high-level contacts said Mr. Brezhnev had collapsed at his dacha outside Moscow. The source said the delay in announcing the death arose from efforts to revive him after he had been taken to the Kremlin clinic on Granovsky Street. **********Within hours of the announcement, red flags with black ribbons went up on buildings and lampposts. Workers began repainting the green exterior of the neo-classical House of Unions, where Mr. Brezhnev will lie in state. **********All sporting events have been canceled through Monday, when the mourning period ends. Schools will be closed on the day of the funeral and artillery salvoes are to be fired here and in other major cities. **********Work is also to be halted for five minutes during the burial, except in industries, such as electric power plants and steel furnaces, where continuous operation is required. Salutes are to be given for three minutes by the whistles of factories, trains and ships. Burial Site Is Unspecified **********The bulletin announcing the formation of the funeral commission did not say where in Red Square Mr. Brezhnev was to be buried. Most prominent personalities who have been honored with a Red Square burial have their ashes immured in niches in the Kremlin wall. A few leaders, including Stalin, lie in a row of graves behind the Lenin Mausoleum. This will probably also be Mr. Brezhnev's burial place. **********A Russian with Central Committee contacts said the choice of successor as the party leader would almost certainly be made by the Politburo, but that, if a deadlock developed, the issue could be thrown to the Central Committee. As it happened, the Central Committee was expected to meet on Monday for a previously scheduled session, and it was thought that it could be used to decide on a new leader or ratify a choice already made. **********As for the other job vacated by Mr. Brezhnev's death, that of the nation's President, it is normally filled by the Supreme Soviet, the nominal Parliament, which, as it happens, was also scheduled to convene next week, on Tuesday, to ratify the budget and economic plan for next year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/25/world.body_text: **********The United States Ambassador to Mexico, John Gavin, said today that he did not share the ''dire expectations'' of some Mexicans about the repercussions in Mexico of adoption of a comprehensive immigration bill ending in Congress. **********In letters to the sponsors of the bill, Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, and Representative Romano L. Mazzoli, a Kentucky Democrat, Mr. Gavin also noted that an embassy report quoted by The New York Times last Sunday sought only to reflect the opinions of key Mexicans. **********''I think it important, as I know you do, that their voices be heard,'' he said. **********But he argued that the report overlooked that the unclassified embassy report had been prepared by two summer interns after many interviews with influential Mexicans and instead ''would have the reader infer that it is based on a recent 'dispatch' from me.'' **********The 17-page report reflected the views of many Mexican officials, academic figures and businessmen that adoption of the bill by Congress next month would harm United States-Mexican relations and ''would foster political unrest with potentially explosive consequences.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/26/busin.main_headline: CHANGES AT A.T.& T. VIEWED BY EX-CHIEF
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/26/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; CHANGES AT A.T.& T. VIEWED BY EX-CHIEF
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/26/busin.body_text: **********From the moment that the Justice Department filed its antitrust suit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Corporation in 1974 until he retired in 1979 at the age of 63 as chairman and chief executive officer, John D. deButts was vehemently opposed to any settlement. He said that A.T.& T. would fight the suit ''to the end,'' and he declared that ''we are going to come out of this action in one piece.'' **********So how does he feel about A.T.& T.'s decision to divest itself of its 22 operating companies in a settlement that would allow the company a free hand to do business in previously prohibited areas, but leave it without its traditional local telephone service? Would Mr. deButts have done the same thing had he still been the A.T.& T.  boss? **********''It's hard for me to say, but probably yes,'' he replied, when interviewed by telephone at his 87-acre farm in Upperville, Va. ''The future of A.T.& T will be better than it was under the uncertain conditions that we were faced with.'' **********Mr. deButts went on to tell why he had battled so hard against divestiture during his chairmanship. ''We charged more for services, if you will, that are not essential, like color telephones and Princess phones, and more for long distance than the cost,'' he said.  ''The extra money was used to defray the cost of local service and everybody tho ught this was a good idea,'' Mr. deButts said. ''What the people wh o were talking about divestiture were doing was transferring the cost of paying for service from the optional to the basic custome r. That's the reason I was opposed to it.'' **********By ''optional,'' Mr. deButts referred to users of long-distance service, rather than local, or ''basic,'' service.  Mr. deButts observed that he now supports the settlement because ''of all the things that Charlie Brown said in his statement'' when the antitrust agreement was announced on Jan. 8. He referred to remarks by his successor, Charles L. Brown. With the possibility of long-term uncertainty, court suits and Congressional and Federal Communications Commission actions, Mr. deButts said: ''I'm sure what he did was right. I'm sure you'll find that Charlie Brown didn't want to break up the Bell System either.'' **********But what about the higher rates for local telephone service that many people say will result from the divestiture?  ''I don't know,'' Mr. deButts said, ''but my hunch is that local rates are going to go up.'' Mr. deButts is a tall, husky Southerner who started his Bell career in 1936 as a traffic trainee. During his career, he worked for a number of operating companies as well as the parent, and once headed the Illinois Bell Telephone Company, a post that has been a stepping stone to the top position at A.T.& T for more than one chief executive. Before becoming chief executive in 1972, he spent five years as A.T.& T.'s vice chairman. During most of his career, the telephone business dominated A.T.& T. thinking, but in the early 1970's Mr. deButts did launch some of the activities that got the Bell System started in new areas of telecommunications that it will now be allowed to exploit. **********And what does Mr. deButts - who resigned as a director of A.T.& T.  last year - think about being on the outside as his company enters the uncharted waters of unregulated businesses. ''I'm very happy and proud of the guys I left in charge of the business,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/28/busin.body_text: **********The Beverly Hills Savings and Loan Association announced yesterday the re-election of its five-member board of directors at its annual shareholders meeting. In early May, the association filed suit charging Severyn Ashkenazy, a Beverly Hills hotel owner, and a group of associates with illegally conspiring to acquire control of Beverly Hills Savings by acquiring its capital stock. The group is also the target of a similar suit by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/12/busin.body_text: **********Chrysler Canada Ltd. is near agreement with the Canadian Government on financial aid needed to begin production of a new, turbocharged diesel engine at an idle plant in Windsor, Ontario, the company said today. **********''We're very close to one,'' said Walt McCall, a spokesman. **********''But there's a lot of paperwork involved. I don't think we have one on paper yet.'' **********However, the auto maker scheduled a news conference for Thursday to explain details of any agreement that is reached, he said.  An agreement could mean about 1,000 jobs for hourly workers at the Windsor plant, which has been closed for two years, Mr. McCall said.  Some 1,200 auto workers lost their jobs when the plant was closed because of reduced demand for the big, eight-cylinder engines that were produced there, he said.
