https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/24/busin.body_text: **********Bond prices rose about half a point and short-term interest rates fell slightly in quiet trading yesterday. Dealers in Treasury securities - the most active sector of the credit markets in recent days - closed at 2.30 P.M. and will be closed today. **********The Treasury completed a week of heavy financing with a $7 billion auction of one-year bills at an average rate of 8.095 percent, down from 8.372 percent at a similar sale four weeks ago. It was the lowest rate for one-year bills since July 1980. **********Based on results of the bill sale, the new rate for one-year taxexempt savings deposits known as ''All Savers'' certificates will be set at 6.26 percent beginning Sunday, down from 6.49 percent currently. **********Although investor demand for Treasury issues was modest yesterday, analysts said the firm tone of the market was a sign that many market participants are willing to buy securities now in anticipation of stronger investor demand early next year. **********All of the new Treasury note and bond issues sold in the last two weeks were offered late yesterday at prices equal to or higher than the average at the auction. The 9 3/8 percent notes due in two years were offered at 99 27/32 to yield 9.47 percent compared with slightly less than 99 27/32 at auction, and the 10 percent notes due in four years were offered at 99 30/32 to yield 10.02 percent compared with less than 99 22/32 at auction. Longer-Term Issues **********Among longer-term issues, the 10 1/2 percent notes due in seven years were offered yesterday at 100 3/8 to yield about 10.43 percent compared with 99 19/32 at Tuesday's auction. The 10 3/4 percent bonds due in 20 years were offered at 100 1/2 to yield about 10.68 percent, compared with 99 30/32 at Thursday's auction. **********Besides a revival of demand in January from investors who have been absent in the last few weeks, some analysts said that the general level of interest rates would decline as the Federal Reserve continued to make credit more available to the banking system. **********The latest banking data published by the Fed showed that in the week ended Wednesday banks borrowed an average of $320 million from the discount window at Federal Reserve banks, down from $490 million a week earlier. While some banks resorted to borrowing from the Fed, others held an average of $274 million of excess reserves, down from $593 million a week earlier. Bank Reserve Position **********Subtracting the borrowings from the excess reserves shows that the banking system was in a net borrowed reserve position of $46 million, in the week ended Wednesday compared with a net free reserve position of $103 million in the previous week. Because the Federal Reserve does not precisely control changes in bank reserves, analysts said the latest data showed that the Fed was continuing to supply about as much reserves as banks are required to hold, a policy it has been following since July. **********Some analysts said the improvement in prices yesterday was related to the Senate's approval of the 5-cent increase in the Federal tax on gasoline. While the tax increase will reduce the budget deficit only slightly, it was said to be significant because it showed a willingness to increase taxes that might be more broad when Congress reconvenes next year. **********Although the Government will be borrowing record amounts of cash in coming quarters, there will be a hiatus in January, when the only auctions will be for one-year bills, two-year notes, and the regular weekly sales of three- and six-month bills. **********Following are results of yesterday's auction of new one-year Treasury bills:

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/11/busin.main_headline: Ford Appoints Leader For International Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/11/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Ford Appoints Leader For International Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/11/busin.body_text: **********While the Ford Motor Company may be suffering with the rest of the automobile industry at home, it is profitable overseas. Yesterday, Ford directors named a new head of the company's international operations. **********Robert A. Lutz, 50 years old, currently chairman of Ford Europe, was chosen to succeed John McDougall as executive vice president of the International Automotive Operations when Mr. McDougall, 65, retires Aug. 1. **********Before joining Ford, Mr. Lutz was a vice president and member of the board of BMW, the West German auto maker. He is a native of Zurich and holds degrees from the University of California at Berkeley. Mr. Lutz joined Ford of Germany in 1974. He became president of Ford of Europe in 1977 and chairman two years later. **********Ford's international division does half of the company's business and its importance is acknowledged within the company. International service has often been a stepping stone to top corporate management. **********As Walter Hayes, Ford's vice president, public affairs, noted, Philip Caldwell hired Mr. Lutz from BMW when Mr. Caldwell was head of Ford of Europe. Now that Mr. Caldwell is Ford chairman he has brought Mr. Lutz to the United States. The promotion ''puts Mr. Lutz among the senior management,'' Mr. Hayes said. **********Mr. Lutz is the son of a Swiss banker and an American mother. He served as a Marine jet pilot the Korean War.  Mr. McDougall has been with Ford for 47 years and has been head of international operations since 1980. Previously, he served as vice president of operations for Ford's North American division and as president of Ford of Europe. **********Several other promotions among Ford executives overseas were reported. Edward J. Blanch will become chairman of Ford of Europe and will be succeeded as president of the division by James A.  Capolongo, currently manager of truck operations for Ford's North American division. **********Mr. Capolongo's current job will be taken by Edson P. Williams, who is president of Ford's Asia Pacific division. Sir Brian Inglis of Australia will be acting president of that division. **********In domestic appointments, the board named Herbert L. Misch as vice president of engineering and research, succeeding Harold C.  Mac-Donald, who is retiring. Daniel F. Cuff

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/11/busin.body_text: **********Florida's House of Representatives today defeated a bill that would have made it illegal for an out-of-state banking company to own more than 25 percent of a Florida bank's stock. **********The vote was 54 to 49. **********This clears the way for the Chemical New York Corporation, owner of the Chemical Bank, to continue its campaign to acquire Florida National Banks of Florida Inc. if interstate banking is approved by the Federal Government. **********Chemical and the Southeast Banking Corporation, Florida's largest banking group, have been fighting over Florida National, ranked No.4 in the state, for almost a year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/05/world.main_headline: SOME ARAB LANDS WARMING TO EGYPT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/05/world.print_headline: SOME ARAB LANDS WARMING TO EGYPT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/05/world.body_text: **********A leading Egyptian Foreign Ministry official said today that there had been encouraging signs in the Arab world about resuming diplomatic relations with Egypt but that he did not feel that the restoration of ties was imminent. **********Osama el-Baz, a Foreign Ministry under secretary and a close aide to President Hosni Mubarak, told a news conference that Egypt was eager to resume the stalled talks with Israel on Palestinian autonomy but that a recent surge in the creation of Israeli settlements in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip was an ''impediment'' to the continuation of the peace process. **********Dr. Baz, noting some kinds words about Egypt in the Arab press since the final return of the Sinai Peninsula by Israel April 25, said, ''We have made it clear that the restoration of our relations with sister Arab countries will not be done at the expense of the peace'' with Israel. **********Many Arab countries severed diplomatic ties with Egypt when the peace treaty with Israel was signed in 1979. In recent days, the leaders of two of those countries, King Hassan of Morocco and King Hussein of Jordan, have sent messages of congratulations to Mr.  Mubarak on the return of Sinai. Moroccan Will Reportedly Visit **********A newspaper report here today from Rabat, Morocco, said a visit to Egypt by the Moroccan Foreign Minister, Mohammed Boucetta, was imminent. But Dr. Baz said, ''I cannot confirm that.'' **********''We do believe,'' he said ''there is a good opportunity for Arab relations to improve in the months and years ahead.'' But, Dr. Baz added, no formal steps toward resuming diplomatic relations have been taken, and he said Egypt was ''not being approached by any Arab country or a third country'' at this time. **********Asked about the scheduled visit of Sultan Qabus bin Said of Oman, which was one of the nations that kept its diplomatic mission in Cairo after the treaty was signed, Dr. Baz said that it ''should not be seen as a mediation mission.'' **********''The Sultan is not mediating on behalf of restoring our relations with any Arab countries,'' he said.  Dr. Baz said that despite the absence of diplomatic ties, Egypt was supplying Iraq with armaments, ''mostly ammunition,'' in Iraq's war with Iran. **********It was doing so, he said, in the hope of an early resolution of a conflict that is ''jeopardizing the security of the Gulf region.'' 'Good Neighborly Relations' **********Asked whether there had been a chill in relations between Egypt and Israel since the return of Sinai, Dr. Baz said, ''Bilateral relations - they are good and are developing normally.'' He termed the atmosphere between the two nations ''not special relations, but good neighborly relations.'' **********Asked about the violent demonstrations in recent weeks in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza, the Egyptian official replied, ''People living under an occupation, they have the right to challenge the occupation.'' **********Dr. Baz acknowledged that the gap between the Israelis and the Egyptians on creating an autonomy plan acceptable to the Palestinians of the West Bank and Gaza was still wide. The issue has resisted solution for nearly three years, but Dr. Baz said the talks should resume soon. **********''We believe more and more the Israelis will come to believe that it is not in their own interest to preserve the status quo,'' on the West Bank and Gaza, he said. **********He urged the United States to enunciate firmly its policy on the growing number of Israeli settlements in the two territories and said the Reagan Administration ''should also intensify efforts to resume the autonomy talks.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/11/world.main_headline: Reagan, in Statement, Acclaims Polish Union
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/11/world.print_headline: Reagan, in Statement, Acclaims Polish Union
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/11/world.body_text: **********President Reagan issued a statement today marking the second anniversary of the Polish Government's formal recognition of Solidarity union, saying the struggle goes on despite attempts to destroy the movement. **********''Today marks the second anniverary of an important milestone in mankind's age-long struggle for freedom,'' Mr. Reagan said. **********''In November 1980, for the first time since 1917, a Communist government was compelled to grant formal recognition to a free trade union, Solidarity. **********''This unprecedented step was brought about by a nonviolent revolution of millions of Polish workers who could no longer tolerate coercion and mismanagement.'' **********Referring to the crackdown on Solidarity the Polish Government began a month later with the declaration of martial law, Mr. Reagan said: **********''It is said that by declaring war on its people, the Polish Government has destroyed Solidarity. This is not so. One can imprison protesters, club and disperse demonstrators with tear gas or water cannons, but the specter remains: Never again will the self-appointed representatives of the workers be able to pretend that they represent anyone but themselves.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/08/busin.body_text: **********Two of New York's biggest savings banks, the Bowery and the Emigrant, are in danger of failing by January if they do not receive Government assistance, Alan R. Cohen, Acting Superintendent of New York State Banks, told Congress yesterday. **********The Bowery, with total assets of $5.1 billion, is the fourthlargest state-chartered savings bank in the state, and Emigrant, with assets of $3.1 billion, is the fifth-largest. There are 94 state-chartered savings banks in New York State. **********In addition to the Bowery and Emigrant, the department projects that the United Mutual Savings Bank of New York and the Mechanics Savings Bank of Elmira are in danger of running out of net worth by January. **********Branching Bill Approved **********In another banking development, the New York State Assembly passed a bill yesterday that would allow out-of-state banks to establish or acquire banks in New York, provided their respective states let New York State banks to do likewise. (Page D12.) **********Mr. Cohen, pleading before the Senate Banking Committee for Government assistance for the thrift industry, cited a survey conducted by the banking department of the 20 most troubled savings banks in New York State. Without Federal assistance, these banks would run out of net worth by July 1984, he said. **********Officials stressed that, even if this were to happen, it would pose no problem for depositors, whose accounts are insured up to $100,000 by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, an agency of the Government. Acquirer's Obligation **********Generally, the F.D.I.C. merges a failing bank into a stronger institution, with most depositors hardly realizing any change has taken place. Under such an approach, even those with deposits of more than $100,000 do not lose any money because the obligation to pay is accepted by the acquiring institution. **********The debate in Congress is not over how to protect depositors, but over whether individual savings institutions should be supported by the Government and over the form such suport should take. The bills before Congress, for example, would allow the Government to provide failing savings institutions with capital notes, a form of Federal guarantees, that would allow them to survive as independent institutions. **********Without such notes, they would have to be merged into other institutions, the policy followed now by regulatory authorities.  The New York State Banking Department has been one of the most ardent proponents of Congressional or Federal action to bail out the thrift institutions. Muriel Siebert, who resigned as Superintendent of Banking last month to run for the Republican nomination for the United States Senate, had lobbied heavily in Washington for aid for the thrift units. **********Miss Siebert, in her efforts to get legislative results, often startled bankers by her public warnings that many savings institutions were on the brink of failure. In the past, bank regulators did all they could to reassure the public that the banking system was sound. **********Mr. Cohen, now the Acting Superintendent, took Miss Siebert's policy a step further yesterday by actually giving a list of troubled banks and projecting when they might fail. **********While the New York banking department is trying to keep the thrift industry intact, other regulators say there is no future for savings banks and contend that the troubled ones might as well be merged into commercial banks or other financial institutions now rather than later. Fear of Power Loss Cited **********Some bank analysts contend that the New York banking department, as well as others elsewhere in the country, fear that their own power would be reduced as a result of the demise of savings banks. State banking departments, they say, generally obtain their revenue from examinations of state-chartered banks, and most savings banks are state-chartered. **********But Mr. Cohen, in his testimony, contended that the states were better equipped to deal with failing thrift institutions than were Federal authorities. ''Without wishing to appear immodest,'' he said, ''we believe we know more about the chances for survival of New York state-chartered institutions than anyone at the Federal level.'' **********And, like Miss Siebert, Mr. Cohen argued that savings institutions ''must continue to be, as they have been in the past, the principal source of home financing for the American family.'' Others, however, contend that such institutions as commercial banks and pension funds can supply the nation's mortgage needs. **********Mr. Cohen's projections about thrift failures assume that interest rates will remain at or near current levels, or rise higher. If interest rates declined, the losses of thrift institutions would be reduced, and the life expectancy of the savings banks would be extended. If interest rates dropped precipitously, many savings banks would begin making profits. Rapid Interest Rate Rise **********The savings banks' losses are the result of the rapid increase in interest rates in recent years, which has forced the banks to offer relatively high rates to attract and maintain deposits. But since the yields on the savings banks' assets, mainly long-term mortgages, have not risen so quickly, almost all savings banks are paying more for their deposits than they are earning on their loans. **********Several years ago, when the general level of interest rates was lower, all savings banks were earning profits and these profits were kept in the banks' retained earnings or surplus accounts. These accounts represent the banks' net worth. **********Savings banks have been dipping into these net worth accounts to cover their recent losses. The net worth accounts act as a cushion between the losses and depositors' money.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/02/world.body_text: **********Chancellor Helmut Schmidt sharply criticized Minister for Economic Affairs Otto Lambsdorff today for remarks Mr. Lambsdorff made in a newspaper interview. **********The Government spokesman, Klaus Bolling, told a news conference that Chancellor Schmidt expressed his ''astonishment and irritation'' over the remarks during a Cabinet meeting today. **********On Tuesday the mass circulation Bild newspaper quoted the Economics Minister as saying voters at local elections in Hesse state this month could show whether they wanted his Free Democrats to quit the coalition. **********Mr. Bolling said the Chancellor felt the remarks could reduce the Government's room for maneuver and its standing abroad.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/25/busin.body_text: **********Hearst Magazines has just made some changes that really put its stamp of ownership on Redbook magazine, acquired last August from the Charter Company. **********It has put in its own publisher and ad director. **********Alan M. Wexenberg, 47-year-old publisher of its Sports Afield, has been moved over as a vice president and publisher to replace Peter S. Chidsey, who resigned. **********Richard J. Sarno, 56, who had worked for Redbook for 13 years before joining Hearst, will be the new ad director. He is coming in from Hearst's Harper's Bazaar, where he held the title of associate publisher and advertising director. **********Back at Sports Afield, meanwhile, the publisher's chair is being filled by Hastings Ross, 44, a one-time Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborne man who once had his own magazine, Hunting Fishing Humor. **********Mr. Waxenberg was once vice president-advertising of Petersen Publishing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/02/world.body_text: **********Hundreds of Panamanian officials, from Cabinet members to county commissioners, resigned in a mass Government shake-up that followed the resignation of President Aristides Royo, officials said today. **********Guillermo Cochez, leader of the opposition Christian Democrats, condemned the military for what he charged was an illegal ouster of President Royo on Friday. Mr. Royo said he had resigned because of health problems. **********Those who resigned reportedly included all 10 Cabinet ministers, their under secretaries, 9 state governors, county commissioners in each state and about 200 diplomats.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/10/busin.main_headline: Investing; HOW TO SPOT A TURNAROUND STOCK
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/10/busin.print_headline: Investing; HOW TO SPOT A TURNAROUND STOCK
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/10/busin.body_text: **********S OMETIMES stocks go up, and sometimes they go down; and with so many stocks in the doldrums today, hundreds ought to rebound eventually. But how do you spot those that will? Professional money managers make a business of identifying such turnaround stocks, so managers from four firms were selected at random and asked how they make their picks. **********Mr. Metz and Mr. Weinger, stock analysts for Oppenheimer & Company, say they often spot turnaround candidates among companies that announce major debt restructurings. ''The first type of restructuring that we love is a bankruptcy,'' Mr. Weinger says. ''We think a stock should go up when a bankruptcy is announced; and in many cases these companies have become some of the best investments.  In those that have worked out, people have made huge amounts of money. When they don't work out, you either lose half your money or you break about even,'' Mr. Weinger adds. **********Among those companies that recently filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy laws and may now be potentially good investments, McLouth Steel, a big supplier to Detroit, is a standout, according to the Oppenheimer team. ''If Detroit ever comes out of this 'We-hate-domestic-automobiles' phase, McLouth may be a very valuable property,'' Mr. Metz added. **********Another important indicator of a turnaround is an announcement that a company plans to sell some of its assets because of a liquidity squeeze. A recent example is the Culbro Corporation. After the company sold off its Ex-Lax division, the stock soared from about $3 a share to more than $20. **********Mr. Addison is publisher of the Addison Report, an investment advisory service in North Quincy, Mass. One thing he looks for in making investment decisions is whether an industry or company has recently made major changes in its operations. An example he cites is Esmark, which has sold off major portions of its Swift meat-packing subsidiary, and a number of other units. ''With the cash that they garnered, they eventually bought shares of their own stock in the market, reducing shares outstanding and increasing earnings,'' Mr.  Addison says. **********Beatrice Foods is another example, Mr. Addison says. The food processing company is divesting itself of certain units and undergoing major internal changes. ''Despite these changes, Beatrice has still managed to produce about a decades' worth of earnings growth,'' he says. **********Other companies that meet Mr. Addison's turnaround criteria are Norton Simon and Ideal Toy.  Trends in the bond and commodities markets are also helpful indications of turnaround situations, Mr. Addison says. Currently, he argues, falling prices in grains and sugars bode well for cereal and bakery companies and food processors such as Interstate Bakers, Warner-Lambert and Fisher Foods. ''With the demand for products from these industries remaining at least constant, their profit margins stand to widen tremendously in the foreseeable future - which will work its way down to increased earnings,'' Mr. Addison says. **********Mr. Dreman, of Dreman, Grey & King Inc., an investment counseling firm in New York, says that ''in a very complex economy, with all sorts of random political, economic and industry events, we don't think forecasting is a very good thing to emphasize.'' He argues that selecting stocks from those industries that have the lowest priceearnings ratios is the most disciplined approach to sound investment in any market. **********''Basically, we're looking for cheap stocks, those with low P-E ratios, because every study that we've seen has shown that these stocks have always done better in the market as a group,'' Mr. Dreman says. But he adds that he takes the process a step further. ''We don't only want low P-E's,'' he says. ''We want to make sure the company's going to last. We don't want to buy a Ford at three times earnings, if earnings are going to go straight down. We want good dividends and the likelihood that dividends will increase.'' **********Mr. Dreman finds good buys right now in the relatively depressed property and casualty insurance industry. Current favorities include Travelers Insurance and Crum & Foster. Another ''out of favor'' bargain is Aetna Life and Casualty, according to Mr. Dreman. **********Banks are another currently depressed group and are potentially good investments over the long run, he says, and recommends Wells Fargo, a ''high-yielding, low P-E stock that we think is very cheap,'' along with Citicorp and Chase Manhattan. **********Mr. LeFevre, a vice president of Purcell, Graham & Company, looks for potential turnaround situations primaril y by plotting a stock's price movement. ''One of my favorites is a sa ucer formation,'' he says. ''This is where a stock has been in a d ecline, and starts to move side-wise in a bottoming process. Then i t starts to edge up in asaucering formation. Usually that means you'r e at the end of something. That is a good time to establish a position.'' **********Volume flow is another good indicator, according to Mr. LeFevre.  The rule is that rising volume on declining prices is bearish, while rising volume on advancing prices is bullish. Mr. LeFevre adds that if a stock reaches new highs but the volume is contracting, it is not necessarily healthy. **********''Usually at the end of a long sustained declined, there's a tremendous amount of volume,'' he says. ''This is where the little guy is being sold out on a margin call.'' But this is often when such stocks start to rally. He cites I.B.M., the Manville Corporation (formerly Johns Manville) and Bethlehem Steel as stocks currently in that situation. **********Still, Mr. Lefevre stresses that a sound investment strategy requires attention to company fundamentals - earnings and dividend records, management changes, etc. - as well as good technical analysis. ''You can get great chart formations,'' he says, ''but if your fundamentals tell you this thing's headed for Chapter 11, then you just forget the chart.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/30/busin.body_text: **********A former Time Inc. chap and a Boston advertising woman have combined their talents with some cash from E.F. Hutton and have formed the Redgate Publishing Company in Vero Beach, Fla. It will bring out a publication called List, a twice-yearly advertising medium (of course) which will be a directory of personal-computer application softwear that follows on editorial material and display advertising. **********The president is Joseph J. Weibel, once the advertising sales manager and associate advertising director of Fortune, who went from that to his own rep outfit in the Southeast. **********His partner, and the publisher of List, is Kimberly Perry Leonsis, a one-time account executive at Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos in Boston, who has since been consulting in the field of minicomputers, and data and word processors. **********She said that while List would have a circulation guarantee of 60,000, actual circulation could be double that. A four-color page is selling for $4,560 and a black-and-white page goes for $3,000.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/22/world.main_headline: ROTATION HOME FOR BEIRUT MARINES MAY BE DELAYED BY THE PENTAGON
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/22/world.print_headline: ROTATION HOME FOR BEIRUT MARINES MAY BE DELAYED BY THE PENTAGON
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/22/world.body_text: **********The Defense Department said today that the scheduled rotation home next month of the marines in Beirut might be delayed, as speculation grew that their role may be more extensive than originally planned. **********A Pentagon spokesman, Henry Catto, said: ''Some delay in their rotation can be expected. The whole situation in Lebanon is a changing one as diplomats make progress toward the withdrawal of all foreign forces.'' **********The 1,200 marines in Beirut, with 600 others aboard ships, had been scheduled to return home in November after a six-month Mediterranean tour. No time limit had been set for keeping the marines, or their replacements, in the three-nation peacekeeping force, but President Reagan has repeatedly talked about a ''limited period.'' Talks on Withdrawal Are Slow **********Within recent days there has been discussion in the State Department, the Pentagon and the White House about a possible shifting role for the marines. **********At the same time, officials indicate, efforts to keep the force in Beirut for as brief a time as possible have run into snags because of the slowness of negotiations on withdrawing Syrian, Israeli and Palestinian forces from Lebanon. **********''There may be changes in the disposition of the marines,'' Mr.  Catto said. ''It is a changing situation.'' Later, he said: ''It is too early to even speculate on a changing role for the marines. Whether or not a change in the current assignment takes place will depend on what happens on the diplomatic front.'' **********Speculation about a broader role for the marines at Beirut Airport - part of a 3,400-member American, Italian and French force in the Beirut area - increased after the visit to Washington this week of President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon. Mr. Gemayel told Mr. Reagan and Secretary of State George P. Shultz that he hoped to see the marines expand their role outside Beirut. **********Besides the multinational force, there are 7,000 United Nations soldiers in southern Lebanon as well as 22,000 Lebanese Army troops.  The Lebanese Army is known to be poorly trained and equipped, and the United Nations force has stirred Israeli distrust and has proved somewhat ineffective. **********A State Department official said the question of how to provide security for Lebanon was under discussion.  At present, American officials say, the options focus on an arrangement that could involve the three-nation force, the United Nations troops and the Lebanese Army. **********''They can be used singly or in different areas or in combination,'' one official said. ''They can be used in different ways. It is not at all determined how this will be done. People have different ideas.'' Britain Willing to Join Force **********The official added that the United States had engaged in discussions with the Israelis and Lebanese on the most viable security set-up in Lebanon, especially in the south. It is known that some Western European nations, including Britain, have expressed a willingness to join the multination force. **********Mr. Reagan, in a news conference last month, raised the possibility that the marines might remain in Lebanon longer than most people had envisaged, saying that they would stay until all the foreign troops had left. The next day, officials said the American presence was not linked to the troop withdrawal but to the desires of the Lebanese Government. **********Mr. Reagan then amended his comments to say it was possible the marines might remain after the Israelis, Syrians and Palestinians departed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/07/world.main_headline: 90 BELEIEVED DEAD IN SOVIET PLANE CRASH IN MOSCOW
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/07/world.print_headline: 90 BELEIEVED DEAD IN SOVIET PLANE CRASH IN MOSCOW
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/07/world.body_text: **********A Soviet jetliner that was believed to be carrying about 90 people crashed and burned early today shortly after taking off from Moscow on a scheduled flight to West Africa. All aboard were reportedly killed. **********The crash of the Ilyushin-62 operated by Aeroflot occurred shortly after midnight, but an announcement by the Ministry of Civil Aviation was delayed for 15 hours. Airport sources said there had been about 90 people aboard and that none had survived. **********The flight was bound for Senegal and Sierra Leone, but officials of the embassies of the two countries said after the announcement that they had received no official confirmation of the deaths of their nationals aboard. Western airline representatives said Soviet officials had refused to give them any details. **********The Soviet announcement said only that the crash had occurred ''in the area'' of Sheremetyevo Airport, on the northwestern outskirts of Moscow, and that a special commission was investigating. The announcement expressed the Aviation Ministry's condolences to relatives of the victims. There was no reference to the number of casualties. **********Airport sources said the jetliner hit the ground about seven miles from the runway, in an area closed to foreigners.  West African diplomats said the passengers included at least 16 citizens of Sierra Leone and a group of Senegalese students, together with a large number of Soviet citizens. In Freetown, Sierra Leone's capital, officials said that the dead included the country's representative to the Budapest-based World Federation of Youth and the former education attache at the country's Moscow embassy. **********The four-engine Ilyushin-62, in service on long-haul flights for 15 years, has a capacity of 186 passengers.  Although Soviet authorities generally announce crashes only when foreigners are involved, Ilyushin-62's are known to have been involved in at least six major crashes in the last decade, four with Aeroflot and two with Eastern European airlines. The last known accident with the aircraft occurred in July 1980, when an Ilyushin-62 crashed at Alma-Ata in Soviet Kazakhstan, killing 163 people. **********Aeroflot, which says it is the world's biggest airline, carrying more than 100 million passengers a year, has had at least 15 known crashes with all types of aircraft since 1972, involving more than 1,400 deaths.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/29/busin.body_text: **********Aided by an increase in travel for pleasure, the nation's major airlines have been experiencing increased traffic this year and are expected to show further gains this month. **********With the exception of a slight decline in May, revenue passenger miles have been up every month this year, and a 7 percent or 8 percent rise is expected to be reported for June. **********For an industry that has undergone two consecutive years of declining traffic and some steep losses, the recent upturn is welcome indeed. But many believe it is too early to call it a lasting recovery and are afraid that any benefits could evaporate in another outbreak of fare wars this fall. **********Such discounts, in fact, are a major reason behind the increase in pleasure travel, as opposed to the business travel that is the industry's backbone. **********Ellen Friedel, for example, a legal secretary for Price Waterhouse & Company, was picking up tickets for a pleasure trip to Boston last week at an Eastern Airlines office near Rockefeller Center - $42, round trip, from Newark. ''If it was $150 or something,'' she said, ''we would just drive down to the beach in New Jersey.'' **********Another customer, a lawyer, was making a trip to Florida over the weekend just to get away from her job. Because of the state of the economy there are few chances for raises and advancement at her firm. ''I just need to get away,'' she said. **********That sort of business is improving the airlines' outlook, at least for the short term.  ''We're beginning to see a slow, gradual recovery in the industry which will strenghten in the third quarter,'' Julius Maldutis, airline analyst for Solomon Brothers Inc., predicted. **********But according to Neil M. Effman, senior vice president of airline planning for Trans World Airlines, ''it's far too early to tell'' whether the improvement will last. In fact, he added, ''I don't see any basic, fundamental increase in traffic that looks like a recovery for this industry.'' **********He also noted that while some of the discounting of fares had moderated, many fares remain at levels where the airlines are not making money. **********Traffic, as measured in revenue passenger miles - or the number of paying passengers multiplied by the number of miles flown - began its rise in February, with a 5.4 percent increase from figures a year earlier. In March, traffic was up 11.2 percent, and in April, 6.7 percent. **********In May, there was a drop of 3.4 percent, but analysts and executives alike noted that a year earlier traffic was extremely strong because of a special $149 fare offered by most major airlines that enabled a traveler to go anywhere in the country. **********Mr. Maldutis said that preliminary figures for June show that traffic has been running about 7 percent to 8 percent higher on domestic schedules of the 11 major trunk airlines. **********He predicted that the upturn would continue into July, when traffic would increase by 8 percent to 9 percent, and that it would be up about 14 percent in August. The big jump in August, he said, would at least partly reflect the sharp traffic declines of a year earlier, when the controllers' strike began. **********The outlook for the fourth quarter, however, is less certain.  ''We don't feel very strong on the fourth quarter,'' said Wesley G. Kaldahl, senior vice president for planning at American Airlines.  He said much depends on the economy then. **********For the year, he expects traffic to be up 6 percent to 7 percent, compared with a 7.4 percent decline last year and a 6 percent decline in 1980. **********What happens to profits this year, airline executives warn, depends on a number of factors besides traffic. If the airlines begin extensive fare cutting like last fall and if they throw new capacity into their routes in attempts to wrest customers from competitors, then yields will suffer. **********Yields, which measure the revenue derived from carrying one passenger one mile, dropped 9 percent in the first quarter, to 12.01 cents, compared with 13.23 cents in the first quarter last year. And the major airlines lost $590 million in the three-month period. **********Working in favor of airline profitability are labor costs, which in many instances have decreased as a result of wage cuts and concessions on work rules by unions, and a decline in fuel costs. **********Still, the fare question haunts airline executives.  One executive of a major airline noted that in the past when there was an upturn in traffic and planes filled up, most airlines began to eliminate the deep-discount fares, and that the same pattern can be seen in the current upturn. **********In time, however, many carriers could not resist the temptation of adding capacity to capture more traffic, often setting off major price wars. **********This time around, he said, the carriers are constrained by the aftereffects of the air controllers' strike, which put severe limits on adding flights at major airports, and by the memory of Braniff's bankruptcy filing. Such constraints could act as a check on fare wars. **********But as Mr. Kaldahl said, ''I'm fearful that once the summer season is over, there will be a going back to pricing actions.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/18/world.main_headline: MAJOR ESPIONAGE SCANDAL REPORTED IN BRITAIN
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/18/world.print_headline: MAJOR ESPIONAGE SCANDAL REPORTED IN BRITAIN
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/18/world.body_text: **********British officials are investigating a major espionage case involving poor security at a top secret communications station, British news organizations said today. **********The Times of London said the case involved the Government Communications Headquarters at Cheltenham, 90 miles northwest of London. **********The headquarters controls a worldwide network of communications and surveillance stations monitoring millions of international messages that code and language specialists analyze. Cheltenham also maintains security links with Britain's allies, including the United States. **********The reports followed the arraignment Thursday of Geoffrey Arthur Prime of Cheltenham on an espionage charge described by prosecutor David Matthews as being ''of the gravest possible nature.'' **********Details were not disclosed, but the formal charge states that Mr.  Prime ''between Jan. 1, 1968, and Dec. 31, 1981, in England for purposes prejudicial to the safety and interest of the state, communicated to other persons information which was calculated to be or might be, or was intended to be, directly or indirectly useful to an enemy.'' **********The Sun reported that the information related to leaks from Cheltenham. The Daily Telegraph described the defendant as a former employee at Cheltenham. **********Mr. Prime, 44 years old, was ordered held in custody. Judicial proceedings were delayed until Nov. 26. He is expected to be tried at London's Old Bailey Central Criminal Court. **********The Financial Times said Cabinet ministers feared the incident ''could develop into the biggest scandal since Kim Philby.''Mr.  Philby, a leading member of Britain's intelligence services, fled to Moscow in 1963 after revealing scores of agents around the world to the Soviet Union.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/16/busin.body_text: **********When the Mexican Government nationalized the country's private banks two weeks ago, it also inherited a huge industrial empire consisting of shares owned by the banks in hundreds of leading Mexican companies. **********The Government soon announced that, rather than hold onto the shares, it would sell them, perhaps putting the proceeds toward compensation owed to the former owners of the expropriated banks. **********But the Government has found that doing this will not be easy. For one thing, Mexico's depressed stock market seems incapable of absorbing a flood of shares. For another, the country's private sector is pressing for the return of the shares to their original owners while leftist groups argue that the state should control them. **********''If the Government keeps these shares,'' said one distraught Mexican businessman who asked not to be identified, ''then we're definitely moving toward a socialist economy.'' Some Large Blocks Involved **********The bank nationalization has already changed the face of Mexican business, temporarily at least. By taking over Banca Serfin and Banpais, for example, the Government automatically inherited 37.37 percent of the shares - making it the largest single stockholder - of Cydsa, a Monterrey-based chemical company. **********Similarly, by expropriating Bancomer, until two weeks ago Mexico's second-largest private bank, the Government became the owner of a controlling 68.7 percent of Minera Frisco, a major mining company.  The Government has even found that it holds 48.5 percent of the shares of El Puerto de Liverpool, a major retail chain, as well as shares in other department stores. **********While businessmen are complaining loudly about the Government's increased role in the economy, leftist economists take a different view. They argue that the bank nationalization exposed enormous power exercised by the country's leading financial groups. **********There was a concentration of resources, with the two largest banks -Bancomer and Banamex - controlling 47 percent of total assets and the top six banks (including two already owned by the Government) controlling 79.5 percent of all assets. Further, although 59 banks were nationalized on Sept. 1, only a handful of the banks were important shareholders in private companies. Stock Accumulation Policy **********Mexico's banks insist they did nothing wrong. The banks not only were authorized to operate nationwide but also were encouraged to invest bank deposits in shares as a way of promoting development. **********The nonfinancial investments of Bancomer were channeled into such diverse areas as chemicals, paper, tires and retailing. At the prevailing exchange rate six weeks ago, these shares were worth $224 million, or 56 percent of the bank's net worth. **********Banamex, which had recently become Mexico's largest bank through its diversification strategy, had widely varied interests, including a 40 percent share of Bufete Industrial, one of the country's largest construction concerns. Banamex also held shares in hotel chains, food processors, telecommunications companies and retail stores. Stocks held by the bank were valued on July 31 at $324 million, or 80 percent of its net worth. **********Some banks were closely linked to major economic groups. Banca Serfin, for example, had been transformed from the traditional Bank of London and Montreal into the country's third-largest bank after it was taken over by the aggressive Visa conglomerate, based in Monterrey. Similarly, Banpais was effectively part of the Vitro glass group, also with headquarters in Monterrey. Timber and Other Holdings **********Multibanco Comermex, the fourth-largest private bank, also had its roots in the provinces in the so-called Chihuahua Group. Its main business is timber, but the bank also had interests in steel, and it owned 21 percent of Transportacion Maritima Mexicana, the country's largest shipping line. **********In some cases, Mexican banks had formed joint ventures with foreign investors (including the Ralston Purina Company, Deere & Company, the Kimberly-Clark Corporation and Anderson, Clayton & Company) because a ''Mexicanization'' program limited foreign ownership to 49 percent of an enterprise. Some subsidiaries of American corporations now find themselves in partnership with the Government. **********Even before the bank nationalization, the public sector already accounted for about 50 percent of Mexico's gross domestic product through control of the oil, electricity and railroad sectors plus major stakes in petrochemicals, fertilizers, mining, steel and aviation. **********Further, the Government had also accumulated hundreds of manufacturing and service companies as a result of its tradition of taking over bankrupt companies and banks to salvage jobs and deposits. Suspension of Stock Trading **********Having nationalized the banks, President Jose Lopez Portillo's administration shows reluctance to alienate the private sector further by holding onto the banks' industrial shares. Yet the Government seems uncertain how to dispose of them. **********The trading of common shares has been suspended on the Mexican stock exchange since the nationalization two weeks ago because of the uncertain status of the shares inherited by the Government. **********Investment analysts argue that, with most stocks already at a low ebb, the Government could not sell its new shares without badly damaging the market. An alternative, they suggest, would be to negotiate a realistic price for the shares and hand them back to the private banks' former owners as partial compensation. **********''The problem with that is political,'' one analyst said. ''The Government is boasting that it has broken the economic grip of the financial groups, but returning the shares would effectively rebuild them.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/10/world.body_text: **********Argentina's most urgent military problem is the acquisition of more advanced weapons from the Western European powers that have sold arms to the country's military establishment for 15 years but that have now imposed an embargo on such sales to Argentina. **********Only an influx of additional advanced weapons, including air-tosurface and surface-to-surface missiles, analysts said, will enable Argentina to match a steadily expanding British task force in the South Atlantic. **********According to NATO sources, Argentina has begun an almost frantic search for more weapons. Buyers have appeared in European capitals and in the Middle East, which is a flourishing center for sales of light surface-to-air missiles and land mines, most of them of Soviet origin. Simultaneously Argentina has pleaded with arm sellers abroad to hurry deliveries of weapons already ordered and paid for.  But such deliveries from members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Common Market - West Germany and France, for instance - are now suspended because of the clash with Britain over the Falkland Islands.  The Common Market embargo against Argentina expires May 17, but it may be extended. **********Would Have to Run Blockade **********Arms deliveries from other countries, military specialists here said, would have to run the British blockade. Although the Royal Navy is not known to have interfered so far with commercial vessels headed for Argentine ports, such interference is considered likely if British intelligence detects merchant ships carrying arms to Argentine ports. **********Political intelligence here does not accept suggestions that Argentina, in desperation, would turn to the Soviet Union for arms.  The reason is practical rather than ideological. The Argentine forces have no training in Soviet weapon systems, and even if the anti-Communist military Government purchased such weapons, it would take months before the Argentines could deploy and use them. **********Argentina's own arms industry is being expanded under the direction of the Armed Forces Scientific and Technical Research Center. The expansion, analysts said, will mean a greater flow of light weapons to the army. But they do not expect Argentine industry to provide advanced weapons or the spare parts for aircraft and ships purchased abroad. **********After Brazil, Argentina has been the second largest arms buyer in Latin America. Brazil has the largest military establishment in South America and a strong arms industry. Brazil Might Send Arms **********Although political sources here emphasized that relations between Argentina and Brazil are usually strained, they acknowledge that there is a possibility that Brazil, to show third world solidarity, might provide some arms to Buenos Aires if deliveries from Europe fail to materialize. **********Over the last five years, according to the International Peace Research Institute in Stockholm, West Germany has supplied 33 percent of Argentina's arms purchases. Scheduled for delivery from West Germany before the beginning of the Falkland crisis were 4 destroyers, 4 submarines and 2 missile-armed naval vessels. Under West German license, Argentina is building 4 submarines, 6 frigates and 220 light tanks. **********Until the late 1970's Argentina bought a wide variety of arms from the United States. The shift to European purchases, experts said, was a result of the Carter Administration's ban on arms sales, imposed because of the junta's reported violations of human rights. **********Since the end of World War II the United States had delivered to Argentina 2 cruisers, 6 destroyers, 2 submarines, 101 combat aircraft, nearly 100 transport planes and about 25 attack and transport helicopters. One Crusier Scrapped, One Sunk **********Only the General Belgrano, one of the cruisers, has figured significantly in the fighting with Britain. She was torpedoed by a British submarine in the first major encounter of the conflict. The other cruiser was scrapped in 1979. **********French-made weapons have done the most damage to the British. A Super-Etendard fighter-bomber, one of the 14 scheduled to replace American A-4's on the aircraft carrier Vienticinco de Mayo, fired the French-made Exocet missile that reduced the British destroyer Sheffield to a smouldering hulk. **********The price of the Exocet, which gives a fighter-bomber the hitting power of a battleship, has risen ''astronomically'' since the attack on the Sheffield, a source in the British arms industry said.  Argentina is believed to have five more Exocet air-to-surface missiles. **********Before the West European boycott, Argentina had been awaiting the delivery of 9 more Super-Etendard aircraft, the source added, as well as 10 Roland surface-to-air missiles and 9 Puma helicopters.  Also on order from France are 3 frigates, additional Mirage fighters, 25 more helicopters, 96 armored cars and an unknown number of surface-to-surface and surface-to-air missiles. Some British Deliveries **********Purchases from Britian, made before the crisis, included three types of missiles, naval radio transmitters and electronic countermeasure devices and control systems. In addition Britain had sold Argentina two frigates. **********Israel has sold 26 Dagger fighters to Argentina. There are reports, vigorously denied by Israeli sources, that 14 more have been purchased. Israel said last week that it would make no future arms deals with Argentina but would deliver those arms already paid for by Buenos Aires. **********British military sources believe that Argentina lacks military depth to maintain a protracted conflict. A continuation of the fighting, they said, would force Argentina to cancel its existing arms exports. Argentina is the seventh largest exporter of arms to third world countries, with most of the weapons going to smaller South American countries such as Uruguay. Stocks May Run Out **********The crunch will come, these sources predicted, when spare parts for advanced aircraft run out and the stock of missiles is exhausted. These, it was said, cannot be replaced under present political and military circumstances. **********The Argentine armed services' ability to maintain weapons varies, the sources added. The air force's ability is rated very high, as many of the ground crews have been trained in the United States and Western Europe. The navy is only slightly behind. **********The army is the questionable service in this regard. A NATO analyst said that the army has been provided with a profusion of advanced weapons but that the use of many is beyond the ability of the conscripts who make up nearly 70 percent of the army.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/13/busin.body_text: **********THE General Motors Corporation, worrying about the recession and the slump in car sales, made an innovative real estate deal some months ago when it received about $500 million for its New York office building on Fifth Avenue. G.M. is using the money for working capital. **********The transaction not only showed the new interest that many companies are taking in their real estate but also indicated potential job opportunities. **********This process has been going on for some time, according to Alan M.  Higgins, president of the General Tire Realty Company and manager of its real estate. ''The turning point in our industry came in the last four or five years,'' he said in an interview. **********Lee Van Leeuwen, who specializes in recruiting real estate managers, describes the trend as ''a slow realization'' by big companies of the latent value of their real estate assets. Mr. Van Leeuwen is managing partner of the real estate specialty division of Korn/Ferry International, a management recruiting firm. **********''In the past two years we have placed more real estate managers with corporations than in the previous 12 years,'' he said. ''The quality of the managers is improving, but many still are not at the top, possibly because the job of real estate manager has never been a route to the top.'' Formerly many real estate managers were recruited from within the company, coming from the law or financial departments. **********''Real estate managers need to know how to negotiate and communicate,'' Mr. Van Leeuwen said, When companies need expert help with their real estate, traditionally they have asked outside consultants to advise them, and often they seek joint-venture partners. But this will change, Mr. Van Leeuwen suggested. Real estate managers, he said, have been ''stepchildren'' for too long. **********He observed that the heads of corporate real estate departments often were not familiar with the objectives of top management. Real estate managers have not had easy access to their company's top officers, who have been too busy with other things to worry about real estate. As a result, many companies have underestimated their real estate holdings on balance sheets, he said. **********Andrew H. Madsen, director of corporate real estate at the Atlantic Richfield Company for the last two years, says there is a ''tremendous need'' for experienced real estate managers. Before joining Arco, he spent 25 years in the Ford Motor Company's real estate department. ''Everything is much more complex now,'' he said.  ''Some companies do not even know how much real estate they own or lease. There is increased pressure to use the real estate efficiently.'' **********Retailing is one field where companies have long recognized the importance of real estate - ranging from huge department store chains to fast-food franchisers. Much of a store's success depends on the choice of a site, so retailers have built up efficient real estate departments and pay among the best salaries, Mr. Van Leeuwen said. **********The new interest in real estate as an important balance sheet item comes at a time when many companies have been badly hurt by the recession and high interest rates. Some have closed outmoded plants and sold them, while some think in terms of selling prospering plants and leasing them back to raise working capital. Others realize that once the recession ends there may be a new boom in real estate, and they want to be able to turn real estate holdings into cash or advantageous rental deals. **********Mr. Higgins of General Tire, who is also chairman of the 2,200-member National Association of Corporate Real Estate Executives, recently calculated that, in Fortune magazine's list of the 500 largest companies, the stock value of a group of middle-size companies approximated only 57.9 percent of the their fixed assets, not including cash, inventories, notes receivable and equipment. The reason, he said, is that many companies have undervalued their real estate assets through conservative accounting. **********As for job opportunities, he said, corporations are looking for seasoned real estate managers with an entreprenurial flair, and they will pay well. **********''Unfortunately, that creates a three-tier system,'' Mr. Higgins said. ''There are beginners with bachelor or master's degrees in real estate, who can command $15,000 to $22,000 a year, those with four to six years' experience who might earn about $40,000 and those with 10 years' or more experience who can command salaries of $70,000 to $90,000 and more. **********''The salaries at the top end are high because there are so few who qualify. Real estate managers cannot afford to make mistakes that might have been acceptable 10 years ago.'' **********Experienced managers are moving around more often as companies build up their real estate departments, he said. The prestige of these corporate real estate experts is growing. **********''The real estate manager holds a highly visible job nowadays,'' Mr. Higgins said, ''and in many companies he communicates weekly with the chairman.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/20/busin.body_text: **********As Shotaro Uchiyma sees it, a truly global company ought to be run from New York City - the financial and information capital of the world, he says. **********So the 66-year-old president of the Fujitec Company, the fourthlargest elevator maker in Japan, is moving his company's worldwide headquarters to 450 Park Avenue. **********Mr. Uchiyama is also fond of Ohio. Next month, construction will begin on a $50 million elevator plant in Lebanon, Ohio. When completed at the end of 1984, it will be the largest elevator factory in the world, Mr. Uchiyama said during an interview at the corporate offices in this city outside Osaka. **********At the 140-acre Ohio site, Fujitec plans to make 3,000 elevators and 600 escalators a year; it also plans a 1,000-foot tower for elevator research and development. Although other Japanese companies have sizable manufacturing sites in the United States, Fujitec is believed to be the first to put its headquarters in America. 'Interesting and Unusual Move' **********''As far as I know, no other medium-sized or large Japanese company has ever moved its worldwide headquarters to the United States,'' said Ikusaburo Kashima, deputy director of the Americas-Oceania division of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry. ''It is a most interesting and unusual move.'' **********''In Japan,'' Mr. Uchiyama said, ''people think what we are doing is very strange. But from our viewpoint, it is very natural.'' Indeed, since its founding in 1948, Fujitec has stood apart from the Japanese business establishment. Mr. Uchiyama is one of Japan's breed of free-wheeling entrepreneurs of the postwar era - a group whose best-known members include Soichiro Honda of the Honda Motor Comany, Masaru Ibuka and Akio Morita of the Sony Corporation, and Isao Nakauchi of Daiei Inc., a supermarket chain. **********All of them have been unusually aggressive, willing to flout traditional Japanese business practices. They are also more globalminded than their corporate peers. **********In the Japanese elevator industry, Fujitec is an outsider in an insider's game. The three largest producers -Mitsubishi Electric, Hitachi and Toshiba - are old-line companies that are part of powerful industrial groups. Holds 10% of Market **********In these circumstances, analysts say that Fujitec has done well to garner about 10 percent of the $500 million-a-year market for elevators and escalators in Japan, compared with 35 percent for Mitsubishi, 30 percent for Hitachi and 12 percent for Toshiba. **********But Fujitec has found the biggest share of its growth abroad, partly because of the domestic competition. In addition, Fujitec has specialized in more sophisticated and costlier elevators - priced from $50,000 to $200,000 apiece - that are installed in high-rise buildings. Such buildings are comparatively scarce in Japan because of earthquake concerns. **********The company refers to its product as the ''Rolls-Royce of elevators.'' Its forte is supplying new buildings that require several elevators with computerized controls. **********''The large-scale project that demands a high level of technology is our market, and such projects are hard to find in Japan,'' said Takakazu Uchiyama, managing director and 30-year-old son of the president. Bulk of Sales Is Abroad **********Only about one-third of Fujitec's $245 million in sales last year came from its operations in Japan. And only 2,000 of its 7,000 employees are in Japan. Overseas, Fujitec has 17 sales offices and manufacturing plants in seven countries. It has been especially successful in the office building booms in Hong Kong and Singapore. **********In the United States, too, Fujitec has captured a number of contracts in the past couple of years. These include supplying elevators for the 43-story Boston Stock Exchange building, the 43-story Louisiana Tower and the Lamar Building in Houston and the 35-story Seattle Sheraton. **********Company officials say that its business has about doubled in the past five years. Shotaro Uchiyama predicts that Fujitec may well grow to the sales level of $500 million a year over the next three years. **********Whether the company can reach or even approach those goals depends largely upon the outcome of its big moves to the United States. Some analysts say the plan involves considerable risks. **********In the United States, Fujitec will be taking on Otis Elevator, a subsidiary of the United Technologies Corporation. Otis is the world's largest elevator producer, with more than 25 percent of the global market. By contrast, Fujitec reportedly has about 2 or 3 percent. The Westinghouse Electric Corporation, another American elevator producer, is also several times as large as Fujitec. **********But others note that Fujitec has a firm track record of successfully establishing local manufacturing facilities abroad. ''We think the Ohio plant will do well,'' said Yasuo Akiyama, an analyst for the Nikko Securities Company in Osaka. **********In recent years, Fujitec has apparently been quite profitable.  Although it is not required to report consolidated financial results, company officials say its profit for the year ended last September was about $24.5 million, for an unusually high 10 percent of total sales. A Leader in Technology **********Moreover, Fujitec is regarded as a leader in elevator technology.  Its top-of-the-line elevator, the company says, is the fastest in the world. At the 500-foot-high tower in Ibaraki City, Mr. Uchiyama enjoys showing a visitor that three coins balanced on edge on the floor do not tip over as the high-speed elevator climbs and descends. **********Last year, Fujitec developed a security system, using a prism on the elevator's ceiling and electronic light-sensing devices. It can ''read'' the difference between normal movement and a fight or between cigarette smoke and a fire in the elevator. In case of trouble, the elevator automatically stops at the nearest floor. In less than a year, about 2,000 such units have been ordered. **********For his part, Mr. Uchiyama does not regard the Ohio plant or the headquarters move to New York as overly risky. ''We are determined to become deeply rooted in the United States, which is the world's biggest market,'' he said in explaining the Ohio plant. **********As for the New York headquarters transfer, Mr. Uchiyama said: ''More and more, Fujitec must become a global company. We must view everything from a worldwide viewpoint, and New York city is the best place for that.'' **********Mr. Uchiyama will leave for New York next month. Finding a place to live, he said, will be easy. He is willing to pay up to $1 million for an apartment or a house. Already, he added as an afterthought, he has received more than enough calls from New York real estate agents.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/28/world.body_text: **********Anatoly Shcharansky, the imprisoned Soviet dissident, began an indefinite hunger strike today because of repeated confiscation of his mail, his mother reported. **********Mr. Shcharansky's mother, Ida Milgrom, said he had not been able to send any letters since last December.  Mrs. Milgrom told reporters that she feared that her son could die from the effects of a prolonged hunger strike because he was still weak from a six-month period of solitary confinement last year. **********The State Department spokesman, Alan Romberg, said: ''We wish to emphasize how thoroughly we deplore the Soviet authorities' willful abuse of Mr. Shcharansky's rights which has led to this desperate decision. We call on Soviet authorities to reconsider their treatment of Mr. Shcharansky and restore his ability to be allowed to communicate with friends and relatives.'' **********Mr. Shcharanksy is in Chistopol prison in the Tatar Autonomous Republic. He was accused of espionage and sentenced to 13 years in prison and labor camp in 1977.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/15/busin.body_text: **********Foreign Minister Yoshio Sakurauchi said today that Japan is preparing new measures to ease trade friction with the United States and other trading partners, according to Japanese news reports. **********The Kyodo News Service said the measures most likely will include decontrols on farm import quotas, tariff cuts, greater access to financial services and simplified inspection procedures for such imports as tobacco. **********Mr. Sakurauchi leaves for Washington on Saturday to explain Japanese efforts to reduce tensions caused by its $16 billion trade surplus with the United States last year, the news service said. **********At a Sunday luncheon for United States Ambassador Mike Mansfield, Mr. Sakurauchi said his Government was preparing measures to liberalize import restrictions to defuse foreign criticism of the nation's export-oriented trade policy, according to the Kyodo News Service. **********Mr. Mansfield urged Japan to further open its market to block enactment of ''reciprocity'' legislation -restrictions on Japanese exports to the United States - now being debated in the United States Congress, according to Japanese officials.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/27/busin.main_headline: VW'S STRATEGY OF EXPANDING IN AMERICA IS HURTING BY SLUMP
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/27/busin.print_headline: VW'S STRATEGY OF EXPANDING IN AMERICA IS HURTING BY SLUMP
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/27/busin.body_text: **********Slumping auto sales in the United States are causing Volkswagen, West Germany's biggest auto maker, to pull back sharply on its North American plans, delaying indefinitely the start of production at two new plants in the United States and Canada. **********A company spokesman reached last Friday at Volkswagen's headquarters in Wolfsburg, West Germany, would not confirm reports that the company had a buyer for one of the new plants, the $300 million facility in Sterling Heights, Mich. But the spokesman said the company ''would consider a sale if an interested party made a serious offer.'' **********Volkswagen purchased the plant in 1980 and refurbished it to manufacture 180,000 units a year of its Rabbit and Jetta models to meet what it thought would be growing demand. **********Last year, the company announced plans to invest $82 million to acquire and equip an auto parts plant in Barrie, Ontario. The goal was to have the Canadian plant supply the plant in Sterling Heights and a Rabbit assembly plant in Westmoreland, Pa., with such items as axles and engine parts. **********Under a United States-Canadian automotive trade agreement, Volkswagen would have been allowed to export parts to the United States or to import finished Rabbit models to Canada duty-free. **********But the continuing slump on the American automobile market has badly hurt Volkswagen sales. According to a spokesman, deliveries in the United States in the first eight months of the year totaled 145,964 units, 36.6 percent less than in the period last year. Sales of the American-made Rabbit were off 47.2 percent and sales of imported models dropped 21.7 percent. **********And now company officials acknowledge that the ambitious strategy of coordinating Canadian and United States production will have to be put off indefinitely. Indeed, analysts here say that if Volkswagen is ready to accept purchase offers for the Michigan plant, it probably would consider shelving the strategy altogether. But company officials say there are no plans to sell the Canadian factory. Earnings Reported **********Reporting on the company's performance, Volkswagen said in a letter to shareholders last week that the company had net earnings of $3.2 million in the second quarter, compared with a loss of $4.6 million in the period last year. That was the company's first quarterly loss since 1975. **********The report said that consolidated net earnings in the first half totaled $25.1 million, at present exchange rates, compared with net earnings of $5.9 million in the period last year. Sales rose to $7.9 billion from $7.6 billion. **********The company said that weak domestic sales and flagging export orders would force it to close most of its West German plants for three to six weeks this fall - affecting two-thirds of its 120,000 workers - to reduce inventories. It is the first time since 1975 that falling sales have forced the company to close its German plants. **********The company also said that worldwide sales to dealers in the first six months dropped 1.9 percent, to 1.17 million units, while production worldwide increased 4.1 percent, to 1.2 million units.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/10/busin.main_headline: VIDEO GAME INDUSTRY IS JARRED ANEW
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/10/busin.print_headline: VIDEO GAME INDUSTRY IS JARRED ANEW
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/10/busin.body_text: **********The video game industry was further jolted yesterday as Warner Communications Inc.'s stock plunged 16 3/4 points on the New York Stock Exchange, to 35 1/8, and Mattel Inc., the second-largest video game company behind Warner's Atari division, said it expects a loss in its current fiscal quarter. **********The announcements indicated to industry officials and analysts that severe competition had quickly soured the once highly profitable game business, hurting even the giants. **********''We've been looking for a shakeout in cartridges all along,'' said Michele Preston, who follows the industry for Cyrus J. Lawrence Inc.  ''The surprise was we didn't expect Atari to be the one shaken out.'' **********The stock market's negative reaction extended to other companies in video games, home computers or retailing, despite statements made by some in an attempt to disassociate themselves from the reaction. **********Coleco Industries, a video game company, dropped 3 1/4, to 34 7/8.  The Tandy Corporation, a retailer of video games and maker of home computers, dropped 6 points, to 50 1/2, while Toys ''R'' Us, a leading toy retailer, fell 4 1/2, to 47. Mattel did not trade at all late Wednesday and all day yesterday. Mattel Earnings **********Mattel said yesterday that earnings for its third quarter ended Oct. 30 rose 39.4 percent, to $28.3 million, or $1.31 a share, from $20.3 million, or 96 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues climbed 28.4 percent, to $479.7 million, from $373.5 million. Mattel said that operating profit in the electronics division, mainly video games, more than doubled to $45 million, accounting for 63 percent of operating profit. **********But for its fourth quarter, which closes at the end of January, the toy-and-game company said it expects a loss, despite the fact that shipments of video game hardware and cartridges are likely to exceed levels of last year's fourth quarter. **********Among the reasons cited for the loss are the general retail industry slump and the stiff video game competition, which entails heavy promotional costs. Mattel has been offering a $50 rebate, recently reduced to $25, for purchase of its Intellivision game machine. Warner Falls Sharply **********Warner's shares plunged when trading on the Big Board was finally resumed yesterday afternoon following a halt at about 3 P.M.  Wednesday. However, over-the-counter trading had continued in the interim at levels around $36 a share. **********The company had said Wednesday that its earnings for the fourth quarter, ending Dec. 31, would be substantially below expectations - roughly 60 cents a share compared with $1.17 a share last year and $1.80 or so that analysts had been estimating. The company attributed the decline to lower-than-expected sales of video-game cartridges and coin-operated arcade games. The company also said that Perry Odak, president of the Atari division in charge of video games, had been relieved of all duties. **********Yesterday, Geoffrey Holmes, Warner vice president for investor relations, said Mr. Odak was still on the payroll although his new responsibilities had not been determined. He said Mr. Odak's removal from office was ''a question of management style and philosophy'' and ''had nothing to do with'' Atari's disappointing sales in the fourth quarter. 'Some Tough Questions' **********Not all analysts were convinced that Warner had told the whole story. ''There are going to be some tough questions to answer,'' said Harold Vogel of Merrill Lynch & Company. **********Meanwhile, other companies tried to disassociate themselves from the panic affecting video-game company stocks.  ''There's no reason why all of the stocks should be off,'' said Arnold C. Greenberg, Coleco's president and chief executive officer.  ''The business is healthy. It's just that Atari no longer has the overwhelming market share.'' **********Coleco, which entered the video game business this year, said it expects fourth-quarter sales to exceed record third-quarter sales of $165.6 million. It also said it has increased production of its new video game system, Colecovision, and expects to ship more than 500,000 in 1982. **********Coleco did not project earnings for the quarter or the year.  However, Mr. Greenberg said in an interview that analyst forecasts of $5.25 to $5.50 a share for the year, or $1.40 to $1.65 a share for the quarter, were reasonable. That would put fourth-quarter earnings below the $2.29 a share recorded in this year's third quarter, but it would be in sharp contrast to the loss of 9 cents a share in 1981's fourth period. Retailers' Sales **********Retailers also said game sales were good.  ''We got painted with the same brush; I don't know why, we're not even in the same business,'' said Garland P. Asher, director of financial planning for the Tandy Corporation, referring to the drop in Tandy's stock. Tandy sells Mattel's video system under its own name. He said the company's game cartridge sales were better than expected although they represented only a tiny part of Tandy's business. **********Toys ''R'' Us issued a statement saying the video game cartridge business has been ''very good'' this year and has continued that way during the Christmas season. **********Another company likely to be affected by the downturn in game stocks is Imagic, a fast-growing game-software company that had been planning to make its first public stock offering this month. William F.X. Grubb, president, said Imagic is assessing the situation. **********David J. Londoner, an analyst with Wertheim & Company, said the shrinkage in game-industry profits was inevitable, although it happened surprisingly swiftly. **********''I think the mistake Wall Street made,'' he said, ''is that they viewed this as a proprietary electronics business. It's the toy business. And the toy business does not get 24 to 25 percent pretax margins.''
