https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/10/world.main_headline: U.N. OPENS PHOTOGRAPHIC DISPLAY OF PALESTINIANS SLAIN IN MASSACRE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/10/world.print_headline: U.N. OPENS PHOTOGRAPHIC DISPLAY OF PALESTINIANS SLAIN IN MASSACRE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/10/world.body_text: **********A photographic exhibition showing Palestinians killed in Beirut refugee camps opened in the visitors' lobby here today after it had been approved by representatives of the Palestine Liberation Organization and Lebanon. **********The 15 photos show victims of the massacre in the Shatila and Sabra camps in September, some sprawled stiffly in streets, others in rows under blankets. One foreshortened picture portrays the corpse of a curly-headed child in sneakers. **********Yasushi Akashi of Japan, the United Nations Under Secretary General for Information, said the photographs demonstrated ''in its extremity, man's inhumanity to man, woman and child.'' **********The display, mounted by Mr. Akashi's department, does not try to fix responsibility for the killings. A caption says, ''Brutal Massacre in Beirut, Lebanon, September 16-18.'' It says, ''The killing began when armed groups entered'' the camps. **********Israeli officials, now conducting an inquiry into the massacre, have shown that the Israeli Army permitted Lebanese Christian militiamen into the camps and the Lebanese did the killing. Preview of the Display **********Last night, just before the exhibit opened, Mr. Akashi invited Zehdi Labib Terzi, the P.L.O. representative at the United Nations, and M. Fakhri Saghiyya, Lebanon's deputy delegate, to examine the display. United Nations officials said that if either had objected, the exhibition would have been delayed. **********Mr. Akashi, however, said the preview was ''just a courtesy'' that was extended because the event took place in Lebanon and the victims were Palestinians. Asked what he would have done if either had protested, he replied, ''I can't answer a hypothetical question.'' **********In a resolution condemning the massacre and Israel, the General Assembly on Sept. 24 ordered the Secretariat to erect the display. It will remain near the visitor's entrance until Nov. 19. **********In a related development, Mr. Akashi dismissed Israeli charges that a United Nations monthly, the UN Chronicle, was guilty of ''biased and unfair reporting'' of Israel's invasion of Lebanon. In a telephone conversation, the United Nations' public relations chief said he had not completed his reply to the complaint, ''but our findings so far have been that there was not any departure from the principles of impartiality.'' The Israeli Complaint **********The charge of bias came from Yehuda Z. Blum, the Israeli delegate, in a letter to Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar. Mr. Blum singled out the Chronicle's account and pictures in its October issue dealing with the events in Lebanon. **********Among other things, he complained of the magazine's reference to ''indiscriminate violence turned on the civilian population.'' He objected to a photograph showing cars passing a roadside stand and captioned, ''Beirut in happier days.'' This, said Mr. Blum, implied that Beirut had enjoyed peace until the Israeli Army came, although the city ''had already endured seven years of bloody civil war.'' **********Mr. Akashi's department, he said, ''has recently taken on the task of misinformation,'' and he asked that the October issue of the Chronicle be withdrawn.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/01/busin.body_text: **********Huge blue cranes began loading a Soviet ship today with British-made components for the natural gas pipeline that will run from Siberia to Western Europe. It is the second such shipment from Europe in defiance of President Reagan's attempts to block Western help for the project. **********At the George V Dock on the south bank of the River Clyde, Scottish longshoremen swarmed over a 4,000-ton freighter called the Stakhanovets Yermolenko, lowering into her hold crates half as big as boxcars containing the parts of six giant turbines. **********They are the first consignment of an order for 21 such turbines, worth $182 million to the manufacturer, John Brown Engineering. This company, with headquarters in Clydebank, just across the river, was ordered by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher to fulfill the contract despite Mr. Reagan's threats of punitive action and despite her friendship with the President. **********Aware of the Controversy **********Members of the 34-man Soviet crew were affable, welcoming reporters and photographers on board today and discussing the loading operation. Karp Srabov, the chief engineer, said he expected to complete the voyage to Leningrad by Sept. 15. **********Adolf Shikhov, the first officer, was asked whether he was aware of the international controversy surrounding his cargo and, if so, what he thought of it. **********''Of course, we are aware of the dispute,'' he replied. ''We read the newspapers, and we listen to the radio. But we just do our job.We take cargo to its port of destination. We leave the rest to others.'' **********This cargo consists of more than 500 cases totaling 2,000 tons. The biggest items - cylinders 20 feet long and big enough for a man to walk through -weigh more than 35 tons each. Each case bears this stenciled legend in both Roman and Cyrillic letters: ''For Machinoimport USSR Contract 50-0401-22007.'' **********Following the first such shipment of equipment last week - by Dresser France for Creusot-Loire - both the subsidiary of Americanbased D**ger Industries and the French company were placed on a trade blacklist by United States authorities. It was reported in Washington today, hk*ver, that senior Administration officials were recommending that the sanctiions be softened, both for the French and other European companies involved. Doubt About a Compromise **********Executives of John Brown Engineering, a subsidiary of John Brown & Company, said privately that they were dubious about the possibility of a compromise, as suggested over the weekend by Bill Brock, President Reagan's special trade representative. Nor could they shed light on unconfirmed reports that Mrs. Thatcher planned to compensate British companies affected by American punitive measures. **********The Prime Minister is to begin a tour of Scotland Wednesday and may discuss her plans at a meeting with trade union officials.  John Smith, the opposition Labor Party's spokesman on trade matters, said Sunday that Mrs. Thatcher should reject any compromise proposals, urged her to work toward a common Western European policy in opposition to that of the United States and argued that John Brown should be indemnified against losses because it was acting in defense of ''a vital national interest.'' **********The Soviet freighter, a trim four-year-old vessel with a black hull and white superstructure, arrived late Monday night after battling heavy seas on her way around the northern tip of Scotland. She will return via the English Channel to avoid the hard going. The ship was especially designed to handle heavy cargo, with two gantries and a loading ramp. Cooperation From Russians **********Loading began at 8 o'clock this morning. Ian McGarvey, an official of the Clyde Port Authority, said the Russians had been polite and cooperative, including helping with the press arrangements. He expressed some surprise at this. **********''I guess it's because all of this is one up for them,'' he said.  ''If it wasn't, none of us would get any closer to the ship than the pier.'' **********The sudden appearance in the last few days of six or seven fresh pipeline photographs from Tass, the Soviet press agency, also led to speculation that Moscow was being particularly responsive to Western requests. But at The Associated Press, which transmitted the photos, Hal Buell, A.P.'s general manager of news photos, said: ''We have over the months requested pictures periodically, and they had not come in. Suddenly they are forthcoming.'' **********The port of Glasgow has been hard hit by the development of container ships, which use the facilities at Greenock, closer to the mouth of the river. So the dock workers, as one heavily tatooed man put it, are ''damned glad of a week's work and not bothered where the stuff we handle goes.'' **********Much the same attitude prevails in Clydebank, which has watched the closure of one shipyard and factory after another in recent years.  Any loss of business by John Brown as a result of American action would cause great bitterness in the view of trade union leaders and politicians here. Criticism in British Press **********British newspapers, including those generally sympathetic to the United States and to President Reagan, such as The Daily Telegraph, have criticized American policy, calling it misguided. **********It may, in fact, be impossible for John Brown to complete its contract, whatever Mrs. Thatcher might wish. The turbines, which will push the gas along the pipeline, need rotors that are supplied by the General Electric Company in the United States. G.E. is unable to provide them because of American policy. Failure to complete the contract could subject John Brown to financial penalties and could cost the jobs of some of the 1,700 Clydebank workers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/09/world.print_headline: Quick Action Predicted On Mi cronesia's Status
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/09/world.body_text: **********The Reagan Administration said today that it hoped to work out ''in a relatively short period of time'' a political status of free association with Micronesia, one of the three major divisions of the Pacific islands, which are now under a United States-administered trusteeship. **********''I am confident that I shall be the last such representative whom any President will need to appoint,'' Fred Zeder 3d told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Mr. Zeder has been nominated by President Reagan as the United States negotiator in the talks on the future political status of the Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands. **********Mr. Zeder, a former director of the Interior Department's Office of Territorial Affairs, said that he ''will not attempt to estimate a date for the completion of these negotiations, which have been going on for over 12 years.'' **********''I believe, however, that the apparent good will and determination I have noticed on the part of all participants indicates that we should be able to complete the task in a relatively short period of time,'' he said. **********He said that the Administration ''prefers the political status of free association, as embodied in the compact initialed in 1980'' by those islands and the United States. **********The 1980 Compact of Free Association referred to by Mr. Zeder was signed by the United States and the Governments of the Palau Islands, the Marshall Islands and the Federated States of Micronesia.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/05/busin.body_text: **********The decline in stock prices accelerated yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 12.94 points, to 803.46, a four-week low. **********The drop marked the Dow's biggest loss in more than five months. **********Analysts said a variety of worries contributed to the erosion of investor confidence, including reaction to an apparent leveling off of interest rates. On the domestic front, the market drop also reflected concern over the slack economy and the uncertain fate in Congress of a tax bill intended to reduce deficits by raising $98.5 billion during the next three fiscal years. Overseas, worries centered on the intensified Israeli attacks on Beirut. **********''Many people appear to be throwing in the towel, although the selling today was not particularly aggressive,'' said Jack Baker, who heads equity trading at the First Boston Corporation. ''A number of institutions pulled their bids to buy stock below current prices and that weakened the market.'' Volume Is Moderate **********Volume was moderate, at 53.4 million shares, down from Tuesday's 60.5 million. However, several block traders at brokerage houses predicted that the trading pace could increase today, particularly if the industrial average drops below 800. **********Losses were especially apparent in the energy, defense, technology, drug, computer, railroad, airline, brokerage and utility sectors.  The market's setback followed a drop of 5.71 points on Tuesday and provided a sharp contrast to Monday's advance of 13.51 points in the industrial average. Monday's rise matched the Dow's best gain in four months. View on Interest Rates **********The broad upswing Monday was attributed to a decline in interest rates, which did not continue Tuesday and yesterday. Mr. Baker summed up the sentiment of numerous market professionals when he said, ''There are signs that the bulk of the interest rate decline - for the present, at least -may be behind us.'' **********One specific piece of news served to unhinge whatever fragile confidence remained yesterday. Shortly before 3 P.M., the Manville Corporation said its directors had voted to omit the quarterly dividend. At 2:30 P.M., the industrial average had been down only 5.90 points. Manville, formerly Johns-Manville, has suffered from the slowdown in the housing market and recently reported a loss for its June quarter. Its shares fell 1 1/8, to 8 1/8. **********The issue is among the 30 components of the Dow industrial average. ''Now we have two Dow stocks -Manville and International Harvester - that don't pay dividends,'' pointed out William M. LeFevre, market strategist at Purcell, Graham & Company. ''I can't recall a similar instance since the end of World War II.'' **********Only 383 issues advanced in price on the New York Stock Exchange, while 1,088 stocks finished lower. Yesterday's setback in the Dow industrials was the biggest since a decline of 13.04 points on Feb.  22, when the average finished at 811.26. Subsequent upswings in the market have been blunted by high interest rates. Tektronix Off Sharply **********Tektronix Inc., a leading producer of cathode ray oscilloscopes, plunged 3 5/8 points, to 38 5/8. Some analysts have reduced their earnings estimates for the company and there were reports that one leading analyst changed his rating from ''buy'' to ''hold.'' **********Amid trader fears of a possible price war in home computers, Warner Communications dropped 2 points, to 39 1/4, in heavy trading. This brought its loss so far this week to 5 3/4 points. There were declines exceeding 2 points in such issues as Pfizer, General Dynamics, Texas Instruments and Motorola. **********Hanna Mining fell 1 1/8, to 17, after reporting sharply lower Junequarter profits and reducing its quarterly dividend to 35 cents from 50 cents. **********Avon Products continued to weaken, declining 3/4, to 20 3/8.  Directors are scheduled to meet today and there is conjecture in Wall Street that the quarterly dividend may be cut - possibly to 50 cents a share - from the 75-cent payment that has been declared since June 1980. **********JWT Group, whose subsidiaries include the J. Walter Thompson advertising agency, fell 1 1/2, to 17 1/2. The company forecast that 1982 earnings will run below last year's results. Howell Jumped **********Scoring the Big Board's best percentage gain was Howell Petroleum, which jumped 3 7/8, to 13 3/4. Reports circulated that the company had discovered a wildcat well in the Gulf of Mexico. Howell Corporation, which controls Howell Petroleum, rose 2 points, to 8 7/8. **********In over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index fell 1.41, to 166.56. This marked its lowest closing since 166.52 on July 14, 1980. This index, consisting of about 3,000 domestic common stocks, set a high of 223.47 on May 29, 1981. **********The American Stock Exchange's market value index retreated 3.27, to 247.85, reflecting a continued pullback in energy issues. Dome Petroleum, the volume leader, slipped 1/4, to 3 3/4. One year ago, it traded at a record of 21 1/4, adjusted for a stock split.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/05/busin.body_text: **********From his ninth-floor command post at 1801 K Street N.W., Raymond Garcia scans a list of 52 House and Senate Budget Committee members, then buzzes his assistant, Alexis Piper.  ''Prepare the Action Alert,'' he orders. **********Carrot-haired, slightly broad of girth in middle age, with steel blue eyes glinting in the excitement of a fresh campaign, Mr. Garcia has just begun to turn up the heat from one of the city's newest ''coalitions'' - the superlobbies that are organizing to influence legislation, especially in the trade sector. **********What distinguishes Mr. Garcia's organization, the Coalition for Employment Through Exports, and other coalitions from the simpler, more socially oriented lobbies of the past is the breadth of their constituency, usually spanning the gap between labor and management. **********Action Alert is a memorandum that is hand-delivered from staff headquarters of the coalition to the line officers - legislative directors of 40 large and medium-size companies, 14 labor unions and three Governors. The objective is to coordinate a campaign of letter writing, Mailgram sending, telephone calling, legislative visiting and some party giving to get more direct lending authority for the Export-Import Bank. **********''We want to prevent our members from tripping all over each other on Capitol Hill so that when we lobby, we can lobby effectively,'' said Mr. Garcia, executive director of the coalition and a longtime participant in earlier export wars as former vice president of the Emergency Committee for American Trade. **********''Wining and dining are less important these days,'' he added. ''In fact, they're a real pain, especially for younger legislators who merely want to go home in the evenings. What counts is coming up with a persuasive case.'' **********Other superlobbies have such names as the Labor Industry Coalition for International Trade (called Licit), the Group of 33 (33 trade organizations and unions seeking more effective enforcement of laws against unfair trade), the Leather Products Coalition (three unions and four trade associations resisting competition from the projected duty-free zone in the Caribbean Basin) and the Committee for the Preservation of American Color Television (known as Compact). **********That they are mushrooming in the trade sector, noted Lawrence B.  Krause, senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, is a reflection of the growing role of international trade in the economy. Imports and exports now account for about 15 percent of the gross national product, twice the percentage a decade ago. ''It's an area where Government policy matters -matters a lot,'' Mr. Krause said. ''There are issues for labor and management to rally around.'' 'Closer Meeting of Minds' **********Stanley Nehmer, an economist advising coalitions seeking tougher import enforcement, added: ''With a $40 billion trade deficit, and all that that means for employment and profitability, a closer meeting of minds between labor and management is a natural reaction.'' **********The Coalition for Employment Through Exports, which held an organizational meeting attended by 140 company, union and state government lobbyists last April 29 at the Mayflower Hotel, is mobilized to fight on a single issue: the Reagan Administration's proposed cutback in direct lending authority of the Export-Import Bank to $3.8 billion in the fiscal year 1983 from $5.4 billion in 1981 and $4.4 billion in 1982. **********The bank, started as a Government agency in 1934, seeks to encourage the exporting of American goods and services, primarily by offering loans to foreign importers at below-market interest rates. **********Other industrial countries have similar institutions to foster their own exports and have managed on a number of occasions to offer more competitive - or, in effect, more heavily subsidized - financing, winning orders from such companies (and coalition members) as Boeing, General Electric, Westinghouse and Caterpillar Tractor and from such smaller companies as Frederick Electronics and Gould Pumps.  Labor Unions' Involvement **********Labor has joined because of fears that American multinational companies, to obtain more competitive financing, will fill export orders from their foreign subsidiaries instead of domestic plants.  This has already led to some job losses for Americans, according to a recent survey by the Machinery and Allied Products Institute. In a poll of 39 companies, it found that in 1981 contracts worth $386.7 million were shifted to foreign affiliates primarily because better financing terms were available. **********Mr. Garcia, noting that every $1 billion lost in United States exports means 30,000 fewer job opportunities, distributes lists of the lost contracts. The lists show, for example, the failure of the Boeing Company to sell six 757's to Singapore Airlines because interest rates at least three percentage points lower were offered by the European Airbus consortium. There was also the Japanese defeat of a General Electric Company bid to sell Venezuela medium-steam turbines, again because of substantially better credit terms. **********The opposition to the Export-Import Bank, which is now losing money in its efforts to meet some of the foreign competition, comes from deep inside the Reagan Administration, mainly from David A. Stockman, the budget director, and from those in Congress opposed to subsidies for companies while social programs are being cut back. Budget Director's Rationale **********In his interview in the December 1981 issue of The Atlantic that drew so much attention, Mr. Stockman explained that he felt it politically necessary to cut the Ex-Im Bank because it gave the impression that he was dealing with business and social programs evenhandedly. **********''If we're ever caught not cutting this while we're biting deeply into the social programs, we're going to have big problems,'' Mr.  Stockman said. ''I've got to take something out of Boeing's hide to make this look right.'' **********Boeing's president, Malcolm T. Stamper, a leader in the coalition, replied to Mr. Stockman with some passion in a recent speech: ''Too bad he didn't know at the time that taking it out of Boeing's hide meant the useless sacrifice of jobs not only at Boeing but also throughout our 3,000 supplier network in 44 states.'' **********The identification of exports with jobs has brought such labor organizations into the coalition as the United Automobile Workers, the Communications Workers of America, the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers and the Seafarers International Union of North America. **********''We cannot allow foreign governments to impair the ability of our exporters to compete effectively in world markets while we declare unilateral disarmament by cutting Ex-Im to the bone,'' said Frank Drozak, president of the Seafarers Union. **********Governors Bob Graham of Florida, Lee Dreyfus of Wisconsin and John Spellman of Washington also joined, noting the importance of farm and industrial exports to their states. **********Mr. Garcia and his legislative directors are now putting their main lobbying efforts behind a budget amendment to lift the Ex-Im lending ceiling to $4.7 billion from $3.8 billion. He expects many more Action Alerts before the battle over the bank's future has ended.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/28/busin.body_text: **********The Consolidated Rail Corporation said today that it lost $25.7 million in the first quarter, the smallest loss for that period in the railroad's six-year history. **********In the comparable 1981 quarter, Conrail lost $65.9 million. **********Firstquarter revenue fell 14.2 percent, to $944.2 million, from $1.1 billion. **********Conrail, which until the third quarter of 1981 had been federally subsidized, said carloadings - the number of freight cars filled with a particular commodity - were down 22 percent this quarter from the comparable 1981 period. **********Declines were recorded in iron and steel carloadings, which dropped 33.7 percent; automobiles and automobile parts, down 27.9 percent; chemicals, down 22.7 percent, and coal, down 16.7 percent. **********''Providing that there is no significant further deterioration of the economy, Conrail should be able to continue its progress this year toward its goal of profitability,'' L. Stanley Crane, chairman and chief executive, said in a statement. **********''Our results for the rest of 1982 depend heavily on the nation's recovery from the recession, although our ability to bring costs into line with revenues is improving constantly,'' Mr. Crane said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/12/busin.body_text: **********The receiver for AEG-Telefunken said today the plans to settle AEG's debt are feasible and the management proposals can bring about a recovery. **********The receiver, Wilhelm Andreas Schaaf, made the statement after talks with the management board and workers at the company Tuesday and today and after reviewing company documents. **********The AEG proposal, announced Monday, calls for settlement of debts outstanding by paying large creditors 40 percent of what they are owed. **********Those with claims of less than the equivalent of $4,000 would be paid in full, and legal sources said that would mean that creditors due up to $10,000 would effectively be paid at a higher rate than 40 percent. **********The statement gave no indication of the size of the claims on AEG under discussion, but banking sources said more than $2.4 billion in liabilities need to be settled. **********The bulk of these fall upon AEG's 25 principal banks, which the sources said have in the main accepted the management prosposal.  Foreign creditors are due to meet Thursday in Zurich. Banking sources here said it was by no means clear that they would be willing to go along with the plan as easily as the domestic banks involved.  Under German corporate law, more than half of the number of creditors representing at least 80 percent of the debt have to agree.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/03/busin.body_text: **********Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith has long shaken its fist at competitors for ''raiding'' its offices and luring away top account executives. **********Last week, it won $250,000 from Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. for ''pirating away'' four of its star employees in New Orleans, as Morrell Trimble, head of that office, put it. **********But how aggressive is Merrill itself in recruiting from competition?  In a memorandum dated Nov.2, 1981, the president of Merrill Lynch Commodities, Richard G. Freeburg, listed ''assignments'' for Stephen Greenberg, who had just left Bear, Stearns & Company, where he managed commodity funds, to join Merrill Lynch. Among them were these: **********- ''You will develop a list of account executives with the competition that might be vulnerable to recruiting and give that list to me by 11/18.'' **********- ''You will work with Guy DiCarlo in an effort to update our competitive file with Bear, Stearns and other firms that you are familiar with.'' **********- ''You will develop a list of prospective customers that might be better served at Merrill Lynch and work with Bob Rossi, Jerry Spielman and me in selecting a proper office or account executives for those accounts.'' **********Mr. Greenberg, reached in his office on Friday, said, ''That's an interoffice memo; you've got something that you shouldn't have; I have no comment.'' **********Mr. Freeburg did not return phone calls. Several others mentioned in the memorandum declined to comment. But, later, the chairman of Merrill Lynch Commodities, John J. Conheeney, telephoned to say: ''I have in my hand a memo written by Richard Freeburg to Stephen Greenberg dated Nov. 2, 1981. All brokerage firms are always in a position to hire people in other firms by offering them normal opportunities. It's normal activity.'' **********''What Drexel did was 'group raiding,' '' James Flynn, a spokesman for Merrill Lynch, contended. In that incident, Drexel Burnham opened a branch in New Orleans and hired four local Merrill account executives. **********Merrill charged that the executives copied company records and solicited customers for Drexel, even before they had quit Merrill Lynch. **********Merrill's approach ''is not at all akin to recruiting a unit that puts another firm out of business regionally,'' Mr. Conheeney added.  He admitted, however, that Merrill's New Orleans unit was not ''put out of business.'' **********Discussing the recipient of the memorandum, Mr. Greenberg, Mr.  Conheeney said: ''Stephen is a fellow who's been in the commodity business all his life; he's had important positions; he knows a lot of people personally. It was a natural for us to ask him to come and tell us who would be likely candidates.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/11/busin.body_text: **********SPECULATORS in Australian oil shares hope that a growing exploration effort Down Under will lead to big profits. Australia has been encouraging exploration to reduce its dependence on Saudi Arabian oil, which now accounts for about 35 percent of what the nation uses. Virtually all of Australia's domestic oil comes from the Gippsland Basin in the southeast. **********Promising areas under development are the Cooper Basin in the eastcentral region, the waters of Bonaparte Gulf in northwestern Australia and, south of there, the Canning Basin. A fourth area is the Amadeus Basin in the nation's heartland. **********These projects could reduce Australian dependence on Arab oil someday, but rising consumption could outpace discoveries for years to come. The Government adopted a pricing policy in 1976 that was intended to stimulate exploration. **********Before that, Australian oil cost $2.60 a barrel in the Gippsland Basin. Under the incentive plan, newly discovered oil was priced at ever-rising prices until parity with Saudi Arabian light crude was reached in 1980. Newly discovered oil sells at $32.25, which is equivalent to $35.50 a barrel in United States dollars. **********Australian oil companies have announced through their trade association that they plan to drill 302 exploration wells and 102 development wells this year. In 1981 they drilled 149 exploration wells and 55 development wells. **********But Trevor Jones of the Wall Street branch of Rivkin Securities, an Australian brokerage firm, says there are not enough rigs to drill that many wells, and he believes the total will fall far short of 404 wells. He expects it to be closer to 280 or 300. **********Anthony Mitchell, another native of Australia, is with the Drysdale Securities Corporation at 55 Water Street. He is urging his firm's retail clients to seek capital gains in the Australian oil and gas boom. In the four promising basins, he notes, one out of every four wells drilled was a success in the last quarter of 1981. **********Mr. Jones agrees that a continuing exploration and development effort is essential because the Gippsland producing fields are expected to peak in the late 1980's, barring new discoveries. **********Major discoveries are certainly possible. Mr. Mitchell said superior American seismic technology had contributed to the success ratio in the Gippsland Basin, where new techniques applied to old seismic data have led to successful drilling. **********Mr. Mitchell said that, if the unusually high success ratio in the new fields continued, American and Canadian rigs would arrive in increasing numbers and the drilling pace would intensify. **********Shares of Australian oil companies are depressed at this time. The Australian oil and gas price index fell 27 percent in 1981, and so far this year it has declined a further 10 percent, to 600. **********With the stock prices at low levels, Australian companies are straining to raise much-needed equity capital. Some have had to sell exploration rights to large American companies, Mr. Mitchell said. **********Even so, he says he believes shares of many Australian companies are poised for substantial capital appreciation. Although his firm does not recommend specific issues, h e said S antos Ltd., BHP and Offshore Oil Ltd. seemed well positioned. Int erests in these companies are available in this country's ove r-the-counter market through the medium of American depositary rec eipts. **********Mr. Mitchell is particu larly impressed with the prospects of Alliance Oil Development Ltd., which is ''in all the highly promising oil and gas producing areas in Australia.'' **********But there are no A.D.R.'s for this stock. American investors can purchase the shares through a street-name account in Australia. The idea of shares being held in a broker's office 12,000 miles away may discourage some people, but the alternative - actual delivery of the shares in the United States - takes six to eight weeks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/22/world.print_headline: IN THE NAMIBIA TALKS, A NEW APPROACH
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/22/world.body_text: **********The five Western nations that have been trying to mediate between South Africa and the South-West Africa People's Organization appear to be revising their tactics in an effort to revive the stalled negotiations on an independence plan. **********When they laid out the ground rules for their latest initiative last year, the Western nations said that the negotiations would be divided into three phases and that agreement from both sides would be needed at each stage before formal proposals were made to resolve the issues in the next one. **********That approach failed this month when the insurgents spurned both a proposed voting formula for the election of a constituent assembly and the phase-by-phase approach itself. Now, according to Western diplomatic sources, drafting is under way on the proposals for the next phase, which concern the machinery for enforcing a cease-fire and the role of a United Nations peacekeeping force. **********Present indications are that these proposals will adhere closely to plans originally drawn up by the United Nations four years ago and will not reflect major concessions to South Africa. A Complex Voting Formula **********The South-West Africa People's Organization, it appears, will then be asked to reconsider the voting issue in the context of this broader proposal -an approach that would implicitly promise that the negotiations might be concluded fairly rapidly. **********There is no indication that South Africa has agreed to reconsider the complex voting formula, which would mix the proportional representation system of voting with direct election on the basis of defined constituencies. But there is speculation that South Africa has agreed to help speed up the negotiations by dropping its major objections to the old United Nations plan. **********These were stressed at the start of last year, when the United Nations got the major sides in the dispute on Namibia, as the territory is also known, to a conference table in Geneva in an effort to win agreement on a cease-fire date. **********South Africa then said it would be impossible to discuss a date until the United Nations demonstrated its ''impartiality'' by rescinding an old General Assembly resolution recognizing the insurgent movement as the ''sole and authentic representative'' of the Namibian people. Some Issues Seem to Be Fading **********South African diplomats later insisted that they could not agree to the stationing of a United Nations force in the former German colony, which South Africa received under a League of Nations mandate after World War I. **********Now ''impartiality'' and the role of the United Nations force appear to be fading as issues. South African officials decline to confirm a press report from London that they have already accepted the proposals for the next phase, pointing out that the proposals have yet to be presented to them formally. But last year's major issues, which were expected to be the big stumbling blocks to the present initiative, are now discussed as if they were minor. **********If this stance is maintained, there will be heavy pressure on the South-West Africa People's Organization to put aside its objections on a voting formula in order to achieve a cease-fire that would end the guerrilla struggle in the northern part of the territory.  Otherwise, the movement will have cast itself in the role of the recalcitrant party, which South Africa formerly played. **********The movement's reasons for objecting to the voting formula have been about as obscure as South Africa's reasons for insisting on it.  But it appears that the movement was pput off by a pattern it discerned in the negotiations, in which the Reagan Administration seemed to it to be tailoring the tactics of the Western group to accommodate South Africa. White Representation in Assembly **********South Africa's reasons for insisting on the mixed voting system, in which each ballot would, in effect, be counted twice, seemed to result from two conflicting aims. One is to insure that right-wing whites supporting the National Party in the territory are represented in the assembly that would draft the constitution for an independent Namibia. **********Since the whites are almost everywhere outnumbered by blacks, this can only be insured under the proportional representation system. But that also happens to be the system that most favors the South-West Africa People's Organization, whose support is thought to be heavily concentrated in the northern part of the country. **********Since it is South Africa's other main aim to see that the insurgents fall short of the two-thirds vote that would be necessary to control the assembly, it follows that it also favors the system of direct voting as a way of diluting the movement's support.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/02/world.body_text: **********The United States support in the confrontation with Argentina was received in Britain today with enormous gratitude and a sense of relief at the sight of two old allies back in the same corner. **********''Yanks A Million,'' screamed The Sun, the country's largest circulation newspaper, in a front-page headline; The Times made the same point more sedately in an editorial titled, ''A Friend Indeed.'' And in sun-drenched Trafalgar Square, a welder named Robert Leland, who with his two young sons was feeding the pigeons, said: **********''It's one of those times, isn't it, when you've got to stand up for what's right just because it's right. That's what we've done over there in the Falklands, and we're glad to have the Americans in it with us.'' **********Throughout the weeks that Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.  was acting as a mediator between Argentina and Britain, spokesmen for the Government here said repeatedly that they understood the necessity for the United States to avoid siding with one or the other, in order to retain the confidence of both. Time and again, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher went out of her way to praise Mr.  Haig, calling him tireless and his peace mission splendid. U.S. Had Been Criticized **********But the public - and some opposition Members of Parliament - did not always see it that way. In one of the earlier debates on the Falklands crisis, David Owen, the foreign affairs spokesman of the new Social Democratic Party, criticized the United States with the observation that ''it is not possible to be neutral between the fire and the fire brigade.'' **********Prime Minister Thatcher has been a particularly strong ally of the United States during her three years in office. When the American hostages were being held in Iran, Britain's support was unswerving, and just last month it was the only Western European country to send observers to the election in El Salvador, doing so at the behest of the United States. **********In recent weeks, Mrs. Thatcher made it clear several times that she expected the United States to support Britain strongly in the Falklands crisis if its mediation effort ended. When that finally happened Friday, Foreign Secretary Francis Pym, speaking for the Government, said: **********''The British people are deeply grateful to the United States. I am extremely glad that the United States has come down decisively on the side of Britain.'' **********In common with several other newspapers, The Times pointed out in its editorial today that the United States decision to impose sanctions against Argentina would raise difficulties for it elsewhere in the Western Hemisphere. But that made the decision all the more admirable, it said, thus gaining the Americans support on this side of the Atlantic. 'Generous and Wholehearted' **********''The decision must be reassuring elsewhere in Europe,'' The Times said, ''showing as it does that when it comes to the hard point, the United States is a friend and ally which can be counted on.'' **********The Guardian said that President Reagan had had a ''stinking choice -between the old ally across the water and the new ally at the toe of the Americas'' and called the decision that the United States made ''both generous and wholehearted.'' **********In the month since the Argentine invasion, Britons have got over the wry amusement with which they first viewed the Falklands crisis.  But some of their comments on it are still tinged with a sense of unreality that the British fleet is really involved in such an adventure so far away. **********That spirit, coupled with the lingering British bemusement at the idea of having a former movie star for President of the United States, was reflected in the paragraph with which The Sun began its front-page story today: **********''Good old Ronald Reagan finally came galloping over the hill yesterday to stand by Britain in its war with Argentina.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/27/busin.body_text: **********To the Business Editor: You do an excellent job of pointing out the shortcomings of an economic and cultural system that many American managers have come to view with uncritical awe. However, you failed to present an effective argument for the point persistently implied: that the Japanese economy cannot continue to prosper if it maintains its present course of development. **********The forte of the Japanese has been to select high-volume, highvalue manufactured products and produce them more carefully and efficiently than anyone else. Their goods are commonly cheaper, of higher quality and more reliably delivered than those of their foreign competitors. Understandably, consumers do not care that the Japanese did not invent the internal combustion engine, the cathode ray tube, the transistor or magnetic recording tape. People buy Japanese televisions, cars, radios, and VCR's because they are relatively inexpensive, they operate reliably and they incorporate the latest features. **********The simple question is, why can this not continue? The Japanese may prove incapable of inventing the next wave of new products, but it is not clear that they need to. Good inventions are often snapped up by others before they reach their peak revenue years. **********The Japanese have stumbled before, and they may do so increasingly if new product technology becomes more turbulent. But it may be wrong to think that a country can prosper by being merely creative. Even if we have created a market by inventing its product, we only hold on to it and profit from it by aggressively pressing the development of product improvements and superior manufacturing methods. These are the areas in which the United States has faltered so disappointingly in recent decades.  PIETER VANDER WERF Cambridge, Mass.  June 18, 1982  ---------------------------------------------------------------------  The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters for publication should include the writer's name, address and telephone number.  Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Business Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/03/busin.print_headline: I.B.M. WILL RENT TIME ON ITS UNITS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/03/busin.body_text: **********The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday announced its re-entry into the remote computer services business.  Under the new service, customers will be able to rent time on I.B.M. computers in Tampa, Fla., and have the use of more than 100 programs stored on those units. **********I.B.M. has been out of the services business, called time-sharing, because of an agreement that settled a private antitrust suit against it by the Control Data Corporation. In that 1973 agreement, I.B.M.  transferred its Service Bureau Corporation, which provided such services, to Control Data and agreed to stay out of the business in the United States until 1979. It is no secret that I.B.M. has been anxious to return. **********''It's a low-cost, low-visibility way to enter the business,'' said Thomas J. Crotty, an analyst with the Gartner Group in Stamford, Conn. ''It's really a tip-of-the-iceberg kind of thing. Nobody knows what's below the surface, but it's huge.'' **********''In the short term, they're offering something very limited,'' said Arthur J. Marks, v ice president of marketing of the General Electric Info rmation Services Company. G.E. is one of the current leaders in th e time-sharing business, along with Control Data, Automatic Dat a Processing and Boeing Computer Services. Total sales of the proces sing services business was $9.7 billion in 1981, according to Input Inc., a Palo Alto, Calif., research firm. **********Analysts explained that I.B.M. was offering computer time and generalized programs, such as financial planning and text editing.  Much of the orientation is geared to helping programmers in large data processing centers. **********By contrast, many computer service companies are moving away from those basic services and providing specific industry packages, such as those designed for banks, hospitals or manufacturers. While I.B.M.'s new service offers no such programs, analysts expect I.B.M.  to move that way soon. **********I.B.M. is also expected to offer more data communications functions, such as electronic mail, bringing it into competition with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. **********The I.B.M. service, called the I.B.M. Information Network, is available now in seven metropolitan areas - New York, Atlanta, Chicago, Dallas, San Francisco, Washington and Tampa. **********Jerome L. Dreyer, president of the Association of Data Processing Service Organizations, which represents computer processing companies, said that his group has questions about the legality of I.B.M.'s re-entry. **********Under a 1956 consent decree that settled a previous Federal antitrust suit, I.B.M. was r equired to operat e its Service Bureau Corporation, later sold to Control Data, as a separate subsidiary notsubsidized by revenues from other I.B.M. prod ucts. That decree is still in effect, he said. Mr. Dreyer added th at his group's members want to insure that I.B.M. does not cross-sub sidize its services. **********An I.B.M. spokesman, Richard E. Coyle, said that the new information network is different from the Service Bureau Corporation and is thus not affected by the 1956 consent decree.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/30/busin.body_text: **********WASHINGTON FIVE men who received notable United States patents will be inducted into the National Inventors Hall of Fame at the Patent and Trademark Office, Arlington, Va., on Feb. 7. One inventor selected posthumously is Henry Ford, who will be honored for a patent entitled ''Transmission Mechanism,'' which was granted him in 1911. **********Besides the automotive field, electronic, printing and mechanical areas are represented. Another posthumous inductee is Ernest O.  Lawrence, who got a 1934 patent on ''Method and Apparatus for the Acceleration of Ions.'' A third posthumous inductee is Ottmar Mergenthaler, a German-born Baltimore resident who got one patent in 1885 on ''Machine for Producing Printing Bars'' and another in 1894 for a ''Machine for Producing Linotypes, Type-Matrices, etc.'' **********Jack S. Kilby of Dallas will be honored for a 1964 patent on ''Miniaturized Electronic Circuits.'' Prof. Max Tishler of Wesleyan University, Middletown, Conn., was selected for his 1941 patent on synthesizing riboflavin and another issued in 1946 for an antibiotic. **********A committee representing many technical societies made the selections for the National Inventors Hall of Fame Foundation, of which Frederick B. Ziesenheim, a Pittsburgh patent attorney, is president. The first inductee was Thomas A. Edison, chosen in 1973 when the foundation was organized. **********The inductions will be made on the second day of an exposition at which many inventions will be displayed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/03/world.print_headline: KENYA'S UNIVERSITIES ARE CLOSED; GOVERNMENT SEARCHES FOR REBELS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/03/world.body_text: **********The authorities closed down the nation's two universities today, deployed heavily armed troops around key intersections in Nairobi and began a house-to-house search for rebels after an unsuccessful attempt Sunday to overthrow President Daniel arap Moi. **********Some of the rebels, identified by Mr. Moi as junior air force officers, were reported by the police to be holding out early today at Eastleigh, an airfield near the center of Nairobi. Tonight, the Government said it had extended the deadline for rebels to surrender until noon Tuesday from noon today. The Government said those refusing to surrender would be dealt with ''ruthlessly.'' **********Hospital officials said 90 people had been killed in fighting Sunday and up to 500 were wounded. But apart from occasional shots, Nairobi seemed quiet by late afternoon today, with Government troops in control of the city center. The Government Sunday night imposed a curfew from 6 P.M. to 7 A.M. No Sign of President **********President Moi, who succeeded Jomo Kenyatta four years ago, was spending the weekend at his country residence 120 miles north of here when the disturbances broke out. In a brief message late Sunday afternoon, broadcast in Swahili, he said he was still in control and urged Kenya's 15 million people to remain calm. **********By midafternoon today, however, the President had not made a public appearance.  The state radio, announcing the closing of the universities, broadcast instructions to all people living in the countryside to report to their local chiefs - apparently part of the measures designed by the authorities to track down the ringleaders of the attempted coup. **********The Government radio today urged people to report for work as usual, but at the hour when offices normally open, the situation in the capital was tense. **********This morning, automatic gunfire echoed between the city's highrise office blocks and hotels. The shooting, police sources said, may have been the work of soldiers deterring looters or pursuing rebels. Many shops and stores had been looted. Citizens Keep Hands Held High **********Ordinary Kenyans, on their way to work, marched with their hands held well above their heads to reassure the army and police patrols on the streets that they were neither looters nor rebels. **********The army deployed soldiers at main intersections and strategic installations such as the central post office. The soldiers, carrying Western-made weapons, searched cars and checked the identity papers of most travelers. Witnesses in areas populated mainly by poor Kenyans said the police and the soldiers were going from house to house, looking for air force rebels who had discarded their uniforms and gone into hiding. **********Soldiers also took up positions around university campuses and hostels, homes to the students who came out Sunday in favor of the attempted coup. **********The coup failed when loyalist officers, led by the deputy army commander, recaptured the Government radio station in downtown Nairobi and routed the plotters. 4 Officers Fled to Tanzania **********Officials said four officers involved in the attempted coup had seized an aircraft and flown it to Dar es Salaam, the Tanzanian capital, when the plan began to falter Sunday at around noon. **********The four officers were reportedly being questioned by Tanzanian officials today and it was not clear whether they would be granted asylum by President Julius Nyerere's Government, a Socialist administration whose relations with pro-Western Kenya are strained. **********The air force men were apparently from the same unit that seized the Embakasi Air Force Base on the ouskirts of Nairobi Sunday and twice flew over the Kenyan capital in jet fighters during the hostilities. **********On the approaches to the downtown area, many cars, buses and trucks blocked the road after being abandoned by their drivers during Sunday's unrest. A witness said he had seen some looters shot dead by loyalist forces. U.S. Backs Government **********WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (Reuters) -The State Department said today that it was gratified Kenya's civilian Government under President Daniel arap Moi apparently had survived an attempted coup. **********Alan Romberg, the spokesman, said: ''We consider Kenya a good and close friend. We continue to support President Moi and the democratically established Government of Kenya.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/16/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Communications Commission today authorized five companies to construct new digital electronic message services that would permit long-distance communications companies to bypass local phone companies in completing data transmissions. **********The new service will be aimed almost entirely at big corporations and other organizations that send and receive large amounts of data, usually through computer-to-computer transmissions. Until now, these transmissions have crossed the country on long-distance lines such as those of the American Telephone & Telegraph Company and MCI Communications Corporation, the nation's second-largest long-distance telephone company. The long-distance networks have been interconnected with local phone company lines to originate and complete each transmission. **********Phone Bottlenecks **********The slower local phone systems have often been bottlenecks for users of high-speed data transmission systems, according to a spokesman for MCI Communications, one of the companies that received approval today. **********The F.C.C. action would affect only a very small part of local phone company revenue. Because it involves very specialized transmissions, the F.C.C. ruling is not expected to set a precedent in the more general issue of permitting long-distance phone companies to bypass local companies in delivering voice transmissions. **********Access charges for voice-grade transmissions are now an important part of local phone company revenue, including the revenue of the 22 Bell system companies that are to be divested under the antitrust settlement announced in January. Once divested, these companies will count on access charges to long-distance phone companies to help pay the costs of local phone service. **********In addition to MCI, those authorized by the F.C.C. for the new service are ISA Communications Services Inc., Satellite Business Systems, the Contemporary Communications Corporation and Tymnet Inc.  All five are capable of using satellites or microwave facilities for transmission. They are planning to build networks that will serve 30 cities. **********In granting today's authorizations, the commission turned aside contentions by two rival companies that ISA should be barred on the ground that it is owned by a wireline, or traditional, telephone company, United Telecommunications Inc. **********The commission had said that it was concerned that wireline phone companies entering the electronic message market might use their monopoly of local wireline distribution in particular cities to restrict access to a network by competing message services. In the applications approved today, however, the F.C.C. found that none had designed a system that included interconnection with local wireline distribution. The five companies will construct local microwave systems to interconnect with their existing long-distance networks. Other Applicants on File **********The circuitry for the system authorized today would be owned and operated by the licensed companies. A number of additional applications are on file and the commisssion said it would act quickly on them. **********A total of 13 operating licenses are available in every metropolitan area, the commission said. The companies would likely operate simultaneously in many areas. **********Gary Tobin, the spokesman for MCI here, said the authorization of the message service, and particularly the approval of digital termination systems, would allow the long-distance companies to build efficient high-speed local distribution connections for data. **********''It is a relatively small business now and generates few revenues,'' Mr. Tobin said, ''but all of us hope the new high-speed capability, end-to-end, will prove more attractive to potential customers.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/01/world.body_text: **********Argentina's President-designate, who takes office Thursday, has selected a Cabinet of nine civilians and one military officer. **********The Cabinet list, announced by the Government late Tuesday, appears in keeping with the army's promise to return the country to civilian rule by the end of the new President's term in March 1984. **********The new President, Maj. Gen. Reynaldo Bignone, a retired army officer, succeeds Maj. Gen. Alfredo St. Jean, an interim chief of state, who took over when Lieut. Gen. Leopoldo Galtieri was forced to resign two weeks ago after the Argentine defeat by Britain in the war over the Falkland Islands. **********The single Cabinet post to be held by an army man will be the Interior Ministry, which oversees the police and political activities. It goes to Maj. Gen. Llamil Reston, a former Labor Minister accustomed to working with labor and political leaders. Reaction Is Guarded **********A Harvard-educated economist, Jose Maria Dagnino Pastore, is to take over as Economics Minister. The present Ambassador to Venezuela, Juan Ramon Aguirre Lanari, is to be Foreign Minister. **********The reaction by civilian political leaders, many of whom are pushing for earlier elections, was mostly guarded.''We will not judge names, but will wait until concrete steps and policies are set down,'' said Antonio Troccoli, a leader of the centrist Radical Party. **********More than 60 militant labor unions, however, have called a protest demonstration Thursday at the cemetery here where former President Juan Domingo Peron is buried. General Bignone takes office on the eighth anniversary of the death of President Peron, whose movement retains a strong political grip on the country. **********In a statement, the unions accused the military of ''misinformation'' and deception in the unsuccessful attempt to hold the Falkland Islands in which 700 to 1,000 Argentines were estimated to have been killed. **********A central concern of the opposition leaders has been the new Government's economic policies. Many business, labor and political groups have demanded that the military abandon its free-market policy and stimulate the economy to pull it out of its year-old recession. Armed Forces Divided **********In an attempt to mollify the political leaders, General Bignone met with many of them last week and promised that he would take their economic proposals into account. **********Many military and political leaders have expressed doubts here that General Bignone's Government will last to its scheduled end because of divisions within the military. The air force and the navy, protesting that a civilian was not named President, quit what had been a joint military Government since the armed forces took power in a coup six years ago.

The gain came despite a 14.7 percent drop in freight traffic. **********The railroad, which was formed in 1976 from four bankrupt railroads, said its earnings for the first half totaled $30.6 million, the first time it had recorded a net income for the first half of a year. In the period last year, the company had a net loss of $52.1 million. **********Revenue for the second quarter totaled $958.8 million, down 10.4 percent from $1.07 billion in the second quarter last year.  L. Stanley Crane, the chairman and chief executive officer of Conrail, said, ''We have continued to demonstrate our ablity to reduce costs in line with declining revenue.'' **********He warned, however, that Conrail's results for the rest of 1982 would depend on a national economic recovery. He said the railroad was closing some major heavy repair plants for seven weeks this summer because of expected lower traffic.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/23/busin.body_text: **********Energy stocks rallied yesterday to lead the market to its highest level in 12 weeks. Trading was heavy.  The Dow Jones industrial average rose 9.70 points, to 853.12. This marked its best closing since 871.10 on Jan. 29. The Dow ended last year at 875. **********With bank trust departments, investment counseling firms, insurance companies and other institutional investors stepping up their activity, volume expanded to 64.5 million shares, the largest turnover in a month, from Wednesday's 57.8 million shares. Over all, advances led declines by more than a 2-to-1 ratio. **********Several Factors Involved **********Oil and oil-service companies benefited from several factors.  ''Emotion played a part,'' said Lincoln A. Werden of Thomson McKinnon Securities. ''Heightened tensions in the Middle East renewed fears of a possible disruption of oil supplies from that area.'' **********In line with this reasoning, he said, shares of companies concentrating their production in the Western Hemisphere performed better than the big international oils. **********The largest gain on the active list among producing companies, for example, was posted by Standard Oil (Indiana). It rose 2 1/4, to 41 7/8. Similarly, Atlantic Richfield, which is an important producer on the Alaskan North Slope, moved ahead 2 1/4, to 39 5/8. **********Gains of more than a point each were registered by Standard Oil (Ohio), Mesa Petroleum, Getty Oil, Superior Oil and Union Oil of California. **********Meanwhile, Exxon, the world's largest oil enterprise, moved up 3/8, to 28 1/8. Texaco and Mobil, two other giants among the international oils, also rose 3/8 each. **********Another factor in sending oil issues higher, according to Eugene Nowak of Dean Witter Reynolds, was the disclosure that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries was producing less than 16 million barrels of oil daily, or more than a million barrels below the group's official ceiling. ''Also, spot prices for crude oil have risen recently,'' he said. **********Finally, energy issues have been so depressed lately that they seemed ripe for a recovery, according to analysts.  In this year's first three and a half months, stock prices of domestic oil companies fell almost 20 percent, Robert L. Stern of Paine Webber Mitchell Hutchins noted. Meanwhile, international oils tumbled slightly more than 11 percent, while oil-service issues plunged almost 25 percent. Schlumberger Rebounds **********The oil-service sector joined in yesterday's rally as Schlumberger, the industry leader, rebounded 2 5/8, to 44 7/8, after showing a 31 percent increase in quarterly profits. Global Marine and Smith International both moved higher after reporting increased quarterly earnings. **********Sears, Roebuck, the volume leader on a turnover of more than 1.3 million shares, gained 5/8, to 20. The company reported this week that profits rose 35 percent in the first quarter. **********Electric utility issues continued to gain. Con Edison rose 1/4, to 37 5/8.  Wendy's rose 1 1/8, to 18 1/8, in active trading, but the company said it could not account for the gain. Polaroid, which reported a sharp drop in quarterly profits late yesterday, fell 3/4, to 18 7/8. Missouri Pacific, down 1 1/4, to 48, also showed lower earnings. **********Improved prices for natural-resource issues resulted in a gain for the American Stock Exchange's market-value index. It rose 2.23, to 273.39. Jupiter Industries gained 1 3/4, to 20 1/8, in response to an offer by major stockhodlers of the company to purchase all shares at 21. **********The class A shares of The New York Times Company climbed 1 1/4 points, to 37 1/2. This followed a report two days ago that the company's first-quarter profits rose 56 percent. **********In over-the-counter trading, Cullum Companies fell 2 3/4, to 27 bid, after reporting a decline in earnings. The Tony Lama Company also dropped 2 3/4, to 28 1/2 bid, in response to an article in The Wall Street Journal stating that the maker of Western-style boots had so far not found a prospective buyer, although its investment banker was seeking candidates. The Nasdaq composite index gained 1.34, to 183.66.
