https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/12/world.body_text: **********President Reagan's nuclear arms control policies have come under criticism from a bipartisan group of 21 senators and from six former senior Government officials. **********On Monday, Senator John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri, and his colleagues sponsored a resolution urging Mr. Reagan to clarify his policies and recent actions, which, the measure states, ''have caused anxiety at home and abroad.'' **********In addition, the six officials, who are either former directors of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency or former arms negotiators, said in a statement that they could not support the President's decision to defer talks on a treaty for a comprehensive nuclear test ban. Tests are now banned in the atmosphere, the sea and outer space, but are permitted under ground. **********The two moves reflect concern in Congress and in arms control circles over Mr. Reagan's approach to arms control. U.S. Objective Since Eisenhower **********The statement of the former officials says his decision last month to postpone talks with Britain and the Soviet Union on a complete test ban ''undercuts a national security objective set by President Eisenhower and pursued by every Administration since.'' **********The officials added that the decision also cast doubt on American sincerity in the talks with the Soviet Union on strategic, or longrange, nuclear weapons and other arms issues. **********The statement, which was issued by the Committee for National Security, a Washington-based group, was signed by four former directors of the arms control agency: William C. Foster, who served from 1962 to 1969; Gerard C. Smith, 1969 to 1972; Paul C. Warnke, 1977 and 1978, and Ralph Earle 2d, 1979 and 1980. **********The text was also endorsed by Adrian S. Fisher, who served in 1967 and 1968 as negotiator of the treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons, and Herbert F. York, who was negotiator in 1979 and 1980 in the talks on a comprehensive nuclear test ban. Two Former Aides Do Not Join **********Two former arms control directors did not join in the statement: Fred C. Ikle, who is now Under Secretary of Defense for Policy, and George M. Seignious, who worked for President Carter. **********On the Senate floor on Monday, Senator Danforth called on President Reagan to provide a comprehensive report on United States nuclear weapons policy by Dec. 1. The Senator noted that more than 10 years had passed since the United States and the Soviet Union had ratified an accord in the arms field. **********''The Government of the United States must get off the dime,'' he asserted.  Senator Danforth also chided the Administration for deferring efforts to negotiate a total test ban and for delaying ratification on two other treaties limiting underground nuclear testing until verification provisions could be strengthened. **********He said ratification of the two treaties was long overdue and the decision to defer the talks for a complete test ban was tantamount to ''throwing years of useful negotiations into the wastebasket.'' The Senator also maintained that it was inconsistent for the President to pursue the strategic arms talks while opposing a complete ban on testing. **********In addition, he said that President Reagan's new policies on stemming the spread of nuclear weapons had created ''grave uncertainty about United States weapons policy.'' Specifically, the Senator called on the President to explain how the relaxation of export controls on nuclear fuel and sensitive nuclear technologies would help halt the nuclear weapons spread. **********''Our credibility as a leader in nonproliferation is at stake,'' Senator Danforth said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/27/world.print_headline: REAGAN AND AIDES MEET WITH SHULTZ TO REVIEW POLICY; HAIG IS NOT PRESENT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/27/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State-designate George P. Shultz conferred with President Reagan today and then said he saw his role as an opportunity ''to advance the causes of peace, freedom and justice in a world so troubled and so anxious to hope for a good future.'' **********Speaking to reporters after flying by helicopter to the Pentagon from Camp David, Md., where he had lunch with Mr. Reagan, Mr. Shultz said he had been ''truly surprised'' by the sudden resignation of Alexander M. Haig Jr. as Secretary. **********Mr. Haig, who is still acting as Secretary of State for an indefinite period, was not present at today's meeting. In his letter of resignation to the President, he said he was leaving because the Administration was not after ''the careful course'' of foreign policy he and Mr. Reagan had originally agreed upon, and he has refused requests from the press to be more explicit. Differences Are Cited **********Mr. Reagan, who announced the resignation Friday, also has given no reasons, and briefings by White House officials have been vague. But a State Department official said today that the Secretary had resigned because of an accumulation of personality and policy differences with Reagan aides. **********Mr. Shultz, who had been in Europe on a business trip, flew here from London aboard a British Airways Concorde jet this morning. He was met at Dulles International Airport in nearby Virginia and taken by the Presidential helicopter to the Camp David retreat in the Catoctin Mountains. **********William P. Clark, the national security adviser, who met Mr. Shultz at Dulles along with James A. Baker, the White House chief of staff, and Edwin Meese 3d, the White House counselor, said later that Mr.  Shultz and Mr. Reagan had had ''a very constructive lunch'' under a pine tree at Camp David. He said they had discussed ''the broad outline'' of the Administration's foreign policy in substantive and procedural aspects. Silent on Policy Matters **********Mr. Shultz, who opened his statement by saying, ''My name is George Shultz; I'm from California,'' declined to discuss policy matters.  ''I have my confirmation hearings to think about and a lot of work to do,'' he said. ''So, these will be days of silence.'' He then went to a guest house for visiting former presidents and other dignitaries on Jackson Place, across the street from the White House. Mr. Shultz planned meetings in coming days with Mr. Haig and other officials. **********According to an aide, Mr. Haig, whose resignation stunned Washington, did not want to embarrass Mr. Reagan by going into detail on his differences with other Reagan aides, but might be willing to talk more freely after he has given up his post permanently. A White House official said the Administration wanted to avoid ''recriminations'' and look ''ahead and not back.'' Resignation Tendered Thursday **********Haig aides insisted that the Secretary had initiated the resignation and had not been asked to step down by the President.  They also said that even though Mr. Haig, who has a well-known temper, has often spoken of resignation to his colleagues, this was the first time that he had ever told Mr. Reagan that he wanted to quit. He did this on Thursday and Mr. Reagan informed him Friday that he had accepted it and that Mr. Shultz would replace him, White House officials said. **********Despite his implied criticism of Mr. Reagan, Mr. Haig was still acting as Secretary for the immediate future. He was in his seventhfloor suite at the State Department this morning engaged primarily in steps to resolve the Lebanese crisis, department officials said. On Friday, after his resignation was announced, Mr.  Haig said that he had assured Mr. Reagan that ''I will stay on in my post for as long as is necessary to insure an orderly transition for my successor.'' **********A spokesman for the Senate Foreign Relations Committee said today that he did not expect confirmation hearings for Mr. Shultz to begin before the week of July 12, when the Senate returns from its Fourth of July recess. This means Mr. Shultz will probably not be able to assume office for nearly three weeks at least. Memos in the Works **********On Friday, shortly after Mr. Haig's resignation became known, senior officials in the State Department were told by L. Paul Bremer 3d, the executive secretary of the department, to prepare brief memos on key issues to bring Mr. Shultz up to date rapidly. Lengthier guidance papers will be prepared in coming days, officials said, to help Mr. Shultz get ready for his confirmation hearings. **********Senator Charles H. Percy, Republican of Illinois, who is an old acquaintance of Mr. Shultz, a Labor and Treasury Secretary in the Nixon Administration, has predicted rapid and easy confirmation by the Foreign Relations Committee, of which Mr. Percy is chairman, and the Senate. **********Senator Alan Cranston, Democrat of California, said Friday that he will want to question Mr. Shultz closely on his Middle East views.  This is because the Bechtel Group, an engineering and construction company of which Mr. Shultz is president, has vast construction projects in Saudi Arabia and Mr. Shultz is said to believe that American policy has been negligent of legitimate Arab concerns. In 1980, for example, he said that if he had any differences with Mr.  Reagan, it was on Middle East policy. **********With the Lebanese crisis the most pressing question, it was uncertain how much of a direct role Mr. Shultz will play in formulating policy in the weeks before he is sworn in as the 60th Secretary of State. One State Department official said much will depend on Mr. Shultz's preferences when he meets with Mr. Haig on Sunday or Monday. Pressure on P.L.O. Is Aim **********The American goal at the moment is to bring pressure on the Palestine Liberation Organization forces in west Beirut to lay down their arms and to have the P.L.O. leadership leave Lebanon for another Arab country. The Israelis, at the urging of the United States, have undertaken another cease-fire in Lebanon, which was still holding this afternoon. **********At the United Nations Security Council early this morning the United States vetoed a French proposal calling for a limited pullback from Beirut of Israeli forces and those of the P.L.O. **********A statement issued by the State Department said the veto was ordered by the department because it did not include a provision for the disarming of the Palestinian forces in west Beirut. ''This was a fatal defect,'' the department said. **********Mr. Haig became convinced early in the week, officials said, that the only way to avoid an all-out Israeli invasion of west Beirut was to get the P.L.O. to put down its arms. To accomplish this, he felt it was necessary for Israel to maintain military pressure on Beirut, but to manage it in such a way that a major attack was avoided. Clark Move Resented **********Mr. Haig was reported to have been irritated when he learned that Mr. Clark, the national security adviser, had told the Saudi Arabian Ambassador that the United States would persuade Israel to loosen its control over Beirut. This word was conveyed to the P.L.O. by the Saudis and reportedly led to a more stubborn position being adopted by the Palestinians. **********Officials at the State Department said that this dispute with Mr.  Clark was a factor in Mr. Haig's decision to quit, but not the only one. They also cited his unhappiness with a recent hardening of the anti-Soviet policy, which led to stronger efforts to prevent allies from making American-licensed products for use in the planned natural gas pipeline from the Soviet Union to West Europe. **********Aides said they did not know what his Mr. Haig's plans are after leaving office. Mr. Haig was president of United Technologies in Hartford for a year before becoming Secretary of State. **********All senior officials have been asked by Mr. Haig to remain in office pending Mr. Shultz's takeover. It is assumed that Mr. Shultz will ask most to stay on for the next several months until he has a chance to become more familiar with the situation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/06/world.print_headline: ATTRITION IN GULF WAR: HOW LONG CAN IRAQ LAST WITHOUT HELP?; Military Analysis
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/06/world.body_text: **********Heavy fighting in the hills east of Baghdad, reported yesterday by intelligence sources, indicates that the Iranians, despite their failure to break through on Friday, are maintaining pressure along this sector of the front. **********United States and North Atlantic Treaty Organization intelligence specialists said that Iran, in attacks around Sumar in the Mandali sector, did not pentrate deeply enough anywhere to spill out onto the plain east of Iraq's capital. **********The current fighting on this central front has been accompanied by a resumption of activity on the southern front, where Iranian forces are within striking distance of Basra. Iranian artillery shelled the city and the Iraqis have admitted to foreign military attaches in Baghdad that shelling did considerable damage Sunday night. **********Iraqis More Active in Air **********The Iraqi Air Force, the sources said, is playing a much more active role in the fighting than the Iranian Air Force is. Fighters and armed helicopters have attacked Iranian positions in the hills.  The Iraqi helicopters, a NATO source said, probably are French-built Gazelles armed with HOT, a tube-launched, wire-guided antitank missile. **********The Iranian Air Force has confined itself to attacks on oil installations far from the front.  The primary military issue raised by Iranian pressure along the frontiers of Iraq, the sources said, is how long Iraq can hold out against a country with approximately three times as many people. **********Although the Iranians have suffered very heavy casualties, especially in their headlong assaults on the Iraqi lines outside Basra last July, they have been able to fill the ranks with relatively untrained soldiers of the Revolutionary Guard whose lack of military skills is balanced by their fanatic valor. One British estimate is that the Iranians have lost at least 25,000 dead since the start of the war in September 1980. The Iraqis, on the other hand, have not risked troops needlessly since the war began. Possible Iranian Plan **********Some believe that the stress laid on conserving manpower was the reason the original Iraqi invasion of the Iranian oil province of Khuzistan foundered in early 1981. **********Since the Iranian attack opened in the hills, the Iraqis have launched several counterattacks. While these appear to have checked further Iranian advances, they inevitably cost lives. **********Intelligence sources analyzing the conflict say Iran may have decided to fight a war of attrition along Iraq's borders to wear down the Iraqi Army, which is the mainstay of President Saddam Hussein's Government. **********If this is to be avoided, these sources said, Iraq must obtain trained infantry and artillery units from outside soon. The Sudan has promised military aid but has not defined the form it will take. **********Intervention by Jordan, which is closer to the battlefield, could be more effective. The Jordanian Army is small, 65,000 compared with Iraq's 300,000, but Israeli intelligence regards it as the best trained Arab army in the region. Jordan: Best and Only **********An Israeli source said he believed that President Hussein would press King Hussein of Jordan, now in Baghdad, to send troops to reinforce the Iraqis in the front line. The King has been the most vocal supporter of Iraq in the Arab world and has repeatedly urged other countries to honor their agreement to defend all Arab countries against aggression and to send troops and supplies. **********Jordan, intelligence sources noted, has sent thousands of volunteers to fight in the Iraqi forces. But the consensus of experts on the war is that Iraq now needs fresh, intact formations. **********''Jordan is not only the best source of trained reinforcements readily available,'' a British source said. ''It is the only one. The Syrians are up to their necks in Lebanon and the Kuwaitis, Saudi Arabians and the small gulf states have nothing to offer now but money. Money won't help the Iraqis if the Iranians continue the pressure.'' **********Some senior American officers believe that despite European pessimism about Iraq's position, that country's air force could force Iran to reconsider a strategy of attrition. Their view is that repeated, successful attacks on Iranian oil export positions such as Kharq Island in the Persian Gulf would so damange Iran's economy that it would be willing to withdraw.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/07/world.main_headline: Rebels Said to Kidnap Over 140 in Salvador
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/07/world.print_headline: Rebels Said to Kidnap Over 140 in Salvador
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/07/world.body_text: **********Leftist rebels kidnapped two soccer teams and about 120 spectators from a rural stadium, forcing them to march through the night to a mountain guerrilla camp, witnesses said today. **********Carmen de Soriano, a municipal worker in the eastern town of San Sebastian, said in a telephone interview that about 150 rebels dressed in olive green uniforms killed several of the spectators who tried to escape from the stadium Sunday. **********She said relatives reported the members of two soccer teams, each with 11 men, and 120 other spectators were taken away by the guerrillas. She estimated that another 40 people were missing, but their relatives were afraid to seek help from the authorities. **********In addition to those believed abducted by the guerrillas, Miss de Soriano said about 10 youths managed to escape and were back with their families. **********Mimsael Ayala, who said he escaped from the rebels, said a guerrilla leader tried to calm the spectators after seizing the stadium. He quoted the guerrilla chief as saying, ''You're only going to work, not to fight.'' **********Mr. Ayala said the rebels surrounded the San Sebastian soccer field and forced the spectators and two teams to march through the night toward their camp at Cerro de San Pedro, near San Sebastian.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/28/busin.body_text: **********Receding from its strongest sustained rally in history, the stock market retreated yesterday in the face of rising interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 8.94 points, to 883.47. **********''It's too early to tell whether today's action marks a temporary top for the market,'' stated John Winthrop Wright, who heads Wright Investors' Service in Bridgeport, Conn. ''Our present view is that the real bull market will begin around the time of the November elections, but this would be dependent upon a further substantial decline in interest rates from present levels.'' **********In yesterday's credit market, short-term rates moved higher while prices of bonds dropped sharply.  For the two weeks ended Thursday, the Dow had soared 115 1/2 points, staging a spectacular response to plummeting interest rates.  The indicator finished this week with an advance of 14.18 points, on the heels of last week's record gain of 81.24 points. Volume Thins **********Trading on the New York Stock Exchange settled back yesterday to 74.4 million shares - considered a heavy turnover under normal circumstances - after exceeding 100 million shares in each of the four previous sessions. Thursday's volume reached a single-day record of 137.3 million shares. **********Trading totaled a weekly record of 549.9 million shares, easily shattering the previous week's mark of 455.1 million shares. The twoweek total of slightly more than a billion shares exceeded the turnover for all of 1960, when trading amounted to 766.7 million shares. **********In the past two weeks, the market value of the nation's 5,000 leading common stocks has climbed by $136.9 billion, according to Wilshire Associates, a financial services firm in Santa Monica, Calif. Manville Falls 2 3/4 **********One depressant on the Dow industrials yesterday was the Manville Corporation, which plunged 2 3/4 points, to 5 1/8, as the second most active issue. On Thursday, Manville announced that it had filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws.  Manville's stock did not trade Thursday. **********Yesterday, Dow Jones & Company said that the American Express Company will be substituted for Manville in the list of 30 stocks comprising the industrial average. The change takes effect at the start of trading Monday. American Express dipped 1/8 yesterday, to 44 7/8. **********Cities Service, again the volume leader after its merger proposal from Occidental Petroleum, rose 3/4, to 47 1/4.  Building-related issues were the market's weakest sector. Jim Walter fell 3 1/4, to 21 1/4, while Owens-Corning dropped 2 1/8, to 19 3/4. Certain-teed declined 1 1/8, to 12 3/4. Analysts noted that housing activity remains quite weak. **********Over all, declining issues on the Big Board outnumbered advances by nearly 2 to 1, reversing the market's strong breadth in recent sessions. **********Analysts have said repeatedly this week that a great deal of institutional money still remains on the sidelines for possible investment in the stock market. **********Mr. Wright, for example, said that his investment advisory firm was now maintaining about 35 percent of equity-portfolio funds - ''or close to $300 million'' - in cash reserves. ''We expect to be fully invested by the end of this year,'' he said. **********In over-the-counter trading, the Hospital Trust Corporation fell 1 1/2, to 23, bid. The bank holding company, based in Providence, R.I., said it had about $22.2 million in loans outstanding to private parties in Mexico that were not guaranteed by United States entities. **********The Nasdaq composite index declined 0.57, to 177.60. The American Stock Exchange's composite index fell 0.96, to 275.41.  On the Big Board, the Mexico Fund declined 3/8, to 2 3/4. This closed-end investment company, formed to invest the bulk of its assets in Mexican securities, was sold in June 1981 at $12 a share by underwriters led by Merrill Lynch. Mexico is now in the throes of a financial crisis brought on by soaring inflation rates.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/13/world.main_headline: MISKITO INDIANS ARE FOCUS OF DEBATE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/13/world.print_headline: MISKITO INDIANS ARE FOCUS OF DEBATE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/13/world.body_text: **********For generations few people, except missionaries from the Moravian Church, knew much about the Miskito Indians who lived in in Nicaragua's Atlantic Coast region. **********But in the last eight months, the Miskitos have found themselves in the center of controversy - the target of the Nicaraguan Government, which has charged that some of their leaders are subversives, and the focus of attention by the United States, which uses their case as an example of what it sees as human rights abuses. **********Disrupted by border warfare, displaced by Nicaraguan attempts to resettle and integrate them, and sometimes motivated by a desire to join Nicaraguans in exile, about 15,000 of the 125,000 Miskitos have fled to Honduras. Most of them are struggling to survive in a grim refugee camp near here. **********Officials from the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees are trying to resettle them on inhabited, fertile land near here. Officials believe that the relocation, in addition to fostering self-suffiency, would reduce the epidemics arising in the squalid conditions at Mocoron. Some Resist Relocation Plans **********The relocation plans have been resisted by some of the Indian leaders, including Steadman Fagoth Muller, who has toured the United States to make a case against the Nicaraguan Government's treatment of the Indians. **********The relief workers believe that he and others who share his view are opposed on the ground that it will be easier to keep world attention on the Miskito issue if they are kept in a group. **********''Their presence is an embarrasment to the Nicaraguans,'' a relief worker said.  American officials focused attention on the issue last winter by charging that the Nicaraguans were engaging in genocide against the Indians. **********Under the regime of Anastasio Somoza Debayle, the Indians were left alone. After his overthrow in 1979, the new Sandinist Government in Nicaragua decided to end their isolation. **********According to Sifrit Williams, a 52-year-old leader of Miskito refugees who wants to overthrow the Sandinists, the Miskitos generally perferred the Somoza Government because it did not intrude in their lives. Sandinists Press Literacy Drive **********Mr. Williams said the Sandinists have, as part of a nationwide literacy campaign, sent in Cubans, whom the Miskitos mistrusted, to teach Spanish to the Indians, whose second language was often English, a language they learned from missionaries or inherited from English-speaking Caribbean peoples who settled along their coast. **********The Sandinists, Mr. Williams said, also tried to persuade the Indians to form cooperatives. Indians, who engaged in communal farming were nevertheless not amenable to having socialism forced on them, he said. **********''The socialist system goes against their grain,'' said Brian Adam, a soft-spoken, 27-year-old volunteer for World Relief, an evangelical orgnization. He is the only one of some 50 relief workers here who speaks Miskito, which he learned as a child. **********He learned it during the first 12 years of his life when he lived with his Moravian missionary parents among the Indians in Nicargua and Honduras. From his parents and other missionaries, Mr. Adam said, the Miskitos acquired ''pro-Western, pro-American'' values. **********In accusing the Sandinists of human rights abuses, Reagan Administration officials have relied in part on Miskitos' accounts of an incident on Dec. 23 last year. On that day, according to some refugee leaders, Sandinist soldiers massacred about 100 Miskitos, including women and children, in the Nicaraguan border town of Leimus. **********But international relief workers here, including Peace Corps volunteers, say that the attack may have been provoked when a force of some 200 armed Miskito men left the Mocoron refugee to take part in a raid on Leimus. A battle ensued, according to the relief workers, ''not more than 70,'' were killed. **********Whatever happened at Leimus, it has been followed by increased military activity in the areas of Nicaragua populated by Indians. The Sandinists have concentrated much of their military buildup in the area. **********Once in Honduras, some relief workers suggest, it is easy for the Miskitos to be used by leaders who want to topple the Sandinist Government. One of the most outspoken of those is Mr. Fagoth. **********''God has shown him his path,'' said Mr. Williams as he sat on the shaky patio of La Perla, a run-down waterfront bar in Puerto Lempira. Sitting in this same bar in June, Mr. Fagoth miraculously escaped death when someone threw a grenade and opened up with automatic rifle fire. Food Diverted to Guerrillas **********Mr. Fagoth and Mr. Williams have allied themselves with the ''Somocistas,'' as former soldiers of General Somoza's National Guard are called. **********Asked if young Miskito men had joined the ''Somocistas,'' Mr.  Williams, whose wrinkled, leather-skinned face had remained expressionless as he talked about the Sandinists, answered flatly, ''not that I am aware.'' **********But then a grin broke between his sunken jaws, and his bony fingers tried to stifle a laugh.  According to the relief workers, food and supplies intended for the refugees are often diverted to the Somocista guerrilla camps, which, they said, operated from bases at Rus Rus, Srumlaya and Cabo de Gracias a Dios. In one instance, they said, all but a very small amount of a large shipment of food, clothing and medicines donated by the fire department in Houston, Tex., for the Mocoron refugees ended up in the possession of the counterrevolutionaries, as the anti-Sandinist forces are frequently called, after being unloaded at Puerto Lempira. **********According to the relief workers, Honduran army officers are providing arms and training for the counterrevolutionaries.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/24/busin.main_headline: DOES IT PAY TO RENEGOTIATE A MORTGAGE?
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/24/busin.print_headline: PERSONAL FINANCE; DOES IT PAY TO RENEGOTIATE A MORTGAGE?
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/24/busin.body_text: **********MORTGAGE rates have fallen and many homeowners who had the m isfortune to buy at peak rates are now beset with a bit of envy. Theq uestion is whether there is anything they can do to get the cheaper r ates, and the answer is yes. Mortgages - even second mortgages and m ortgages on investment and business properties - can be r enegotiated, and such a move might pay if rates have fallen far e nough. **********Many mortgage lenders report an increasing number of inquiries about renegotiating. But trading in a mortgage is not an easy task and it may not be profitable in all instances. The cost of renegotiation - paying closing costs and bank fees all over again - can be several thousand dollars and there are so many variables, including the many different kinds of mortgages involved, that the decision becomes an individual judgment. **********Fixed-rate loans have fallen in a year from 17 1/2 percent and higher to as low as 13 3/4 percent, with most of the decline taking place in recent weeks. The falling-interest-rate environment is as new to the banks as to mortgage holders. ''I've been in the business 34 years,'' said Herbert A. Schneider, executive vice president of the Columbia Savings Bank in New York, ''and 20 years ago there was a slight dip, from 6 to 5 1/2 percent.'' Otherwise, it's been uphill for rates. **********''The key word now,'' said Norman Kailo, sales manager of the Soldoveri Agency in Totowa and Wayne, N.J., and a past president of the New Jersey Association of Realtors, ''is that anyone who bought in the last two years or so should dig out their mortgage instrument, check it over and do some shopping. You can go back to the realtor who sold you the house and ask for advice.'' **********James W. Christian, chief economist for the United States League of Savings Associations, concurred. ''Sure consumers ought to be thinking about it,'' he said. ''But they need to put a sharp pencil to it and figure out whether it's really worth their while.'' **********James Panepinto, vice president in charge of the Chase Manhattan Bank's New York State residential mortgage lending, said the bank was getting a considerable number of inquiries on renegotiating, ''but every case is a little different'' and the number of people involved was a small element of the market. From the customer's point of view, he said, ''there's a break-even analysis to do - it costs x amount to do the refinancing to gain a reduction in monthly payments.'' **********Mr. Kailo believes that money can be saved, depending on the size of the mortgage, on as little as a 2 percentage point spread between a current high-fixed-rate mortgage and what is available now. **********If, for example, Mr. Kailo said, someone has a 16 percent fixedrate $50,000 mortgage for 30 years, the principal and interest portion would come to $672.50 a month. If that mortgage could be traded in for one of 14 percent, the comparable payment would be $592.50 a month, a saving of $80 a month. MR. KAILO estimated that closing costs and points charged by the b ank in renegotiation might add up to $1,600 to $2,000, which is muchl ess than on the original closing, he said. ''In most cases you don'tn eed a full title search, just an update,'' he said. ''You generally d on't need a new survey or another title insurance policy. There's non eed to put down any new escrow fees. **********''Normally if you tell your bank you're going to another,'' he added, ''they're going to lose your loan anyway so they might decide to recast it for you themselves. This could lower your costs even more. You probably would not have to take out a new application fee, which is generally $125 to $250.'' **********Mr. Kailo's examples suppose that the bank is charging two points as its origination fee for the recast mortgage. A point is 1 percent of the $50,000 mortgage in the example and two points equals $1,000.  His example also supposes that there are no prepayment clauses imposed by state statute; there are none in New Jersey and none in New York after the first year of the mortgage. **********But many states have such penalties and Federally chartered thrift institutions have the option of imposing penalties - these would have to be figured into the new closing costs. **********The average life of a mortgage in a metroplitan area ranges from six to nine years, Mr. Kailo said. ''If somebody transferred jobs quite often, it sure as heck wouldn't pay to renogotiate unless there was a 3 or 4 percent difference.'' **********Joseph J. Holzka, a lawyer with Holzka, Donahue, Kuhn & Howard, which represents some banks, suggested that if rates continue to drop, people with mortgages of, say, 17 1/2 percent might get a compromise if they asked their banks to match the cheapest rate available, say 14 percent. ''The bank might say, 'we won't drop you to that, but how's 15 1/2 or 16 percent' - numbers that reflect diminished closing costs in dealing with the same lender,'' he said. **********Inertia, though, would probably keep many homeowners from approaching the task of renegotiating even if it might mean savings, he added. **********How do the banks view these renegotiations? ''Naturally we're going through this now,'' said Mr. Schneider of Columbia Savings. Say interest rates are 14 percent, he said, and someone with a higherrate mortgage comes in to negotiate. ''We would give him a 14 percent rate, provided he would pay three or four origination points. We're not going to do it and just reduce the mortgage rate.'' **********He said he felt it would not be worthwhile to negotiate for a two percentage point difference. ''When you start getting 4 percent and if rates continue the way they are then I can see that some consideration should be given,'' he said. **********If a person decides to switch banks he would face new charges.  There would be, for example, a bank attorney fee of perhaps $200, an appraisal fee of about $125, a recording fee of $15 and a credit investigation charge of $25, he said. But if the new bank accepted documents by assignment, he said, the customer would not have to pay his mortgage tax again. ''If you have to pay that, forget it,'' he said. In New York City the levy on a $50,000 mortgage would be $600 and in Nassau County $350. **********As for second mortgages, Mr. Kailo, the New Jersey realtor, said that some people had taken out secondary financing at 20 percent or more. Now such financing is available at 16 percent in some cases, and there are no points or closing costs involved in renegotiating.  Businesses should also consider renegotiating mortgages, he said, to cut monthly payments and increase cash flow. **********Generally, then, it is up to homeowners to look into what is available if rates continue to fall. ''I'm a believer in window shopping, instead of just going to the bank you're dealing with.'' said Connie S.P. Chen, president of the Chen Planning Group in New York, a financial planner. ''What have you got to lose?''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/16/world.main_headline: Swiss Refusing to Extradite 4 Who Seized Polish Embassy
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/16/world.print_headline: Swiss Refusing to Extradite 4 Who Seized Polish Embassy
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/16/world.body_text: **********Switzerland will definitely not extradite the four gunmen who occupied the Polish Embassy for three days last week and is determined to try them in a Swiss court, the Justice Ministry said today. **********After Swiss policemen stormed the embassy and freed staff members held hostage last Thursday, the Polish Government said it would ask for the extradition of the men, all of whom were born in Poland. But the Swiss Justice Minister, Kurt Furgler, said at the time that Switzerland was not obliged to hand them over. **********A ministry spokesman said that an extradition request had not yet been received but that if it came Switzerland would definitely not comply.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/05/busin.print_headline: FREDDIE MAC MORTGAGE BAR; Freddie Mac Mortgage Bar
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/05/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation has decided to ban homeowners from taking over the lowinterest mortgages it holds, an action that could further reduce prices of residential real estate. **********The action, which takes effect Aug. 2, follows the Supreme Court decision last Monday that Federally chartered savings and loan institutions could ban the so-called assumption of old mortgages despite state laws to the contrary. **********The corporation, commonly known as Freddie Mac, owns from 700,000 to 900,000 mortgages across the country. It is one of the agencies that buys mortgages from lending institutions financing housing.  Homeowners do not usually know when their mortgages are in the hands of Freddie Mac because their original lender still collects payments for the agency. **********Freddie Mac's decision, reached Friday, does not affect Federal Housing Administration or Veterans Administration loans, which still can be fully assumed. Those mortgages are controlled by the Department of Housing and Urban Development. **********The practice of passing on low-interest mortgages has benefited only a few home buyers, said Richard A. Mackey, executive vice president of Freddie Mac. When low-interest mortgages are assumed, lending institutions must raise interest rates on new loans more than they would otherwise have to do to keep pace, he added.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/02/world.body_text: **********Irish Republican Army guerrillas waiting in ambush in an apartment that they had seized shot dead two British soldiers in civilian clothes riding in an unmarked van today. **********They were the fourth and fifth soldiers killed in ambushes in a week. **********The I.R.A. took responsibility for the attack and said it was also responsible for a bombing near Newry that closed the main @Belfast-Dublin rail line this morning. **********The attacks came as Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Cabinet approved a plan to set up a 78-member elected assembly in Northern Ireland this fall as a first step toward restoring partial self-rule.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/29/busin.main_headline: Company Earnings; MOBIL OFF 49.1%; SUN UP 3.3%
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/29/busin.print_headline: Company Earnings; MOBIL OFF 49.1%; SUN UP 3.3%
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/29/busin.body_text: **********Continuing the trend of depressed earnings reports by major oil companies, the Mobil Corporation yesterday reported a 49.1 percent drop in its first-quarter profit, citing a sharp downturn in its foreign energy operations because of the oil glut. **********The nation's second-largest industrial concern, trailing only the Exxon Corporation in annual sales, said its earnings fell to $326 million, or 77 cents a share, from $640 million, or $1.50 a share, a year ago. **********However, Mobil said that, excluding a $143 million decline in foreign inventory profits, earnings for the latest quarter decreased only 32 percent from the 1981 quarter. **********Revenues slipped 4.2 percent, to $16.4 billion, from $17.1 billion a year earlier.  According to industry analysts, Mobil was hindered by its partnership in the Arabian American Oil Company, which produces most of Saudi Arabia's crude oil. Mobil has been committed to paying $34 a barrel for light crude while earning as little as $28 for every barrel it refines and markets. **********The other three partners previously reported first-quarter earnings declines. Exxon profits slid 22.5 percent, Socal's 65.5 percent and Texaco's 4.2 percent. **********Mobil's earnings from foreign operations fell 64 percent from the 1981 period to $169 million in the first quarter.  Alvin D. Silber, vice president and international oils analyst for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said Mobil's inventory profits have been declining, and he estimated a $44 million drop in that category in in the current quarter, down 76.5 percent from $187 million in 1981. **********Domestic energy earnings rose 9 percent, to $253 million, from $232 million a year ago, as earnings from exploration and production and natural gas prices rose slightly. **********Worldwide chemical earnings were cut by half, to $13 million, because of lower domestic results.  Mobil's Montgomery Ward unit showed a $44 million loss in the first quarter, slightly narrower than the $47 million loss it sustained a year earlier. Sales declined 11 percent for the unit. The Sun Company **********The Sun Company, the nation's No. 12 oil company, yesterday said its profits rose 3.3 percent, largely because of reduced financing costs. **********Sun earned $124 million, or $1.03 a share, in the first quarter, up from $120 million, or 97 cents a share, a year earlier.  Revenues were down a marginal 2.5 percent, to $3.9 billion, from $4 billion in 1981.  Sun said an aggressive investment program allowed it to reduce to $1.1 billion the $2.3 billion debt incurred in its 1980 acquisition of the domestic oil and gas properties of the Texas Pacific Company from Seagram Ltd. **********The company's domestic refining and marketing operations loss narrowed to $6 million in the first quarter, from $24 million a year ago. **********Sun's 75 percent-owned Canadian Petroleum Company recorded operating income of $1.1 million, a 96 percent decline from $27.7 million a year earlier, primarily because of a fire at a plant and because of lower refining and marketing volumes, Sun said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/01/busin.main_headline: Citicorp Move West Is Led by a Texan
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/01/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Citicorp Move West Is Led by a Texan
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/01/busin.body_text: **********Citicorp's charge into California, one of the major current developments in the banking industry, is being led by Betty Sue Peabody, a Texan who proved her banking abilities as head of Citicorp's upstate New York branches. **********Citicorp acquired the failed Fidelity Savings and Loan Association of San Francisco earlier this week despite strong opposition after the Federal Reserve Board reversed policy and approved the merger. It was the first time the Fed allowed a savings and loan association to be acquired by a bank holding company across state lines. **********Mrs. Peabody, 41 years old and a consumer banking expert, was chosen by Citicorp to be president and chief executive of Fidelity, which is based in Oakland and has 81 branches in northern California. The bank said yesterday that she was in meetings and unavailable for an interview. **********Mrs. Peabody made her mark in upstate New York as head of Citibank (N.Y.S.) N.A., a Citicorp subsidiary with 35 branches from Albany to Buffalo. She was named president in 1978 and in her tenure the subsidiary's assets increased to $2 billion from $860 million. **********She was also in charge of the bank's student loan program and the consumer service development center, which comes up with such plans as helping parents to save for their children's education expenses or help for buying their first home. **********Under Mrs. Peabody, the student loan program grew from a portfolio of $90 million, to $800 million, in part by aggressively purchasing the student loan portfolios of other banks. **********Many Citicorp consumer banking services were also introduced successfully upstate by Mrs. Peabody, including self-service banking machines and savings certificates for small savers. The certificates avoid normal $10,000 minimum deposit requirements by having the bank lend up to $7,000 toward the certificate at 1 percent interest. These ''loophole'' certificates are not generally available in California, a Citicorp spokesman said, and are the kind of consumer banking products that Fidelity may introduce. **********In general, Mrs. Peabody's consumer banking experience fits in with savings and loan association business. The Fed has told Citicorp to run Fidelity as a savings and loan association and not as a commercial bank. **********Mrs. Peabody joined Citicorp in 1976 - the first bank she worked for - and two years later was named to head the upstate subsidiary.  She previously worked for 11 years at W.R. Grace & Company, primarily as a financial officer. **********Mrs. Peabody, of Longview, Tex., is a graduate of Rice University, with an M.B.A. from the University of Virginia. Her husband is employed by W.R. Grace.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/24/busin.main_headline: Viacom to Buy Rest Of Pay-TV Service
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/24/busin.print_headline: Viacom to Buy Rest Of Pay-TV Service
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/24/busin.body_text: **********Viacom International Inc. agreed yesterday to buy 50 percent of Showtime, a pay-television service, from Group W Cable Inc., for more than $75 million, the companies said. **********Viacom would then be sole owner of Showtime, which is the nation's second-largest pay-TV service, after Home Box Office, a subsidiary of Time Inc. Group W is owned by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation. **********Group W would maintain Showtime as its main pay-cable service in all its cable systems for at least five years, the companies said.  ''We are sorry that, despite our strong desire to purchase, Viacom did not wish to sell its interest in Showtime to Group W,'' said Daniel L. Ritchie, Group W's chairman. ''Since Viacom is Showtime's founder and was its sole owner for so many years, we felt it appropriate to sell our interest to them.'' **********Viacom had sold a 50 percent interest in Showtime to Teleprompter -which operates a cable-TV system in Manhattan - before Teleprompter was bought by Group W last August. **********Showtime serves about 1,800 cable systems and nearly 3.5 million subscribers. Group W encompasses about 1.8 million subscribers and nearly 1.5 million pay units. Viacom Cable includes nearly 600,000 basic subscribers and more than 400,000 pay units.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/26/busin.main_headline: G.M. SETS CLOSING OF 4 PARTS PLANTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/26/busin.print_headline: G.M. SETS CLOSING OF 4 PARTS PLANTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/26/busin.body_text: **********The General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it would permanently close four automobile parts plants in the next two years. It said it can obtain the parts less expensively elsewhere. **********The move, which will put 9,620 employees on indefinite layoff, brings to seven the number of plant closings announced by General Motors since the company's contract negotiations with the United Automobile Workers collapsed at the end of January. **********However, Alfred Warren, General Motors' vice president for industrial relations and the company's chief negotiator in last month's U.A.W. talks, told a reporter in Detroit that the company might be willing to negotiate keeping open some - but not all - of the four parts plants, if the union comes back to the bargaining table before its contract with G.M. expires in September. **********He added that General Motors might decide to close an assembly plant if auto sales don't improve soon. They have been in a slump for more than two years. Plant in Trenton Included **********The four parts plants, which are part of General Motors' Fisher Body division, include one in Trenton with 3,615 employees; the Detroit Fort Street plant with 2,900 employees; the Cleveland Coit Road plant with 2,810 employees, and Plant No.37 in Detroit with 256 employees. More than a third of the employees at these plants have already been laid off. **********Jim Sponseller, a spokesman for the Fisher Body division, said that the plan to close the plants followed ''a broad-based review of our long-term competitive position.'' He added that auto parts ''are not competitive in the production of many automotive components at this time.'' **********General Motors, he said, had found in a recent study that the plants had a labor disadvantage of about $10 an hour compared with other independent suppliers. Mr. Sponseller said the company would seek parts from suppliers in the United States and Canada. **********Earlier this month, General Motors announced that it would close assembly plants in Fremont and South Gate, Calif., and a trim plant in Euclid, Ohio. Closing Pattern Called Confusing **********''It's kind of confusing because the closings are coming in piecemeal,'' said Arvid Jouppi, a Detroit-based auto analyst with the Colin, Hochstin Company. ''It seems that if they had a general strategy they would announce all the closings at the same time.'' **********Roger B. Smith, the chairman of General Motors, has said since the contract negotiations broke down in January that he would resume talks after the U.A.W. ratified a contract with the Ford Motor Company. General Motors officials have argued that more jobs will disappear at the company if the union fails to go along with its demand for wage and benefit concessions. **********Ford and the auto workers union have reached an agreement, still to be ratified by the union membership, that ties wage and benefit concessions to greater job security. Before the General Motors talks broke down, company officials and union leaders had agreed in principle to link worker concessions to reductions in auto prices. 'Difficult Decisions' **********''These are always difficult decisions for us because we have been located in these facilities for a long time,'' Charles Katko, general manager of Fisher Body and a vice president of General Motors, said in a prepared statement. ''However, we have been unable to operate these plants at costs which are competitive with those of other domestic suppliers.'' **********A total of 249,701 employees have been laid off indefinitely throughout the auto industry, many of them in recent weeks and months as the industry struggles through a prolonged slump in auto sales.  During the 1974-75 recession, these layoffs reached 360,000. Those employees on indefinite layoff are not told that there is a possibiliy of returning to work, whereas those on temporary layoff expect to be recalled. **********General Motors reported 143,000 indefinite layoffs, and the company has temporarily idled an additional 25,150 workers. Ford has laid off 54,261 people, with 12,925 on temporary layoff. The Chrysler Corporation has idled 45,000 employees, with 1,600 on temporary layoff, and the American Motors Corporation has 6,100 auto workers on indefinite layoff and 7,500 on temporary layoff. **********Domestic auto production plunged 30.1 percent this week, to 91,343, from 130,712 in the comparable period of 1981, according to Ward's Automotive Reports, a trade publication. Ward's added that production for this week was down 12.5 percent from the week before.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/30/world.main_headline: ACCOUNT OF AMERICAN'S DEATH IN EL SALVADOR IS PUT IN DOUBT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/30/world.print_headline: ACCOUNT OF AMERICAN'S DEATH IN EL SALVADOR IS PUT IN DOUBT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/30/world.body_text: **********An autopsy on a young American who was killed by Salvadoran soldiers last month cast doubt today on military claims that he was shot while trying to escape. **********According to people familiar with the autopsy, the American, Michael Kline, had been shot three times in the back and head and had received a fourth wound, which left powder burns. This would indicate that the fourth bullet had been fired from a much closer range than had the other three. **********Mr. Kline, 21 years old, was killed on Oct. 13 after Salvadoran soldiers removed him for questioning from a bus in Morazan Province.  What he was doing in the area, which has seen heavy fighting recently, is a mystery, as are many other details of the case. **********The Salvadoran military had used the bullet wounds in the man's back to support its more recent version of the incident - that Mr.  Kline had been shot from a distance of about 30 feet while trying to escape from soldiers who had removed him from the bus as ''suspicious looking.'' 'Long Hair, Dirty Clothes' **********He had ''long hair, dirty clothes and rubber sandals,'' the soldiers who seized him reported. They said he spoke and understood little if any Spanish, and his only identification was his signature on $500 in traveler's checks. **********According to the soldiers, the shooting took place about 4 miles from the checkpoint where Mr. Kline was originally seized, while he was being transported to the military headquarters at San Francisco Gotera in a private pickup truck that the soldiers had commandeered. **********The account was given to United States officials by Sgt. Jose Desposorio Lopez Garcia, one of the soldiers involved in the incident. **********The military's initial report, delivered Oct. 15 by a spokesman for the armed forces press committee, was that Mr. Kline was a 32-yearold ''gringo mercenary'' who was shot by soldiers after seizing a gun from one of them. His identification as a mercenary was based on his carrying of ''medicines,'' including Alka Seltzer, and machine oil. The account was later modified to say that he tried but failed to grab one of the weapons. **********Neither account would explain the appearance of the powder burn, however, and an embassy official here said the three Salvadoran soldiers involved in the incident would be interviewed again in an effort to resolve the discrepancy. **********The official said the embassy had ''just received the report'' of the autopsy, which it had requested, and was ''analyzing it to draw our own conclusions.'' 'At Least One Powder Burn' **********The embassy official confirmed, however, that ''there is at least one powder burn'' on the body but declined to specify where it was.  According to the official, Mr. Kline had arrived in the country on Oct. 11, having recently spent time in both Mexico and Guatemala. The purpose of his trip, the official said, ''is just a big mystery - his mother said he had an interest in journalism, but there is no evidence he ever pursued it.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/24/world.body_text: **********A judge sentenced a member of Prime Minister Menachem Begin's Cabinet today to suspended prison sentences totaling 51 months and fined him $175 for larceny. **********The official, Aharon Abuhazira, the Minister of Labor, Welfare and Immigrants Absorption, said he intended to resign his post while appealing his conviction to the Israeli Supreme Court. **********Mr. Abuhazira was sentenced to one jail term for paying the family grocer and depositing money in an election fund with checks drawn on a charity fund he had headed in 1975. https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/27/busin.body_text: **********Eastern Air Lines Inc. yesterday reported a third-quarter loss of $32.8 million. The deficit was narrower than the $38.7 million a year earlier, but it nonetheless underscored the airline industry's continuing difficulties. **********The Miami-based carrier said its third-quarter revenue was $956.1 million, up from $902.1 million in the same period last year.  Commenting on the results, Frank Borman, Eastern's chairman and president, said the industry was feeling ''intense pressure from the recession, which has caused excess capacity and increasing fare competition.'' **********Robert J. Joedicke, first vice president and airline analyst at Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb, said that despite Eastern's loss, operating revenues increased by 6 percent over last year versus a lesser, 2.6 percent increase in expenses.'' **********That revenue improvement, he said reflected a 3 percent increase in passenger traffic, along with improvement in average revenue per passenger mile, which, he suggested, was noteworthy, coming at a time when many other airlines have been seeing dilution in their average revenue per passenger mile. **********''This improvement at Eastern,'' Mr. Joedicke observed, ''reflected recent expansion into South American markets where average yields are above the domestic level.'' **********Stressing the importance of that move into South American routes once flown by Braniff International, Eliot Fried, executive vice president at Shearson Loeb Rhodes, said that its favorable impact on passenger yield meant that Eastern's third-quarter performance had been ''better than one would perceive looking at the bottom line.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/06/world.main_headline: BRITAIN CHARTING A COURSE FOR FUTURE OF FALKLANDS AS ITS TROOPS REMAIN POISED TO RETAKE THE CAPITAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/06/world.print_headline: BRITAIN CHARTING A COURSE FOR FUTURE OF FALKLANDS AS ITS TROOPS REMAIN POISED TO RETAKE THE CAPITAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/06/world.body_text: **********The British Government has begun to map long-term development plans for the Falkland Islands that would maintain British sovereignty over the islands for the indefinite future, according to officials here. **********Meanwhile, British troops remained poised to retake Stanley, the islands' capital. Little news was forthcoming again today from the battlefield, but the assault will occur as soon as weather conditions improve and needed supplies and troops are positioned, probably within the next day or two, according to correspondents on the scene and military sources here. **********''British troops are knocking on the door of Port Stanley,'' said a pooled dispatch received today from the Falklands. **********Setback for Moderates Sighted **********The plans for future development, which have been discussed with increasing frequency in recent days, appear to represent a blow to moderate British officials, including Foreign Secretary Francis Pym, and to the United States, which had hoped that an accommodation could be reached with Argentina once military hostilities ended. **********But the tough line of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher - that the islands are not being retaken merely to be handed over to Argentina - is now clearly in ascendancy, and planning has begun for permanent military defenses, for economic development, for encouraging new settlers and perhaps even for eventual independence. **********''I cannot, myself, see a role in anything relating to sovereignty for the Argentines on the Falkland Islands,'' Mrs. Thatcher said in a television interview Wednesday. The islanders ''never wanted to go to Argentina before,'' she said. ''They'll be even less likely to do so now.'' 'We Must Be Loyal to Them' **********Mrs. Thatcher, speaking of the islanders, said that ''they've been loyal to us, we must be loyal to them.'' Legally, the 1,800 islanders are British citizens, although 300 do not have the automatic right to live in Britain because neither they nor a parent or a grandparent was born here. **********On Tuesday, Mrs. Thatcher asked Lord Shackleton, son of the explorer Sir Ernest Shackleton and author of a 1976 report on the future of the islands, to bring his recommendations up to date. **********''Things are a little bit different,'' Mrs. Thatcher said, ''but I want to be ready to go ahead as soon as we are able to.'' In her planning, Mrs. Thatcher is said to be hoping to involve other countries, particularly the United States and particularly to help maintain the islands' security. **********That is among the subjects Mrs. Thatcher plans to raise with President Reagan at their various meetings in France and Britain this weekend and early next week. An Expensive Proposition **********Maintaining British sovereignty is likely to be an expensive proposition. Even before the current difficulties, the islands had been costing Britain about $9 million a year. About 80 percent of that went to pay for the ice patrol ship Endurance and the small garrison of 40 marines. The remaining $1.8 million was provided by Britain's Overseas Development Administration for a variety of projects like road building and public services. **********''We do need things like development that we just don't have the funds for,'' said Alastair Cameron, an official at the Falkland Islands Office, which represents the islanders' interests in Britain. ''We need a broader based economy.'' **********The cost is likely to be high. For one thing, a far larger military garrison is being contemplated, although little discussion of its precise size has taken place. For another, damage done in the fighting will have to be repaired. **********The loss of the economic ties to Argentina will also prove expensive to the islands. In recent years, the only regular air service was provided by the Argentine state airline from Comodoro Rivadavia. A variety of supplies, including oil and gas, also came from Argentina, which is 250 miles away. **********Mrs. Thatcher said Wednesday that the small airstrip at Stanley would have to be extended to handle long-haul planes. That would cost $21.6 million, according to estimates by the Overseas Development Administration. Viable Economy Is Goal **********Perhaps most importantly, Mrs. Thatcher and her aides have been talking about providing the islands with a viable economy. In recent years the limited business opportunities have resulted in a slow population decline - a loss of 200 residents in the last four years alone. **********One issue in forming development plans will be the fact that the islands are virtually run economically by the 131-year-old Falkland Islands Company, a miniature version of the great trading companies like the East India Company. **********The Falkland Islands Company owns nearly half the land on the two main islands, employs about a third of the workers, provides the main banking service, manages the external sea-freight service, dominates retail distribution on the islands and controls the only significant product - about 2,250 tons a year of wool. **********Among the complaints of the islanders is that the company, a subsidiary of the Coalite Group of Britain, is run from London and brings its profits back to Britain as dividends rather than using them for further development of the islands. The only British taxes paid by the islands or their inhabitants are on the dividends sent to Britain. Possibilities and Problems **********But how much industry can be profitably developed is questionable.  Export of mutton would probably not be viable because the sheep on the Falklands are bred for their wool and are not suitable for use as meat. Oil and gas has been widely discussed, but no commercial reserves have been discovered. **********Another proposal has been tourism and the Overseas Development Administration has made money available for promotion, but no one has applied for it. ''The Falklands are a long way from anywhere,'' a development administration official said. **********According to the 1980 census, the islands' population of about 1,800 included only 890 wage earners. And whether development can proceed as long as relations with Argentina are hostile also remains in doubt. **********For his part, Lord Shackleton, whose earlier report complained about the flow of money out of the islands and to Britain, professed confidence about the islands' prospects, although he acknowledged that time would be needed. Among the possibilities raised were fishing and alginate, a product of seaweed, which is plentiful. **********''You can see immense possibilities,'' he said, ''if you look over a very long time scale.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/16/world.main_headline: SOVIET 'HERO' INFORMER, 13, LEAVES A BITTER LEGACY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/16/world.print_headline: SOVIET 'HERO' INFORMER, 13, LEAVES A BITTER LEGACY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/16/world.body_text: **********Fifty years ago a 13-year-old boy named Pavlik Morozov denounced his father to local authorities and was hacked to death by vengeful relatives in his muddy Urals village, leaving behind a legend and a troubled legacy. **********''His name must not die,'' declared the writer Maxim Gorky, and Pavlik became a Communist folk hero, one of the first models of Soviet behavior held up to schoolchildren for emulation. **********He is portrayed as the martyr who put the state above oldfashioned loyalties, a Pioneer hero whose statue and school in the village of Gerasimovka, in the northern Urals' Tavda district, draw legions of youthful pilgrims, and whose story is recounted in books and newspapers. A Moscow street is named for him, and his name is borne by countless chapters of the Young Pioneers, the Communist children's organization. **********Stalin's Informers Recalled **********But as an informer, Pavlik was also a pioneer of a practice that became the mainstay of Stalin's terror, sending millions to forcedlabor camps or to their death for real or imagined crimes against the state. One memoir of the time describes a woman who had denounced so many neighbors that she suffered a paralyzing stroke when she learned that labor camp inmates were being rehabilitated after Stalin's death in 1953 and would be coming home. **********Denunciations may no longer pack the wallop they did in Stalin's day. But habits and memories die hard, and the legacy of Pavlik Morozov survives in the distrust Soviet citizens often still demonstrate for strangers, in the whispered hints that an acquaintance may be a ''stukach,'' an informer. **********The 50th anniversary of the 1932 killing of Pavlik demonstrated no diminution of his legend, including a tribute by one reporter who wrote that his heart contracted with painful emotion as he entered Gerasimovka and read the sign, ''Home of Pavlik Morozov.'' Line Is Difficult to Draw **********It is difficult to draw the line between official surveillance and unsolicited informing in a society as controlled and secretive as that of the Soviet Union. Each research institute, factory or government office is presumed to have its resident watchdogs. **********There are also innumerable free-lancers - the pensioners who report what they view as suspicious doings in their housing projects, the would-be emigre who is promised an early visa if he cooperates with the authorities, the jealous worker who denounces a better-paid colleague in an anonymous letter. **********The endemic distrust often serves in itself as a curb on activities that may be deemed suspicious by the authorities. A prominent Soviet poet, recounting one of his many trips abroad, fell silent or changed the subject each time his maid walked through the room. At a small gathering of intellectuals, all friends, a foreign reporter is quietly steered aside by a man with information to impart. **********A dissident writer who works at home said he had been summoned several times to the local police station to explain how he made a living. It turned out that someone had denounced him as a ''parasite,'' meaning a person seemingly living without earned income. Some Official Irritation Shown **********The scope of such practices may be gauged by the fact that the authorities have been showing sporadic irritation in the press, at least over anonymous denunciations, popularly known as ''anonimki,'' that are deemed unfounded. **********At the last party congress, in February 1981, Leonid I. Brezhnev said the party's view of such denunciations was well known. ''They have no place in our life!'' he said. **********These words, the official record states, ''drew prolonged applause.'' They also prompted yet another spate of criticism in the press against officials who pay heed to anonymous informants and against the leniency shown slanderers when they are brought to light. **********In one such report, the daily newspaper Sovetskaya Rossiya told the story of a graduate student whose doctoral dissertation - on the critical subject of ''intensifying livestock production in semi-arid areas'' - had been pigeonholed for years by false denunciations that generated successive inquiries. **********''Whatever the anonimshchik churned out was taken on faith, while his victim was told: Prove this is not so if you can,'' the newspaper said. 'Honorable' Informing Approved **********But even while assailing the authorities for acting on anonymous information, the reporter reminded his readers that ''constructive criticism'' - even from an ''honorable anomimshchik'' - had a vital role in Soviet society. **********The weekly newspaper Literaturnaya Gazeta recently described an informer who was said to have falsely besmirched an investigative reporter in more than 50 letters. When finally imprisoned, the weekly said, the man could not understand why it was wrong to pass on rumors and insinuations. **********''He still believed, he was absolutely certain, that he had done nothing illegal, improper or punishable,'' the newspaper wrote. In jail, he told the paper's reporter, ''I simply wanted to bring these things to the attention of the agencies of control.'' **********In fact, people brought up on the Pavlik Morozov legend may be justified in questioning the prosecution of a man for sending what is euphemistically called a ''signal'' to the authorities. Time of Kulaks' Persecution **********The deed for which Pavlik was murdered - and immortalized - was to turn in his father for aiding fugitive kulaks, the landowning peasants who were being expropriated and persecuted by Stalin during the farm collectivization drive of the late 1920's and early 1930's.  Generations of young people have since then been raised on the image of the tall Urals village youth standing under a portrait of Lenin in the courthouse and proclaiming, ''I accuse my father not as his son, but as a Pioneer.'' **********Soon after, Pavlik's grandfather and cousin killed the boy and his 9-year-old brother with knives fashioned from scythes, a deed for which they were executed by a firing squad. **********According to another recent report in Sovetskaya Rossiya, children still do write in about their parents. But the paper's attitude toward the letters suggested a waning, or at least a new interpretation, of the Pavlik legend. **********Informers' scribblings on sheets of school notebooks, the paper said, leave one feeling somewhat uneasy. Behavior Now Called Unnatural **********''There is something fundamentally unnatural,'' the paper said, ''in having a child, an adolescent, a youth assailing the holy of holies - respect and love for father and mother.'' And yet, the paper continued, such letters may simply be an expression of a mature love, the discovery of parental qualities ''that cannot possibly be left unquestioned.'' **********The paper quoted a schoolgirl called Sveta Morozova, who reported that her mother had been stealing from the food store where she works. The paper advised the girl to confront her mother herself.  Predictably, the wayward mother was fully rehabilitated. **********The latter-day Morozov morality tale seemed a far cry from the original, although the legend about Pavlik curiously omit any word on what befell his father, just as official history remains vague about the fate of the hundreds of thousands of kulaks who were uprooted and hounded by Stalin as ''sworn enemies of the collective farm movement.''
