https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/04/busin.body_text: **********To the Business Editor: Those who agree or disagree with Harvard Professors Hayes and Abernathy in ''Management Gospel Gone Wrong'' (May 30) will find themselves in accord if they will consider one all-encompassing thought: **********In manufacturing, all capital flows through the company as work-inprocess inventory. Capital, invested in labor, materials, equipment and overhead, completes its cycle as finished goods and is measured as accounts receivable. **********These accounts receivable encompass the capital (to be reinvested for another cycle) and profit. **********Cycling the work flow quicker is, in fact, cycling the cash flow quicker, which achieves all the gains in profit, timely delivery and productivity. With a little deeper investigation it becomes clear that the two qualities we think of as ''Japanese'' also are achieved: quality of product and quality of life in the work environment. **********This faster cycling comes only from management devoting better attention to operations.  In 14 years of guiding management organizations, I have witnessed each exceed Japan's productivity growth in less than the first 90 days of managerial effort, and with little notice by industry. Hats off to Hayes and Abernathy. They have achieved more attention in less time with theory written in their Harvard ivory tower than I have as a shirt-sleeved pragmatist on the shop floor. WILLIAM E. SANDMAN Chairman, Wm. E. Sandman Inc.  Dresher Pa., June 22, 1982

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/26/world.print_headline: ARABS' ARMED STRENGTH: STILL A WORRY FOR ISRAELIS; Military Analysis
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/26/world.body_text: **********Despite Israel's victory over Palestinian guerrillas and Syrian troops in Lebanon last summer, Israeli intelligence officials say they are concerned over the pace of arms supplies to Arab nations.  They say this could eventually erode Israel's superiority. **********An immediate problem for Israel, the informants say, is Libya's shipments of weapons to Palestinian guerrillas still in Lebanon.  Israeli estimates are that there still are 10,000 to 12,000 guerrillas. **********But the Israelis also cite a long-term problem - what they see as an Arab military potential. They say they fear that the stream of weapons and support equipment, American, Soviet, British and French, into the Arab countries could in time give their Arab neighbors a qualitative strength approaching Israel's present superiority. **********Speaking of immediate concerns, one Israeli informant said that field guns and antitank and antiaircraft weapons were being airlifted from Libya into northern Lebanon. The weapons are drawn from stocks that were sent to Libya by the Soviet Union and, according to Western analysts, were beyond Libya's ability to absorb. 2,000 Guerrillas in Beirut **********The informant said that 2,000 Palestinian guerrillas remained underground in Beirut, that 6,000 were with the Syrian Army in the Bekaa Valley of eastern Lebanon and that 2,000 to 4,000 were around Tripoli in the north. Most of the arms being flown into Lebanon, Israeli sources said, probably will go first to the guerrillas with the Syrians and then to the forces around Tripoli. **********At the moment, the Israelis say, they do not see the Syrians as an immediate danger. Syrian forces along the Lebanese frontier, they say, have pulled back slightly and show no signs of aggressive action. **********The Israelis are worried, however, by the pace of Soviet arms shipments to Syria. Some say that Syrian losses in tanks, which were relatively light, already have been made up, and they say there is a steady flow of SAM-8 and SAM-9 surface-to-air missiles into Syria. **********The Syrians were imprudent enough to deploy the first of these in the Bekaa Valley, where they were promptly destroyed by Israeli planes. Since then the missiles have replaced the SAM-6's guarding the approaches to Damascus. Later Reports More Sober **********Later reports by Israeli veterans of the summer's military campaign are a good deal more sober than the estimates made in the moment of victory. **********For example, they point out that the Syrian armor and infantry fought effectively in defense, clinging to their positions under heavy air and artillery attack. Two weaknesses, however, were said to have developed. **********The Israelis said that Syrian coordination of the artillery with armor and infantry was slipshod and that the Syrians were not impressive when they operated outside fixed positions. **********A long-term Israeli view is that, given time to obtain new supplies, and with more training, the Syrian Army and Air Force can re-emerge as Israel's most dangerous potential foes. **********An independent study group sponsored by Israeli universities reported in a recent paper that, from 1973 until the present, Arab arms purchases were as follows: Syria, $9.2 billion; Iraq, $8.35 billion; Saudi Arabia, $13 billion, and Libya, $9.4 billion. Egypt, which Israeli intelligence classifies as at least a potential enemy, received $3.51 billion in arms. Outstanding Orders Listed **********The known outstanding orders, the report said, are: Iraq, $6 billion; Saudi Arabia, $17.92 billion; Libya, $450 million, and Egypt, $2.66 billion. Jordan, whose army and air force are rated highly by the Israelis, has received $980 million in arms supplies to date but is said to have outstanding orders for $2.38 billion in arms. **********The Arab armies and air forces, an Israeli intelligence source said, ''are going through a cycle of complete rearmament in the most advanced weapons.'' He said that the Syrians had almost completed the cycle and that the others were ''moving rapidly toward completion.'' He said also that the armed forces in each of the countries were being trained in the maintenance of their weapons as well as in their use and in the command and control systems to be employed in battle. Arab Strength Is Projected **********On the basis of the arms sales, the independent study concluded, by 1986 five Arab countries - Syria, Iraq, Jordan, Saudi Arabia and Libya - will be able to deploy 12,300 tanks, 11,100 armored personnel carriers, 8,050 artillery pieces, 230 surface-to-surface missile launchers, 2,370 combat planes, 1,045 helicopters, 520 surface-to-air missile batteries and 101 combat ships. **********Israelis, however, note that there are weaknesses in the Arab military structure. One is the failure of Arab high commands to work together in war against Israel. A second is the rivalries in peace among them. **********Jordan and Syria are mutually hostile, the Israelis point out.  Iraq's military substance is being eroded by the war with Iran.  Egypt, potentially the most powerful Arab country, is still ostracized because of its peace treaty with Israel. **********A final weakness, Israelis say, is a lack of initiative shown by unit commanders in battle, a weakness that is common to all the Arab armies save that of Jordan. This is said to be a legacy from the years of Soviet military tutelage.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/12/world.main_headline: MEXICAN WRATH FALLS ON TEEN-AGE SEER AND SECT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/12/world.print_headline: MEXICAN WRATH FALLS ON TEEN-AGE SEER AND SECT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/12/world.body_text: **********All over Mexico there are shrines to the Virgin Mary and myriad saints that are visited by thousands - in some cases millions - of pilgrims each year. The visitors ask for miracles, give thanks for favors granted or merely seek forgiveness and protection. **********But New Jerusalem, site of a reported apparition of the Virgin Mary in October 1973, has suddenly become famous throughout the country, not because of its miracles but because Mexican news organizations have chosen to denounce those in charge of the shrine as charlatans, asserting they use violence, sex and extortion to promote their faith. **********The particular targets of the attacks are 72-year-old Nabor Cardenas, an unfrocked priest who is referred to as Papa Nabor, and 16-year-old Arcadia Garcia, who claims to receive messages from the Virgin Mary and is known here as Mama Maria de Jesus. Between them, they control the lives of the 5,000 or so pilgrims who have settled in New Jerusalem, some 180 miles northwest of Mexico City. **********On Sept. 18 violence erupted when a small group of ''dissidents'' who followed a different medium were attacked with sticks and stones and chased out of the community. They then took their complaints to newspapers and a leading television station, which began a fierce campaign against the sect, calling for state intervention and repeating unproved charges that pilgrims were forced to pay huge sums of money and that Mama Maria participated in orgies with her ''monks.'' 'Virgin Will Protect Us' **********The controversy, however, has served only to strengthen the faith of those living here. ''The Virgin provoked the scandal so that the Word would spread, so bells would ring all over the world,'' Father Nabor said. ''But nothing can happen to us. The Virgin will protect us.'' **********The Bishop in nearby Tacambaro, Luis Morales Reyes, is alarmed.  For years he has quietly combated the sect, but now he is more fearful of society's reaction to New Jerusalem.  ''I'm not saying we're going to have a Guyana,'' he said, alluding to the mass suicide at Jonestown in 1978, ''but even two or three dead would be serious.  I say, leave them in peace.  It's enough to say that the apparitions are false.'' **********He has met with the Governor of Morelia state, Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, and obtained assurances that the police will not intervene. ''They're an enclave and we must accept them,'' the Bishop said.  ''I know Father Nabor well. He was my teacher when I was a seminarian. He's a good man. But he's now suffering from religious paranoia.'' Sect Grows More Isolated **********Since its foundation nine years ago, the sect has become gradually more isolated from society. According to the faithful, the Virgin of the Rosary appeared to an old peasant widow, Gabina Romero de Sanchez, with instructions that a shrine be built here. Then, on Oct. 7, 1973, before a crowd of some 10,000 people gathered by Father Nabor, at that time the parish priest in nearby Puruaran, Mrs.  Sanchez unwrapped her shawl and an image of the Virgin appeared ''miraculously'' on a piece of cloth. **********Soon afterward, construction of the shrine began, with Mrs. Sanchez - who became known as Mama Salome -claiming to be receiving daily messages from the Virgin of the Rosary on how the religious community should be formed. Word of the miracle spread through Mexico and busloads of pilgrims would arrive at the shrine each weekend. **********But after the Bishop of Tacambaro at the time, Jose Abraham Martinez, declared the apparitions to be false and suspended the priest, Father Nabor turned his wrath against the entire Roman Catholic Church. The messages from the Virgin suddenly began to denounce Rome and proclaim that only those living in New Jerusalem would be saved when the world ends in 1990. **********Father Nabor also built up his own organization, with hundreds of nuns and monks adopting the names of saints and taking vows of poverty, chastity and obedience to the orders emanating from the stern priest and his aging medium. **********Even after Mama Salome died in March last year, the phenomenon survived because, within weeks, Arcadia Garcia, then only 14 years old, and a 21-year-old ''nun'' known as Santa Maria Margarita claimed to be receiving messages from the Virgin through the spirit of Mama Salome. Until the clash between followers of the two groups in September, Father Nabor listened to -or used - them both. An Unlikely Seer **********Today Mama Maria de Jesus has been accepted as the chosen vehicle for messages from above, but she seems an unlikely seer. Although wearing a special habit, much of the time she seems to behave like a spoiled teen-ager, running around the shrine in tennis shoes and carrying a doll called Yolis that is dressed to look like her. Among her closest aides are three brothers, Michael, Patrick and John Moore, who moved here from Fort Collins, Colo., several years ago. **********But she is not shy of exhibiting her powers. While answering the questions of visitors, she was prompted by Father Nabor to offer some message from the Virgin Mary. She then appeared to go into a trance, rolled onto the floor, where she was held by Michael Moore, and then, with her eyes closed, proceded to speak in the different voices of various saints, each willing to be interrogated by the visitors. **********''The Pope is a fraud,'' she said, supposedly speaking in the voice of the Archangel Gabriel. ''Pope Paul VI is imprisoned in the basement of the Vatican so that the Antichrist can enter. The anti-Christ is already here. He is 29 years old and comes from Guadalajara and soon he will be called to Rome. This is the Ark of our Holy Mother. Only those at Her feet will be saved.'' **********As she spoke, a huge crowd of nuns, monks, children and old people gathered to watch in silent awe.  Barely two miles away in Puruaran, though, New Jerusalem was still viewed with skepticism. ''I tell you, they're all mad,'' said a gas station attendant, who warned the visitors against traveling to the shrine. ''But madder still are those who go there.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/17/world.main_headline: Europe Missile Compromise Is Proposed by U.S. Experts
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/17/world.print_headline: Europe Missile Compromise Is Proposed by U.S. Experts
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/17/world.body_text: **********An arms control group headed by Paul Warnke, former United States arms negotiator, proposed a compromise today in limiting missiles in Europe. **********Under the plan, the Atlantic alliance would drop plans for the deployment of 572 medium-range missiles and the Soviet Union would scrap 380. **********Mr. Warnke and three other former officials, members of the Committee for National Security, a private group, told reporters that this would leave the Russians with 215 SS-20's carrying 645 warheads and the West with 184 American, French and British submarine-launched missiles with 544 warheads.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/20/busin.body_text: **********Two of Pennsylvania's largest bank holding companies, the Pittsburgh National Corporation and the Provident National Corporation, said today that they had agreed in principle to merge. **********The combination would create one of the nation's biggest banking organizations. **********Under the merger, a new holding company, the PNC Corporation, would be started with assets of about $10.2 billion. But the existing holding companies would retain their separate names, directors and staffs. **********The merger must be approved by the banks' shareholders and directors and regulatory agencies.  Pittsburgh National, the state's second-largest bank behind the Mellon Bank, had 1981 year-end assets of $6.9 billion, and Provident National of Philadelphia was ranked seventh with $3.3 billion in assets. **********''I think it's a superb combination,'' said Paul Mackey, a banking securities analyst with Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc.  ''You're putting two extraordinarily capitalized, very high earning banks together,'' he said. ''You're increasing the economic size of the unit, so right away it greatly strengthens the bank's equity base and makes it able to handle larger credits.'' **********Merle E. Gilliand, chairman of Pittsburgh National, would become chairman and chief executive of PNC. Roger S. Hillas, chairman of Provident National, would become president. **********Under the agreement, Pittsburgh National's common stock would be exchanged for that of the new corporation on a share-for-share basis, the banks said. **********The merger is the second involving a Pittsburgh bank since a new law liberalizing state banking went into effect in March. The new law permits more branch banking and allows bank holding companies to buy up to eight banks in the next eight years.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/20/world.main_headline: A MAYOR IN SOUTH PHILIPPINES TAUNTS MARCOS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/20/world.print_headline: A MAYOR IN SOUTH PHILIPPINES TAUNTS MARCOS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/20/world.body_text: **********In this southern Philippine city, which is still under martial law, opposition to the 17-yearold presidency of Ferdinand E. Marcos appears to be growing under the flamboyant leadership of Mayor Cesar C. Climaco. **********Zamboanga was the only city in this southern region to produce a majority vote in assembly elections on June 7 against the President's ruling party, the New Society Movement. It was defeated here by the Concerned Citizens Group, a party that was created and led by Mr.  Climaco. **********Although the 66-year-old Mayor does not personally represent a political threat to Mr. Marcos, he has used his office and the city of Zamboanga to illustrate what he calls the failures of the Marcos regime. **********One of his first projects after he became Mayor in 1980 was to erect a billboard on the front of the two-story City Hall listing the crimes committed in this city of 350,000. For 1981 the figures are 255 killed, 10 kidnapped, 208 robbed. Eight Bombings During May **********''Practically every night people get killed here,'' said Mayor Climaco. ''In May eight bombs killed two and injured about 50.'' The billboard, he said, is his way of challenging the regional and district military commanders who are in charge of security in this southern area. **********President Marcos has declared the Government the victor in the 10-year-old battle with the secessionist forces of the Moro National Liberation Front, but Mayor Climaco said his scoreboard and the frequent bombings here proved otherwise. **********Region 9, of which Zamboanga is part, is one of the two autonomous regions established by the Marcos Government to give the Moslem minority a say in the administration of the southern part of the country. **********''But the autonomous government is a joke,'' said Mr. Climaco. He said he was convinced that it was Mr. Marcos's failure to give the Moslems what had been promised that made Zamboanga a battleground. **********For several years, this city was considered unsafe for outsiders.  Residents carried guns, and there was a curfew. Industrialization Sought **********Zamboanga, now open again, is part of the region that the Government is seeking to revitalize and industralize, largely in response to urging by Moslem countries of the Middle East that supply oil to the Philippines. Some of the projects, however, are badly behind schedule and over their budgets. **********On the unpaved road outside the site where the Ministry of Tourism is building a convention center for the city, Mayor Climaco has put up two billboards attacking ''incompetence, irregularity and graft'' in the project. One sign reads, ''Lord Almighty, hear our prayers, as we know not when this long-overdue and extravagant monster of the Ministry of Tourism will be complete.'' **********Mayor Climaco, an energetic showman, has vowed not to cut his hair until martial law is lifted. Though his hair has been growing for 10 years, it is sparse and graying and only reaches his shoulders. **********During Mr. Climaco's tenure, the city's income has increased from $3 million to $6.7 million. New streets have been built, and the Mayor has planned an industrial park and new housing areas that he hopes will accommodate some of the refugees who came to Zamboanga to escape guerrilla fighting in the rural areas. Returned From U.S. **********He said it was the development of a grassroots opposition here that had led his supporters to bring him back to the Philippines from the United States in 1978. He had been Mayor of Zamboanga earlier, from 1953 to 1961, but retired to law practice after losing three attempts to win election to the national Senate. He then emigrated to the United States. Two of his six children are surgeons in Illinois.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/28/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Texaco Executives Exchanging Posts
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/28/busin.body_text: **********James W. Kinnear, a 53-year-old executive vice president of Texaco Inc., has been named to the additional post of president of Texaco U.S.A., the corporation's largest division, which is based in Houston. At the same time Annon M. Card, a 62-year-old executive vice president who previously held the presidency of Texaco U.S.A., will return to the Harrison, N.Y., headquarters to oversee many of the international activities of the company that Mr. Kinnear previously supervised. **********The management changes at Texaco, the nation's third-largest oil company, place Mr. Kinnear in a key position under John K. McKinley, the chairman, president and chief executive officer, who will be 62 in March. The third executive vice president, Alfred C. DeCrane Jr., is a 50-year-old lawyer and, like Mr. Kinnear, a director of the company. **********Texaco U.S.A., which accounts for 44 percent of the parent's assets and 37 percent of its earnings, encompasses exploration, refining, transportation, and marketing of oil, gas and petroleum products in the United States. It was established two years ago when the corporation underwent an organizational overhaul that set up five new divisions, three geographical and two functional. **********Mr. Kinnear, a graduate of Annapolis, has spent his entire career with Texaco, starting in marketing in 1954. He became a vice president 12 years later and senior vice president for strategic planning in 1970. He has been an executive vice president for about four years. **********Mr. Card has been with Texaco since 1947 and was appointed vice president for United States marketing in 1966. Among the posts he held before becoming an executive vice president in 1980 was head of Texaco Europe. Mr. Card will now have overall responsibility for that unit, as well as for Texaco Canada, Caltex Petroleum and others.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/21/busin.body_text: **********The well-known loan losses of some of the nation's most prominent banks have prompted some money market funds to withdraw hundreds of millions of dollars from those banks and have thereby created a destabilizing force in American banking, according to Federal Reserve officials, bankers, and even some money fund executives themselves. **********The fear is that the money funds, which have become an important source of funds for banks, are reacting in lockstep in withdrawing their money from banks whose troubled loans have become widely publicized. Bankers and officials are concerned that money funds have become excessively sensitive to publicity given banking problems and are pulling out their money from unquestionably sound institutions. **********Although the money funds, by offering much higher rates of interest than banks, have attracted billions of dollars that might otherwise have gone into savings accounts, much of this has been recycled back into the big banks by investing the funds in large certificates of deposits. **********At present the money funds control about $200 billion. Based on figures supplied by Donoghue's Money Fund Report of Sept. 13, the 10 largest money market mutual funds, out of a total of 205, held $24.7 billion in bank C.D.'s. The problem, bankers say, is not so much the aggregate size of these holdings, but the fact that at times a fund will suddenly pull a large amount out of a bank. **********Millions Withdrawn **********Last July, for example, following the failure of the Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma City, a number of money market funds pulled hundreds of millions of dollars out of the Chase Manhattan Bank and the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago, or did not renew deposits when they expired. **********As a result, Chase, the nation's third-largest bank, and Continental, the sixth largest, had to pay considerably more than other banks for their deposits. **********The Chicago Board of Trade, the world's largest commodities exchange, removed Chase from the list of banks whose certificates of deposit may be delivered against the board's domestic futures contracts. Earlier, Continental had voluntarily removed itself from the list. **********The pullback by the money market funds was in response to losses incurred by the two giant banks as the result of energy-related loans they had purchased from the Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma City, which failed last July 5. Chase, in addition, had experienced a large loss as the result of its dealings with the now-defunct Drysdale Government Securities Corporation. Quarterly Losses for 2 Banks **********These problems caused Continental to report a $61 million after-tax loss in the second quarter and Chase a $16 million loss. This was the first time in recent history that any of the nation's top 10 banks had reported a quarterly loss, and in that sense the news was dramatic. **********In terms of the banks' basic soundness, the losses were minute. At Continental, the loss represented only 2.9 percent of its equity and reserves for loan losses, and at Chase only 0.35 of 1 percent.  Equity is the amount invested in the bank by its shareholders. **********Chase and Continental were not the only major banks affected.  Rumors spread about other big banks and they, too, became victims.  Most of the withdrawn deposits were shifted into Treasury bills or commercial paper, which are i.o.u.'s of large corporations. **********In many cases, the money fund managers themselves had no fears about the basic soundness of the banks from which they had withdrawn money. **********The problem is that the fund managers must worry not only about the actual creditworthiness of the bank whose C.D.'s they hold, but also about the public's perception of that bank's creditworthiness.  Each money fund regularly publishes a prospectus showing its investments. The fear is that the fund's investors might withdraw their money if they see that the fund is holding a C.D. of a bank that had recently encountered problems. **********''There are two things that we consider - creditworthiness and perception of creditworthiness,'' said Jeffrey B. Lane, senior executive vice president of Shearson/American Express, which runs a number of money market mutual funds, the largest of which is the $6.4 billion Shearson Daily Dividend Fund. **********There are 400,000 investors in Shearson funds who make their investments through 4,200 brokers, Mr. Lane noted. ''I don't want to have to convince the 4,200 brokers that the bank's C.D. is good, it's not worth my time,'' he said. Impact on Markets Cited **********It is this kind of attitude that is troubling many officials and bankers. They argue that because of the vast size of some of the money market mutual funds, their managers should consider the effect of their actions on the financial markets as well as the short-term interests of their clients. **********Most money fund managers do not agree. ''You have $200 billion of assets floating around, that's no small matter,'' Mr. Lane acknowledged. ''But we are not being paid to take risks, be diplomats or heroes. We want our customers to sleep well.'' **********Mr. Lane, like most other money fund managers interviewed, declined to discuss specific investments.  Even those who are deeply concerned about the impact of the money funds on the market concede that the fund managers' first responsibility is to their investors. **********''I've felt for a long time that we'd be better off if we had a smaller money market mutual fund industry,'' said J. Charles Partee, a governor of the Federal Reserve Board. ''I've always thought of the funds as being impersonal investors with no continuing relationships that they want to preserve. They represent total self-interest - I wouldn't expect anything else from them.'' 'Social Responsibility' **********There are some money fund executives, however, who have begun to ponder whether the size of their organizations has created new responsibilities. ''Our first responsibility is the interests of our shareholders,'' said the manager of one of the nation's biggest money market mutual funds, who asked not to be identified. ''At the same time, we realize that we have some kind of social responsibility too. There are other constituencies that must be served, including the overall economy.'' **********Continental, Chase and other banks that had trouble raising deposits from the money market funds obtained funds from other banks, both domestic and foreign. **********''We took care not to be simply reactive, and based our decisions on judgments about the real creditworthiness of the banks involved, not about popular perceptions,'' said Charles S. Sanford Jr., executive vice president of the Bankers Trust Company. **********Many bankers and officials are saying that the giant money funds should have recognized similar responsibilities. Major Banks Dropped **********But John N. Breazeale relates how his fund no longer holds deposits in any of the nation's major banks, except for the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company. Mr. Breazeale is first vice president of the $6.75 billion Cashfund Inc., which is managed by Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis Inc. **********On March 31, according to its prospectus, Cashfund held $233 million in C.D.'s issued by Continental Illinois. ''If you had called me at that time, I would have been very proud of that,'' Mr.  Breazeale said. But since then Continental's second-quarter loss was disclosed and Cashfund rid itself of Continental paper. Continental, as well as other banks, declined to comment for the record on the actions of the money funds. **********Cashfund also no longer will hold C.D.'s of the Bank of America, the nation's largest. On March 31, Cashfund held $50 million of that bank's C.D.'s. Asked why Cashfund dropped Bank of America, Mr.  Breazeale said he was not sure, but thought there might have been concern about its foreign loans. **********It also will no longer buy C.D.'s of the Seattle-First National Bank, another bank that reported a $55.4 million loss in the second quarter. On March 31, Cashfund held $95 million in C.D.'s from the Seattle bank, the largest in Washington State. **********Although Cashfund no longer holds deposits in the nation's major banks, except for Morgan, Mr. Breazeale said, ''I believe personally that these banks are viable entities, but I thought for a while that things would get worse before they'd get better.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/17/busin.main_headline: PRIME BACK TO 16 1 2% AT 4 BIG BANKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/17/busin.print_headline: PRIME BACK TO 16 1 2% AT 4 BIG BANKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/17/busin.body_text: **********A tentative trend toward lower interest rates was aborted yesterday as four major banks raised their prime lending rates half a percentage point, to 16 1/2 percent, reversing a downward move they made March 8. **********As a result, the prime rate at all the nation's major banks now stands at the 16 1/2 percent level.  The four big banks that announced they would return their prime to the 16 1/2 percent level were the Chase Manhattan Bank, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, the Bankers Trust Company and the First National Bank of Chicago. **********''We were very reluctant to make this move, but the fact is that the cost of funds over the past week has significantly exceeded this increase in the prime,'' said Willard C. Butcher, chairman of the Chase. Money Supply Rise Cited **********Despite hopes last week that interest rates had begun a downward trend, in recent days most short-term rates have risen. Part of the impetus for the reversal, according to bankers, was the announcement by the Federal Reserve System last Friday that the money supply increased by $3.4 billion in the week ended March 3. **********Money market participants expect the Fed to tighten its monetary policy when the growth in the money supply exceeds its targets, as it now does. For this reason, holders of funds demand greater returns on their money, and interest rates are driven upward. **********As a result, the interest rates that banks must pay to borrow funds themselves have been rising sharply. The rate on three-month certificates of deposit that are issued in denominations of at least $1 million - a chief source of bank funds - rose to almost 14 1/2 percent yesterday from 13.65 percent a week earlier. **********Similarly, the rate on Federal funds, overnight money that banks trade among themselves, rose to about 15 1/4 percent yesterday from 13.7 percent a week earlier. 'Overburdened Credit Markets' **********A number of bankers and economists were surprised by the sudden spurt in interest rates. ''The consensus forecast of declining interest rates has been refuted again by the reality of overburdened credit markets,'' said Alan Lerner, senior vice president and economist at Bankers Trust. **********At 16 percent, the prime was the lowest it had been since last December, when it stood at 15 3/4 percent before going back up to 17 percent in mid-February and then falling again. **********Some bankers, even some whose banks had not gone to the 16 percent level, had been hopeful that interest rates would fall considerably further as a result of the recession and declining inflation. ''We could be seeing a prime of 14 percent within the next 30 to 45 days,'' George R. Baker, executive vice president of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, said last week. **********But the recent rise in basic interest rates has dashed some of these hopes.  Mr. Lerner said the prime rate might climb an additional two percentage points within the next few months. He expects the increase because he believes the money supply will rise in the weeks ahead, which will encourage the Fed to maintain a relatively tight grip on the money supply. **********The prime is a key lending rate because interest rates on many business loans are tied to it. In borrowing from banks, major corporations are often charged rates below the prime, while interest rates charged on loans to smaller companies are usually scaled up from the prime.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/22/world.main_headline: JOYFUL CHEERS ATTEND THE ROYAL BIRTH
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/22/world.print_headline: JOYFUL CHEERS ATTEND THE ROYAL BIRTH
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/22/world.body_text: **********A long day of waiting for a royal birth ended tonight. A crowd of about 500 people waving Union Jacks and holding bottles of champagne cheered the arrival of the second-in-line to the throne shortly after 9 P.M., when the word flashed through the crowd that it was a boy. **********The news came from a reporter carrying a small walkie-talkie, and it moved through the crowd like a wave and came back in the form of cheers. Within a minute there were ''hip hip hoorays'' followed by a chant of ''We want Charlie!'' **********After about an hour, Prince Charles came out. As the crowd roared, he answered reporters' questions briefly, but as any new father might. 'Rather a Shock to My System' **********How do you feel, he was asked.  ''It's rather a grown-up thing, I find, rather a shock to my system,'' he replied.  What's the baby like?  ''The baby is blond, sort of fairish.'' How is Diana doing?  ''She is just so relieved. We're both delighted.'' What is the boy's name?  ''You better ask my wife. We've thought about one, but we had a little argument.'' Hilde Vernlie from Zurich broke through the metal barricades to the center of the street and popped a cork on a bottle of champagne she had been carrying all day. Young men squatting on a wall opposite the hospital, St. Mary's, tore paper into confetti and threw it into the air; the pieces were caught in the lights of television lights behind them. Crowd Begins a Chant **********Now the crowd did a turn on a soccer cheer: ''Nice one, Charlie.  Nice one, son. Nice one, Charlie. Let's have another one.'' It was a happy ending to a long day under dripping skies. Fiona Stevenson, of Wrexham, Wales, said it was worth the wait. She had listened to reports on the radio all day, she said, but finally, ''I had to come.'' **********She said she was pleased that such a joyous event had come so soon after the end of the fighting in the Falklands. The point was echoed by others in the crowd who were stirred by the sense of national unity that happy events for the royal family can bring. Policemen Stand Guard **********Throughout the day two policemen stood at the top of the steps at the entrance to the Lindo Wing of the hospital. They kept the goodnatured crowd at bay across the street but granted passage to those who needed to get in, including one pregnant woman who arrived, to the crowd's cheers, with her husband. **********Joanna Fitzgerald, of Willesden, and her sister Mary were wearing red felt bowlers banded in a Union Jack motif. They stood against the barrier yelling, ''Come on Diana.'' **********Occasionally people arrived with bouquets of flowers. A teen-aged girl, clad in a summery white dress, received an ovation when she came bearing a single yellow rose. A woman selling flowers around the corner said that Americans were among those who had ordered bouquets to be sent in. **********Vendors were busy. One was selling Wedgwood ware for 1, or $1.80, a plate. Selling better were Union Jacks, to the entreaty, ''Show your colors - buy a flag.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/29/busin.main_headline: MEXICO SOFTENS IMPACT OF BANK NATIONALIZATION
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/29/busin.print_headline: MEXICO SOFTENS IMPACT OF BANK NATIONALIZATION
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/29/busin.body_text: **********Mexico's new Government moved to soften the impact of the nationalization of the country's private banks last September by announcing plans to sell off 34 percent of the nationalized banks. **********The move is expected to stir criticism from leftist and nationalist groups that have pledged to fight any efforts by the one-month-old Government of President Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado to reverse or weaken the state takeover of the banking system. **********But the proposal, contained in a bill sent to Congress Monday night, does not contemplate returning shares to the former bank owners. It would offer them for purchase by Federal, state and municipal agencies, bank workers and bank users. No single shareholder would be allowed to own more than 1 percent of the stock in the banks. **********The Federal Government will retain a controlling 66 percent interest in the banks, while the Minister of Finance will serve as chairman of the board of all the banks, the proposal stated. **********In his inaugural address Dec.1, Mr. de la Madrid stressed that the bank nationalization was ''irreversible,'' but he promised ''new and imaginative'' ways of enabling society to participate in both the management and ownership of the banks. His proposal to sell 34 percent of the nationalized banks was in fulfillment of that campaign pledge. **********''To nationalize does not imply absolute state control,'' Mr. de la Madrid said. ''The nationalized banks should belong to the people and not to a new minority of leaders.'' Means of Selling Shares Unclear **********According to the Mexican Bankers' Association, the total capital of the nationalized banks exceeded 80 billion pesos, or around $500 million at current exchange rates, last September. Theoretically, the Government could obtain some $170 million from the sale of 34 percent of the stock.Many other questions raised by the bank nationalization last September still have to be clarified, including how the former bank owners are to be compensated and what will happen to the shares owned by the banks in major Mexican industries. **********Monday night, in an apparent move to open negotiations on these issues, Jesus Silva Herzog, Finance Minister, met for the first time since the change of Government Dec.1 with a small group of former bank executives, including Agustin F. Legorreta, formerly head of Banco Nacional de Mexico; Manuel Espinosa Yglesias, formerly chairman of Banco de Comercio, and Carlos Abedrop Davila, president of the Bankers' Association. **********But Mr. Abedrop told reporters after the 30-minute meeting that two lawsuits brought by owners of expropriated banks challenging the constitutionality of the nationalization decree signed by former President Jose Lopez Portillo on Sept.1 would not be withdrawn and would await a ruling by the courts. Reorganization Planned **********Meanwhile, the Government is reportedly preparing to reorganize the 57 different banks nationalized into six to eight large financial institutions. Four banks with joint public and private capital before the state takeover - Banco Mexicano Somex, Banco Internacional, Banca Promex and Banco Provincial de Sinaloa - will also eventually conform to the new 66:34 share ratio. **********When the bank nationalization was announced, there were strong rumors that Mr. de la Madrid, at that time President-elect, disapproved of the measure and of Mr. Lopez Portillo's charge that the banks were responsible for the huge flight of capital that provoked a series of currency devaluations this year. **********Since then, the bank nationalization has been enshrined in the Mexican constitution and, as such, is politically almost impossible to reverse.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/23/busin.body_text: **********James R. Heekin Jr., who has been president of four ad agencies and a partner in a top marketing consulting firm, said farewell yesterday to the chairmanship and chief executive's job at Doyle-Heekin, which he founded last May with William S. Doyle. **********The agency has been dissolved but the William S. Doyle Company will take its place at 500 Park Avenue with the same clients and the same $10 million in billings. **********The joint statement was: ''We gave it our best shot but as things turned out, our objectives were different. We both intend to remain in the advertising business and wish each other the very best.'' **********At the time of the agency's founding Mr. Heekin said that the shop was well capitalized and was negotiating to buy one or both of two agencies of the $20 million to $40 million class. **********That never happened, but Mr. Doyle said yesterday that the differences that led to the rift included those over the type of agency to acquire. **********Mr. Heekin, 54 years old, had been president of Ogilvy & Mather and Doyle Dane Bernbach, but chief executive of neither. More recently, he was a partner in Canter Achenbaum Heekin. Mr. Doyle, 38, more of a client-side type, was Deputy State Commissioner of Commerce on the ''I Love New York'' campaign.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/22/busin.body_text: **********The Rockwell International Corporation, which was awarded two Air Force contracts yesterday for $2.2 billion for the development of the B-1B bomber, reported today that net income for its first fiscal quarter of 1982, which ended Dec. 31, was $61.9 million, or 81 cents a share, an increase of 11.7 percent from last year's comparable period, when net income was $55.4 million, or 73 cents a share. **********Sales eased to $1.62 billion from $1.64 billion in the year-earlier period. **********Robert Anderson, chairman and chief executive officer, said the increase reflected improved results in automotive and electronics businesses and higher interest income. He said the principal reason for the improvement in automotive earnings was a $22 million pre-tax provision. Mr. Anderson said general industry earnings were lower because of the pretax gain of $24 million on the sale of the McEvoy Oilfield Equipment operations that were included in la st year's first-quarter results. Aerospace earnings also were lower.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/10/busin.main_headline: U.S. WON'T ASK BETTER STEEL OFFER
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/10/busin.print_headline: U.S. WON'T ASK BETTER STEEL OFFER
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/10/busin.body_text: **********Lionel H. Olmer, Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade Administration, said today that the Government had no plans to ask the European Community to improve its offer to resolve a steel trade dispute, despite rejection of the offer last week by the domestic steel industry. **********His comment came in an interview as the Commerce Department prepared to issue findings that could set new penalties on imports of European steel to the United States. Such penalties would further intensify the trade conflict that involves tough competition for the American industry from European exporters. **********''The arrangement last week was an intricate package of concessions, representing a good-faith offer by the Europeans, and at this point we have no plans to work for any sweeteners,'' Mr. Olmer said. ''We have to let the dust settle.'' **********He said he was still hopeful that the American industry would reconsider its position, and noted that the Commerce Department awaited the industry's identification of specific objections to the offer. ''I know some people in the industry felt the proposals were not so bad,'' he said. **********The arrangement called for European steel shipments to this country to be reduced by 10 percent from 1981 levels over the next three years. Shipments in 1981 totaled 6.5 million tons. **********David M. Roderick, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, called the arrangement - the results of three days of negotiations last week between the Commerce Department and the European Community's Executive Commission - ''neither fair nor equitable.'' Other steel companies also expressed their displeasure. **********Principal objections, steel officials said, were that the Europeans did not offer to cut back their steel shipments deeply enough and did not include lucrative oil pipe and tube products among sectors they were willing to restrain. Industry Has a Veto **********For any arrangement to be valid between the United States and the E.E.C., the seven domestic companies would have to withdraw unfair trade charges they filed against European and other foreign steelmakers last January. The situation gives the industry veto power over the proposals. **********The steel companies that filed the unfair trade cases also accused the same countries of ''dumping'' their steel in the United States.  Dumping means selling a product at less than its fair market value. **********Commerce Department officials said they would announce Tuesday preliminary findings on dumping margins - the difference between the sale price and fair value - as required under the unfair trade cases. **********Last June 11 the department found in a preliminary determination that the foreign steelmakers subsidized their exports to the United States by as much as 40 percent, or $250 a ton. The effect of that ruling was to force the Europeans to post bonds for the amount of countervailing duties -fees sought to offset subsidies by foreign governments - that could be imposed once the cases were fully adjudicated. **********The dumping findings and the countervailing duty findings are cumulative, meaning that a company in Europe could be hit with a countervailing duty on top of an antidumping duty. **********Although bonds are posted, the actual fines will not be levied until after a final determination of whether the domestic industry has been injured by imports. The International Trade Commission, which makes this finding, has until Oct. 8 to decide. **********Mr. Olmer said he hoped that a settlement would be reached before Oct. 8, but gave no indication of how this may be achieved.

The Turin daily, La Stampa, which is owned by Fiat, noted that while the bank's overseas creditors were sent away empty-handed, a major beneficiary of the new arrangement will be Italy's biggest commercial bank, the Governmentcontrolled Banca Nazionale del Lavoro. **********While the seven-bank group has inherited the Ambrosiano's domestic risks, it stands to get first choice when the failed bank divests itself of its nonbanking activities in the coming months. These include mainly insurance and publishing interests.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/21/busin.body_text: **********When travel agents lose faith in an airline, as Braniff International can testify, the results can be disastrous. The nation's 19,000 agents sell 65 percent of all airline tickets, and a reluctance on their part to place travelers on a given flight shows up quickly in empty seats. **********Executives from Braniff, for example, said that a major reason they had to file for protection under Chapter 11 last week was the large drop in ticket sales - put at 40 to 50 percent -by travel agents. **********Now, confronted with the Braniff bankruptcy action, some travel agents and their customers are showing reluctance to buy tickets on other financially troubled carriers, including Continental, Republic, Western, and World Airlines. **********The pressure comes just as those carriers are beginning to rebound from an increase in traffic, and in an effort to allay travel agents' fears, Republic has mounted a major campaign to reassure them. **********Risks to Carriers Serious **********While it is too early to tell how widespread these fears are, the possible risks to the troubled carriers are great. **********''The financial destiny of a weak airline is, in reality, in the hands of a travel agent,'' according to Julius Maldutis, the airline analyst for Salomon Brothers Inc., ''rather than those of senior lenders or banks, as is commonly assumed.'' **********As Paul Bessel, vice president of industry affairs for the American Society of Travel Agents, noted, the agencies also have a great deal of discretion in choosing airlines. Only an estimated 20 percent of customers specify an airline, usually specifying only time and date. **********''It is making us more cautious,'' Rudolf U. Gross, president of Englewood Travel, a large travel agency in New Jersey, said in discussing the Braniff case. He acknowledged in an interview that he was being particularly cautious about making advance bookings on the troubled carriers. **********Skip Oldham, vice president of George Oldham Associates, a travel firm in Johnson City, Tenn., has printed in red an explanation of travelers' rights under the airline default protection plan. **********''I want people who are buying tickets on the financially troubled carriers to know what they are getting into and the risk they are running,'' he said. Travel Could Be Delayed **********He said that in case of a bankruptcy, some travelers could find their trips delayed because other carriers would take them only on a standby basis. And in some of the country's smaller cities, finding an alternate carrier could be difficult. In any case, however, tickets would be honored and travelers would lose no money. **********Though he has not asked his agents to avoid booking on such carriers, as some travel agencies have done, he said he was not buying tickets from such carriers for flights far in advance. **********Many agencies have not changed their policy in dealing with troubled carriers. Sandy Leto, for example, the retail manager of Revere Travel Inc., a large agency in New Jersey, said her only criteria continued to be the best fare and time for her customers. **********But, she acknowledged, if a customer brought up the potential problem of a troubled airline, she would tell them of the possible risks and ask: ''Do you want to take a chance?'' **********Not surprisingly, it is the business community, which accounts for about half of air travel, that seems most sensitive to the booking issue. **********Even though almost all passengers who were stranded by Braniff's sudden suspension of service on May 12 were able to get seats on another carrier, it was on a standby basis, with delays. That, Mr.  Gross of Englewood Travel said, is very hard on an executive expected at a certain place at a certain time. Some Refunds Sought **********''It's just not acceptable to a businessman,'' Mr. Gross said, adding that some business people bought new tickets on other airlines and a few were seeking refunds for the Braniff tickets from him. **********Most agents said in interviews that they do not try to dissuade a customer from switching from a troubled airline, since to do so could mean loss of the customer's business in the future. Some also noted, however, that there were customers who specified flying on one of the troubled carriers in order to help them survive. **********Among the airlines themselves, reaction to the booking problem has been mixed. At Republic in Minneapolis, David E. Moran, senior vice president of marketing, sent telegrams to all travel agencies last Monday seeking to reassure them. **********''In view of the current industry situation, you may have certain concerns with respect to booking carriers which have, over the past several months, been reported to be in financial difficulty,'' the telegram read. ''We wish to take this opportunity to reassure you of Republic's position.'' **********In addition, Mr. Moran said, the airline was getting help from some retired employees who were calling agents around the country to reassure them. Sales Up at Republic **********Like other executives, Mr. Moran stressed the positive. Republic had an operating profit in the first quarter, he said, and sales by travel agents so far this year have totaled $234 million, an increase of 33 percent from the comparable period a year ago. **********Other carriers, such as Western, said that so far they had not seen a decrease in sales from travel agents. Craig B. Benedetti, vice president-marketing for Western, said the airline was not making any special efforts to reassure travel agents. **********He also noted that Western and the other airlines with financial probems were not in such severe straits as Braniff.  Braniff repeatedly had to promote quick discount sales, in which two tickets were offered for the price of one, to raise enough cash to meet the week's expenses. **********Bruce Plowman, director of public affairs for Continental, said the carrier had been hurt when Laker had failed and there was a falloff in travel agent sales. But, he said, traffic had been increasing and there was a cash reserve of $100 million held between Continental and Texas International Airlines, both owned by the Texas Air Corporation. Short-Term Help **********While some agents are taking protective measures, they do not want to contribute to the failure of any carrier. Thus while Mr. Gross is being careful about advance bookings on Pan American World Airways, he is promoting the airline on a short-term basis to help it survive. **********Mark Carter of Anchor Travel, however, an agency that handles sailing tours to the Carribbean, said he was advising his agents to avoid writing tickets on some of the troubled airlines if possible.  ''We might get stuck with clients who will be unhappy and want a refund on the spot,'' he said. **********Under an airline default protection plan worked out among the carriers and travel agents, customers who buy regular tickets from travel agencies on airlines that default or go bankrupt are guaranteed travel on other airlines, generally on a standby basis.  Under the plan, travel agents are not required to refund money for tickets. **********In the case of Braniff, some airlines also honored tickets bought directly from that airline though not required to do so.  Many travel agencies are now including in their ticket folders an explanation of the rights of passengers in the event of an airline bankruptcy. The notice was drafted by the American Society of Travel Agents, which is an industry group representing 10,000 travel agencies. **********Part of the note reads that ''although some airlines are having serious financial probems, this does not mean that they will go bankrupt or suddenly suspend operations.'' The note then adds the warning, ''But they might.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/02/busin.main_headline: WESTERN SAVINGS IN WEBB STOCK PACT

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/02/busin.body_text: **********Western Savings, the nation's 29th-largest savings and loan association and the biggest in Arizona, said today that it had agreed to acquire a nearly 25 percent stake in the Del E. Webb Corporation for $26 million. **********A block of 2.4 million shares, or 24.9 percent of common shares outstanding, is to be purchased from the Del E. Webb Foundation at $10.75 a share, according to Gary Driggs, president of Western Savings. **********Mr. Driggs said, ''We simply think the investment in Webb will be an extremely profitable one for Western.'' The transaction would remove the foundation and its chairman, Robert H. Johnson, a former Webb chairman, from a position of influence as the largest shareholder at the company, which owns and operates casinos, hotels and other real estate. **********The agreement with Western Savings, plus some previous sales of Webb stock by the foundation, will effectively end the foundation's holding of Webb stock. **********Western Savings acted under an Arizona law that permits thrift institutions to invest up to 3 percent of their assets in a wide range of investments that can include common stock. Webb More Profitable **********Mr. Johnson's successor, Robert K. Swanson, has raised more than $150 million in cash by selling many of Webb's large hotels and casinos since taking the reins of the company last year. Analysts have credited him with putting the formerly debt-laden company on a profitable path. **********Webb, which is based in Phoenix, had a net income of $5.3 million on revenue of $414.8 million in 1981.  William E. Hallinan, research director of Young, Smith & Peacock Inc., a Phoenix brokerage, said the sale by the foundation would likely be a boon to the price of Webb shares because its major stockholder no longer will be in a position of having to sell part of its holding each year. **********As is required of all charitable foundations by the Internal Revenue Service, the Webb Foundation must distribute 5 percent of its assets annually. The Webb Foundation earned no income from its sole holding, Webb stock, which has not paid a dividend since December 1980. **********The sale should help the Webb Foundation, set up by the late Del E. Webb, to provide for medical charities in in the far western part of the United States, Mr. Johnson said. **********John Driggs, chairman and chief executive of Western and its parent company, the Western Financial Corporation, and a brother of Gary Driggs, praised Mr. Swanson in a prepared statement. He added that the investment ''will provide Western with important diversification of assets.'' Western Savings, which is also based in Phoenix, has more than $2.5 billion in assets. **********Among its interests, Western Savings operates Leisure World, a retirement community in Mesa, Ariz. Webb, in addition to its other interests, operates two large retirement communities, Sun City and Sun City West, northwest of Phoenix. Western Savings provided the first mortgage loan at Sun City in 1962. **********Shares of Western Financial closed at $11.75, up $1.375 on the American Stock Exchange. The announcement of the acquisition was made today after the market closed. Webb, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange, closed at $9, up 25 cents.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/09/busin.main_headline: Financial Futures Drop In a Cautious Session
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/09/busin.print_headline: COMMODITIES; Financial Futures Drop In a Cautious Session
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/09/busin.body_text: **********Traders in financial futures continued to move to the sidelines yesterday while prices fell and the general caution resulting from the Drysdale default still pervaded the market. After some carry-over buying from Monday's feeble rally, prices resumed their declines early in the day. Brokers said the financial futures closely reflected the pattern in the cash market. **********Treasury bond futures closed down 8/32ds; Treasury note futures dipped 3/32ds. Each 32d of a point is equivalent to $31.25 per contract of $100,000 face value. Treasury bill futures fell 18 basis points, each of which represents $25 per contract of $1 million face value. **********The four-week-old decline in financial futures has been especially pronounced in the Treasury bond market. Yesterday's closing quote on the expiring spot June contract, 61 10/ 32ds, was 3 full points below the mid-May level. A full point in Treasury bonds works out to $1,000 per contract, or half the minimum initial cash margin required to buy or sell a contract. **********Because most individual speculators prefer the long, or buy, side of any commodity market, mainly because of the ingrained fear of selling something they do not own, the sharp price drop since mid-May has driven many small traders out of the market. **********Since then, the open interest in Treasury bond futures has plunged to 170,000 contracts from 201,000, while that in Treasury bills has fallen to 46,000 contracts from just under 50,000. Treasury notes futures did not begin trading until May 3. **********Open interest is, in effect, the number of contracts available for trading, and a closely watched indicator of market liquidity. The more liquidity a market has, the greater its usefulness to portfolio and other trade hedgers. Spate of Problems **********''Given the blowouts we've witnessed in the financial futures, particularly in the long-term bonds, as well as the confusion over the trend in interest rates, many speculators and hedgers have taken to the sidelines,'' Thomas J. Ramseth, floor trading manager for Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis Inc., Chicago, said in a telephone interview. ''There were two days last week when falling prices caused the open interest in T-bonds to drop by 5,000 contracts.'' **********In New York, Jerry Laurain, financial futures trader at Merrill Lynch Commodities, observed that the decline in open interest ''could also be directly linked to the slowdown in activity in the cash market for Government paper since the Drysdale affair erupted last month.'' **********Mr. Laurain noted: ''Everyone in the money market has become extremely cautious since then. Government securities dealers and others in the market have been limiting their exposure. And when one reduces house positions in the cash market, one doesn't need to hedge as much in futures.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/29/busin.body_text: **********Led by a surge in major office projects, the value of new construction contracts rose sharply in June, the second consecutive monthly gain, the F.W. Dodge division of the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company reported yesterday. **********The Dodge Index, which rates the construction industry's strength on a numerical scale, rose from a low of 88 in April to 118 in June. **********The index measures the health of construction contracting by comparing current activity with the 1977 market, which is assigned a value of 100. **********The company attributed June's gain to the start of 15 major office projects and a contract to build an electric power plant in Arkansas.  Despite improvement in May and June, the average rate of contracting in 1982's second quarter, as measured by the seasonally adjusted Dodge Index, fell 5 percent from the first-quarter average, the company said. For the first half of 1982, the value of all construction started was $71 billion, a decline of 11 percent from the total for the same period last year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/04/busin.main_headline: House Passes Bill to Allow Control of Oil
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/04/busin.print_headline: House Passes Bill to Allow Control of Oil
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/04/busin.body_text: **********Legislation giving the President emergency powers to ration crude oil and impose price controls in case of a severe disruption of supply was passed by the House of Representatives late today, 246-144, and sent to the White House. **********President Reagan is opposed to the bill, and the Energy Department has recommended that he veto it. However, a veto is uncertain because of heavy Republican support for the measure in the Senate, where the bill passed Tuesday, 86-7. **********The bill, a compromise between House and Senate bills passed earlier, would replace emergency powers that expired last year.  It would require the President to draw up an emergency plan within 180 days to deal with severe supply disruptions. It pre-empts state laws allocating supplies and setting prices, but allows the states to carry out conservation programs. The bill does not authorize gasoline rationing. **********The President would have full discretion as to whether the plan would be put into effect, a point stressed by the bill's supporters.  And the powers expire Dec. 31, 1984, 20 days before the end of Mr.  Reagan's term, a date selected to counter conservative arguments that the authority could be misused by a President in the future. **********While Senate Republicans supported the measure, many in the House opposed it. They said it merely reinstituted powers that had failed to deal with supply disruptions in 1973 and 1979. They supported Mr.  Reagan's argument that the free market - including higher prices - was best equipped to deal with such disruptions. **********Representative James T. Broyhill of North Carolina, senior Republican on the House Energy Committee, said the bill ''is going to send entirely the wrong signals to the marketplace.'' **********But supporters of the bill said the United States was highly vulnerable to a supply cutoff, and they noted that Mr. Reagan could not be forced to use the emergency powers.
