https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/01/world.print_headline: POPE ARRIVES IN MADRID ON VISIT; PLANNING TRIP TO RESTLESS REGIONS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/01/world.body_text: **********Pope John Paul II stepped off an airliner onto Spanish soil today for the start of the first visit by any Pope to this predominantly Roman Catholic nation. **********The Pope is beginning his 10-day pastoral journey at a time of high political excitement in Spain, which only Wednesday elected its first Socialist government in nearly half a century. **********Because Felipe Gonzalez, the Socialist leader, has not yet been installed as Prime Minister, the Pope was greeted on behalf of the Government by the outgoing Prime Minister, Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo.  King Juan Carlos, accompanied by Queen Sofia, was the first to salute the Pope as he stepped from the plane at the airport outside the capital. **********Pope Notes Tensions **********The Pope, in reply to welcoming remarks by the King, recalled ''the well-known tensions, sometimes leading to open clashes, which have taken place in the bosom of your society.'' **********But, he went on, ''my journey is beyond any political or partisan purpose.'' The Pope will nonetheless confront some of Spain's major political problems when he visits, in the course of an exceptionally long foreign trip, the Basque and Catalan regions, where autonomist and even separatist movements are strong, and Andalusia in the south, a traditionally impoverished area. Unemployment is running high throughout the country. Warm Welcome on Drive **********The Pope was warmly received on his drive through the capital after a restrained welcome by a carefully limited crowd at the airport. **********The Pope is expected to make statements on the political problems at appropriate moments as he meets with farmers, industrial workers, students and intellectuals, as well as Mr. Gonzalez and other political personalities. **********He confined his remarks today largely to religious matters. But in a subsequent address to the Spanish bishops, he urged them to defend the church positions against abortion and divorce. The new Government is widely expected to move for the legalization of abortion. King's Welcoming Remarks **********The King, in his welcoming remarks, recalled that since 1494 Spain's Kings and Queens had borne the title Los Reyes Catolicos, conferred upon them by the papacy, and noted that the Pope had already seen the consequences of Spain's spreading of the Catholic gospel in America, the Philippines and Africa. **********The King did not mention that in the years since Francisco Franco died in 1975, the Catholic church in Spain has lost a great deal of its power. **********A new Constitution has for the first time separated church from state, a fact later enshrined in a new concordat with the Vatican. A sweeping liberalization of public life, including the right to divorce, has excluded the church from much of the position of official guardian of public morality that it occupied through the centuries. Election Delayed Visit **********The Pope's visit was postponed from earlier this month when elections were called for last Wednesday. The parties of the left protested that the Pope's presence during the campaign would give unfair advantage to the parties to their right. The visit was originally planned for last year but was put off after the Pope had been wounded by a Turkish gunman in May 1981. **********Liberal Spanish church sources in Rome stressed that the Pope was visiting the country at a moment when the Socialist election victory had underlined the church's loss of influence on public affairs.  Parish priests are known to have communicated the church's lack of enthusiasm for the left-wing parties during the campaign, advice that was clearly ignored. **********Recent statistics compiled by Spanish church sources indicate that 82 percent of a population of 37.5 million list themselves as Catholics; 52 percent say they practice Catholicism. Eleven percent define themselves as nonbelievers. ---- Bomb Kills Policeman **********VITORIA, Spain, Oct. 31 (AP) - A bomb explosion killed one policeman and wounded five tonight in this Basque city, the national news agency EFE reported. **********It said no one took responsibility for the attack, but Basque guerrillas have been waging a terrorist campaign for years in an effort to gain autonomy for the Basque region in northern Spain.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/10/world.main_headline: ZIA SAYS SOVIET MAY BE FLEXIBLE ON AFGHAN WAR
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/10/world.print_headline: ZIA SAYS SOVIET MAY BE FLEXIBLE ON AFGHAN WAR
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/10/world.body_text: **********President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan said in New York yesterday that there was a ''hint of flexibility'' in the Soviet attitude toward its military intervention in Afghanistan and that the Soviet leadership might recognize a need for an early resolution of the Afghan crisis. **********But Mr. Zia said his Government would refuse to accept the Soviet Union's ''rigid insistence'' that Pakistan hold direct talks with the Soviet-supported Afghan Government of Babrak Karmal. **********In a luncheon speech at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel before the Foreign Policy Association, Mr. Zia also made these points: **********- The six-year, $3.2 billion United States aid package for Pakistan reaffirmed by President Reagan during Mr. Zia's official visit to Washington ''has laid the foundation for a credible and enduring relationship.'' **********- His Government is determined to pursue ''a relationship of good neighborly cooperation'' with its traditional enemy, India. **********- Pakistan ''has neither the means nor, indeed, any desire to manufacture a nuclear device,'' and welcomes international inspection of its nuclear installations ''provided the same treatment is meted out to others,'' apparently an allusion to India. Mr. Zia arrived in New York at noon yesterday for a three-day visit after an official stay in Washington that began on Monday. He will also visit Texas and California before returning home. **********He met at the United Nations yesterday afternoon with Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar. The United Nations Secretariat said the two men discussed the Middle East, Afghanistan, the Iran-Iraq war and economic problems. **********In his speech, Mr. Zia summarized his Government's position on several foreign policy questions. 'The Deepest Concern to Us' **********Calling the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan the ''major problem which continues to cause the deepest concern to us,'' Mr. Zia said he saw signs of ''flexibility'' in the Soviet attitude at a meeting with the new Soviet leader, Yuri V. Andropov, during the funeral last month for Leonid I. Brezhnev. ''I have the feeling that there now exists on the Soviet side a recognition of the need for an early resolution of the crisis,'' he said. **********But Mr. Zia declared that his Government's ''dialogue'' with the Soviet Union had remained ''uneven'' because of the Soviet view that a solution to the Afghan problem, and the return home of the 2.8 million Afghan refugees in Pakistan, lay in direct talks between the Pakistani and Afghan Governments. **********Departing from his prepared text, Mr. Zia said: ''To be crude and direct, we have always stated that Pakistan will not talk to this man who came to be head of the Afghan regime by riding on Soviet tanks.  We will not talk to him.'' **********Mr. Karmal came to power in December 1979 as the result of a Soviet-supported coup that overthrew the Marxist Government of President Hafizullah Amin. Soviet forces intervened in Afghanistan hours after the coup. 'We Have Shouted the Loudest' **********Mr. Zia contended that ''Pakistan has remained in the vanguard of efforts directed toward insuring the restoration of Afghanistan's freedom,'' and has thus ''raised the Soviet Union's ire against us.'' **********''We have shouted the loudest,'' he said.  Mr. Zia agreed last year to indirect talks with the Afghan Government, but he contended in his speech yesterday that ''there is no occasion to believe that a solution to this grave problem is at hand.'' **********On relations with the United States, Mr. Zia recalled the ''severe strains'' that emerged in the late 1970's, when, concerned that Pakistan was refusing to permit the international inspection of its nuclear installations, the Carter Administration suspended aid. **********He said that the aid program reconfirmed by President Reagan Tuesday would enable Pakistan ''to safeguard national integrity and withstand potential threats to its security.'' **********''It bears repetition that the region in which Pakistan is situated is beset by continuing strife and ceaseless turmoil,'' Mr. Zia declared. ''At the periphery of a highly volatile region, Pakistan serves as a bastion of stability, and offers the best hope for the restoration of a measure of tranquility.'' **********He added, ''The assistance which we expect to receive from the United States, by consolidating Pakistan as a nation confident in its security, would inevitably impart to the geopolitics of our region an essential equilibrium.'' **********In response to a written question on Pakistan's refusal until now to permit international inspection of its nuclear sites, Mr. Zia said that Pakistan would allow such inspection, ''but not on discriminatory grounds.'' He meant, presumably, that other nations with nuclear development programs were not subject to inspection. **********Mr. Zia said he had called on India to arrange the mutual inspection of nuclear installations by the two countries, but he said India had not replied to the offer. 'A Social Evil' **********Mr. Zia was also asked about accusations that Pakistan was a major source of illicit drugs destined for the United States. ''Our policy is that Pakistan is trying to stop this traffic, not only because it is hurting somebody else but because we feel it is a social evil,'' he said. **********He contended that Pakistan, since embarking on a vigorous effort to crack down on drug smuggling in 1979, had drastically reduced its production of opium. But he also placed blame for the problem on the huge profits that derive from drug trafficking in this country. **********''You are so kind,'' Mr. Zia said in reference to the great amounts spent by Americans on illicit drugs. ''You have so much money to give that I don't know what to do at this end'' to curb drug trafficking.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/23/world.main_headline: BRITON AND HAIG IN 'USEFUL START' ON THE FALKLANDS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/23/world.print_headline: BRITON AND HAIG IN 'USEFUL START' ON THE FALKLANDS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/23/world.body_text: **********Britain's Foreign Secretary, Francis Pym, said after a four-hour meeting today with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. that they had made ''a useful start'' in discussing the latest ideas for resolving the Falkland Islands dispute. **********But alluding to the failure so far of diplomacy to end the threeweek-old crisis, he said on arriving here, ''I will not disguise from you that there are real difficulties and real obstacles.'' He refused to tell reporters what the plans of the British flotilla heading toward the Falklands were. **********Meanwhile, the Argentine President, Lieut. Gen. Leopoldo Galtieri, said his Government was prepared to ''continue the dialogue'' with Britain, but reiterated that Argentina would fight to hold on to the archipelago. He made his comments while on the way to the Falklands, his first visit there since Argentine troops seized the islands April 2. (Page A8.) **********'American Ideas' Considered **********Mr. Pym brought from London his Government's counterproposals to those offered by Argentina earlier in the week to Mr. Haig in Buenos Aires. But he said that in his talks with Mr. Haig, in which they were alone for two hours, they also considered ''American ideas'' for bridging the differences between the Argentines and the British. **********Mr. Pym refused to say whether he was hopeful or not because he said that the Americans and British would work on the various detailed proposals overnight and that he and Mr. Haig would meet again Friday.  Mr. Pym was also scheduled to see President Reagan on Friday. **********''So, we've made a useful start, but there is much work to be done and we are dealing with a very difficult problem,'' he said to reporters at the State Department. **********''We've begun to discuss the details of our various ideas and we are exploring them and we are going to do further work and I can't say more than that at the moment,'' he said. ''In the sense that we've shared ideas, and come together and had a good talk, that is progress.'' **********The British flotilla is believed to be only days away from the Falklands area; British military defense sources have said that the fleet will be within aircraft range of the islands by late Friday, and there were indications that some sort of action might be taken even sooner against South Georgia, a Falklands dependency 800 miles to the east. But there was surprisingly little sense of crisis surrounding today's meeting. **********British officials stressed their Government's interest in finding a diplomatic solution, and American officials said they were working behind the scenes with both sides to avert conflict that Washington believes is in neither side's interest. Argentine Minister Due **********Foreign Minister Nicanor Costa Mendez of Argentina is due to arrive in Washington on Sunday to attend the special meeting Monday of foreign ministers of the Organization of American States. The meeting will consider Argentina's request that action be taken against Britain for its threat to the Argentine occupation of the Falklands. **********Mr. Haig will meet with Mr. Costa Mendez, the State Department spokesman, Dean Fischer, said, but no firm date is set. As to the idea of Mr. Pym remaining in Washington for either direct talks with the Argentine official or indirect contacts through Mr. Haig's mediation, that seemed unlikely. **********Mr. Pym said today that ''my intention is to return tomorrow night to London.'' Diplomats said the British have stressed to Mr. Haig their insistence that Argentina withdraw its troops from the Falklands; that British administration over the islands be restored, at least for a short period; that the ultimate question of sovereignty be subject to future negotiations, and that the wishes of the inhabitants of the Falklands be taken into account. Argentina Demands Guarantees **********The Argentines have been willing to consider various interim arrangements after the withdrawal of their forces, but want guarantees that they will ultimately be recognized as having sovereignty over the islands. **********Mr. Pym, alluding to the fairly wide differences, said on arrival aboard a British Airways Concorde at Dulles Airport: ''We will do everything we can to try to find a peaceful settlement to this dispute. But I have not disguised from the British people and I will not disguise from you that there are real difficulties and real obstacles.'' **********Mr. Pym's visit to Washington went beyond the diplomatic talks with Mr. Haig. He also sought to build support for Britain's position with American public opinion. He went directly from the session at the State Department to the Senate to meet with members of the Foreign Relations Committee. **********A member of that committee, in advance of the meeting, said the Reagan Administration should openly condemn the Argentines for their occupation of the Falklands. 'Inherent Bias' Noted **********Senator Paul E. Tsongas, Democrat of Massachusetts, said the Administration should ''condemn unequivocally, openly and loudly'' the Argentine action. **********''I am struck by the inherent bias of a so-called policy of neutrality which treats a blatant aggressor and its victims as equals,'' he said. ''If Argentina has a claim to the Falklands, then Mexico has a claim to much of the southwestern United States.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/09/busin.body_text: **********Everyone, it seems, is trying to enter the home video game business, bringing forth a profusion of new game-playing machines and games. **********Where there was once little more than Space Invaders, there are now such games as Space Raiders, Space Wars, Space Battle, Spacechase, Space Fury, Space Cavern, Space Hawk and Space Vultures, not to mention Communist Mutants From Space. Needless to say, the exhibits for all these new games take up a lot of space at the Consumer Electronics Show here, and are clearly the high point of an otherwise somber trade gathering. **********The profusion of entrants is not surprising. Home video game cartridges, which sell for $20 to $25 apiece, have been one of the fastest-growing areas of consumer electronics, accounting for an estimated $1.2 billion in sales last year. **********Yet the market has been controlled by a handful of companies. Last year there were four manufacturers of video game devices - Atari Inc., Mattel Electronics, Magnavox and Astrovision, now called Astrocade. Then, there was one company, Activision, that concentrated on game software for the Atari system - that is, the cartridges of instructions that make the game work. In its second full year, marked last March 31, Activision earned $12.9 million on sales of $66 million. More Newcomers **********This year there appear to be another half-dozen producers of game machines. They include Coleco Industries, a toy and game company, the Emerson Radio Corporation and Commodore International Ltd. **********There are also about a dozen new companies making software for Atari machines and, to a lesser extent, for Mattel systems, the two leaders in producing hardware for home video systems. They include start-up companies such as the Imagic Corporation of Saratoga, Calif., and Apollo Inc. of Dallas. **********Also involved are CBS Inc., and more traditional game companies such as Parker Brothers, Tiger Electronic Toys Inc. and the U.S.  Games Corporation, a subsidiary of the Quaker Oats Company. Hollywood is also getting into the act. Twentieth Century-Fox, MCA Inc., Paramount and Lucasfilm Ltd. have announced plans to enter the business. **********James H. Levy, president of Activision, said that if all the products displayed here reached the market, the number of games available for the Atari game system alone would double, to more than a hundred from about 60 now. Market Potential **********The entries come as there is growing Wall Street speculation that the business of making devices - essentially, microcomputers dedicated to the sole function of playing video games - is slowing down. One threat to these machines, which range in price from $150 to $300 - are inexpensive personal computers that play games as well as performing other, more computer-like things. **********Many analysts, however, among them Michele Preston, with Cyrus J.  Lawrence Inc., reject that notion. She said that while there were 4.5 million game machines sold last year, some eight million will be sold this year, representing a gain of 70 percent. Only eight million households, or about 10 percent of the nation's total, have games. **********Michael J. Moone, president of Atari's Consumer Electronics division, also said that the business is healthy in the United States and the international market has barely been scratched. ''We're beginning to see the tip of the iceberg of the two-game home,'' he said. **********Even if the overall business is still growing, the crowded field is sure to reduce profits. ''They can't all have prosperity at the same time,'' said Harold Vogel, an analyst with Merrill Lynch . Crowded Shelves **********The newcomers are expected to have a tougher time entering the market, if only because retailers will be hard-pressed to find shelf space to carry all the competing products. **********''There is a fairly narrow funnel at the retail level,'' said Josh Denham, president of Mattel Electronics.  Competitors say the weakness of the market leader, Atari, which has 70 percent of the installed machines, is the relatively poor quality of its graphics. Its home video version of Pac-Man, despite the hoopla surrounding its release, disappointed to consumers used to the more refined arcade version. **********By emphasizing superior features, others think they can make inroads on Atari's market. Mattel and Magnavox have introduced audio attachments to their games. Other Exotic Effects **********Another company receiving widespread attention at the show is the General Consumer Electronics Corporation of Santa Monica, Calif., a company formed a year ago by former Mattel officials. Instead of attaching its game to a TV set, General plans to sell a game that includes its own screen that will allow for superior graphic effects. **********The game companies are also competing vigorously to win the licensing rights to popular arcade games as well as themes from movies and comic books that can be spun off as video games, such as Parker Brothers' first game, The Empire Strikes Back, a space war game. **********For its part, Atari is introducing a more expensive game, priced at $300, about twice that of its existing units. Another company, the Arcadia Corporation of Santa Clara, Calif., is planning to sell a $70 ''supercharger'' that would upgrade the quality of Atari's existing game. **********Other manufacturers, among them Emerson & Tryon Inc. of Beechwood, Ohio, a maker of computerized backgammon and chess games, hope to compete with Atari on the basis of price. Many of the newcomers say they will be satisfied with achieving only a tiny sliver of the huge market. **********''We're not expecting to do a billion and a half dollars in this product,'' said Tim A. Shane, president of Tryon.  Barry Britman, director of product and marketing development for Emerson, said his company had little choice. ''This is the hottest area right now,'' he said. ''Our audio business has been a tough push.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/02/busin.body_text: **********The Government's index of leading economic indicators, which is being watched for a sign that economic recovery is near, declined six-tenths of 1 percent in January, the Commerce Department reported today. The decline would have been much greater if the index had not been adjusted to remove the impact of winter weather on the number of hours logged by factory workers. **********As it was, the six-tenths of 1 percent drop added to other recent economic developments that are dampening hopes that a recovery from the current recession will begin this spring. Last month, for example, the Government reported a drop in industrial production and in retail sales. **********The January decline was the ninth in a row for the index of leading indicators, which is intended to forecast movements in the economy. The December index, which was originally reported as an increase of six-tenths of 1 percent, was revised by the Commerce Department to a decline of three-tenths of 1 percent. The tentative increase, reported a month ago, had been seen as the first sign that the end of the recession might be near. Factory Workweek Left Out **********For January, the Commerce Department took the unusual step of leaving out one of the 10 components of the index - the average factory workweek. With it left in, the decline would have been 2.8 percent. **********Commerce Department officials said they had removed the workweek figure - which declined sharply to 36.9 hours in January from 39 hours in December - because it had been distorted by severe winter weather during the reporting period. Using it, they said, would have distorted the pattern of the index. ''It is not serving the right purpose to put out a number that is an aberration,'' said Robert Ortner, the Commerce Department's chief economist. **********This was the first time in recent years that one of the components of the index had been dropped.  William Cox, who was the Commerce Department's deputy chief economist in the Carter Administration, agreed with adjusting the index because of the impact of the January weather. ''I understand it,'' he said. ''The drop in the workweek was simply wild in January, and it would have been misleading to leave it in.'' Mr. Cox is now assistant chief of the economics division of the Congressional Research Service. **********Of the index's nine components that were reported for January, six declined, led by a drop in new orders for consumer goods and a drop in stock market prices. A rise in the money supply showed the biggest gain of the three components that went up in January. **********While the Reagan Administration is sticking officially to its forecast of a recovery in the second quarter, Deputy Treasury Secretary Richard McNamar said today in a Washington speech: ''We'll have poor economic numbers through April. In fact, the current downturn will be far worse than envisioned in our earlier scenarios.'' Outlook for Unemployment **********The unemployment rate, which was 8.5 percent in January, ''may yet get to 10 percent before we get things turned around,'' Mr. McNamar said. ''Don't be surprised.'' His comments seemed much less hopeful than the recent assertions of Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan that the economy, led by a recovery in the second quarter, would come ''roaring back.'' **********The January index of leading indicators, Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said in a statement, ''provides evidence that the recession has yet to run its course.'' But the January figure, he added, is ''not inconsistent with the forecasts of a second-quarter recovery in the economy.'' **********Mr. Ortner said, ''I think the January index means the economy was not up in January, probably not up in February, and possibly not up in March.'' If the index is down in February and March, he added, ''then the best you might hope for is a June upturn.'' **********Alan Greenspan, a key outside economic adviser to the President, said today that a spring recovery would be put off a month or two unless there were some signs of a rebound in economic data in the next two weeks. **********''While the evidence suggests the rate of decline is slowing and, in fact, we may have hit bottom, indications of an upturn are scant at best,'' Mr. Greenspan told the Senate Budget Committee. A Bleaker Point of View **********Another economist, Jack Carlson of the National Association of Realtors, was more pessimistic. He said the downturn in the indicators in January means the recession will last ''at least six months more.'' **********The December index was revised downward because of new data showing lower inventories. This decline will make the economy more sluggish in the first quarter, Mr. Ortner said. But he said the drop in inventories eventually would open the door to a recovery. When they get low enough, he explained, companies will begin ordering again and production will rise. **********The index of leading economic indicators is closely watched, especially during recessions, because it has not failed to foretell a recovery since World War II. During recent recessions, in fact, the index has risen for two months on the average before the recovery began. **********Even though some private forecasters, such as Lacy Hunt of the Fidelity Bank in Philadelphia, still predict a recovery in the second quarter, they have scaled down their expectations. ''The recovery is very weak,'' Mr. Hunt said. ''It is not going to be that visible.'' **********One of the key risks still is high interest rates. ''The actual course of activity will be heavily influenced by the trend of interest rates,'' Mr. Baldrige said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/19/world.body_text: **********The Soviet press agency Tass acknowledged today that, as Western news outlets reported, there had been a disaster in a tunnel in Afghanistan. But the agency did not confirm reports that Soviet troops were involved. **********Tass, quoting Afghanistan's Bakhtar press agency in a dispatch from Kabul, said: ''A road accident took place a few days ago in a tunnel on the Salang Pass. There is loss of life.'' **********Earlier this month Western sources in Pakistan said as many as 700 Soviet troops and 2,000 Afghan civilians were killed in the tunnel, about 70 miles north of the Afghan capital. But a week later the diplomats said later information indicated that 300 to 400 Russians may have died along with 500 to 800 Afghans. **********The sources conflicted on what caused the disaster. Some reports said a fuel truck smashed into the head truck of a Soviet convoy, setting off a fire in the tunnel, which is 1.7 miles long. Other reports said Moslem guerrillas blew up the tanker with bombs planted inside the tunnel. **********Tass did not say whether Russians were involved but rejected the reports of guerrilla sabotage. 'Groundless Allegations' **********''Reports of Western news services about acts of subversion that, allegedly, took place in the tunnel are groundless allegations, the Bakhtar news agency stresses,'' Tass said. **********Western sources said the fire occurred on Nov. 2 or Nov. 3, but an Afghan witness said the date was Oct. 30.  The state-run Soviet press seldom reports major disasters inside the Soviet Union or on violence involving Soviet troops in Afghanistan. The decision by Tass to distribute the report indicated that the authorities felt a need to counter the Western reports, which would reach the Soviet Union through Western radio broadcasts. **********Soviet newspapers have not reported how many Soviet troops are in Afghanistan, referring to them only as a ''limited contingent.'' According to Western estimates, 100,000 Soviet troops are leading the fight against Afghan guerrillas opposed to the Marxist Government of President Babrak Karmal. The troops were sent into the country in December 1979, at the same time that Mr. Karmal came to power in what was believed to be a Soviet-backed coup.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/07/busin.body_text: **********WASHINGTON A device that counts and memorizes the number of surgical instruments used in an operation was patented this week by Herbert Schainholz, president of the Medin Corporation in Wallington, N.J. https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/27/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Reserve is providing the banking system with an ample supply of funds at the same time that business credit demands are weakening, according to Fed data published late yesterday. **********The combination of an accommodative monetary policy by the Fed and weakening credit demands among large businesses keeps alive the hope that short-term rates will decline further in coming weeks, analysts said. The latest data, however, do not point toward an immediate drop in rates. **********In the week ended Wednesday, the central bank supplied enough reserves to the banking system that banks and other financial institutions were able to reduce their borrowings from the Fed to an average of $235 million, down $271 million from a week earlier.  Because some banks had excess reserves, the banking system as a whole had a net free reserve position of $16 million, compared with a net borrowed reserve position of $85 million a week earlier. **********Reserves are funds that financial instititons must hold in the vault or on deposit with regulators. By making reserves more plentiful, the Fed encourages expansion of lending and money supply.  If it were to make reserves scarcer, the Fed would be encouraging slower growth of lending and money supply. Business Credit Demand **********Business credit demands also remained weak, as business loans on the books of large New York City banks rose only $3 million in the week ended Nov. 17, while businss borrowings in the commercial paper market fell by $458 million. **********In the credit markets there was no reaction to the Fed data, which was released two hours after dealers in government securities agreed to stop trading. Earlier in the day, interest rates were mixed in very quiet post-holiday trading. Treasury bill rates rose by about five basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, with the sixmonth issue rising to 8.25 percent. Prices of notes and bonds rose by a quarter of a point at most. **********Money supply and balance sheet data for large banks across the country will be delayed to next Monday because of the Thanksgiving Day holiday. Analysts expect the basic money supply to increase by less than $1 billion, but noted that the weekly changes are of little importance to the conduct of monetary policy or the level of interest rates. Treasury Bill Sales **********With many market participants absent, the most significant development was the announcmeent that the Treasury next Tuesday will sell $5 billion of cash management bills maturing in 50 days and $3 billion of bills maturing in 143 days. **********It is well known among government securities dealers that the Treasury has been borrowing money in recent months at a rate indicating that it expects a budget deficit far higher than the official forecast of about $115 million. According to analysts at Merrill Lynch, the Treasury will raise about $57.9 billion of new cash this quarter, or $10 billion more than Government officials estimated a month ago.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/09/world.body_text: **********The Sudan's four universities were ordered closed today because of recent student demonstrations and rioting over increases in the price of gasoline and sugar. **********The state-run Sudanese radio reported from Khartoum, the capital, that the universities would remain closed for an indefinite period ''due to recent avents which have made the atmosphere unsuitable for study.'' **********Several days ago, when the protests began, the nation's secondary schools were shut after rampaging students set fire to shops and gas stations. **********Reports reaching Cairo said the situation in Khartoum was quiet Thursday and today. Gasoline Goes Up by 30% **********The cost of gasoline suddenly went up 30 percent, and the cost of sugar went up 60 percent because the Government of President Gaafar al-Nimeiry was forced to cut back on Government subsidies for the two commodities to improve the nation's beleaguered economy. **********On Tuesday, according to diplomatic reports and the accounts of travelers recently returned from Khartoum, university students, carrying flaming stalks of sugar cane, demonstrated in the capital's central business district. **********The four-hour protest included rock throwing and in some cases the shouting of anti-American slogans. Since 1979 the United States has been a primary provider of military and economic aid to the Nimeiry Government. That assistance amounted to $115 million last year. **********There were reportedly also slogans criticizing the International Monetary Fund, which has advocated the cutback in Government subsidies as part of the effort to get the economy on a sounder footing. 'Foreign Conspiracies' **********The Sudan's First Vice President, Abdel-Magid Hamid Khalil, at one point told the Sudanese Socialist Union, the party controlled by President Nimeiry, that ''foreign conspiracies'' were behind the protests. He did not elaborate, but the comment was v iewed as alluding to theSudan's archenemy, Libya, which President Ni meiry has repeatedly insisted is trying to topple his Government. **********Reports reaching Cairo indicated that the price increases went into effect suddenly and that only after they were increased did the Government try to explain that it had no alternative because of the economic situation. **********At one stage during the street protests, knots of students gathered around the American Embassy, chanting, ''Down with the United States!''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/14/busin.body_text: **********Ensign-Bickford Industries is a little known but by all accounts highly successful privately held company in Simsbury, Conn., that makes products ranging from detonators to paints. **********Yesterday, the company announced that it had named Herman J.  Fonteyne, a vice president of the Monsanto Company, as its new president and chief executive. **********Mr. Fonteyne, 43, has been managing director of Monsanto's Agricultural Products Company in St. Louis. He replaces David J.  Andrew, 64, who plans to retire in 18 months. Mr. Andrew, who joined Ensign-Bickford in 1946, was named vice chairman. **********The company dates to 1836, when William Bickford invented a safety fuse for the mining industry. Detonators for mining and construction are still the basic products, along with explosive bolts used in aerospace for separating rocket stages. Its major consumer product is Cuprinol wood stains. **********The company, which does not disclose sales or earnings, employs about 1,000 in the United States and has operations in Mexico, Chile and Canada. Its major owners are the Lovejoy, Darling and Ellsworth families. Joseph E. Lovejoy is chairman. **********Mr. Fonteyne was born in Belgium and remains a Belgian citizen. He was educated at the University of Louvain and the University of Ghent. He worked for Union Chemique Belge before joining Monsanto in Europe in 1966. **********Mr. Fonteyne came to the United States with Monsanto in 1972, went back to Europe in 1974 and returned in 1978. He said he had no trepidation about working for a closely held company. **********''I'm sure certain things will be different,'' he said, ''but it's not new to me, since my family owns a business and I know quite well how those things work. It's a matter of chemistry more than anything else - understanding the desires of the shareholders.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/03/busin.body_text: **********The NLT Corporation, a Nashville insurance company that also owns that city's Grand Ole Opry, said yesterday that it had been tendered 32.4 percent of the American General Corporation's common and 32.7 percent of its preferred shares. **********The preliminary tally of shares tendered before the NLT offer's first deadline expired surprised some analysts, who had said that NLT's bid would not be taken seriously by shareholders and was only a ''tactic'' in the takeover contest between the two insurance companies. Each has made a tender offer for the other. **********NLT, which already owns 2.2 percent of American General, had bid $600 million for 11.2 million, or 45.9 percent, of American General's common stock at a $50 a share, and all of the company's 1.3 million junior preferred shares at $40 each. The preferred, if converted to common, would give NLT 48 percent of American General's common stock. **********NLT, which had announced its bid several days after American General said it would try to acquire NLT, has offered early payment for 1.4 million of the American General common and all of the preferred that are tendered. Later, other shares would also be purchased on a prorated basis, if the offer were oversubscribed by the end of the tender offer, June 19. **********The shareholder response ''shows a fairly decent reading of NLT's $50-a-share offer, if they can get one-third of the stock with the caveat that they would only pay for 1.4 million shares now,'' said T. Michael Smith, an analyst with Bradford & Company in Nashville. **********American General had ''no response'' to the NLT announcement, according to Nicholas Rasmussen, its vice president and treasurer.  But the company reiterated its charge that the ''early-pay'' provision of NLT's offer was illegal. **********Shares tendered by yesterday, the deadline for proration, qualified for the early-payment pool of stocks.  While the 7.9 million common shares tendered far exceeded the 1.4 million limit for early payment, the 425,000 preferred shares tendered fell short of NLT's goal of 600,000 preferred. It needs 530,000 preferred shares to be able vote down the issuance of new preferred shares that American General must use in its own tender offer for NLT. American General is seeking all of NLT's outstanding common in exchange for $1.1 billion in American General securities. **********In another development, a Federal judge in Houston, where American General is based, will hold a hearing to consider that company's request for a preliminary injunction against NLT's tender offer. **********American General closed yesterday at $39.75, unchanged, and NLT closed at $26.875, up 50 cents, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/08/busin.body_text: **********INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS MACHINES, a disappointment for almost a decade, could produce good gains for its 737,000 owners over the next two to three years. **********Otis Bradley of Alex. Brown & Sons, who has followed I.B.M. for more than 20 years, thinks the shares could double by 1984. He bases this view on a long-range earnings projection to $10 or more a share in 1984 with a price/earnings multiple of 12. **********At present, I.B.M. carries an earnings multiple of 10 on profits estimated at $5.65 a share for the calendar year 1981. Mr. Bradley notes that I.B.M.'s multiple has at least equaled 12 in every year in the last quarter century. The stock closed yesterday at 56 3/4, unchanged. The relatively unimpressive 1981 result in part reflects currency loss es estimated by Mr. Bradley at more than 50 cents a share. **********I.B.M. earned $6.10 a share in 1980, with about 28 cents of that reflecting a tax rate uncharacteristically low for the company, Mr.  Bradley said. **********In his bullish outlook, Mr. Bradley calls I.B.M.'s incoming orders and shipments ''quite strong.'' He argues that the company's impressive acceleration in revenue growth has been masked by currency setbacks amounting to $1.5 billion in the first nine months of 1981. **********He believes, therefore, that the indicated 9 percent growth resulting in revenues of $20.1 billion for the nine months is significantly understated. ''The true growth is almost double that percentage and accelerating,'' he said. **********Most importantly, he believes revenue growth in 1982 could approach 20 percent, particularly if the dollar either stabilizes or weakens or if the world economy strengthens more than most expect. **********For 1982, Mr. Bradley estimates I.B.M. will earn $6.75 to $7.30 a share and that the company will earn $8.25 to $8.80 a share in 1983 and thus set the stage for at least $10 a share in 1984. **********The analyst says that the world markets for I.B.M.'s many products are very strong and that the company has introduced many important new products in recent years that are about to emerge from start-up cycles. **********In Mr. Bradley's view, I.B.M. is in roughly the same position in its current product cycle as it was some years after its 360 mainframe computer was introduced in 1964, and some years after its 370 mainframe model was introduced in 1970, when these lines began to pour forth major profits. **********This time around, he says, the product line is ''much broader.'' The success he says I.B.M. has been achieving with its 303X, 4300 and 8100 families of computers has been obscured by the currency setbacks. **********Mr. Bradley also notes that I.B.M. has undergone a major change in share ownership as evidenced by the 133 million shares traded last year, or some 526,000 shares per trading session. **********''Obviously, a lot of that trading has to do with covered options and other arbitrage,'' Mr. Bradley said. ''But it is also highly probable that the percentage of individual ownership has risen sharply in the last couple of years.'' I.B.M.'s 4-for-1 stock split in 1979 priced the shares below 100 for the first time in more than a generation and was designed to makethe stock more attractive to individuals. Com pany statistics are saidto indicate success. **********Mr. Bradley believes that individuals setting up Individual Retirement Accounts under the expanded law will in some cases buy I.B.M. since the stock has provided predictable dividend growth in the past and offers the prospect of capital appreciation in future. **********An analyst at the Value Line Investment Survey views the shares positively, too, noting that I.B.M. is about to move back into the profitable computer services business after an eight-year absence. In addition, I.B.M. is soon expected to introduce robots for use in factories. The analyst went on to say that, ''while less expensive systems will make up an ever-increasing percentage of the sales mix, capital additions should provide profit protection via improved operating efficiencies.'' **********The Value Line analyst added that I.B.M.'s agreements to sell its personal computers through Sears and Computerland represented a cost-effective method of distribution. **********Whether I.B.M. will show the kinds of stock market gains that once accompanied its key measures of growth - book value per share and return on equity - I.B.M. has slowed considerably from its heyday. **********With a revenue base estimated at $28.3 billion in 1981, the company ranks among the top 10 industrial companies in the nation and as such is believed by many to be too large to grow at a 20 percent or better rate for long.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/12/busin.main_headline: BACK IN VOGUE WITH MUTUAL FUNDS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/12/busin.print_headline: BACK IN VOGUE WITH MUTUAL FUNDS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/12/busin.body_text: **********RICHARD TISCH, president of the Richbar Sales Corporation, a 46-year-old New York dress importer, has a bout $850,000 in investments, and almost all of it is in mutual f unds. ''I used to trade stocks, but frankly I couldn't keep up with i t,'' he said. ''There were tons of trading slips and it was s upercostly.'' **********Almost without interruption since 1975, Mr. Tisch has had his assets in the 44 Wall Street Fund, an aggresive growth mutual fund.  ''Now I only have to check one price,'' he added. **********Mr. Tisch's experience is one of the indications that mutual funds, the billion-dollar babies of the 1960's, are back on the investing scene in a big way. **********While money market funds have taken the headlines, cumulative assets of stock and bond funds shot up to a record $63.8 billion through last September, surpassing the previous record of $59.8 billion set in 1972. And net sales - representing purchases minus redemptions, again excluding money funds - amounted to $3.2 billion in the first seven months of 1982, far exceeding the former peak of $3.1 billion in all of 1969. These records, moreover, were set before the bull market surge that began last summer. **********Mutual funds boomed despite a long-slumping stock market, a depressed bond market and a plethora of competitive investment vehicles largely because of new marketing techniques adopted by the leading companies in the industry, according to fund specialists. In effect, the business awoke to the challenges of the 1980's and hammered home its sales message to the public. **********''People began to realize that it's as easy to open a mutual fund as it is to go into a bank,'' said Laura Berger, executive director of the No-Load Mutual Fund Association. ''It wasn't as hard as they imagined to go into an account.'' **********Born of the 19th century Scottish and British investment trusts, the mutual fund became a popular item in the 1950's, promoted heavily as a way for the small investor to reap the benefits of big money. One's small investment became part of a big pool that offered diversity, liquidity and lower transaction costs, with professional management thrown in for good measure. **********But in the 1970's, the stock market went sour, and funds had net redemptions in seven of the 10 years. During this period, moreover, money market funds began to become very popular with the public. It was not until 1980 that another reversal occurred - one that is still gathering steam - and mutual fund purchases again exceeded redemptions on a consistent basis. **********A bright marketing idea currently in vogue has been to multiply the number of funds offered under one roof. This recent emphasis on allowing shareholders the right to move money among a ''family'' of funds under the same management company has been an important lure in attracting additional business. **********''Mutual funds have become segmented to serve more and more specialized purposes,'' said George S. Johnston, president of Scudder, Stevens & Clark, a New York-based investment adviser that manages nine mutual funds. ''The consumer, as well as the big institutions, has become a selective shopper.'' **********Reflecting this, $16.8 billion was shifted in the first nine months of this year from one fund to another within a single mutual fund organization. This compares with $14.4 billion moved among fund families in all of 1981. The two biggest shifts were to municipal bond funds and aggressive growth funds. **********Fund groups allow almost limitless transfers by telephone, regardless of their size. Most organizations charge about $5 for each movement, but others allow free, restrictionless phone switching. **********The funds, quick to notice the rise in shifting, even offer guides to their own increasingly complex groups of offerings. As an example, for a fee of one-tenth of 1 percent of any portfolio of $100,000 or more, Scudder Fund Investment Counsel provides a consultant to give advice and recommend exchanges among the funds managed by the company. Those with smaller portfolios in mutual funds must decide the three basic switching questions on their own: when to get in, when to get out and when to get back in again. **********In addition, there are a number of newsletter advisory services that track the performance of different funds as a guide to those contemplating a switch. Among them are Telephone Switch Newsletter, Huntington Beach, Calif.; Switch Fund Advisory, Gaithersburg, Md., and NoLoad Fund X, San Francisco. **********''There are mutual funds across the entire financial spectrum from the most conservative kind of investment to the most speculative kind of investment,'' said David Silver, president of the Investment Company Institute, the national association of mutual funds. ''It's the whole idea of risk-adjusted investments.'' **********The institute categorizes the 515 non-money market funds that existed as of September 1982 into nine broad groups, each with a distinct financial objective and a different risk-reward relationship. They range from capital appreciation funds to balanced funds and from natural resources funds to fixed-income funds. Newer types of mutual fund products include gold funds, international funds and option funds. **********''The fundamental in choosing a mutual fund is your own circumstances,'' Mr. Silver said. ''Look at your age and your financial resources. What is your personal style? How will you sleep best at night?'' **********Because personal styles differ and some people can accept risk more easily than others, investors in mutual funds have portfolios ranging from $500 to $1 million or more. Many people consider their fund to be their one-stop shop for financial services and have all or most of their assets in this single investment. **********Further attracting more and more investors is the record that mutual funds have achieved in the five years through last Sept. 30.  Mutual funds in general, and stock funds in particular, turned in significantly better returns than the Dow Jones industrial average, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks and the Consumer Price Index, according to Lipper Analytical Services, which tracks fund performance. **********Its tabulation shows that all funds advanced 107.16 percent and equity funds rose 90.86 percent, compared with gains of 43.54 percent for the Dow, 63.48 percent for the S.& P. 500 and 59.40 percent for consumer prices. **********To simplify starting and marketing new funds, fund managers have recently developed a series concept - one fund with, say, three different portfolios from which an investor can choose the appropriate grouping for his needs. The portfolios are generally centered around a particular industry, like technology, energy or consumer products, and run by the same money managers and board of directors under a single prospectus. **********The future growth of mutual funds may be augmented by other investment vehicles with which the funds can join forces. For instance, the new and enormously popular retirement plans are already heavily into mutual funds. Twenty-six percent of all the money in Keogh plans and 10 percent of all the money in Individual Retirement Accounts were placed in mutual funds last year - and the dollar amounts this year have already exceeded 1981. **********Almost half of the sales by the mutual fund industry are currently accounted for by no-load funds, which sell their shares at net asset value without the addition of a sales charge. In 1972, only 20 percent of fund sales were of the no-load variety. **********''Individual investors have become aware that they could call a number and there would be people to answer questions,'' Mrs. Berger said. ''Many previously thought that if they bought a load fund from a broker, he would be there but there would be no one if they bought a no-load.'' Of course, millions of Americans still buy mutual funds with a sales charge because of the performance of these funds or the persuasion of the salesman. **********The anticipated expansion of money management accounts at brokerage firms, banks and savings and loan associations is also expected to be a boon for mutual funds. Many of these accounts, which attempt to give customers continuous access to current money market rates, now sweep cash automatically into money-market funds based on a predetermined formula. **********''There's no reason,'' as Mr. Silver put it, ''why money cannot be swept into equity funds directly.'' Others see even more new markets developing that will appeal to many of those who have never before been involved with mutual funds. **********''Until now, mutual funds have been relatively small, serving specialized niches in the market for savings and investment vehicles,'' said Paul V. Teplitz, director of Cambridge Research Institute, which studied the subject for the no-load association.  ''Although the product appeal of bond and equity funds may not be as dramatic as the recent appeal of money funds, their potential market is very large.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/21/world.main_headline: Kohl, Despite Setback, Is Hopeful on '83 Vote
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/21/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Kohl, Despite Setback, Is Hopeful on '83 Vote
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/21/world.body_text: **********Chancellor Helmut Kohl said today that he still believed his Christian Democratic Party had a good chance of winning the general election in March, despite losing a Hamburg state election Sunday. **********''We did not achieve our aim; we have undoubtedly suffered a setback,'' Mr. Kohl told reporters after party leaders met to discuss the victory of the opposition Social Democrats. **********Meanwhile, the Social Democrats issued a draft of a manifesto today calling for an international employment agreement to revive the world economy. **********The draft proposed an immediate meeting of major industrial nations to devise a joint policy on economic expansion. One of the most important elements in such a policy would be an agreement on further reductions in interest rates, it said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/25/busin.main_headline: Atari Computers Gets Marketer as President
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/25/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Atari Computers Gets Marketer as President
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/25/busin.body_text: **********Atari Inc. has gone outside the ranks of the computer industry to find a new executive for its fast-growing home computer division.  The company said yesterday that John C. Cavalier, with a background in marketing, will be the division's new president. **********Mr. Cavalier, 43, succeeds Roger H. Badertscher, who resigned in June. Mr. Badertscher, said to be more technically oriented, is attempting to set up a company to produce a new personal computer. **********Mr. Cavalier ''is going to bring a way of relating to the consumer, which is probably as important as relating to technology,'' said Lee S. Isgur, an analyst with Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis Inc. **********Mr. Cavalier, who was traveling yesterday and unavailable for comment, comes from the American Can Company, which he joined in 1969 as a financial analyst. His most recent job was vice president and general manager of American Can's Dixie and Dixie/Marathon unit, makers of consumer paper products. **********Atari, a subsidiary of Warner Comunications Inc., has geared its computer sales to the home market. Mr. Isgur predicted the company would be No.1 in home sales next year, with revenues of $700 million to $1 billion. **********He estimated that Atari's 1982 revenues from home computers would be between $300 million and $500 million. By contrast, he said, just two years ago the division's volume was only $20 million. **********Mr. Cavalier, who will be responsible for worldwide operations, will report to Raymond E. Kassar, the division's chairman and chief executive. Atari is based in Sunnyvale, Calif. **********Before joining American Can, Mr. Cavalier worked for five years at the Itek Corporation in market research and sales planning. He is a graduate of Notre Dame and earned his M.B.A. at Michigan State University.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/15/busin.body_text: **********New car sales by the nation's Big Three auto makers fell 14.8 percent in the July 1-10 period, the companies reported today. **********Early July marks the third consecutive period in which sales levels were below those of a year earlier. Analysts attribute the lag to the lack of consumer incentives, which had been in effect in May. The first 10 days of June showed only a marginal gain, eight-tenths of one percent. **********''Consumers have been conditioned over the past three years by incentives,'' said Peter Zaglio, an analyst **********Businesses cut inventories by nine-tenths of 1 percent in May, the biggest drop on record. Page D3. with Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc. ''When incentives are on, people buy. When incentives are off, consumers wait for the next round to buy.'' **********''Auto manufacturers have to slowly wean the consumers away from incentives,'' Mr. Zaglio added. ''It can't be done in one month.'' The General Motors Corporation, the nation's leading auto maker, reported the steepest decline of the Big Three, down 18.9 percent from the comparable period a year ago. The Chrysler Corporation's sales were off 15.9 percent while the Ford Motor Company reported sales down 3.7 percent. **********Including Volkswagen of America and the American Motors Corporation, domestic auto manufactuers sold 108,318 cars in the early July period, down 16.4 percent from the 129,572 cars sold in the comparable period last year. There were eight selling days in the period both this year and last. Daily Rate at Low Level **********The daily selling rate for the five companies for the period was 13,540, the lowest daily rate for the period since 1958 when the rate was 12,038. The daily selling rate in the mid-June period was also the lowest since 1958. **********The seasonally adjusted annual selling rate for the period was 4.8 million, down from the 5.8 million annual rate recorded during the July 1-10 period in 1981. **********General Motors, whose sales have declined since the ending of their 12.8 percent financing program in May, today announced an incentive program for dealers, not customers, involving compact and subcompact cars. The program, effective immediately through August, will allow dealers a cash allowance on the selected models to be used as they wish to increase sales. **********''We are planning no other reduced retail financing rate activities or passenger car rebates to customers as we close out the model year,'' said Robert D. Lund, vice president for sales and marketing staff at General Motors. Impact of Dealer Program **********The dealer incentive program at G.M. may signify a return to a traditional merchandising method, analysts say. **********''Bare rebates by the manufacturer to the consumer should give way to more realistic pricing and dealer assumption of the old role of controlling the actual price at which the consumer buys,'' said Arvid Jouppi, an analyst with the Colin, Hochstin Company in Detroit. **********G.M. sold 61,844 cars in the early June period, down from 76,296 sold in the similar period last year. G.M. reported a decline in market share in the period, to 57.1 percent from 58.9 percent. **********Ford sold 29,071 cars compared with 30,182 in the 1981 period. It reported a gain in market share, to 26.8 percent from 23.3 percent in the period last year. **********Chrysler reported sales of 13,817 in the most recent period, down from 16,435 in the period last year. Chrysler held 12.8 percent of the market, almost even with the 12.7 percent last year. A.M.C. Drops 38.1% **********A.M.C. sold an estimated 2,200 cars, a 38.1 percent decline from the comparable period in 1981 when 3,555 cars were sold. A.M.C. has 2 percent of the market, down from 2.7 percent in early July last year. A.M.C. reports on a monthly basis only. **********New car sales by Volkswagen of America continued to decline in the July 1-10 period, down 55.3 percent on sales of 1,386 cars compared with the 3,104 sold last year. Volkswagen held 1.3 percent of the market, down from the 2.4 percent in the comparable 1981 period. **********Thus far this year, the five domestic auto makers have sold 3,043,142 cars, off 11.5 percent from last year when 3,437,641 cars had been sold.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/02/busin.main_headline: Advertising; New Guide For Agency Shoppers
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/02/busin.print_headline: Advertising; New Guide For Agency Shoppers
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/02/busin.body_text: **********WHEN a person has such a great desire to sell advertising that he creates a cross-Channel, motorized hang-glider race just to sell the space on the underside of the wings, that is compulsion. **********Such a driven man is Richard Fenwick, president of Editions Fenwick, a Frenchman with a French law degree and a Wharton M.B.A., who says: ''What I love is just to sell advertising.'' **********But he has come to realize that he must put more of his time into repeatable media and less into one-shot ventures.  ''So I looked for a product that could be sold on a regular basis like a magazine,'' he said, going on to describe the Agency Book, an annual directory, now on the drawing board, that is scheduled to bow by the end of the year. **********It is the latest attempt to profit from ad agencies' desires to be visible to advertisers who are looking for a new agency. A more elaborate effort is a two-year-old British import called the Advertising Agency Register, which has a file of 10-minute, agencyproduced videotapes of promotional messages, which may or may not include examples of their work, to be screened by advertisers. **********In the past year and a half, more than 60 advertisers have used the facilities, which include access to each agencies' portfolio of print advertising (with or without case studies). Agencies supply brochures on themselves for any interested potential clients. About 21 agency changes have grown out of the 60 visits. **********Advertisers pay $1,500 to shop and agencies pay $4,000 to be seen.  Mr. Fenwick, whose New York office is at 75 East 55th Street, will be selling two-page spreads to ad agencies for $5,500 and will suggest that the left-hand page be used for examples of their work while the facing page is to be used for such things as a statement of the agency's philosophy and listing of awards, but not the statistical kind of information already available from Standard Rate and Data's Agency Red Book. **********Business Week is a sponsor of the effort and will take reponsibility for distributing 10,000 copies to 1,500 advertiser companies. That will leave Mr. Fenwick free to sell his advertising to the agencies, each of which will be supplied with a computer printout of the names of executives who have received copies. **********Meanwhile, in another part of town, Arthur Hawkins, one-time corporate creative director of Ketchum, MacLeod & Grove and partner in the now-defunct Hawkins, McCain & Blumenthal, has been motivated to come out with a dissimilar kind of publication with the same raison d'etre. **********A pocket-size monthly called Credits with the subtitle ''Current Advertising and Who Created It,'' it is a joint venture of Mr.  Hawkins and Carnegie Communications, which publishes Club Living magazine and is a division of Landon Associates, newspaper advertising representatives. **********Credits will be a black-and-white publication, which would seem to be a drawback. It expects to have a distribution of 23,000 copies and a page rate of $695. **********The magazine, its founder says, is intended to forever answer the question: ''That's a great ad, I wonder who did it?'' It does not, however, address the question: ''Why isn't it listed in Credits?'' **********Mr. Fenwick, of Paris and New York, was in Paris yesterday, most assuredly plotting even greater advertising sales triumphs. It is the city where he once worked for Banque Rothschild and then for TBWA, an ad agency with one American principal. He stayed just long enough to gather the expertise to go into business for himself as a marketing consultant. **********While following this pursuit, his life took a strange turn and he found himself in the business of producing board games as advertising media. It worked this way: **********He would bring together a specialists in game creation with an expert from a particular industry, who would make up a game that had commercial possibilities. **********Then Mr. Fenwick would do what he loves most to do: sell it to sponsors or a group of advertisers. It would be sold through regular game distribution channels or given away by the sponsor as a promotion tool. **********The first success was the game named for the Fortune 500. Each company whose name was used paid $30,000 for the honor. Versions of it were sold in a number of countries, and in France, where it was available for six years, Mr. Fenwick's research tells him that the game was played by 1.6 million people. It certainly did help the economy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/07/busin.print_headline: MAN IN THE NEWS; MARTIN FELDSTEIN: ECONOMIC ADVISER
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/07/busin.body_text: **********Martin Stuart Feldstein, selected by President Reagan today as the new chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, is a conservative economist from the mold that produced the President's economic policy. **********But he has also expressed beliefs that Ronald Reagan does not want to hear: He has, for example, suggested that the third year of the President's cherished personal tax cut be delayed as a way to reduce Federal budget deficits. **********Such a stand, however, is the kind of complicated position that the sometimes-controversial Harvard economist likes to take. And it may suggest the type of analysis that could help the Reagan Administration get its economic policy working. **********A leader of the growing ranks of young conservative economists, the 42-year-old Mr. Feldstein is committed most to reducing the deficit by chopping domestic spending, especially the growth of entitlement programs, the biggest of which is Social Security. And while he has suggested delaying the July 1, 1983, instalment of the tax cut, he is against taking it away entirely and opposes most other permanent tax increases because they just encourage spending. **********This makes him a supply-sider, as is the President. But while he pushes for tax cuts and incentives to spur investment, he is not in tune with the all-out supply-siders who directed early Reagan economic policy and who were subsequently frustrated by restrictive monetary policy. **********Mr. Feldstein acknowledges the need for a restrictive monetary policy to fight inflation. This is the Administration's current mix of policy, but it is one that has so far led to a sharp recession, high unemployment and large budget deficits. **********Mr. Feldstein comes to the council at what is probably one of the most difficult economic junctures in recent history. Some economists wondered today whether he would be able to have a strong impact on an economic policy that has essentially been taken over by politics. **********''It's a very tough environment for economic policy making at this time,'' said Alan Greenspan, chairman of the council in the Ford Administration. ''He is coming to an environment in which more than any time in recent history, political forces are dominating economic policy making.'' **********But some others felt that if someone can do it, it would be Mr.  Feldstein. He was at the top of the list to replace Murray L.  Weidenbaum, who resigned to return to Washington University in St.  Louis. **********Mr. Feldstein is serious and precise and, with his 5-foot, 9-inch unathletic frame, balding pate and horn-rimmed glasses, he looks it.  He is not known as a charmer. His concern is for quality, not style.  While he has created some controversy in his current position as head of the National Bureau of Economic Research, he is wellrespected among his fellow economists. Merchandising Economics **********At the same time, Mr. Feldstein has done well in merchandising his brand of conservative economics. He turned the bureau, an independent institution best known for its offical role of declaring the beginnings and ends of recessions, into a trimmer, business-like operation. **********But according to some critics, including the former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Arthur Burns, the bureau under Mr. Feldstein has moved from objective research to special issues, reflecting his direction of studies toward his area of interest -the effect of tax policies on savings and investment. **********Mr. Feldstein took over the bureau, based in Cambridge, Mass. in 1977, at the age of 38. It was his second laurel of the year.  Earlier, he had won the John Bates Clark Award from the American Economic Association, the highest honor for an economist under 40. **********Ten years earlier, Mr. Feldstein had come to Harvard as an assistant professor of economics. After graduating from Harvard in 1961, with the idea and the pre-med courses to go to medical school, he changed course while at Oxford on a Fulbright Scholarship. He took three degrees at Oxford, ending with a Ph.D. in economics. Dumping Keynesian Thought **********When he returned to Harvard, he was still a mainstream Keynesian, then the school of leading liberal economists. But once he started examining the products of this demand-oriented approach - which favors Government intervention in the economy - he began the move to his conservative track, deciding that big social programs with good intentions had just ''ended up making things worse.'' **********Mr. Feldstein, who will take a two-year leave of absence from Harvard to head the council, had been sought for one of the two other slots on the council during the Ford Administration and was considered at the beginning of the Reagan Administration. The nomination has to be confirmed by the Senate. **********He now lives in Belmont, Mass., outside of Boston. His wife, Kathleen, whom he met at Oxford, holds a Ph.D. in economics from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and writes a newspaper column with her husband. They have two daughters, Margaret 12, and Janet, 9. **********Mr. Feldstein was born in the Bronx on Nov. 25, 1939, where his father was a lawyer, and later moved to Rockville Centre on Long Island.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/12/world.main_headline: ISRAELIS FAN OUT IN NORTH LEBANON
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/12/world.print_headline: ISRAELIS FAN OUT IN NORTH LEBANON
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/12/world.body_text: **********Israeli tanks moved into strategic positions in northern Lebanon today as Israeli planes and artillery shelled Palestinian areas of west Beirut for the third consecutive day. **********But officials here, in Jerusalem and in Washington voiced optimism that accord would be reached on the plan for Palestinian withdrawal from west Beirut that is being negotiated by Philip C. Habib, the American envoy. **********The Israeli advance north of Beirut involved some 40 tanks that moved along the coast highway beyond the port of Junieh to the area of the ancient harbor of Byblos, which bears the modern name of Jubeil. **********It is the northernmost point reached by the Israeli forces, and the advance puts them into position for a thrust farther north, toward Tripoli, or east into Lebanon's central mountain range. **********President Elias Sarkis and Prime Minister Shafik al-Wazzan discussed the widening grip on northern Lebanon at a meeting, and Mr. Wazzan was reported by the Government radio as having said that ''Israel's fanning out'' presented a serious problem. **********Aside from the guerrillas trapped in west Beirut, Palestinian forces are based in refugee camps near Tripoli as well as in the town of Baalbek, in the Bekaa Valley of eastern Lebanon. Those Palestinians are not included in Mr. Habib's plan for the evacuation of west Beirut; they are to be covered in a later set of negotiations. **********Some of the Israeli armored vehicles near Byblos were sent east into the mountains during the day to the Laqluk ski resort area.  A detachment of eight tanks with bridge-building equipment was reported going into the upper Metun valley in the mountains east of Beirut, according to the Phalangist radio, operated by the Lebanese Christians, who control that area. **********The bombing runs in west Beirut began shortly before noon, sending plumes of white smoke from refugee camps on the southern fringe of the city. Artillery fire picked up in the afternoon and continued into the night, with flares lighting up targets for gunboats in the seaside city neighborhood of Ain Muraisa. **********There was fighting near the National Museum, a crossing point on the green line that separates the western Moslem and eastern Christian sectors of the Lebanese capital. The Israelis attempted to advance into west Beirut along the Corniche Mazraa road, but were apparently held off by Palestinian fire. **********The Palestinian press agency, Wafa, said the Israeli had attempted to push forward with bulldozers and tanks to clear the mounds of earth heaped on the road but were driven back and the bulldozers destroyed. In Israel, the military command said nine soldiers were wounded during the day. In Jerusalem, meanwhile, Mr. Habib met twice with Prime Minister Menachem Begin, then returned here tonight, apparently with new points raised by Israel. He is to present them to the Lebanese negotiators and return to Jerusalem with their reply. **********Reports from Israel indicated that one problem was Mr. Begin's objection to the immediate deployment of the French units of an international peace force as the first Palestinians leave. **********The prompt deployment of the peace force, which would later also include United States marines and Italian troops, was demanded by west Beirut's Lebanese Sunni Moslem community, which fears that, without the protective shield of the international force, the Lebanese Christian militia would sweep into west Beirut. The fears are based on the memories of the 1975-76 civil war, which has left many unsettled scores. **********The Lebanese Cabinet canceled its regular weekly meeting, which was to be held today, as it awaited Israel's reply to Mr. Habib's latest draft. When Israel gives its approval, the Lebanese Government is expected to issue a formal call for the international peacekeeping force, which would be a rare exercise of authority. **********One issue that has yet to be dealt with is how the evacuation will affect the families of the Palestinian military people in west Beirut.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/06/busin.body_text: **********Judge Harold Greene of Federal District Court here, who has charge of the antitrust case against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, granted permission today to the Justice Department to file by next Wednesday a requested statement describing the ''competitive impact'' of the proposed settlement of the case. **********The report had been due today, but the Justice Department late yesterday asked for a postponement of the deadline. **********Judge Greene also said that a 60-day period for public comment on the proposed settlement would commence Feb. 19 and conclude April 20.  In an unrelated matter, A.T.& T. filed a paper with the court describing the sequence of communications with the Federal Government concerning the settlement proposal. **********The following sequence was reported: **********- On Dec. 30, 1981, Charles L. Brown, chairman of A.T.& T., and Howard Trienens, vice president and general counsel, met with William F. Baxter, antitrust chief at the Justice Department, to review and discuss the settlement proposal. **********- Mr. Brown and Mr. Baxter conferred again, by phone, on the terms of the settlement. **********- Subsequently, Mr. Brown met and talked to several other Government officials about the settlement, including Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, on Jan. 6, 1982, and Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige, Jan. 7. **********The paper said that, in addition, he had talked with two White House aides, Edwin Meese 3d and Fred Fielding, also on Jan. 7.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/27/busin.main_headline: Wide Price Differences On Super Bowl Ads
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/27/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; Wide Price Differences On Super Bowl Ads
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/27/busin.body_text: **********There were a lot of people who were shocked when they heard that the CBS-TV Network was asking $345,000 for a 30-second commercial slot during the Super Bowl last Sunday. But considering the number of people being reached, the local CBS-owned and affiliated stations were asking even more. **********The New York market that is reached by the television signal of WCBS-TV, Channel 2, contains 8.3 percent of the national population, but was asking for $70,000 and $75,000. **********''That's too rich for a lot of people's blood,'' said Phil Guarascio, senior vice president, media, at Benton & Bowles, who said that the Channel 2 people were still selling last Friday. **********Eglon Simons, the station's national sales manager, said that all 13 of the 30-second units were sold for the game, as were the 10 units in the pregame and postgame shows. **********Meanwhile, KPIX, Channel 5, in San Francisco, a Westinghouse affiliate, was getting $30,000 a spot for reaching 2.5 percent of the country. The game, however, broke all records for San Francisco audiences with a 53.2 rating and a 91 percent share.
