https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/07/busin.body_text: **********A CCORDING to conventional wisdom many management problems are caused by a ''lack of communication.'' But, if anything, the reverse may be true: Too much talk, and too many meetings and memos are prime confusion creators. **********Much of the new electronic circuitry enabling us to communicate more quickly results not in better communication but in more. That simply adds to the confusion. Too much communication may be as bad as too little. **********People also don't realize that lack of communication may in fact be a form of communication; that if the boss doesn't tell you something it may be because he or she has nothing to say, or doesn't know what to say. The conventional wisdom is that if the administration doesn't communicate, it is because it doesn't want the rank and file to know. It is as likely to be the case that the administration may not want the staff to know how little it knows - not necessarily because the administration is stupid, but because it is waiting for more information. **********The staff may also not understand that in many circumstances doing nothing is best. Saying or doing nothing may be the administrative analogue of the medical commandment: ''Above all, do no harm.'' Nor is waiting to ''let nature take its course'' all that easy - because the administration is often pressed to do something. Managerial selfrestraint can save everyone time and misplaced energy. **********Instead, we seem to see a whole class of administrators emerging, who are so busy communicating that they have little time to do anything else, e.g., their jobs. Communication has become an end rather than a means. **********There is some truth in the aphorism that those who say don't know and those who know don't say, but even more truth in the idea that the clearest form of communication is what people do, not what they say. **********There is a herd instinct in management, as there is everywhere else. The virtue of communication has been so touted that the virtues of a lack of communication are forgotten. So much of what passes for information today is misinformation, disinformation, dated, ephemeral, biased, plain wrong - and to ''share'' (the current euphemism) all of it immediately may only widen the pool of ignorance. Such sharing may paralyze, panic, or cause serious mistakes to be made. More may be accomplished by a judicious silence, while the facts are checked, re-checked and assessed. **********The thoughtful administrator will share what is worth sharing.  Meetings should not be called for their own sake nor memos issued to show that ''we are communicating.'' The time wasted in pointless communication is clear in the widespread cynicism about meetings, conventions and the like. That doesn't mean these have no place.  Rather, formal business communication should meet the five-way test: 1. Is it necessary? 2. Do we have something solid to say? 3. Do we have somethin g concrete to ask? 4. Is it not known? 5. Does it need explanation? **********The profusion of electronic communication may lead to further confusion. The emphasis is on how little time it takes or how easy it is to communicate, yet the experienced executive knows how often he was grateful for not being able to communicate instantly either his feelings or his directions. There is something about composing our hot thoughts at leisure on cool paper that forces us to arrange, winnow and work through our ideas.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/11/busin.body_text: **********The Dow Chemical Company and Japan's Asahi Chemical Industry Company are ending a 30-year joint venture to allow both companies to pursue their respective operations in Japan, Dow announced. **********Asahi will buy 50 percent of Dow's interest in Asahi-Dow Ltd. for about $185 million, obtaining sole control of seven Japanese plants, a Dow spokesman, A.A. Wolf, said. **********Dow, in turn, will assume control over the Asahi-Dow Styrofoam brand plastic foam business, Mr. Wolf said. Two plants, at Sapporo and Kanuma, Japan, manufacture the Styrofoam, he said. **********The agreement is part of a Dow move to shift gradually to the manufacture of specialty and consumer products in Japan, Mr. Wolf said. **********Under the agreement, however, Asahi will continue to manufacture Saran Wrap, the plastic food wrap, in Japan.  The two companies, which formed the joint venture in 1952, are discussing the future cross-licensing of several products to allow Dow to manufacture some Asahi products in the United States and Asahi to manufacture some Dow products in Japan, Mr. Wolf said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/30/busin.body_text: **********Late payments on mortgage loans rose to a 17-year record last month as recession and high interest rates continued to squeeze household budgets, a savings and loan industry group said in a report scheduled for release Tuesday. **********In February, payments on 1.21 percent of the mortgages held by savings and loan associations were considered delinquent, compared with 1.17 percent in January and 0.94 percent in February 1981, the United States League of Savings Associations said. **********The industry considers a home loan delinquent when no payment has been received in the past 60 days. **********Last month's was the highest delinquency rate since February 1965, when 1.28 percent of all outstanding mortgages were considered delinquent. The association, which began compiling the figures in 1953, said the delinquency rate reached a record 1.41 percent in February 1962 and again in February 1964. **********But the league said that while deliquencies continued to rise last month, the rate of increase slowed.  The February figures were based on a survey of 1,475 savings associations holding about half of the industry's $655 billion in assets.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/18/busin.print_headline: DOW SOARS BY 38.81; VOLUME NEAR PEAK
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/18/busin.body_text: **********The stock market exploded yesterday as prospects of lower interest rates sent the Dow Jones industrial average soaring to its best single-day advance in history in near-record trading volume. **********By the final bell, the Dow average, the market's blue-chip barometer, had climbed 38.81 points in a dazzling session to finish at 831.24. The former record was set on Nov. 1, 1978, when the Dow rose 35.34 points, a spurt that was set off then by news that the Federal Reserve had acted to strengthen a declining dollar. **********''The market acted today like a hungry dog grasping for a ragged bone: declining interest rates,'' commented Monte Gordon, research director of the Dreyfus Corporation. **********Comparatively Little Fanfare **********Volume on the New York Stock Exchange, where floor members greeted the heavy trading and increasing stock prices with comparatively little fanfare, rose to 92,860,000 shares, the second highest ever, from 55.4 million shares traded on Monday. **********The record turnover on the exchange of 92,880,000 shares was posted on Jan. 7, 1981, after Joseph Granville, a prominent stock forecaster, sent his clients a flash telegram advising them ''to sell everything.'' **********The exchange's tape, which records each stock trade, was only about 4 minutes late during most of the session, despite the near-record volume. **********Charles Comer, technical analyst of Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc., attributed this to the fact that most of the activity was from large institutional investors who trade in blocks of 10,000 shares rather than the 100-share trades common among small investors, and thus the tape had to handle fewer trades. A record 1,564 blocks changed hands yesterday on the Big Board, compared with 959 on Monday. Forecast by Kaufman **********The market opened the session higher and prices started to shoot up late in the morning after Henry Kaufman, the prominent Salomon Brothers economist known for his interest rate expertise, forecast that rates in long-term Government bonds would plunge to 9 percent or 10 percent in the next 12 months from the present 12.5 percent. Mr.  Kaufman's forecast reversed the view he had held for months, that interest rates would rise. **********Mr. Kaufman also said that he expects the Federal funds rate, the cost of short-term loans that banks make to each other, to trade between 6 percent and 7 percent within a year, against the current 10 percent. **********''Mr. Kaufman today did a double-take over the course of interest rates for the next 12 months and this triggered a wild bond rally today which was followed by the upsurge in stock prices,'' commented Kenneth S. Rolland, chief investment officer of the trust and investment division of the Chemical Bank. 'Fundamental Trends' **********However, Wayne Nordberg, chairman of the investment committee of Prescott, Ball & Turben, said ''it's unfortunate that investors find it necessary to rely so heavily on the judgment of one individual and seem unable to perceive for themselves fundamental trends that have been developing for many months in the capital markets.'' **********Mr. Rolland of Chemical Bank said, ''The rally should continue in such groups as utilities, banks and housing.'' The stock market in the last three sessions has soared 54 points, mainly because interest rates have been falling steeply since Thursday. When interest rates decline, many investors switch money to stocks from Treasury issues, savings certificates and other interest-bearing investments. Declining interest rates are also an indication that corporate profits will improve as companies reduce the cost of borrowing funds. **********Another bullish factor for the stock market yesterday was the report of a 33.7 percent jump in July housing starts, to an annual rate of 1.2 million units. It was the first time in more than a year that housing starts have risen above the 1 million rate. **********In the day's trading, the Dow was up 9.32 points at 10:30 A.M., then eased a bit before surging ahead after 1 P.M. when Mr.  Kaufman's remarks circulated around Wall Street. At 3 P.M., the index was up 22 points and in the last hour of trading it climbed 15.8 points. Blue Chips Biggest Gainers **********Price advances on the Big Board yesterday led stocks that declined in price by almost 10 to 1, with the blue chips the biggest gainers.  General Motors soared 4 1/4 points, to 45 3/8; International Business Machines added 3 1/8, to 66; American Telephone, 2 1/2, to 55 1/8; Procter & Gamble, 3 1/8, to 88; General Electric, 4 1/4, to 68 3/8; DuPont, 1 5/8, to 32 3/4, and American Brands, 1 7/8, to 40 1/8. **********Early this month, major market indicators other than the Dow had dropped to their lowest levels since the spring or summer of 1980.  Yesterday, however, they rebounded with a vengeance. The New York Stock Exchange composite index of approximately 1,500 issues rose 2.66, a daily record, to 62.41, and the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index made its largest single advance in its 64-year history, climbing 4.95 points, to 109.04. Utilities Rise **********Utility stocks, which are sensitive to interest rates, dominated the active list yesterday. In addition to benefiting from lower interest rates, investors in utilities also retain certain tax breaks in the latest Congressional tax plan. Middle South Utilities was up 7/8, to 13 7/8, Consolidated Edison rose 3/4, to 19, and Northern Indiana Public Service gained 3/4, to 11 7/8. **********Cities Service, which rejected a $3.8 billion takeover bid from Occidental Petroleum on Monday, was halted from trading at 2:46 P.M.  when the stock was up 4 3/8, to 37 5/8. Occidental Petroleum rose 3/4, to 18 1/4. **********In the computer group, Hewlett-Packard climbed 3 1/2, to 32 3/8, after reporting that its profits in the quarter ended July 31 rose to 83 cents a share from 65 cents. **********J.C. Penney added 2 5/8, to 39 3/8, after reporting higher secondquarter profits.  Prices on the American Stock Exchange also rose, with the marketvalue index gaining 6.03, to 244.30. In the over-the-counter market, the Nasdaq composite index climbed 2.60, to 162.28.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/09/busin.body_text: **********Sales of rough gem and industrial diamonds by the Central Selling Organization for the six months to June 30, 1982, amounted to 636 million rand compared with 747.5 million rand in the same period of 1981, De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd. said today. **********One South African rand equals about $1.15. **********The sales figures for the diamond company's marketing arm were higher than the 501.9 million rand total in the latter half of 1981, but a De Beers spokesman said that the improvement did not necessarily signal a long-term recovery in the market, which has been weakened by high interest rates in the United States. **********The Central Selling Organization is currently handling more than 80 percent of the world's rough gem diamond trade, a slight increase partly reflecting new output from Botswana, the spokesman said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/22/busin.body_text: **********Roger B. Smith, chairman and chief executive officer of the General Motors Corporation, once again played the reluctant host of the automobile industry's version of the old television game show ''Beat the Clock'' as he presided over the annual meeting of stockholders today. **********As he had last year, Mr. Smith limited questions and statements from shareholders to two minutes each, with a large illuminated clock ticking off the seconds. Anyone tempted to ramble on, or to talk about homes demolished for a new G.M. plant in the area of Detroit and Hamtramck known as ''Poletown,'' was likely to have his or her microphone turned off. **********This year, Mr. Smith's plan was to tighten up the meeting to as little as one hour by eliminating the traditional period for general questions and answers. **********The plan failed. The meeting went on for four hours, and Mr. Smith sat through complaints about ''X''-car transmissions, parts falling off Chevrolets, air bags, executive bonuses -and Poletown. **********Although annual meetings give individual stockholders their one chance a year to directly address top management, Mr. Smith and other corporate executives have grumbled that minor shareholders seeking publicity and groups pressing for social causes have made the sessions unruly, irrelevant and long. **********Thus, in G.M.'s annual report for 1981, the company announced that this year's meeting would be split into morning and afternoon sessions, with the morning meeting held only to satisfy legal requirements. ''At this statutory meeting, stockholder questions and comments will be limited to matters pertaining to the election of directors and to those management and stockholder proposals included in the agenda,'' the report said. 'Stockholder Forum' **********Public comment would be reserved for what the company termed a ''stockholder forum'' at its Technical Center in Warren, Mich., about 15 miles from G.M. headquarters here. As originally explained by Mr.  Smith, the company directors would be meeting at the same time, so none would be present at the forum. **********Mr. Smith said today that the split sessions were mainly an effort to save the corporation money by combining the stockholders meeting and monthly board meeting. G.M. directors are paid $500 for each meeting they attend, in addition to annual retainers of $15,000, plus $10,000 to $15,000 for service on board committees. **********However, G.M.'s announcement drew a flurry of complaints and the company did an about-face, adding two periods for general comment, one of which stretched the morning session to four hours. **********About 500 of the 675 stockholders then boarded buses for a free lunch at the Technical Center and the forum, which, despite earlier indications that no board member would be present, was conducted by F. James McDonald, president of G.M. Polite Questions on Cards **********As it turned out, that was the quiet session, lacking the activists present in the morning meeting and lasting only about an hour and a half. Polite questions were written out on cards for Mr. McDonald, who was flanked by lower-ranking executives. **********At the morning meeting and a subsequent news conference, Mr. Smith said that negotiations were continuing with Toyota on producing one of the Japanese company's cars in one of G.M.'s idled plants on the West Coast. He said it ''would not be unreasonable to expect a decision one way or the other by fall.'' Earlier negotiations on joint production between Toyota and the Ford Motor Company dragged on for months before the effort was dropped. **********Mr. Smith also had to contend with a flurry of questions about the company's plans to change the way it pays bonuses to its senior exectives. The new plan, disclosed on the same day the United Automobile Workers union had signed a new labor contract containing concessions for the first time at G.M., appears likely to produce executive bonuses at a lower level of profitability than the old plan. It promptly became the subject of intense negotiations between the company and the union. **********Mr. Smith said the company had agreed with the union to pay bonuses at the old level and not expand stock options for the life of the labor contract, which runs until September 1984. But he also said that executives could begin to accumulate credits under a new ''performance achievement plan'' without limitation. This latest plan, which is in addition to the bonus and stock option plans, provides for as much as $60 million a year to be paid to the top 500 executives of the company, if certain long-term goals are met. No Bonuses in Last 2 Years **********The G.M. proxy statement said payments are expected to begin in 1985 if the automobile business improves. No bonuses have been paid for the last two years. **********Perhaps reacting to recent moves by white-collar workers at G.M. to seek union representation, Mr. Smith said, ''We are not planning any additional across-the-board layoffs of salaried employees.'' More than 27,000 salaried workers have been dismissed over the past three years, he said. Unlike the past, the recent layoffs have been based on performance evaluations, rather than seniority, and some dismissed workers have complained the company has been trying to trim costs by laying off older, higher-paid employees. **********Mr. Smith said the company's reduced costs and the ''huge pent-up demand for motor vehicles that has been building out there for several years'' would restore the company to something resembling its past profitability. Last year, G.M. reported a profit of $333 million. In 1979, it earned $2.89 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/09/busin.body_text: **********BACK when Manhattan-born Bill Giles, now vice president and group creative director at Grey Advertising, was an English major at Notre Dame, he remembers: ''They had all kinds of trees out there. A lot of snow and a lot of oaks.'' **********Which just goes to show the value of a liberal arts education.  It is true that Mr. Giles does not get to see a lot of trees these days, because his home is on Madison Avenue and he has not been jogging in Central Park lately because of what he calls ''the press of business in a recessionary time.'' **********But he still harbors fond thoughts about trees, and those thoughts have now borne fruit in a $3 million, four-month network television advertising campaign for the life insurance and health insurance industries. It will appear on evening news programs on the three major networks tonight. **********''The first thing we wanted the advertising to do is to be visible,'' he said this week. ''More than anything else, we had to make sure the advertising was out there grabbing people and making them stop and think.'' **********Doing some heavy thinking, two or three teams working within the 20-member Giles group came up with tree-type notions, and so did Mr.  Giles himself, who had been doing his own independent thinking. And so the campaign features on-screen depictions of a symbolic, sturdy, sheltering, good-for-all-seasons tree. **********''It's our tree,'' Mr. Giles said proudly to a visitor to a windowless conference room at Grey's Third Avenue headquarters. ''The tree idea literally took root,'' he went on. ''It seemed to stand for what the life insurance and health insurance people are.'' **********Sitting across the conference table from him was John P. Little, a vice president at one of the two industry organizations that are jointly underwriting the campaign. Mr. Little's group is the American Council of Life Insurance, which boasts 550 member companies and 97 percent of the assets of all United States life insurance companies. **********''The attributes of a tree,'' Mr. Little said, ''equate with the attributes of the life insurance industry.'' Similar views concerning the health insurance industry were voiced by James R.L. Holdsworth, an advertising expert with the other co-client, the Health Insurance Association of America, which says it has 325 member organizations responsible for 85 percent of total private health insurance premiums in the country, not counting Blue Cross/Blue Shield. **********Once the tree symbol was picked, a specific kind of tree had to be settled on. The sequoia was discussed, and then discarded as being a specifically West Coast tree - and an ill-proportioned one at that. **********In due course, it was decided to depict what Mr. Giles called a ''good old solid oak.'' ''There was no philosophical reason to go to an oak,'' he confessed; it simply came to the fore in their discussions as ''the classic tree.'' **********Oak, Mr. Holdsworth said, ''has a protective quality.'' ''Permanent protection,'' Mr. Giles observed.  Then came the question of whether to show film of a real oak or to use an animated oak - that is, to put it crassly, a cartoon. As Mr.  Giles told it, ''We thought we could make the tree more magical'' by animation than by going the real-oak route. **********And Mr. Little said that using an oak drawn by an animator - in this case, Richard Williams - offered more flexibility, notably in showing the tree growing before the viewer's eyes. **********''A real tree doesn't grow'' so that the viewer can see it growing, Mr. Little said. ''It just sort of sits there.'' And so the commercials have as their logo what Grey calls ''an animated tree of life and health.'' It is not any individual species of oak, but a sort of generic oak - what Mr. Little called ''a Giles oak.'' **********For his part, Mr. Giles said: ''We thought of having the tree talk, but it's hard to take a talking tree too seriously. The tone of the commercials had to be serious and direct.'' **********Accordingly, the first of the commercials has a human offstage voice intoning: ''The life and health of the nation are rooted in the life and health of its people'' and similar sentiments while the Giles oak is seen sprouting, growing and enduring in fair weather and foul. And a Grey brochure about the campaign shows the oak in full greenery, over a headline that reads, ''A Growing Commitment to America's Life and Health.'' **********Why make the oak green? ''The answer is realism,'' Mr. Little said. ''I don't see many red trees or purple trees out there.'' And Mr. Giles said: ''Green is healthy; life is green.'' As he spoke, he leaned across the conference table, made of a gleaming, richly grained wood.  Oak wood, right?  ''Mahogany,'' Mr. Giles suggested.  ''Rosewood,'' Mr. Holdsworth countered, and that settled that.  The client is always right.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/14/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that he had obtained President Hosni Mubarak's agreement for an intensified effort in coming months to achieve a breakthrough in the negotiations with Israel on Palestinian self-rule in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. **********In a 90-minute meeting at Mr. Mubarak's office in Oruba Palace, Mr. Haig was reported to have said that the United States believed Egypt and Israel had spent enough time over the last 20 months inconclusively discussing the issues and that he was ready to give his attention to helping them accelerate their efforts for an agreement. **********Kamal Hassan Ali, Egypt's Foreign Minister, told reporters later, ''Our view is that we welcome the participation of Secretary Haig in the process because we feel that it will push forward the negotiations for the autonomy.'' Haig to Meet With Begin **********Mr. Haig flies to Israel on Thursday to confer with Prime Minister Menachem Begin and Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir on their reaction to his plans for pushing the negotiations forward. Assuming that the Israelis agree, Mr. Haig must then decide whether to devote a considerable part of his time in the near future to Middle East negotiations or whether he will appoint a special negotiator to do most of the work, with Mr. Haig giving instructions from Washington. **********Mr. Haig told reporters that he had received ''the very firm and clear commitment of President Mubarak to intensify our efforts in the period ahead to achieve progress on autonomy and to work in concert for broadening the peace process with a view toward a lasting, just peace in the region.'' **********He said he hoped ''to achieve a greater momentum with the results of a breakthrough in the period ahead.'' Accord on Principles Sought **********The Israelis and Egyptians have been negotiating to draw up a broadly worded declaration of principles that would outline the duties and responsibilities of a so-called self-governing authority that would be elected by the Palestinians living in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. Both areas have been occupied by Israel since the 1967 war. **********Israel and Egypt have been in fundamental disagreement since the negotiations began in May 1979. The chief obstacle arises from differing interpretations of the self-governing authority itself. **********The Egyptians believe that this body should have about 120 members and should have administrative, legislative and judicial authority for running the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. The Israelis, concerned that this might lead to more independence than they are willing to concede, want the body about 15 members who would have only administrative responsibility. **********The Israelis are scheduled to complete their withdrawal from Sinai on April 25 and the Americans believe that in the three months before then there is an opportunity for more active negotiations. **********The Egyptians and Israelis also disagree on future security arrangements for the Palestinian are a, with the Egyptians wanting theIsraeli milit ary and police presence and duties to be very limited.  There is also a major difference over whether East Jerusalem should be included a s part of the West Bank and its Arab residents permittedto vote for t he ruling authority. **********The Egyptians contend that since East Jerusalem, like the West Bank, was controlled by Jordan before 1967, it should be treated in the same way as the rest of the West Bank. The Israelis, having annexed East Jerusalem, have refused to include it in the negotiations and have said that Arab residents should not be allowed to vote in the West Bank negotiations. **********Following Mr. Haig's meeting with Mr. Mubarak, American and Egyptian officials met to review in detail the Egyptian position on the issues so that Mr. Haig would have a clear idea of where Cairo stood. The Americans will do the same with the Israelis, officials accompanying Mr. Haig said. There is no intention on this trip, they said, to introduce any new American plan, although American suggestions for compromises have already been submitted. **********Both Mr. Haig and Egyptian officials said there was no intention to set a deadline or target date for concluding the negotiations, and Egyptian officials went out of their way to say they felt no particular sense of urgency. **********The United States would like to show progress in the autonomy negotiations to demonstrate to Saudi Arabia and Jordan that it takes seriously the possibility of carrying out the Camp David accords, despite Saudi and Jordanian skepticism. ---- Israeli Rules Out 'Concessions' **********JERUSALEM, Jan. 13 (Reuters) -Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today that Israel was not prepared to make any ''further concessions'' in negotiations on autonomy for Palestinians in the occupied areas. **********He also said at a meeting of Parliament's Foreign Affairs and Security Committee that as far as Israel was concerned the question of East Jerusalem was closed. In 1980, Israel declared that all Jerusalem, including the Arab eastern sector captured in the 1967 Middle East war, was its capital. **********Mr. Shamir rejected a suggestion by former Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of the opposition Labor Party that the Government allow Arab residents of East Jerusalem to vote in elections for an administrative council in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. **********''Such suggestions cannot influence the Government, but they do impair Israel's image abroad,'' the Foreign Minister said.  ''There is no room for further concessions,'' he declared. ''As far as we are concerned, the matter of East Jerusalem is closed, and we have advised Egypt and the United States to this effect.'' **********Mr. Shamir also told the committee that the security situation in southern Lebanon would be high on the agenda in talks with Mr Haig.  He said Israel would stress that the situation along its border with Lebanon was ''unbearable.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/18/busin.main_headline: STOCK TRADING LINK HAS SLOW START
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/18/busin.print_headline: STOCK TRADING LINK HAS SLOW START
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/18/busin.body_text: **********The experimental electronic link between the nation's stock exchanges and the over-the-counter market got off to a slow start yesterday. **********Specialists and brokers at the New York Stock Exchange said they spotted no drop in orders because of off-the-board trading facilitated by the new network that ties their paper-strewn trading floor to the upstairs offices of market-making firms. And, as often happens on the first day of a new procedure on Wall Street, mechanical problems arose, and the connection was broken a number of times. **********''It's a nonevent day as far as trading goes,'' said Pat Marchese, a floor broker for E.F. Hutton & Company. ''It had no effect on the volume of business.'' **********A Lack of Drama **********''It was not as dramatic as most people would think,'' said Hugh Quigley, managing director of the over-the-counter department of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc., a leader in the effort to stimulate off-the-board trading in listed stocks. ''We did not have as many transactions as we anticipated.'' **********The limited program links the computers of the New York and American stock exchanges and five smaller exchanges with the computers of hundreds of broker-dealers in the over-the-counter market. The tie allows the electronic pooling of price and size information on 30 stocks - the most active of a group of 200 that can be traded both over-the-counter and listed on exchanges. Twenty-three of those stocks are traded on the Big Board, which fought an unsuccessful battle against creating this linkage without rules restricting ''internalization'' - the matching of buy and sell orders in brokers' offices. **********Under the new system, a customer's order does not go to an exchange floor as was routine. Now it may first be filled within the customer's own brokerage house, or be exposed, simultaneously, to exchanges and other market makers for execution at the best price.  Only if the exchange shows the best price will the order be routed there and filled either by a specialist or through the outcry auction system. Praise for Trading Floor **********On the Big Board floor yesterday, prices declined sharply and volume was 45.6 million shares, down from the average daily volume for the first four months of this year of 52.4 million. There seemed to be little talk therefore about the new tie, and when asked about it, brokers insisted that the viability of their auction market, rather than the possibility of losing volume and revenue, was the major reason for their reluctance to embrace the experiment. **********''Certainly there's a degree of self-interest on the part of the specialists,'' said George H. Rose, floor partner of Lazard Freres & Company, about the opposition to the linkage. ''But there is concern about the public getting the best price.'' **********''I'm not the usual veteran who says that everything that's new is wrong,'' said George C. Dinsmore of Stokes, Hoyt & Company, a specialist firm. ''But I don't think you can play in a ballpark where one team has three strikes and one team has two. We don't mind another competitor, as long as the rules and regulations are the same.'' **********''If the market gets fragmented and order flow gets short-stopped, the structure of the market will be irreparably harmed,'' added Donald Stone, a partner of Lasker, Stone & Stern, another specialist concern, and vice chairman of the Big Board. ''This is a step backwards, not forwards, in building a national market system.'' **********Mr. Quigley of Merrill Lynch sees things differently.  ''This was an extraordinary market day, down sharply on light volume, and not many people were concerned with this event,'' he said. ''But as time goes by, and people begin to utilize this linkage, our penetration should increase. The linkage, to the extent that it was utilized, was effective.'' **********The New York Stock Exchange and the brokerage houses involved said they could not provide the total number of shares that traded through the new linkage yesterday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/26/busin.body_text: **********Common Market representatives held firm today on their refusal to consider phasing out agricultural export subsidies, one of the major demands of the United States at a world trade conference here. **********Barbed exchanges between American and European officials marked the second day of the conference, as delegates from 88 signatory nations to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade discussed proposals to check worldwide protectionism and halt trade wars. **********Although compromise formulas were being circulated, covering agriculture and other contentious issues, there were few signs of movement by any of the principals, conference sources said. A top American official, summing up prospects at a background briefing this evening, said the chances were only 50-50 that the conference, which may run through Saturday, would be a success. **********Added Peter Rees, Britain's Minister of Trade, ''The fog of war still covers the field.'' Failure Could Add Tension **********A conference failure could heighten world economic tensions by causing countries to flout international rules more than in the past and to turn more to nationalistic and protectionist policies. **********The United States has threatened to dump surplus grains and dairy products on world markets if the Europeans refuse to phase out their export subsidies, which American farmers say have depressed world farm prices and hurt their earnings. The Europeans pay $8 billion a year to subsidize their farm exports. **********Sir Roy Denman, the Common Market's chief trade negotiator, said that farm export subsidies were ''a fact of life'' and that the United States, too, had the right to subsidize exports. He said the only international rule governing such subsidies was that they may not lead to the acquisition of more than an fair share of the market. **********Other officials said that if the United States dumped its surplus farm products to punish the Common Market, countries outside the 10-nation bloc, such as Australia and New Zealand, would be hurt more than Common Market members. **********Added Robin W. Gray, Deputy Secretary in the British Department of Trade: ''Quite a lot of people in the world would get cheap food.'' An American official, who asked not to be identified, said the United States was considering selling surplus butter and grain at below-market prices to countries in the Middle East, Africa, Asia and even the Soviet Union. **********The United States is having trouble selling as much grain as it wants to the Russians. Under pressure from France, the European Economic Community has been negotiating a big cut-rate grain sale to the Russians. American sales of cheap food to the Soviet Union could touch off a major political row in Washington. One-Year World Supply of Butter **********Richard E. Lyng, Deputy Secretary of Agriculture and a member of the American delegation here, estimated current stocks of butter in the United States at 220,000 metric tons, a year's supply for the world. He put stocks of all types of grain after domestic consumption this year at 160 million tons. **********Many European officials here believe the United States will begin dumping surpluses in world markets, regardless of what occurs at this meeting. But the hard line against the American farm demand reflects other factors as well. **********For years, the United States has protested against the common agricultural policy, which many in Europe consider to be the cement of the Common Market. Agriculture is one of the few areas where the community is integrated. The United States protested because the common policy guaranteed high prices for farmers and provided for subsidized exports to reduce surpluses. **********Common Market officials believe that the fresh American demands against Common market subsidies are part of the long-range campaign of the United States to dismantle the common policy. This is why, they say, they have to stand firm. Support for the French **********France's Trade Minister, Michel Jobert, has been especially adamant, but at an unusual Common Market council meeting here tonight, all the ministers supported Mr. Jobert, according to community sources. The council meets again Friday to consider any fresh compromises. **********The American demand for a phasing-out of subsidies had been characterized earlier by American officials as ''the bottom line'' for any successful conference. An American official said tonight: ''Other important issues should be separable from agriculture,'' a statement that was seen by some analysts as the beginning of an American retreat on the issue. **********One American official suggested a compromise under which the conference would agree merely to study the agricultural issue, without any commitment to end subsidies. But, according to this official, in an agreement between the United States and the Common Market, the Europeans would pledge to accept certain disciplines over their subsidies. ''Willing to Discuss Troubles'' **********Asked about such a formula tonight, Mr. Denman, the Common Market negotiator who is also the Common Market's Ambassador to Washington, said: ''We're reasonable people and always willing to discuss other people's troubles.'' **********Little progress was cited elsewhere, although a hint from Brazil that it might consider a study of relaxing trade in services within the GATT framework aroused considerable interest. **********Developing countries, led by Brazil and India, have resisted such a study on grounds that any liberalization is precluded by their national development programs and their critical debt situation. **********The United States - joined by Canada, Japan and the European community - is pressing for a services study, hoping it would lead to negotiations to bring about more liberal trade in services by the end of the decade.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/10/busin.body_text: **********Businesses and factories across southern Connecticut are reporting millions of dollars in flood damage and lost sales after the heavy rains last weekend, a spot-check yesterday showed. **********The survey of businesses, chambers of commerce and state agencies indicated that three companies suffered losses of $5 million or more: the Mite Corporation, a metalworking plant in New Haven; Century Brass of Waterbury, that city's biggest employer, and Packaging Plus Ltd. in Milford. **********The Governor's office is expected to start computing total damage today, as state and Federal inspectors report their findings.  About 400 holders of national flood insurance have filed claims so far, and that number is expected to climb to a thousand, according to Brendon Bailey, a spokesman for the Federal Emergency Management Agency. The Federal Government has offered national flood insurance since the early 1970's; most private insurance agencies do not offer flood insurance. **********Packager Would Close Down **********Packaging Plus could go out of business because of $7 million in damages. ''Absolutely everthing in our business was ruined,'' said William Holodak, president of the promotional packaging company, whose annual revenues run less than $10 million. ''We are hoping the Federal Government will get involved with grants or loans,'' he added. ''If not, it is the end for us.'' The 55 employees have been laid off. **********Mayor Alberta Jagoe of Milford has estimated that the total business damage in the area came to about $9 million. ''All the downtown merchants have damages of $10,000 and up,'' said Frank Gormley, assistant to the Mayor. **********Others hurt by the flooding included most of the manufacturing plants along the Mad River in Waterbury, industrial plants bordering the West River in New Haven and a tire and rubber plant and warehouse, and a chocolate factory in Naugatuck. **********William Ryan, senior vice president of Mite, shouting over the background noise of pumping specialists and electrical engineers at work, said the damage would cost Mite about $2.5 million beyond its insurance coverage and $4 million to $7 million in lost sales. Mite had sales of $68 million in 1981. Mite to Close for 3 Months **********The Mite plant will remain shut for about three months and about 330 employees have been asked to take their vacations now or file for temporary unemployment, Mr. Ryan said. **********The Mite plant sits at the confluence of the West River and Wintergreen Creek, and when the rivers flooded on Saturday, not even a four-foot wall of sandbags around the plant could keep the water back. **********''The water pressure blew the sandbags 20 feet in the air and broke down walls and doors and windows,'' Mr. Ryan said. With eight feet of water covering - and destroying - computer and electrical equipment and inventory and personnel records, the company evacuated. **********''We finally had to leave because the river was rising even higher,'' he added. The river washed the eight cars in the parking lot downstream. ''I found mine stuck on a fence way down the river,'' Mr. Ryan said. Cave-Ins Near Waterbury **********Buildings sagged and caved in at Century Brass, where vacuum trucks were still pumping out water, said Frank Santaguida, vice president.  Fleisher Finishing and Multimetals Manufacturing were also damaged.  ''The Mad River sure lived up to its name,'' said Robert Zelinger, a vice president at the Chamber of Commerce. **********The Waterbury Buckle Company lost some of its land in the flooding, adding up to about $50,000 in damages, said Allan Frew, executive vice president. **********TRW Inc.'s Geometric Tool plant in New Haven faces ''easily $1 million in damages,'' said Thomas Vaccaro, the plant manager, who watched the plant basement and some outer buildings fill with water.  Most of the factory workers will be laid off temporarily, he said.  The flood destroyed precision cutting tools waiting to be shipped out, along with blueprints, production orders and electrical wiring. **********Mayor William Rado of Naugatuck said that the Uniroyal Inc.'s footwear warehouse ''is digging boots out of the water'' and that the Peter Paul Cadbury Company was pumping out its basement. **********As the plants bailed out and calculated their losses, electrical engineers and pumping specialists were doing a brisk business. ''You couldn't believe it,'' said Gene Nadeau, project manager at Northeast Testing, which dries and restructures transformers and switch gears.  ''We are working double shifts, but there are only so many of us.'' **********The Geometric Tool plant has been pressed by a number of eager flood specialists. ''We had a fellow pull up in front of the plant with a moving van; he wanted to sell us boots,'' Mr. Vaccaro said.  ''Eleven dollars a pair, so we bought some.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/22/world.main_headline: U.S. URGES P.L.O. NOT TO RETALIATE FOR ISRAELI RAIDS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/22/world.print_headline: U.S. URGES P.L.O. NOT TO RETALIATE FOR ISRAELI RAIDS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/22/world.body_text: **********The United States urged the Palestine Liberation Organization today not to retaliate against Israel for bombing raids in Lebanon. **********Administration officials said the message was sent to the P.L.O.  leadership through Saudi Arabia and other Arab nations in an attempt to prevent a breakdown in the nine-month-old, American-negotiated cease-fire. The United States has promised Israel that it would not deal directly with the P.L.O. **********Officials confirmed that President Reagan sent a letter of assurances to Prime Minister Menachem Begin on Tuesday in advance of Israel's final withdrawal from Sinai. **********In return for the pullout on Sunday, the letter said, the United States will maintain Israel's military superiority over the Arabs and will not deviate from the Camp David formula for peace. **********The Israeli radio called the Reagan letter ''the best document ever sent by an American President to Israel.'' The reports of the Israeli air strikes against P.L.O. positions in Lebanon were carefully monitored here. The Administration has been concerned for weeks that Israel might attack southern Lebanon in force before withdrawing from Sinai. **********The Administration was relieved, officials said, that the Israelis limited their action to aerial strikes and did not send troops across the border. **********But there was worry that P.L.O. retaliation, such as with heavy artillery attacks, might give Israel an excuse to carry out an invasion. **********Officials said the Administration decided to avoid saying anything in public about the air raids that might exacerbate the situation.  They said the Adminstration recognized that the situation in Israel was tense over the forced evacuation of 2,000 protesters from the Sinai settlement of Yamit, and that Israel felt the air attacks were justified by what it said were P.L.O. violations of the truce. **********The White House and State Department issued identical statements in which an effort was made to avoid laying blame for violations of the cease-fire while seeking ways to prevent them. **********''There have been a number of actions recently which have threatened or violated the cease-fire, including violence against Israelis and the Israeli air strikes into Lebanon,'' the statement said. **********It said the United States ''deplores these actions and remains committed to the maintenance of the cease-fire, which serves the interests of all the parties.'' **********''It calls upon all the parties involved to exercise the utmost restraint and to avoid actions which could prolong or escalate the violence,'' the statement said. ''The United States strongly urges all concerned to respect scrupulously the spirit as well as the terms of the cease-fire, which is of such importance to the stability and welfare of the peoples of the entire region.'' **********The cease-fire between Israel and the P.L.O. was negotiated last July by Philip C. Habib, the special Presidential envoy to the Middle East. He negotiated directly with Israel and through Saudi Arabia with the P.L.O. **********In recent weeks, American officials expressed apprehension that Israel was planning to invade Lebanon to wipe out P.L.O. bases. Mr.  Begin repeatedly said that Israel would not move into Lebanon unless there was a clear provocation. **********The letter from Mr. Reagan to Mr. Begin was not made public by the White House, but officials said the contents were consistent with previous statements by the Administration. **********They said it reaffirmed American commitments to Israel under the Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/11/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; WESTMINSTER BANK SELECTS NEW CHIEF
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/11/busin.body_text: **********The National Westminster Bank, Britain's second-largest commercial bank after Ba rclays and the owner of the National Bank of North America, anno unced yesterday that Philip Wilkinson, now one of two deputy group chief executives, will become its new group chief executive, ef fective January 1983. **********When he assumes his new position, Mr. Wilkinson plans to make few changes at National Westminster. **********''It requires more a touch of the tiller -that's more my style - than suddenly going about,'' he said.  ''The ship is going well at the moment.'' **********Like many of his colleagues, the 54-year-old executive bypassed college and began his association with National Westminster - a bank founded in Britain in 1658 - when he left secondary school at 15. His rise to the top of the management ladder was gradual, and some would say, methodical. **********Mr. Wilkinson saw his career take flight in 1972 when he was appointed director of the Orion Banking Group, then a subsidiary of National Westminster. **********Although the balance sheet for the six months ended June 1981 showed pretax profits of $364 million, the bank was burdened substantially by what Mr. Wilkinson referred to as ''a nasty shock'' - the surprise one-year-only ''windfall profits'' tax included in the Conservative Government's budget in 1981. Nevertheless, he is optimistic about Britain's economic future and said he believes that despite the ''still unfortunate level of unemployment,'' the worst of the recession is past. **********Accompanying Mr. Wilkinson on his upward journey through the management ranks of National Westminster were two younger executives. Denis Child was named deputy group executive and Thomas Frost was appointed general manager of the business development division.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/10/busin.main_headline: F.T.C. AIDES DENY BREAKING UP DEAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/10/busin.print_headline: F.T.C. AIDES DENY BREAKING UP DEAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/10/busin.body_text: **********Federal Trade Commission officials denied responsibility today for the Gulf Oil Corporation's decision to drop its bid to acquire the Cities Service Company. **********John Carley, general counsel for the F.T.C., said, ''We were ready, willing and able to negotiate on any aspect of the proposed merger with the objective of accommodating the needs of the parties consistent with our obligations under the law.'' **********Mr. Carley added, ''If the merger was as legal as they contended, they could have taken it to court, and within two weeks, probably had a determination.'' **********Gulf, in giving up its campaign Friday to acquire Cities Service for about $5 billion, cited the F.T.C.'s antitrust objections as the principal reason. On July 30, Gulf's board had said it would ''vigorously contest'' the F.T.C.'s decision to delay the merger and it made a new proposal to the agency last Tuesday. But the F.T.C.  turned down that proposal Wednesday and called for Gulf to divest a major refinery. **********An F.T.C. official, who asked not to be identified, said that Gulf's recent statements asserting that the agency had blocked the bid were possibly an attempt to fend off a breach of contract suit from Cities Service. Suit Against Gulf **********''Gulf has got to say we're the cause because there's probably a clause in the merger agreement that allows them to get off when there is government interference,'' the official said. He emphasized, however, that he had no actual knowledge that such a clause existed.  Earlier today, Cities Service, charging breach of contract, filed suit against Gulf, asking for $3 billion in damages. **********F.T.C. officials also stressed that their objections to Gulf's proposals that the merger would diminish competition in retail markets should not be seen as a shift in the agency's antitrust policies. ''There have been no formal changes whatsoever, certainly not since the recent merger guidelines came out,'' said Walter Vandaele, economic adviser to the director of the Bureau of Competition. ''We were surprised as other people were that Gulf pulled back. We were willing to negotiate any terms and said we would sit down at any time.'' **********The F.T.C. voted unanimously on July 29 to bar Gulf from proceeding with its plan, saying the effect of the action would be to limit competition in several areas of petroleum marketing. A hearing on a prelimimary injunction was scheduled in Federal District Court here on Aug. 16, at which time the court was to decide whether to allow the merger. **********The key issue apparently blocking the F.T.C.'s approval of the merger plan was the agency's insistence that either Cities Service sell its refinery in Lake Charles, La., or that Gulf divest itself of one of its refineries to lessen concentration in the gasoline market. The F.T.C. also was concerned that Gulf would gain a major stake in the Colonial Pipeline, a major conduit for petroleum products from the Gulf of Mexico to the New York area. **********''Gulf said that the sale or divestiture of a refinery was nonnegotiable,'' said an F.T.C. official. ''We responded that there was no issue that was not negotiable.'' **********In assessing why Gulf decided to drop its merger bid, most F.T.C.  officials said that they were surprised by the action. Officials said repeatedly that if Gulf felt strongly that the agency's position on the antitrust issue was wrong, the best forum for dealing with their differences would have been in court.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/04/busin.main_headline: COMPETITIVE EFFECT OF NEW BANK BILL
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/04/busin.print_headline: COMPETITIVE EFFECT OF NEW BANK BILL
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/04/busin.body_text: **********A price war between traditional rivals, thrift institutions and small commercial banks, could result from the landmark banking bill that won final Congressional approval in a voice vote in the House Friday night. **********The renewed competition could occur if a large number of savings and loan associations made use of the new commercial lending powers that the bill makes available to them, banking analysts say. **********The new law will allow the nation's approximately 5,000 thrift institutions - savings banks and savings and loan associations - to make commercial loans up to 10 percent of their total assets. They would be competing primarily against 14,000 small commercial banks. **********The benefactors are expected to be small businesses that, until now, have been totally dependent on their local banks for credit.  Now, with thrift institutions allowed to make business loans, borrowing options could increase for many small companies and prices could decline. **********''There is a lot of room to compete,'' said Allan G. Bortel, first vice president for research at Shearson/American Express in San Francisco. ''If small banks are charging their business borrowers one or two percentage points above prime, the thrifts could charge less and still make money.'' **********But many bankers fear that the result will be that both the thrift institutions and the banks will lose. Many analysts have been predicting that the nation already is overbanked and that, even before the latest measure, market forces would cause many banks to go out of business. Now, instead of 14,000 or so institutions lending to small, local companies, the number could rise to 18,000 or 19,000. **********''All of a sudden we have 4,000 new commercial banks on the scene,'' said Llewellyn Jenkins, president of the American Bankers Association and vice chairman of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company. Opposition From Banks **********For this reason, although most banks are pleased with the provision in the bill that allows them to offer higher rates to attract deposits back from money-market mutual funds, many are disturbed by the measure, calling it a ''sweetheart bill'' for the thrift institutions. **********''My judgment is that this is not such a great thing,'' Mr. Jenkins said. ''This is a way the thrifts might be able to help themselves in the long run, but they can't do it overnight. They could get into a lot of trouble.'' **********It remains unclear how many savings and loan associations will begin making business loans in the near future. Even some thrift executives are not sure. **********''I don't know if we will or not,'' said Thadis R. Seifert, executive vice president of the Southern Missouri Savings and Loan Association in Poplar Bluff, a $122 million-asset institution. **********Mr. Seifert said that, until about four years ago, Southern Missouri had been making commercial loans that were secured by real estate, which is allowed by Missouri law. But Federal regulators ''were too nit-picky'' about these loans, so Southern Missouri's board decided the business was not worth the effort. **********Others are more certain, however. ''More will take advantage of the new powers than many people expect,'' predicted Mr. Bortel of Shearson/ American Express. **********''Commercial checking and commercial lending will bring us low-cost funds and give us the ability to make loans even when high interest rates shut down the mortgage market,'' said Roy G. Green, president of the Fidelity Federal Savings and Loan Association in Jacksonville, Fla., who is also chairman of the United States League of Savings Association, the trade group of the savings and loan industry. **********Mr. Green predicted that Fidelity, which has assets of $280 million, would start slowly. ''We'll probably first buy loans'' from other financial institutions, Mr. Green said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/13/world.main_headline: SYRIANS FELT WAR WAS TOO PERILOUS, ENVOYS SAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/13/world.print_headline: SYRIANS FELT WAR WAS TOO PERILOUS, ENVOYS SAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/13/world.body_text: **********The most compelling reason behind Syria's decision on Friday to observe a cease-fire in Lebanon, according to Western diplomats, was President Hafez al-Assad's unwillingness to risk an Israeli attack on his country. **********The short but furious military confrontation with the Israelis in Lebanon caused Syria heavy losses in planes, antiaircraft missiles and tanks and men, according to Syrian communiques. **********The most damaging loss, Western diplomats reported, was the destruction by the Israelis of a radar command center that fired and guided Soviet-supplied SAM-6 antiaircraft missiles. **********According to the diplomats, the Israelis have apparently developed a new technology, possibly a special homing missile fired from long distance, that enabled their planes to knock out the command center, leaving the missiles blind and virtually useless. **********The loss of the command center, just inside the Syrian border, was a signal that other missiles sites protecting vital targets in Syria were vulnerable to similar attack, the diplomats said. **********The Syrian leaders did not want to invite attacks by continuing the war, the diplomats added. Disappointment With Moscow **********The Syrians were also hard pressed because of what was seen here as a bitterly disappointing Soviet reaction to the Israeli invasion. It is believed that Damascus expected the Soviet Union would quickly make up for the Syrian losses in planes and missiles. But the only new equipment arrived here early Friday - a few hours before the cease-fire - in only six transport planes, according to diplomatic sources. **********Unlike Japan, France and Britain, which publicly denounced the invasion of Lebanon and called for the immediate withdrawal of Israeli forces, Moscow issued only a relatively mild public statement through Tass, the official press agency. **********''The Japanese threatened to take sanctions against the Israelis.  No such threat was made by the Soviets,'' a Syrian said. ''We knew the Soviets would not use their whip against Israel in our defense but they could at least have waved it.'' Trip to Moscow Put Off **********President Assad had intended to travel to Moscow early this summer to obtain a firm commitment of support, but the trip was delayed at Soviet request, according to Syrians. The Soviet Ambassador here has been summoned at least three times, the first time on the day of the invasion, by Foreign Minister Abdel Halim Khaddam. **********For the Syrians, what was at stake throughout this week was the security of their country, much more than any desire to help the Palestinians or to protect Lebanese civilians, Western diplomats say. **********The vital national interests of the Syrians include a continuation of the country's military and political presence in Lebanon, a country that Syrian officials often describe as ''the lung through which Syria breathes.'' **********Secondly, the Syrians wanted to keep the Israeli Army away from the strategic Beirut-Damascus highway and out of the Bekaa Valley, a potential Israeli invasion route into Syria. **********Although Syrian officials deny it, there are indications that on the first days of the Israeli invasion the Syrians took at face value Israel's assurances that their only objective was to drive the Palestinians back so they could not reach Israel with shells and rockets. Syrians at First Shunned Combat **********The Syrians would not have endangered their own vital security interests to prevent the Israelis from achieving this. Syrian forces did not intervene in the first stage of the invasion, and most Western diplomats here believe that they would have stayed out of the fighting altogether if the Israelis had not attacked them. After the Israelis moved into Syrian-held areas, the Government here declared that the fighting had been ''imposed'' on it, an expression used by all Syrian spokesmen and since then. **********But even then, for at least two days, the fighting was like shadowboxing. Clashes were confined to artillery exchanges and demonstrative sorties by the air force. Only after the Israelis threatened the Bekaa Valley and the Beirut-Damascus highway - and the missile sites and access road to Syria - did the fighting became savage. **********On Wednesday,the Syrians committed more than 200 planes and lost about two dozen, according to their own reports. Reinforcements were rushed to the force in Lebanon. **********Still, throughout that fighting the Syrians seemed certain that the Israelis would not attack them through the Golan Heights from Israel. Once the missiles in the Bekaa Valley had proven so vulnerable, this assumption no longer seemed valid and the Syrians did not want to put it to the test, diplomats say. Syria Guards Its Own Interests **********The Syrians' emphasis on their own territorial security has been a long feature of Syrian policy toward Israel and the Palestinians.  Despite its hard-line position toward Israel, since the war of 1967 Syria has not permitted Palestinian guerrillas to operate against Israel from Syrian territory. **********Syrian-Palestinian relations in Lebanon have been swaying back and forth between close association and open military confrontation.  When the Palestinians challenged Syrian control over Lebanon during the 1975-76 civil war there, the Syrian Army turned on them. It drove the Palestinians from controlling positions east of Beirut - along the same highway that was at stake in this week's fighting -but permitted them to take up positions in the south of the country toward the Israeli border. **********But the diplomats also feel that by taking on the Israeli Army despite their troubled relations with the Palestinians, the Syrians have been able to enhance their role in the Arab world as the only Arab power able to challenge the Israelis militarily.

Marcos in the United States. **********The family of Tommy Manotoc said it had received a ransom note purportedly written by Mr. Manotoc, a 32-year-old basketball coach who won the Philippines amateur golf championship four times, who was last seen dining with Maria Imelda Marcos, 26, last Tuesday. **********They told reporters he had eloped with Miss Marcos in the United States last month after divorcing his wife, a former beauty queen. However, the official Philippines News Agency said Mr. Manotoc was still married to th e former Aurora Pijuan. The family also said they understood that t he marriage was opposed by President Marcos. https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/01/world.main_headline: RELIEF OFFICIALS VISIT POLAND TO CHECK DISTRIBUTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/01/world.print_headline: RELIEF OFFICIALS VISIT POLAND TO CHECK DISTRIBUTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/01/world.body_text: **********American relief agencies, concerned over th e effect of martial law on the distribution of their aid in Poland, h ave begun sending representatives there to insure that the supp lies are reaching the people for whom they are intended. **********Stanley Mitten, executive director of Church World Service, the overseas aid division of the National Council of Churches, began a visit to Poland last Saturday. Officials of the agency are awaiting a report on his visit before deciding whether to resume aid shipments, which were suspended shortly after the crackdown by the Polish Government. **********The executive director of CARE, Dr. Philip Johnston, is scheduled to leave for Poland tomorrow. The organization had just completed one round of distributions when martial law was declared Dec. 13. **********''What we desire now,'' Dr. Johnston said yesterday, ''is confirmation that the two primary concerns of CARE are going to continue to be met by the Polish Government - unhindered access to the beneficiaries, and assisted access, free travel through Poland for our people.'' Food Aid Is Planned **********''We are going to have difficulty retaining credibility with our donors,'' he added, ''unless we can assure them in good faith that we can guarantee the delivery of their CARE packages directly into the hands of the beneficiaries.'' **********If an acceptable arrangement can be found, CARE is planning to send 50,000 food packages to Poland each month for the next 10 months.  A spokesman for CARE said that the United States Government, which cut off its own aid shipments to Poland after the crackdown, had allocated 65 million pounds of grain and vegetables from the Food for Peace program for distribution by CARE. The spokesm an, Alex Klein, said that there had been ''no indications'' that the Polish Government was interfering with aid shipments. '' But these things are subject to interpretation,'' he said, ''and w e want to be sure that the present Government, face-toface, understands and agrees with the policies that have been followed so f ar.'' CARE Expects No Difficulty **********Dr. Johnston said he assumed ''there's going to be absolutely no difficulty,'' but wanted to be sure.  Mr. Mitten, the executive director of Church World Services, has been visiting Poland with representatives of Danchurchaid, the aid organization of the Danish Ecumenical Council. Church World Services distributes medicines, hospital equipment, blankets, heavy winter clothing and some food through the Polish Ecumenical Council. . **********Late yesterday officials in New York had not heard from Mr. Mitten, who was believed to be in Copenhagen.  Larry Hollon, an aide, said the purpose of Mr. Mitten's visit was threefold: to study the ''logistics'' of the situation, to talk to Polish church officials to ''determine what they see the needs to be,'' and to ''simply express the continuing support and solidarity and to tell them that we continue to be concerned about the needs there.'' **********Catholic Relief Services, which distributes food staples and clothing through churches in Poland, increased shipments last July and has been continuing them despite the crackdown. Bishop Edwin B.  Broderick, the agency's director, said distribution was closely monitored through a system that required signed receipts from recipients.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/20/world.body_text: **********Military authorities today annnounced the arrest of 51 leftists and said that about 7,660 suspected terrorists were at large, some in self-exile in Europe. **********The 51 reported seized in raids throughout Ankara were members of the underground Revolutionary Path and Revolutionary Left organizations, which were blamed by the Government for most of the left-wing violence that occurred before the military coup in September 1980. **********Security agents confiscated 14 handguns when they made the arrests, a statement said. https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/17/world.main_headline: ISRAELI FOCUS IS ON PILOT HELD BY P.L.O.
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/17/world.print_headline: ISRAELI FOCUS IS ON PILOT HELD BY P.L.O.
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/17/world.body_text: **********While the names Begin, Sharon, Habib and Arafat have been constantly on the lips and minds of Israelis during the war in Lebanon, attention has now begun to focus on a new name: Aharon Ahiaz. **********Mr. Ahiaz, an air force pilot who was shot down over southern Lebanon on June 6, the first day of the invasion, is the only Israeli prisoner being held in west Beirut by the Palestine Liberation Organization. Israeli officials say his unconditional release is the last major demand that must be met before Israel agrees to the Palestinian evacuation. **********Israel also demands the return of the bodies of nine soldiers killed in Lebanon, but the freedom of Mr. Ahiaz is of prime concern.  His captivity has provoked sporadic controversy because of attempts by two prominent Israelis to visit him. **********Israeli officials say the talks on a Palestinian withdrawal do not involve the release of two pilots shot down during the war and being held by the Syrians. That, the officials say, would be an Israeli demand in future talks on the withdrawal of Syrian and Israeli forces from Lebanon. Israeli military officials say that they are holding 7,400 Palestinian guerrillas captured during the war, but that the disposition of these prisoners will not be determined until after the evacuation of west Beirut. Israeli Pilot Sent Two Letters **********Little is publicly known about the captured pilot. The military spokesman here would say only that Mr. Ahiaz was born in 1946, has a wife and two children and flew a Skyhawk fighter-bomber. The spokesman declined to disclose the pilot's rank or say whether he was a regular or reserve officer. **********But his wife, Yael, and his father-in-law, Aharon Sakharov, discussed the pilot's situation briefly today by telephone from their homes in Herzliya. **********''I don't think anything right now,'' said Mrs. Ahiaz, with apparent nervousness in her voice. ''Let him first come home.'' Her father, Mr. Sakharov, who is in the banking and insurance business, said Mrs. Ahiaz was ''managing just like any other mother in Israel while her husband is in the army.'' He said the older child, Ari, 3 years old, ''understands more or less'' about his father's captivity. The other child, Itai, is one year old. **********Mr. Sakharov said the family had received two letters from the prisoner through the Red Cross, but he declined to disclose the contents. He also said he doubted that the Red Cross had been able to deliver one of the packages the family had sent the pilot two weeks ago, although a package sent about a month ago did apparently reach him. Photographed and Interviewed **********Since he was captured, the pilot has been seen twice in photographs that were distributed by United Press International. In an interview with U.P.I. on June 28, he said that he was being well cared for and that the Palestinians had saved his life, which had been threatened by farmers when he landed by parachute after his plane was hit. The pilot, who was accompanied to the interview by two guards, was quoted as having said that he hoped the Israelis would not invade west Beirut. **********The only Israeli to visit the prisoner was Uri Avneri, a leftist former member of Parliament. After a visit July 3, he said Mr. Ahiaz was in relatively good spirits and had not been seriously injured when he was shot down. **********An attempted visit by Abie Nathan, the self-styled peace advocate, aroused controversy in Israel. Mr. Nathan said he met with P.L.O.  officials in west Beirut on July 7 and asked for the release of Mr.  Ahiaz. The Palestinians refused, he reported, but said that Mrs.  Ahiaz and her children would be permitted a visit. Mrs. Ahiaz declined the offer. The Minister of Tourism, Avraham Sharir, has urged Attorney General Yitzhak Zamir to take measures to prevent Israelis from visiting P.L.O. officials in time of war.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/19/busin.body_text: **********To the Business Editor: William Winpisinger seems to hold the view that worker health and safety can only be measured in terms of inspections, citations and fines, and that employers must be bullied by big government into providing decent workplaces for their employees. **********We reject that notion. We don't believe that the Occupational Safety and Health Administration should be a police agency sending enforcement officers to every worksite in this great land regardless of the health and safety records of individual employers. That isn't necessary and, for an agency with positions for 1,200 inspectors covering three million worksites, it isn't possible. **********We must be discriminating in the allocation of our resources. That is why in fiscal year 1982 we doubled inspections at the most hazardous worksites and have excused many employers with established safety and health records from scheduled inspections, although we still respond to complaints and investigate accidents. **********We certainly have not exempted 75 percent of all manufacturing firms from OSHA inspections, as Mr. Winpisinger charged, however.  We have pioneered a self-inspection program. We also encourage firms with strong safety and health programs to participate in our voluntary protection program. Some of these firms have never experienced a lost workday incident. **********Mr. Winpisinger said we have renamed our inspectors ''safety and health consultants.'' They are encouraged to provide that service when asked, but we call them compliance officers because we expect employers to comply with health and safety regulations. Most are very willing to do so, not only because most care about their employees as human beings but because injuries and illnesses, with workers' compensation, lawsuits and downtime, cost a lost of money. **********We don't measure success in terms of how many dollars in fines we collect. We count injuries and illnesses. The rate of job-related injuries and illnesses declined in 1981, and we expect continued improvement.  THORNE G. AUCHTER Assistant Secretary Occupational Safety and Health Administration Washington, D.C., Dec.13,1982  ---------------------------------------------------------------------  The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters for publication should include the writer's name, address and telephone number.  Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Business Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or return unpublished letters.
