https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/01/world.main_headline: ISRAELI LOOTED ARCHIVES OF P.L.O. OFFICIALS SAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/01/world.print_headline: ISRAELI LOOTED ARCHIVES OF P.L.O. OFFICIALS SAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/01/world.body_text: **********Before they withdrew from West Beirut this week, Israeli troops looted the research center of the Palestine Liberation Organization, its director said today. Several Israeli soldiers also reportedly broke into the offices of the Institute for Palestine Studies, a private establishment, but removed only a few items. **********Dr. Sabry Jiryes, director of the P.L.O. research center, said the troops took away its entire library of 25,000 volumes in Arabic, English and Hebrew, a printing press, microfilms, manuscripts and archives. He said they smashed filing cabinets, desks and other furniture and made off with telephones, heating equipment and electric fans. **********He also said they spent a week in the seven-story building, which is in a residential quarter of the mainly Moslem West Beirut, and left the place ''a mess.'' **********''More seriously,'' he added, ''they have plundered our Palestinian cultural heritage.'' Rubber Stamps Stolen **********Reporting on the break-in at the Institute for Palestine Studies, officials of that organization said several Israeli soldiers entered last week, looked around and took rubber stamps and a few publications but did not loot the place. **********The institute, a nonprofit research organization, was founded in 1963 by intellectuals from a number of Arab countries. It is run by a board of 40 trustees from Lebanon, Syria, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Iraq, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates. **********According to Dr. Jiryes, the documents taken by the Israelis from the P.L.O. research center had been collected since it was established in 1965. **********The building is littered with broken furniture and fixtures, twisted metal shelves and a blown-up strong box. ''They used explosives to pry the safe open,'' Dr. Jiryes said. **********He estimated the material losses at $1.5 million. ''But the papers we have lost are invaluable and possibly irreplaceable,'' he said.  According to the center's brochures, these were the world's largest collections of manuscripts on the question of Palestine. P.L.O. Sign Was Altered **********The Israeli troops' positions in West Beirut have been taken over by a force comprising United States Marines, French paratroopers and Italian soldiers, as well as units of the regular Lebanese Army. The area where the center is situated was patrolled today by French forces. **********The Israelis had also occupied the P.L.O.'s main office on the Corniche Mazraa, at the southernmost edge of downtown West Beirut.  Before they left, they removed the word ''Palestine'' from a sign carrying the P.L.O.'s name that was mounted outside the office. **********A Palestinian source asserted that the Israeli invasion was intended ''to obliterate all memory of Palestine, the country we have left behind.'' **********Several thousand Palestinians came to Lebanon as refugees in 1948 after the state of Israel was founded in Palestine. Their number in Lebanon eventually grew to about half a million. **********Beirut became not only an operation base for the P.L.O. fighters but also a place where the Palestinians tried to revive their cultural heritage. In addition, it became a center for diffusing Palestinian informaton and collecting archives on the Palestinian problem. Institute Has Reopened **********The Institute for Palestine Studies, where such archives are kept, had been closed since the Israelis entered West Beirut on Sept. 14, but it reopened Wednesday. **********A Syrian, Dr. Constantine K. Zurayk, a professor emeritus at the American University of Beirut, is chairman of the board at the institute. A Palestinian, Dr. Walid Khalidi, currently a visiting professor at Harvard University, is secretary. **********Aside from its documentation of events bearing on the Palestine question, the institute publishes the Journal of Palestine Studies, a quarterly magazine, in English and French. Its publications are done in cooperation with the University of Kuwait. **********Kuwait, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates are among the main providers of funds for the organziation. Obscenities in Hebrew **********At the P.L.O. research center, Dr. Jiryes said he and his eightmember staff were working to reopen it as well. The center was established with the approval of the Lebanese Government and, like the P.L.O. office, it has diplomatic immunity.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/05/world.body_text: **********President Reagan has been invited to address the West German Parliament when he visits Bonn in June, Government officials said today. If Mr. Reagan accepts, he would be the first American President to speak in the West German legislature. **********Officials said Richard Stucklen, president of the lower house, had asked the West German Ambassador in Washington to invite Mr. Reagan to speak June 9, the day before Mr. Reagan attends a meeting of NATO leaders in Bonn. **********The news followed a report in the Welt am Sonntag newspaper that Mr. Reagan had been invited and was eager to accept the invitation.  The newspaper said President Reagan's speech would probably concentrate on American-West German relations and the NATO plan to deploy new missiles in Western Europe. **********In another development, former Chancellor Willy Brandt criticized the ''nonsense and confusion'' of the Reagan Administration and said West Germany should not ''run around like a frightened rabbit'' trying to please the United States, the magazine Der Speigel reported today.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/03/world.print_headline: BRITISH REPORTING FURTHER ADVANCES ON ARGENTINE BASE; Mrs. Thatcher's remarks, page A14.
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/03/world.body_text: **********After further advances, British forces are within sight of Stanley and now hold all the important high ground around the low-lying capital of the Falkland Islands, military sources here and correspondents on the scene said today. **********In keeping with the growing sense that an assault is both inevitable and imminent, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said this afternoon that ''I don't think there is anything more I can do'' to achieve a peaceful settlement with Argentina. But she said further hostilities could still be avoided if Argentine forces were withdrawn. **********''Everything, but just everything, has been turned down'' by the Argentines, she said in a television interview. Asked if the battle for Stanley could be avoided, she said, ''There is just a possibility now, but I don't rate it very highly.'' **********Reinforcements Brought In **********Tonight, Mrs. Thatcher told reporters: ''We shall repossess those islands. There will be, I am afraid, a very considerable battle at Port Stanley, very considerable.'' **********Reinforcements and supplies, including more Harrier jets, are being brought in by land, sea and air for a final push. With British forces just seven miles from the center of Stanley, artillery ferried into place on sites above the capital by helicopter has begun pounding Argentine positions. **********''We have got very close in and we are beginning to apply pressure to the main enemy positions throughout Stanley,'' Maj. Gen. Jeremy Moore, the ground commander, said in a British Broadcasting Corporation radio interview today. ''Clearly, I'm going to build up that pressure.'' Among the close-in positions captured by the British was Two Sisters Ridge overlooking Moody Brook Camp, the former base of British marines stationed on the islands. 7,000 Argentines in Stanley **********Military sources here said today that the Argentine strength in Stanley was officially estimated at 7,000 men, 2,000 of whom were believed to be airmen and sailors whose land fighting ability was questionable. **********The British forces, the sources said, are equal in size or larger.  This means that the 3,000 men of the Fifth Brigade, shipped to the South Atlantic aboard the liner Queen Elizabeth 2, have almost certainly joined the 5,000 troops who landed around Port San Carlos 12 days ago. **********The rapid advance toward Stanley -partly on foot and partly by helicopter - and the softening up of the Argentine defenders were vividly described today in dispatches from the battlefront.  Correspondents told of troops slogging 40 miles through marshes and rivers and up hills while carrying equipment, of sporadic but intense clashes with Argentine outposts and patrols, and of helicopters crossing East Falkland Island to the forward positions within 50 feet of the ground to avoid attack. **********''Men travel in fighting order, their packs coming up later in the rear,'' reported Robert McGowan of The Daily Express in a pooled dispatch. ''Spending freezing hours in the open, in falling snow, without cover or sleeping bags, has become almost routine in the headlong drive to the capital.'' **********British military sources cautioned today that several pockets of Argentine troops were clustered around Stanley and that the British forces might choose to take them on one at a time. They said it would be up to the commanding officers to decide whether to allow all or part of the Argentine garrison an opportunity to surrender before an attack. Reagan Phone Call Reported **********On the diplomatic front, President Reagan was reported to have telephoned Mrs. Thatcher to urge a postponement of a final assault ''while the victory at Goose Green sinks in,'' and Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. was said to have been lobbying Foreign Secretary Francis Pym. But British officials said operational plans were now in the hands of commanders with the troops. **********''I am not seeking to humiliate anyone at all,'' Mrs. Thatcher said in her the television interview. ''I am just asking that the invader returns his troops to the mainland.'' She said the attack could be avoided only if Argentina agreed to begin withdrawing now and completed the pullout in 10 to 14 days. **********The questioner noted that Mrs. Thatcher had been urged by Mr. Haig to be ''magnanimous'' in victory, and asked: ''What does 'magnanimous' mean to you?'' She replied, ''It is not a word that I use in connection with the Falklands.'' To ''hand something'' to the Argentines, ''to an invader, and an aggressor, and a military dictator, that would not be magnanimity,'' she said. ''It would be treachery or betrayal of our own people.'' **********Meanwhile, the Ministry of Defense said today that two more Harriers were lost in raids on the Stanley area ''in the last few days.'' The planes, damaged by ground fire, were forced to ditch on their return to the task force at sea and the pilots were recovered safely, a spokesman said. **********The ministry reported that additional Harriers had been flown directly from Britain to the Falklands, using inflight refueling, but did not say how many. The 17-hour, 8,000-mile journey set a record for the Royal Air Force. Harriers are now known to be operating from land positions on the islands, which means that an almost unlimited number could be accommodated in the South Atlantic. **********The ministry also said today that ''an accident involving explosives yesterday at Goose Green has caused some casualties among our troops'' and among the Argentine prisoners there. Reports from the scene suggested that an ammunition supply had blown up, killing several Argentines. One report suggested that the ammunition had been booby-trapped by the Argentines, but another said the ammunition was defective.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/14/busin.main_headline: TIMEX SETS ENTRY INTO GROWING FIELD OF HEALTH PRODUCTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/14/busin.print_headline: TIMEX SETS ENTRY INTO GROWING FIELD OF HEALTH PRODUCTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/14/busin.body_text: **********The Timex Corporation, the world's largest watchmaker, yesterday announced its entry into the expanding home health-care field with a line of health monitoring instruments that it will sell through drugstores. **********The company said it would start marketing the first products - a blood-pressure monitor, a thermometer and a bathroom scale - in California drugstores in October and would move to national distribution by April 1983. The products all use digital electronics developed earlier for Timex clocks and watches. **********''We are very comfortable with this product line because it is an extension of our work with electronics and sensors,'' said Norman Zatsky, chief scientist at Timex, which is based in Waterbury, Conn. **********The move is the private company's second major attempt this year to branch into fast-growing markets in high technology. Three months ago, Timex announced its plan to produce a personal computer for about $100, the least expensive microcomputer so far. Drugstore Distribution Network **********In entering the competitive high-technology market, Timex's strategy has been to hold back until it can mass-produce the products cheaply. It then distributes a low-priced item through the many discount outlets and drugstores that sell its inexpensive watches.  ''Existing drugstore distribution is a key to our business strategy,'' said Bruce Dodson, director of operations for Timex's new Medical Products Corporation. **********But this time, analysts are questioning whether Timex will be able to parlay its household name and distribution channels into a lucrative business. ''What works in watches does not carry over to health care,'' observed David Talbot, a health-care industry analyst for Drexel Burnham Lambert. Just because Timex sells watches in drugstores ''does not mean that they have any leverage with pharmacists,'' he added. **********The products, although competitive, are not the cheapest on the market, Mr. Zatsky said. The blood pressure monitor will sell for about $70, the scale for $50 and the thermometer, which takes a reading in 10 seconds, for $25. **********Most home health-care equipment is sold through dealers who work directly with hospitals. For example, the American Hospital Supply Corporation, a leader in home health care, markets through one of the largest dealer chains, Abbey Medical, which it recently acquired. 'Health-Conscious Environment' **********But Timex said that, for now, it plans to use only drugstores. The company will open its sales campaign in more than 4,000 California drugstores because the state ''is a more health-conscious environment,'' Mr. Dodson said. **********In the home health-care industry, a $2 billion business that is growing at a rate of more than 20 percent annually, the biggest selling items are respiratory and renal dialysis machines, analysts said. Timex declined to say what other home health-care products it intended to manufacture, but the next round of items it plans to announce by year's end ''will be more serious health products,'' Mr.  Dodson said. **********Timex, which does not make public any financial information, is reported to have annual sales of more than $400 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/28/world.main_headline: U.S. AND INDONESIA, LONG CLOSE, DRIFT APART ON SEVERAL ISSUES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/28/world.print_headline: U.S. AND INDONESIA, LONG CLOSE, DRIFT APART ON SEVERAL ISSUES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/28/world.body_text: **********A modest protest recently at the United States Embassy in Jakarta by a group of Moslem youths protesting American support for Israel was just one example of the tensions between Indonesia and the United States. **********Disagreements on China and the world economy are also straining a relationship that has remained friendly since General Suharto came to power in the mid-1960's. **********Indonesians believe that the tensions are the fault of the United States. Although relations have grown closer in recent years, it is the complaints of the Indonesian Government that are being voiced most clearly. **********Diplomatically, relations have improved in one respect since last spring, when Morton Abramowitz was rejected by Indonesia as the United States Ambassador. **********Having taken the extraordinary step of rejecting Mr. Abramowitz - and been accused of doing so because he is Jewish and outspoken as well - the Indonesian Government is now said to be prepared to take anyone offered. Suharto to Visit U.S. in October **********President Suharto is expected to be warmly received when he visits Washington next October, his first such trip since 1975. Moreover, a recent visit to Washington by the Indonesian Minister of Research and Technology, Bachruddin Jusuf Habibie, who has been seeking advanced American weapons, reportedly went well. **********While Jakarta has been seeking more weapons and while it believes that the United States is right to want to match the Soviet Navy's buildup in the Pacific, some Indonesians are worried about the focus on military matters. **********''The Reagan Administration is so military,'' said Jusuf Wanandi, director of Jakarta's Center for Strategic and International Studies. Dr. Wanandi, who is highly regarded by diplomats for his knowledge of government and military thinking, said the American military focus was out of step with Indonesia's top priority, the economy. Need for Economic Aid Stressed **********''The countries around here think of their main threat as domestic,'' he said.  He said Indonesia needed economic help more than ever because world prices for its oil, tin, rubber and other exports have been so depressed that the country's reserves and development plans are swiftly being cut back. **********Yet the United States, he said, has withdrawn support for international commodity agreements that might have kept prices higher, has lost interest in aiding international lending institutions and has declined to sign the Law of the Sea Treaty. **********''It is boggling our mind,'' Dr. Wanandi said. ''Economic help is more important for our stability than a few more tanks.'' Reflecting Indonesian ambivalence about the rearming of Japan, which occupied Indonesia in World War II, Dr, Wanandi asked where it might end if the United States kept urging Japan to bear more of a military burden in Asia. Concern About Japan Voiced **********''What, really, do you want the Japanese to do?'' he said. ''If they really decide to arm, if they set their minds to it, if they can work out some consensus in the next five years, they could become a nuclear power. They can do anything they want, you know.'' **********American policy toward China causes further grumbling, an attitude that in the military's case goes back to 1965, when Peking was accused of encouraging the Indonesian Communist Party, which was powerful at the time, to stage a coup. The party was later liquidated. **********Foreign Minister Mochtar Kusum@aatmadja said in a recent interview: ''I wish that the United States more actively supported our position, especially on the Cambodian question, rather than the Chinese position.'' **********He was alluding to China's emphasis on opposing the Vietnamese militarily and making their occupation of Cambodia as expensive as possible. Indonesia For Aid to Vietnam **********Though a member of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, an anti-Communist grouping, Indonesia favors economic aid for Vietnam and feels that its fear of China is well founded. **********On June 10, the Deputy Secretary of State, Walter J. Stoessel Jr., told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee that United States relations with China ''are seen by our Asian friends as a positive influence on the future direction of China's foreign policy and a stimulus to regional cooperation.'' **********When asked about that testimony, Dr. Wanandi said, ''One of the confusing things is what your China policy is.'' Indonesia, which broke diplomatic relations with China in 1967, but has revived trade relations since then, has its own problems with its China policy. **********In an interview with Newsweek last month, the Foreign Minister said China was the most dangerous influence in Southeast Asia. Two weeks ago, the Minister of Information, Lieut. Gen. Ali Murtopo, said in a seminar that the greatest threat in Southeast Asia was the Soviet Union. **********The Foreign Minister later explained that perhaps he had been thinking of the past, and his colleague of the future. But what struck some Indonesians as most significant about the mix-up was its possible relevance to Indonesia's stance in the East-West alignment. **********''According to us,'' said the newspaper Merdeka, ''to cry anti-Soviet and anti-People's Republic of China and, at the same time, to sing the United States' song will lead the people to interpret our foreign policy wrongly.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/11/busin.body_text: **********Thomson Newspapers Ltd., citing troubles at its flagship newspaper, The Globe and Mail of Toronto, today reported a 2.8 percent drop in second-quarter earnings. **********The newspaper group also announced the acquisition of two more dailies in the United States, The Daily Mining Gazette in Houghton, Mich., and The Griffin (Ga.) **********Daily News, raising its total holdings to 139 daily and weekly newspapers in Canada and the United States. **********Thomson said it earned $24.3 million (Canadian), or 49 cents a share, in the quarter ended June 30, compared with a profit of $25 million, or 50 cents a share, in the same period of 1981. Revenues rose 5.5 percent, to $172.8 million from $163.8 million. The Canadian dollar is worth about 78 cents in American currency.

**********House and Senate conferees on the $98.9 billion tax bill said tonight that they were deadlocked over proposals to cut welfare spending. **********''We have reached a temporary impasse,'' said Senator Bob Dole, the Kansas Republican who is chairman of the conference committee. ''If we are not going to make spending cuts, we won't raise taxes. I don't plan to deliver the revenue side until the spending cuts are in place.'' **********Representative Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois and chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, responded that the two sides were very close to agreement on spending cuts. But he also noted that the prospect of making the kinds of cuts the Senate seemed to be looking for would be ''very painful for the House.'' **********The tax bill calls for spending cuts of $17 billion besides new tax revenues totaling $98.9 billion in the next three fiscal years. Earnings Limitation at Issue **********Four provisions that appear to have caused the present logjam involve the earnings an individual could have and still be eligible for aid to families with dependent children. All four provisions were proposed by the Ways and Means Committee and would cost the Government an estimated $325 million over three years, according to figures before the conference committee. **********The conferees from the House also had indicated their willingness to accept a compromise that would cost only $246 million.  But Senator Russell B. Long, Democrat of Louisiana, charged that these provisions would really cost three times as much as the estimates said, or roughly $1 billion, and would allow people to make as much as $12,000 to $18,000 and still receive welfare. ''The whole purpose of this conference is to deal with welfare and to get the genie back inside the bottle,'' Senator Long said. **********Earlier in the day the committee had moved ahead on a host of provisions that would pare Medicare costs to the Federal Government. Conable Seeks Compromise **********The committee, however, continued to postpone action on the most controversial aspects of the bill, including those that would raise taxes on business. But Representative Barber B. Conable Jr., the upstate New York Republican who is the ranking minority member of the House Ways and Means Committee, started trying to fashion a new compromise on proposals to limit tax advantages in leasing. **********Separately, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said at a news conference that the Administration would ''go all out to make sure'' that the bill passes. A key strategy being used by the Administration is to give the impression that the bill deals primarily with closing existing tax loopholes and not with enacting new taxes. **********Meeting off and on through the afternoon, the committee agreed on nearly a dozen proposals that would reduce the cost of Medicare to the Government by $8.6 billion over three years. Medicare Steps Agreed Upon **********The committee did agree to back off from two provisions that would have raised costs directly to Medicare beneficiaries. One would have increased certain deductibles, and the other would have required copayments by patients for home health care services. **********Another area of agreement today would require employers to offer older employees - age 65 to 69 - the same health benefits given to younger employees, and these would take precedence over Medicare.  The measure is expected to save the Government $1.1 billion over three years, but it would apply only to companies with more than 20 employees. **********The committee did not take up major business provisions, including reductions in accelerated depreciation and in safe harbor leasing.  But Representative Conable began floating a new proposal on leasing that would penalize leveraged leases to retain benefits for some safe harbor leases. Sales of Tax Credits Allowed **********Safe harbor leasing permits companies to sell to other companies tax credits they cannot use themselves. This became possible under last year's tax act. Certain kinds of leases, known as leveraged leases, had been permitted even before that. **********Tax experts said the Conable proposal would appear to create problems for some major companies, including the Xerox Corporation.  A staff member for the minority counsel's office of the House Ways and Means Committee said the proposal, which would raise the same $8 billion in tax revenues as the Senate proposal on safe-harbor leasing, had been distributed to conference members. **********''The Senate bill would virtually wipe out safe-harbor leasing,'' the staff member said. ''Our proposal would take a little out of safe-harbor leasing and a little out of leverage leasing. We have received overwhelmingly favorable reaction from the companies that are involved in safe-harbor leasing, including airlines, steel companies, paper companies and builders of oil refineries.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/20/world.body_text: **********Western Europe reacted quietly but with an evident sense of relief today to the news that the Israeli Cabinet had agreed to the plan, negotiated by the United States, for the withdrawal of the Palestine Liberation Organization from Beirut. **********There were no official comments from senior Western European leaders, many of whom are on vacation. But officials of several foreign ministries said they welcomed the prospect that the plan, worked out by the special American envoy, Philip C. Habib, would restore a measure of peace to the area. **********In London, a ranking official paid tribute to what he described as Mr. Habib's ''almost unbelieveable perseverance,'' and expressed the hope that nothing would happen to upset the agreement. But he voiced doubts that it would lead to a long-term settlement of the Palestinian problem ''because of the continued intransigence of the Israelis.'' **********Much will depend, specialists here and in other Western European capitals said, upon the way in which P.L.O. attitudes evolve.  Almost no support for Israel has been expressed in Western Europe in recent weeks, even by those normally sympathetic to its problems. A 'Terrible Moral' Price **********A diplomat in Madrid said this month that, in his view, Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel had ''paid a terrible moral and political price for what will prove to be ephemeral gains'' - a view that appeared to be quite widespread. **********Reaction to the Israeli invasion of Lebanon has been hostile here from the start, even among many prominent British Jews.  Although Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who is on vacation in Switzerland, has made no public comment, a junior minister at the Foreign Office, Douglas Hurd, said last week that ''thousands of innocent civilians, Lebanese and Palestinian, have been killed or wounded in Lebanon in pursuit of objectives which are very far from clear and are probably not going to be realized.'' **********Mr. Hurd called upon the United States to reassess its entire approach to the Palestinian problem if it wanted to give the Israelis any real security. **********Other Western European politicians have made the same point. The vast majority were highly critical of President Reagan's policies until he finally spoke bluntly to Mr. Begin in a successful effort to force an accommodation. 'The Savagery of Its Attack' **********In an editorial this morning, The Times of London suggested that the United States would remain less sympathetic to Israel for some time and might evolve a more evenhanded policy. It said that Israel, ''by the savagery of its attack,'' had ''come perilously near putting itself on the same level as those who seek the destruction of Israel.'' **********French officials, eager to defuse the tensions resulting from anti-Semitic attacks in Paris, made no immediate comment. But the country's newspapers paid tribute to Mr. Habib and President Reagan for bringing about the agreement. **********Figaro called the envoy ''the tireless negotiator.'' Sud-Ouest, a large provincial paper published in Bordeaux, said that although Washington at first gave ''an impression of complicity with Jerusalem,'' Mr. Reagan's telephone call on Aug. 12 ''forced the Israeli Cabinet to submit'' to the Habib plan. **********The comments represented a considerable shift because most papers previously supported the P.L.O., and several had dismissed Mr. Habib as a ''messenger boy.'' More Trouble Ahead? **********Nonetheless, the French press predicted more trouble ahead. Le Monde said the ''specter of partition'' of Lebanon haunted many minds, and Le Matin, which follows a left-of-center line, suggested the next battle ground might be in the north of the country. **********In Bonn, a ranking West German source said: ''The Government is pleased about any advance toward peace in the area and the end to the suffering of the people there, and hopes that the Habib plan will help to re-establish the independence, sovereignty and safety of the Republic of Lebanon as well as advance the discussions toward a just solution for the Palestinian problem.'' **********Chancellor Helmut Schmidt has voiced sharp criticism of Israeli policy, telling the newspaper Die Welt that ''people are being killed indiscriminately - women and men who have nothing to do with the war, who bear no responsibility for this war.'' Some newspapers used the word ''vernichtungskrieg,'' which means ''war of extermination,'' to describe the Israeli thrust. **********Prominent public figures have been more outspokenly anti-Israeli than at any time in decades. The publisher of Die Zeit, Countess Marion Donhoff, compared the Israeli cutoff of water and food for west Beirut to Nazi actions against the Warsaw ghetto in World War II. Johannes Rau, the deputy chairman of Mr. Schmidt's Social Democratic Party, said on the West German radio last Sunday that Mr.  Begin's policies were ''inconceivable and incomprehensible.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/18/busin.main_headline: DECLINE IN RATES IS EXPECTED TO CONTINUE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/18/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; DECLINE IN RATES IS EXPECTED TO CONTINUE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/18/busin.body_text: **********With the Federal Reserve all but advertising an easier credit policy, interest rates are expected to resume their downward trend this week despite the sudden and unnerving disappearance of buyers last Thursday and Friday. Money market specialists became even more convinced of this Friday, after the Fed reported a $6.9 billion jump in the nation's basic money supply for the week ended Oct.6. **********Despite the central bank's strenuous efforts to de-emphasize this M-1 figure, which consists of currency in the hands of the public and funds in all types of checking accounts in banks and savings institutions, expectations that the number would be much higher tended to drive many institutional buyers away late in the week. So did the sharp price swings earlier in the week, dealers said. **********Downward Trend Seen **********Now that the market's immediate fears of a retightening of credit have been soothed, analysts believe that interest rates should have a downside bias at least until after the Nov.2 election, or perhaps until after the equally crucial Christmas shopping season. **********''Regardless of how the remarks of Fed officials are interpreted, we believe that its current easing is only a temporary departure caused by the weakening economy,'' said Philip Braverman, vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank and senior economist of its bond department. ''At this time, the Fed's No.1 problem is not inflation, but the state of the economy, and it must act accordingly.'' **********How temporary will the Fed's new easier credit tack be? ''Probably no longer than early January,'' Mr. Braverman said.  By then, he continued, the market should be responding to a number of factors that could force the Fed to once again tighten the credit spigot. These factors include the growing belief that the recent easing of consumer credit rates will be translated into a strong Christmas retail season, as well as the release of consumers' pent-up demand for new cars and housing. Shift Seen After January **********After Jan.1, prices for natural gas and other basic consumer needs are expected to rise sharply, which would also raise the specter of renewed inflation, all of which would then provoke the Fed into resuming the monetary course it embarked on three years ago, or at least so goes the argument. **********Mr. Braverman said that despite the expected pick-up in consumer demand, the economic recovery was still a long way off. ''It certainly won't be visible in the first quarter of 1983,'' he added. **********Meanwhile, the money market will be struggling with pent-up demand from business borrowers as well as the ballooning credit needs of the Government in the short term. Corporate borrowers are seizing upon the lower interest rates to convert short-term debt into long term, rather than using their borrowings for expansion and upgrading of existing plant, Mr. Braverman noted. Inventory Problems for Dealers **********Another reason for last week's erratic money market, which could be repeated this week, is the financial situation faced by the dealers who serve as both distributors and marketers of fixed-income securities for the Government and private business. **********''Nonbank dealer finance rates are about the same as the overnight interbank, or Federal funds rate, 9.25 percent,'' Mr. Braverman said Friday. ''The dealers expected much lower financing costs and now find their inventories, heavily weighted with issues selling at deep discounts, most uncomfortable.'' **********This is especially true of Government securities dealers who inadvertently took on large amounts of deep-discounted Government coupon issues, mostly in swap deals, at a time when retail interest declined. Several dealers said this was also true of ''premium issues,'' such as the 14 percent Treasury bonds of 2011, which sold as high as 29 points over face during the week and dropped to 126 1/2 by late Friday. Each point is equal to $10 on each $1,000 of face value. **********Dealers stocking Treasury bills, which closed the week with yields of roughly 7.5 percent, compared with the carrying cost of 9.25 percent on average, were also unhappy. But the low short-term rates did help the long end of the market and strengthened the positive yield curve (in which long-term rates are higher than those on shorter instruments, which is a normal yield structure). **********But, here again, if short-term credit becomes cheaper, there will be less incentive for corporate borrowers to stretch out their debt by shifting to the longer maturities, Mr. Braverman pointed out.  ''Piling up short-term debt is not good, no matter the purpose.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/20/world.main_headline: A U.S. ARMS IMPORT CURB ANGERS ALLIES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/20/world.print_headline: A U.S. ARMS IMPORT CURB ANGERS ALLIES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/20/world.body_text: **********Officials at the State and Defense Departments have become concerned that an import restriction that Congress enacted late last year may jeopardize arms cooperation efforts between the United States and its allies. **********The little-noticed Congressional amendment, known as the specialty metals clause, prohibits the import of military products containing a number of metals. The amendment has prompted American allies to charge that the United States, which is itself a leading arms exporter, is unwilling to make military purchases abroad. **********''The allies are really upset over this,'' a State Department official said. ''I can't overestimate how much they're upset about it.'' **********Lack of cooperation in the arms field has been a perennial problem in the Atlantic alliance. Metals Have Special Alloys **********Specialty metals are metals with special alloys such as cobalt, titanium and zirconium. They are found in virtually all items of military equipment, including aircraft, missiles, ships and ammunition. **********The restriction on the import of items containing the metals, according to a Defense Department memorandum, jeopardizes the procurement of equipment or components bought from American allies by the Pentagon or by its contractors. In 1980, according to the memorandum, such trade amounted to $400 million. **********Although the Pentagon estimates that the military equipment bought by the United States from foreign nations contained less than 1 percent of the specialty metals, the entire military trade package would be placed in jeopardy, officials said. **********Imports of the metals were first restricted in 1973, but Congress, expressing its support for standardization and interchangeability of equipment within the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, gave the Pentagon authority to waive the restriction in 1977. Defense Department officials are now considering strategies to restore the waiver, which was eliminated in the Defense Appropriations Bill at the urging of the specialty metals industry last December. The legislation was submitted by Senator James Abdnor, Republican of South Dakota, and was accepted by the House in conference. **********Pentagon officials are equally concerned that the principle of arms cooperation and standardization in NATO and among other allies may have already been harmed. 'Every Embassy' Said to Protest **********A Pentagon official said ''every embassy in NATO'' had written protest letters about the trade restriction. ''They're expressing their concern that we are going back on an agreement,'' the official said. ''We're concerned that it will kill standardization. They'll get annoyed with us, turn inward and develop their own equipment that won't be adaptable to ours.'' **********The United States sells about six times as much in military systems to its allies as it imports, and Pentagon officials are concerned that the specialty metals clause may cause the allies to view ''our efforts at alliance cooperation as nothing more than an effort to sell U.S. arms by reimposing barriers to cooperation.'' **********Negotiations are now under way for the sale of weapons systems such as the F-18 fighter and the M-1 tank to United States allies. ''It is estimated these sales could amount to several billion dollars, providing tens of thousands of jobs,'' the Pentagon memorandum said.  ''These jobs could be placed in jeopardy.'' **********Wolfgang Kandel, first secretary for defense, research and engineering in the West German Embassy here, said West German officials hoped that the waiver would be reinstated. ''We are very concerned,'' he said. ''All the defense cooperation we have built up would not be possible. It is supposed to be a two-way street.'' **********Pentagon officials fear that the clause may also prompt the renegotiation of a number of foreign contracts for American arms.  The sale of F-18's to Australia, for instance, carries an American commitment to buy Australian arms components. But, a Pentagon official said, unless the Australians buy the specialty metals for those components in the United States, ''it's going to be real difficult to keep our commitment.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/08/world.body_text: **********A meeting between President Reagan and Leonid I. Brezhnev is ''highly possible, even probable'' in 1982, though no arrangements have been made, Edwin Meese 3d, the President's counselor, said today. **********So far the two sides remain at loggerheads, with the White House pushing for a get-together in June and the Kremlin publicly urging a more formal conference in October. **********Evidently in an effort to promote a face-to-face meeting, Mr. Meese said that despite current differences he thought the President would be willing to consider a formal summit meeting ''before the end of the year.'' **********''I am basing this primarily on the President's desire to do everything possible on arms control and reducing tensions,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/08/busin.main_headline: VOTE DUE ON U.S. AUTO CONTENT BILL
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/08/busin.print_headline: VOTE DUE ON U.S. AUTO CONTENT BILL
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/08/busin.body_text: **********The way was cleared today for a House vote as early as Thursday on the most bitterly contested trade bill to hit Congress in years - the so-called domestic content bill requiring cars sold here to be built mostly with American parts and manpower. **********The legislation has been promoted as a jobs bill by the United Automobile Workers union, is strongly supported by Speaker Thomas P.  O'Neill Jr., Democrat of Massachusetts, and has more than 220 cosponsors. It was introduced by Richard L. Ottinger, Democrat of Westchester. **********Its progress through the legislative process is a sign of growing distress over high unemployment and growing resentment against the trading practices of Japan, the bill's principal target. A highway bill that passed the House this morning contained ''Buy American'' provisions reflecting similar protectionist sentiments. **********However, the domestic content bill is vehemently opposed by the Reagan Administration, whose chief trade representative, Bill Brock, calls it the most serious threat to the international trading system in a decade. **********Mr. Brock is to speak at a breakfast meeting of the United States Chamber of Commerce Wednesday to lead a campaign of free trade lobbyists to fight the bill. But many analysts are predicting passage in the House. They are less certain, however, about what might happen in the Senate, where a major push is being made by the bill's supporters. **********The House Rules Committee, which sets the agenda for the chamber, cleared the bill for two hours of debate, anticipating in daylong proceedings today some of the arguments that may be heard on the floor. The Speaker's office said the debate may be scheduled Thursday. **********President Reagan's strong endorsement of free trade policies in his radio message two weeks ago almost assures a veto if the bill should clear the two chambers. 'Strong Message to Japan' **********Representative Ottinger said that even if the bill only passes one chamber it would send a ''very strong message to Japan that they had better act'' to open markets. **********The bill, which was introduced more than a year ago, requires that all manufacturers selling more than 100,000 cars in the United States meet an increasing standard for the percentage of American parts and labor. **********For every 100,000 cars sold in the United States, the manufacturer would have to show 10 percent domestic content up to a maximum of 90 percent by 1986. On the basis of sales in the last model year, Nissan would have had to show 73.6 percent domestic content with sales of 736,000 units. Toyota would have been at 71.9 percent with 719,000 units. **********There is a dispute between the bill's supporters and opponents over whether Honda, which has just spent $250 million to build Accords in Marysville, Ohio, and Volkswagen, which has had an assembly plant making Rabbits at New Stanton, Pa., since the mid-1970's, would come under the standards. **********Spokesmen for both the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company testified against the bill, known as the Fair Practices in Automotive Products Act, arguing that it was not the right way to solve the problems of the industry. Both companies had joined forces with the U.A.W. in its bid two years ago to get quota restraints imposed on Japan. The Reagan Administration in the spring of 1981 negotiated a three-year voluntary restraint package with the Japanese. Jurisdictional Disputes **********The leadership's handling of the bill has created jurisdictional tensions in the House. Sam M. Gibbons, Democrat of Florida and chairman of the trade subcommittee of the House Ways and Means Committee, is a fervent opponent of the bill. He complained today that even though this was a trade bill, his committee got only eight days to to consider it, while the Energy and Commerce Committee kept it for nine months. That committee's chairman, John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, is one of the bill's most vocal supporters. **********Mr. Gibbons, whose committee never even voted on the bill, said there had been a ''violation of Ways and Means jurisdiction.'' He likened the bill in the rules panel's deliberations today to the Smoot Hawley tariff of 1930 that touched off the protectionism of the 1930's. That bill, which began as a narrow tariff measure, ultimately encompassed virtually all imports as legislators sought to protect their industrial constituencies. Studies Question Benefits **********Studies by the Congressional Budget Office have found that the bill would actually cause jobs to be lost because of foreign retaliation and would lead to higher automobile prices for American consumers. **********By 1990, said the office's director, Alice M. Rivlin, some 38,000 auto jobs would be created, while 104,000 jobs would be eliminated because of restrictions placed on nonauto exports. **********Barber B. Conable Jr., Republican of upstate New York and ranking Republican on the Ways and Means Committee, warned that passage of the bill would ''render meaningless'' what was agreed on in the ministerial document at a recent trade conference in Geneva at which 88 countries agreed to ''refrain from taking or maintaining'' protectionist measures. **********Representative Dingell countered: ''This is not protectionist legislation. We are merely doing what every other nation does. The issue is the survival of American industry. If we're not careful we'll have to put on a loin cloth like Mahatma Ghandi because there will be nothing left.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/21/busin.body_text: **********To the Business Editor: Regarding ''The Curse on Cigars'' (March 14), far from the bleak outlook portrayed, cigar sales in 1981 were the most promising in more than 10 years. Units sold totaled 3.9 billion and dollar sales rose for the second straight year. **********Over all, the decline of 7.6 percent in units sold in 1980 had been pared to a modest 2.5 percent decline, in the best year-to-year sales trend in a decade. **********These positive results can be traced to several factors, including development of new cigar products for young smokers, and an industrywide information campaign focusing on the traditional symbol of the cigar as a mark of success and achievement. A national duespaying organization of cigar smokers called Friends of the Cigar, begun about six months ago, already boasts some 1,500 members.  JOSEPH E. https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/26/busin.print_headline: MAN IN THE NEWS; A MAN WHO CHALLENGES PRESIDENTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/26/busin.body_text: **********Back in 1978, when President Carter tried to block exports of advanced oil exploration equipment to the Soviet Union, John V.  James came out fighting. The chairman of Dresser Industries, maker of the equipment, Mr. James publicly branded the President's move "sheer idiocy." **********This time around, as Dresser battles to avoid being penalized by the Reagan Administration for its French subsidiary's sales to the Soviet gas pipeline project, Mr. James has left the public discussion to Dresser's senior vice president, Edward R. Luter, and to the company's lawyers in Washington, at least so far. **********Is Mr. James reticent because he was an early and avid supporter of the Reagan-Bush ticket (George Bush is a former Dresser employee) and because President Reagan named him to his Export Council in 1979? **********Wall Street followers of Dresser, as well as business associates and friends of Mr. James, say that would be completely out of character. They expressed the view, confirmed by Mr. Luter, that his silence reflects a desire to speak with one voice in the trade dispute rather than a reluctance to take a personal stand against President Reagan. Believes Reagan Is Misled **********Further, Mr. Luter explains, Mr. James believes that President Reagan has been misled by advisers in adopting the policies that now threaten Dresser. **********''Jack James is the type of man who would support you as long he thinks you are right - then he would feel free to speak out,'' said J. Rawles Fulgham, a Dresser director who is president of the Interfirst Corporation, a Dallas bank holding company. **********''It's just a case of recognizing that Ed Luter does well handling the media on controversial issues,'' said John Lawrence, Mr. James's predecessor as chairman and chief executive at Dresser. **********Silent on the specifics or not, Mr. James is clearly behind Dresser's decision not to order its French subsidiary to stop shipment of compressors to the pipeline project. **********''We feel like we are on the horns of a dilemma,'' Mr. James said in a telephone interview Wednesday from Dresser's headquarters in Dallas. ''We have to try to be good citizens in every country in which we operate. The laws of the United States are not the laws of the whole world.'' **********A conservative, finance-oriented executive, the 64-year-old Mr.  James is described on Wall Street as a man who ''watches everything down to the last penny,'' one analyst said. 'Made Dresser Blossom' **********''There's no question in my mind that he is a far better manager than I ever was,'' added Mr. Lawrence, who now runs a consulting company bearing his name in Dallas. ''I put some things in place, but he made Dresser blossom.'' **********Mr. James became president and chief executive in 1970, and chairman in 1976. Dresser's sales of oilfield equipment, energy transportation and processing machinery, industrial equipment, refractories, and mining machinery jumped from just over $900 million in 1972 to more than $4.61 billion in 1981. Net income in that period rose to $292 million from $38.9 million. **********A native of Pennsylvania, whose family owned a small coal mine, Mr. James served as an Army intelligence officer in Europe during World War II. His Army service and the death of his brother Delbert in the Normandy invasion contributed to what friends describe as ''Jack's super-patriotism.'' **********After the war, Mr. James graduated from the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania, joined the Corning Glass Works as a financial executive and moved to Dresser in 1957. Fought U.S. Inquiries **********The patriotism that friends allude to has not stopped Mr. James from frequent jousts with the United States Government. Under his leadership, Dresser attracted attention for its litigious and vocal resistance to Federal investigations of its questionable payments overseas, which Dresser's own investigation in 1976 put at $313,500. **********Later, there was the battle with the Carter Administration, during which Mr. James argued that a ban on the export of equipment ''would hand American export business to foreign competitors on a silver platter.'' **********Nor has Mr. James backed away from bitter business disputes. He joined Willard F. Rockwell Jr.'s slate of candidates for the board of the SCM Corporation in Mr. Rockwell's long, but unsuccessful effort to topple SCM's management. **********Mr. James has been amply rewarded for his accomplishments at Dresser. Although his base salary last year was $377,651, additional benefits, deferred compensation, and realized stock gains lifted his compensation from Dresser to $2,640,223, according to a report in Forbes magazine. That ranked him ninth among the nation's top executives at publicly held companies. The year before, the New York-based management consulting firm of Towers, Perrin, Forster & Crosby said that his total compensation package of about $1.27 million was the highest reported. **********The compensation does not result in high living. Mr. James lives quietly with his wife, Helen, in Dallas, his daughter having married and moved away. Pressed to name a hobby, he will say he enjoys reading history. Acquaintances say that running Dresser is both his work and his favorite hobby. **********''He's a very hard worker - sometimes it seems like he does nothing else,'' Mr. Lawrence said.  Mr. James laughs when asked about such descriptions, noting that he has one year left until his retirement. ''I have cut back on my travel to about 75,000 miles a year from 100,000 miles,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/25/busin.body_text: **********The Kloss Video Corporation said it had scrapped plans to acquire the Advent Corporation, a maker of stereo speakers and large-screen televisions that has been operating under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code since last year. **********Herbert Kloss, president of Kloss Video, said that ''we made a proposal to Advent but it wasn't possible to do it under the conditions we had set.'' **********He declined to specify what the proposal or the conditions were. **********Advent was founded by Mr. Kloss in 1967 to produce large-screen projection televisions. He left Advent in 1976 and formed Kloss Video, which makes large-screen projection television systems under the name Novabeam Model One. **********Advent, which also makes high-fidelity audio components, sought court protection while attempting to pay $14.8 million in debt. The company had been buffeted by a series of management changes, heavy competition, pricing problems on its audio equipment and mounting losses from its television operation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/05/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS DIGEST; WEDNESDAY, MAY 5, 1982; The Economy
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/05/busin.body_text: **********President Reagan agreed to impose quotas on sugar imports. His aim is to avoid having to buy and store domestic sugar under the price support plan he accepted last year in return for votes for his economic program. One result will be to raise the price candy companies and soft drink producers pay for sweeteners. (Page A1.) **********New-car sales by the Big Three auto makers fell 5.1 percent in late April, the companies reported. G.M.'s sales rose 1.7 percent, but Chrysler's dropped 34.1 percent and Ford's 4.4 percent. Analysts attributed the decline to a lackluster response to incentives as well as poor economic conditions and high interest rates. (D1.) **********April retail sales in New York City dropped below 1981 levels for the second month this year as sales declined an average 0.3 percent, according to a spot-check. Many retail executives cited the month's heavy snowfall, while some noted a new reluctance to buy among affluent customers worried over the economy. (D1.) **********A budget compromise calling for a freeze on social programs and a tax increase was proposed by Senator Pete V. Domenici, chairman of the budget committee. (B11.) **********New Federal rules to permit larger double-trailer trucks are being urged by Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis as a way to persuade the trucking industry to accept higher taxes. (A20.) International **********Charges that American companies paid millions in bribes to obtain contracts from Mexico's Government-owned oil company are being investigated by a Federal grand jury, the Justice Department said.  The inquiry came to light in a suit filed against Crawford Enterprises, which confirmed it is a target of the inquiry but denied any wrongdoing. (D1.) Mexico has charged four directors of a Mexican company with tax evasion on commissions from Crawford. (D6.) **********Argentina will probably keep up with payments on its $35 billion of foreign loans outstanding despite the intensification of the Falklands crisis, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said. (D12.) Companies **********RCA will ''resist to the utmost'' any attempt by outsiders to acquire or dismember the company, its chairman, Thornton F. Bradshaw, told a stormy annual meeting. He sought to reassure shareowners that the company was on the way toward establishing a new focus on communications and electronics. (D1.) **********Pan Am filed suit against Braniff, asking for $100 million in damages and the return of a $7 million down payment it made for the right to lease Braniff's Latin American routes. The payment was made before the C.A.B. awarded the routes to Eastern instead. (D5.) **********Sperry reported a decline of 11.5 percent in its fourth fiscal quarter. Internorth's first-quarter net slipped 8.9 percent. (D4.) **********Polaroid announced its entry into the 35-millimeter camera market and brought out several other new products. (D4.) **********Hermetite and two senior executives were accused by the S.E.C. of violating the accounting and reporting provisions of the Federal securities laws. The executives agreed to repay funds to the company, while neither admitting nor denying the allegations. (D6.) Markets **********The stock market registered a moderate advance, with the Dow Jones industrial average up 5.42 points, to 845.45. (D8.) Demand was strong for the Treasury's new three-year notes, which sold at an average yield of 14.07 percent. (D12.) The dollar rose in foreign-currency trading, while gold prices dropped $2.25 an ounce, to $342.75, in New York. (D14.) Sugar futures prices fell after the President's decision to reimpose sugar import quotas was announced. (D14.) Today's Columns **********Many conservatives are joining liberals in the belief that Reaganomics is a failure. However, the markets have adjusted smoothly to the prospect of big deficits. In fact, they may be scenting the imminent decline of interest rates. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene.  (D2.) **********Is the Treasury's new 10-year note a good buy for individual investors? Analysts disagree. The advantage is that a relatively high interest rate will be locked in for a decade, while the risk is that interest rates may move even higher. Market Place. (D8.)

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/30/world.body_text: **********Philip C. Habib, the special United States envoy to the Middle East, arrived here today, and the authoritative Al Ahram newspaper said he would meet with top Egyptian officials to discuss the withdrawal of foreign troops from Lebanon. **********Mr. Habib, who negotiated the withdrawal of the main body of Palestine Liberation Organization guerrillas from Beirut, was greeted at the airport by a Foreign Ministry Under Secretary, Abdel Hamid el-Shafei. **********The envoy arrived on a private Saudi plane. As is his policy, he gave no statement to reporters.  Al Ahram said Egypt would ask him when Israel will withdraw from Lebanon, which Israel invaded June 6. It said the withdrawal of other foreign troops from Lebanon - Syrian and Palestinian - would be discussed, as well as the transfer of power to the Lebanese Government and the role of the United States in the Middle East. **********Egyptian officials will also receive a report on Mr. Habib's recent talks in Israel, Jordan, Syria and Saudi Arabia, the paper said.  Mr. Habib is scheduled to meet with Foreign Minister Kamal Hassan Ali on Thursday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/30/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; San Marino, at Last,; Gets a Papal Visit
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/30/world.body_text: **********Greeted by a military band and citizens applauding from flower-bedecked balconies on a medieval square, Pope John Paul II today made the first papal visit in the 1,681-year history of San Marino, the world's oldest republic. **********John Paul met with the only Communist head of state in Western Europe and said mass for about 10,000 people in the sports stadium in the walled capital of the 23-square-mile nation, perched atop Mount Titano in northern Italy. **********The Pope drove into the San Marino square in a navy blue convertible and waved to the crowds, many of whom dropped colorful leaflets saying ''Viva il Papa!'' from their balconies. **********After the ornately uniformed band played the national anthem, John Paul went into the castle-like Government palace to a greeting by Giuseppe Maiani, a Communist and one of San Marino's two governing captains regent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/08/busin.body_text: **********The International Monetary Fund announced today that it had authorized the Islamic Development Bank in Saudi Arabia to hold and trade special drawing rights, the asset issued by the I.M.F. for use in the reserves held by governments. **********Only the monetary fund itself, its 145 member governments and 11 other intergovernmental banks and funds are authorized to deal in S.D.R.'s. More than 21 billion have been issued. **********S.D.R.'s were quoted today at $1.11244 each, a figure based on the daily market value of the American dollar, the Japanese yen, the British pound, the French franc and the West German mark. The main use of S.D.R.'s is for settling accounts among governments and the other institutions that hold them. Their value fluctuates less than that of national currencies. **********At the end of 1980, the monetary fund has estimated, only 4 percent of the world's reserves were held in I.M.F. drawing rights (including the special drawing rights) and 57 percent in gold - which S.D.R.'s were originally intended to replace.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/04/world.main_headline: WEINBERGER SEEKS TO DECLARE POLES IN DEFAULT ON DEBT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/04/world.print_headline: WEINBERGER SEEKS TO DECLARE POLES IN DEFAULT ON DEBT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/04/world.body_text: **********Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger reportedly intends to keep pressing to have Poland declared in default of its debts to the West and to have Western European nations halt their natural gas pipeline deal with Moscow. **********On the recommendation of the State, Treasury and Agriculture Departments, President Reagan recently agreed to have the Administration pay American banks the $71 million owed them by Poland to forestall a declaration of default and a possible disruption of East-West economic relations. **********But, in the continuing debate on the question within the Administration, high Pentagon officials oppose this action. They insist that the issue of Polish default has n ot been finally settled.Mr. Weinberger is known to favor the tougher stance of allowing default and the disruption of Western credit relations with the East so as to impose an economic penalty on Moscow and Warsaw for the repression in Poland. **********Salvadoran Intervention Opposed **********On the issue of El Salvador, however, Mr. Weinberger opposes American combat involvement and is understood to be wary of military operations in the Caribbean, such as a blockade of Cuba or Nicaragua, that would require Congressional approval. **********Tuesday, in Congressional testimony, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. seemed to reopen the threat of American intervention in Central America by asserting that the United States would do ''whatever is necessary'' to prevent the overthrow the Salvadoran Government by leftist guerillas. Today, Larry Speakes, a White House spokesman, left Mr. Haig's comments standing but emphasized that there were no plans ''at the moment'' for American troops to go into combat in El Salvador or elsewhere. **********Mr. Speakes said the Secretary ''was discussing contingencies,'' and added, ''The President has said he has no plans to send troops anywhere and he has no plans.'' **********A high Pentagon official, acknowledging domestic poliical opposition to American military involvement, added that ''one of the lessons of Vietnam is that we can't engage in a war that is not supported by American public opinion.'' **********In comments on another, more distant trouble spot, a senior Administration official revealed rising concern over reports that the Soviet Union was providing aid to the Communist Tudeh Party in Iran and was ''very likely'' sending arms and military supplies across the Soviet-Iranian border to other groups fighting the regime of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. **********On the issue of possible Polish default, Mr. Weinberger was reported to have been taken by surprise by the Administration's decision to pay off the American banks, primarily because he had been preoccupied with preparation of the new Pentagon budget. But since the Defense Secretary did not get a chance to press his own views on the issue with President Reagan, the Pentagon does not regard the matter as settled. **********Mr. Weinberger is said to feel that the recent decision to bail out the banks was an ''interim'' action. He is said to believe that the question is still ''a live issue'' among Administration policy makers and certain to be reconsidered as future installments of Polish debts come due. **********''This is a continuing debate,'' a high Pentagon official said.  ''The default issue is with us continuously. There are quarterly payments due so it will come up again. It's a live issue.'' **********The default question is linked, in Mr. Weinberger's opinion, to the pipeline deal, which has for months been a major target of Pentagon officials and American diplomats. **********The Defense Department's view, reportedly backed by William J.  Casey, Director of Central Intelligence, is that the pipeline would not only make Western Europe dependent on Moscow for vital energy supplies but would also earn the Soviet Union about $10 billion a year in hard currency that could be spent on Western technology with military applications. **********Mr. Weinberger is understood to believe that a Polish default would not only impose further economic burdens on the Soviet Union but would delay the pipeline. The Administration concedes, however, that West European banks and governments are shying away from this approach. **********Secretary of State Haig, in testimony Tuesday before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, defended the Administration's decision to pay the Polish debts. He said the President's action ''will require the Soviet Union to make the money good.'' He added, ''Had we called default, they would have been relieved of that burden'' because Poland could have been considered bankrupt. **********Mr. Weinberger's arguments with the Western Europeans is that the West should not help the Soviet Union develop its oil and natural gas resources, especially when Western intelligence estimates anticipate Soviet shortages in the years ahead. **********In the Reagan Adminstration's internal debates over Poland, Mr.  Weinberger and some of his Pentagon aides have taken the most pessimistic view of developments. Recently, for example, Mr.  Weinberger commented that he felt ''the Polish Government is run by a Russian general in a Polish uniform.'' **********Covert Operations in Poland? **********Although he is known to favor most policies that would make it harder for the Soviet Union to support the military regime in Poland, Mr. Weinberger has not pushed for covert operations in support of Polish resistance to martial law. The Administration's announcement Monday th at the Government would pay American banks rather than allow Poland t o go into formal defaulthas come under fire from conservative groups. **********''Default would require the Soviet Union, rather than the American taxpayer, to bail out the bankrupt Polish Government,'' Howard Phillips, leader of the Conservative Caucus, said today. **********Mr. Phillips said at a news conference that his organization had launched a $100,000 letter-writing campaign to urge banks to force Poland into default by seeking immediate repayment of outstanding Polish loans.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/06/busin.body_text: **********A California savings and loan association was given Government permission today to cross state lines and acquire four institutions in Florida and Georgia. **********The merger, arranged by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, was the sixth interstate acquisition since the insurance corporation was given authority last March to cross state lines to find merger partners for weak savings and loan associations. **********In the latest merger, the California Federal Savings and Loan Association of Los Angeles acquired the United Federal Savings and Loan Association of Broward County, Fort Lauderdale, Fla.; the Guaranty Federal Savings and Loan Association of Adel, Ga.; the Peach State Federal Savings and Loan Association of Bremen, Ga., and the First Federal Savings and Loan Association of Sylvania, Ga. **********The merger gives California Federal $8.4 billion in assets, according to the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, which regulates Federal savings and loan associations. **********The bank board said United had $689 million in assets and 17 offices; Guaranty, $35 million in assets and three offices; Peach State, $117 million in assets and six offices, and First Federal, $18 million in assets and two offices. **********The bank board said ''limited financial assistance'' would be provided by the insurance corporation to bring about the Peach State merger. No Government money was needed in the acquisiton of the other three associations, it said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/10/world.body_text: **********AROUND THE WORLD; Italy's Biggest Party Will Support Spadolini **********ROME, Aug. 9 (AP) - Italy's Christian Democratic Party proposed today that Giovanni Spadolini, whose coalition Cabinet fell three days ago, be given a mandate to form a new government. **********Christian Democratic leaders gave their support to Mr. Spadolini, leader of the tiny Republican Party, during talks with President Sandro Pertini. Mr. Pertini is expected to name a caretaker Prime Minister by Thursday. **********The Prime Minister-designate must then try to assemble a majority in Parliament. **********Mr. Pertini, an 85-year-old Socialist, said ''I will do everthing possible to avert early elections.'' ---- **********BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 9 (Reuters) -Foreign Minister Emilio Colombo of Italy began talks today aimed at thawing relations between Argentina and the European Common Market, which imposed sanctions on Argentina during the Falkland conflict. **********He met Foreign Minister Juan Ramon Aguirre Lanari and was seeing President Reynaldo Bignone later.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/31/busin.body_text: **********Political Economics **********If opinion polls are accurate, voters on Tuesday are likely to resist the Administration's admonition to ''stay the course'' on economic policy. If there's a real rebellion the nation could wake up Wednesday with Democrats in control not only of the House, as today, but of the Senate too. That would be good news for the party, but analysts fear its implications for economic policy. **********It could yield a Congress of fractious Democrats fighting among themselves for key committee posts and fighting with the Republican White House over policy. The result, analysts say, would be legislative paralysis. **********If voters are somewhat less hostile and merely increase the Democratic majority in the House, there is likely to be more progress on economic matters, says Barry Bosworth, a senior economist at the Brookings Institution. He would expect action then on Social Security and defense spending. **********In addition, he says that the next Congress is likely to be more aggressive than its predecessor in urging the Federal Reserve Board to pursue a generally more stimulative monetary policy. Given the depths of the recession, he thinks such action would be warranted. Eroding Employment **********The battle against double-digit unemployment is likely to last longer than many dared to think even a few months ago. The Labor Department report on employment for October, due Friday, is almost certain to show further erosion, analysts say. The reason: continued weakness throughout the economy. Roughly 300,000 workers were laid off last month, says Donald Ratajczak, director of Georgia State University's economic forecasting project. That should push the jobless rate to around 10.4 percent. And, since unemployment is a lagging indicator, and the economy has not yet shown clear signs of touching bottom, further rises are likely. On a monthly basis, unemployment could peak at around 10.8 percent late this year or early in 1983, Mr. Ratajczak says - but an 11 percent rate is not out of the question. Moreover, a sluggish recovery, low inflation and high productivity gains make a rapid reduction in the jobless rate unlikely. Judging Inventories **********For corporate managers, few problems this year have proven more intractable than determining proper inventory levels. After cutting sharply into stocks during the first half, many businesses geared up production in anticipation of a rise in demand during the second half. But the economy has not come roaring back, and inventories again are riding at unacceptably high levels. **********Due in large part to the pile-up of unsold autos, total manufacturing inventories probably rose slightly during the third quarter, says M. Kathyrn Eickoff, executive vice president at Townsend-Greenspan & Company. **********Consumer demand remains weak, and industrial production seems to have fallen further in October, Miss Eickoff says. As a result, she says, stocks are likely to be drawn down again by an inflationadjusted $6 billion during the fourth quarter, putting a drag on G.N.P. Moreover, after so many mistakes, companies are likely to be even more cautious about adding to stocks well into 1983, Miss Eickoff says. Soft Landing for the Dollar **********Despite falling interest rates and rising trade deficits, foreign exchange traders have continued to bid up the value of the dollar.  After posting impressive gains in 1981, on a trade-weighted basis the dollar has risen another 14.5 percent since the beginning of the year, according to economists at Morgan Guaranty Trust. **********Most experts do not expect the rise to continue. Against currencies like the German mark and the Japanese yen the dollar is at least 20 percent overvalued, they say. But they think it's unlikely the dollar will give back all of its gains over the next 12 to 18 months. **********A selloff is coming, argues David Rolley, an economist at Chase Econometrics, but the dollar is likely to remain a safe and quality currency, two characteristics that have been key to its recent rise.  In spite of what is likely to be a record 1983 trade deficit, these qualities should help limit the dollar's fall, he says. **********The drop is likely to be most pronounced vis-a-vis the mark and the yen, says Charles Raymond, president of Predex, a currency forecasting firm. By the end of 1983, the dollar should decline 8 percent against the mark and 13 percent against the yen, he says. **********Kenneth N. Gilpin
