https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/14/world.body_text: **********Queen Beatrix consulted party leaders on the Dutch political crisis today after the collapse Wednesday night of the country's three-party coalition Government. **********The Netherlands appeared headed for a period of minority government followed by elections in the autumn as no clear view emerged among parliamentary parties on how to solve the political crisis. **********Leading politicians said the most likely outcome was an effort by the Christian Democrats and Democrats-66 to maintain a minority government until September, when new elections would be called. **********The Christian Democrats and Democrats-66, both centrist groups, remained in the coalition from which Labor resigned Wednesday after a long dispute on economic policy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/26/world.main_headline: MARINES' LANDING IN BEIRUT DELAYED BY LACK OF ACCORD
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/26/world.print_headline: MARINES' LANDING IN BEIRUT DELAYED BY LACK OF ACCORD
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/26/world.body_text: **********The United States said today that the Marines would not land in Beirut on Sunday, as planned, because no accord had been reached on the Israelis' pullback from Beirut International Airport. **********In a separate incident, officials said, four United Nations military observers, including two American officers, were killed outside Beirut today when their vehicle ran over a land mine. (Page 22.) **********Also in Beirut, Israeli officials said they expected their troops to be out of West Beirut by Sunday night, paving the way for deployment of the multinational peacekeeping force. (Page 23.) **********With negotiations continuing among Lebanese, Israelis and representatives of the United States, France and Italy, the three nations contributing troops to the new Beirut peacekeeping force, it now appeared likely that the Italian and American troops would not land before Tuesday. This is because of the Yom Kippur holiday on Monday. French Units Confined to Embassy **********Some French troops have already landed in Beirut, but have been confined thus far to the French Embassy, the ambassador's residence and a French cultural center. **********Officials said that the marines would not land on Sunday, as scheduled, because Philip C. Habib, the American special envoy, meeting in Israel with Defense Minister Ariel Sharon and other officials, had been unable to work out a satisfactory arrangement. **********A State Department official said the United States wanted ''no intermingling'' between the Marines and Israeli troops.  The main problem is that the 800 marines are supposed to be deployed at Beirut International Airport, which is situated south of the city and has been under Israeli control. The Americans want the Israelis to leave before the marines arrive, and there has been no agreement on a timetable. Peace Force to Total 3,000 **********The three-nation force, expected to total about 3,000 troops, is being sent to Beirut to help the Lebanese Government establish control, although the troops are not supposed to engage in combat.  Their presence is also meant to put pressure on the Israelis to hasten their withdrawal from the Beirut area and eventually from all of Lebanon. **********The Israelis, who had previously moved into the predominantly Christian eastern sector of Beirut, entered the city's largely Moslem western sector on Sept. 15 after the assassination of President-elect Bashir Gemayel. They said they were going into West Beirut to prevent further bloodshed, but the massacre of Palestinians last week by the Christian militia, an Israeli ally, led to fresh demands from the United States for the Israeli withdrawal. **********One official said he believed the matter of the Marine deployment would be resolved without too much difficulty, but he acknowledged that the negotiations had become protracted. **********While the Israelis have announced a schedule for withdrawing from West Beirut and turning over their positions to the Lebanese Army.  President Reagan is seeking an Israeli pullback from the entire Beirut area, including the airport. Israel has not responded directly to that demand, although it consented to the deployment of the threenation peacekeeping force. The Israelis have wanted to keep a presence in Beirut as the three-nation force was deployed, and to retain rights to continue to remove captured Palestinian munitions and to send patrols in and out of Beirut. **********The new Lebanese Government of President Amin Gemayel aswell as the United States, France and Italy oppose a continued Israeli presence.  And Mr. Gemayel has rejected Israel's request for the right to patrol freely. **********Throughout the past week, the State Department has sought to leave the impression that the arrival of the peacekeeping forces would occur without difficulty, and that, even if some Israelis remained in West Beirut, the deployment would proceed. **********On Friday, a senior State Department official, meeting with reporters, said he expected the Israelis to be gone from West Beirut by Sunday. But there are apparently differences over the limits of West Beirut, with the United States including the airport and the Israelis apparently not. **********The Italian contingent, which is aboard a chartered ship, had been supposed to land today, but has delayed its landing because of the continued Israeli presence in the port area. **********American officials said that they have concluded an exchange of letters with the Lebanese Government on the terms for the presence of the American troops, similar to the document that was made public when a three-nation force was in West Beirut in late August and early September supervising the evacuation of Palestinian and Syrian forces. **********In the killing of the United Nations observers by a land mine, the Defense Department said the two Americans were majors, one from the Air Force and the other from the Army. They were in a jeep 9 miles east of Beirut in the vicinity of the Beirut-Damascus highway when it struck a the land mine. **********An Irish major and a Finnish captain, also in the jeep, were also killed, the Pentagon said. Names were withheld until next of kin were notified.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/13/world.print_headline: FALKLAND IMPASSE: HAIG SEEMS UNABLE TO WORK OUT A PACKAGE SOLUTION YET; News Analysis
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/13/world.body_text: **********The dispute over the Falkland Islands is proving far more intractable than Secretary of State Alexander M.  Haig Jr. had expected it to be, and there is no assurance that he will be able to find a formula that will avert open hostilities between Argentina and Britain. **********As the Secretary, gray with fatigue, ended 11 continuous hours of negotiations with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher Monday night, the hopeful atmosphere that had built up here in the last 48 hours evaporated. Mr. Haig seemed sorely disappointed. Asked whether he was more hopeful, he replied, ''Not at all.'' Then early this morning doubts arose about the willingness of the Argentines even to continue the talks. **********Mr. Haig had expected to head back to Argentina Monday night, but the American Embassy announced early today that he was staying over in London after having had a number of telephone conversations with the Argentine Foreign Minister. **********There was no dependable, detailed account of what had occupied Mr.  Haig, Mrs. Thatcher and the other officials inside 10 Downing Street all day. But it is believed that the Secretary failed, at least for the time being, in an intensive attempt to put together a package solution to break the stalemate and avoid British naval action. **********According to diplomats monitoring the progress of Mr. Haig's diplomacy, the discussions have involved two broad questions: Who moves first to defuse the immediate military threat, and what happens to the Falklands and their 1,800 inhabitants after that? An Atmosphere of Bitterness **********In an atmosphere that is full of distrust and bitterness, the first question seems no closer to solution than it did four days ago. The Argentine junta says that Britain must turn back its main battle fleet, now only about a week from the islands, before Argentine troops can be withdrawn from the Falklands. The British say the troops must leave before the fleet can be halted. **********The obvious diplomatic solution is some mechanism under which the two things could be accomplished simultaneously. But for either side to do that would involve grave political risks: Lieut. Gen. Leopoldo Galtieri could be accused of knuckling under to British sea power and Mrs. Thatcher could be accused of giving up this country's only really strong bargaining chip. **********To put the matter another way, General Galtieri and his junta partners do not want to have to negotiate with a British naval gun pointed at their heads, and Mrs. Thatcher does not want to negotiate with someone who, from the British point of view, remains in control of a British possession that has been seized by illegal means. **********The Prime Minister had very little elbow room in her talks with Mr. Haig. Whatever she agreed to, she knew when the long meeting began, she would have to defend on Wednesday at a special session of the House of Commons. And even as she talked, it became obvious that many Members of Parliament were prepared to accept few concessions. Three-Part Package Proposed **********One of the plans that was on the table reportedly called for a three-part package: Argentine withdrawal from the islands, British recall of the fleet and a joint interim adiministration with a single Argentine flag left flying in Stanley, the capital of the Falklands, as a token of sovereignty while larger issues were sorted out. That, said Alan Clark, a hard-line Tory M.P., was unacceptable; it was ''exactly the sort of solution we forced on Czechoslovakia at Munich.'' Appearing with Mr. Clark on television, Stanley Clinton Davis, a foreign policy spokesman for the Labor Party, agreed. **********Neither of the national leaders involved is in a strong position at home, and the Falklands crisis is more about domestic than about international politics. For Mrs. Thatcher to seem to yield to aggression might bring her down; for General Galtieri to fail to retain some vestige of a sovereignty tenuously established after 149 years of national frustration might cause his regime to collapse. **********A number of ideas have been put forward to hedge on the sovereignty question, including the ''Hong Kong solution'' - under which Argentina would gain control but lease the islands back to Britain for a given period - and the ''Andorra solution'' - under which sovereignty would be shared. **********But officials in Buenos Aires have been saying privately that those ideas are unacceptable, presumably because they fear that the Argentine public would see them as a sellout after a glorious victory. It is not known whether the Falklanders, who rejected similar proposals in 1980, have changed their minds in the 10 days since the invasion on April 2. Concern for Islanders' Views **********Mrs. Thatcher has tied herself, seemingly irrevocably, to the idea that the views of the islanders themselves are paramount. She has said so several times in recent days. But how are those wishes to be determined, and when? How to be sure the islanders are free to say what they think? **********Once that is decided, other questions will arise. Is she offering a veto, a guarantee that no solution unacceptable to them will be acceptable to Britain? Or is she merely promising that their interests, which can be defined in many ways, will be served? **********Few people in British politics believe that there can be any return to the status quo ante, because Britain lacks the military means to protect the islanders for years to come from a hostile Argentina. It would take thousands of troops or a large flotilla or both, and this country cannot afford to tie down a large proportion of its resources in the defense of a small colony without strategic importance. **********Yet Mrs. Thatcher's comments about the primacy of the islanders' wishes have created the expectation that she will take exactly that stand. Fleet Entering South Atlantic **********The deadlock will be broken, if it is broken at all, only by the pressure of events. As the fleet, now thought to be about 1,000 miles north of Ascension Island, enters the South Atlantic, it may come to seem to General Galtieri, and perhaps even to the resolute Mrs. Thatcher, that it is better to accept some loss of face, whatever the political risks, than face the consequences of military engagement. **********In any war between the two countries, the odds would favor Britain, a fact that must worry General Galtieri. But substantial British casualties would also be highly likely, and Mrs. Thatcher will have to take into account that while opinion polls show wide support for her present policy, they also show that a majority of the public thinks that regaining the Falklands is not worth losing the life of one British soldier. **********Late Monday night, as Mr. Haig and his deeply gloomy entourage awaited further word from Buenos Aires, a British official said, ''Our message to the Argentines remains: 'Get out or be put out.' '' For his part, he said, he expected Mrs. Thatcher to continue to send it.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/12/busin.body_text: **********LIKE junkies denied their fix, many members of the business c ommunity are complaining mightily about the recently passed Federal t ax reform act. Most strident are the loophole pushers who lobby in W ashington. Some of them made millions peddling the tax breaks they h elped create and they are bitterly upset that their supplier has s tarted to crack down. If business executives can straighten out t heir heads long enough to think clearly, however, they will fall d own on their knees, thank God for this tax bill, and beg for more l ike it. **********Business's unhealthy addiction to tax subsidies has grown like Topsy since the early 1970's. Successive Presidents and Congresses have responded to increasingly insistent pleas from business for more ''confidence boosters'' by adding and adding to the loophole dosage. **********These deep corporate tax cuts may have induced temporary busineses euphoria, but they never had any noticeable effect on business investment as a share of the gross national product, a ratio that has shown no discernible trend up or down since World War II. And predictably, by favoring some kinds of investments over others, the ever-expanding loopholes seriously distorted capital spending patterns, to the detriment of business productivity. **********Last year, business overdosed on tax breaks. The huge new injection literally turned the corporate income tax into a corporate income subsidy. So intemperate was the new approach that a panel of loophole-crazed executives told the House Ways and Means Committee this spring that they preferred it to paying no taxes at all. **********At the same time, the 1981 act made corporate tax sheltering, rather than marketplace forces, the paramount factor in capital spending choices. Bad investments were made good, and good ones bad.  So extreme were the act's distortions that, by 1987, an investment in an industrial plant would need over four times the expected pretax profitability of an investment in office equipment to compete on the after-tax bottom line. The victims of such loophole madness include economic growth, jobs, productivity, wages, and ultimately even business profits. **********Compounding the problem, the cost of augmenting business' selfdestructive dependence on tax breaks was financed with borrowed money. Unlike the pattern of previous years, the 1981 corporate tax cuts were not offset by automatic individual tax increases from inflation-driven ''bracket creep.'' **********Instead, the $500 billion in business tax reductions over this decade, together with the rapid defense buildup, created an intolerable imbalance between Federal receipts and expenditures.  These changes - and not the illusory tax cuts for most individuals - share almost all the blame for the enormous booming Federal deficits. **********Last year's hallucinogenic rosy scenario has been discolored by recession, high interest rates, runaway deficits, record unemployment and business failures, and declining investment. Facing up to the colossal failure of its experiment with subsidized corporate profits and suspension of the basic rules of economics, Congress responded so rationally and so responsively this year that one could almost forget it was the same deliberative body that enacted the 1981 bill. **********The first task was to reduce the Government's fiscal imbalance without disturbing whatever fragile recovery we may be on the edge of. Here, the 1982 tax act was finely crafted. Far from raising taxes during recession, as some have charged, the bill only nicks at next year's scheduled tax reductions, adding a mere $18 billion -or less than 3 percent - to expected fiscal year 1983 receipts. In fiscal year 1987, however, the act is expected to raise some $64 billion - cutting the deficit by about one-third. **********AT the same time, the 1982 act creates substantial new incentives for more productive, higher-quality business investment by cutting back on the worst excesses of last year's corporate tax changes. To be sure, most earnings from new equipment will remain slightly subsidized, or, at best, tax-exempt. But this is clearly an improvement over the huge tax rebates - ranging as high as 194 percent of pretax profits for some investments -instituted by the 1981 bill. **********The efficiency of market incentives will be further enhanced by provisions narrowing or closing loopholes under which particular industries - such as insurance, defense contractors, drug companies and oil - had been freeloading on the tax system and the economy for years. **********Business leaders can complain that the 1982 act is a wage-earner's bill -and to a large degree that's right. The overwhelming bulk of the tax increases will come at the expense of corporate freeloaders and tax cheats - a far cry from the individual income tax increases advocated by big business or the consumer energy taxes unsuccessfully floated by the Administration. But the 1982 act is good for business, too. **********The decline in interest rates that paralleled progress on and passage of the 1982 bill may be mere coincidence, but it probably isn't. A return toward reliance on the marketplace to govern investment decisions is far more consistent with business' avowed economic philosophy - and it makes far more sense - than the complex web of tax subsidies enacted last year. **********Business should see the 1982 act not as a defeat but as an opportunity - a chance for companies to start kicking the loophole habit and become productive, tax-paying members of society once again. If business leaders can finally face up to the pain of withdrawal and admit they can't win while everyone else is losing, the new tax bill will be an important first step on the rehabilitation process toward a fairer, more rational tax system and a healthier economy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/22/world.print_headline: NEW PROTEST MADE BY POLES IN CRISIS; Text of petition, page A10.
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/22/world.body_text: **********A sharply worded petition against martial law and its repressions, signed by more than a hundred intellectuals and artists, was sent today to Parliament and to Archbishop Jozef Glemp, the Roman Catholic Primate. **********The petition, which includes an appeal to the Human Rights Commission of the United Nations, is the strongest written protest to date against the Dec. 13 military takeover in Poland. **********The new petition demands the lifting of martial law, the release of thousands who have been detained, an end to ''repressions'' against Solidarity union members, and the resumption of a dialogue with the the church and the union's ''legally elected authorities.'' **********''The methods used to intimidate and enslave societ y cause our indignation a nd protest,'' the petition said. ''We protest against the brutal br eaking of workers' strikes by the police and army, the shooting of p eople, beatings, the internment of many thousands of people in pri sons and camps. **********''We protest against the breaking up of families, the separating of children from their parents, the imprisonment of the sick and of minors. **********''We deem disgraceful and illegal the practice of breaking human dignity by forcing people to sign so-called declarations of loyalty, using various kinds of pressure and blackmail and dismissing from work those who refuse to sign.'' **********The petition began by citing a principle of international agreements - that all nations have the right to self-determination and to freely develop their own political, economic, social and cultural lives. This principle, it said, lay at the basis of the ''renewal'' that began with the creation of the Solidarity union in August 1980, and it was therefore violated in the military takeover. **********The petition ended with the observation that, except for the German occupation in World War II and the Stalinist postwar period into the middle 1950's, never has there been so many overcrowded prisons and camps on Polish soil as now. **********''Whoever until now has tried to enslave our nation has met with resistance and anger,'' the petition said. ''We remind those who introduced the state of war of this.'' **********''State of war'' is the constitutional provision under which martial law was declared.  Sources involved in circulating the petition said that it was sent to Parliament instead of the ruling Military Council of National Salvation because the signers did not regard the council as a legally constituted authority. Andrzej Wajda Joined Petition **********Among the original 101 signers were artists and scholars such as Tadeusz Konwicki, novelist; Julian Stryjkowski, author; Daniel Olbrychski, actor; Feliks Falk, director; Krzysztof Kieslowski, film director; Edward Lipinski, economist; Marek Nowakowski, writer; Waldemar Swierzy, graphic artist; Stefania Woytowicz, singer, and Edward Zebrowski, director. **********The petition, which is reportedly still being circulated, is reported to have gained new adherents. Among them is said to be Andrzej Wajda, the film director. Mr. Wajda, who had been politically active in Solidarity and became something of an unofficial spokesman for the union's cultural members, dropped his activities under martial law and spent much of his time at home. His decision to sign the petition is said to have been an agonizing one. **********The demands in the petition, for releasing detainees, ending martial law and holding a dialogue with the union, are similar to those made in the West and also by the church. **********The Polish Conference of Bishops, which met two days ago, drafted messages to both Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, and to the Polish people. The second message, which is to be read from pulpits on Sunday, contains an attack on the limitations on freedom under martial law and a forceful appeal for e nding it. **********General Jaruzelski is scheduled to address Parliament on the situation next Monday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/06/busin.main_headline: Business and the Law; Insurance For Past Risks
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/06/busin.print_headline: Business and the Law; Insurance For Past Risks
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/06/busin.body_text: **********POPULAR wisdom aside, there are times when it does make sense to lock the barn door after the horse is gone. Take the case of a motor oil manufacturer whose product, instead of protecting engines, damages them. The harm is already done, and the manufacturer is faced with a lot of $800 to $1,200 claims. But with a little luck, he can still buy an insurance policy to cover the claims - even though the damage has already occurred. **********Such a policy is called retroactive insurance; the most prominent example involved the MGM Grand Hotel fire in Las Vegas, Nev. When the blaze that killed 85 people broke out 18 months ago, the hotel only had $30 million of insurance. Faced with more than a billion dollars of claims, the hotel managed to buy an additional $170 million of backdated coverage. **********Although the tax consequences of so-called retro insurance are unclear, and some critics say such insurance interferes with prompt resolution of legal claims, similar policies have caught on with a variety of purchasers. Some of them are trying to obtain after-thefact protection for a particular mishap. But others, including a growing number of lawyers and doctors, are now buying retro insurance to cover periods during which they know of no unusual claims against them. **********''Some years ago there was a shortage of capacity, and many people found the insurance they wanted was unavailable,'' said William Quinn of Frank B. Hall & Company, which brokered the MGM Grand coverage.  ''Now there's a soft insurance market, and they are going back and trying to cover the gaps.'' **********Retro insurance can serve other purposes, too. For the electrical contractor who wired the MGM Grand Hotel, $40 million of backdated coverage cleared the way for the company to be bought by an acquirer who did not want to take on a dangling contingent liability that would not be resolved until the lawsuits arising from the fire went to trial. **********According to Paul Ingrey, president of Gibraltar Casualty, the MGM Grand situation prompted interest in retro insurance in some unusual subsequent cases. There was an individual inquiry, he said, from the owner of a boat that crashed and a corporate request from the General Dynamics Corporation to cover cost overruns. Neither of those received Gibraltar coverage, he said. **********Asbestos manufacturers, too, have shown interest in retro insurance, although Mr. Ingrey said no insurer had yet been willing to take them on. **********''The kind of case where I can see this having a real public policy use would be in something like the hospital industry,'' Mr. Ingrey said. ''Ten years ago, a 500-bed hospital might only have bought $5 million of insurance. Today, they'd probably look to buy $20 million, and they might want that much for the whole period in the 70's, too.  It's to everyone's advantage for the hospital to be properly insured. The patients know the money is there, and the hospital can manage its risks better.'' **********There is a tax advantage to retro insurance, too. Normally, MGM Grand would have had to wait until it actually paid the disaster victims before it could deduct the cost of their claims. **********But insurance premiums are deductible in the year they are paid.  Retroactive insurance premiums are more valuable as deductions than normal premiums because they are larger. How much larger depends on how likely the insurer thinks it is that he will have to pay a claim. According to a lawyer for MGM Grand, for example, the hotel will deduct the full $37 million of premiums paid for its $170 million retro coverage. **********It is here that the legal problems begin. Robert Hunter, president of the National Insurance Consumer Organization, a consumer activist group in Alexandria, Va., said retro insurance premiums were not really insurance and should not be deductible.''You can't insure a person who's already dead,'' Mr. Hunter said. **********Earlier this year, the Internal Revenue Service said it was considering issuing a revenue ruling on how retro insurance should be treated. **********Mr. Hunter raises other problems. Because the insurance companies make their profit on retro insurance by investing the premium money at high interest rates until the claim is paid, he said, there is a strong incentive for them to delay payment, or refuse settlement offers in order to get the use of the money for a longer time. **********''There is an element of truth to that,'' Mr. Ingrey conceded.  ''But insurance companies don't generally control court or settlement schedules.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/04/world.body_text: **********Israeli television broadcast an interview today with a man who identified himself as a Lebanese Christian militia commander and who said that he killed 15 Palestinians in the Beirut refugee camps during the massacre last month. **********''I was in Shatila and Sabra and I killed Palestinians,'' the man was quoted off camera as saying. **********''I killed only 15 Palestinians in the camps, but I will continue to kill them all my life.'' **********The broadcast said the man, who called himself Michael, refused to repeat the statement on camera.  The television report described the man as a 24-year-old engineering graduate. He spoke in French during the interview at an Israeli television studio in East Beirut. **********''I don't believe it was a massacre,'' Michael said on camera, ''because this is a war and in a war on a frontier it is not a massacre if people are killed.'' **********The number of dead, he said, was ''but 200 or 300, so it is much ado about nothing.'' When reminded that women, old people and children were killed, Michael said: ''There are Palestinian children of 8 years old who make war. You can't say a person who is 8 and who shoots at you is a child.'' **********On the question of whether Israel could have prevented the massacre, as many people have charged, he said: ''The Israeli Army could not prevent what happened in Sabra and Shatila because it would have happened whether or not it was there. The Lebanese have been fighting the Palestinians for eight years, and it is not Israel which is now going to prevent it.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/22/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; RATES STABLE IN QUIET TRADING
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/22/busin.body_text: **********Interest rates were little changed to slightly lower in quiet trading yesterday. Securities dealers said investors seemed to be taking a breather after the heavy buying in August and earlier this month. **********Although yields now available on notes and bonds are at their lowest levels since 1980, many dealers and economists are optimistic that short-term interest rates will decline further, thereby encouraging investors to shift funds from short-term securities to higher-yielding notes and bonds. **********The return on money market instruments such as commercial paper and large certificates of deposit are now slightly below 9 percent, compared with yields of up to 11 1/8 percent on Treasury notes due in 10 years and still higher yields on corporate issues. Yesterday, for example, $100 million of American Express Credit Corporation 11 5/8 percent notes due in 1992 were offered by Shearson/ American Express at 99.439 to yield 11.72 percent. **********''Interest rates will probably decline for another six months and then stay unchanged or rise only slowly,'' said Peter Treadway, chief economist at Cralin & Company. He estimated that if the economy showed steady growth over the next two years, prices would rise a modest 5 percent to 7 percent a year. Comment on Fed Policy **********Mr. Treadway said the recent decision by the Federal Reserve ''to promote the decline in interest rates and thus insure that the U.S.  and world economies would recover'' did not necessarily mean that the Fed would expand the nation's money supply at such a rapid rate that it fueled inflation. Inflation will be guided by nonmonetary events such as the course of Federal spending and world oil prices, he said. ''Investors are probably better off not assuming that inflation has been permanently derailed,'' he added. **********In yesterday's trading, prices of Treasury notes fluctuated narrowly, closing with gains of about a quarter-point. Bonds were mostly unchanged. **********The new 9 3/4 percent notes due in two years rose to an offered price of 100 from the average of slightly over 99 29/32 at Wednesday's auction. Among longer-term issues, the 13 3/4 percent notes due in 1992 were offered at 115 1/4 to yield 11.12 percent, and the 14 percent bonds due in 2011 were offered at 127 1/8 to yield 10.82 percent. **********Analysts at Merrill Lynch Government Securities Inc. said in a daily market comment that price increases in the near term might depend on how fast overnight interest rates declined and whether the Fed announced another cut in the discount rate. ''The lack of a cut in the discount rate today or over the next few days will be disappointing for the markets and could cause a meaningful price correction,'' the analysts said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/31/world.body_text: **********Kuwait has become the first Arab nation on the Persian Gulf to permit abortion.  The all-male Parliament approved the measure Tuesday night while Kuwaiti women marched outside demanding the right to vote.  It permits abortions if the pregnancy would result in ''gross physical harm'' to the woman or if the fetus has brain damage ''beyond hope of treatment.'' **********The abortion must be approved by a gynecologist and two other physicians except in emergency cases, and the operation must be performed in a Government hospital. **********The vote was 27 to 3 with 9 abstentions and 11 members absent.  As the measure was passed, women pressed their protest to Parliament's rejection, 27 to 3, the previous week of a bill to grant women the right to vote. **********The suffrage bill was reported out of committee with a recommendation that ''time is inopportune for receiving the idea in the light of well-established traditions.'' **********Only 42,000 Kuwaiti men who can trace their ancestry in Kuwait to 1920 or earlier are eligible to vote. Kuwaitis make up only 41 percent of the country's 1.3 million residents. Demonstrations Are Threatened **********Women are threatening to stage demonstrations reminiscent of those held five years ago against a bill that would have denied women the right to take office jobs. The bill was dropped. **********In addition, they are sending delegations to Members of Parliament who voted against women's suffrage or abstained in the debate.  ''We hereby register our protest and reject ion of Parliament's voting down of the bill granting women the ri ght to vote in general elections,'' the Kuwait Women Social and Educ ational Society said in a telegram to the Speaker of Parliament, Moha mmed Yousuf Aradasani.  ''The outcome of the voting runs counter to t he role of Kuwaiti womenand the high standards they have achieved.'' **********Kuwait is more progressive than neighboring countries such as Saudi Arabia, where women are forbidden to dine alone in a restaurant, work in most offices or drive a car. Many Kuwaiti women study abroad, and women hold key posts in the Ministries of Education, Foreign Affairs, Health and Social Affairs. A Promise but No Action **********Dating as it is known in the West, however, is forbidden in Kuwait and marriages are arranged. Women are educated separately and receive separate treatment in hospitals. **********A year ago the Prime Minister and Crown Prince, Sheik Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah, promised that women would be allowed to vote in elections to Parliament but would not be allowed to run for office. **********No action was taken, however, and Parliament was elected last Feb.  23 without the participation of women.  Badriya al-Awadhi, dean of women at Kuwait University Law School, said at the time that it was schizophrenic to allow women to hold high executive positions but deny them the right to vote and to run for Parliament. **********''We will fight on,'' she declared. ''We will set a precedent for all Gulf women. Allah willing, the future is ours.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/23/busin.body_text: **********New orders for factories' durable goods increased 1.4 percent in May, partly recovering from April's steep decline, the Commerce Department reported today. **********The May increase included gains of 5.5 percent in orders for automobiles and other transportation equipment and 4.4 percent for household goods such as furniture and appliances, according to the report. **********''It's another installment in the flow of good reports for May,'' said Robert Ortner, the Commerce Department's chief economist.  Earlier Government reports had indicated that retail sales, personal income and housing starts all rose substantially in May. **********But a crucial category that reflects business spending, nondefense capital goods, fell 4.7 percent.  Manufacturers shipped $2.7 billion more in goods than they received in new orders, a 3 percent increase from the previous month. As a result, some of the manufacturing momentum was lost as the order backlog slipped eight-tenths of 1 percent, to a value of $305.6 billion, the department said. **********The small and volatile category of defense capital goods orders declined by 10.2 percent, the report said, pulling down the overall measure from what otherwise would have been a 2.4 percent increase.  It was the third substantial decline in a row. However, most analysts expect that category to rise strongly again before long, in line with President Reagan's plans to increase military spending. **********Orders for primary metals rose 3.7 percent, the second consecutive monthly gain after eight straight declines. May Value at $78.7 Billion **********The increase in durable goods orders brought their value in May to $78.7 billion. April had produced a major setback, a decline of a revised 3.6 percent. In March orders rose 1.6 percent. **********Durable goods orders are closely watched by economists since they are the fuel for business activity in the immediate future. Since the relatively expensive items usually require financing, the orders level is also an indicator of how willing consumers are to spend. And factory employment levels are also closely linked to the orders rate. **********Durable goods account for about half of the value of all manufactured products. Heavier Decline Forecast **********The decline in business spending was at a somewhat heavier pace than was indicated by the Commerce Department's latest survey on such spending, according to Michael Evans of Evans Economics. ''It's one more indication that businesses are cutting their capital spending very sharply for the rest of the year,'' he said. **********The survey indicated a 2.5 percent decline this year, but Mr.  Evans predicted a drop of about 5 percent.  All of the figures were adjusted for normal seasonal variations.  The April decline of 3.6 percent in overall orders was a revision of the 3.9 percent drop first reported, and the new May figures are also subject to later revision when more complete information becomes available.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/30/busin.body_text: **********Robert B. Claytor, 60 years old, has been named chairman and chief executive officer of the new Norfolk Southern Corporation, a combination of two of the country's most profitable railroads, The railroads, which will merge June 1, are the Southern Railway and the Norfolk & Western Railway: Together they link some 17,500 miles of track. **********Mr. Claytor has been president and chief executive officer of the N.& W. Harold H. Hall, the 55-year-old president of Southern, will become president and chief operating officer of Norfolk Southern, which will have its headquarters at the Roanoke, Va., offices of Norfolk & Western. The merger of the two railway systems was approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission March 25. **********Mr. Claytor's appointment yesterday to head the merged companies - which last year had combined revenues of $3.6 billion - seems to follow from a comment he made last September when he was given the added duties of chief executive at N.& W. At that time, he observed that he was concentrating on the consolidation of the two railroads, adding: ''If it works out that way, I may well work my way out of a job before my first stockholder's meeting.'' **********A close associate of Mr. Claytor in Roanoke, who asked not to be identified, yesterday said that Mr. Claytor, a lawyer by training, had developed ''a good grip'' on the railroad business. A graduate of Princeton University and Harvard Law School, Mr. Claytor started his career at the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in 1948 and joined N.& W. as a solicitor in 1951. He became senior vice president in 1968, an executive vice president in 1971 and president in 1980. **********Mr. Hall, on the other hand, is a longtime railroad man, having started with the Southern in 1943 as an agent-telegrapher. He rose through a variety of jobs, became executive vice president for operations and then president in 1979. **********Norfolk Southern also yesterday named successors at both railways, which will operate separately, and selected four executive vice presidents and thirteen vice presidents. **********Although each railway had revenues of $1.8 billion last year, Norfolk Southern will have to grapple with a recession that has cut sharply into railroad shipments, which have only partly been offset by increased hauling of coal.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/21/busin.main_headline: Talking Business with Zvi Porath of Elscint; CAT Scanner's New Rival
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/21/busin.print_headline: Talking Business with Zvi Porath of Elscint; CAT Scanner's New Rival
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/21/busin.body_text: **********In advanced medical diagnostics, a new generation of technology is competing with the CAT scanner, which has revolutionized medical imaging. Nuclear magnetic resonance, or N.M.R., systems, producing pictures of the body based on the responses of atomic nuclei in a magnetic field, are considered by some experts to be safer and more effective than the CAT scanner. A half-dozen companies worldwide produce one or two of the systems. But only Elscint Ltd., an Israelbased company whose stock is traded on this country's over-thecounter exchange, derives almost all of its revenues from three imaging systems. **********Zvi Porath, Elscint's chief economist, had been a consultant to the World Bank and his country's representative to the board of the International Monetary Fund. Here the 41-year-old executive discusses his company's prospects. **********Q. How can a small company in a small country compete with the world's technology giants? A. Our management believes that 75 percent of success is being in the right field and only 25 percent is hard work. Among the world's technology giants, imaging is only about 4 or 5 percent of sales. It is our total business so that survival depends upon excelling in our specialty. Those with the highest market share pay enormously for medical market education. We don't want the largest market share. The market is big enough for giants and small companies. **********Q. Will the new N.M.R. system hurt the CAT scanner's sales? A. The excitement about the nuclear magnetic resonance potential has created some confusion in the marketplace over both the scientific and commercial aspects. It will probably have a marginal, short-term impact on CAT scanner purchase decisions. But the market for the CAT scanner is too large and viable to be seriously set back in the next two to three years. The N.M.R.'s cost is about twice that of the CAT scanner and requires a special site in the hospital. We are showing our N.M.R. prototype system and booking orders for delivery in mid-1983. We see parallel markets. **********Q. What is Elscint's main thrust? A. It is not so much our products as our strategic planning. Since Elscint was founded in 1969 by Dr. Avraham Suhami, our management has concentrated only on the medical imaging field, building expertise in different technologies, all of which have a synergistic effect, while developing the company into a multinational concern. **********This has resulted in the introduction of CAT scanners, nuclear medicine, ultrasound, digital radiography and most recently nuclear magnetic resonance systems. We have had some failures. But through managerial depth, the addition of many skilled scientists and perhaps above all a pure stubborn streak, we have survived. We don't like to operate on the edge of disaster but we have come to enjoy working under pressure. **********Q. But aren't you taking risks by growing fast? A. Scientific companies always take high risks. The question is whether they have the hard-headed ability to generate the expertise to minimize failure. Last May, we decided to spend about $60 million on R.& D.  over the next three years to maintain our international posture. An infant company has to show products before it gets orders. A mature company shows its specifications to the market. When it gets the order, it means that its credibility has been accepted. It took us less than five years to advance from one stage to the other. Managing R.& D. money productively and building market infrastructure in Israel and 15 foreign countries will help us minimize our risks. **********Q. What is your company's growth outlook? A. The market today is over $2.5 billion a year but it is projected by 1986-1987 to rise to more than $5 billion a year. Our goal is to obtain 10 percent of this world market and we expect to be there by next year. **********One of our most ambitious efforts was our first full display of all of our medical diagnostic systems at last week's annual convention of Radiological Society of North America in Chicago. The medical imaging field is continuously growing, whether in war, peace or economic difficulties, and we expect to grow with it. Isadore Barmash

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/11/world.print_headline: 4 DEMOCRATS URGE U.S. TO SEEK A TRUCE IN SALVADOR
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/11/world.body_text: **********Four Democratic members of Congress introduced a resolution today calling on the Reagan Administration to seek an internationally supervised cease-fire in El Salvador and negotiations leading to a political solution to the civil war there. **********Senators Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut and Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, and Representatives Michael D. Barnes of Maryland and Stephen J. Solarz of Brooklyn, all considered liberals, said at a news conference this morning that they believed that they could win bipartisan support for their nonbinding resolution. **********They added that if the Administration failed to heed the sentiments of the opposition in Congress they would seek legislation blocking further American assistance to the civilian-military junta led by Jose Napoleon Duarte. But the prospects of such legislative moves in a generally conservative Congress are not seen as bright. **********Vietnam Parallel Is Drawn **********''The situation in El Salvador is all too reminiscent for many of us of a decade and a half ago,'' Senator Dodd, a member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said this morning. ''Because we failed to properly debate the issue before we became too deeply involved and enmeshed and mired in Vietnam, we found ourselves in an extremely difficult situation.'' **********The Reagan Administration has consistently rejected the idea of negotiations with the armed Salvadoran opposition, saying this would be tantamount to handing the country over to leftists who would create an undemocratic government. **********Thomas O. Enders, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, has said several times in hearings over the last two weeks that the example of Nicaragua taught the Administration that however broadly based the opposition might appear to be, once in power, it would drift leftward toward a totalitarian system. **********Putting its hopes on an election for a constituent assembly in El Salvador scheduled for March 28, the Administration has begun sending, under a Presidential order that does not require Congressional approval, $55 million in emergency military equipment and other supplies to the Salvadoran Government. Mr. Enders has said that more military and economic assistance will be requested from Congress. Certification on Rights **********At the end of last month, the White House concluded that El Salvador had made adequate progress in reducing human rights violations and political violence to allow continued United States assistance to that nation. The cer tification requirement was attachedto foreign aid legislation late last year. **********The White House certification has provoked widespread criticism of the Administration's support of the Salvadoran Government.  On Tuesday, the head of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops repeated his opposition to continued support for military aid to El Salvador voiced at the time of the White House certification decision. **********Archbishop John R. Roach of Minneapolis-St. Paul, who is president of the conference, said nothing occurred in the last year in El Salvador to change the view of many Roman Catholic bishops that ''internal issues of social justice and human rights are the principal questions in El Salvador.'' Rights Group Disputes Reagan **********Amnesty International's United States office sent a telegram to President Rea gan on Tuesday taking issue with the White House findings that led to certification. In the telegram, the organization, which monitors cases of political prisoners and rights violations ar ound the world, said that President Reagan's contention that the situ ation had improved and that the junta had increased its control over the armed forces was ''not consistent with Amnesty International information.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/04/busin.body_text: **********The Big Three auto manufacturers reported today that sales rose 10.5 percent in the final 10 days of May, mostly as a result of a strong showing by General Motors. **********The General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation had also reported higher sales in the May 1-10 and May 11-20 selling periods, compared with the similar periods last year. As a result, their sales increased 14.9 percent for the full month, the first such gain since last September. **********''Industry figures are beginning to appear like they did in the laborious recovery of 1975, although June sales will have to confirm that,'' said Arvid Jouppi, a Detroit-based auto analyst with Collin Hochstin, a securities firm. He said that sales have been helped by consumers who are starting to replace aging cars. **********Nevertheless, the Big Three's sales of 569,605 cars in May, up from 495,898 in May 1981, is still far short of the domestic industry's goal of selling 8 million cars or more this year. Annual Selling Rate Rises **********The annual selling rate for the Big Three and the two other domestic auto makers, Volkswagen of America and the American Motors Corporation, was 6.5 million cars in May, up from less than 6 million in most other months this year. In May 1981, the annual selling rate was 5.9 million. **********Harvey Heinbach, auto analyst at Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc., said he expected June sales to be flat or only slightly higher than June 1981, primarily because G.M. ended its program of offering 12.8 percent auto financing on May 31. He said that program had made industry sales stronger than anticipated in May. **********''I think G.M. will want to see what the market looks like without any incentives'' before considering a new program, Mr. Heinbach said.  For the May 21-30 period, G.M. reported a sales increase of 15.2 percent from the comparable period last year. Sales by Chrysler rose 5.7 percent, and Ford reported a gain of only five-tenths of 1 percent. **********General Motors sold 136,006 new cars in the late May period, compared with 118,090 a year earlier. The nation's leading auto maker took 64.7 percent of the domestic market, up from 59.8 percent last year. **********Chrysler sold 24,210 cars, up from 22,903 sold in late May last year. Chrysler held 11.5 percent of the market, almost even with the 11.6 percent share last year. **********Ford sold 44,191 cars, up from 43,986 last year. Ford claimed 21 percent of the market, down from 22.3 percent last year.  There were eight selling days in the period both this year and last. For all of May, there were 25 selling days this year and last.  In May, General Motors sold 384,015 cars, up 22 percent from a year ago, when 314,764 cars were sold. G.M. took 65.8 percent of the market during the month, up from 60.1 percent last May. Chrysler Gained in May **********Chrysler's sales in May rose 4.8 percent, to 61,603, from 58,791.  Chrysler held 10.5 percent of the market, down from an 11.2 percent share last year. **********Ford sold 123,987 cars in May, a 1.3 percent rise from 122,343 last year. Ford's market share fell to 21.2 percent from 23.3 percent.  American Motors sold 8,170 cars in May, down 40.1 percent from a year ago, when 13,648 cars were sold. A.M.C. claimed 1.4 percent of the market, down from 2.6 percent. **********Volkswagen of America's sales fell 56.5 percent in May on sales of 6,299 compared with 14,475 a year ago.  Thus far this year, domestic auto makers have sold 2,483,394 cars, down 11 percent from the comparable figure of 2,790,214 in 1981.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/05/busin.body_text: **********Dr. Arthur H. Hays Jr., commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, said today that drug patents should be extended to reflect the seven years companies usually lose during reviews by his agency. **********The commissioner added that companies generally needed 12 to 19 years of monopoly sales to earn a reasonable profit on the $54 million to $70 million that is typically involved in the research and development of each drug introduced. **********He was testifying before a House subcommittee on legislation that would extend any product's patent life by the time lost, up to seven years, in any Federal review process. While broadly written, the legislation would primarily benefit the pharmaceutical and agricultural chemical industry. **********No one at the hearing disagreed with Dr. Hays's assessment of the regulatory process, but some witnesses contended that extending patent duration would only spur drug makers' profits, not necessarily the research and development of more innovative pharmaceutical products.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/15/busin.body_text: **********The Mexican Government, modifying existing restrictions, announced Monday night that foreign investors in Mexico would be allowed to repatriate profits and royalties under its new system of exchange controls. **********The Government also confirmed that Mexican concerns would have access to foreign currency at a ''preferential'' rate of 50 pesos to the dollar to pay interest and principal on foreign debts acquired before exchange controls were announced Sept.1. **********Although dollars for repatriation will have to be bought at the ''ordinary'' rate of 70 pesos, the announcements nevertheless brought some relief both to foreign investors who have a $10.5 billion stake here and to foreign bankers who are owed some $20 billion by the Mexican companies. **********The new rules as of next Tuesday will govern imports, exports, capital transfers, tourist activities and all other exchange operations. **********The preferential rate will be available first for payments on the public sector's $60 billion foreign debt, followed by that of the newly nationalized banking system. The next priority will be vital imports and last comes the servicing of the private sector's foreign debt. **********The Government also has top priority in gaining access to dollars at the ordinary rate, followed by the country's banks and border operations, and, last, royalty and profit remittances by foreign investors. **********Mexico also eased its $250 limit on dollars available to Mexicans traveling abroad, allowing up to $6,000 for those requiring medical attention outside the country, $3,000 for those on business trips, up to $10,000 for those studying abroad and $1,500 for all other travelers, all over one year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/22/busin.body_text: **********The Inland Steel Company reported today that it lost $23.2 million in the second quarter of 1982, in contrast to a $29.5 million profit in 1981's second quarter. Sales fell 29 percent, to $743.6 million. **********The company, which suffered its third straight quarterly loss, said a turnaround in its steel product market was ''still not in view.'' Shipments dropped 34 percent, to 1.08 million tons, the lowest of any quarter since 1971. **********Inland said that its steelmaking facilities operated at 60 percent of capacity and lost money but that other segments of its business were profitable. **********Inland also said that cost containment efforts taken at the end of the first quarter helped it to improve its liquidity as secondquarter cash and marketable securities increased to $48 million from $35 million in the 1982 first quarter.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/08/busin.body_text: **********The Ford Motor Company introduced a twopassenger car that burns natural gas and can be refueled at home.  There are no plans to produce the car. **********The car, called AFV, for alternative-fuel vehicle, will be on display at the Detroit Auto Show later this month and, if built, would be ''slightly more expensive'' to buy than conventional gasoline-powered cars, Ford officials said. **********However, the relatively lower cost of natural gas would make the AFV substantially cheaper to operate, Thomas J. Feaheny, Ford vice president for vehicle research, told reporters during a news conference at the automaker's Design Center in suburban Dearborn. **********Mr. Feaheny said that natural gas is equivalent in cost to gasoline at 90 cents a gallon. ''We estimate that even with decontrol of methane prices by 1990, methane would be 15 percent to 20 percent less expensive than gasoline,'' he said. **********With a special compressor unit, car owners would be able to refuel the car at home, eliminating the need for regular trips to a service station.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/26/busin.body_text: **********The Data General Corporation announced that it would close all seven of its United States plants for nine days in July to trim increased inventories caused by falling sales. **********It is the first production shutdown in the company's 14-year history.  The company said the shutdown from July 6 to July 16 will affect 4,000 production and staff workers at plants in Westbrook, Me.; Portsmouth, N.H.; Southboro, Mass.; Clayton and Apex, N.C.; Austin, Tex., and Sunnyvale, Calif. **********The company said it was taking the action ''to adjust manufacturing output and inventories to market demand.'' Separately, Scientific-Atlanta Inc. said it had indefinitely laid off 260 employees in its Atlanta work force, principally in its communciations products group.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/02/busin.body_text: **********Inside Sports magazine, which was just beginning to see light at the ends of both advertising and circulation tunnels, has suspended publication. Valerie Salembier, who holds the publisher's post, yesterday attributed the magazine's difficulties to ''no cash and not enough investors.'' **********Publishing the magazine since last January has been Active Markets of Seattle, which has also suspended publication of its Sports and Athletes magazine for schoolkids. It bought Inside Sports from the Washington Post Company, which began the magazine in the spring of 1979 as a sister publication to Newsweek. **********Editor John Walsh said he was cautiously optimistic. He said he was going to talk to a prospective buyer today and added that he hoped the December issue would be printed, although ''it seems a little remote.'' The December issue was scheduled to carry 42 pages of advertising, the most the magazine had run with its new owners. Its circulation rate base was 510,000 but it was actually selling an average 535,000 copies per issue. That meant a bonus for advertisers. **********About half of the magazine's 40 employees sat inside a Manhattan bank for nearly five hours when the bank refused to cash their severance checks, waiting until funds were wired from an Active Markets bank account in Seattle.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/22/busin.body_text: **********The Dow Chemical Company yesterday reported a 4.2 percent rise in second-quarter net income, but said sales dropped 11.1 percent. The earnings rise was attributed to a gain from the dissolution of a partnership with the Asahi Chemical Company of Japan. **********Dow, which is the nation's second-largest chemical producer after Du Pont, said that net income in the quarter advanced to $197 million, or $1.02 a share, from $189 million, or $1 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Sales fell to $2.73 billion from $3.07 billion. **********Leonard Bogner, chemical industry analyst at Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc., said, ''Second-quarter results were slightly below what we had estimated, which was 50 cents a share.'' **********Dow's gain from the termination of the venture with Asahi totaled about $120 million, or 62 cents a share. Dow's operating earnings for the period contributed about 40 cents a share, compared with $1 a share last year, or a decline of 60 percent. Dow received $162 million from the Ashai deal, which it used to help reduce short-term debt. **********The analyst said, ''The major factors behind the reduced earnings include the global recession, which has impacted both volume and price, the strength of the United States dollar abroad, and the decline in drilling-rig activity in the United States.'' **********For the first six months, earnings fell 4.9 percent, to $351 million, or $1.82 a share, from $369 million, or $1.98 a share, in the first six months of 1981. **********''We expect significant gains as soon as demand picks up and our operating rates improve,'' said Robert M. Keil, executive vice president and chief financial officer of Dow. Colgate-Palmolive **********The Colgate-Palmolive Company said net income in the second quarter remained flat at $55.9 million, or 68 cents a share, while sales slipped 3.8 percent from the 1981 period, to $1.25 billion from $1.3 billion. **********''We have been able to maintain our second-quarter profit levels primarily through higher investment income, as a result of our improved utilization of capital resources and cost-containment programs,'' said Keith Crane, chairman. **********Colgate, a producer of consumer and health-care products, said that for the first six months of this year, earnings rose seven-tenths of 1 percent, to $109.8 million, or $1.34 a share, from $109 million, or $1.33 a share, in the first six months of 1981.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/23/busin.body_text: **********A Federal administrative law judge has found the International Harvester Company guilty of deceptive and unfair practices because it did not tell owners of its gasolinepowered tractors of a fire hazard, the Federal Trade Commission announced today. **********However, the F.T.C. judge, John J. Mathias, did not issue an order to the company or assess a fine because International Harvester ''has now made adequate disclosure'' of the hazard. **********The company said it would withhold comment on today's action pending a review of the F.T.C. opinion.  The ruling grew out of a 1980 complaint that International Harvester failed to disclose that the machines, which have a gasoline tank in front of the operator, were subject to so-called geysering - the eruption of heated fuel from an improperly sealed tank, which could then ignite. **********According to the complaint, there have been 90 such incidents reported since the 1950's, including one that resulted in a death.  According to the F.T.C., the tractors involved were manufactured between 1939 and 1978. It said an estimated 400,000 of the machines are in use.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/11/busin.body_text: **********AN automatic telephone device invented at Bell Telephone Laboratories, Murray Hill, N.J., enables callers to reach their parties by speech instead of finger movements: It is necessary only to pronounce names or numbers. The spoken-word ''dialer,'' which is not in production, can replace rotary or push-button devices. **********Patent 4,348,550 on the system was granted this week to Frank C.  Pirz, Lawrence R. Rabiner, Aaron E. Rosenberg and Jay G. Wilpon, staff scientists at Bell Labs. **********The caller is actuated by 7 command words, 10 digits and as many as 20 names. A user can activate it by saying ''off hook,'' and give the name or number wanted. At the end of the conversation, the caller just says ''hang up.'' The listed names, telephone numbers and instructions can be changed by voice commands. Any accent or language may be used, as the instrument can be adjusted to accept the user's manner of speech. **********Bell Labs will consider applications for licenses under the patent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/23/busin.body_text: **********Braniff International, which had hoped to consummate a deal by this weekend to lease its South American air routes for urgently needed additional cash, said yesterday that ''we will do our best to continue to fly'' while negotiations continue. **********Meanwhile, Eastern Airlines officials said that carrier would make an offer for a major portion of the Braniff routes on Tuesday. Air Florida said it was studying figures that Braniff had put before its negotiators Wednesday. **********Pan American World Airways, whose bid for an immediate takeover of most of the routes under a four-year $30 million lease was blocked by the Civil Aeronautics Board, was said by company sources to be preparing an alternate proposal that the agency might find more palatable. **********The critical issue in the complex maneuverings was whether Braniff would be able to continue to absorb losses on its South American network long enough to work out an acceptable lease or sale. Decision Due Shortly **********Sam Coats, vice president for domestic and international affairs, indicated that a decision on whether to terminate the runs would have to be made in the next week or two. **********In a telephone interview from his office in Dallas, Mr. Coats said, however, that there was no immediate threat of bankruptcy for the airline as a whole since it has until Oct. 1 to try to restructure its debt. **********A spokesman said that some prospective passengers have been reluctant to make reservations with Braniff on the South American flights because of the continuing problems. **********It was on March 17 that Braniff and Pan Am announced their leasing agreement, with a request to the C.A.B. to give it prompt approval.  Last Friday, the C.A.B. rejected the request, although not ruling out eventual approval after board hearings. It has made clear that a prime reason for the rejection was concern that the lease would give Pan Am a virtual monopoly of American-flag service to the area, at least for the time being. The agency's policy has been to foster competition. **********Braniff's routes run primarily to the west coast of South America while Pan Am's concentrate on the east coast. The routes Braniff has sought to lease to Pan Am go to Bogota and Cali, Colombia; Quito, Ecuador; Lima, Peru; La Paz, Bolivia; Asuncion, Paraguay; Santiago, Chile; Buenos Aires, Argentina and Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/09/busin.main_headline: MASTERCARD CLEARED TO OFFER FINANCIAL SERVICES VIA BANKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/09/busin.print_headline: MASTERCARD CLEARED TO OFFER FINANCIAL SERVICES VIA BANKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/09/busin.body_text: **********Commercial and savings banks that are members of the Mastercard system will start next month to offer card holders discount brokerage services, money market funds and other investment services, Mastercard International and the Fidelity Financial Services Group announced yesterday. **********Under the plan, member banks and savings institutions will also offer their checking account customers various certificates of deposit, money market certificates and other bank-sponsored investment plans that will place them in direct competition with brokerage houses and bring the one-stop financial supermarket closer. **********''For the first time,'' said Russell E. Hogg, president and chief executive officer of Mastercard, ''investments in money market funds will be available to holders of checking accounts and Mastercard credit cards issued by commercial banks, savings banks and savings and loan institutions through a facility of Fidelity, which manages many leading securities and money market funds.'' **********The new range of banking services will be introduced in April by a cross section of the 12,500 American banks and thrift institutions that are members of Mastercard, Mr. Hogg said, and gradually be extended to all members ''once the pilot test program is proven satisfactory.'' **********Huge Withdrawals of Funds **********He went on to note that savings institutions, particularly the thrift units, have experienced huge withdrawals of funds in recent years because their customers have been investing in money market funds and related instruments. ''Meanwhile, brokerage houses have been moving into the banking field through mergers with financial services institutions and providing yet another rival for the saver's dollar,'' Mr. Hogg said. **********But wouldn't the Mastercard-Fidelity system also encourage the withdrawal of funds from the banking and savings institutions? Not quite, Mr. Hogg replied. Most members of the plan would set ''thresholds'' that would force customers to keep between, say, $2,000 and $2,500 in interest-free checking accounts. ''Anything above these thresholds would be automatically swept into a money market fund, much the same way as some brokerage houses do with idle money in the accounts of their securities customers,'' he explained. **********Perhaps the most dramatic part of the new system is that commercial banks and savings institutions, which are currently prevented from engaging in the securities brokerage business, will be able to offer their customers discount brokerage services. The Fidelity Financial Services Group would execute these orders for the member institutions in a manner similar to their regular buying and selling of stocks and bonds for the many mutual funds it manages. Some 52 million people have Mastercards through 24,000 banks and savings institutions worldwide. Visa Proposal Rejected **********Mr. Hogg added that the plan was approved by the Securities and Exchange Commission last Friday, while a similar proposal by Visa U.S.A., another major credit card association, was rejected the the S.E.C. that day. **********A spokesman for Visa, Richard Rossi, said the S.E.C. rejected his company's plan because the agency thought its member banks would channel the investment funds back to member banking institutions. Mr. Rossi also said last Friday that Visa planned to discuss the matter with the regulatory agency this week with a view to eliminating the objectionaable aspects. **********Mr. Hogg said the Mastercard plan was approved in part because the various investment funds placed by the customers of its member banks would be handled by Fidelity Financial Services, a separate and professional money management company that manages 25 mutual funds with assets of $14 billion. **********''It is conceivable that Fidelity could, for example, use some of the funds from a member bank to buy its certificates of deposit because it handles so much investment funds,'' he said, adding: ''But our new system is not intended to provide member banks with an inflow of investment funds from its customers; it is aimed at offering them competitive investment vehicles currently denied us.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/13/busin.main_headline: JAPAN'S G.N.P. OFF 0.9%, FIRST DECLINE SINCE 1975
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/13/busin.print_headline: JAPAN'S G.N.P. OFF 0.9%, FIRST DECLINE SINCE 1975
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/13/busin.body_text: **********With its exports slowing significantly, Japan's economy declined by slightly less than nine-tenths of 1 percent in the quarter that ended last December, the Government reported today. **********It was the first quarterly decline in nearly seven years, since the first quarter of 1975 during the first oil price shock, when economic activity declined about seven-tenths of 1 percent in the first quarter. **********The components of the gross national product are not reported here on an annualized basis. If they were, the drop in the fourth quarter would represent a 3.5 percent annual rate. The decline in the first quarter of 1975, if annualized, would represent a 2.9 percent annual rate. **********''Until the fourth quarter, real gross national product grew on the strength of our export performance,'' said Masaru Yoshitomi, chief economist of Japan's Economic Planning Agency. ''But in the fourth quarter, exports slowed down drastically.'' **********The fourth-quarter contraction will probably intensify the economic policy debate under way in Japan. In recent months, some Government officials and others have recommended that Japan adopt an expansionary fiscal policy to speed up the economy and increase imports, thus easing trade tensions and putting more money into the pockets of Japanese workers as well. Pressure for Stimulus **********''This does increase pressure for stimulus of the economy,'' Mr.  Yo@shitomi said. **********The Government of Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki has thus far resisted any stimulative measures. Last year, Mr. Suzuki said that he would stake his ''political life'' on his ability to trim the size of the public sector and balance the budget by 1984. Any Government measures to expand the economy would almost certainly increase the Government's deficit, which Mr. Suzuki has pledged to eliminate. **********Through most of last year, Japan seemed immune from the worldwide economic slowdown. The official Government forecast for the fiscal year ending March 31 calls for economic growth of 4.1 percent. **********But now an expansion of about 6 percent in the January-March quarter would be required to attain the growth level predicted by the Government. ''I think that is extremely difficult,'' Kiichi Miyazawa, the Government's Chief Cabinet Secretary, conceded today. Decline in Exports **********According to the economic planning agency's statistics, exports fell 4.5 percent during the last three months of 1981, compared with the previous quarter. However, there were some tentative signs of recovery in domestic demand and imports increased by 2.6 percent.  Private demand - which includes personal consumption and private capital formation - rose nine-tenths of 1 percent, after a decline of three-tenths of 1 percent in the quarter ending Sept. 30.
