https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/03/busin.body_text: **********The Seven-Up Company held a press conference yesterday to release the timely news that it had already started a new campaign positioning its popular soft drink in its war against the more popular colas as the drink that contains no caffeine. **********This is interesting in that in various markets Coca-Cola or Pepsi-Cola bottlers are also the Seven-Up bottlers. **********Seven-Up has heard that the 150 of its 464 bottlers who are also Pepsi bottlers have received a Mailgram warning against using any anti-caffiene advertising. Back in 1968, when the Un-Cola campaign was introduced, some of those bottlers walked out of the room. **********It is probably only a coincidence, but not hard on the egos of Al Ries and Jack Trout, chairman and president of Trout & Ries, but they were quoted in this column in January as suggesting that the Seven-Up strategy should be attacking caffine in colas. **********Another bit of history - slightly more ancient - Canada Dry, a subsidairy of Norton Simon, twice brought out 99 percent caffeinefree colas. In 1968 it was called Sport and in 1979 it was called Spur. Both were failures. Perhaps ahead of their time.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/29/world.body_text: **********KIDNAPPERS IN ZIMBABWE APPEAR PART OF GROUP THAT HAS KILLED 30 **********HARARE, Zimbabwe, July 28 (AP) - The gunmen holding six foreign tourists hostage in western Zimbabwe are believed to be among about 1,000 supporters of the opposition leader Joshua Nkomo who have slain at least 30 people, ambushed vehicles and attacked isolated farmhouses and stores. **********The authorities said today that the police and army troops had lost the trail of the kidnappers after villagers drove cattle across the trail. The villagers in the region have been accused of sheltering the kidnappers, but army officers said they could not be sure whether the cattle were used deliberately to obliterate the trail. **********The kidnappers have warned that they will kill their six hostages on Friday unless Zimbabwe releases detained aides and followers of Mr. Nkomo, an ousted Cabinet member. **********The hostages are Bruce Baldwin, 23 years old, a student, and Kevin Ellis, 22, a painter, both from Seattle; two Australians, Tony Bajzelj, 25, from Tasmania, and William Butler, 31, from Newcastle, and two Britons, James Greenwell, 18, a student from Liverpool, and Martyn Hodgson, 35, a civil engineer from Peterborough. Break Between 2 Leaders **********The band of about 12 men who seized the hostages on a main highway last Friday are officially labeled ''dissidents'' - the Government term for army deserters loyal to Mr. Nkomo. **********Mr. Nkomo and Robert Mugabe, now Prime Minister, were allied in the seven-year guerrilla war to end white rule in the former British colony of Rhodesia. They clashed often, however, even during the war, and in February Mr. Nkomo was accused of plotting a coup and was dismissed. **********Since then, anti-Government gangs of armed men have been waging a campaign of lawlessness. Most of it has been in the province of Matabeleland, the home of Mr. Nkomo's Matabele tribe. Prime Minister Mugabe is a, a member of the dominant Shona tribe, and hostility between the two tribes dates to the 19th century when the Matabeles, although in the minority, virtually enslaved the Shona tribe. **********Mr. Mugabe says the gunmen are bandits, and Mr. Nkomo disowns them. But diplomats and other foreign observers believe they are politically motivated. They say they are retaliating for Government actions that appear to be directed against the Matabeles and for Mr.  Nkomo's dismissal. **********''There's no profit motive in these abductions,'' one Western diplomat said, noting that the gunmen were demanding the release of nearly 200 supporters of Mr. Nkomo. ''This is a political act.'' **********Hundreds of Mr. Nkomo's former guerrillas who had joined the army have deserted with their arms. The Government blamed ''dissidents'' for an armed attack on Mr. Mugabe's official residence on June 24. **********They were also blamed for a holdup in the Victoria Falls Hotel, in northwest Matabeleland, last Saturday by three gunmen who killed a hotel employee. The gunmen were captured. **********The next day time bombs exploded in the jet intakes of warplanes at an air force base in Gweru, formerly called Gwelo, destroying or damaging at least 13 planes. The Government blamed saboteurs but did not identify them. **********(Reuters, quoting security sources, said that 11 people had been detained in connection with the attack on the air base.) Matabele fears that the Shona sought political domination over them were heightened by Mr. Nkomo's dismissal, moves by Mr. Mugabe toward a one-party state and detention without trial of some 200 people, most of them Nkomo supporters.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/21/world.main_headline: HUMAN SERVICES DEPT. SEEKS RIGHT TO CUT PUBLIC ROLE IN RULE-MAKING
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/21/world.print_headline: HUMAN SERVICES DEPT. SEEKS RIGHT TO CUT PUBLIC ROLE IN RULE-MAKING
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/21/world.body_text: **********The Department of Health and Human Services is proposing to change its procedures so that new rules for Social Security, Medicaid, welfare and other programs could be issued without advance public notice. **********The proposal, which has drawn fire from some who receive benefits from those programs, would also permit the Government to change the rules for these programs without receiving comment from the public. **********Department officials said that in most cases they would continue to use the ''notice and comment'' procedures they have been following for 12 years. **********But under the proposal, the department could choose to ''omit the use of notice and comment procedures for rules relating to public property, loans, grants, benefits and contracts if, in its judgment,'' the delay ''would impair the attainment of program objectives or would have other disadvantages that outweigh the benefits'' of public comment. **********The proposal itself is passing through the procedure it would modify. It was published last month in the Federal Register, the medium through which the Government gives advance notice of changes in regulations. It is open to public comment until Aug. 23; at that point the department decides on its final form, and it takes effect after publication in the Register. Regulations are then subject to judicial review. **********Department officials said one of the major disadvantages of current procedure is the inordinate amount of time, often a year, that notice and comment require. **********For months the department has been preparing new or revised rules for several programs, including Medicaid, Medicare, Social Security and Head Start, which provide benefits for the poor, the elderly and children. **********While the department can make substantial changes in Federal benefit programs by issuing new regulations, it cannot make a change inconsistent with laws passed by Congress. The discretion of the Secretary of Health and Human Services is broadest in areas where Congress has not been very specific. **********The Secretary, for example, has broad discretion in defining ''reasonable'' hospital costs that will be reimbursed under Medicare, in deciding how to count the financial resources of a family applying for Medicaid benefits and in setting health and safety standards for hospitals and nursing homes. **********Advocates for the poor, consumer groups, hospital administrators, nursing home operators and others who receive benefits from the department are opposing the change. 'End Public's Right to Comment' **********Sara Rosenbaum of the Children's Defense Fund, a national nonprofit organization, said Friday that the proposal would ''end the public's right to comment on regulations before they are issued.'' The change, she said, ''could not have come at a more important time'' because of the major regulatory changes being prepared. The changes are expected to reflect not only new laws enacted by Congress but also the Reagan Administration's efforts to control Federal spending. **********Eugene Tillman, a lawyer in private practice here, said that under the proposed rules, the department could ''escape judicial review'' of any decision to forgo public notice and comment. The proposal says that although the department will try to offer opportunities for public comment, this policy ''is not intended to create any judicially enforceable rights.'' **********Mr. Tillman, who used to work at the department, said the proposed rules ''represent an erosion of the public participation principle which has been firmly established over the past decade.'' **********''Given the broad range of health, welfare, commercial and research interests affected'' by the department's regulations, he said, the ''opportunities for public participation should not be diminished.'' **********Department officials acknowledge that rules have often been improved as a result of comments submitted by state and local officials, trade associations and private citizens. **********''Our main concern is situations where we do not have enough time for notice and comment because of statutory deadlines and program needs,'' said Terry Coleman, the department lawyer who supervises the issuance of regulations. ''The vast bulk of regulations take a year to put out when we go through notice and comment.'' **********Last year the department had only seven weeks to issue regulations carrying out many statutory changes in welfare, Medicaid and Medicare. The changes, signed into law by President Reagan on Aug.  13, took effect at the start of the fiscal year on Oct. 1, in some cases before the public comment period was over. **********A Federal district judge in Pennsylvania held that the welfare regulations were invalid because the Government had not allowed enough time for public comment. But the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit later allowed the cuts to take effect under the new rules. Procedures Required by Law **********Under the Administrative Procedure Act, Federal agencies are supposed to publish proposed rules in the Federal Register and then allow at least 30 days for public comment. The agencies must consider the comments before issuing final rules. However, the law says that an agency may waive this requirement and issue emergency rules when ''good cause'' exists. Some courts have held that a statutory deadline is ''good cause.'' **********Under the law, rules relating to ''public property, loans, grants, benefits or contracts'' are exempt from the requirement. But since 1970, the department has, in effect, waived the exemption and solicited public comment on rules pertaining to social welfare programs. Federal courts have often upheld the right of citizens to participate in the rule-making process under the department's policy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/14/busin.body_text: **********To the Business Editor: In ''What's Behind Today's Disinflation'' (Oct.31), William Nordhaus asserts that the recent decline in inflation reflects declines in rates of rise of energy and other volatile prices, and declines in wage increases because of recession. **********He concludes that slower money growth was not a factor. This is puzzling. Where did the recession come from? Does Prof. Nordhaus absolve the Federal Reserve from all responsibility for the recession? Surely a more balanced and internally consistent view is that both disinflation and the recession are consequences of reducing money growth.  ROBERT E. WEINTRAUB Senior Economist Joint Economic Committee Congress of the United States **********Washington, D.C., Nov.1, 1982

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/08/busin.body_text: **********Business failures soared during the first six months of 1982, Dun & Bradstreet Inc. said yesterday.  The 11,498 failures reported by the credit rating and business information service represented a 45 percent increase from the period a year earlier and more than the total for all of 1980. **********The service said 522 businesses failed in the week ended July 1, compared with 448 the previous week. https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/15/world.main_headline: NICARAGUANS CHALLENGE U.S.: PROVE YOUR CHARGES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/15/world.print_headline: NICARAGUANS CHALLENGE U.S.: PROVE YOUR CHARGES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/15/world.body_text: **********The Nicaraguan Government has accused the Reagan Administration of issuing ''lies and half-truths'' against the 30-month-old revolution and has challenged Washington to prove its charges that Nicaragua is shipping arms to Salvadoran guerrillas. **********''The United States has been unable to provide any evidence of a supposed arms traffic from Nicaragua to El Salvador simply because it does not exist,'' said Sergio Ramirez Mercado, a member of Nicaragua's three-man ruling junta. **********Mr. Ramirez added that Nicaragua favored a political solution to the Salvadoran war but doubted that next month's elections could bring peace. ''The elections will exacerbate the war and the United States will want to find someone to pay for the broken plates,'' he said. **********After a rebel attack Jan. 27 destroyed numerous Salvadoran helicopters and aircraft, the Reagan Administration asserted that infiltration of arms to the Salvadoran left had reached levels comparable to those recorded before the guerrillas' abortive ''final offensive'' of January 1981. 'Export' of Subversion Charged **********Without offering any specifics, Administration officials also suggested that both Nicaragua and Cuba were continuing to supply weapons to the Faribundo Marti National Liberation Front. Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. described Nicaragua as ''a base for the export of subversion and armed intervention throughout Central America.'' **********But Western diplomats in the region have expressed open skepticism about United States charges that huge arms shipments from Nicaragua to El Salvador have been renewed. **********''I'd say that the more concerned Washington becomes with the situation in El Salvador, the more it seems to be striking out against Nicaragua in frustration,'' one influential Western diplomat said. **********The diplomat said that Nicaragua remained an important propaganda base for the Salvadoran left and that top guerrilla commanders as well as democratic opposition leaders frequently visit Managua. They also said that some Salvadoran guerrillas receive training here and others pass through Nicaragua to and from Cuba. **********But while a small amount of armaments were thought to be still reaching Salvadoran rebels from Nicaragua, the diplomat said there was no evidence of large-scale smuggling. ''If you manage to cut of Nicaragua completely, it wouldn't make much difference to the situation in El Salvador,'' a Western diplomat said. **********In an interview, Mr. Ramirez said ''the best way to end speculation about this is for the Nicaraguan and Honduran armies to carry out joint patrol operations'' along their common border. He added that Nicaragua had long insisted on such an approach and that he was hopeful that the new Honduran administration of President Roberto Suazo Cordova would soon agree. **********Mr. Ramirez said that despite Nicaragua's ''confrontation'' with Washington, the Sandinist Government remained hopeful that relations would improve. He pointed out that the United States was permitting anti-Sandinist exiles to undergo military training in Florida and was trying to block credits to Nicaragua in the World Bank and the Inter-American Development Bank. ''But we continue to insist that a dialogue with the Reagan Administration is possible, that a permanent channel of communication be maintained,'' he added, **********Domestic opponents of the Sandinist regime have also been sharply critical of Washington's verbal attacks on Nicaragua. ''I wish the United States would keep quiet for a while,'' said Alfonso Robelo Callejas, a former junta member and now opposition leader. ''Every time Haig opens his mouth, he strengthens the Sandinists by justifying their arms buildup and stimulating the nationalism of the people.'' **********The Reagan Administration has nevertheless expressed growing concern at the rapid buildup of the Sandinist army, which, it claims, now poses a serious threat to Nicaragua's neighbors in Central America. Washington has also charged that Soviet, East German and Cuban officers are training Sandinist troops. Last month, it censured France for agreeing to sell $15.8 million worth of arms, including rockets and rocket-launchers, to Nicaragua. Defense Against 'Aggression' **********In response, Nicaraguan officials have argued that they must be prepared to defend themselves against outside ''aggression'' and they have pointed to press reports as evidence that the United States had discussed the possibility of forming an inter-American peace force with Argentina, Chile, Uruguay and Paraguay to operate in Central America. **********Despite the rapid growth in the Sandinist army over the last year, however, Western diplomats here question recent claims by United States officials that Nicaragua now had some 125,000 people under arms. The diplomat said that the most reliable reports indicated the Nicaraguan Army now had some 22,000 uniformed soldiers, including the National Police and a powerful state security apparatus, as well as some 30,000 members of a people's militia. **********Since the July 1979 revolution, diplomats believe that Nicaragua's main military acquisitions have been 25 to 30 Soviet-made T-54 and T-55 tanks, surface-to-air missiles and a large quantity of automatic rifles. **********Under the recent agreement with France, Nicaragua is also to buy two helicopters, 45 trucks, two missile-firing patrol boats, 100 rocket-launchers and 7,000 rockets. ---- Business Leaders Released **********MANAGUA, Feb. 14 (AP) - Three business leaders imprisoned in October after criticizing the Government were released today on $10,000 bail each, authorities announced. **********The three had been taken into custody Oct. 21 for violating national emergency laws. They had accused the Sandinists of leading Nicaragua to Communism. **********The businessmen are Enrique Dreyfus, president of Nicaragua's Superior Council of Private Enterprise; Gilberto Cuadra, chairman of the Chamber of Commerce, and Benjamin Lanza, president of the Chamber of Contractors.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/05/busin.main_headline: Summary of the Economic Meetings Held by the Seven Nations Since '75
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/05/busin.print_headline: Summary of the Economic Meetings Held by the Seven Nations Since '75
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/05/busin.body_text: **********The economic summit conference has been an annual event since 1975. Following are summaries of the seven previous meetings.  Rambouillet, France, 1975 - The conferees rejected a return to fixed exchange rates among their currencies, while agreeing on the need for monetary stability and for international economic cooperation. But currency upheavals and international economic sparring matches ensued. **********Dorado Beach, P.R., 1976 - The nations agreed that the greatest danger was overly rapid, inflationary growth. But unemployment, which was not officially discussed at the meeting, soared to 15 million people in the industrial countries over the following 12 months as world economic growth ''paused.'' **********London, 1977 - The industrialized nations committed themselves to a 5 percent growth rate for the year. But West Germany and Japan failed to meet goals for rapid growth that had been set for them as a means to bolster the world economy. While the American economy spurted ahead, promises for a comprehensive energy program were not fulfilled. **********Bonn, 1978 - The conference ended with a modest set of pledges to maintain policies of slow growth and with lower expectations of what economic meetings could accomplish. The United States had to promise to put its own economic house in order by reducing oil imports in order to win concessions from Tokyo and Bonn. But oil consumption and imports continued to swell, increasing inflation and aggravating monetary instability. **********Tokyo, 1979 - The energy issue dominated the meeting. The United States and other nations agreed to specific limits on oil imports through 1985 to curb market speculation. Because of its recession, the United States was the only nation to meet its import goal, and interest in the oil market faded as supplies increased. **********Venice, Italy, 1980 - The economic talks again centered on energy, with the participants agreeing to develop alternate energy sources and to reduce oil imports sharply. A world surplus of oil began to develop during the following year because of higher prices and slower economic growth worldwide. **********Ottawa, 1981 - This meeting, the first summit conference for many of the heads of government, including President Reagan, was largely a get-acquainted session, a medium for communication rather than a generator of decisions. Worrisome disagreements on economic policies, because of France's election of a Socialist Government, and resentment of Japan's trade protectionism did not materialize. But the leaders remained divided on aid to less-developed countries.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/08/world.main_headline: EXCERPTS FROM INTRODUCTION TO STATE DEPT.'S HUMAN RIGHTS COUNTRY REPORTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/08/world.print_headline: EXCERPTS FROM INTRODUCTION TO STATE DEPT.'S HUMAN RIGHTS COUNTRY REPORTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/08/world.body_text: **********Following are excerpts from the introduction to the 1981 Human Rights Country Reports prepared by the State Department, submitted to Congress and made public today: **********Unfortunately, the widespread longing for rights in the contemporary world confronts a real lack of consensus on these rights. Many governments fear individual liberty; many others do not even accept the original and distinctive intellectual foundations of the belief in human rights. Those opposing the human rights movement find themselves in a world already shaped by it, and they are compelled to fight on its ground, using the terminology of democracy. A nominal consensus on human rights thus hides the reservations of leaders who remain more comfortable with the ancient priority of duties over rights, and of rulers who simply find it inconvenient or threatening to respect their subjects' rights. For such people there is a great temptation to legitimize their own interests by broadening the basic concept of rights to include these interests - thus allowing some to claim, for example, that duty to authority is a special kind of right and others to claim that certain theoretically desirable rights cannot be afforded at their country's stage of development. **********This leads to increasing uncertainty as to what desirable things really are rights. This uncertainty has been encouraged by some new interpretations of social and economic rights, such as the newly minted concept of the ''right to development.'' The urgency and moral seriousness of the need to eliminate starvation and poverty from the world are unquestionable, and continue to motivate large American foreign aid efforts. However, the idea of economic and social rights is easily abused by repressive governments, which claim that they promote human rights even though they deny their citizens the basic rights to the integrity of the person, as well as civil and political rights. Human Rights In Inte rnational Relations A continuing problem for human rights polic y is the fact that it traditionally aims at affecting the domestic behavior of other countries, while governments are reluctant to alter their nation's polit ical system for foreign policy reasons. The leverage that the United States does have is strongest in friendly countries , where we have more access and more influence. Such influence is an important resource in pursuing human rights, but its concentration i n friendly countries creates a danger: human rights policy might high light and punish human rights violations in friendly countries, whil e giving unfriendly countries immunity. If this took place it would not fairlyrepresent the distribution of human rights abuses in the w orld.  Moreover, a nation that came to display a general pattern of undermining or estranging friendly governments would obvio usly limit its future influence over them, including its influence ov er their human rights behavior. This is a second problem of human r ights - theneed to avoid pressing only where our influence is greates t rather than where the abuses are greatest. **********The world after 1945 has been characterized by competition between two adverse ideologies, one represented by the United States and one by the Soviet Union. The United States is the nation that has most vigorously undertaken the effort to make human rights a specific part of its foreign policy. The Soviet Union, on the other hand, is ruled by a very small elite through a massive bureaucratic and police apparatus. Its regime inherits in a modified form the Marxist tradition that reacted against the philosophic ideas on which the original human rights concept was based, and superimposes this on a heritage of absolute monarchy. In contrast to the Western democracies, whose original human rights principles gradually radicalized themselves, producing a greater and greater transformation of social life, the alternative Marxist conception of justice in the U.S.S.R. was soon withered by tactical compromises with the necessities of absolute rule. Effect of Soviet Policy **********The effect of Soviet foreign policy has not been to encourage human rights. The Soviet Union dominates, without their consent, not only the non-Russian peoples of the former czarist empire, but also the nations of Eastern Europe. The efforts of the people of East Germany, Hungary, Czechoslovakia and Poland to create freer and more pluralist systems have all been frustrated by Soviet intervention or pressure. In 1979 the Soviet Army invaded Afghanistan to impose a government unacceptable to the overwhelming majority of the Afghan people. In the developing countries, the Soviet Union has a tendency to use its influence to move governments toward political structures of the Soviet type where possible. For example, in Ethiopia, whose Government is a friend of the Soviet Union, there has been persistent Soviet pressure to create a Communist Party on the Soviet model. Thus a world in which several major powers were in theoretical agreement over human rights has given way to a world in which the two great powers are fundamentally divided over this issue. United States Human Rights Policy **********This Administration believes that human rights is an issue of central importance both to relieve suffering and injustice and to link foreign policy with the traditions of the American people. **********But no nation can carry out an effective human rights policy unless it shows that its principles can make it successful and confident.  The strength and prestige of the most powerful democratic nation is inevitably important for human rights. **********The other side of this principle is that it is a significant service to the cause of human rights to limit the influence the U.S.S.R. (together with its clients and proxies) can exert. A consistent and serious policy for human rights in the world must counter the U.S.S.R. politically and bring Soviet bloc human rights violations to the attention of the world over and over again. U.S. Response **********At the same time, the United States must continue to respond to serious human rights problems in friendly countries. U.S. human rights policy will not pursue a policy of selective indignation.  Every act of torture or murder is equally repugnant to the American people, no matter who commits it. Of course, the means available to us to halt such human rights violations always vary with the specific case. Our specific response to human rights violations appropriately differs from country to country, but the intensity of our concern should not. **********But a realistic policy must be alert not only to human rights violations by governments, but also to those by opposition groups. It should be obvious that murder, torture, the intimidation of free expression, interference with free elections or attacks on the independence of the judiciary are equally reprehensible whether they are committed by a government or by a group attempting to replace or capture it. Building Freedom It would narrow the range of action of our human rights policy ex cessively to limit it to responding to individual violations of hu man rights when they appear. This ''reactive'' aspect of human ri ghts policy is essential. But it must be accompanied by a second tr ack of positive policy with a bol der long-term aim: to assist the gradual emergen ce of free political systems. It is in such systems that we can mos t realistically expect the observance of human rights across the boar d. The development of liberty is, in turn, encouraged by the emergenc e of areas within a political system where free choiceand free expres sion can become familiar and respected, even while they are not pe rmitted in other parts of the political system. Among these areas whe re freedom can develop are labor unions, churches, independent jud icial systems, bar associations and universities.  Where we do not have leverage over the shape of an entire society, wecan nourish the growth of freedom within such institutions. **********United States policy is guided primarily by the criterion of effectiveness, choosing the response that is most likely to actually improve human rights. In the majority of cases this criterion suggests an emphasis on traditional diplomacy. Traditional diplomacy maximizes the limited leverage we do possess, while minimizing counterproductive reactions, damage to bilateral relations and international tension. Traditional diplomacy has the drawback of being least visible precisely where it is most successful. But this Administration is pledged to employ traditional diplomacy vigorously on behalf of human rights.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/04/world.print_headline: BRITISH NAVY NOW FIGHTING BUDGET WAR; Military Analysis
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/04/world.body_text: **********The Royal Navy, which emerged battered but triumphant from the Falkland Islands war, is now the center of a struggle for money and power within the British military establishment. The outcome of that struggle, American naval sources believe, will affect not only Britain's role in NATO but also the extent of United States maritime responsibilities in the North Atlantic. The primary lesson of the Falkland war for Britain was that although the country's main military interests lie in the security of Western Europe, there must be enough flexibility to enable Britain to intervene outside the area. **********In the view of one American naval officer, Britain must examine its responsibilities area by area and adjust resources to the possibility of missions outside the area of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. The Royal Navy's claim to priority treatment in this re-examination rests on its performance in the Falklands. **********As The Economist of London said, ''A fleet designed to fight an antisubmarine war in the North Atlantic was able to fight a creditable antiaircraft war in the South Atlantic.'' **********American naval sources would agree with this view. They question, however, whether Britain has the financial resources to provide a navy strong enough to contribute to NATO antisubmarine forces and simultaneously to operate outside the alliance area. **********Defense Minister John Nott announced in the House of Commons on Thursday a major program to build about $1.7 billion worth of new warships and fighter planes to replace some of those lost in the South Atlantic fighting. But he said the decision did not change his plans to trim the Royal Navy's surface fleet to help pay for a $13 billion Trident submarine missile program. **********Mr. Nott appears determined, on the basis of an official position paper circulated in Parliament last month, to stand by the reductions proposed earlier for frigates and destroyers. The total of these ships is to be cut from 60 to 42. **********An American naval expert said the British might be able to ''get away'' with this reduction as long as there were no calls for naval operations elsewhere. Even so, he pointed out, building replacements for the lost ships will strain the budget. **********At the same time, British and American sources see serious weaknesses in Britain's military posture. There are not enough surface-to-air missiles or advanced fighter aircraft to offer an effective air defense of the island.  Well Trained but Ill Equipped **********The army, particularly in West Germany, is also in a sad state. The general opinion at NATO headquarters is that the British Army of the Rhine is the best-trained and worst-equipped force on the alliance's central front. More modern tanks and more helicopters are desperately needed. **********The Falkland war, from the standpoint of the ground forces, was hardly a test of weaponry. The two main antiaircraft weapons, Rapier and Blowpipe, served well, and the British say Blowpipe is the only weapon that can hit a target coming head on; but neither is new. **********British sources say a debate is under way over the use of aluminum in the frigates that are to be built. Aluminum is light, which is an advantage, but it melts at high temperatures. **********All-steel ships would be more resistant to damage from missiles and shells but less efficient, because if steel radar and missile installations were placed high on a ship, the vessel would become unwieldy. Similar Problems for U.S. **********Similar problems face American naval designers. British sources say the United States Navy uses more aluminum in construction than do the British. This could be a disadvantage against an enemy armed with the French-made Exocet missile or a comparable weapon. **********The Royal Navy, Britons and Americans argue, also needs to design a surface-to-air missile that is more effective than the Sea Dart.  That missile takes too long to aim and fire. **********The Falkland war also underlined to the navy lobby in London the need for a third light aircraft carrier. Present plans call for two carriers for service in the North Atlantic. But some naval sources in London contend that in the light of the Falkland experience, three carriers are needed, two for NATO and one for contingencies outside the alliance area. Britain, they argue, has as much at stake in the Persian Gulf as the United States and should be able to deploy a carrier in a crisis there without weakening the alliance. **********Basic to the overall British military problem is the cost of the submarine-launched Trident ballistic missile. The newest version of this missile, the D-5, will raise the cost to $13 billion over the next 10 years. Opposition to Trident **********The Government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher is determined to acquire the Trident. But it faces serious opposition in Parliament and among military experts. **********The opponents do not deny the need for a British nuclear deterrent, but they oppose the acquistion of one whose cost will eat into the funds available for conventional forces. These funds are already limited. The British will do well if planned military spending for the fiscal year that began in April maintains an increase of 3 percent after inflation. **********The 3 percent increase was agreed upon five years ago by NATO members. Until now Britain has kept fairly close to the figure.  Critics of the Trident program argue that by going to a less expensive form of nuclear deterrent, money could be saved to strengthen the country's conventional forces. Most American military experts agree with this. In their view, recent events in the South Atlantic and the Middle East have emphasized the importance of professional conventional forces.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/16/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Shelley Feldman Sues Allegheny
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/16/busin.body_text: **********Shelley Feldman Associates, a Miami-based consultant and manager in the food service equipment business, filed suit in the Federal District Court in Chicago against Allegheny International, its subsidiary the Sunbeam Corporation and the Welbilt Corporation. **********The suit charges that Allegheny breached its contract to sell to Feldman the five food service subsidiaries of the Sunbeam Corporation after Allegheny acquired Sunbeam ealier this year. Instead, Allegheny has agreed to sell the companies to the Welbilt Corporation for about $12 million. **********The suit asks that Allegheny either pay $15 million in damages plus interests to Feldman, or sell to Feldman the five food companies. Allegheny refused to comment on the suit, said a spokesman, Richard Skaare.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/19/busin.body_text: **********The Standard-Coosa-Thatcher Company, a Chatanooga, Tenn., textile maker, said yesterday it had agreed with Technical Equipment Leasing and Hickory Furniture that the Technical group would drop its $60-ashare tender offer for 36.9 percent of S.C.T., which in turn would pay the group $300,000 in legal fees and end all litigation.  S.C.T. said it would continue with a previous agreement to be acquired by a group of its executives in conjunction with Wolsey & Company, a New York investment firm, for about $28 million, or $53 a share.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/14/busin.body_text: **********The New York Insurance Exchange, the first centralized commercial insurance exchange in the United States, provides a marketplace for underwriters and brokers to transact insurance business face-toface, facilitating rapid placement of risks in property, casualty, marine and life insurance. **********Donald E. Reutershan, who has been president of the exchange since it began operating on March 12, 1980, says that it was not set up specifically to rival Lloyd's of London, but was intended to allow American insurance companies to insure almost any type of risk in the United States and to prevent loss of domestic business to foreign insurers. At least half of the more than $4 billion in premiums that Lloyd's writes every year originates in the United States. **********The New York Insurance Exchange was created by legislation enacted during the 1978 and 1979 sessions of the New York Legislature. Mr.  Reutershan, who has spent virtually his entire working life in the insurance business, assesses the exchange's progress and its future. **********Q. Has the exchange been able to broaden the scope of the business it can handle? A. At first, business was conducted in reinsurance of all kinds in the U.S. and international, direct business of all kinds outside the U.S., and direct business rejected by the Free Trade Zone in New York State, which was set up to protect certain specially licensed domestic insurance companies in New York State from competition in ordinary lines of business. In February 1982, the New York State Legislature passed an amendment that permits the exchange to write direct business throughout the United States. **********Q. Are you meeting your goals in premium volume, since the insurance industry is faced with soft market conditions? A. The goals we had set for growth in premium volume are on target, despite soft market conditions. Premiums of $63.2 million for the first six months of 1982 were 133 percent higher than in the corresponding period in 1981. We predict $150 million for the year, more than double 1981's premiums, and $850 million in five years. **********Q. Who makes up the exchange membership and how is it managed? A.  Currently, the membership stands at 78 brokers and 31 underwriting syndicates whose aggregate capital is $150 million. The exchange, whose chairman is T.V. Learson, formerly chairman of the International Business Machines Corporation, is managed by a 12-man board of governors. One-third of the governors are public representatives and the others represent underwriting and broker interests in the exchange. Currently, there are about 60 foreign syndicate investors from 21 countries, and they provide about a third of the total investment in the exchange's syndicates. **********Q. There is a growing fear that many reinsurers, particularly newcomers, may not be able to meet their payment obligations if faced with major catastrophes. What is your feeling about this? A. There is the possibility of some reinsurers going insolvent since current soft market conditions and low prices have made many of them accept sizable risks at inadequate premiums. The New York Insurance Exchange's security fund covers this contingency of insolvency of an underwriting syndicate member and is unique in the insurance industry anywhere in the world. The security fund now exceeds $16.6 million and covers all proper contracts written on the exchange, whether direct or reinsurance - domestic or foreign. **********Q. The exchange initially expressed hopes of providing employment for thousands in the metropolitan area. Have you revised your forecasts? A. We made a projection on the number of people to be employed by the exchange and its related operations of 15,000 at the end of 10 years. We're actually ahead of our target with more than 1,000 currently employed. Unfortunately, other observers applied the 10-year goal to employment results after one or two years of operation. Phillip H. Wiggins

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/22/busin.body_text: **********The Northrop Corporation today welcomed the Reagan Administration's approval of the first sale of Northrop's new F-5G Tigershark airplane. **********The deal, facing Congressional review in 50 days, is for Bahrain to buy four F-5G's, two F-5F trainer planes, 60 Sidewinder missiles and spare parts, totaling about $180 million. **********The proposed sale, which was announced by the Defense Department late Monday, is not big enough to put the Tigershark into full production, said Greg Waskul, a Northrop spokesman. But the order is expected to spur requests from larger countries.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/04/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; CLAROSTAT'S CHAIRMAN WINS PROXY CHALLENGE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/04/busin.body_text: **********Glen E. Swanson, the chairman of the Clarostat Manufacturing Company, a $20 million-a-year electronics parts producer based in Dover, N.H., does not live in Dover. In fact, the 75-year-old chairman, who owns nearly 30 percent of the company's stock, does not even live in New Hampshire. Mr. Swanson lives in Los Angeles. **********Moreover, according to a proxy statement filed by a group of dissident shareholders who tried unsuccessfully recently to oust Mr.  Swanson, he has not attended a company annual meeting in seven years. **********The dissidents' loudest complaint, however, was reserved for the company's dividend policy: Clarostat has not paid a dividend since 1962. Clarostat officials, in turn, argued that the funds had all been reinvested. Last week the company filed suit against the group, claiming securities law violations. **********Yesterday, however, the suit was dropped, and the dissident shareholders, who controlled 12.2 percent of the common stock, were bought out by the company for $1.78 million plus another $201,000 in legal fees. Mr. Swanson, still in California, was allowed to remain as chairman. **********He refused, however, to be interviewed.  Born in South Bend, Ind., in 1907, Mr. Swanson made his fortune in the mid-1930's when he founded, with an investment of $1,400, a company to manufacture electronic coils for use in radios. **********In those early days, Mr. Swanson said in an interview some years ago, it was far from easy going. ''For a while we accepted i.o.u.'s instead of salaries,'' he said. By the early 1950's, Mr. Swanson's company, the Standard Coil Products Company, was the leader in its field. **********In the late 1950's he joined Clarostat. By the mid-1960's, he had become chairman of the company's four-man board, as well as its largest shareholder. Last year his total compensation from Clarostat was about $80,000.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/25/world.main_headline: Armenian Suspect Is Sentenced in France
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/25/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Armenian Suspect Is Sentenced in France
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/25/world.body_text: **********EN-PROVENCE, France, Jan. 24 (Reuters) - A man suspected of being an Armenian guerrilla was sentenced to two years in prison Saturday night for trying to kill the Turkish Ambassador to Switzerland in Bern two years ago. Court officials said the prisoner, Max Kilnajian, a French citizen, would be freed almost immediately because of the amount of time he spent in jail awaiting trial. **********Mr. Kilnajian, who had pleaded not guilty, was tried in France, where he was arrested, because France does not extradite its nationals. Turkish officials had said they feared that Mr. Kilnajian would receive lenient treatment in France, in view of recent Armenian threats and terrorist acts. **********The Ambassador, Dogan Turkheim, escaped with slight injuries after six shots were fired at him. About 1,000 Armenian sympathizers gathered outside the courthouse in the two-day trial.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/22/world.main_headline: AMIN GEMAYEL ELECTED PRESIDENT IN A DISPLAY OF UNITY BY LEBANESE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/22/world.print_headline: AMIN GEMAYEL ELECTED PRESIDENT IN A DISPLAY OF UNITY BY LEBANESE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/22/world.body_text: **********Amin Gemayel, a 40-year-old Maronite Christian, was elected President of Lebanon today by a nearly unanimous vote of Parliament in an unusual display of Christian and Moslem unity. **********As President-elect, he replaces his brother, Bashir, who was chosen by Parliament on Aug. 23 and was killed in a bomb explosion a week ago today. **********Amin Gemayel, a lawyer who has been a Member of Parliament for 10 years, is due to be sworn in on Thursday morning for a six-year term, succeeding President Elias Sarkis. 'It Is Time to Work' **********Pledging to work toward ''reuniting and reconstructing Lebanon,'' the President-elect told Parliament that ''Bashir is calling us'' to face the nation's vast problems. **********''It is not time to cry,'' he said. ''It is time to work.'' More Israeli soldiers, meanwhile, left West Beirut today, continuing the thinning out of the forces that invaded the city after Bashir Gemayel's death. Israeli tanks and armored personnel carriers, however, were still in evidence in downtown areas, along the Corniche Mazraa and near the former headquarters of the Palestine Liberation Organization, and there were patrols with rifles at the ready elsewhere. Israelis Are Loading Trucks **********The state radio said that units of the Lebanese Army, which began replacing Israelis in West Beirut on Monday, would move into more downtown areas on Wednesday. The Government said an Israeli withdrawal was under way, and Israeli troops could be seen loading trailer trucks with captured vehicles, weapons, P.L.O. files and materials from Arab banks and taking them south. **********(The Algerian press agency said Israeli troops had stormed the Algerian Embassy in Beirut and stolen documents, Reuters reported from Paris.) **********At the shattered Palestinian refugee camps of Sabra and Shatila, where hundreds were slain by Lebanese Christian militiamen late last week, the body count continued to increase, but there was confusion over the figures because more than one group was doing the counting. **********Beirut's civil defense workers said they had been mistaken late Monday when they reported the total at that time to be 302. They said their actual count, by late today, was 271. **********A spokesman for the International Committee of the Red Cross, which began its count later, said that by the close of today's work 205 dead had been officially identified. But ''many, many'' bodies remain, the spokesman said. **********The presidential election was held at a special session of Parliament convened at a military academy in Fayadiye, three miles east of Beirut, with a heavy cordon of policemen and sharpshooters on guard. **********Of the 80 Members of Parliament who attended, 77 voted for Amin Gemayel. There were three abstentions. Twelve were not present, but some reports said at least some had been prevented from arriving by security problems. **********By contrast, the session at which Bashir Gemayel, the leader of the rightist Christian militias, was elected was attended by only a bare quorum, or 62 members, as Moslem leaders sought to organize a boycott. Bashir Gemayel was chosen on the second ballot, receiving 57 votes. Five ballots were blank. **********Symbolizing the new mood of unity, Amin Gemayel entered the auditorium, where the vote was held, with his brother's chief political foe, former Prime Minister Saeb Salam, who organized the boycott of the Aug. 23 election. **********After the vote was announced, the President-elect delivered a short speech, standing under a black-draped portrait of Bashir Gemayel.  ''I pledge to uphold Lebanon's continuity,'' he declared, ''and shoulder the monumental responsibility you have invested in me of reuniting and reconstructing Lebanon in the fashion my martyred brother had hoped to accomplish.'' **********He then embraced the 82-year-old former President, Camille Chamoun, who was nominated last Friday by the National Liberal Party to run against Mr. Gemayel but who withdrew Monday in the name of national unity. **********The shock of the news of last Saturday that Israeli-supported Lebanese Christian militiamen had slain Palestinians in the two camps at the southern outskirts of Beirut on Thursday and Friday appears to have been a factor in Mr. Chamoun's decision. His candidacy had received the support of most Moslem politicians by then; his withdrawal insured the election of Amin Gemayel. **********The President-elect, noted for his attempts to maintain links with Lebanese Moslems, Palestinians and other groups, was nominated last Thursday by his Lebanese Christian Phalangist Party. It expressed the hope that he could be a ''consensus candidate,'' and this he turned out to be in today's election. **********Mr. Gemayel said today that Lebanon's traditional Moslem-Christian balances had to be strengthened. In the hunt through the Sabra and Shatila refugee camps for bodies, the official Red Cross spokesman, Jean-Jacques Kurz, said today that he still knew nothing about the fate of many camp residents who were seen Friday being driven away by the Christian militiamen, alive, in trucks. **********Meanwhile, reporters visiting Beirut's largest Palestinian refugee camp, Burj al Brajneh, found today that it was not being given the protection by the regular Lebanese Army that the Government promised after last week's killings at Sabra and Shatila. **********Some inhabitants of Burj al Brajneh, where tens of thousands of Palestinians and Lebanese Shiite Moslems are estimated to be living, said they had appealed in vain for an increase in the small force on duty there. They said they lived in such fear that they did not sleep in the camp at night but with relatives in adjoining neighborhoods, in bombed-out buildings and on the streets. Thousands were said to leave the camp each night. **********Residents said that in recent weeks the Lebanese Army had asked them to give up their guns. Hundreds of automatic rifles and other arms were said to have been deposited in a mosque and collected by the army.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/26/busin.main_headline: LABOR DEPT. TIGHTENS KEY DATA RELEASE RULES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/26/busin.print_headline: LABOR DEPT. TIGHTENS KEY DATA RELEASE RULES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/26/busin.body_text: **********The Labor Department, responding to the possibility that key economic indicators are being leaked before they are announced, said today that release procedures had been tightened. **********Janet Norwood, the Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, said that the change in procedures, effective April 2 with the release of the unemployment rate, had been made because of the ''perception in the markets'' that the data might be being leaked early. ''It could be possible,'' she acknowledged, for someone to profit from advance knowledge of the key indicators. **********She said that the bureau had reports in the last several months from people in the markets in Chicago and New York that they had heard the numbers of the Consumer Price Index, the unemployment rate or the Producer Price Index before the official release time of 9 A.M. **********According to these reports, she said, the number has been known only about 10 or 15 minutes before 9 A.M. And, she added, no one in the bureau has got a telephone call before 9 A.M. from anyone who could actually quote the figure before its release. Present Procedures **********Under present procedures, the news media get the number at 8 A.M.  for release at 9 A.M. Under the new procedures, the release time will be moved up to 8:30 A.M., with the press getting the release at 8 A.M. The President, through the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, is the only person who gets the numbers a day early. **********Peter Sternlight, senior vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said today that he had reported to the Bureau of Labor Statistics that some of his contacts in the markets had reported to him they had heard of people getting the numbers early. **********''They call me and tell me they hear this or that number around early,'' Mr. Sternlight said, ''and I get the impression that something is already being bandied about the market.'' **********But both he and Mrs. Norwood said they had no confirmation that any actual leak had occurred. They both speculated that the people in the markets could have mistaken one of the many predictions by various economists for the actual report. **********Referring to the possibility of a leak, Mrs. Norwood said: ''There is no way for us to know if it is a fact. There is a large forecasting industry out there, and it is entirely possible that people who have heard the forecast think they have heard the actual number early. But it is also possible that the number has leaked out a few minutes early.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/21/busin.body_text: **********Interest rates fell yesterday, with the steepest declines occurring in the Treasury bill market, where they dropped about five-eighths of a percentage point from Monday's auction level for the three-month issue and by slightly more than a quarter of a percentage point for the six-month issue. **********''Treasury bills satisfy the two main concerns of investors at this time: quality and short maturities,'' said George Hester, a vice president in the government securities division of Paine Webber Inc. **********Although prices for notes and bonds have increased recently, Mr.  Hester said demand for those longer-term issues had not been robust, partly because ''investors know perfectly well that in a week the Treasury is going to announce plans for a quarterly refunding.'' **********The reluctance of many investors to buy large amounts of notes and bonds is a sign of lingering fears that heavy Treasury borrowing might push interest rates higher later this year. Although the amount of Treasury borrowing will depend on the performance of the economy, estimates call for the Treasury to raise at least $90 billion of new cash in the last half of this year. **********13.16% Yield on 2-Year Notes **********For now, the Treasury market is not burdened by heavy borrowing needs, dealers said, despite today's auction of a record $6 billion of two-year notes. In advance of that auction, dealers were offering the upcoming notes to large customers with a yield of 13.16 percent.  At the quarterly refunding, dealers are certain of new issues due in about three and 10 years, but doubt that the Treasury will issue more 30-year bonds. **********In yesterday's trading, dealers said that prices rose only slightly after it was learned that the Federal Reserve planned to maintain its 2 1/2 percent to 5 1/2 percent growth target for M-1 during the second half of this year and in 1983. **********When the Fed's chairman, Paul A. Volcker, told a Senate committee that the Fed would tolerate above-target growth for a while if economic conditions warranted, some analysts became more optimistic that rates might decline further in the short-term market. **********The overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market fell to as low as 10 3/4 percent yesterday, but many analysts said that rate as an aberration on the low side. They estimated that the funds rate might average about 11 3/4 percent in the near future. **********Of course, there are still many economists, traders and investors who expect short-term and long-term rates to rise above current levels later this year as an expanding economy increases private credit demands while the Treasury borrows large amounts. Positive Yield Curve Seen **********According to many observers, the Fed's willingness to encourage lower short-term rates and the heavy supply of longer-term issues will result in a positive yield curve, with short-term rates signficiantly lower than long-term rates. **********That has certainly been the case since June 28, when three-month bills averaged 13.27 percent, five-year Treasury notes yielded 14.92 percent and the 14 percent, 30-year bonds yielded 14.18 percent.  Yesterday, the three-month bill rate was 10.52 percent, the five-year issue yielded 13.53 percent, and the 30-year bond was offered at 105 3/4 to yield 13.2 percent. **********The drop in short-term rates helped sales of recently announced corporate issues but has not yet led corporations to announce plans for long-term issues due in 10 years or more. Late in the day, a Morgan Stanley group announced that it would offer today $100 million of Swedish Export Credit Corporation 15 1/2 percent notes due in 1990 at a price of 100. **********In the tax-exempt market, underwriters led by the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company said a $60 million issue of Aa-rated Chicago Metropolitan Sanitation District bonds had an unsold balance of about $20 million. The bonds were offered at prices scaled to yield from 9 percent in 1984 to 11.5 percent in 1992 and 12.7 percent in 2001-03. **********In the revenue bond sector, underwriters led by Merrill Lynch tentatively priced a $78 million issue of 13 1/4 percent Ohio Air Quality Development Authority bonds due in 2012 at par. The bonds will finance pollution control facilities for the Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/28/busin.main_headline: Technology; Taping Shows Off the Air
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/28/busin.print_headline: Technology; Taping Shows Off the Air
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/28/busin.body_text: **********THE taping of music or television shows off the air has become a sore point with movie and record companies, who say such taping deprives them of sales of records and recorded video cassettes. **********But some companies think such over-the-air taping could be turned into a business, in which the producers would get their fair share.  They are planning or have started ventures in which music, movies, video games and other forms of entertainment or information would be transmitted electronically to homes and recorded by machines that would automatically be turned on to receive the transmission. **********Such electronic distribution of programming, sometimes called telesoftware, has the potential of being cheaper than traditional forms of retailing, such as record stores and video outlets. **********The American Broadcasting Companies, for instance, plans next year to introduce its Home View Network, in which movies and other pay television programming would be broadcast in scrambled form by ABC stations and affiliates in the pre-dawn hours. Subscribers to the service would have videotape recorders equipped with special decoders made by Sony. The transmitted signals would automatically awaken the tape recorders, which would tape the programs and then shut off. **********National Public Radio, in cooperation with a Codart Inc., a San Francisco company, plans a similar service for music. It will be introduced next month over KQED, the public radio station in San Francisco. **********Subscribers will punch in the numbers for the pieces they want to record. The recorder would then be turned on and off automatically all night, allowing subscribers to make customized records. **********Information might also be distributed that way. Dow Jones & Company has a business news service in which subscribers can receive and record radio broadcasts on topics that interest them. **********EECO Inc., an electronics company in Santa Ana, Calif., has developed a system in which magazines, newspapers or catalogues could be broadcast over the air or over a cable TV channel for taping on a video cassette recorder. A 150-page magazine, including color pictures, text and sound, could be sent in 15 seconds and would take up only five inches of tape, according to Stuart Krasney, director of marketing development. **********Video game software and computer software -which consist of instructions for the computer -are also viewed as potential candidates for electronic distribution. **********Such distribution, is already being done on Compuserve and The Source, two electronic information services for personal computer owners. National Public Radio has teamed up with National Information Utilities of McLean, Va., in an attempt to send out computer software by radio frequencies, also during the night, to automatic recording machines. The NABU Manufacturing Corporation of Ottawa plans to start delivering software by cable in that city next month and will test its concept in the United States next year. **********The plans vary in detail but have similar characteristics. They are aimed at avoiding physical distribution. But unlike ''on-line''services, they do not require the person to be constantly connected to a central computer or tuned to a television set or radio. **********The advantage of electronic distribution, say its proponents, is that prices would be lower than with physical distribution. Yet there is uncertainty as to what the price of the various services would be and whether they would catch on. It is far from certain that the future will show a nation of recording devices clicking on and off while people sleep. **********''All of these schemes have a lot to say for themselves, but they're the first ones out,'' said Mark R. Kriss, an analyst with the Yankee Group, a Boston telecommunications consulting firm.  ''Typically, they run into problems.'' **********One major problem, he said, could be opposition from retailers, whose software sales are the profitable part of the consumer electronics business. The hardware, from home computers to video cassette recorders, is heavily discounted. **********One such plan has already failed. Last year, the Digital Music Company attracted attention when it proposed to distribute music over cable television systems, allowing subscribers to record some of it on a pay-per-album basis. But record wholesalers and retailers opposed it, and the record companies decided not to supply programming. **********The new services might face similar problems in that program providers might not want to participate. ABC, for instance, has not yet announced agreement with any movie studios for programs for its pay-television service. Other companies proposing such services are vague about suppliers and their charges for the service. **********Companies entering the electronic distribution business say they will pay royalties to producers. But the producers might not consider the fees sufficient and might have concerns about piracy. **********A company selling a $250 program for personal computers will not let a software service broadcast it for home recording to subscribers who pay $10 a month. Also, many such programs require detailed manuals for users, which cannot be easily distributed electronically. So such telesoftware plans could evolve into ''junk services,'' broadcasting only programs that do not carry high value, Mr. Kriss said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/17/busin.body_text: **********A Federal bankruptcy judge here cleared the way today for an Ohio auto parts company to purchase the United States assets of the DeLorean Motor Company for $1.5 million, plus assumption of about $9 million in debt. **********The sale, which yields DeLorean's secured creditors about 3 cents on each $1 in debt, gives Consolidated International Inc. of Columbus, Ohio, ownership of 649 cars with an estimated retail value of $17.5 million; spare parts worth another $1.2 million, and sole United States distribution rights. **********DeLorean Motor filed for protection from its creditors on Oct. 25, six days after John Z. DeLorean, its founder, was arrested in Los Angeles on Federal drug charges. The British arm of the company was ordered liquidated by the British Government on Oct. 19. **********In his decision to allow the sale, Judge George Woods said the case was complex but a timely decision was required. ''The DeLoreans could almost fall into the category of a perishable item,'' he said. **********Attorneys for Consolidated, which is headed by a 70-year-old investor, Sol. A. Shenk, disclosed in court that the company had also purchased 1,090 cars from the British receivers and would sell them in this country. **********Mr. Shenk has also made an $80 million offer to lease the DeLorean factory in Northern Ireland, to resume operations there at a reduced rate.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/17/jobs/.print_headline: OUTLOOK FOR JOBS IN THE NEW YORK CITY AREA; CONNECTICUT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/17/jobs/.body_text: **********CONNECTICUT is in the midst of a historic shift in employment, with a decline in traditional manufacturing industries and a rapid growth i n high-technology companies. The overall job picture is good for w orkers with the right skills. ''There are 58 firms in Connecticut n ow making fiber optics,'' said Anne Wingate, vice president of the C onnecticut Business and Industry Association, citing an example of af ield that is growing quickly. ''The really strong manufacturing in t he future probably will be in high-tech areas.'' Companies involved i n such advanced fields as robotics and biochemistry have also l ocated in Connecticut, she said. **********The statewide unemployment rate has hovered around 7 percent in recent months, consistently several points below the national average. However, according to the state's Department of Economic Development, Connecticut's unemployment rate has averaged an impressive 6.2 percentage points below the national rate for the last four and a half years. According to economists, however, this low figure masks a continuing succession of workers losing their jobs in older industries - textiles, rubber, brass and various kinds of metalworking - and the creation of new jobs. Manufacturing in advanced fields such as electronics is healthy, but much of the slack is being taken up by nonmanufacturing employment, such as finance and real estate, insurance, law and professional, hotel, educational, and government workers. Over all, nonmanufacturing employment now accounts for 71.2 percent of jobs in the state, up from 67.9 percent six years ago, according to statistics compiled by the Connecticut Department of Labor. **********Such shifts in labor trends are valuable for those who are prepared. ''The insurance industry has gotten rid of file clerks and replaced them with programmers and systems analysts,'' said Mrs.  Wingate, commenting on the advance of the computer. ''The job opportunity of the decade is going to be repairing these fantastic machines.''  Matthew L. Wald

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/31/busin.main_headline: DU PONT POSTS SMALL DROP IN QUARTER
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/31/busin.print_headline: DU PONT POSTS SMALL DROP IN QUARTER
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/31/busin.body_text: **********E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company reported yesterday that net income in the second quarter fell slightly, to $247 million, or $1.03 a share, and that without the inclusion of the results of the recently acquired Conoco Inc., the decline would have been much larger. **********With the $7.8 billion acquisition of Conoco last September, Du Pont has been able to avoid the kind of sharp earnings decline that has been suffered by other major chemical companies. **********Du Pont, the nation's largest chemical producer, said that net income for the latest quarter compared with earnings of $248 million, or $1.05 a share, in the second quarter of 1981. Sales increased to $8.5 billion from $8.1 billion. **********''Earnings per share for the second quarter were approximately 25 cents higher as a result of the merger,'' C. Raeford Minix, treasurer of Du Pont, said in a telephone interview. 'Results Are Encouraging' **********''Although return on investment is at an unsatisfactory level, these results are encouraging when viewed in light of the poor economic conditions prevailing in most world markets,'' Edward G.  Jefferson, chairman of the Wilmington, Del., company, said in a statement. ''Declines in most of our traditional chemicals, fibers and plastics businesses were largely offset by good performance in petroleum, coal and biomedical products segments.'' **********Mr. Jefferson said that Du Pont had projected last year that the merger of Conoco would moderate the negative impact of business cycles on the company's earnings. **********''First-half results confirm this expectation,'' Mr. Jefferson said. ''Earnings per share for the first six months were approximately 55 cents higher as a result of the merger.'' **********For the first six months of the year, Du Pont said, net income dropped 11.6 percent, to $497 million, or $2.09 a share, from $562 million, or $2.38, a year earlier. Sales increased 3.1 percent, to $16.8 billion, from $16.3 billion. **********Although Du Pont showed strength in the latest period, the longterm earnings outlook might not be quite as bright. ''Earnings remain under pressure, and we have reduced our estimates - for 1982, to $4.25 per share, from $4.50; for 1983, to $6 a share, from $6.25,'' said William R. Young, chemical analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., in a recent report. **********The company's industrial and consumer products unit was one of five business segments reporting lower results for the second quarter, while three segments registered gains. Profits from industrial and consumer products fell 39 percent, reflecting the declines in photosystems and electronics, partly offset by gains in the refinishes business, Du Pont said. ---- Earnings table, page 43.
