https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/06/busin.main_headline: HOUSE PANEL APPROVES THRIFT UNIT AID PROGRAM
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/06/busin.print_headline: HOUSE PANEL APPROVES THRIFT UNIT AID PROGRAM
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/06/busin.body_text: **********A House subcommittee today approved a financial assistance program to aid thrift institutions and commercial banks.  The bill would authorize Federal regulatory authorities to issue ''guarantees'' - a form of Government promissory note - to a savings and loan association, mutual savings bank, commercial bank or credit union whose net worth had dropped below two percent of its assets. **********The guarantees would, in effect, increase a financial institution's assets. The Government would only make good on the notes if an institution failed. **********In addition to its low net worth, a qualifying institution would have to have suffered earnings losses for at least two consecutive quarters, and have 20 percent of its loans in residential real estate or securities backed by residential real estate. The institution would also be required to demonstrate that it had ''reasonable prospects of long-term viability.'' **********The proposal, approved by the Housing banking subcommittee in a 19-to-3 vote, also would authorize an appropriation of up to $8.5 billion to help pay the debts of institutions that fail. The bill still faces a vote by the full House Committee on Banking, Finance and Urban Affairs. **********Last fall, the House Banking Committee passed a bill to facilitate mergers of troubled thrift institutions, but it did not include capital infusion provisions. That measure is stalled in Congress. The action today was the first approval by any Congressional panel of legislation that would provide financial subsidies for troubled thrift institutions. **********Many of the 4,500 savings and loan associations and savings banks have been losing money because high interest rates have made their deposits more costly than the returns they earn from their portfolios, which are made up largely of low-interest, long-term mortgages. **********Earlier this week, in what appeared to be a major concession to the thrift industry, Senator Jake Garn, chairman of the Senate Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs Committee, announced that he would soon introduce legislation to provide Federal capital infusion assistance similar to the proposal approved today. In the past, the Utah Republican has repeatedly opposed what he called short-term, bail-out measures for industry. **********Curt Burnett, an aide to Senator Garn, said today that the House subcommittee action ''clearly sets the stage for Senate consideration of similar legislation, and I believe that the Senator fully expects some type of capital infusion bill to be passed by Congress this year.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/26/world.main_headline: REAGAN NAMES SHULTZ; Reagan and Haig transcripts, page 4.
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/26/world.print_headline: HAIG RESIGNS OVER FOREIGN POLICY COURSE, BUT CITES NO ISSUES; REAGAN NAMES SHULTZ; Reagan and Haig transcripts, page 4.
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/26/world.body_text: **********Alexander M. Haig Jr. resigned today as Secretary of State. In a letter to President Reagan, he said the Administration's foreign policy had moved away in recent months from the ''careful course'' he and the President had laid out. **********Mr. Reagan made the first, surprise announcement of the change at 3 P.M. without giving any reasons for Mr. Haig's departure. He said he would nominate George P. Shultz, a former Treasury Secretary, to the State Department post. **********It was unclear, even to some of Mr. Haig's most intimate advisers, whether his resignation was at his initiative or had been forced upon him. **********A Stunning Surprise **********Mr. Reagan's announcement was stunning, coming as it did during what may be the culmination of the Israeli campaign against the Palestine Liberation Organization in Lebanon. Mr. Haig, who appeared before reporters in the State Department's main auditorium an hour and a half after the President's statement, did little to clear up the mystery over the circumstances of his resignation. **********He read his resignation letter, in which he said that when the Reagan Administration took office, ''we agreed that consistency, clarity and steadiness of purpose were essential to success.'' **********''In recent months,'' the letter went on, ''it has become clear that to me that the foreign policy on which we embarked together was shifting from that careful course that we had laid out.'' Speculation on Lebanese Issue **********There was immediate speculation on Capitol Hill, particularly among supporters of Israel, that Mr. Haig was leaving because of disagreement over the policy to be followed in Lebanon. **********Mr. Haig has advocated a conciliatory approach toward the Israelis and had seemed to be supported by Mr. Reagan over the opposition of Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger and William P. Clark, the national security adviser. There had also been disputes over how strenuously to try to prevent Washington's European allies from going ahead with the construction of a gas pipeline from the Soviet Union. **********A White House official later told reporters that Mr. Haig had informed the President of his plans to resign on Thursday but had not given him his resignation letter until today. Mr. Shultz, president of the Bechtel Group Inc., an international construction and engineering company, was contacted by Mr. Reagan in London this morning, the official said. **********The official said there was no single precipitating event that caused the resignation. A close friend of Mr. Haig's said he had quit for a mixture of policy and personality reasons. He was concerned about White House officials becoming personally involved in operational matters, such as dealing with Middle Eastern ambassadors, and he was upset at the harder line being taken toward the European allies by Mr. Reagan. **********One aide said that Mr. Haig, who was involved in trying to bring pressure on the Palestinian forces in Beirut to give up their arms and leave before the Israelis moved into the city, was upset that Vice President Bush had taken it upon himself to advise Arab nations that the United States would persuade Israel to stay out of Beirut.  Mr. Haig was said to have felt that this would encourage the P.L.O.  not to leave Beirut. **********Mr. Haig, 57 years old, had been involved in a continuing series of disputes with other senior Administration officials almost from the start of the Administration. In the past, he reportedly threatened to resign over what he perceived as encroachment by other officials on his responsibilities. **********Pending Mr. Shultz's confirmation by the Senate, something that is expected to occur promptly, Mr. Haig has agreed to remain in office.  Hearings on the Schultz appointment are planned by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, possibly as early as next week. **********The news of Mr. Haig's departure came as a complete surprise in a city accustomed to leaks even of the most delicate decisions. At 2:45 P.M. White House reporters were told that President Reagan would make an announcement in 15 minutes in the press room. This usually happens only in matters of the highest importance. **********Some reporters speculated that the President, who had just attended a working lunch with Mr. Haig and other members of the National Security Council, might speak about the Lebanese crisis. Others thought he might announce the resignation of another controversial Cabinet member, Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan. Reagan Reads Statement **********Instead, shortly after 3 P.M., Mr. Reagan appeared and seemed to have trouble reading his brief statement. He said he would take no questions when he was through. **********''It's an announcement I make with great regret regarding a member of our Administration who has served this country for 40 years above and beyond the call of duty, who has served me so well and faithfully with his wisdom and counsel I have respected and admired for all the time our Administration has been here, but who now is resigning, leaving Government service after all this great time,'' the President said. **********By not mentioning Mr. Haig at the start, the President created a sense of drama. He ended the suspense a moment later: ''And with great regret, I have accepted the resignation of Secretary of State Al Haig. I am nominating as his successor, and he has accepted, George Shultz, to replace him. And that's the extent of the announcement. Again I say I do this with great regret.'' **********Initial indications were that the change in secretaries of state would not necessarily produce any major shifts in policy. Mr.  Shultz, who is highly regarded by such foreign policy authorities as former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, has had no direct experience in foreign affairs, but is particularly strong in international economic matters, the area in which Mr. Haig had been weakest. **********Mr. Weinberger, commenting on the Haig resignation, said: ''I am sorry Al Haig is leaving the Government. I have known him for many years and have the utmost respect for his ability, his knowledge, and his effectiveness in foreign policy and many other areas of public affairs.'' **********As the news of his resignation swept through Washington, Mr. Haig returned to his seventh floor office at the State Department and summoned his senior aides for a meeting, an official said. **********He seemed tired, one official said, as he discussed the sudden resignation. According to several participants, he did not go into much more detail than he had in his resignation letter. Mr. Haig said that he had been ''increasingly concerned about the drift of policy and how it was being made.'' **********Then, accompanied by such longtime aides as Lawrence S.  Eagleburger, the Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, and Sherwood Goldberg, the executive assistant, Mr. Haig walked to the rostrum in the Dean Acheson Auditorium. **********After prolonged applause from department employees, Mr. Haig was introduced by his spokesman, Dean Fischer, and then immediately started reading from his resignation letter. **********Asserting that Mr. Reagan's assumption of office had ''brought an opportunity for a new and forward-looking foreign policy resting on the cornerstones of strength and compassion,'' Mr. Haig said, ''I believe that we shared a view of America's role in the world as the leader of free men and an inspiration for all.'' **********''We agreed that consistency, clarity and steadiness of purpose were essential to success,'' Mr. Haig wrote to Mr. Reagan. ''It was in this spirit that I undertook to serve you as Secretary of State. **********''In recent months it has become clear to me that the foreign policy on which we embarked together was shifting from that careful course which we laid out,'' he continued. ''Under these circumstances, I feel it necessary to request that you accept my resignation. **********''I shall always treasure the confidence which you reposed in me,'' he said. ''It has been a great honor to serve in your Administration, and I wish you every success in the future.'' **********He then praised Mr. Shultz for his ''experience, professionalism and integrity.'' And he said he had the ''most profound respect'' for the Foreign Service and the State Department's employees. He concluded by thanking the press for its ''professionalism and objectivity.'' **********In his time in office, Mr. Haig accomplished no significant diplomatic breakthroughs. No major treaties or other documents were worked out. Rather, many months were spent in seeking agreement within the Admininistration on policy positions on a number of issues. Much time was also spent in seeking White House and Congressional approval for senior appointments in the department.  Some of those named were less conservative than many of Mr. Reagan's supporters wanted.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/07/world.body_text: **********The Security Council's President, Noel G. Sinclair of Guyana, met separately with the other 14 members today to discuss a French-Egyptian plan to preserve the Palestine Liberation Organization as a political force in Lebanon, but there was no sign that either France or Egypt was pressing for an early vote. **********Egyptian diplomats said that should the P.L.O. agree to withdraw from Lebanon, the resolution would be revised to take account of the new situation. **********In any event, Egypt and France hope to win Council suppport for a declaration of Palestinian rights, implying the right of Palestinians to a separate state. This is strongly opposed by Israel and is likely to draw a veto from the United States. **********Council members talked of a possible vote on Friday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/03/busin.body_text: **********New factory orders increased by a scant two-tenths of 1 percent in December, the Government reported today.  However, the increase was seen as encouraging in light of separate reports that showed sales of newly built houses in December rose 10.9 percent, the third straight monthly gain, and that the value of new construction in December was up 21 percent from November, the low point of 1981. (Page D12.) **********Orders for manufactured goods rose to a seasonally adjusted $160.3 billion in December from November's level, the Commerce Department report said. These orders had increased a revised six-tenths of 1 percent in November after having fallen in each of the three previous months. The November rise earlier was estimated at two-tenths of 1 percent. **********Other figures reported by the Commerce Department showed that manufacturers' inventories fell in December, a long-awaited indication that stockpiles of unsold factory goods are being reduced. **********Manufacturers are not likely to increase currently depressed production or begin hiring back laid-off workers until inventories diminish. **********While the modest December increases were welcomed by Donald Straszheim, vice president of Wharton Econometrics in Philadelphia, he said that they were nothing compared with the increases - ''probably on the order or 15 to 20 percent a month'' -that might be expected when a genuine recovery gets under way. **********Wharton Econometrics forecasts a turnaround in the April-June quarter, as do the Reagan Administration and a number of other private forecasters. More Layoffs Seen **********Meanwhile, production cuts and new layoffs can be expected for at least a short time longer, Mr. Straszheim said. **********For all of 1981, new orders totaled $2,000 billion, up 7.4 percent from 1980, the report said. The increase appeared to be more the result of price rises than growth in volume. **********The decline in factory inventories brought the inventory-toshipments ratio down from 1.73 to 1.72, the first decline in that measure since last June, when it was at 1.57 . Because manufacturers would rather ship goods than store them, they try hard to keep the r atio low. **********Shipments of manufactured goods declined in December for the sixth straight month in December, but only by two-t enths of 1 percent.  Shipments for all of last year increased 8.2 percent, to about $2,000billion. **********The Commerce Department said that December factory orders for durable goods increased by three-tenths of 1 percent, rather than the 1.6 percent estimated last week. **********December's orders for nondefense capital goods decreased 4.2 percent, to an adjusted $22.81 billion, following an increase of 13.4 percent in November. New orders for nondurable goods in December rose two-tenths of 1 percent, to an adjusted $80.09 billion, after having fallen 1.5 percent in November.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/15/world.main_headline: POLAND CUTS BACK ITS CULTURAL TIES WITH U.S. AGENCIES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/15/world.print_headline: POLAND CUTS BACK ITS CULTURAL TIES WITH U.S. AGENCIES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/15/world.body_text: **********Poland announced today that it was cutting back on cultural and scientific relations with the United States Government and was restricting visas for Americans. **********The Polish Government said it would stop cooperating with the United States Information Agency, the State Department's public relations arm, and ''any other Federal agencies that engage in anti-Polish activity.'' **********In another development, Lech Walesa, head of the outlawed Solidarity movement, gave Western reporters the prepared text of a speech calling for ''open, democratic and peaceful means'' to win back the gains made by the union before the imposition of martial law a year ago. Walesa Hopes to Speak Thursday **********Mr. Walesa intended to deliver the speech on Thursday in Gdansk at a rally marking the shooting of workers during riots in 1970 and the erection in 1980 of a monument in their honor. **********It would be Mr. Walesa's first political appearance since his release last month from 11 months of internment. But Jerzy Urban, the Government spokesman, said Monday that no permit for such a rally had been issued. **********The Polish announcement on the cutback of cultural relations with United States Government agencies said special procedures would be introduced in considering any American invitations, grants or offers of training to Poles. **********No more Polish visas are to be issued to employees of the United States Information Agency. U.S. Contacts Already Limited **********The United States Government had already limited its exchange projects with Poland under martial law. However, scholarly exchanges under private American auspices, such as the International Research and Exchanges Board of New York, had continued. It was not immediately clear whether these nongovernmental contacts would now be affected. **********The Polish announcement of retaliations against what it called a ''notoriously'' anti-Polish policy of the United States came after a cool Western reaction to moves made by Poland ostensibly to ease the rigors of martial law. **********For weeks, Polish officials had been saying that procedures to end military rule would be introduced at a meeting of Parliament on Dec.  13, the anniversary of the military takeover. **********Poland had hoped that the West would then lift trade sanctions imposed under martial law. The sanctions have struck a blow at the already ailing Polish economy. **********But the legislation introduced in Parliament on Monday, while eliminating the internment of political prisoners and the monitoring of telephone calls, kept sweeping Government powers, actually strengthening many aspects of military rule. **********Martial-law rules prohibiting the distribution of antigovernment leaflets and the creating of public disturbances are to become part of the penal code. Other practices to remain institutionalized include the dismissal of workers who ''sow disorder,'' the use of the riot police, wiretapping, press censorship, summary military trials, and the militarization of key factories, mines and transport facilities. Parliament Reconvenes Saturday **********Parliament is expected to approve the legislation on Saturday.  Before adjourning today after a two-day session, it enacted a new state secrets law under which Poles may be liable to prison terms up to 10 years for divulging unauthorized information. **********Secretary of State George P. Shultz, traveling in Western Europe, told Pope John Paul II on Monday that the moves modifying martial law did not meet American criteria for lifting sanctions. The foreign ministers of the European Economic Community meeting in Brussels took a wait-and-see attitude. **********The cutback in cultural relations with the United States came against a background of acerbic sniping between the two countries.  On Dec. 3, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, made a bitter speech attacking the United States before an audience of coal miners and threatened to restrict relations. He was believed to be especially incensed by a remark by Secretary of State Caspar W.  Weinberger calling him a ''Russian general in Polish uniform.'' Visa Applications to Be Screened **********In addition to barring employees of the United States Information Agency outright, today's announcement said visa applications from all Americans would be scrutinized ''with an eye to the interests and security of the state.'' **********''In its visa policy,'' the announcement continued, ''the Polish side is taking into account the fact that the American side has for months markedly reduced all kinds of political contacts.'' **********Referring to General Jaruzelski's warning, the announcement said there had been continued criticism of Poland and ''intensification of the aggressiveness in the program of the Voice of America and Radio Free Europe.'' **********It said that Washington had reneged on some joint scientific projects and that intelligence agents had ''repeatedly abused scientific and cultural cooperation for the purposes of penetration and subversion.'' **********The American radio stations, which are popular in Poland, have been a constant target of invective, with officials charging that ''foreign stations'' were fomenting unrest. **********Mr. Walesa, in the prepared text of the speech he had planned for the Gdansk rally on Thursday, said the efforts of the outlawed Solidarity should now be channeled into four areas - labor unions, factory self-management, cultural unions and youth organizations. **********But the speech seemed ambiguous on precisely what course of action he was advocating and how it was to be achieved. He appeared to be deliberately vague and to keep his options open in an attempt to salvage some of Solidarity's gains. **********''We must find ways to achieve our aim,'' the prepared text said.  ''We need, perhaps, more time and different ways. It is now time for this great social movement, this great river to divide itself into several channels and flow peacefully to the sea.'' **********The first channel, he suggested, would be ''the trade unions we have won.'' It was not immediately clear whether he was suggesting that workers make use of the new official unions that have replaced Solidarity. These unions, which have been condemned by some Solidarity activists, are hemmed in with restrictions in their ability to strike. Self-Management Is Weakened **********The second channel, Mr. Walesa said, would be the worker selfmanagement councils that were long sought by Solidarity but were weakened in their functions in the legislation that was recently adopted. **********The third would be independent associations of writers, scientists and performing artists to safeguard ''free but wise and responsible thought,'' he said. **********And the fourth would be ''independent organizations where young people could speak their mind,'' he said.  ''None of these channels will flow without the other,'' he said.  ''All of these elements are essential, otherwise we will once again make mistakes. I am ready to serve toward a true agreement in that direction.'' **********Mr. Walesa, affirming that he remained ''faithful to our ideals,'' ended his prepared text as if he expected his audience at the proposed rally to be surrounded by hostile police and security forces. He advised his listeners to go home in peace and said: **********''Let no more damage be done today and may the others go home. Let us not be pushed off a peaceful way of achieving our aims.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/08/busin.snippet: A computer improvement patented this week for the International Business Machines Corporation provides automatic spelling corrections. Patent 4,328,561 was obtained by Danny B. Convis and two associates on the I.B.M. staff in Gaithersburg, Md.
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/08/busin.body_text: **********A computer improvement patented this week for the International Business Machines Corporation provides automatic spelling corrections. Patent 4,328,561 was obtained by Danny B. Convis and two associates on the I.B.M. staff in Gaithersburg, Md. **********Besides making calculations, the computer does word processing. It has a keyboard and display enabling the operator to type a letter or other text. The machine can be set to detect any misspelled words and offer corrections, or to correct one selected by the operator. **********The improvement reduces the number of words compiled from a dictionary memory and submitted as substitutes. The characters in the misspelled word are counted and substitutes suggested that differ only in a specified length. The operator makes the final selection.  The invention is used in the I.B.M. 8100 computer system.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/10/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Stock Market Called Bargain
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/10/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Stock Market Called Bargain
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/10/busin.body_text: **********JOHN M. TEMPLETON, an investment fund manager, said recently that there was a 50-50 chance that the Dow Jones industrial average would reach 3,000 in five years - a startling prediction at a time of considerable market distress. **********In a telephone interview from his home base in Lyford Cay, Nassau, the Bahamas, yesterday, he discussed the stocks he has been buying in his continuing quest for market gains. He mentioned as he always did that the overall market itself did not have to go up for his portfolio to profit if he chose individual stocks with skill. But his portfolio would, of course, do better if a rousing bull market developed, he added. **********Mr. Templeton is not the only investor who thinks there is a good chance of a considerably higher market in the years ahead. However, few of the optimists have so much at stake. He has managed the $600 million Templeton Growth Fund with signal success over the years. **********A $10,000 investment in 1954 would have bee n worth $374,000 through April 30, 1981, had all distributions been reinvested. This record has earned Mr. Templeton a reputation in Wall Street as a stock picker without peer. **********Mr. Templeton also manages the five-year-old Templeton World Fund, which experienced explosive asset growth in reaching $588 million at the end of January. The World Fund duplicates the holdings of the Growth Fund and is based in the United States. Individuals here can own the World Fund without paying the penalties imposed on foreigners who buy the Canadian-based Growth Fund. **********That Dow 3,000 prediction comes about through Mr. Templeton's usual approach to investments. In short, he buys bargains. At current prices, he says the market, as measured by the Dow industrials, represents the best bargain in his lifetime. **********Looking back to the Depression, Mr. Templeton notes that the stock market reached a valuation nadir in June 1932. At that point, the Dow Jones industrials had fallen from their peak level of 360 in September 1929 down to 42. Prices, then, were one-ninth as high as they were before the crash. **********Even so, replacement costs of the assets owned by the 30 companies making up the Dow were 20 percent less than the combined book values of the Dow companies. The contrast today is startling. On the same basis, replacement costs of the 30 Dow stocks are 70 percent above combined book values. Translated into market terms, the replacement costs for the 30 Dow components would amount to 1,700. Yesterday, the Dow closed at roughly half that level, or 830.57. **********In the telephone interview, Mr. Templeton said that people who said wistfully that it would be wonderful to get the great bargains of June 1932 failed to recognize that prices were far lower now. **********Ever cautious - Mr. Templeton once said that he made far too many mistakes - he added that he was talking long-term, not short-term.  It is entirely possible in his view that the market will drop 20 percent more before prices go higher. **********If so, Mr. Templeton will not be stuck with a lot of high-priced shares. For he is still buying shares at low price/earnings ratios, as he did in 1939 when he borrowed $10,000 to buy $100 worth of every stock selling for no more than $1 a share on each of the two major exchanges. Thirty-four of the 104 companies that qualified were bankrupt. Still, he liquidated his account four years later for $40,000. **********Under the securities rules, Mr. Templeton cannot disclose the shares he is buying today. But he has completed his buying in the following: **********American Standard was purchased at 4.8 times this year's earnings.  He notes that Alcan Aluminium is selling at 15 times this year's earnings but estimates that, in five years, earnings could reach $12 a share, up from the current $1.25. There is the Australian & New Zealand Banking Corporation, now at 4.4 times this year's earnings.  and a position in Canadian Pacific Enterprises at 3.8 times the year's earnings. **********He notes that Champion International, the building materials and paper product company, is selling at a somewhat high price relative to this year' s earnings at 8, but says current earnings are ''depressed.' ' The Ewnia Insurance Company of the Netherlands, a recent purcha se, is selling at 3.3 times this year's earnings. Gulf Oil, another new holding, sells at 4.2 times this year's earnings. **********Heck's Inc., a Charleston, W.Va., discount store chain, is at 4.7 times this year's earnings. It is at that low multiple, he notes, although the company has not had a down year in the last 20. **********Mr. Templeton has also completed his buying in a publisher named News International of London, now selling at 1.6 times this year's earnings. He bought Northern Trust of Chicago, which is selling at 4.3 times this year's earnings. He has also purchased shares of Republic New York, the bank-holding company, at 4.6 times this year's earnings, and shares of the Royal Bank of Canada, now selling at 3.8 times this year's earnings. **********He bought Royal Dutch Petroleum at 3.5 times this year's earnings, and United States Home at 5.3 times this year's earnings. Recently Mr. Templeton purchased Union Carbide, selling at 4.5 times this year's earnings. As the name of the World Fund suggests, Mr.  Templeton roams the globe in search of bargains. Whether he will continue to do as well as in the past with twice as much money to put to work remains to be seen.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/01/world.main_headline: SPAIN'S NEW LEADER OUTLINES CAUTIOUS PLANS TO PARLIAMENT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/01/world.print_headline: SPAIN'S NEW LEADER OUTLINES CAUTIOUS PLANS TO PARLIAMENT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/01/world.body_text: **********Felipe Gonzalez said today that his new Cabinet would pursue a domestic policy of austerity and would review its military ties to the United States and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. **********In a 70-minute address to Parliament, Mr. Gonzalez, who led his Socialist Party to victory in the election Oct. 28, outlined a domestic and foreign posture as moderate and cautious as the men he has carefully picked for the first Socialist Cabinet since the Spanish Civil War. A parliamentary vote naming the 40-year-old Mr.  Gonzalez Spain's third Prime Minister since the death of Francisco Franco is expected Wednesday or Thursday after a full debate. **********Mr. Gonzalez promised an economic program that he acknowledged could have been adopted by the center-right Governments that led the country for six years; although standing by an electoral pledge to create 800,000 new jobs over the next four years, he called for greater domestic saving, promised to encourage private investment and rejected any nationalizations or major state intervention in the economy. Few Bold Changes **********''The people have voted for change, and it is our duty to fulfill it,'' Mr. Gonzalez said. ''The singularity of the program does not lie so much in the details as in the manner of its execution.'' Aside from a broad commitment to modernizing and streamlining the administration, the boldest specific changes he sketched were a new university law and a bill to prohibit politicians and high state officials from holding more than one Government post. **********Mr. Gonzalez's cautious approach is dictated by an extremely difficult economic situation - Spain's unemployment of 16 percent is the highest in the West - and by distrust of the Socialists by some senior businessmen and the conservative military establishment. **********The Socialist leader offered only the bare bones of a foreign policy. He said it would not be presumptuous for Spain to expect to enter the European Economic Community within the next four years, extending somewhat a demand by his future Deputy Prime Minister, Alfonso Guerra, that Spain be admitted by 1985 or withdraw its application. Bases Treaty With U.S. **********Mr. Gonzalez insisted that while Spain was a member of ''the Western world,'' his Government would ''examine with all attention'' its military treaty with the United States and ''restudy with the necessary rigor'' its six-month-old membership in NATO. He reasserted Spain's longstanding claim to the British colony of Gibraltar but hinted that his Government wanted to open the land frontier that has been shut since 1969. **********His language on the Atlantic alliance appeared to confirm a statement by Fernando Moran, the next Foreign Minister, that the new Government will stop work on Spain's integration into the NATO military structure. But, according to Socialist sources, the Government will not pull out of the alliance. **********In selecting members for his Cabinet, Mr. Gonzalez picked a team considerably more moderate than the sometimes radical base of his party. The new Economics Minister will be Miguel Boyer, a 43-year-old representative of the party's Social Democratic wing who has considerable experience in Spanish industry. The key Defense Ministry post will be held by Narcis Serra, the Mayor of Barcelona. The Interior Ministry will be run by Jose Barrionuevo, who was in charge of the Madrid police force.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/17/busin.body_text: **********A bipartisan group of Congressmen has decided to file suit this week to challenge the constitutionality of the $98.3 billion tax bill before Congress on the ground that it originated in the Senate and not in the House of Representatives as the Constitution requires. **********Representative W. Henson Moore, a Louisiana Republican, said today that despite pressures from the White House and the House Republican leadership and the personal disapproval of President Reagan, he would take the lead in filing a lawsuit in Federal court before the scheduled vote on the tax bill on Thursday. **********Representatives Philip M. Crane of Illinois and James G. Martin of North Carolina, both conservative Republicans, and Carroll Hubbard Jr. of Kentucky and Stephen L. Neal of North Carolina, both conservative Democrats, said they would join the suit. Still Supports Reagan **********Mr. Moore said that, unlike some conservatives, he does not oppose raising taxes now, nor does he want to break with President Reagan politically. But he stated that he felt on principle that the Federal courts should be asked to reassert constitutional procedures. **********In a telephone interview, he contended that the legislative strategy of the Administration and House leadership had ''made a mockery of the Constitution'' by allowing the Senate Finance Committee to write a complete tax bill and the Senate to pass it, without the proposal ever being reviewed by the House before being sent to a House-Senate conference committee. **********''This is the first time in the Reagan Administration that I've not been on the President's team,'' said Mr. Moore, a four-term Republican. ''A lot of us were shocked by the procedure when it was first brought up. I told the President at the White House on Aug. 5 about my feelings and the probable lawsuit and he was not very happy.'' **********Mr. Moore continued: ''Their approach has been, 'Let's break the rules. Let's brush aside the Constitution.' As much as I want the President to win, as much as I want to help with the deficits and to bring down interest rates, I can't be a part of that. I just think this is wrong.'' **********Although the Senate has modified tax bills in the past and has even originated bills raising funds in various ways, Mr. Moore and his colleagues contend that the procedure followed this year was unprecedented. **********The Representatives contend that they must file suit now, before the bill becomes law. Waiting to let a taxpayers suit begin the process later on, Mr. Moore said, could lead to a protracted fight in the tax courts. **********The suit by the Congressmen will be based on the first clause of Article I, Section 7 of the Constitution, which states: ''All bills for raising revenue shall originate in the House of Representatives; but the Senate may propose or concur with amendments as on other bills.'' **********Earlier this year, the House passed H.R.4961 which included six minor, technical modifications of the tax code, each reducing revenues slightly. The Senate Finance Committee removed all six provisions, Mr. Moore said, and wrote its own tax bill, which included 107 different provisions. **********''The only things they kept were the House enrollment number and the 'be it enacted' clause,'' complained Mr. Martin. The Separation Question **********Representative Barber B. Conable Jr. of upstate New York, ranking Republican on the House Ways and Means Committee, said that historically Federal courts had been unwilling ''to go beyond the H.R. number'' - designating that the bill had technically originated in the House - ''because they don't like to intrude on the internal functions of Congress because of the doctrine of separation of powers.'' **********For his part, Mr. Moore, a lawyer who specialized in constitutional law at Louisiana State University, cited the case of Hubbard v. Lowe in 1915, in which a Federal court voided a bill that had begun in the Senate and to which the House added a tax provision. Even though the tax action was initiated by the House, he said, the court nullified the bill because it had been enrolled with a Senate number and was thus deemed a Senate revenue bill. **********In another case, United States v. James, he said, lawyers had been advised that the courts allowed Senate-originated legislation changing the price of stamps in 1875 - from one cent for a two-ounce letter to one cent for a one-ounce letter - on grounds that that was not a revenue-raising bill in the sense of the Constitution. **********''Our case clearly does not fall under that type of decision,'' Mr. Moore said. ''This is not about postage stamps. This is the largest revenue-raising bill in history.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/27/busin.body_text: **********The Atlantic Richfield Company, the nation's seventh-largest oil concern, said yesterday that net income for the second quarter rose 2.5 percent from a year earlier, to $409.8 million, or $1.62 a share, from $399.6 million, or $1.60 a share. Sales declined 2.8 percent, to $6.8 billion, from $7 billion in the comparable 1981 period. **********Arco attributed its earnings gain to increased oil production from Alaska's Kuparuk River Field, as well as to higher natural gas prices. The company said, however, that its chemicals, metal fabricating and minerals segments had been ''adversely affected by the depressed economy.'' **********Domestic production of crude oil and natural gas liquids in the second quarter averaged 598,200 barrels a day, an increase of 70,600 barrels over last year's second quarter, the company said. **********For the first six months, Arco reported profits increased to $795.2 million, or $3.15 a share, from $767.9 million, or $3.07 a share, in the first half of 1981. Pretax earnings from refining and marketing totaled $273 million, up nearly $200 million over depressed first-half 1981 results, Arco said. Mesa Petroleum **********The Mesa Petroleum Company, which was defeated by the Gulf Oil Corporation last month in a takeover battle for the Cities Service Company, said that its second-quarter profit rose 31.4 percent, to $32.2 million, or 48 cents a share, compared with $24.5 million, or 35 cents a share, in the comparable quarter last year. **********Revenues for the quarter totaled $99.8 million, down marginally from $100.9 million in the comparable 1981 period.  The company noted that second-quarter earnings were increased by an after-tax gain of $24.9 million on the sale of its 5 percent stake in Cities Service to Gulf. Mesa received $55 each for its 4.1 million shares, for which it had originally paid an average $44.28 a share. **********Barring that sale, Mesa would have reported profits of $7.3 million, a 70.2 percent plunge from the 1981 second-quarter results.  For the first six months, Mesa reported earnings rose to $61.8 million, or 91 cents a share, from $54.3 million, or 78 cents a share, in the first half of last year. Revenues were $204 million, virtually unchanged from the $204.5 million reported previously.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/14/busin.main_headline: Real Estate; A Couple's Big Project In Midtown
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/14/busin.print_headline: Real Estate; A Couple's Big Project In Midtown
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/14/busin.body_text: **********THAT hole in the ground in the block between Fifth Avenue and Madison Avenue from 48th Street to 49th Street will become a 44-story office tower in early 1984, largely as a result of the work of an ambitious couple who head Solomon Equities, a 12-person company. **********David Solomon, who turned 30 in April, started the company in August 1980 and was later joined by his wife, Jean, who is now 29. A partner in the concern, she is project manager for Tower 49, as the new building is to be called. The project is a joint venture with the First Boston Corporation. **********At first Solomon Equities owned a handful of office buildings and apartment buildings in the city and concentrated on upgrading them.  Then in July 1981 Mr. Solomon spotted an opportunity to start a major Manhattan office development project. He said Tower 49 had its origins when a group of British investors wanted to sell a partial assemblage in midblock. **********In the next six months, Mr. Solomon said, the property was acquired, with the British group remaining as limited partners. Then additional parcels were bought to complete the assemblage, a financial package was worked out with First Boston, more than 100 commercial tenants were vacated, project plans were raced through city offices to become eligible for the expiring midtown zoning laws and air rights were purchased from some surrounding properties to enhance the size of the building. **********The initial work was swift and expensive. Mr. Solomon grimaces when asked about the cost of vacating tenants and paying some of them to break their leases. He denied a story that he had paid Adonis Gargassoulas $2.3 million to vacate his dance studio at 9 East 48th Street four years before the lease expired. ''That's a privileged matter,'' he insisted, adding that the figure ''was less than $2 million.'' **********Solomon Equities also paid a dollar short of $1 million to the Church of Sweden at 5 East 48th Street for air rights over the building. **********Tower 49 is virtually an all-consuming project for Solomon Equities. The company's only other properties now are two apartment buildings at 55 East 86th Street and 50 East 72d street - both to become condominiums. **********The design for Tower 49, a 16-sided building sheathed in soft green glass with about 15,000 square feet per floor, is being done by the architectural firm of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill. The building will have a landscaped public plaza, and there will be 13,000 feet of retail space at and below street level. **********Mrs. Solomon, who met David when they were both studying architecture at Cornell University, has focused on the development side of the project, working with the architects and construction managers of the Tishman Construction Corporation. She used to be a loan officer for Citibank. **********Mr. Solomon has concentrated on financing and on vacating tenants for the project. Before starting his own company, he had been a partner in another New York real estate firm, Nelson & Solomon Associates. He said he had also taught architecture at the University of Virginia and Harvard. **********A working partnership between husband and wife in a small company has presented no problems, the Solomons said. ''I like to say we work side by side, not together,'' Mrs. Solomon said. It's a subtle distinction that both feel is important. They have divided their labors so successfully, Mr. Solomon said, that sometimes they work all day without ever seeing each other. **********At a time when many sages of the real estate business in New York are worrying about the market, Mr. Solomon insists that his leasing prospects look good. Like other developers with projects in progress, Mr. Solomon sees a continued demand for quality office space in midtown. He said space in Tower 49 would lease for about $40 or $45 a square foot. **********The First Boston Corporation, an international investing banking and securities concern, is a relative newcomer to Manhattan real estate development. In its first joint venture here, First Boston teamed with Fisher Brothers on the construction of Park Avenue Plaza, a million-square-foot office building at 55 East 52d Street. First Boston is also a partner with Fred Wilpon of Sterling Equities in developing the old Korvettes site at 575 Fifth Avenue for offices.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/06/busin.body_text: **********The Exxon Corporation joined the trend toward ''shelf registration'' yesterday with the announcement that it planned to issue $500 million in company-guaranteed debt securities under the Securities and Exchange Commission's new Rule 415. This allows a company to issue securities ''off the shelf,'' without further disclosure, after the initial filing has been made. Exxon filed the notes with the S.E.C. yesterday. **********The company said that the securities would be issued through the Bermuda office of Exxon Finance N.V., a subsidiary based in the Netherlands Antilles. Bermuda currently has no withholding tax on capital gains. Exxon said that it planned to issue the securities in stages throughout the rest of 1982 on whichever market had most favorable rates at the time. **********Morgan Stanley Inc., which has been Exxon's investment banker for many previous securities issues, declined to comment on the announcement, except to say that it intended to ''remain competitive in a marketplace in which there will be increasing experimentation and aggressive competition.'' 'A Matter of Flexibility' **********''It's a matter of flexibility,'' said Jack F. Bennett, a senior vice president of Exxon, at a news conference at the company's headquarters. ''The 'shelf' rule will allow us to sell at the most attractive times on the most attractive markets: Today Europe may be most attractive; next week that may change.'' The issue will be the company's only external financing in 1982, he added. **********According to the statement to the S.E.C., Exxon's pending securities would be issued in both bearer and fully registered forms. Those issued in registered form, most common for bond issues in the United States, would be $1,000 each, while those in bearer form, more often used in the Eurobond market, would be issued in denominations of $1,000 and $5,000 each. The minimum investment in either form, however, would be $100,000. **********Both Moody's Investors Service Inc. and Standard & Poor's have assigned a provisional AAA rating to the securities. Mr. Bennett said that the maturities and terms of the issues had not yet been determined. However, he said, he expected most to be in the three- to five-year area, possibly with provisions for extension to 15 years. Sales to Private Investors **********Mr. Bennett said the securities would be sold to private investors as well as to investment banks. Under previous S.E.C. rules, such issues would have been sold through a specific investment bank, or syndicate; under Rule 415, the company may split its issue among several investment houses, or sell directly to investors. **********Exxon is the 11th company to have announced a securities issue under Rule 415. Other large registrants include Du Pont, Citicorp and American Telephone and Telegraph. So far, however, there have been no sales because of the delay required between filing a statement and issuing the securities. **********Analysts said that Exxon was probably issuing the securities now to compensate for a cash-flow problem caused by falling oil prices, which has hurt earnings at all the major oil companies. They added that the money would probably not be applied to any single project.  The planned sale would be Exxon's first offering of guaranteed registered debt since 1976.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/09/busin.main_headline: TOYOTA AND G.M. STUDY JOINT PLANT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/09/busin.print_headline: TOYOTA AND G.M. STUDY JOINT PLANT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/09/busin.body_text: **********The world's two largest auto makers, the General Motors Corporation and the Toyota Motor Company, are discussing joint production of small cars in the United States, Toyota said today. **********In a three-sentence statement, the Japanese company confirmed that on March 1, Eiji Toyoda, president of Toyota, and Roger B. Smith, chairman of G.M., had met in New York to discuss the possibilities of such a venture. ''The two companies have committed themselves to give further consideration to this possibility,'' the statement said. ''It is too early for any additional announcement.'' **********(General Motors, in Detroit, confirmed the Toyota announcement in an equally brief statement.  (In Grand Rapids, Mich., F. James McDonald, president of General Motors, said in a speech that, if an agreement with Toyota were reached, the joint venture would build 400,000 to 500,000 small cars annually, The Associated Press reported. ''It's imperative for us that we be in the small-car business,'' Mr. McDonald added.) The statement by Toyota was apparently prompted by a report of the March 1 meeting in this morning's issue of Nihon Keizai, Japan's leading economic newspaper. **********If the talks did lead to joint production, it would be the most significant of the international ties between car producers. ''This announcement will send a tremor through the industry worldwide,'' said an executive for the Nissan Motor Company, who asked not to be identified. **********For General Motors, a link with Toyota would offer access to the Japanese company's small-car technology and manufacturing expertise, which analysts here said the American company needed. **********''G.M. has not been so successful yet with its small lines like the 'J' car,'' said Yukio Kobayashi, an analyst for the Nomura Securities Company. ''If G.M. had full confidence in its ability to develop small cars by itself, it would not talk to Toyota.'' **********According to Nihon Keizai, the tentative plan calls for production of small cars that would be designed by Toyota and built in a currently idle G.M. plant. The plan, the newspaper reported, had been prepared by G.M. The first high-level contact between the two companies, it added, had been in December, when Seishi Kato, chairman of the Toyota Motor Sales Company, called on Mr. Smith in Detroit to suggest joint production. Advantages to Toyota **********For Toyota, a joint venture with G.M. would represent a comparatively low-risk means of starting to produce cars in the United States. A cooperative effort might also help deflect any drive to place further restrictions on imports of Japanese autos to the United States. **********Toyota has been actively interested in beginning auto production in the United States for more than a year. Last July, Toyota and the Ford Motor Company suspended months of inconclusive negotiations on a possible joint venture. **********Recently, three extensive studies for Toyota were completed to assess the advantages and pitfalls of setting up an American production facility. They were done by the Nomura Research Institute, Arthur D. Little and S.R.I., formerly the Stamford Research Institute and now a private consulting group. Their results have not been disclosed. Company Has Been Reluctant **********Unlike Nissan, which is building a $300 million plant near Nashville to make light trucks, Toyota has been reluctant to start its own manufacturing facility in the United States. Its biggest concern is whether it can transplant its highly efficient manufacturing system into a different cultural context. **********Toyota does have a small plant in Long Beach, Calif., where it makes truck beds; the plant, opened in 1972, is part of the company's testing of the American manufacturing climate. According to the company, productivity at the California plant remains 30 percent below that of comparable operations in Japan. **********''Joining with G.M. would give Toyota a way of going into the U.S.  without making a big investment and taking a big risk,'' said Hisamichi Sawa, a director of Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Ltd. of Japan. **********Given the current trade tensions between Japan and the United States, the Japanese Government has been encouraging companies in sensitive industries such as autos to join in projects with American concerns. **********''If Toyota does link in some way with General Motors, we would welcome it as an important instance of industrial cooperation between companies from the two countries,'' said Yoshiyasu Nao, deputy director of the automobile division of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry. ---- The View From Detroit Special to the New York Times **********DETROIT, March 8 - Industry analysts were skeptical of Toyota's motives for entering the talks.  Some said that Toyota might try to use the negotiations to deflect growing trade frictions between the United States and Japan by emphasizing a willingness to make cars here, thus reducing auto exports to the United States. **********''There is some thought in Detroit that Toyota actually has no plans to build cars in the United States, that they are just buying time'' against growing American protectionism, said one industry executive, who asked not to be identified. **********But one analyst disagreed. ''The motivation for Toyota is mostly political,'' said David Healy, of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., in New York. ''If they were making a financial decision, they would continue to make cars in Japan. Nevertheless, I think they will do it. Toyota has been very conservative in the past, but now with Nissan and Honda planning vehicle production here,'' pressure on Toyota has increased, he said. Failed Talks With Ford Cited **********The skeptics pointed to last year's failed negotiations between Toyota and Ford as evidence that Toyota might not be serious. Those talks failed partly because the two sides could not agree on what kind of vehicle to build. **********Toyota has lagged behind its Japanese competitors in moving some production to this country. In addition to Nissan's Nashville plant, The Honda Motor Company is planning to build passenger cars in Marysville, Ohio, where it currently makes motorcycles. **********General Motors is interested in joint production with Toyota as a means of reducing the investment the company would have to make to produce a new line to replace the aging Chevette subcompact, Mr.  Healy said. G.M. has already made huge investments in new mid-sized, front-wheel drive models, but the prolonged sales slump has forced the No.1 auto maker to defer capital investment for some lines. **********G.M. could ''shift off the small car development costs when it comes times to replace the Chevette,'' Mr. Healy said. ''I think the sharp-pencil guys at G.M. took a look at it and figured they couldn't do it'' - profitably build a new line of subcompacts - ''in the United States.'' Possible Sites in California **********If a joint production venture were agreed upon, attention will focus on two G.M. assembly plants in California, at Fremont and South Gate. G.M., which has announced that it is closing these plants, refused to comment on the possibility they would be used in a venture with Toyota. **********Such a venture would complicate the already entangled alliances among the world's major auto makers.  G.M. owns 34.2 percent of Isuzu Motors Ltd. of Japan, which has supplied G.M. with small pickup trucks, deisel engines and other components. G.M. has also purchased a 5 percent interest in the Suzuki Motor Company, and industry observers have speculated that Suzuki and G.M. will eventually begin joint production of minicars.  ''It does get complicated'' if Isuzu, Suzuki and Toyota all get involved in joint ventures with General Motors, Mr. Healy conceded. **********Ford owns 25 percent of Toyo Kogyo of Japan, which makes Mazda cars. The Chrysler Corporation has developed close ties with the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation and owns 15 percent of that Japanese auto maker. Mitsubishi and Chrysler said last month that they were discussing joint small-car production in the United States.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/21/world.body_text: **********Two of the 52 Americans held captive in the United States Embassy in Teheran said today that they felt no animosity toward the Iranian people. **********William H. Keough, 52 years old, who was the superintendent of American schools in Teheran, said, ''I have no anger or ill feeling against the Iranians as a nation, only against those who were misguided enough to keep U.S. citizens in violation of international law.'' **********Col. Thomas E. Schaefer, who was the military attache at the embassy when it was seized on Nov. 4, 1979, said he also harbored no animosity or hatred for Iran. **********They spoke before their wives unveiled a plaque at the United States Air Force hospital here, where they spent four days after their release by Iran on Jan. 20, 1981. The plaque dedicated the wing of the hospital where they stayed as Freedom Hall.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/17/busin.body_text: **********The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company reported yesterday that the continuing deep slump in the auto industry caused net income in the first fiscal quarter ended Jan. 31, 1982, to drop 97.4 percent, to $2 million, while sales dropped 16.9 percent. **********The Akron, Ohio, company, the nation's second-largest tire company after the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, said that net income in the first fiscal quarter dropped to $2 million, or 3 cents a share, from $76 million, or $1.32 a share in the first fiscal quarter of 1981. The 1982 quarter result includes a $1 million tax credit.  Sales fell to $889 million from $1.07 billion. **********Profits in the 1981 quarter include a net gain of $50 million from the sale of Firestone's polyvinyl chloride business. ''Excluding the profit from that sale, Firestone earned 35 cents a share in the first quarter of 1981,'' said Donald F. De Scenza, tire industry analyst for the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation. **********John J. Nevin, president, chairman and chief executive of Firestone, said, ''The downturn in the domestic economy and a continued slump in the auto industry were the principal reasons for the decline in sales and operating results.'' He also blamed temporary plant shutdowns caused by declining demand and reduced sales for the lowered profits. **********At the end of January, Firestone completed the purchase of 5.1 million shares of its common stock outstanding for $65 million.  ''The company has not yet determined whether it will hold in its treasury, retire or use for acquisitions or other corporate purposes the shares it recently purchased,'' Mr. Nevin said. Northrop Corp. **********The Northrop Corporation announced that net income in the fourth quarter increased 8.9 percent, to $17.1 million, or $1.16 a share, from $15.7 million, or $1.10 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1980.  Sales increased 19.6 percent, to $564.2 million, from $471.7 million. **********Northrop, a major manufacturer of military aircraft, said that net income for the full year dropped 44.4 percent, to $47.9 million, or $3.31 a share, from $86.1 million, or $6.04 a share, in 1980. **********The Los Angeles-based company said that the decline in net income for the year was primarly attributable to expenditures for the F-5G Tigershark aircraft. Dresser Industries **********Dresser Industries reported that net income in its first fiscal quarter of 1982 ended Jan. 31 increased 24.6 percent, to $76.9 million, or 98 cents a share, from $61.7 million, or 79 cents a share. Revenue increased 14 percent, to $1.14 billion, from $1 billion. **********J.V. James, chairman and chief executive officer of the diversified Dallas-based manufacturer of products for the energy and natural resources industries, attributed the gain in the 1982 first quarter to continuing strength in oilfield products and services. ----Earnings tables, page D6.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/08/world.body_text: **********Syria and Egypt indicated today that they were prepared to accept some of the Palestinian guerrillas trapped in west Beirut, senior Lebanese officials said. **********The confirmation by the two Arab nations to Philip C. Habib, the special United States envoy, that they would accept some Palestinians, coupled with the willingness of Jordan and Iraq to take others, raised hopes here that the evacuation of the Palestine Liberation Organization from Lebanon could begin as early as the middle of next week. **********''Habib now has to take everything that has been agreed upon in principle with the P.L.O. and put it together in a formal package for withdrawal,'' said former Prime Minister Saeb Salam of Lebanon, the main intermediary. ''The only major question left is the Israelis.'' **********Plan to Be Conveyed to Israel **********Lebanese officials said they expected Mr. Habib to convey to Israel this evening the results of the negotiations during the last three days so that they can be considered at Sunday's meeting of the Israeli Cabinet. **********(In Jerusalem, a high-ranking official said Israel would not accept a withdrawal plan under which a substantial number of Palestinian guerrillas would still be in west Beirut while a peacekeeping force was being deployed.) **********There is always the danger that either side could derail the plan by stirring up a clash along the battlefront. That fact was underlined this evening when a brief duel involving artillery, machine guns and rockets broke out between Israeli troops entrenched around Beirut International Airport in the southern suburbs and Palestinian guerrillas in the Burj al Brajneh refugee camp. **********Egypt and Syria previously demanded various forms of political compensation for consenting to take in the guerrillas, but a Lebanese official indicated that the demands had been abandoned. He quoted Mr. Habib as having said, ''That problem has been solved.'' **********Asked whether all the Arab nations had now agreed to take guerrillas so that a withdrawal could be carried out, Prime Minister Shafik al-Wazzan of Lebanon said, ''We have sufficient answers to start a comfortable implementation.'' **********According to senior Lebanese officials, a meeting is set for Sunday at the presidential palace in Baabda, a southeast suburb of Beirut, between Mr. Habib and military experts from France, the United States and Lebanon, with the Lebanese representing both themselves and the Palestinians. **********The meeting will draw up a final plan and timetable for the withdrawal, specifying exit routes and forms of transportation and the deployment of a peacekeeping force, made up mainly of French and Americans, in the Palestinian camps and around west Beirut in conjunction with the Lebanese Army. **********The Beirut radio said that a French military delegation arrived today and that the United States would be represented by an embassy military attache. The meeting is expected to last 48 hours. **********It is understood that Mr. Habib is waiting for a list from the Palestinians stating precisely how many people would be leaving, their affiliations and their destinations. **********There are three categories of Palestinian armed personnel in west Beirut: part-time militiamen, who are Palestinian civilians living and working in Lebanon; professional soldiers belonging to one or another of the eight member groups in the P.L.O. coalition and, most importantly, three brigades of the Palestine Liberation Army. **********The army is made up of Palestinian refugees organized into brigades that are attached to the army of the country in which the Palestinians reside. At the moment there are four brigades stationed in Lebanon - one each from Syria, Jordan, Iraq and Egypt. **********Since the start of the Israeli siege of west Beirut, most officials have said that there weare about 6,000 Palestinian military people trapped in west Beirut. It now appears that the number is closer to 9,000, Lebanese Government sources said. Since the P.L.O. does not keep a formal roster of military personnel, it may take some time to come up with a list. **********Lebanese officials described Mr. Habib as confident that if he can tie up all the details with the Palestinians and the Lebanese, he will be able to bring the full weight of the United States to bear on Israel to accept the deal. **********There is no difference between the basic objectives of his plan and what Israel has been demanding, since both want an immediate Palestinian withdrawal from Lebanon. There are, however, differences over details. **********Israel wants the peacekeeping force to arrive here only after the Palestinians have left. The Israelis fear that if the force is interposed between them and the Palestinians, the Palestinians will not leave, or at least not all of them. **********According to the Habib plan, the peacekeeping force would be deployed at the start of the Palestinian withdrawal. The basic idea is for the force to arrive in the morning and begin to take over Palestinian frontline positions. The Palestinians would then begin withdrawing in the afternoon and continue doing so in stages over a period of 14 days. Arrival Time of Peace Force **********Mr. Habib conceded the point of the earlier arrival of the peace force because the Sunni Moslem leaders in west Beirut were making the same demand. They fear that the Palestinians' withdrawal would encourage the Israelis and their Lebanese Christian Phalangist allies in east Beirut to try to impose their authority in the predominantly Moslem western sector. **********''We want to be protected from the Israelis and Phalangists as much as the Palestinian refugees do,'' said former Prime Minister Salam, who is the titular head of west Beirut's Sunni Moslem community. **********The Israelis have expressed no preference for the mode of withdrawal, except for the stipulation that the Palestinians take only their personal weapons with them. The Palestinians have conceded that point, saying that they will turn over their heavy weapons to the Lebanese Army on the last day of the evacuation. **********Another potential problem is that the Israelis want the Palestinian military removed from all of Lebanon. The question remains whether this is meant to cover the estimated 5,000 Palestinians in the northern port of Tripoli and in the Syrian-controlled Bekaa Valley. **********These Palestinians are not covered by the Habib plan, although there is a basic understanding that they will either leave or subject themselves to Lebanese authority as soon as the P.L.O. leadership departs. Lebanese Government sources said they expected the leadership to go to Damascus, where the P.L.O. maintains its formal headquarters. **********Finally, the P.L.O. will be allowed to keep a diplomatic mission in Beirut, as it has in other Arab capitals, and it is not clear how Israel will react. ---- Israeli Aide's Reaction Cool Special to the New York Times **********JERUSALEM, Aug. 7 - A high-ranking Israeli official said tonight that Israel would not accept an evacuation plan under which a substantial **********The official said that Israel had not received any new plan, but that it would not accept a plan that would provide the deployment of a peace force on the **********''The vast bulk of them must be gone before the peacekeeping force gets into place,'' the official said. ''There cannot be 90 percent of them still left because we think they would then hide behind the peacekeepers as a screen and refuse to leave.''
