https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/13/busin.body_text: **********IN the go-go years of the 1960's, the days of soaring stocks and rampant market fever, there was no bigger name on Wall Street than Gerald Tsai, the Shanghai-born stock picker who dazzled investors by doubling their money in one year's time. All good things come to an end, however, and they did for Mr. Tsai in 1968, when the five mutual funds he managed - the most noted was the Manhattan Fund - entered a bear market. Their values plunged and so, correspondingly, did Mr. Tsai's reputation for financial wizardry. **********But Mr. Tsai (pronounced sigh) walked away from that debacle about $30 million richer - the profit from the sale of his mutual fund management company to the CNA Financial Corporation of Chicago. In the years since, his public visibility has receded, but his riches have increased. Today, at 53, he is an executive vice president and the largest shareholder of the American Can Company, a $5 billion packaging concern, and has grandiose plans for turning the sluggish, old-line manufacturing company into a department store of financial services. **********It is an endeavor that has more than its share of skeptics.  American Can, which has suffered from steadily declining earnings, has a history of ill-fated acquisitions, leading some analysts to question the wisdom of this move. And, the healthy price American Can paid to acquire Mr. Tsai - by way of buying the Associated Madison Companies, the insurance company he controlled - has caused some to wonder whether American Can or Gerald Tsai got the better deal. **********''This is something that bears close watching,'' said George Thompson, an insurance industry analyst with E.F. Hutton. ''American Can's track record is questionable when it comes to diversifying into businesses they are not entirely familiar with. But they'll probably dive in with both feet. They've been known to change their course in the past. And nothing Tsai does surprises me. He always seems to land on his feet.'' **********IN this case, Mr. Tsai has certainly landed upright. As owner of 669,613 shares of American Can - just under 4 percent -with a market value of slightly over $18 million, Mr. Tsai, who was recently named to the company's board, owns more of its shares than the rest of its directors combined. As head of the American Can's financial services sector, Mr. Tsai will receive a $248,500 yearly salary plus a maximum $350,000 bonus a year. **********But Mr. Tsai has always had a knack for getting the best out of a situation. ''With Gerry, you don't bet the horse, you bet the jockey,'' said one close business associate. ''You invest when Gerry invests, and you get out when he does. He starts Manhattan Fund, sells it to CNA and makes a personal fortune. He leaves CNA and buys Associated Madison and sells that for a fortune. How many times can you do that? I don't know.'' **********There was a time when Mr. Tsai was the king of Wall Street. Glowing newspaper and magazine articles sang the praises of a man with a Midas touch. The CBS television network even aired a documentary about his money magic. **********While he has slipped from public view, he says that bothers him little. ''I really don't miss those days,'' he said in an interview in his Pan Am building office, which is decorated with family photographs, an aerial picture of his 10-acre waterfront estate in Greenwich, Conn., and models of the helicopter he once piloted for relaxation. (A forced landing in the Hudson River made him think twice about his hobby.) **********Nonetheless, while not missed, those days are certainly remembered. He has a press kit ready with information about his 30-year career as an investor and, while generally exuding calmness, he bristles at any suggestion that the performance of his mutual funds was less than stellar. ''For eight years, we were always at the top,'' he said.  ''People don't remember that. We had one bad year - 1968 - and they criticize me. But I wasn't even managing the fund. I had two portfolio managers, and they managed it.'' **********The move to American Can is the culmination of a desire - the desire to build a financial services supermarket - that began two decades ago, and he is quick to stress that his dream existed before Sears, Roebuck & Company and Dean Witter got into the act. **********''I had the idea long before them,'' he declared. ''For many years, even back in 1965, I remember telling people that 'Someday you will see a building and it will have a bank on the first floor, an S.& L.  on the second, a brokerage next and then an insurance company, and a cemetery on the 13th floor. It will be a financial department store.' '' he said **********''That's been in my head for all those years and today I'm doing what I've dreamed of all that time. I really want to build a large successful financial services company. I have an obsession to do that.'' **********American Can apparently shares that obsession. Finding its core paper products and container business on the decline, it has been trying to latch onto higher growth areas, and had decided late last year to expand more heavily into financial services, which promise higher returns and less capital investment. **********About that time, Mr. Tsai saw a newspaper article on American Can's intention to use the proceeds of the sale of some of its forest product assets to pay for its foray into financial services. Mr. Tsai proposed a meeting with William S. Woodside, chairman of American Can, and the two spied opportunity in each other. **********''WHEN the opportunity arose with Mr. Tsai, it was too good an opportunity to let go by,'' said Mr. Woodside. ''Gerry Tsai is one of the key factors in our whole financial service sector, and when we bought his company, we were more interested in buying Gerry.'' **********Mr. Woodside said that American Can plans to invest at least $500 million in financial services and anticipates that the sector will have more than $1 billion in assets within three years. He said he and Mr. Tsai had decided to expand into two areas: buying more specialty insurance companies and expanding into related financial services such as the brokerage business. But Mr. Woodside's plans are still fuzzy. **********''It depends on what comes up,'' Mr. Woodside said. ''We're openminded about it. We have no specific thing next; it depends on an opportunity, the price and the potential for growth.'' **********Since coming to American Can last April, Mr. Tsai has already orchestrated the $152 million acquisition of the Transport Life Insurance Company, a specialty insurer based in Fort Worth. At a price equal to 10 times the earnings of Transport Life, analysts noted that Mr. Tsai had paid top dollar for his first acquisition.  ''How do you maintain earnings at those prices?'' one analyst said. **********More recently, American Can received permission to operate a money market fund - the National Benefit Life Daily Income Fund - which would be distributed through the Associated Madison insurance companies. **********Some say breaking into financial services is not as simple as merely buying up finance companies. ''It's like asking how fast Dean Witter can get into the phonograph, greeting card or beer bottle business,'' Robert H. Stovall, senior vice president of Dean Witter Reynolds, said. ''It's a different business and would take quite a while. It has taken us a couple generations to build Dean Witter.  When we think of the competition, we think about those in the business today rather than somebody like American Can.'' **********Mr. Tsai, however, is undaunted and says it is not his intention to compete with giants like Dean Witter anyway. ''That's not our game plan,'' he said. American Can, he said, will find its own niches. **********Mr. Tsai's history on Wall Street, however, is an interesting tale in itself, a story in which he became richer at every stop along the way. **********In 1968, when Mr. Tsai sold his mutual fund management company to CNA, he moved over, too, as a top executive and a CNA director. This sale had netted him a tidy profit. He had initially invested between $500,000 and $1 million (he says he can't recall the exact number) to start the funds and received stock valued at about $30 million when he sold them to CNA. **********(Fortunately for Mr. Tsai, he got out in time. In June 1971 a United States appeals court ruled that any profits from the sale of a mutual fund management company must go to the fund shareholders and not to the fund managers.) **********Then, in 1973 , after selling his CNA stock, he left the company to form his own institutional brokerage firm, G. Tsai & Company, a private, 30-person brokerage firm with offices in New York, Boston and Los Angeles, and formed his own personal holding company, the Tsai Financial Corporation. Through Tsai Financial, he made his investments. **********In 1978, Mr. Tsai spent $2.2 million to buy the controlling interest in Associated Madison Companies, a relatively modest insurance company. After greatly expanding the company's operations and investing another $2.4 million, Associated Madison was sold to American Can for $127 million in cash and stock. **********Mr. Tsai, who earned $429,290 a year as chairman of Associated Madison, also owned 18.6 percent of Associated Madison's common shares, which he exchanged for $18 million in American Can stock. **********Close associates describe Mr. Tsai as extremely courteous and gentle, devoted to his family, and as a workaholic who exists on little sleep. Indeed, Mr. Tsai, in all seriousness, said he wishes that someone could ''invent a pill so that one doesn't have to sleep.'' Even his nightly sleep of five hours is interrupted by thoughts. ''I write myself notes all through the night,'' he said, pulling a card from his pocket covered with his nocturnal scribblings. These sleeping habits ''give him a leg up on normal human beings,'' said John Rosenwald Jr., a director of Associated Madison and a senior partner at Bear Stearns & Company, the brokerage firm. **********MR. TSAI'S office, as his demeanor, is calm. Dressed immaculately in a gray suit and gray tie, he sits behind a large desk with a slick black top and only three papers neatly resting on it. There are several blank computer screens at his elbow. Modern art - a large canvas with bright stripes -covers one wall and a panorama of the city spreads out from a picture window behind his desk. **********It is from this spot that Mr. Tsai mapped his plans. Indeed, his first step toward his goal of heading a financial services company was his interest in Associated Madison. **********''Associated Madison was a cheap, small, solid company,'' said William A. Shea, an Associated Madison director and senior partner at Shea & Gould, a Manhattan law firm. ''It was a good little company and a good place to start.'' **********Mr. Tsai, who did not have prior experience in the insurance business, is credited by analysts with turning a sleepy insurance company around and supervising the growth of its assets to $180 million from $50 million. **********As chairman of Associated Madison, he made three key moves. He lured top insurance executives from the rival United States Life Corporation with promises of managerial freedom and attractive salaries; he bought National Benefit Life, a high-growth massmarketing insurance company, and he upgraded Associated Madison's investment portfolio to increase its yield. **********He says he earned a return ''substantially higher'' than 15 percent from Associated Madison's investment portfolio and points out that running an insurance company, with its large pools of investment money, is ''not different than running a mutual fund.'' But while Associated Madison was growing, it was still not large enough to satisfy Mr. Tsai's ambitions. **********''He would smell opportunity, and someone bigger would end up taking the deal,'' Mr. Rosenwald said. ''A number of acquisition ideas were frustrated when bigger companies snapped up the things he identified.'' **********And National Benefit Life was developing some unanticipated problems. Its inside financial controls were flimsier than first thought, making cost control difficult, and some of its reserves were insufficient. ''The problems at National Benefit were bigger than they thought, and they saw a few rough quarters ahead,'' said Thomas G. Richter, an insurance analyst with Robinson-Humphrey/ American Express in Atlanta. **********Even without the problems, large amounts of capital were essential if National Benefit was to grow. ''We were growing so fast, we needed new capital,'' said Mr. Tsai. And, hence, when he picked up the newspaper that day and read about American Can, Mr. Tsai's interest was piqued. **********Today, Mr. Tsai has his capital, he has a comfortable corporate position, and he has the ability to add more stories to his financial department store. But it did not come without a price -his independence. Giving that up, he said, was a long and hard decision.  Instead of making business decisions alone, he now has a boss, something on the minus side of the ledger when he analyzed the deal.  But he has accepted the trade-off with a philosophical calmness.  ''You can't,'' he added, ''have everything in life.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/23/world.main_headline: HABIB BEING SENT TO ARAB CAPITALS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/23/world.print_headline: HABIB BEING SENT TO ARAB CAPITALS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/23/world.body_text: **********Philip C. Habib, the special Middle East envoy, is being sent by President Reagan to Syria, Saudi Arabia, Egypt and possibly other Arab countries to try to persuade them to accept the Palestine Liberation Organization forces in west Beirut as part of a solution to the Lebanon crisis. **********Administration officials said the decision to have Mr. Habib leave Beirut for the weeklong mission, which will include a visit to Israel, was taken when it seemed that the Arabs were not moving quickly enough on working out a way for evacuating the Palestinian forces. It is feared that Israel will lose its patience and move its troops into west Beirut. **********Today's Israeli attacks against Syrian and Palestinian positions in eastern Lebanon and west Beirut were regarded by officials as part of Israeli psychological pressure, meant to warn that force would be used, if necessary, to insure the withdrawal of the Palestinians. **********Arab Plan Presented **********The White House and the State Department said Mr. Habib's mission was intended ''to explore further the ideas and understandings that have emerged in Washington and in Beirut for further progress toward a solution of the problems of Lebanon in general and of the west Beirut crisis in particular.'' **********Two Arab Foreign Ministers, Prince Saud al-Faisal of Saudi Arabia and Abdel Halim Khaddam of Syria, met here this week with President Reagan, Secretary of State George P. Shultz and other officials and presented a plan for ending the siege of west Beirut. **********The plan calls for the transfer of the 6,000 Palestinian troops in west Beirut to northern Lebanon until decisions have been made by the Arab League on evacuating them to other Arab countries. The Americans told the visitors that the idea would not be acceptable to Israel or to Lebanon unless plans were worked out in advance on what countries would give refuge to the Palestinians. Use of U.S. Troops Held Possible **********If there were guarantees of an ultimate haven, the Americans said, then it was possible to conceive of a plan in which the United States would provide troops to help insure the safety of the Palestinians in transit. **********A meeting of Arab League foreign ministers is expected next week, maybe on Tuesday, to discuss possible arrangements for an evacuation.  In return for the Palestinian withdrawal, the United States has undertaken to insure that Israel will live up to its pledge to pull back its troops, initially from Beirut and eventually from all of Lebanon. **********American officials fear that enough Arab countries may not agree to take the Palestinians or that somehow the P.L.O. leadership will renege on its avowed willingness to withdraw. The Israelis seem willing to allow one more week or so for the American diplomatic efforts to succeed, officials said. The Americans said Israel was growing restless at the inability of Mr. Habib to conclude a deal. Habib Carries Reagan Letters **********Mr. Habib, carrying letters from President Reagan, will discuss the situation with the leaders of each country he visits, officials said. In addition to Syria, Saudi Arabia and Egypt, he will probably also go to Jordan if King Hussein returns from a trip abroad in time, officials said. **********Among the countries that were said by Prince Saud to have offered a refuge are Iraq and Algeria. But officials said there were no plans for Mr. Habib to go to either one. **********Mr. Habib will be accompanied by Morris Draper, Deputy Assistant Secretary for Near Eastern and South Asian affairs, who has been with him throughout the Beirut negotiations. **********The talks with President Hafez al-Assad of Syria on Friday are viewed as important because Syria is still expected to take a large Palestinian contingent even though it has so far refused to accept more than the P.L.O. leadership. Relations With Syria a Topic **********In addition to discussing the crisis in Lebanon, Mr. Habib is expected to be empowered to talk about Syrian-American relations.  The United States believes that, in the aftermath of the Lebanon crisis, Syria is looking to end its dependence on the Soviet Union and expand contacts with the United States. Officials said they were impressed by the moderation displayed here by the Syrian Foreign Minister. **********One issue that continues to bother American officials is the perception in the Arab world that the United States is willing to enter into direct talks with the P.L.O. without American conditions being met first. The State Department stressed again today that it had no intention of dealing with the P.L.O. directly until the guerrilla group t recognized Israel's right to exist and accepted certain United Nations resolutions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/20/world.body_text: **********Virginia Fox Hartley, a retired State Department official, died at Georgetown University Hospital Monday of a heart attack. She was 74 years old. **********Mrs. Hartley, who was born in Montana in 1907 and raised in Portland, Ore., received M.A. and B.A. degrees from Stanford University. In 1930-31 she studied at L'Ecole Libre de Sciences Politiques in Paris. **********Mrs. Hartley then began her career as a research assistant at the Library of Congress in Washington. From 1937 to 1941 she served on the National Resources Planning Board, where she met her husband, Robert W. Hartley, a former vice president of the Brookings Institution. **********She began her service at the State Department in an office that dealt with postwar planning for what was to become the United Nations. As an adviser to the United States delegations, she participated in the Dumbarton Oaks Conference and the San Francisco Conference that adopted the United Nations Charter. During a leave of absence in 1946-47, Mrs. Hartley assisted in the preparation of the biography of Cordell Hull, the former Secretary of State. **********Mrs. Hartley resumed her State Department career as a special assistant in the Bureau of International Organization Affairs. She retired in 1977. **********A funeral service is scheduled Thursday at 11 A.M. at St. Patrick's Episcopal Church in Washington.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/10/busin.main_headline: LIBYAN OIL CONCESSIONS RELINQUISHED BY MOBILE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/10/busin.print_headline: LIBYAN OIL CONCESSIONS RELINQUISHED BY MOBILE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/10/busin.body_text: **********The Mobil Corporation announced yesterday that it would end its oil exploration and production operations in Libya by July 13.  Mobil, the nation's second-largest oil company, did not explain why it was withdrawing from Libya beyond saying in a prepared statement that the decision was based solely on economics. Industry analysts said that Mobil might have been under pressure from Saudi Arabia to withdraw from Libya, because the two Arab nations are at odds. **********Mobil is one of the four American oil companies in the Arabian American Oil Company, which produces most of Saudi Arabia' oil.  Mobil becomes the second to announce its withdrawal from Libya. The Exxon Corporation said last November that it was withdrawing from the North African nation, which as recently as 1980 was the third-largest source of American oil imports. A few days after Exxon announced its plan to withdraw, Mobil said that it had halted oil production in Libya. **********Mobil, which had been active in Libya since 1955, filed its ''notice of surrender'' of its exploration and producing interests with Libya's Secretary of Petroleum on April 13, and the 90-day waiting period ends July 13, said John Flint, a company spokesman. He said he did not know why the action had not been disclosed earlier. **********Mobil said yesterday that it was negotiating with Libyan officials on compensation for its holdings. The company declined to discuss this issue in detail until it is resolved. **********Mobil's Libyan operation, Mobil Oil Libya Ltd., was a 34 percent partnership with the National Oil Corporation, the Libyan Government oil company, which held 51 percent, and Veba, the state-run West German company, with 15 percent. **********The Reagan Administration, charging that Libya was behind terrorist activities, imposed an embargo in March on oil imports from Libya. At that point, Libyan oil sales to the United States had slowed to 21,000 barrels a day from an average of 320,000 barrels a day in 1981. **********Oil industry analysts said that Mobil's main dispute with Libya was over price. Mobil and most other foreign oil companies in Libya operate in joint ventures with the Libyan Government's oil company, which usually controls 51 percent of the ventures and imposes a basid price of $35.50 a barrel, $1.50 more than Saudi Arabia's base. **********It was also difficult for Mobil ''to serve two masters,'' said Alvin D. Silber, an analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., explaining that Libya and Saudi Arabia ''have been at opposite poles of the internal OPEC struggle.'' The Saudis, moreover, have sided with Iraq in that country's war with Iran, while Libya has favored Iran. **********Although both countries are members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Counties, Libya has sought to keep prices relatively high, while Saudi Arabia has been more moderate, and Libya has lost some of its market to less expensive crudes. **********''So, an oil company that operates in both places is sort of in the middle,'' Mr. Silber said.  He called Mobil's undepreciated investment in Libya ''negligible,'' and said that it should not result in a write-down of more than 10 cents or 20 cents a share. Mobil would not estimate its Libyan investment. Its operation consisted until last November of 86,000 barrels a day produced in a partnership field with the Libyan Government oil company. Part of the Mobil share then went to Veba. **********Mobil had 200 workers in Libya, 60 of them Americans.  After Exxon pulled out of Libya, that company said it had collected ''somewhat lower than book value'' for its Libyan assets from the Government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. The figure has been estimated within the industry at $95 million. Other Companies in Libya **********Other American oil concerns still in Libya are the Occidental Petroleum Corporation and the Oasis Oil Company, which comprises Conoco Inc., the Marathon Oil Company and the Amerada Hess Corporation. **********An Occidental spokesman said that the company would stay in Libya.  Reuters news agency quoted a spokesman for Conoco as saying that the company has been holding discussions with Libya for the past year, ''but they are not concluded yet.'' **********In referring to these companies, Mr. Silber noted: ''They don't have this problem of also being large operators in Saudi Arabia. I don't think they're subject to the same kind of pressures.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/25/world.main_headline: SALVADOR ASSURES U.S. ON LAND PLAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/25/world.print_headline: SALVADOR ASSURES U.S. ON LAND PLAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/25/world.body_text: **********The State Department said today it had been assured by the Constituent Assembly in El Salvador that key provisions of that country's land redistribution program would be carried out despite a new decree that has aroused concern about the future of the program. **********In a statement issued in response to queries, the department added, however, that despite the assurances the United States would ''continue to watch the situation very closely in order to insure that it does in fact continue.'' **********The continuation of what is known as phase 3 of the land redistribution program of 1980 is a highly sensitive issue for the Reagan Administration, which has pledged its backing to the Salvadoran Government in part because of its continuation of the various economic changes. **********Congress has made further military aid to El Salvador conditional on assurances from President Reagan that the economic changes, in particular the land redistribution, will not be halted by the conservative coalition that emerged victorious from the elections at the end of March. **********Under phase 3 of the land redistribution program, 125,000 to 150,000 families who have been working as sharecroppers or tenant farmers were to be allowed to apply for up to 17 acres of land. **********Last week, the newly elected Constituent Assembly voted to suspend that phase of program for one crop year. which in the case of sugar, one of El Salvador's main crops, is four calendar years. The legislators argued that landowners should be allowed to put into production fallow land without being concerned that it might be expropriated, officials said. **********The department said that the new legislation did not affect the rights of beneficiaries ''who have applied for, but not yet received provisional titles'' to the land. **********''Nor does it affect those who have not yet applied for titles,'' it said through the spokesman, Dean Fischer. ''In sum, it remains our understanding that the right of all potential beneficiaries under Decree 207 of 1980 to gain title to land they have been farming are preserved intact and unaltered.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/08/world.body_text: **********An 80-year-old Polish-born priest, described by associates as a dynamic man with a wide range of skills and interests, took on a new task today - negotiating with gunmen holding the Polish Embassy here. **********The Rev. Josef Maria Bochenski, a Dominican priest and a retired professor of philosophy at Switzerland's Fribourg University, was called in by the Government's hostage crisis staff as an expert on Poland. **********Those who know him say his personal history, despite nearly 40 years of living in Switzerland and Swiss citizenship, mark him as a proud Pole. **********Father Bochenski was born in Poznan in 1902 into a family that produced numerous writers and scholars. His brother, Alexander Bochenski, is a writer and frequent harsh critic of the Warsaw regime. **********After entering the Dominican order in 1927, Father Bochenski taught philosophy in Cracow and in Rome in the 1930's. Serving as a chaplain in the Polish Army during World War II, he was wounded and taken prisoner by the Germans. He escaped to Britain in 1940. **********In 1945, he went to Fribourg, where he had studied briefly in the 1920's. He taught philosophy there until his retirement in 1972.  He is described as no friend of Communist thinking. He published numerous books and articles in his special field of scholarship, Soviet philosophy, and founded Fribourg's Institute for East European Studies. He has lectured and taught frequently in the United States. **********Rarely has he been far from the political scene. In 1954, he was the principal author of a report that led to the banning of West Germany's tiny Communist Party on charges of unconstitutionality. **********Friends describe him also as a fan of fast cars. He earned his pilot's license at the age of 67 and continues to fly his own plane.

It did not give details. **********Capital punishment rarely is reported in the Soviet Union.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/19/world.main_headline: Debray, the Leftist Theorist, Visits Nicaragua for France
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/19/world.print_headline: Debray, the Leftist Theorist, Visits Nicaragua for France
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/19/world.body_text: **********President Francois Mitterrand's special adviser on Latin American affairs, Regis Debray, arrived here today for a four-day visit. **********Nicaraguan officials said Mr. Debray would meet with the three members of the ruling junta. **********He arrived from Panama as part of a Central American tour that will also include stopovers in Honduras and El Salvador. **********Six months ago France granted Nicaragua an $18 million credit for the purchase of defensive military hardware, including Alouette helicopters. **********Mr. Debray, a former University of Havana philosophy professor, is author of the book, ''Revolution in the Revolution,'' published in 1967. In April 1967, he was captured by Government troops in Bolivia while accompanying a guerrilla force led by the Argentine-born Cuban revolutionary Che Guevara. He was sentenced to 30 years in prison, but was pardoned after an international outcry by Pope Paul VI and President Charles de Gaulle.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/26/busin.body_text: **********People who eat frozen TV dinners are harassed and hard-working, a researcher found.  Based on that finding, Leo Burnett, the Chicago advertising agency, created ads for Swanson frozen TV dinners that showed an overworked housewife reaching for the product. The campaign proved ill-conceived when it made its debut some years ago. Harassed consumers, it turned out, did not like to be reminded of how hectic their lives were. **********In a study in the early 1970's, Needham, Harper & Steers/Chicago, on behalf of its client, the McDonald's Corporation, confirmed what consumers could see for themselves: Many fast-food establishments were dingy. The agency set about making McDonald's fast-food outlets seem more inviting. **********Its efforts included the now-famous slogan, ''You deserve a break today,'' and coupled with McDonald's work to add sparkle to its resturants, helped sales to soar. **********Research can indeed make the difference between success and failure in advertising campaigns, and spending for such studies has been growing rapidly in recent years. Estimates of the amounts vary, but some experts calculate it at $250 million to $500 million a year, substantially more than twice its level 10 years ago. 'Getting the Right Insight' **********''What is really crucial,'' said Joseph T. Plummer, research chief at Young & Rubicam, the country's largest advertising agency, ''is getting the right insight into the consumer. When you are armed with that, you can really have the creative imagination do its best work.'' **********Advertising research has been defined as the study of the making, the value and the placement of advertising. Advertising agencies, research companies and the advertisers themselves are the major practitioners of such research. Much of it studies how well specific products sell and therefore also fits under the broader heading of marketing research. **********''What's happening.'' said Alan J. Gottesman, a senior analyst at L.F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin, ''is that more and more people are believing that having information is really vital and necessary in planning for the future. The world has become full of data freaks. More and more data are being created, and people are figuring out ways to utilize them.'' **********Alvin J. Silk, professor of management science and associate dean of the Alfred P. Sloan School of Management at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said the increases in research included the testing of advertising copy, the selection of advertising media and more experimental studies, largely involving appraisals of cost efficiency. Competition a Key Factor **********Analysts said outlays for advertising research had apparently been rising each year, outstripping inflation for more than a decade - although expenditure data are scanty because companies generally keep this secret for competitive reasons. **********Michael J. Naples, a former Lever Brothers research executive who heads the Advertising Research Foundation, said: ''Increased competitiveness in the marketplace in the 1970's has led to greater research expenditures to reduce the risk of making wrong decisions - which could be very expensive for a company.'' **********That competitiveness, he suggested, was caused by ''a maturing of the consumer marketing companies'' such as Procter & Gamble, Johnson & Johnson and Kellogg. **********Another reason why research expenditures have grown, Mr. Naples said, is that ''since new products have become very important to the growth of businesses, and since the introduction of a new product is the single largest risk factor that many companies have in terms of expenditures, there has been a need for better information.'' **********Research determined, for instance, that of the one-third of the population that often consumes low-calorie sodas, a majority were women. Coca-Cola wanted its recently introduced new beverage, diet Coke, to generate additional male drinkers of low-calorie soda. **********Accordingly, its initial advertising featured two well-known men - Phil Esposito, the sports announcer and former hockey player, and Judd Hirsch, the actor who appears on the television show ''Taxi.'' **********Indeed, it was only after research in the late 1970's had shown that the market for low-calorie soda was broadening that Coca-Cola was encouraged to put its new product on the market. **********Another reason for the growth in research, analysts said, was the proliferation of techniques and tools.  Specialized research companies have also proliferated. In the past 15 years or so, said Mr. Plummer, an executive vice president at Y.& R., the number of research companies ''has exploded - there are hundreds of them, all over the map.'' **********In addition to research companies, the more than 350 members of the Advertising Research Foundation of New York include advertisers, ad agencies and companies such as newspapers that serve as media for advertising. The foundation's mission is to help increase the saleseffectiveness of advertising through research. **********Advertising research inspires considerable enthusiasm and loyalty among its champions, who say the chance of error is higher in the application of research findings than in the findings themselves. **********''Research is just information,'' said Mr. Plummer. ''It doesn't do anything itself. It just sits there. Data are inert. So most of the time, mistakes involving research are made in the interpretation, not in the actual carrying out of the research itself.'' **********In terms of expenditures, a major form of the research explores media. Jack J. Honomichl, who writes a column about research for the trade journal Advertising Age, has estimated that about $150 million a year is spent on the measurement of audiences for electronic and print media. Delivering the Message **********Analyzing that emphasis, J. Kendrick Noble, first vice president and a media specialist at Paine Webber, said, ''Ultimately, the advertiser wants the most sales per dollar'' spent on advertising. **********He suggested that ''advertisers are spending more time trying to determine how to position their messages before the public most effectively,'' and that this ''traces back to the advent of the computer,'' which facilitated more sophisticated data analysis. **********Other forms of ad research include what the industry calls ''campaign tracking studies,'' which provide information about ad campaigns; ''copy testing,'' which means testing specific pieces of advertising; ''qualitative research,'' which includes in-depth interviews about specific products or advertising copy; and ''attitude research,'' which deals with aspects of consumers' life styles.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/10/world.body_text: **********The chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, Clement J. Zablocki, said today that Congressional support for Israel had ''somewhat diminished'' in the aftermath of Israel's attacks on Palestinian strongholds in Lebanon. **********''There's less support for Israel than historically in the past,'' Mr. Zablocki, a Wisconsin Democrat, said in an interview. ''Now they've gone after the Syrian missile sites and they've seem to gone beyond just going after the Palestinians.'' **********Mr. Zablocki's statement came as questions arose in Congress and within the Reagan Administration about Israel's use of American arms in the invasion of Lebanon. The United States has traditionally supplied arms to Israel on the agreement that the weaponry would be used only for defense. **********''Obviously the issue has to be considered,'' said a senior State Department official. ''It's got to be addressed in some ways in the future. But at the moment the focus is a cease-fire and diplomacy.''  'We Should Call a Halt' **********Former Under Secretary of State George W. Ball told a House subcommitee that the United States ''shouldn't permit the Israelis to accept our bounty every year and work at cross-purposes to our larger interests.'' **********''At some point we should call a halt,'' he added. ''That's the one sanction we have that they'd pay attention to because they're wholly dependent upon it.'' **********The increased tempo of the conflict today, with Israeli jets battling Syrian MIG's and attacking Syrian antiaircraft sites, has plainly concerned some members of Congress. **********''Many members have asked my assessment of this, and there are questions about the use of our foreign military items,'' Mr. Zablocki said. He added that the $6.8 billion foreign aid authorization bill, which was scheduled to reach the House floor in the next few days, had been delayed until the summer because the Reagan Administration had been unable to gather support for it and because the Lebanon fighting had caused Administration uneasiness about appearing to support the Israeli invasion. **********The bill would provide $2.4 billion in military and economic assistance for Israel in the fiscal year 1983, including $1.7 billion in military loans and grants. **********Moshe Arens, the Israeli Ambassador, met key legislators in private sessions today to give them Israel's position. ''The Israelis got questions on what their aims are, but they saw no shifts,'' away from support for Israel, said one lobbyist close to the Israelis.  ''The feeling is, there is potential for change if this thing drags on and people see the Israelis moving deeper into Lebanon.'' U.S. Avoids Criticizing Israel **********State Department officials voiced considerable concern about Israel's air attacks on Syrian missile batteries in Lebanon but declined to specifically criticize the Israelis. Officials insist privately that the Reagan Administration wants to avoid any statements that would upset Israel because the key aim of American diplomacy is to bring about a cease-fire in Lebanon. **********Alan Romberg, a State Department spokesman, said the United States had been told by Britain that three suspects arrested in last week's assassination attempt on the Israeli Ambassador to Britain, Shlomo Argov, were linked to ''a dissident terrorist group called Black June.'' He said the group had ''opposed recent P.L.O. policy and leadership.'' **********Although Israel's attacks against Palestine Liberation Organization bases in Lebanon came after the shooting of Mr. Argov, Israeli officials have made it clear that it was only one of what they said were many terrorist attacks against Israelis that had led to the invasion. No Comment on 'Justification' **********Asked whether the information from Britain had altered American judgments of Israel's rationale for the military assault, Mr. Romberg said, ''I'm not going to address the question of justification.'' **********Israeli officials, in their meetings on Capitol Hill, told members of Congress that Syria had ''provoked'' the latest Israeli attacks on antiaircraft sites in Lebanon.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/27/busin.body_text: **********The United States Synthetic Fuels Corporation today selected five projects in five states to compete for multimillion-dollar Federal subsidies to develop synthetic fuels. **********The projects, survivors of a lengthy process that began with 63 candidates, now enter into final negotiations over terms under which the subsidies would be granted. Most of the five, representing a range of technologies and resources, are expected to eventually get the subsidies. **********The proposed plants would be in Memphis; Gillette, Wyo.; Breckenridge County, Ky.; Creswell, N.C., and West Pittsburg, Calif. **********Enthusiasm Has Waned **********The selection, more than 17 months after the Government corporation conducted its first meeting, comes at a time when a world oil surplus has generally damped enthusiasm for synthetic fuels and bills are before Congress to dismantle the corporation. **********''My answer,'' commented Edward E. Noble, chairman of the Synthetic Fuels Corporation, ''is that, whatever the immediate supply situation, the Middle East remains highly volatile and the free world continues to depend on imported oil. Synthetic fuels can support the economic and defense security of this country and they can act as a brake against unwarranted oil price increases anywhere in the world.'' List of Projects Selected **********The projects selected today, their sponsors and the sponsors' estimates of total costs were: **********- Memphis: Memphis Light, Gas and Water, a city agency, which wants to turn coal into synthetic natural gas; $822 million. **********- Gillette: Hampshire Energy, a joint venture of several concerns, including Koppers, which proposes a coal-to-gasoline conversion plant; $2 billion. **********- Breckenridge County: Ashland Sythetic Fuels, a subsidiary of Ashland Oil, and Bechtel Petroleum, a subsidiary of the Bechtel Corporation, which want to build a plant to produce fuel oil from coal; $5.2 billion. **********- Creswell: Peat Methanol Associates, which plans to convert peat to methanol; $350 million. **********- West Pittsburg: California Synfuels Research, which proposes to convert heavy crude oil that refineries cannot now handle into a variety of liquid fuels; $49 million. **********Wycoal Inc., which had planned to build a $3.5 billion coal gasification plant in eastern Wyoming, dropped out of the competition this week, citing high interest rates, rapidly rising costs and an abundance of crude oil that cast doubt about ''the marketability of the product.'' Appeals Will Be Accepted **********Projects that lost out in today's decision will be able to apply by May 31 for a second round of awards. The corporation, created by a 1980 law, has $14.6 billion to use over the next several years. The five losers were a coal liquefaction plant in Murphy Hill, Ala.; a coal gasification plant in Daggett, Calif.; a coal liquefaction plant in Shelbyville, Ky.; a coal liquefaction plant in Oak Ridge, Tenn., and an oil shale plant in Uintah County, Utah. **********Three major synthetic fuels projects are already under way with Federal aid provided under an interim program of the Department of Energy: the Great Plains coal gasification project in North Dakota, and neighboring shale-oil projects in Colorado sponsored by the Union Oil Company of California and by a partnership of the Tosco Corporation and the Exxon Corporation. **********But the Tosco-Exxon Colony Project has drawn increased scrutiny for possible cost overruns, and the corporation today passed a resolution authorizing Mr. Noble to develop a monitoring system and take other steps that he feels necessary, short of ending the commitment. **********The contract, which includes a loan guarantee of $1.1 billion for Tosco, is reported to provide that it can be cancelled if total overruns exceed the original $3.1 billion estimate by more than 32 percent. Exxon did not apply for Government support. Meeting With Tosco Planned **********The corporation said that it had not yet decided whether to permit Tosco to draw its guaranteed loan -amounting to $100 million - from the Federal Financing Bank. Tosco has asked for this money next month. Mr. Noble said there would be a meeting with Tosco in the next few days to discuss the project. **********The original goal of the corporation was for a synthetic fuels industry that would produce the equivalent of 500,000 barrels of oil a day by 1987 and 2 million by 1992. This has been abandoned, and the expectation is that perhaps only a half dozen or so plants will be built in the foreseeable future, instead of 20 or more.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/21/busin.body_text: **********The Bath Iron Works Corporation, a subsidiary of the Congoleum Corporation, said yesterday that it had been awarded a $300 million contract by the Navy to construct combat cruisers. **********Bath said it might build as many as seven or eight of the heavily armed ships, known as CG47-class Aegis cruisers. The award will raise the shipyard's business backlog to a record $1.1 billion, Bath said. The lead shipyard in the program is the Ingalls Shipbuilding division of Litton Industries, which has contracts to build six of the cruisers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/06/world.main_headline: Polish Leader Assures Czechoslovakia on Ties
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/06/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Polish Leader Assures Czechoslovakia on Ties
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/06/world.body_text: **********Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, assured Czechoslovakia on a visit here today that Poland was once again firmly in the Soviet bloc after the suppression of the Solidarity labor movement. **********''Poland remains an indivisible part of the socialist community and it will remain so forever,'' General Jaruzelski said in a dinner toast reported by C.T.K., the official press agency. **********The Polish leader flew back to Warsaw after the dinner. **********It was his third visit to a Polish ally in five weeks. He visited the Soviet Union the first week in March and East Germany a month ago. **********Today, in a meeting with Gustav Husak, the Czechoslovak leader, General Jaruzelski ''emphasized that Poland will strengthen relations of sincere friendship and firm alliance with the U.S.S.R., Czechoslovakia and other fraternal countries in the interest of socialism and peace,'' the Czechoslovak press agency said.

Separately, the company said that a subsidiary had signed an agreement with the Hotel Corporation of the Bahamas to design and build a casino and other structures at a value of $33.4 million. *********** Continental Bank International, the Edge Act subsidiary of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, said it was opening branch offices in Cleveland, Dallas, Minneapolis, Philadelphia, San Francisco and Seattle. *********** Ethyl Corporation said that its Saytech Inc. subsidiary would build a plant in Arkansas to produce a bromine-based flame retardant for the plastics industry. The plant, which will employ about 200 people, will take about two years to build, with construction beginning in April. **********Darvin E. Smith, chairman and chief executive officer of the consumer products company, said the project is contingent upon obtaining building and environmental permits, acceptable financing and land titles,and satisfactory completion of engineering studies at the site. Kimberly-Clark is based in Neenah, Wis. **********According to Bowen Smith, an analyst at Salomon Brothers: ''Kimberly is looking at the South as the population growth segment of the U.S. The labor cost advantage in the South is old news. I knew they were planning to build a plant, but I didn't expect the investment would be this big.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/14/busin.body_text: **********The stock market rose sharply yesterday on near-record volume with the Dow Jones industrial average closing at its highest level in almost 18 months. **********The Dow, which was up 23 points at 2:30, closed ahead 11.40 points, to 1,015.08, its highest since April 28, 1981, when it finished at 1,016.93. The late selling pressure yesterday was attributed to profit taking. **********Volume rose to 139.8 million shares, the second highest ever, from 126.3 million shares on Tuesday. The record was set last Thursday when 147.1 million shares were traded. **********Analysts said the market's impetus came from another surge of buying by cash-laden institutional accounts and from the growing participation of small investors who are apparently convinced that interest rates will continue to decline and that stock prices will rise. Tape Is Late Again **********The analysts noted that the increased public participation was apparent in the delay experienced again by the New York Stock Exchange yesterday in handling many of the small buy and sell orders. The tape that records transactions was behind 37 minutes at the market's close. At the end of trading on Tuesday, the tape was 55 minutes late. **********The advance yesterday on the Big Board was across the board, with stocks that rose outnumbering issues that declined by more than a 3-to-1 ratio. The best performers were some of the blue chips, transportation, energy-related, technology and brokerage stocks. **********Charles M. Lewis, a vice president of Shearson/American Express, noted that yesterday's advance was also helped by a huge amount of short-covering, especially in many of the blue chips that have led the market's recent advance and have options expiring at the end of the week. **********Mr. Lewis said that 19 of the 30 stocks in the Dow industrial average have options expiring on Friday. Traders go short by selling a borrowed stock with the hope of buying it back later at a lower price, thus covering the sale and earning a profit. Merck Is Up 4 3/8 **********In the stronger blue-chip group yesterday, Merck climbed 4 3/8 points, to 86 3/4. American Brands was up 1 1/2, to 49 3/8, the Allied Corporation 1 1/8, to 35, and Du Pont 1 5/8, to 40 1/8. **********The biggest gainer in the technology group was Teledyne, which jumped 5, to 119 7/8, on heavy trading. Analysts said the upsurge was due mainly to heavy short-covering because of the number of Teledyne options expiring on Friday. **********Other strong issues in the technology category included Honeywell, which rose 2 1/8, to 92 3/4; National Semiconductor, up 1 3/4, to 20 1/8, and Digital Equipment, ahead 1 1/4, to 95 1/4. **********Reflecting the advance in the transportation issues, the Dow Jones Transportation average climbed 10.34 points, to 407.97. In this group, Delta Air Lines rose 1 1/4, to 32 1/4; Union Pacific was up 2, to 48 7/8, and Burlington Northern added 1 1/2, to 50 1/2. **********The oil-service issues and some oil producers, which had been laggards in the market's recent upsurge, registered sharp advances in heavy trading. Getty Oil gained 2 1/2 to 62 1/2; Halliburton 2 7/8, to 31 3/4; Dresser Industries 1 1/2, to 17 7/8; Helmerich & Payne 2 5/8, to 20 3/4; Global Marine 1 3/4, to 10; Occidental Petroleum 1 1/4, to 22 1/4, and Pennzoil 1, to 32 1/8. **********The heavy volume continued to strengthen the brokerage stocks, which derive much of their profits from high volume. Paine Webber was up 3 3/4, to 35 1/4; E.F. Hutton 1 1/8, to 40, and Merrill Lynch 1 1/8, to 48 1/8. **********Prices also climbed sharply on the American Stock Exchange, where the market-value index advanced 7.79 points, to 314.79. It was the largest one-day gain in the index since Jan. 28, 1981, when it rose 12.92 points, and was the highest close in the index since Jan. 4, when it finished at 321.41. **********In the over-the-counter market, the Nasdaq composite index rose 3.01, to 205.17. The Navco Corporation was ahead 2 1/2, to 19 bid, after it agreed to be acquired by the General Re Corporation for $21 a share.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/20/busin.main_headline: Personal Finance; HOW THE I.R.S. CAN SAVE YOU AN AUDIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/20/busin.print_headline: Personal Finance; HOW THE I.R.S. CAN SAVE YOU AN AUDIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/20/busin.body_text: **********The taxpayer was a United States citizen who owned a vacation home a broad and wanted to sell it to a foreign charitable organization.  B ut the charity was going to pay a bargain price for the house, and t he taxpayer wanted to know whether the difference between the fair m arket value of the vacation home and the amount he intended to c harge could be claimed as a charitable deduction. **********Thousands of dollars hung on the outcome, and the taxpayer could not afford to go ahead with the deal if the deduction were denied. So he did what more and more people are doing these days and requested a special advance ruling - known as a private letter ruling - from the Internal Revenue Service. The answer, issued earlier this year, was favorable, and presumably it gave him peace of mind as he went forward with the deal. **********''The major purpose of the letter ruling program is to provide taxpayers with certainty in advance of consummating a transaction,'' said Gerald G. Portney, the I.R.S.'s top technical expert and head of the section that issues the rulings. Because the program helps to avoid potential wrangles that can lead to audits, appeals and litigation, he added, ''it's a case where everybody wins.'' **********Private letter rulings are an arcane part of the nation's tax system that are generally familiar only to professionals such as lawyers and accountants who routinely deal with the intricacies of the law. ''John Q. Public doesn't know about them,'' said G. William Clapp, a tax partner with the accounting firm of Deloitte Haskins & Sells. ''But they probably should be more widely used than they are.'' **********As long as the actual transaction is exactly the same as the one outlined in the ruling request, a favorable private letter ruling virtually guarantees immunity against audit on the issues raised in the request. A taxpayer can still be audited on other, unrelated issues, however. **********The vast majority of the 5,000 or so such rulings the I.R.S. issues each year in response to voluntary requests deal with knotty business questions such as the tax implications of corporate reorganizations.  But many others deal with personal tax problems as well. **********Recent rulings, for example, considered whether an extra pair of special orthopedic shoes for a child with cerebral palsy were deductible (they were) and whether a husband-and-wife choral coaching team for a church were subject to Social Security and Federal income tax withholding (they were). **********Another case involved a taxpayer seeking a charitable deduction for a ''loveboat'' he planned to give to a tax-exempt organization that was formed to provide retreats for families to renew their familial relationships (The deduction, for the four-bedroom houseboat was granted). In yet another ruling request, the parents of a child with a birth defect sought a medical deduction for the costs of constructing a swimming pool for the youngster. (The parents, who were told the child must begin a swimming program in early infancy or face paralysis, received the deduction.) **********Frequently, investors thinking of swapping one piece of business property for another ask for a letter ruling so they will know whether the exchange will be considered tax-free. Another common request comes from executives being transferred abroad, who want to know whether the income tax of the foreign country will qualify as a creditable income tax for United States purposes. UNLIKE revenue rulings, which are only issued after an I.R.S. policyr eview and which apply to all taxpayers, the opinions in private r ulings apply only to the taxpayers requesting them. They cannot be c ited as precedent by other taxpayers. But ever since the law was c hanged in 1976 requiring the I.R.S. to publish all its letter r ulings, tax professionals have looked to private rulings as an i ndication of how the revenue service is likely to rule. Roscoe L.  E gger, the revenue service commissioner, has expressed concern that p rivate rulings are being cited too frequently as precedents in courtc ases, and he has warned that the revenue service may subject them toa higher level of review, which would sharply reduce the number i ssued. **********Private rulings are issued by a team of I.R.S. tax law specialists who are entirely separate from the revenue agents and tax auditors who examine returns. These specialists are required to contact taxpayers within 21 days after they have requested a letter ruling.  Though the ruling itself may not be issued for months, this informal contact with the specialist can be very helpful to a taxpayer. Often, the specialist will suggest ways to modify a proposed transaction so that it would qualify for a favorable ruling. **********''If the transaction is complex, the service may say, 'We will rule positively if you change it in this way,' '' said Michael I.  Saltzman, a partner in the law firm of Saltzman, Garbis, Schwait. **********On the other hand, the specialist may say he intends to issue an unfavorable ruling no matter how a taxpayer structures the deal. But even this advance information can be helpful. The drawback in going ahead with a transaction after the I.R.S. says it intends to issue an unfavorable ruling is that the taxpayer may be inviting an audit.  Frequently, the rulings division will send a copy of a withdrawn ruling request to a local I.R.S. office, where it can act as a red flag on a taxpayer's return. **********Another disadvantage to requesting a ruling is the cost of hiring a lawyer or accountant. ''It's kind of an expensive process,'' said Albert B. Ellentuck, national tax partner with the accounting firm of Laventhol & Horwath, who estimated the cost of a preparing a simple request at a minimum of $2,500. Moreover, the I.R.S., which currently issues rulings at no charge, is considering imposing a fee. **********Still another drawback is the time it takes to get one.  ''Generally, 80 percent of the rulings are issued within six months or less and maybe two-thirds are issued within four months or less,'' Mr. Portney of the revenue service said. **********At the same time, taxpayers do not have to retain a lawyer or accountant to request a private ruling, though most do. An I.R.S.  analysis indicates that about 8 percent of all ruling requests are filed by unrepresented taxpayers, and Mr. Portney said they fare as well as those with counsel. **********There is no magic to applying for a private ruling. Indeed, there is not even a special form, and Ellen Murphy, a spokesman for the I.R.S. says many taxpayers who write in for advice don't even realize they are in effect asking for a ruling. **********To request a letter ruling, a taxpayer should write the I.R.S.  Associate Chief Counsel-Technical, Room 6545, 1111 Constitution Ave.  N.W., Washington, D.C. 20224. The letter should include a description of all the facts concerning the proposed transaction, a statement of the legal points and authorities supporting your position, and a specific statement of what ruling you are asking for. **********Even though a ruling is requested, the I.R.S. may not comply. It will not issue private rulings on hypothetical transactions, for instance, or on questions of fact, such as whether the amount of compensation being paid to an executive is reasonable. **********There are also a host of particular tax matters on which it will not rule, because of pending court cases. Currently, the no-ruling list includes such questions as depreciation, whether scholarships and fellowships are taxable income, and whether a home being sold by a taxpayer age 55 or older qualifies as a principal residence for purposes of the $125,000 capital gains exclusion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/11/world.main_headline: IRAN ELECTED AN 83-MEMBER PANEL TO SELECT A SUCCESSOR TO KHOMEINI
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/11/world.print_headline: IRAN ELECTED AN 83-MEMBER PANEL TO SELECT A SUCCESSOR TO KHOMEINI
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/11/world.body_text: **********Iran's 82-year-old revolutionary leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, led Iranians today in voting for a special 83-member assembly to choose his successor after he dies. **********The Iranian state radio said he cast his vote in Teheran and other prominent ayatollahs voted in the holy city of Qum. **********All Iranians older than 16 were eligible to participate. **********Ayatollah Hussein Ali Montazeri, regarded as Ayatollah Khomeini's most likely successor, reportedly emerged from the polling place and prayed for long life for the revolutionary leader and for victory in Iran's war against Iraq. **********In a speech last month, Ayatollah Khomeini urged Iranians to vote as a measure ''to preserve the unity of the country.'' In reporting on the election, the Iranian press agency did not identify the candidates for what was described as the assembly of experts nor did it specify how they became eligible to run. But it was assumed that the assembly would consist of ayatollahs and other prominent clerics or laymen known for their religious fervor. **********The assembly is to decide whether to name one person as Ayatollah Khomeini's successor or to appoint a council of five or six.  Election of the assembly is provided for in the Constitution adopted by Ayatollah Khomeini's fundamentalist Islamic Government, which overthrew the Iranian monarchy in February 1979. **********The Teheran radio said the authorities banned motorcyclists in the capital from midnight Thursday though today ''to thwart possible plots by counterrevolutionaries.'' Motorcycles have been extensively used by members of the anti-Khomeini underground, who have been waging a campaign of assassination and bombing against Khomeini supporters.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/18/busin.main_headline: MAZDA GAINS A MARKET BY STAYING WITH THE ROTARY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/18/busin.print_headline: MAZDA GAINS A MARKET BY STAYING WITH THE ROTARY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/18/busin.body_text: **********HIROSHIMA, JAPAN IT was nearly 20 years ago, in March 1963, that Kenichi Yamamoto was called into the office of the late Tsunei Matsuda, then the president of the Toyo Kogyo Company, and told that he would lead a team to develop the rotary engine as a practical source of power for automobiles. **********''Frankly, I was not so interested in the rotary engine at the time,'' conceded Mr. Yamamoto, who is known as the ''father'' of the contemporary rotary engine and is now a senior managing director of Toyo Kogyo, the maker of Mazda autos. ''I did not believe that an engine other than the conventional engine was possible.'' **********Soon afterward, Mr. Yamamoto, an engineer, became a believer in the potential of the unconventional engine. But he was one of the few.  Indeed the long, checkered history of Toyo Kogyo's efforts with the rotary engine is a story of technological perseverance in the face of considerable odds and financial adversity. **********The case is also one of the most vivid examples of the difficulty and risk of doing one of the things that Japan does best: bringing to market - or commercializing - technology that originated elsewhere. **********By contrast, the United States is strong in basic research. But, as Presidential science adviser George A. Keyworth and others have warned, America seems to have slipped in recent years in transforming scientific knowledge into products for the marketplace. **********The rotary engine was invented in 1954 in West Germany by Dr. Felix Wankel in cooperation with Audi NSU Auto Union of West Germany. In 1961, Toyo Kogyo was among about 23 companies that licensed the technology from Wankel and Audi/NSU. **********Today, Toyo Kogyo, Japan's third-largest auto maker, is the only auto maker in the world producing the rotary engine. Bigger and wealthier auto manufacturers, including the General Motors Corporation and the Nissan Motor Company tried without success to commercialize the rotary engine for automobiles. Both abandoned their projects because of problems with poor fuel economy and high exhaust emissions. NOT that development went all that smoothly for Toyo Kogyo. Its e xecutives occasionally had their own doubts about the wisdom of p ursuing an unproven engine technology. And in the mid-1970's, as g asoline prices soared after the 1973 Arab oil embargo, it was l argely the company's reliance on the rotary engine, which then got o nly 10 miles a gallon in city driving, that pushed Toyo Kogyo to t he brink of financial disaster. Inventories, losses and debts piled u p. From sales of 119,000 cars in 1973, Mazda's 1974 sales plunged to7 0,000 cars. It had a 15-month supply of rotary engine cars at a t ime when a two-month supply was considered normal. In 1975, the c ompany lost $57 million - the biggest loss in its history. **********A spirited internal debate ensued. Eventually, Toyo Kogyo and its main financial backer, the Sumitomo Bank, decided not to abandon the rotary engine, though its production was scaled back, mostly for use in the company's high-performance sports car, the RX-7. The number of rotary engine-equipped cars sold by Mazda fell from a peak of 224,241 in 1973 to a low of 43,732 in 1977. Last year, the total of rotary-powered vehicles was 63,975. Toyo Kogyo also makes conventional piston engines and diesel engines. **********Now the company's rotary engine is comparatively fuel-efficient, getting 21 miles a gallon in city driving and 30 miles a gallon on the highway, and Toyo Kogyo is solidly profitable. In the six months ended April 30, the company reported that its earnings rose 13.5 percent from the comparable period a year ago, to $45.2 million, on sales of $2.5 billion, up 1.5 percent, from $2.46 billion a year earlier. **********For Mr. Yamamoto, the rotary engine has been more than a marketing and engineering challenge, it has been a daily obsession from the start. This thin, intense man says he believes that there is a lesson in his company's experience. ''For the development of new technology like the rotary engine,'' he explained, ''you need consistent passion, not just logic.'' **********Much of that passion was plain corporate pride, Toyo Kogyo executives concede. In the early 1970's, before all the problems with the rotary cropped up, the corporate motto was ''Mazda is making history.'' For years, the rotary attracted some of Japan's brightest young automotive engineers to Toyo Kogyo, lured by the prospect of working on the rotary project. Thus, to admit failure publicly by abandoning it altogether would have been a great loss of face for Toyo Kogyo, in a country where corporate face matters very much. **********In Japan - as in the United States - corporate commitment tends to be measured by a double standard: A new product or technology is praised in fulsome tones when it has become a success. But when the new idea turns out to be a dud, the corporate commitment is usually deemed inflexibility on the part of management. **********In Toyo Kogyo's case, the rotary engine was ultimately a modest success. It has become a marketable product.  Yet that achievement was expensive. Toyo Kogyo has spent an estimated $100 million on research and development of the rotary, in addition to the untold cost of sales opportunities missed by not having a fuel-efficient line in the mid-1970's. IN 1961, Toyo Kogyo was mainly a producer of trucks, including t hree-wheeled vehicles sold throughout Asia. To become a full-fledgedi nternational auto producer, Tsuneji Matsuda, then the president, r easoned that Toyo Kogyo needed a competitive weapon that would give i t a distinctive niche in the marketplace. A trained engineer, Mr.  M atsuda chose as that weapon a new technology, the rotary engine. **********In theory, the rotary engine had great appeal. It would be 30 percent lighter, 50 percent smaller and contain only a fraction of the moving parts of the piston engine. **********By May 1963, Mr. Yamamoto had assembled a team of more than 40 engineers whose mission was to hone the German technology into a massproduction item. In April 1967, Toyo Kogyo began producing the rotary engine. ''That's when we crossed the Rubicon,'' Mr. Yamamoto said. **********The rotary engine that Toyo Kogyo produced in 1967 was almost entirely different from the German design it licensed six years before, except for the basic rotary concept. **********But once that technical Rubicon had been crossed, there were to be other obstacles in bringing the engine to market. In the late 1960's, air pollution became a pressing concern and a political issue in the United States. In early testing, the rotary-driven Mazdas were found to be polluters, emitting high levels of hydrocarbons. **********At the time, some scientists said the rotary engine could never meet the emissions requirements and would be relegated to being a museum curiosity. Yet by 1970, Toyo Kogyo was able to meet the American emissions guidelines through the development of a thermal reactor, a chamber for further burning its exhaust emissions. STILL, Toyo Kogyo executives believed that the pollution c ontroversy had blemished the reputation of the rotary. To burnish i t, the company decided in 1972 to stretch to meet the much more s tringent emissions control requirements then being proposed by S enator Edmund Muskie, Democrat of Maine. The approach of most of thea uto industry was to fight the so-called Muskie bill. At hearings in W ashington in May 1973 for the bill, only two companies testified, H onda and Toyo Kogyo. ''The others just said it was impossible,'' r ecalled Mr. Yamamoto, who represented his company at the hearings.  ' 'They wanted to maintain the establishment.'' **********Five months later, when the Arab oil embargo began, fuel efficiency replaced pollution control as the focus of public concern, and the Muskie bill was shelved. **********But in redesigning the rotary to meet the requirements of the proposed Muskie bill, Toyo Kogyo had paid a stiff penalty in fuel economy. And it paid dearly for being out of step with a suddenly changed market. The rotary was branded as a Japanese engine with an American disease - it was a gas-guzzler. Inventories piled up. **********Still, the company chose not to abandon the rotary engine. Its engineers believed that fuel efficiency could be improved considerably in a few years through a series of changes in fuel mixture, materials and design. **********In 1974, Mr. Yamamoto became the chief of ''Project Phoenix.'' His search for fuel-saving innovations was eventually successful: In 1981, when the RX-7 sports car, the hope of the rotary's future, was introduced in Las Vegas, it was an emotional moment for Mr. Yamamoto. **********''The tears ran down my face, '' he recalled. ''After all that difficulty, we came back.'' The rotary engine is now used in only about 8 percent of Toyo Kogyo passenger cars. Though it works well as a sports car engine, the rotary engine tends to lose power at low speeds, a liability in stopand-go driving. Mr. Yamamoto says a ''supercharged'' rotary that will have greater power at lower speeds will be on the market ''in the near future.'' But Toyo Kogyo is not expanding capacity to meet any surge in demand for rotary engines. **********Accordingly, it seems fair to ask whether all Toyo Kogyo's travails with the rotary were worth the effort. ''All things considered, I think it has been extremely good for Toyo Kogyo,'' said John T. Eby, president of the Ford Motor Company of Japan, and who is a Toyo Kogyo director. In November 1979, Ford bought a 25 percent stake in the Japanese company. **********Mr. Eby notes that the corps of engineers originally attracted to the company to work on the rotary has given Toyo Kogyo considerable strength in creating its own products, such as its highly successful front-wheel drive GLC/323, introduced in 1980. **********Furthermore, Toyo Kogyo executives believe that the rotary engine will be a useful weapon in an era of increased international competition. Ichiro Maeda, Toyo Kogyo's managing director for corporate planning, says that to thrive through the 1980's and 1990's his company must concentrate on certain ''niches'' in the market, rather than by trying to emulate giants like General Motors and Toyota, whose many lines of vehicles cover the automotive spectrum. **********''The rotary engine is very good for sporty cars,'' Mr. Maeda said. ''This will be one of our niches.''  THE LITTLE ENGINETHAT FINALLY COULD **********Felix Wankel, a West German automobile engineer, invented the rotary engine in 1954 and a Japanese company modified it after acquiring the rights in 1961. But it wasn't until years later that the United States got its first rotary-engine auto -a Mazda - and today Mazda's RX-7 remains the only rotary-powered car on the American market. **********The rotary engine popularized by Mazda's RX-7 is one of three commercially successful internal-combustion automobile engines. The others are the conventional piston-driven engine that has powered cars since 1886, and the diesel, which burns fuel by heat from compression, rather than explosions from spark plugs. **********The rotary has no pistons, intake or exhaust valves, connecting rods, or crankshaft. With fewer moving parts, it is lighter, vibrates less and makes less noise than a piston engine. **********The challenges of modifying the Wankel design for mass production were formidable enough to dissuade most of the other companies that acquired rights to the technology. Engineers at Toyo Kogyo, the makers of Mazdas, changed almost everything but the basic rotary concept. Metallurgists had to develop alloys and castings that could withstand the heat and friction. Seals had to be designed that would withstand high pressure and heat while preventing leaks.  Energyefficient fuel-air intakes and environmentally sound exhaust systems had to be created. **********''You have to take your hat off to the Toyo Kogyo people,'' said Mitsuya Goto, general manager of the international division of the Nissan Motor Company in Tokyo. ''Despite all the troubles the rotary gave the company, they did eventually succeed with it.'' **********Unlike a piston engine that creates power with pistons that move up and down within cylinders and turn a central crankshaft, Mazda's rotary engine has two triangular rotors with rounded edges that turn within vaguely figure-eight-shaped combustion chambers. Ignition of the air-fuel mixture by two spark plugs in the path of each rotor creates the explosive force that keeps the rotors turning. The central shaft turned by the spinning rotors transmits the power that drives the wheels. **********The Mazda's rotary displaces about 70 cubic inches and is relatively light (245 pounds for the manual transmission engine). It delivers 100 horsepower at 6,000 revolutions per minute. **********By comparison, the Datsun 280ZX, another popular Japanese-built sports car, is powered by a six-cylinder, overhead-cam piston engine that is more than twice as heavy but delivers 145 horsepower at 5,200 revolutions per minute. **********About 185,640 of the Mazda RX-7's have been sold since the car was introduced in the United States in May 1978. The top-of-the-line model has a suggested list price of $11,895. The newest RX-7 equipped with catalytic converter is rated at 21 miles a gallon for city driving and 30 miles a gallon for the highway.
