https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/12/busin.body_text: **********THE late Stephen Potter, famous as the discoverer of Gamesmanship (''the art of winning at games without actually cheating''), also made important but less noticed contributions to economics, which he called ''the plonking science.'' By plonking he meant the uttering of trite and obvious ideas in a heavy, pompous manner. **********Mr. Potter discovered two basic ploys used by plonking economists.  The first (Economic Approach A) relies on ''a little wild incomprehensibility.'' A still-useful example comes from Mr. Potter's 1952 book, ''One-Upmanship'': **********''If you want to influence the general liquidity situation of banks and public,'' the economic plonker begins, pretending to expect a reply. ''If you do,'' he quickly goes on, ''I think you're forgetting that the Bank of England's discretionary action on the cash basis took the shape of dealing in Treasury Bills, the market rate of discount on which could and did fluctuate.'' **********The second, more classic ploy (Economic Approach B) is the ''approach of utter obviousness,'' also known as ''stupefaction of the exhaustingly clear.'' An example, to be delivered in a cuttingly audible voice capable of dulling the organs of comprehensibility: ''Unless something happens to change the state of demand, more will be bought at any given price than at any higher price.'' **********The just-released annual report of President Reagan's Council of Economic Advisers breaks new ground in its use of Economic Approach B. Here are a few of its plonks: **********- ''In a market economy, individual income depends upon what one has to sell and on the amount which others are willing to pay for it.'' **********- ''Individuals have different preferences and desire different goods and services.'' **********- ''Many people prefer not to live in a society where there is poverty and thus have an incentive to transfer some of their resources to the poor voluntarily. When one individual performs such a transfer, all individuals who dislike poverty benefit. Thus, most people will have an incentive to reduce their contributions to the poor and rely on the contributions of others.'' The authors' conclusion: Voluntary transfers will in all likelihood be too low to keep people out of poverty, so perhaps Government should do something. However, that will hurt the society's efficiency. For, as the report goes on: **********- ''Regardless of the form of transfer, there is still an efficiency cost. Transfers reduce the incentive of recipients to work, and the taxes imposed on the rest of society to finance these transfers also cause losses in efficiency.'' (This was also the argument of the 19th-century Social Darwinian, Herbert Spencer, who was against free public libraries, because he thought they caused loafing. Presumably nobody ever learned anything useful in a free public library.) **********But the Council of Economic Advisers often switches from Economic Approach B (utter obviousness) to Approach A (a little incomprehensibility.) A couple of examples: **********- ''The volatility in borrowed reserves could be reduced by tying the discount rate to market rates so as to reduce variability in the incentive to borrow. To keep such variability to an absolute minimum, the Federal Reserve would also have to set its discount rate som ewhatabove market interest rates - that is, to act as a penalty.'' **********- ''An important reason for going back to contemporaneous reserve accounting would be to permit greater flexibility in the discount rate, at a penalty rate or otherwise, which in turn would provide more precise short-run control over total reserves by reducing the volatility of borrowings.'' **********Mr. Potter was convinced that the purpose of plonking was to snow an audience. That may be. But it contains a danger: It may also act as a form of self-hypnosis upon the plonker, who may grow convinced that what he is saying makes sense, and is the only thing that does.  It may lead him to become deaf to counterarguments and counterevidence. It may even breed hostility to reality when reality fails to conform either to the uttterly obvious truths the plonker utters or to his brilliantly incomprehensible reasoning. **********But the council's report suggests that its members have not quite gone off the deep end yet. While they insist that monetarism and supply-side economics are ''two sides of the same coin,'' they recognize that big and continuing deficits (the consequence of too large supply-side tax cuts) may in a time of expansion sop up too much private saving and foreign capital inflows, drive up interest rates, retard investment and economic growth, create uncertainties about the Government's ability to control spending, make the task of the Federal Reserve harder and raise inflationary expe ctations.  However, the council declares, quickly recove ring its sang-froid, ''Maintenance of monetary restraint is a key part of the Administration's program and hence the potent ially inflationary effects of monetizing the Federal deficit wil l not be realized.'' Belief hardens into ideology. The plonker is self-plonked.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/23/world.main_headline: A MILD NEW PRESIDENT FOR ARGENTINA
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/23/world.print_headline: MAN IN THE NEWS; A MILD NEW PRESIDENT FOR ARGENTINA
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/23/world.body_text: **********Reynaldo Benito Antonio Bignone, who was thrust into Argentina's presidency today, is a curious complement to the man who put him there, Lieut. Gen. Cristino Nicolaides. **********While people use such terms as ''tough,'' ''no-nonsense'' and ''hard-line'' to describe General Nicolaides, the new army commander, the description of General Bignone is often simply ''nice.'' **********''He is a mild man, not a hawk, and very different from Nicolaides,'' a Government official said today. He added that the new President, who retired from active duty as a major general late last year, was unlikely to give the army high command major problems in managing a Government that, with limited navy and air force support, appears likely to be less stable than its predecessor. **********No Involvement With Falklands **********That may have been part of his appeal to General Nicolaides, whose harsh manner and lack of political experience were said to have eliminated the possibility of his filling the job of President himself. **********Another was that General Bignone had no involvement in Argentina's war with Britain over the Falkland Islands, whose unsuccessful conclusion led to the ouster of President Leopoldo Galtieri last week. **********General Bignone, who is 54 years old, is known to be a strong supporter of the free-market economic policies of Jose Alfredo Marti de Hoz, who served as Minister of the Economy under President Jorge Rafael Videla. This was the policy that made him least attractive to the air force, which has favored tough controls on Argentina's battered economy. **********General Bignone has also spoken forcefully about the need for civil liberties, but has tempered his statements with warnings against Communists and other subversives. 'Civil Courage' Urged **********Commenting last year on the changes that had taken place in Argentina since its violent antiguerrilla campaign of the 1970's, he said, ''If someone was afraid to speak, now he can do it; if someone was afraid to write, now he writes; if someone was afraid to act, now he has no reason for it, and if someone was afraid of criticism, with reason or without it, now he can express it.'' **********But while calling for ''civil courage,'' he added that he excluded from these liberties ''the subersives and corrupt ones who we think and hope should have the greatest fear possible.'' **********General Bignone was born Jan. 21, 1928, in the town of Moron, west of the capital. He is married to the former Nilda Raquel Belen, and they have three children. **********His training and background are purely military. He entered the National Military Academy as a cadet at the age of 16, graduating as a second lieutenant in 1947. He worked his way upward, becoming a captain at the end of 1954 when he entered the Superior War College. **********He continued his climb, taking command of the Cadet Corps in the National Military Academy in 1970 and being named secretary to to high command in 1973. Subsequent posts were director of the National Military Academy, second in command of Argentina's military institutes, and secretary general of the army. Some Political Experience **********In December 1980 he became commander of military institutes, serving in that post until his retirement.  For a country where civilian politics has been suspended for six years, General Bignone's political experience is relatively extensive. **********A soft-featured, balding man who wears wire-rimmed glasses, he was an intimate of the generals who seized power from civilians in 1976.  As secretary general of the army during President Videla's tenure, he often served as liaison between the military and the political parties, by then suspended. **********His skills in this area should be useful if the army intends, as it pledged today, to return Argentina to civil government by early 1984.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/03/busin.body_text: **********''If you think of the food business as being your desk top, picture a wide segment in the middle that takes up about half of the desk,'' says John Morris, vice president of corporate development at the Campbell Soup Company. ''That's where Campbell is today. What we want to do is get on either side.'' **********Campbell, which opened its first factory here 113 years ago, has embarked on a strategy to expand beyond its base of soups, Swanson frozen food and Pepperidge Farm baked goods, and that activity has increased in the last three months. A company long known for its conservative approach to business, Campbell is now committed to a growth-through-acquisition strategy and a new emphasis on marketing. **********In January, it entered the frozen-sandwich market when it purchased for an undisclosed sum Snow King Inc., a Pottstown, Pa., maker of frozen sandwich meat whose sales in 1981 were $32 million. **********Then, in late March, Campbell announced an agreement in principle to buy Mrs. Paul's Kitchens for an undisclosed price. The privately held Philadelphia company has about 25 percent of the frozen fish market, and with some 65 frozen food varieties and $124 million in sales in 1981, it is the largest producer of frozen fish products. **********Mrs. Paul's, however, is engaged in a costly rebellion by franchisees of its Arthur Treacher's Fish & Chips Inc. subsidiary, who refused to buy Mrs. Paul's products or pay it royalties. The proposed purchase by Campbell does not include the Arthur Treacher's operation. What it does include is brand names, current inventories, three frozen-food plants and a headquarters building. 'You Have to Acquire' **********Campbell manufactures a variety of processed foods at about 80 plants in the United States and a dozen foreign countries. Last year it reported earnings of $129.7 million, up 6.6 percent from $121.7 million in the fiscal year 1980, on sales of $2.8 billion, which were up 7.7 percent from $2.6 billion. **********''We determined we are going to grow at about 5 percent above inflation, which means you have to sell 5 percent more each year,'' Mr. Morris said of the acquisition push. ''The food business grows at about 1 to 2 percent a year, so if you want to grow at 5 percent you have to acquire to make the difference. **********''Our strategy is to acquire in areas of the food business where we are not represented and we prefer small companies that are on the fast track, that are in rapidly growing parts of the industry.'' **********In the past three years, that acquisition push has netted for Campbell such operations as Vlasic Foods, a pickles and relish producer; the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation's European food operations; Swift-Armour S.A. Argentina, a meat producer that supplies beef to Campbell; German Village, an Ohio pasta manufacturer; a couple of Southwest poultry growers; two mushroom farms; Martino's Bakery Inc., a California pie and cake maker, and Domsea Farms Inc., breeder of plate-size salmon and trout in Washington State that has $3 million in sales. Different Eating Patterns **********Campbell is now focusing the expansion on product lines that address changing food consumption patterns. Americans are eating more in the way of ''lighter'' foods such as fish and salads, and less beef. Mr. Morris said Campbell was looking to gain entry in the refrigerated salad lines, and new juice lines. **********''We are trying to head this company toward lighter types of protein, less carbohydrates, less salt,'' said R. Gordon McGovern, Campbell's president and chief executive officer. ''I think the underlying interest came in our analysis of the changing trend from meat, which is very expensive and has a high conversion feeding rate.'' By that he meant that more protein must be fed to a pound of beef than to chicken or fish for the amount of protein extracted. **********Mr. McGovern noted that Americans still eat less fish than do Europeans, but that Campbell intends to benefit from the changing eating patterns. He said that the proposed acquisition of Mrs. Paul's ''gives us the complete operation, from purchasing of ocean fish to preparation.'' Campbell will aggressively market Mrs. Paul's fish products and line of frozen vegetables. ''They've had to pull back on marketing because of difficulties with Arthur Treacher's,'' Mr.  McGovern said. ''We hope to restore it, and hope to come up with new items for them.'' **********Campbell entered the fish market in a small way when it purchased Domsea Farms, Union Carbide's pilot sea-ranching operation in Bainbridge Island, Wash. Mr. McGovern indicated Campbell was interested in a long-term venture of raising fish for its food products. **********''In the future it may be promising to raise some varieties of fish yourself,'' said Richard Larsen, a food industry analyst with the First Manhattan Company. ''They have Domsea Farms, which is in that business, so they are a few inches further along on the learning curve than other people.'' A New Marketing Thrust **********Besides such ventures into new food lines, Campbell is sharpening its marketing efforts. Mr. McGovern, who was named chief executive officer in January 1981, was reportedly brought in because of his marketing skills. He was president of the Pepperidge Farm Inc.  subsidiary. **********''The decision makers at Pepperidge Farm were marketers as opposed to the decision makers at the rest of Campbell, who were engineers.'' Mr. Larsen said. ''This is an indication that they are being marketing oriented.'' **********Barry Ziegler, a vice president at Bache Halsey Stuart, who follows the company, said: ''It's a company that has done things in a conservative fashion for so long. They've been dominated by protection of their soup franchise, trying to keep market share, and increase productivity. Under McGovern there seems to be something of a new tack. He's breaking up the company into business units. He would also like to be more aggressive with new products.'' **********Indeed, under Mr. McGovern, Campbell is experimenting with new versions of its standard soup product. ''A lot of people in the press call our soup products 'mature,' '' Mr. McGovern said. ''I'm calling them 'underworked.' '' **********He said Campbell was test-marketing soups intended to address new tastes. They include a line with ''crispy'' vegetables, a low-sodium line, and what he calls ''candlelight'' soups - upscale and noncondensed varieties such as clear oxtail soup and Serbian bean soup. https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/24/world.body_text: **********The Christian Democratic Party of Prime Minister Amintore Fanfani denounced its Socialist coalition partner today for accusing Bulgaria of complicity in the shooting of Pope John Paul II last year. **********An article on the front page of Il Popolo, the Christian Democratic Party paper, accused the Socialists of ''manipulation'' of the case against Bulgaria for internal political advantage. **********Il Popolo said the Christian Democrats were aware of the gravity of the facts that suggest a Bulgarian role. But it said the party was also aware ''that in matters so delicate, in the relations between states, it is necessary to stay within the area of facts that have been ascertained and proved.'' **********For their part, the Socialists replied angrily with a front-page editorial in their paper, Avanti! They rejected the charge of political manipulation and accused the Christian Democrats of a ''classical campaign of disinformation'' and ''turning a deaf ear'' to ''a case that has aroused the emotions of world public opinion.'' Attack Called an 'Act of War' **********Il Popolo was clearly commenting on a statement to Parliament last Monday by Defense Minister Lelio Lagorio, a Socialist, who denounced Bulgaria and also said, in an apparent allusion to the Soviet Union, that the attempt to kill the Pope was an ''act of war'' that was an alternative to an invasion of Poland. **********Christian Democrats and other politicians and diplomatic analysts say they suspect that the motive for the Socialist attack was to embarrass both the Christian Democrats and the Communists. **********Under the leadership of Bettino Craxi, the Socialists, the second largest party in the four-party coalition, are making a strong effort to portray themselves as more vigilant over Italy's security than the Christian Democrats. At the same time, accusations against a country of the Soviet bloc are viewed here as directed also against the powerful Communist Party, Italy's second largest political organization. **********A Bulgarian diplomat who asked not to be identified said today that he agreed with the Christian Democratic contention that the Italian Socialists were attempting to turn the issue to their political advantage. **********''What will be the consequences if these accusations cannot be confirmed?'' he asked. ''The responsibility for the results will not be ours.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/15/world.print_headline: REAGAN AIDES AT ODDS; News Analysis
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/15/world.body_text: **********The continuing differences between Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Defense Secretary Caspar W.  Weinberger seem so obvious to some ranking officials that they say the effective management of the Reagan Administration's foreign policy is being threatened. **********It has been clear for some time that the disagreements between the two secretaries were more than the usual State Department-Pentagon rivalries, despite repeated efforts by both men and their aides to gloss them over publicly. **********But in recent months, with the Administration deeply involved in trying both to maintain a cease-fire in the Middle East and to keep the Western alliance together in the midst of the Polish crisis, these Haig-Weinberger differences appear more acute. White House Frowns on Conflict **********Because the White House has made it clear that it does not like to see any public debate among its top aides, Mr. Haig and Mr.  Weinberger have been under pressure to play down the intensity of the conflict. Mr. Haig, who lacks Mr. Weinberger's longstanding personal friendship with the President, has in particular sought to avoid any public clash. **********However, when pressed today about public disagreements on how hard to press the Soviet Union, Mr. Haig acknowledged on the ABC News television program ''This Week'' that the dispute existed. **********''I think there are clearly differences,'' he said, ''but what's new about that? Each department comes at these problems from their differing perspectives. That's inevitable. It has always been so.'' Differences Grew During Trips **********Mr. Weinberger and Mr. Haig both returned to Washington on Saturday night after separate trips abroad, during which some of these differences became more pronounced as a result of public statements and through unattributed remarks from each man's Air Force plane. **********On the Middle East, the dispute is significant because Mr. Haig and Mr. Weinberger seem to have differing assessments of the importance of Israel to the United States. The Israelis and their supporters in this country have long said that Mr. Haig is more sympathetic to Israel's interests than Mr. Weinberger. Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel, at one point, publicly accused Mr. Weinberger of being hostile to his country. **********This perception arose because Mr. Weinberger, following Israel's unexpected attack on an Iraqi nuclear reactor last June, was reported to have urged much stricter sanctions against Israel than were subsequently approved. Furthermore, after each of the policy disputes with Israel, Mr. Haig has seemed to go out of his way to repeat the longstanding American pledges of support for Israel's security. **********Mr. Weinberger was depicted by Pentagon officials as having been at least initially opposed to signing the strategic cooperation agreement with Israel that was worked out at Mr. Haig's urging. And even though the accord was suspended after Israel annexed the Golan Heights, Mr. Haig has been received warmly by Mr. Begin and other top officials during his two recent trips to Israel. Israel Omitted From Itinerary **********The Defense Secretary, on his trip to the Middle East last week, went to Saudi Arabia, Oman and Jordan but omitted stopping in Israel, further fueling Israeli suspicions. Moreover, Mr. Weinberger and his aides were repeatedly quoted in ways that the Israelis found offensive. **********This reached a peak on Saturday when Mr. Weinberger said in Jordan that he favored the sale of arms such as advanced F-16 fighters and mobile antiaircraft missiles to Jordan. In addition, reporters on his plane said a senior official on his staff had said that the Reagan Administration was trying to ''redirect'' military policy away from Israel and toward the Arabs. Today Israel publicly protested those statements. **********State Department experts on the Middle East are very uneasy about those remarks because of a fear that the Israelis, already tense over the prospective return of the last segment of Sinai to Egypt in April and the reported buildup of Palestinian forces in southern Lebanon, might carry out a major military attack against the Palestinians and the Syrians out of frustration if Mr. Begin believes that the Administration is trying to work against Israel's interests. View Shared by Military Aides **********Mr. Weinberger's position, which is widely shared by senior military officers, is that the United States has neglected its ties to friendly Arab countries because of being hostage to Israeli policy. **********The Defense Secretary took the lead in pushing for the sale of Awacs radar planes to Saudi Arabia last year, and he seems convinced that Israel has not shown itself to be acting as a friend of America. Israel, he appears to believe, should pay a price for its bombing of the Iraqi reactor, the bombing raids in Beirut that killed many civilians and its annexation of the Golan Heights, all of which complicated overall American interests in the Middle East. **********Mr. Haig, on television today, said that he had coordinated with Mr. Weinberger, before they both left Washington, on what would be said on foreign policy issues, and declared that Mr. Weinberger was ''very close to those agreements.'' 'A Very Incorrect Word' **********But then, he added that he wanted ''to set the record very, very clear'' on the policy toward Israel. He said that the policy of President Reagan, ''who is the ultimate authority,'' had not changed in its support of Israel. When asked if the Weinberger aide had used the wrong word in saying there was an effort to ''redirect'' policy, Mr. Haig said, ''it is a very incorrect word if that is how it has been interpreted.'' **********The problem for the management of American policy is that the impression that Mr. Weinberger is hostile to Israel tends to undercut the effort being made by Mr. Haig to keep the Israelis from launching a new attack and to keep them interested in working out with Egypt an agreement on Palestinian self-rule. **********On the European questions, Mr. Weinberger and his chief aides seem to believe that the major allies are too detente-minded and unwilling to share a fair burden of defense and political costs in confronting the Soviet Union. As a result, European diplomats have tended to see Mr. Haig as their friend within the Administration, particularly during the Polish crisis. Pentagon Opposes Pipeline **********The Pentagon, which traditionally opposes any kind of technological transfer to the Soviet Union, has seized on the Polish crisis to advance its view that there should be ironclad controls on trade with the Russians and that renewed pressure should be brought on the allies to scrap their arrangements for a natural gas pipeline from the Soviet Union. **********In Madrid last week, Mr. Haig made it clear that while he personally opposed the pipeline project, he also was against allowing the differences over that deal to upset allied unity on Poland. **********Today, he said he was personally ''appalled'' by France's decision to go ahead with the pipeline project, but added, ''What I do not want done is to suddenly seize the anguish of the Polish situation to attempt to accomplish what has been a longstanding United States policy, and that is, to convince our allies that there are other alternatives, and above all to avoid blackmail of those allies on this very sensitive issue.'' Effectiveness of Sanctions **********On the overall question of sanctions, reporters on Mr. Haig's plane were told on Saturday that the curbs already imposed had been significant in forcing the Polish authorities to seek to moderate their crackdown. **********''We're not trying to pursue policies that will inevitably lead to violence and Soviet intervention,'' the reporters were told. ''That might make a lot of ideologues happy and enable them to say 'I told you so,' but I don't think it meets the prudent objectives of our historic needs.'' **********The reference to ''ideologues'' appeared to underscore Secretary Haig's defensiveness about charges that he has not been tough enough toward the Soviet Union. Central American Problems **********Mr. Weinberger has escaped such criticism and this rankles Mr.  Haig's senior aides, who like to point out that on Central America, for instance, Mr. Haig has been more willing to countenance the use of American military force to counter Cuban influence than has Mr.  Weinberger. **********Mr. Weinberger and his backers, however, argue that they have a better understanding of what is possible in America today. They say that the dispatch of American combat forces would be rejected on Capitol Hill and would cause major problems for the Pentagon in obtaining its appropriations for programs designed to counter the Soviet Union globally. **********The debate on what to do about the situation in Central America is apparently reaching its end within the Administration, with Mr.  Reagan due to give a major speech on his Caribbean Basin plan soon.  Mr. Haig, on television today, declined to give details of the speech in advance, except to say that it would deal with economic, social and security problems in the area.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/08/busin.body_text: **********Although serious talk is expected from all concerned, 14 of the nation's governors at this week's annual meeting of the National Governors Association are likely to seem a bit less nervous than the rest, and with good reason: They won't have to face the voters this fall. **********Those who take to the hustings face a grim vista; for the past three years, state balance sheets have been eroding steadily. **********And unless the economy starts growing at rates few experts outside the Administration expect, things are likely to get worse. **********Thus far, only two states have declared that they will run deficits in 1983. But 17 more are projecting surpluses of $5 million or less. In its most recent survey, the association estimates that states will end the fiscal year 1983 with surpluses of $1.8 billion, far below 1980 levels.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/17/busin.body_text: **********The Pabst Brewing Company, citing costs associated with the closing of its Peoria, Ill., plant, reported yesterday that it had a secondquarter net loss of $371,000. **********The Milwaukee brewer said it had operating income of $8 million in the quarter ended June 30 on revenue of $218.9 million. The net loss resulted from an $8.9 million charge resulting from the Peoria plant shutdown. **********In last year's second quarter, Pabst earned $3.2 million, or 39 cents a share, on revenue of $245.1 million. That was 10.7 percent higher than revenue in the second quarter this year. **********Pabst, one of the nation's largest brewers, said that for the first six months of this year it had revenue of $395.2 million, down 5.9 percent from $419.9 million in last year's first half. Net income slipped 14.2 percent, to $1.2 million, or 15 cents a share, from $1.4 million, or 17 cents a share, in the first six months of 1981. **********William S. Smith Jr., Pabst's president and chief executive, said that operating results ''make clear that the many cost-cutting and streamlining measures we have implemented in the last nine months have had important positive effects on Pabst.'' **********The brewer, which last year ranked fifth among the nation's beer makers, said its beer shipments in the first half fell 8.6 percent, to 6.4 million barrels, from 7 million in the same period last year. **********Pabst, which has proposed a merger with the Olympia Brewing Company of Tumwater, Wash., has been fighting off a takeover attempt by an investor group headed by Irwin Jacobs, a Minneapolis businessman. Eli Lilly **********Eli Lilly & Company reported that strong sales of antibiotics helped push up second-quarter net income 22 percent, to $93.2 million, or $1.23 a share, from $76.4 million, or $1.01 a share, in the comparable period in 1981. Sales advanced 13.4 percent, to $708.2 million from $624.6 million. **********For the first six months of this year, the Indianapolis-based company said that earnings rose 13.8 percent, to $228.8 million, or $3.01 a share, from $201.1 million, or $2.65 a share, in the first half of 1981. Sales advanced 9.8 percent, to $1.57 billion from $1.43 billion. **********Richard D. Wood, chairman of Lilly, said that while all areas of Lilly's business contributed to the earnings increase, he noted especially ''the outstanding performance of the pharmaceuticals group and the strong sales of its principal antibiotics: Moxam, Ceclor, Mandol and Keflex.'' ---- Earnings tables, page 34.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/14/busin.body_text: **********To fend off growing Japanese competition, manufacturers of silicon memory chips today announced plans to expand university research spending to $20 million over the next two years. **********The original program, announced in December, called for spending $5 million.  The program is intended to encourage long-term semiconductor research and to increase the supply of professional staff, said Robert N. Noyce, vice chairman of the Intel Corporation and chairman of the Semiconductor Industry Association. The trade group, which includes about 50 companies, is sponsoring the effort through a new, nonprofit affiliate, the Semiconductor Research Cooperative. **********The semiconductor industry in Japan has adopted a similar approach. The major difference has been that the Japanese Government has acted as both the catalyst and the major financial contributor. The American program, to go into effect May 1, will operate without the direct support or participation of the American Government. **********American companies are barred by antitrust laws from pooling research for joint product development, but not from pooling funds for basic research in universities. Silicon memory chips are wafers the size of a fingernail that are linked together to build computer components. **********The new partnership, which has been incorporated as a nonprofit group, is open to foreign companies that have significant manufacturing operations in the United States, Mr. Noyce said. **********But officials at a news conference today left it unclear whether Japanese companies could become members. Several have begun to expand in the United States. One, the Nippon Electric Corporation, has just announced a $100 million expansion of facilities at Roseville, Calif., near Sacramento. **********''We expect some reciprocity,'' Mr. Noyce said, referring to the limitations placed on access by American companies to joint research in Japan. Members of the Steering Unit **********Of the 13 members of the steering committee, two are subsidiaries of European companies - Fairchild Camera and Instrument, which is controlled by Schlumberger, and the Signetics Corporation, controlled by Philips of the Netherlands. **********Other members include Advanced Micro Devices, Burroughs, Control Data, Digital Equipment, I.B.M., Intel, Hewlett-Packard, Monolithic Memories, Motorola, National Semiconductor and Rockwell International. **********Although the research findings are expected to be published, and thus freely available, participants in the cooperative would probably get an edge on their competitors in the utilization of the technology. **********The International Business Machines Corporation, which has tended to insulate itself from industry activities, has taken a leading role in the new program. I.B.M.'s vice president for research, Erich Bloch, was named chairman of the research cooperative. Univesities Not Yet Selected **********Larry W. Sumney, executive director of the cooperative, said the participating universities had not yet been selected. He said that the steering committee had invited proposals from a number of academic institutions for research projects of three to ten years' duration, which were too long-range or speculative for single companies or universities to undertake. **********The cooperative expects to spend $6 million in the first year of its operations and $10 million to $15 million in its second year. The participants will be assessed on the basis of their annual sales of semiconductors, with no one company bearing more than 10 percent of the total annual budget. **********''Whatever is patentable, we expect to patent,'' said Mr. Bloch of I.B.M., noting that the universities would get the patents and issue licenses and that a participant's financial contributions to the program would be considered as prepayment of royalties. **********Mr. Sumney said the sponsors insisted on a free flow of information, but it was unclear how this would mesh with Government concern over access to information related to national security. The Government has already acted in some cases to restrict information flows from universities where research work is related to national defense.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/12/world.main_headline: ANKARA TAKES EMERGENCY STEPS AS POLLUTION REACHES 'DANGER LEVEL'
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/12/world.print_headline: ANKARA TAKES EMERGENCY STEPS AS POLLUTION REACHES 'DANGER LEVEL'
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/12/world.body_text: **********The authorities took emergency measures today as air pollution in Ankara reached ''the danger level.'' The Governor of Ankara, Mustafa Gonul, announced that primary and secondary schools would be closed until Thursday, central heating and coal stoves would be banned for the next 24 hours and the use of private cars would be limited to odd or even days based on license numbers. He said children and the elderly should stay home, and he advised people who did go outside to walk slowly and cover their mouths and noses. **********The Ankara Hygiene Institute said air pollution has increased threefold in the capital in the last 24 hours. The carbon dioxide level was twice its normal level. **********The state radio reported tonight that the amount of sulfur dioxide had reached 752 micrograms per cubic meter of air, or five times the maximum level for safety set by the World Health Organization. **********Downtown Ankara was wrapped in thick smog all day. It was impossible to see 20 yards ahead, and it was dark by 3 P.M. 2 Deaths Reported **********Hospitals reported more heart and lung patients today. The Turkish news agency said the pollution had been blamed for two deaths.  ''The sulfur dioxide particles have reached their maximum level in recent years and the situation is now one of emergency proportions,'' Engin Ural, secretary general of the Environment Problems Foundation, said in an interview tonight. **********Mr. Ural said the smog level was not known because Turkey does not have measuring equipment, but he said equipment was not needed to know that the situation had reached ''the danger level'' today. **********The causes of Ankara's pollution are known: the poor quality of lignite coal used and the lack of desulfurization units in refineries producing fuel oil, Mr. Ural said. **********''The problem is the technicians and bureaucrats who have talked about pollution for years but have done nothing about this serious issue,'' he said. **********Dr. Abdullah Ileri of the Ankara Hygiene Institute warned that the present air quality could cause deaths among people with asthma, chronic bronchitis and respiratory problems. He compared the pollution crisis in Ankara to emergencies in London in 1952 and 1962 in which hundreds of people died.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/30/busin.body_text: **********Dart & Kraft Inc. reported yesterday that first-quarter net income fell 6.3 percent, to $96.9 million, or 77 cents a share, as a result of the recession. **********The results for the Northbrook, Ill., maker of a variety of consumer products compared with net income of $103.4 million, or 90 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1981. Sales rose to $2.44 billion from $2.40 billion. **********John M. Richman, Dart & Kraft's chairman and chief executive, said that the decline was ''not unexpected'' given the difficult economic environment. **********''We are making operating adjustments in those businesses being affected by the recession,'' Mr. Richman said. ''Meanwhile, we continue to concentrate on programs designed to upgrade the company's longterm performance.'' **********Excluding foreign currency and nonoperating gains, first-quarter operating profit was $1.71 a share, versus $1.76 a share in the first quarter of 1981. Dart & Kraft said that foreign currency and nonoperating items added 6 cents a share to net income, compared with the addition of 14 cents a share from such items in the first quarter of 1981. **********Analysts say that economic conditions should continue to impede Dart & Kraft's progress in the first half of 1982, but earnings growth could return to more normal levels thereafter. **********''The earnings were slightly above what I expected,'' said Peter Barry, senior food analyst at E.F. Hutton & Company. He said that he was looking for an operating profit of $1.70 a share in the latest quarter. **********''The company's basic business -food - is doing well, while its food-preparation equipment business is having problems,'' Mr. Barry added. Johnson & Johnson **********Johnson & Johnson reported that a strong peformance by its international operations despite the strengthening of the dollar abroad caused net income in the first quarter to climb 28.4 percent, on a sales gain of 9.6 percent. **********The New Brunswick, N.J., company, one of the world's leading manufacturers of health-care products, said that net income in the latest three months increased to $155.7 million, or 83 cents a share, from $121.3 million, or 65 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1981. Sales advanced to $1.49 billion from $1.36 billion. **********Johnson & Johnson said that domestic sales for the first three months of 1982 were $816.5 million, an increase of 9.3 percent from 1981 first-quarter sales of $746.9 million. Domestic net earnings for the latest three months increased 43 percent, to $89.4 million, from $62.5 million. **********Sales by international subsidiaries totaled $635.4 million for the first three months of this year, an increase of 7.9 percent, from $589.1 million in the first quarter of 1981, the company said.  International net earnings in the first quarter rose 12.8 percent, to $66.3 million, from $58.8 million in the 1981 quarter. Tenneco Inc. **********Tenneco Inc. reported that high interest rates were the major factor in causing net income in the first quarter to drop 33.5 percent, to $129 million, or 88 cents a share, from $194 million, or $1.51 a share, in the first quarter of 1981. Revenues edged up eighttenths of 1 percent, to $3.84 billion, from $3.81 billion. **********''We have relied on borrowed money in the past to expand our energy operations as rapidly as possible, and thus we feel the impact of high interest rates more than some other corporations,'' J.L.  Ketelsen, Tenneco's chairman and chief executive told shareholders at the company's annual meeting in Houston. United Brands **********The United Brands Company said that net income in the third fiscal quarter ended March 31, 1982, slipped 6.1 percent, to $3.1 million, or 24 cents a share, from $3.3 million, or 26 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1981. Sales slipped nine-tenths of 1 percent, to $955.9 million, from $964.2 million. **********United Brands said that earnings from bananas and related products reflected seasonal improvements but were still below the comparable quarter last year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/26/world.main_headline: THE ISRAELI STATEMENTS ON THE EVENTS IN LEBANON
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/26/world.print_headline: THE ISRAELI STATEMENTS ON THE EVENTS IN LEBANON
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/26/world.body_text: **********Thursday, Sept. 16. Israeli Army spokesman: ''The I.D.F. is in control of all key points in Beirut. Refugee camps harboring terrorist concentrations remained encircled and closed. The I.D.F.  calls on citizens to return to normal activity and on all terrorists and other armed persons to lay down their arms.'' Friday, Sept. 17. The Cabinet: ''Following the assassination of President-elect Bashir Gemayel, the I.D.F. took positions in West Beirut in order to prevent the danger of violence, bloodshed and anarchy, while about 2,000 terrorists, equipped with modern and heavy weapons, remained in West Beirut, thus blatantly violating the departure agreement.'' **********Saturday, Sept. 18. Israeli Army spokesman, about noon: ''We do not know anything of these alleged massacres. There is no Israeli presence in the camps themselves. We do not know what is happening in the camps, and we are trying to establish the facts.'' Foreign Ministry, about 11 P.M.: ''Israel condemns the massacre.  There was an exchange of fire between Israeli forces and extremist Phalangists, which were engaged in the criminal acts. Only thanks to the intervention of Israeli forces, which were in West Beirut, that the number of casualties was not much higher.'' Sunday, Sept. 19. The Chief of Staff, Lieut. Gen. Rafael Eytan: ''We don't give the Phalangists orders, and we're not responsible for them. The Phalangists are Lebanese, and Lebanon is theirs, and they act as they see fit. The Phalangists went fighting within this camp here, Shatila, according to their guidelines, if you can call them that, of warfare. We didn't really know what was going on. It was at night. It was assumed it was ordinary fighting. Then in the morning light, when we saw what was happening and what could happen further, we intervened quickly.'' Maj. Gen. Amir Drori, northern commander: ''Before these events took place, I met with the deputy chief of staff of the Lebanese Army, who is the personal representative of the Prime Minister, Shafik al-Wazzan. I told him that we are under strict instructions not to go into the camps, and that if we don't go in, and if the Lebanese Army doesn't go in - and he knows the way things are here in Lebanon - then he could well imagine what might happen. I begged him in every language possible to take responsibility for the security situation in the camps.'' Monday, Sept. 20. An aide to Defense Minister Ariel Sharon: ''Sharon learned about it Saturday.'' Army spokesman: ''We knew that groups of the Lebanese Forces entered Thursday night with the intention of carrying out a purging process.  The atrocious picture began to become clear early Friday morning, but nobody ever could imagine the real circumstances. However, there were suspicions that the reports given by the Lebanese Forces about dead and wounded (not regarding civilians) seemed to be slightly exaggerated. Something seemed to be out of place, and then a senior I.D.F. officer asked the Lebanese forces liaison officer to cease fire and leave the camps. Many hours later the Lebanese Forces left the camps.'' Senior Foreign Ministry official: ''As far as we were concerned, these were Lebanese units, disciplined units. We never imagined that anything like this would happen. There was a certain fog over what was happening. There were disquieting reports. Gradually it became clear that something was wrong. When it became clear to us that these units were killing civilians, we immediately went into action. We were forced to open fire and sealed off the camps to prevent them from going in and continuing the killing.'' Wednesday, Sept. 22. Prime Minister Menachem Begin: ''I have a right to express my belief that there is no one guilty in Israel. There is no one guilty in the I.D.F. Just a tragedy.'' Defense Minister Ariel Sharon: ''The Phalangists entered the refugee camp of Shatila on the night of the 16th of September, 1982, and their activities were halted by the I.D.F. on the 17th in the afternoon, after rumors reached us as to what was occurring in the camp. The area was completely evacuated by Saturday the 18th of September in the hours before noon. **********''On the 15th of September, after the murder of Bashir Gemayel, at 3:30 A.M., a meeting was carried out with the Phalangist command in which the Chief of Staff and northern commander participated, and during which we discussed the operations of the Phalangists and the entry of the I.D.F. into the western part of the city. And we spoke in principle of their dealing with the camps. **********''On the 16th of September, in the afternoon, a meeting was held between the northern commander and the commander of the Phalangists with regard to several matters, and on the same day in the afternoon a meeting was held between the division commander in the area and the representative of the Phalangists to coordinate the entry of the Phalangists into the camp of Shatila. **********''The agreement was that the Phalangists would enter the camp from the south and the west to search out terrorist nests. In the coordinating meeting, it was stressed that the operation was against terrorists, and that it was forbidden to harm the civilian population, especially women, children and the elderly. **********''On the night of the 16th of September, a force of the Phalangists entered Shatila camp.  ''On Friday the 17th around noon - actually around 11 A.M. - the division commander met with the northern commander. The division commander raised suspicions concerning the method of operation of the Phalangists. Even then it was not known what was going on in the Shatila camp. The northern commander ordered the immediate halt of the Phalangist activities, by means of the Phalangist liaison officer at the headquarters. **********''On Friday the 17th at 4:30 P.M., a meeting was held with the Phalangist staff and the Chief of Staff and the northern commander, in which it was agreed that all the Phalangists would leave the refugee camps on Saturday morning, the 18th of September. It was also agreed that no further forces would enter the camps. At this meeting as well, the events in Shatila camp were still not known. **********''On the 18th of September in the morning, the Phalangist forces left the areas of the refugee camps.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/27/world.body_text: **********Divers have recovered a treasure of gold coins from the wreckage of the 17th-century man-of-war Kronan, the pride of the Swedish Navy before it capsized and exploded in 1676. **********Authorities believe the coins, $150,000 worth, may have belonged to Adm. **********Lorenz Creutz, supreme commander of the Swedish Navy who, with 800 of his men, went down with the ship in a battle against Denmark. **********One of the more than 100 coins discovered by divers excavating the wreck off southern Sweden is a Charles IX ducat from 1606. Only one other such coin is known to exist. **********''From a numismatic point of view it is very interesting, but archeologically not more valuable than an old shoe,'' said Thorbjorn Sjogren, who is in charge of the excavation. But Harald Nilsson, an official of Sweden's Royal Mint, said after studying the coins, ''It is a sensational find.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/22/busin.print_headline: Advertising; Getting the Best From An Agency
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/22/busin.body_text: **********IF you graduated from the Harvard Business School in 1934, you probably remember that Stanley J. Goodman was first in your class.  And if you worked at the May Department Stores Company in the 1960's and 70's, you doubtless recall that sales doubled from $1 billion in 1968, the year before he became chief executive, to $2 billion in 1976, when he stepped down at the mandatory retirement age. Profits spurted, too. **********Mr. Goodman now heads Top Management Services, a St. Louis consulting concern that specializes in revving up sputtering companies, and he has distilled some of the wisdom of his 72 years into a new book, ''How to Manage a Turnaround: A Senior Manager's Guide.'' **********How much can advertising help a company to achieve marked improvement in its performance? It can help a lot, Mr. Goodman replied, if the campaign and the circumstances are right. **********''Too much advertising, far too much, is routine, and not enough is bold,'' he said in a telephone interview. ''But money put into a bold advertising campaign, with a brilliantly designed product, for a skillfully identified market segment - that pays off handsomely.'' **********As examples of good, bold advertising, he cited the introduction of Miller's light beer and Anheuser-Busch's counterattack with its own light brew. **********In getting the most out of advertising, Mr. Goodman said, it is vital for a top executive at client company to have an understanding of what the advertising agency is doing. **********''The top management of the business must have a feel for that,'' he said. ''The role of the client is terribly, terribly important.'' As examples of managers with a feel for what Madison Avenue is up to, he cited Chrysler's chairman, Lee A. Iacocca, and his opposite number at Johnson & Johnson, James E. Burke. **********''Some managements may be tone-deaf to this type of thing,'' Mr.  Goodman went on, ''and when they are, it's very difficult for them.  You can't just say to the agency, 'This is what we want you to do.' The top management must be careful not to dominate the creative people, but to be on their wavelength and to stimulate them.'' **********When a senior manager of a client company inhibits work by creative people at the advertising agency, he said, then the manager ''is not really getting the best out of their brains: They're giving you what they think you want, instead of what their talent tells them is the right thing.'' **********But what if the manager can't shake the nagging feeling that the creative people are a bunch of kooks?  ''It's a bad sign,'' said Mr. Goodman, ''when the manager feels that the creative people are kookie, because it shows that his own development and his own awareness of what's going on in the world may be limited. The manager must have a broad awareness of how people live in all walks of life.'' **********And just how good a job has the American advertising industry been doing for its clients, the aware ones as well as the others?  ''I don't feel very critical about the advertising industry,'' he replied. ''It's in constant ferment, as it should be, and good progress has been made, over the past decades, in the quality of advertising. A company that needs the right kind of advertising is not at a disadvantage in the U.S.A.'' **********As for recent advertising that knocks the competition, Mr. Goodman said: ''I don't admire it particularly - I wasn't brought up that way - but it may well be effective.'' **********Which is not to say Mr. Goodman is not innovation-minded - and competition-minded. In his book, which is put out by Macmillan's Free Press division, he writes: ''The management of a turnaround company should take a fresh and searching look at all aspects of its advertising program. Is there a consistent theme or approach that fits the competitive situation? **********''Does the wording of the ads speak with the true voice of the company?'' he goes on. ''Compare your advertising copy with that of your most successful competitors and judge whether or not your customers might take it to be old-fashioned or boring.'' **********Expanding on that theme, he said the other day that a basic truth he had learned during his years in merchandising was that, ''One thing that Americans won't stand for is boredom. Monotony is the enemy.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/19/busin.main_headline: JACOBS RAISES HIS BID FOR PABST STOCK TO $24
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/19/busin.print_headline: JACOBS RAISES HIS BID FOR PABST STOCK TO $24
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/19/busin.body_text: **********The battle for the Pabst Brewing Company intensified yesterday when a group of financiers led by Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis investor who is the company's largest stockholder, made a $76.8 million bid to acquire the troubled Milwaukee brewer and sell approximately half of its capacity to the G. Heileman Brewing Company. **********The latest bid, which involves a $24-a-share cash tender offer for a minimum of 3.2 million shares, or 39 percent of Pabst's outstanding stock, is designed to overcome Justice Department antitrust objections to a Heileman-Pabst merger. **********The Jacobs group also wants to prevent Pabst from mergering with the Olympia Brewing Company, another ailing brewer. Thus, one condition of the bid was that Pabst would not acquire more than 5 percent of the shares or a substantial amount of the assets of Olympia, based in Tumwater, Wash. Early this month, Pabst made a $70 million cash-and-stock tender offer for 49 percent of Olympia's common shares. **********Group Holds 15.3% of Pabst **********Mr. Jacobs, together with associates, already owns 15.3 percent of Pabst's stock and ''is protecting his investment,'' said Emanuel Goldman, an analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. ''A combined Pabst-Olympia organization would be even tougher to turn around'' than Pabst alone, he added. Olympia, which has been beset by high marketing costs and competitive pricing, lost $1.4 million last year. **********If its conditions regarding Olympia were not met, the Jacobs group said, its offer would be reduced to $22 a share.  In a statement, Mr. Jacobs said that, if his group succeeded in acquiring Pabst, it would sell to Heileman for $135 million Pabst's Newark and Georgia breweries, as well as the right to manufacture Pabst's brands in those breweries and distribute them in a 27-state area, an arrangement that Heileman had agreed to. Pabst's plants in Milwaukee and Portland were not included in the Heileman agreement. **********''The deal gives Heileman a fair chunk of volume in the Northeast and South,'' areas where its sales are relatively weak, Mr. Goldman said. He noted that Heileman and Pabst would not be linked in the three states, Illinois, Wisconsin and Minnesota, where together they hold 50 percent or more of the market. Earlier Offer by Heileman **********Last month, Heileman offered $24 a share for Pabst stock, but the proposed merger was opposed by the Justice Department last week on the grounds that it would lessen competition, especially in Northern states. Russell G. Cleary, chairman of Heileman, said yesterday that the Justice Department's opposition had led his company to negotiate with the Jacobs group, despite the fact that Heileman ''wanted very much to purchase'' all Pabst's stock. **********In Washington, a spokesman for the Justice Department said that it had begun considering whether the new bid would violate antitrust laws. **********Pabst shares, in active over-the-counter trading, closed yesterday at $20.50, up 12 1/2 cents. On the New York Stock Exchange, Heileman closed unchanged, at $23.375. Olympia, traded over the counter, closed at $19.875, down $1.625. **********The offer for Pabst stock was made by the JMSL Acquiring Corporation, a new company formed by Mr. Jacobs and three associates. Previously, a different group headed by Mr. Jacobs had offered $20 a share for 2 million shares, which Pabst refused. In April, Mr. Jacobs waged an unsuccessful proxy fight for control of Pabst. **********Another unsuccessful Pabst suitor is C. Schmidt & Sons, a Philadelphia brewer. Last month, Schmidt offered $25.50, in a combination of cash and subordinated debentures, for each share of Pabst. While Pabst management rejected the offer, it indicated that it would not oppose an all-cash bid of the same value. **********Pabst refused to comment on the new bid. https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/03/busin.main_headline: THE HIGH PRIEST OF A TROUBLED CHURCH
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/03/busin.print_headline: THE HIGH PRIEST OF A TROUBLED CHURCH
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/03/busin.body_text: **********WASHINGTON M OST years, the president of the American Economics Association is largely a figurehead, albeit one of considerable prestige. But these are difficult times for economists, who have been struggling not only with the normal self-doubt generated by a troubled economy, but also with the Reagan Administration's assault on the funding of economic research. **********William J. Baumol, the association's president for the past year, found himself at the forefront of the battle against the sharp budget reductions. **********As the association opened its annual meeting here last week, Mr.  Baumol was elated. He had just been told that the Administration had agreed to trim its proposed cutbacks for economics funding from the National Science Foundation, a major source of economic research funds. **********''We were threatened with cutbacks equal to 25 percent of the level that the Carter Administration had proposed,'' Mr. Baumol said. ''And while we are not nearly up to that proposed level again, we are no longer being shockingly singled out for onerous treatment. The word has come out that the Administration itself now feels that it went too far in its original proposals.'' **********The Carter Administration had proposed a $14 million budget for funding economic research in fiscal 1982, up from about $12 million the previous year. The Reagan Administration cut the 1981 budget to $8.6 million and planned to slash that to $3.7 million for 1982. Now, the 1982 budget is back to $6.5 million. **********Some economists might bemoan the reductions even now. Others might apologize for the state of the profession and econ omists' apparent inability to devise the means of maintaining a healthy economy. But Mr. Baumol, a professor at Princeton and New York Universities, takes a reaso ned approach both to the smaller budget and to the turmoil of mo dern economics. **********''I believe very strongly that some hand-wringing is healthy, although I feel that in economics today, it is basically unjustified,'' he said in an interview in the Presidential suite at the A.E.A. meetings here this week. Any discipline recognizes that what it doesn't know is much more than what it does know.'' **********To Mr. Baumol, the intellectual process in economics, as in other fields, is one of evolution. ''Every once in a while there is a breakthrough and everyone exaggerates its value,'' he said. ''Then gradually it sinks in that it is not quite that way.'' **********Indeed, whatever the current problems in economics, Mr. Baumol, 59 years old, does not interpret them as a sign of setbacks or even as an indication that economists know less than t hey used to. He simply thinks that the 1960's were a period of innoc ent bliss for economistsand the 1970's a period of cold reality. Econ omic knowledge, however,continued to advance. **********''Economists in the Kennedy and Johnson years made some forecasts that were virtually right on the nose,'' he said. ''But it was basically dumb luck. What happens to the economy depends very much on what happens in Iran or Mexico or on who is appointed to the Federal Reserve. And there is no econometric model that can forecast those things.'' **********If the 1960's were a decade of few unanticipated disruptions, the following 10 years were chock-full of shocks, such as the 1973 oil crisis, a series of crop failures and the fall of the Shah of Iran.  ''Luck was working the other way,'' Mr. Baumol contended, ''and people concluded that we didn't know anything about economics. That view was as nonsensical as the opposite view.'' **********While the schizophrenia might strike some as awkward, Mr. Baumol accepts it as inevitable. ''It is the nature of creativity to live in a manic depressive state,'' he said. ''One moment you think you know everything, and the next moment nothing.'' **********Mr. Baumol, an American, earned his Ph.D. at London University, specializing in such topics as antitrust, optimal pricing and resource allocation. Since his expertise is the organization of firms and other microeconomic subjects, rather than the broader workings of the economy as a whole, he has not been prominent in the public debate over Government policy, and his name is not widely known outside the economics profession. Within that profession, however, he is regarded as a scholar of the highest order. **********Over the years, he has turned his skills to subjects as diverse as antitrust suits and the funding of the arts. One of the subjects that he is grappling with now is the lack of growth in business productivity. It is an issue that has already attracted a good deal of attention and one that Mr. Baumol predicts will be crucial in the next few years. **********''Our productivity gain rate has virtually vanished,'' he said.  ''For two decades, it has been about half the rate of that in European countries, and about one-third of the rate of the rapidly growing Far Eastern economies. If we extrapolate, that spells serious troubles for us in one or two decades, since those differences will begin to explode in just a couple of years.'' **********He likens the situation to that of Britain, whose productivity growth in the late 1800's and early 1900's also began to shrink. He blames that continued trend for Britain's troubles today, and warns that ''some of the same sorts of things threaten here.'' **********What is the source of the American problem? In Mr. Baumol's view, there may be no single culprit.  ''There is evidence that there has been a relative absence of savings and investment,'' he said. ''There is also data that shows that if you look at productivity per hour - rather than productivity per person - things don't look so bad. We have simply had a sharp decrease in the number of hours worked.'' **********But he also cites another factor: the absence of the go-get'em ethic. ''The entrepreneurial spirit was very much with us in the 1940's and early 1950's,'' he said. ''But it has been 20 years since I have heard anyone say, 'The impossible takes a little longer.' '' **********Mr. Baumol predicted that the solution to the productivity problem may not even lie strictly within the realm of economics. ''The source of the problem may be something we cannot do anything about,'' he said. He offered as an analogy another problem: the reduced rate of personal savings. **********''If the reason for the lower savings rate is the disappearance of the Protestant ethic, there is no way we can deal with that problem,'' he said. ''Sure, we could help subsidize churches and synagogues, with the admonition that every fifth sermon be about saving. But if psychologists thought that might work, at best it would take a very long time. Instead, we might try to increase savings throu gh tax policy and interest rates.'' **********Mr. Baumol believes that the supply-side economics approach to spurring growth in productivity might work if the incentives were tied to achieving results. But even if that were to succeed, he said, it would not necessarily make everyone happy. ''Growth is not something you achieve without cost,'' he said. ''There are environmental costs and people would have to work harder. But the payoff would be a higher standard of living.'' **********As Mr. Baumol sees it, it is not only blue-collar workers who are working less. ''People have chosen more leisure and less pressure on the job, management as much as anyone. Much of the antitrust action we see is business trying to protect itself from the pressures of the marketplace - opting for the easy life.'' **********For himself, Mr. Baumol faces a somewhat easier life than he has for the past year. He is returning to full-time academic life, leaving the defense of the economics profe ssi on to his successor as head of the A.E.A, Gardner H. Ackley. Mr. Ack ley was a member of President Kennedy's Council of Economic Advis ers and chairman of President Johnson's in the 1960's, who is now at the University of Michigan.   THE NEW MAN:GARDNER ACKLEY **********WASHINGTON The economics building at the University of Michigan burned down on Christmas Eve, taking with it cherished professorial books and papers. **********But Gardner H. Ackley, the Henry Carter Adams University Professor of Political Economy at the university, left Michigan anyway to attend the annual meeting of the American Economics Association. It was a meeting he could not miss. Last week he became the association's president, and it was he who arranged this year's program and its key theme: the role of Government in the economy. **********That theme has always been a key interest of Mr. Ackley's. Like others of his generation, the 66-year-old professor was attracted to economics by the the Great Depression. ''The problems were apparent, and I was interested in public policy and the role of Government in fixing the economy,'' he explained in an interview. He earned his Ph.D. from the University of Michigan, where he specialized in microeconomics. ''At that time, there wasn't any macroeconomics to speak of,'' he said. **********Indeed, Mr. Ackley is one of the economists who helped shape the notion of the Government's role in economic policy-making. His first Government job was on the staff of President Roosevelt's National Planning Board. He later became a member of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Kennedy, and chairman of the council under President Johnson. Between his periods in the Government, Mr. Ackley taught and wrote one of the first textbooks on macroeconomics. **********From the beginning, he felt that Government should be involved in the economy. ''Roosevelt was making the Government bigger and a more important influence in the economy - and hopefully more constructive,'' Mr. Ackley said. **********How about today? ''I think the Government has continued to be constructive - no question about it,'' Mr. Ackley said. ''The Reagan efforts may be a temporary step backward, but I think attitudes will shift again and that it will go in the other direction.'' **********That is not to say Mr. Ackley is in favor of unlimited Government involvement. ''Substantial further regulation would be a step backward,'' he said. ''But if it is a question of the size of the budget or income redistribution activities, I am not alarmed by developments in these areas at all.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/12/world.print_headline: BEGIN ARRIVES FOR VISIT TO U.S.; TALKS SCHEDULED WITH REAGAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/12/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel arrived in the United States yesterday to start a 10-day visit that is to include talks with President Reagan. **********Mr. Begin's trip comes at a time of considerable strain between the Israeli Government and some American Jews, some fundamentalist Christians and the Reagan Administration. **********Mr. Begin is to meet with President Reagan at the White House on Nov. 19. **********'Deep Friendship' **********In a statement at Kennedy International Airport after his arrival, Mr. Begin said his discussions with Mr. Reagan would be ''imbued with the deep friendship between our two countries based on the community of interests between the United States and Israel.'' **********He declined to answer other questions about his planned meeting with Mr. Reagan or his reaction to the death of Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader. **********Mr. Begin is scheduled to have breakfast today with several prominent American Jews in New York before flying to Los Angeles to address the Council of Jewish Federations. Early next week he is scheduled to fly to Dallas to meet with Jewish fund-raisers and with fundamentalist Christians, whom Mr. Begin described yesterday as ''wholeheartedly devoted to Israel's just cause.'' **********This does not seem to be a view widely shared among American Jews.  Several prominent Jews said this week that they were troubled, among other things, by Mr. Begin's efforts to solicit special support from fundamentalist groups, such as the Moral Majority. **********Howard Squadron, the president of the American Jewish Congress, said the courting of the fundamentalists risked alienating Jews who oppose the fundamentalists' political agenda. ''The fundamentalists won't go to the barricades for Israel when the crunch comes,'' he said. **********More broadly, however, Reagan Administration officials and many American Jews have expressed concern about Mr. Begin's policies toward the West Bank and about Israel's determination to continue building settlements there. **********Senior Reagan Administration officials said in interviews this week that the President planned in his meeting with Mr. Begin to take a ''tough'' line on the settlements issue. **********President Reagan, speaking last night at a news conference in Washington, said the Israeli moves to continue establishing settlements in the West Bank were ''a hindrance to what we are trying to do.'' **********Mr. Reagan said he and Mr. Begin would discuss the issue when they meet next week. But, when asked about the possibility of sanctions, the President said he did not think that threats would be good diplomacy. **********One senior Administration official said this week that Mr. Reagan was ''very unhappy'' with the timing of the Israeli announcement on settlements and that the Administration was now weighing a variety of ways to make its displeasure known. **********The official said one idea under discussion was deleting the approximately $200 million in economic assistance that Israel spends each year on the settlements.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/04/busin.body_text: **********Short- and long-term interest rates declined yesterday as credit market participants grew more confident that a weak economy and rising unemployment would lead the Federal Reserve to encourage lower interest rates in coming weeks. **********The announcement yesterday morning of a larger-than-expected fourtenths of 1 percent increase in the unemployment rate for November, to 10.8 percent, touched off a sharp rally in the credit markets. In the late afternoon, the Federal Reserve lent further support to the view that interest rates would continue to decline by announcing a steep drop in business loan demand and a $1.3 billion drop in the nation's basic money supply. **********Concern about the health of the economy has already led the Fed to reduce short-term interest rates from more than 14 percent in early July to less than 9 percent in the two weeks ended Dec.1. However, the declines have come more slowly in the past month, leaving markets confused about the timing of future drops. **********Speculators expressed the hope yesterday that the rise in unemployment would prompt the Fed to continue encouraging lower interest rates and to announce a another cut in the discount rate, its charge on loans to financial institutions. **********Many analysts said a cut in the discount rate was unlikely so soon after the half-a-percentage point reduction, on Nov. 19, to 9 percent. But their warnings did not prevent a flurry of activity that raised prices of short-and long-term issues. Treasury Issues Slide **********The Treasury's actively traded 10 3/8 percent bond, due 2012, went as high as 99 29/32, or about 1 3/4 points above Thursday's close.  However, prices of Treasury securities fell during the afternoon by between one-eighth and one-half point in the last hour when it became apparent that the Fed would not cut the discount rate. **********The 10 3/8 percent bonds, for example, closed at 98 7/8, up about three-fourths of a point on the day, to yield 10.5 percent, compared with 10.58 percent on Thursday. **********''With the market doing well on its own,'' said analysts at Ried, Thunberg & Company, the Fed was likely to delay a reduction in the discount rate until some time when it ''might get more bang for the buck.'' **********Rates for Treasury bills and other short-term securities declined yesterday, with the three-month Treasury issue falling to as low as 7.82 percent before rising during the afternoon to close at 7.95 percent, down only two basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, on the day. **********The three-month bill rate was down from the 8.28 percent average set at last Monday's auction, but was still well above the 7.44 percent average rate at the Oct. 18 auction, when market participants thought that the Federal Reserve was going to bring rates down more quickly than it has. **********The $1.3 billion decline in the M-1 measure of the basic money supply, to $475.8 billion in the week ended Nov. 24, was in line with market expectations. Growth of M-1, which consists of currency plus all kinds of checking accounts, ''is likely to be volatile'' this month, according to economists at Money Market Services.  Increases might total about $5 billion in the next three weeks, but would be followed by large declines when banks introduce money market accounts on Dec. 14, they predicted. **********In the latest 13 weeks, M-1 has averaged $466.7 billion, and has grown at an annual rate of 12.7 percent.  Robert Schwartz, an economist at Merrill Lynch, said the growth of M-1, which is about $13 billion above the Fed's 5 1/2 percent growth target for 1982, was not alarming and would not prevent the Fed from announcing a discount rate cut later this month. **********Fed data also showed that business credit demands continued to weaken in the week ended Nov. 24, a development that tends to lower interest rates. Business loans outstanding at large banks across the country fell by $778 million, while business borrowing in the commercial paper market fell by another $972 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/27/world.print_headline: SEOUL UNITY OFFER REFUSED BY NORTH
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/27/world.body_text: **********North Korea today rejected South Korea's latest proposal for reunification, insisting that United States troops be withdrawn from South Korea first. **********In response to a plan announced Friday by President Chun Doo Hwan, North Korea said, ''To our regret, it cannot be considered a 'proposal' worthy of any positive significance.'' **********The North Korean press agency, in announcing the rejection, transmitted a speech by Vice President Kim Il, chairman of a North Korean committee for reunification, calling for acceptance of North Korea's own plan to end the 36-year division. **********The negative response was not unexpected. The South Korean plan was believed intended mainly to rally public opinion behind President Chun. **********Mr. Kim did not address President Chun's proposals for trade and communications, nor his suggestion for an exchange of envoys with Cabinet rank. **********''If the so-called 'unification proposal' brought forward by the South Korean rulers recently stems from a sincere desire for reunification, we would not have turned away from it but attached due importance to it,'' Mr. Kim was quoted as having said. **********Mr. Chun's proposal, calling for a conference to draft a charter for the two countries, for elections and a unified Government, ''is nothing but a formality of politics ignoring the actual reality of our country,' ' the North Korean statement said. ''In light of the actual compli cated North-South relations, it is clear to everyone that a possib le time for general elections is far off.'' **********Both sides have made repeated proposals for talks on unification.  Talks were started in 1972 and were suspended the following year.  In 1981, Mr. Chun offered to meet with the North Korean leader, Kim Il Sung, but North Korea spurned the idea.  North Korea's plan, announced by Mr. Kim Il Sung in October 1980, calls for a federal republic. This was rejected by the South as an unfeasible attempt to achieve reunification at one stroke, instead of using a step-by-step approach favored in Seoul.
