https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/21/world.body_text: **********A Palestinian extradited from the United States went on trial today on charges that he planted a bomb that killed two Israeli boys and injured 36 people. Ziad Abu Eian, 23 years old, faces life imprisonment if convicted on murder charges in the May 1979 bombing in the Galilee town of Tiberias. **********Mr. Abu Eian, from the occupied West Bank, had been living with his sister in Chicago when Federal Bureau of Investigation officials arrested him in August 1979. He was returned to Israel last December after losing a United States Supreme Court battle to bar his extradition. He had argued that he was not assured a fair trial in Israel and that the bombing had been a political act.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/07/busin.body_text: **********The controller of the International Business Machines Corporation, James Forese, said today that I.B.M.  expects third-quarter earnings to surpass last year's $693 million but that the company should not be considered ''recession-proof.''. **********He also told a meeting of securities analysts here that the company's capital expenditures will exceed $7 billion in 1982.  Because of current market conditions, he said, I.B.M. will continue to select debt over equity offerings to finance capital spending. **********Mr. Forese said the earnings gain in the third quarter and for the first three quarters together will be greater than the 15 percent gain recorded in the first half. **********Mr. Forese said the company anticipates a moderate turnaround in 1983, with a growth rate below 5 percent a year.  ''Let me assure you that we are not recession-proof, and some of our smaller systems have clearly been impacted by the economy,'' he said. ''We are also seeing somewhat higher order cancellations and deferral rates on some products.'' **********The news pushed I.B.M. up 3 7/8, to 79, on the New York Stock Exchange.  Separately, I.B.M. announced that it had been chosen to provide a computer-to-computer communications network linking agencies and companies in the property and casualty insurance business. **********The network will be built by the I.B.M. Information Network, a computer services operation set up by I.B.M. earlier in the year, for the Insurance Institute for Research.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/10/busin.body_text: **********IN-RESIDENCE programs are being widely used at graduate schools of business to introduce students to business leaders. At the same time, the programs provide the executives with an interesting experience, sometimes tinged with nostalgia. **********Programs vary. Some schools invite retired executives, some working ones. Cornell asks a recently retired executive for a full semester on campus, where he serves as a kind of visiting professor.  Dartmouth asks executives to spend a week or so, while other schools invite them for a few days. **********Talking about the students, the executives overflow with such adjectives as ''eager, bright, ambitious.'' But what about suggestions or contrasts with M.B.A.'s in earlier years? **********''When I graduated from Harvard Business School in 1940, I was not interviewed by anyone,'' said William Wendel, former president of the Kennecott Corporation and a recent executive-in-residence at Cornell. ''I don't think students are nearly innovative enough in finding jobs. They rely too much on recruiters, and most recruiters on campus come from big companies. Students should consider second-tier companies, like those listed on the American Stock Exchange.'' **********He added: ''I also think recruiters' stress is on specialization, and I don't like that. I feel strongly that the real benefit of an M.B.A. education is that it gives you knowledge of all aspects of the business scene.'' He questions whether future managers need specialize, unless they are headed for such professions as accounting. **********One apparent irony is that virtually every company that hires M.B.A.'s insists that it takes only the brightest. ''That's nonsense,'' M r. Wendel said. ''I couldn't be at all sure that the grades I gave were at all accurate.'' He said that in management courses, for example, grades do not necessarily reflect brightness ofthe student. **********There has been criticism in recent years that some M.B.A. students lack writing and speaking facility, and many graduate business schools are trying to remedy this by a required communications course or a remedial course. Today, most programs require all students to take such courses as accounting, management, marketing, statistics and computer science. **********Whatever their lack of imagination in finding jobs, the students today are better equipped than those of 30 years and more ago, Mr.  Wendel said. ''There is nothing so brash as an M.B.A.,'' he said.  ''The job of manager is much more difficult these days than when I graduated.'' He offered this advice to top managers: ''When you pick a successor, you should pick one you're sure is better than you are.'' **********''One weakness I did notice at Cornell is that students need more reality,'' he said. ''I guess I think there's a definite place for the executive-in-residence.'' In his course, he said, he used specific business cases. ''I told what I thought,'' he said. ''The experienced professor is adroit enough with questions to get the class around to understanding his way of thinking. I am not expert enough, so I had to tell them outright what I thought.'' **********Another executive-in-residence, George Howick, a former vice president of the Carborundum Company, and now a small-business man, agrees with Mr. Wendel about job-hunting M.B.A.'s. ''More smaller companies are looking at M.B.A.'s,'' he said. ''Don't let recruiters run the job search.'' **********Mr. Howick is spending a quarter term at Bowling Green University, in Ohio, teaching a course called ''Special Problems in Advanced Policy Making.'' He said the students have ''a breadth of knowledge that I did not have.'' **********Mr. Howick is also impressed by the s tudent s' communications ability, both oral and written, compared with that of the students heknew six or seven years ago. ''I think part o f the reason is the culture has changed,'' he said. ''These stude nts are intent on getting good jobs.'' **********He worries that business schools ''have become highly quantitative -perhaps too much so.'' Students have been trained in certain functions, he explained, but the task of a general manager often involves separating out what is important. ''I consider that they receive largely training rather than education,'' he said. ''They want jobs, and the universities are responding to what the market is demanding.'' **********''There is a limited opportunity for liberal education in business school,'' Mr. Howick went on. ''Students don't read great books and they don't study history.'' He urges students not to let ''their studies interfere with education.'' **********''I spend some time here making students aware of different management styles and cultures,'' he said, noting that this is a subject you cannot learn from books. **********Mr. Howick also thinks students' expectations are too high, as when they expect a vice presidency after just a few years. But like Mr.  Wendel, he believes that a student with a ''B'' average can do just as well with his M.B.A. as an ''A'' student. **********''Finally, I think students should be aware of all kinds of opportunities to change careers,'' Mr. Howick said. ''They need to be more flexible. They are a little bit rigid about where they expect to go.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/13/world.body_text: **********A martial law court today sentenced to prison three accomplices of Mehmet Ali Agca, the man who tried to assassinate Pope John Paul II, on convictions of hiding Mr. Agca after his escape from a Turkish prison in 1979. **********Officials said the three, Hasan Murat Pala, Mehmet Dursun and Mustafa Dikici, were each sentenced to three years and one month for hiding Mr. Agca and for helping him out of Turkey after his escape from a military prison in Istanbul on Nov. 25, 1979. **********He had been sentenced to death for killing Abdi Ipekci, editor of the newspaper Milliyet, in 1979. **********Mr. Agca, who is serving a life sentence in Italy, was seized after the assassination attempt on the Pope on May 13, 1981.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/01/world.body_text: **********Belisario Betancur Cuartas, the Conservative Party candidate, was elected President of Colombia over three opponents Sunday, according to nearly complete results announced today. **********More than 7 million of an electorate estimated at close to 13 million voted, many more than is usual in Colombian elections. **********Polling was marked by a notable absence of violence. **********Mr. Betancur's nearest opponent was the Liberal Party candidate, 69-year-old Alfonso Lopez Michelsen, President from 1974 to 1978, who lost by nearly 400,000 votes.  Mr. Betancur, 59, appeared to have nearly 47 percent of the vote, while Mr. Lopez Michelsen received more than 40 percent. **********It was the third race for the presidency by Mr. Betancur, one of 22 children of an illiterate peasant.  Mr. Lopez Michelsen was opposed in his own party by Senator Luis Carlos Galan, whose New Liberalism movement had the backing of one of the party's elder statesman, former President Carlos Lleras Restrepo, and its intellectual and youth sectors. He received more than 700,000 votes, or more than 11.5 percent. **********The fourth candidate, Gerardo Molina, who represented a coalition of Communists and Socialists, appeared to have won more than 72,000 votes, or about 1 percent. **********Mr. Betancur campaigned on a platform calling for measures to reduce Colombia's inflation, which is more than 30 percent a year, and unemployment. He said he planned steps to ease credit and generate employment opportunities by the stimulation of industrial development. **********Mr. Lleras Restrepo offered his support to the winner, and Mr.  Lopez Michelsen promised ''constructive opposition.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/29/world.body_text: **********For the seventh straight day, Israeli planes, artillery and gunboats hit Palestinian bunkers and residential areas in west Beirut today. **********Artillery and rocket duels raged into the night in the southern suburbs as the two sides appeared to ignore efforts by Philip C.  Habib, the special American envoy, to restore a cease-fire. **********In west Beirut, buildings rattled from the impact of Israeli shells that lighted up the night sky with orange flashes and produced a film of rancid smoke that wafted across the city. **********The day-long barrage came as Mr. Habib returned after having told Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel that he would determine within two days whether the 6,000 Palestinian troops trapped in west Beirut were indeed prepared to leave Lebanon. **********No Sign of Early Withdrawal **********The Palestinians, who have been fortifying their positions by setting up dirt barricades, erecting antitank barriers and adding fresh sandbags, do not appear to be preparing to leave soon. **********Hani al-Hassan, the chief Palestinian negotiator with the Lebanese Government, and indirectly with Mr. Habib, said Mr. Begin's repeated deadlines ''were becoming humorous.'' **********''They are designed to cover up his failure in Lebanon,'' said Mr.  al-Hassan, adding that the Palestinians were ready to withdraw and reorganize their political and military presence in Lebanon provided their conditions were met. **********The Palestinians, he indicated, want a permanent cease-fire, a disengagement of forces and the deployment of a multinational force to cover any withdrawal, and want the entire package framed in a United Nations resolution that would advance the Palestinians' right to self-determination. **********The Israeli bombardments are interpreted by the Palestinians as an unambiguous signal that Israel will not settle for anything less than a total and immediate withdrawal from Lebanon. **********Wafa, the Palestinian press agency, said that at least 28 people were killed or wounded in this morning's air raids. Most of the raids appeared to be concentrated on military positions and residential areas largely evacuated by civilians, unlike Tuesday's attacks, which took the lives of 120 people, most of them civilians. Shelling From Gunboats Offshore **********After a night in which Palestinian gunners traded artillery fire with Israeli warships about 10 miles offshore, Israeli planes struck in mid-morning, blasting the Palestinian refugee camps of Sabra, Shatila and Burj al-Brajneh. The planes also hit the Palestinians' office complex in the Fakhani district, positions near the airport and an outpost in the city stadium, which has been bombed so many times that it looks like the Coliseum in Rome. **********Israeli artillery positions in the southeastern hills and the gunboats along the coast kept up artillery fire against the Palestinian neighborhoods of Lailake and Uazi and the seafront districts of Ramlet el Baida, Bain Militaire and Manara, setting off large fires, the Lebanese Government radio said. **********The Palestinians returned the fire, sending Katyusha rockets into the Israeli hillside encampments. The rockets arced over west Beirut in a thunderous roar. The guerrillas also fired their heavy 130-millimeter cannons at the gunboats, but did not appear to have much effect. **********The Lebanese Christian radio said several Palestinian rockets had landed in the Christian-controlled eastern sector of Beirut and near the Presidential Palace in suburban Baabda, but made no mention of casualties. **********Besides their human and material impact, the weeklong artillery duels are taking a psychological toll on the 500,000 civilians living in the predominantly Moslem western sector of Beirut. Adding to their plight is the fact that the Israelis occupying east Beirut have cut off electricity and water supplies to the western sector for the last three days. The two sectors of have been divided along the so-called Green Line since the civil war of 1975-76. **********Saeb Salam, the titular head of west Beirut's Sunni Moslem community, said neighborhood delegations had been visiting him all day, pleading with him to seek American help in getting the water and electricity turned back on. **********''People have no water and no electricity, and with the constant bombing cannot sleep,'' Mr. Salam told reporters. ''Doesn't anyone in the world care? S O S, S O S.'' **********After a meeting involving Mr. Habib, President Elias Sarkis and Prime Minister Shafik al-Wazzan at the Presidential Palace, Mr.  Wazzan said the American envoy's visit to several Arab capitals and Jerusalem had produced some progress. The important thing, he added, ''is that the progress be translated on the ground.'' **********Lebanese Government sources said the negotiations for a Palestinian withdrawal were waiting for several factors to come together . **********First, the sources said, Mr. Habib was apparently able to obtain tentative agreements from Egypt, Syria and Jordan to take some of the Palestinians, provided that it was in the context of an Arab League decision. The Arab foreign ministers are meeting in Jidda, Saudi Arabia, to see whether they can lay the groundwork for a unified stance. **********Second, there is still no agreement on how the Palestinians would withdraw, whether directly out of Lebanon or first to the Bekaa Valley and the north, leaving Lebanon only when the Israelis do. **********Third, the Palestinians and the Lebanese still need to work out the details of what the Palestinian troops would do with their heavy weapons, what guarantees would be provided for the security of the 650,000 Palestinian civilians remaining in Lebanon and what kind of residual political and military presence the Palestine Liberation Organization would maintain in Lebanon. **********Finally, the Palestinians want any withdrawal from Lebanon to take place in the framework of an American or United Nations initiative that would not only provide for a multinational peace force to oversee a pullout, but would also recognize the P.L.O. and its demands for a Palestinian state.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/11/world.body_text: **********The Soviet Union today assailed President Reagan's new sanctions against Poland, saying he was trying to worsen its economy to the detriment of the Polish people. **********Mr. Reagan announced Saturday that he was going to suspend the most-favored-nation trade status that Poland has enjoyed for 22 years, saying the United States ''could not stand idly by'' after the Polish Parliament on Friday outlawed Solidarity and severely restricted any new trade union activity. **********The Moscow radio, echoing criticisms made by the official press agency Tass, said Mr. Reagan was pursuing a policy of ''interfering in the internal affairs of sovereign countries.'' **********''The head of the U.S. Administration made no secret of his intention to have the new sanction worsen the situation in the Polish economy,'' the state radio said. **********Tass charged that Mr. Reagan also planned other ''discriminatory measures'' against Poland and was holding ''urgent consultations'' on joint measures with United States allies. **********Mr. Reagan ''did not even try to conceal that the White House thus intends to worsen the situation in the Polish economy and that the United States openly blackmails the Polish Government by these measures, pressing for 'acceptable' changes in its domestic policies,'' Tass said late Saturday in a report from Washington. **********Tass said Mr. Reagan's offer for economic aid ''sounded as mere hypocrisy against this background'' of new sanctions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/07/world.body_text: **********A police officer who lost his arms and legs in the explosion of a terrorist bomb two weeks ago died early today in his hospital room, police sources said. **********Bernard Mauron, a 37-year-old bomb disposal expert, was injured Aug. 21 while approaching a bomb discovered in a parking space that had been occupied by a car belonging to an American diplomat. **********He was the second police victim of the attack. Bernard le Dreau, another explosives expert, was killed by the blast when the bomb exploded on a fashionable residential street about 500 yards from the Eiffel Tower on Paris's Left Bank. **********Officer Mauron was the 10th person to die in a wave of terrorist violence that began in Paris in late July. About 50 other people have been injured in 18 attacks in the French capital since then.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/21/busin.body_text: **********The American Telephone and Telegraph Company faces some difficult personnel problems in reorganizing its staff to accommodate the terms of the divestiture agreement reached in January with the Justice Department. **********But the company, the country's largest non-government employer, has a unique guide to help it deal with the sensitive issues of relocating people and redirecting careers. More than 25 years ago, A.T.&T.; began monitoring a group of young managers' attitudes toward jobs to see how they evolved over time. A year and a half ago, two staff research psychologists pulled their findings together for a report, ''Career Motivation in Mid-Life Managers.'' The following is an adaptation of it. **********By ANN HOWARD and DOUGLAS W. BRAYEXPECTATIONS and advancement desires among managers seem to fade g radually, gracefully, and for most, fairly early. By the time m anagers were interviewed after 20 years on the job, most had long a go given up their early dreams, and many couldn't even remember how h igh they had aspired in the beginning. At least on the surface, mosta ccepted their career plateaus and adjusted to them. Mid-life was a c risis to some of our participants, but not to the majority. **********Aside from adjusting to career plateaus, many had sound reasons for not wanting further promotions, even if they were available. A major problem is that relocation often accompanies promotions. After 20 years, respondents indicated that as the number of job-required moves increased, the number of unfavorable reactions to them also increased, especially on the part of the family. At middle-age, nearly half thought a proposed future move would evoke an unfavorable reaction, even with a promotion. **********Other reasons for resisting further promotions included not wanting the aggravations of additional responsibility or not liking the politics expected at a higher level. Thus, the absence of further promotional opportunities is not necessarily seen as a personal tragedy. **********There are also reasons why the organization may not want employees to look ever upwards. Not everyone has the ability to perform the job at the next higher level. **********Participants in the Management Progress Study were college graduates newly hired into management and non-college people hired for non-management jobs but promoted into management before turning 32. Because this was in the late 1950's, this meant that all were white males. **********At the original assessment, staff members made predictions of whether the participants would make the third level of management within the first 10 years. Among the noncollege group, about the right number of mostly the right men had risen this far by the end of 16 years. Among college graduates, an optimal number of promotions had occurred by the eighth year; by the time 16 years had passed, nearly all the qualified men had been moved up to third level, but so had nearly two-thirds of those rated low in potential. **********Our advice is: Don't inveigle the system to dangle promotions in front of those who don't really want them and those the organization shouldn't really want at higher levels. Another lesson is: Don't feel too sorry for those who have plateaued. **********Many have reached the level to which they aspired, and others are frankly relieved they don't have to. Others adjusted to the inevitable many years before, gradually and gracefully. Still others are at least able to muster up enough defense mechanisms to keep them from crashing into the despondencies claimed to plague the middle-aged. Perhaps most important, after 20 years the correlation of management level with happiness was conspicuously not significant. On average, these men were just as happy with career success or without it. **********Middle age did not bring reduced motivation to respond to job challenge, regardless of job level. Also, greater desire for autonomy was notable by the eighth year, but rose even more in the next 12 years. Expanding opportunities for achievement and autonomy without necessarily involving promotion suggest rich opportunities for lateral transfers. **********But one precaution: Transfers are likely to be resisted if they involve relocation. When asked their feelings about relocations for a lateral transfer, fully three-quarters of the respondents in the 20-year interviews said their feelings would be negative. Family resistance can be quite strong. **********In addition, it is difficult to come out ahead financially; even the most liberal company relocation plans involve unforeseen costs and problems exacerbated by high inflation and skyrocketing mortgage rates. Because the average move costs the organization about $30,000 a year, this is not a step for the company to take lightly. **********If transfers without relocation are difficult to come by, an alternative may be to enlarge the scope of the current assignment.  But if jobs are made richer in responsibility and authority, will they also require sacrifices of personal time? This may be a problem. **********The relative importance of work in the men's lives was gauged in interviews with them over the years that were coded by a clinical psychologist for the relative importance of nine life themes, such as marriage and family, religion, community service, recreational and social pursuits and occupational involvement. **********As early as the first year it was becoming clear who was turning on and moving up. The differences between the groups continued to spread as the years went by, and it became clear that career success and the importance of work in the managers' lives were highly related. **********For those who ended up at the bottom, at the first and second level, the process of withdrawal from job involvement began almost immediately, when they were in their early 30's. For those at middlemanagement level, disengagement began after 10 to 13 years, when they were in their late 30's. Those who reached levels of vice president and above still had not withdrawn by their mid-40's.WITHDRAWAL from occupational involvement is a function of age and r elative career success. But even the lower-level men would like t heir hours to be absorbing. They just don't want to go beyond their 4 0 per week. **********In large organizations, most middle-level managers are middle-aged, and a few will emerge as the top management of the future. The Bell System has made efforts to identify potential officers from middle managers and to help prepare them for their presumed future responsibilities with an executive development course. **********Two groups of managers in the Bell Advanced Management Program, or BAMP, were given many of the same questionnaires that had been given to middle-aged participants of our Management Progress Study. **********When asked how soon they expect their next promotion, almost all BAMP managers said within the next three years while only 21 percent of the MPS men anticipated this and 62 percent thought they would never get another promotion. **********When asked about the importance of advancing one more level, more than half the BAMP group said it was extremely or very important compared to only 16 percent of the MPS men. Ambition was not dead among high-flying middle-aged managers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/23/world.main_headline: CLUSTER BOMB DEBATE PUTS FOCUS ON OVERALL ARMS SALES TO MIDEAST
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/23/world.print_headline: CLUSTER BOMB DEBATE PUTS FOCUS ON OVERALL ARMS SALES TO MIDEAST
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/23/world.body_text: **********The controversy over Israeli use of American-supplied cluster weapons and reports that Israel has made such weapons have focused attention on the high level of arms shipments to the Middle East by the Soviet Union, France, West Germany, Britain, Italy, the United States and a number of smaller arms producers. **********An American military expert said it was impossible to fix a figure for the total arms transfers involved because in many cases the value of the sale and the date of delivery has not been announced. **********At present $1.5 billion worth of combat aircraft, self-propelled guns and armored personnel carriers are in the pipeline for delivery to Israel. The sale of 11 F-15 fighters is also being negotiated. **********Sales and transfers to Israel have expanded rapidly since 1980. So, however, have sales and transfers to Arab nations.  American military sales to Egypt amounted to $10.5 million in 1977. In 1980 and 1981, after the Camp David agreements, the sales were $203.8 million and $203.3 million. Deliveries from 1981 through 1983 are expected to include more than 300 M-60 tanks, 12 batteries of improved Hawk surface-to-air missiles and nearly 1,000 air-to-air missiles for installation in Egypt's fighters, including 40 F-16 aircraft under order. U.S. Arms Sales to Saudis **********American arms transfers to Saudi Arabia have included a number of high technology weapons, including Dragon antitank missiles and their launchers, Maverick air-to-surface missiles, 1,000 TOW antitank guided missiles and 50 launchers. **********According to Israeli officials, these types of advanced weapons and others supplied to Arab countries by the Soviet Union, France and Britain point out the danger that by the end of this decade the qualitative superiority in weapons and technical training that Israel has held for a quarter of a century could be seriously eroded. **********Although Israeli armor and artillery had little trouble with the Soviet-made T-72's used by Syria in the Lebanon fighting, some sources attribute this to the inefficiency of the Syrian crews rather than to any faults in the tank itself. The Israeli argument is that given time and thorough training programs, the T-72 and its crews will eventually pose a far greater threat to Israel. **********Syria has 400 T-72's. British military analysts believe that the Soviet Union has promised the delivery of another 250. United States analysts could not confirm this report. **********Syria will receive from the Soviet Union in the remainder of this year, according to a NATO intelligence source, ''a considerable number of self-propelled guns and Frog surface-to-surface missiles.''  Israeli Air Superiority **********The Israeli Air Force has maintained its superiority over any combination of Arab air forces since the 1956 Suez crisis. But Western and Israeli sources believe this advantage could be endangered when sales of modern aircraft to Arab nations are completed and pilots and aircrews trained. **********Saudi Arabia, for example, will received 47 American F-15 fighters to carry Sidewinder air-to-air missiles and Maverick air-to-ground missiles. Syria has an undisclosed number of MIG-23 fighters on order from Moscow. Tiny Qatar will receive 11 Mirage F-1 fighters from France. Iraq, after some minor losses in the war with Iran, is to receive 150 MIG-23's, 25's and 27's as well as 24 more Mirage F-1's from France. **********Although the Camp David agreement took Egypt out of the ranks of Israel's enemies, Israeli officials are privately worried about the modernization of the Egyptian Air Force. One reason is the numbers, a second is the belief that Egyptian maintenance and command and control are better than in other Arab countries. **********Under present programs Egypt will receive 40 F-16's, 16 Mirage 5's and a number of Alpha jets for ground attack and training.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/21/busin.main_headline: AN INCISIVE TEACHER: GEORGE JOSEPH STIGLER
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/21/busin.print_headline: MAN IN THE NEWS; AN INCISIVE TEACHER: GEORGE JOSEPH STIGLER
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/21/busin.body_text: **********At the University of Chicago's business school, a popular item of attire is a T-shirt showing a back view of an odd couple of economists strolling together down a leafy walk. The very short one is Milton Friedman, the monetarist who is considered the core of the conservative Chicago school of economics; the very tall one is George J. Stigler, a professor at the business school and a longtime champion of deregulation. **********Mr. Friedman, 70 years old, won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science in 1976. Yesterday his friend Mr. Stigler was also awarded that prize. In a telephone interview, the tweedy, whitehaired professor was asked where the two economists parted company. ''Milton's out to save the world,'' he said, ''and I'm out to understand it.'' **********The remark disclosed much, both about Mr. Stigler's sense of humor -widely described as his most striking feature - and his approach to economics. **********For two decades, much of his research has focused on government regulation, from the Securities and Exchange Commission to the regulation of public utilities. While his conclusion has often been that such regulation is neutral or worse, ''I've become more interested in why things happen than how to change them,'' he said. Welcomed by His Colleagues **********The selection of Mr. Stigler, who is 71, was widely hailed by fellow economists, including those at the opposite end of the theoretical spectrum. **********''His research is controversial but respected,'' said Paul Samuelson, a Massachusetts Institute of Technology professor and Nobel award winner who, as an undergraduate at the University of Chicago, knew Mr. Stigler. But as Mr. Samuelson, who is a Keynesian, noted, if Mr. Stigler represented a minority view when he began his research, ''a growing fraction of economists are coming around to that view.'' **********Mr. Stigler may also be the first Nobel economist who has written extensively about the history of economics. ''He represents the humane tradition of scholarship,'' Mr. Samuelson said. **********In addition, he has established a reputation among legal experts for his study of the interaction of economics and law in such areas as antitrust, law enforcement, privacy and the theory of legislation. ''He is one of the pioneers of economic analysis of law,'' said Richard Posner, a Federal appeals court judge in Chicago who formerly taught law at the University of Chicago. **********A hallmark of Mr. Stigler's career has been his close association with Mr. Friedman. The two studied together under Frank Knight, then the guru of neoclassical economics at Chicago. In 1946, they wrote a book that argued that if controls were eliminated, the shortage of housing would be quickly ended. For a number of years, both Mr.  Stigler and Mr. Friedman taught at Chicago. 'He's Good Theater' **********''They're both difficult professors, tough graders,'' said Richard Thain, the business school's dean for career development, noting that many commercial banks and investment houses had a special interest in Mr. Stigler's students. ''As a lecturer, he's good theater,'' Mr. Thain added. **********''He has an exceeding wit and an exacting standard,'' said Paul MacA@voy, a Yale economics professor who began his teaching career under Mr. Stigler at Chicago more than a decade ago. At that time, he recalled, Mr. Stigler dominated the university's weekly workshops on industrial organization, attended by doctoral candidates. ''I've seen people break into tears under his insistent application of the highest standards,'' Mr. MacAvoy said. **********''He's very witty, and it's better to be laughing with him,'' Mr.  Samuelson said. ''His wit has point, and it's drawn blood.'' Born in Renton, Wash., in 1911, George Joseph Stigler graduated from the University of Washington in 1931 and received a master's degree in business administration from Northwestern University the following year. He studied economics, he said yesterday, because ''it was the middle of the Depression, and it seemed better to go to school than look for work.'' He got his doctorate at the University of Chicago in 1938. His Many Study Posts **********His teaching posts have included Iowa State College, the University of Minnesota, Brown University, the London School of Economics and, from 1947 to 1958, Columbia University. In 1958, he returned to the University of Chicago as the Charles R. Walgreen Distinguished Service Professor of American Institutions. **********He was a Guggenheim Fellow in 1955 and a fellow at the Center for Advanced Study in Behavioral Sciences in 1957-58. In 1964, he was president of the American Economic Association. While he has accepted a number of minor government assignments, he turned down a high-level appointment with the Nixon Administration because, he said, ''I didn't want to go down there for two years.'' **********A widower for the past 12 years, Mr. Stigler has three sons: One is a statistics professor at the University of Chicago, another is a lawyer with Heublein and the third is a social worker in Toronto.  His hobbies are photography and golf. Recent Winners of the Nobel Prize for Economics 1978 Herbert A. Simon (United States) For his analysis of structure and decision making in economic organizations, a relatively recent area of economic research. 1979 Arthur Lewis (Britain) Theodore Schultz (United States) For their work in developmental economics. Lewis has developed models that seek to explain the instrinsic problems of underdevelopment.  Schultz has criticized development policies that neglect agriculture 1980 Lawrence W. Klein (United States) For his work on econometric models and the application of those models to the analysis of economic policies and fluctutations in the business cycle. 1981 James Tobin (United States) For his work on the analysis of financial markets and their effect on how businesses and individuals spend and save their money. 1982 George J. Stigler (United States) For his studies of industrial structures, the functioning of markets, and effects of public regulation. Stigler believes in the free market system and government deregulation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/21/busin.main_headline: Head of Jim Wilson Bets On New Shopping Malls
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/21/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Head of Jim Wilson Bets On New Shopping Malls
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/21/busin.body_text: **********In the moribund market for new shopping malls and in the face of sluggish retail sales, at least one developer is plunging fearlessly ahead. He is Jim Wilson, founder and president of Jim Wilson Associates, which operates 16 centers across the Sun Belt. **********Mr. Wilson, who served in 1979 and 1980 as president of the International Council of Shopping Centers, says that nationally, only 15 to 20 shopping malls are under construction. His company has opened three this year -in Shelby, N.C., Spartanburg, S.C., and New Orleans - and is scheduled to open a fourth in Greenville, Tex., Oct. 14. Five more are in the pipeline for 1984. **********Mr. Wilson, 47, acknowledges that he is taking a gamble. ''We can't tell whether the amount of risk is going to be equal to the reward,'' he said. ''The jury is still out on that. We still can't tell yet whether we're smart or stupid.'' **********The growth of shopping mall construction has been slowed in the recession by a curtailment of long-term financing, the unwillingness of many developers to get involved in shorter-term transactions, lack of potential tenants and shrinking availability of choice sites. **********In short, it seems a good time to hunker down. But Mr. Wilson said he had decided to use interim mortgage financing of five and seven years. When it comes time to renegotiate for the more conventional 20-year terms, he is betting that interest rates will be down and more financing will be available. **********Mr. Wilson, whose company is in Mongomery, Ala., has been in real estate for some 20 years. After graduating from Tulane University, where he was a center and linebacker on the football team, he went into his father's accounting firm but found it too sedentary. He got a job collecting rents and eventually prospered and founded his own company. **********Jim Wilson Associates has just purchased the old Montgomery railroad station for a main office and Mr. Wilson, who is the model of a big, soft-spoken Alabamian, says he plans to ''open a fancy restaurant'' on the premises, too.  Daniel F. Cuff

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/04/busin.body_text: **********The troubled French franc came under heavy pressure today on foreign exchange markets.  The Bank of France acknowledged that it was once again losing reserves at a dangerously rapid rate and that it was struggling to avert the third devaluation of the franc since the Socialists came to power 15 months ago. **********Figures issued by the central bank Thursday night showed that it had lost the equivalent of $575 million worth of foreign exchange reserves during the week ended Aug. 26 in combating a speculative attack on the franc sparked by rumors that President Francois Mitterrand would soon withdraw the franc from Europe's fixed-rate monetary system and let it float freely against other currencies. **********Reserves Decline Precipitously **********As a result, France's foreign exchange reserves are now falling at approximately the same rate as they were during the weeks before the last franc devaluation, in June. **********And at the current rate of loss, the central bank's holdings of foreign currency will be exhausted within two months, although the Bank of France still possesses large amounts of gold as well as substantial borrowing rights from other central banks and the International Monetary Fund. **********Dealers ascribed the franc's latest bout of weakness to these four factors: **********- France's yawning trade gap, with record deficits in June and July. **********- The Government's inability to rebuild its foreign exchange reserves, which are still a quarter lower than when it took office, despite two exchange rate adjustments that should have raised export earnings while slowing imports. **********- Doubts about the Socialists' ability to carry out a tough budget strategy, introduced earlier this week, which was intended to restore confidence in the franc. **********- Nervousness that Finance Minister Jacques Delors may take advantage of the I.M.F.'s annual meeting next week in Toronto to negotiate a new devaluation of the franc with other finance ministers. **********The franc was slightly stronger against the dollar than last week, when it traded at more than seven to the dollar; it stood at 6.96625 to the dollar today, slightly weaker than Thursday's rate of 6.9375.  Against the German mark, it reached a record low of 2.817, compared with 2.8115 Thursday. **********Dealers said they believed the central bank intervened in the market again today, using up more reserves to support its ailing currency.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/21/busin.body_text: **********LIKE the business cycle, careers can go through dramatic ups and downs. These days a faculty shortage at engineering schools, for example, has reached ''crisis proportions,'' according to educators.  There are possibly 2,000 unfilled jobs, or about 10 percent of engineering schools' faculty. **********Engineering enrollment is at a record high, thanks to the lure of high corporate salaries, but many schools are short of teachers because a lot of them, too, have been enticed by high industry pay. **********The National Engineering Action Council met recently in New York to consider ways to alleviate the faculty shortage, under the aegis of Paul Gray, president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. **********The council's chairman, Edward E. David Jr., president of the Exxon Research and Engineering Company, said the shortage threatened ''the quality of engineering education.'' A need for higher faculty salaries, new equipment and greater cooperation with industry were stressed. **********There are intangible benefits, however, that an engineer might consider when choosing between industry and academia.  The $30,000-a-year starting salary a young engineer might command in industry involves a full year's work, while a faculty member works only about nine months when the Christmas, spring and summer vacations are subtracted. Thus a $24,000 faculty job would be equivalent to $30,000 or so in industry. **********At Cornell University, the associate dean of the engineering school, Donald F. Berth, said recently, ''We're putting together packages for young engineers with a Ph.D.'' In addition to $27,000 in salary, an arrangement is made for them to spend a month or so consulting for a fee ranging from $4,000 to $10,000. This, he added, brings income up to industry levels. **********In addition, campus life offers many advantages for faculty members and their families - tennis, swimming pools, gymnasium, golf course, squash courts. Campus nursery schools are often available, and good public schools are nearby. For older children of faculty members, college tuition is often free. **********Low-cost housing is another perquisite at some universities, and costs tend to be lower anyway in a nonurban setting. Meanwhile, an engineer taking a company job in California's Silicon Valley is unlikely to find a house for less than $180,000, according to Robert J. Parden, dean of the University of Santa Clara's engineering school. **********Campus advantages can thus be worth many thousands of dollars to young faculty members. As they rise toward tenure, opportunities for research grants, consulting fees and endowed chairs increase. **********As another inducement, an engineer on the faculty of a thriving engineering school can keep pace with new technology, while one employed in industry may fall behind developments or become overspecialized. **********The shortage of qualified engineering teachers can also mean a quicker route to high-level positions than in industry, where the competition can be fierce. **********To alleviate the shortage, the National Engineering Action Council favors setting faculty compensation ''at a level recognizing realistically the market for such talent in industry.'' **********It also urges high priority for modernizing equipment to sustain ''frontier research'' and instruction based on current technology. It favors the use of technical aid to give professors more teaching and research time and part-time employment of engineers from industry as adjunct professors. **********The council suggests that engineering schools reconsider the Ph.D requirement for faculty, placing greater reliance on practical skill. And it urges creative methods of research to attract industry involvement. **********Meanwhile, engineering schools already use varied techniques.  The University of Minnesota has raised engineering tuition about $250 a semester, earmarking the extra money for faculty salaries.  M.I.T. has a cooperative program for graduate students. They work in industry but receive time off for studying.  Fifteen companies now support Carnegie-Mellon University's Robotics Institute.  Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute has established business-related projects, including an industrial park on land it owns.  The Massachusetts High Technology Council has urged its members to allot 2 percent of research and development expenditures to engineering education - an indication of the growing flow of industrial money into engineering schools. Major companies that have increased their aid to engineering education include Arco, Dow, Exxon, Union Carbide, Eastman Kodak, General Electric, Shell and Hughes Tool.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/29/busin.body_text: **********William Duncan, the 59-year-old deputy chairman of Imperial Chemical Industries, will become chairman of Rolls-Royce Ltd., Britain's state-owned producer of aircraft engines. Next April the Scot will succeed Lord McFadzean, 66, who will retire after having been chairman since 1980. Mr. Duncan will begin a five-year term in which he hopes to see the company begin moving toward denationalization. **********''I would hope to improve Rolls-Royce's profit and profitability until it can be restored to the private sector,'' Mr. Duncan said in a telephone interview. ''I would be very much in favor of a robust and healthy private company.'' **********After Rolls-Royce filed for bankruptcy in 1971, the Government bought its plane-engine operation. (The car-making division became a separate corporation, since merged with the Vickers holding company.) **********With its 54,000 employees, Rolls-Royce had sales of $2.45 billion last year. Its profit of $25 million was wiped out when extensive restructuring costs left the company with a net loss of $5 million. **********Mr. Duncan, who was trained as a mechanical engineer at Glasgow University, has been with Imperial Chemical Industries since 1941. He lived in the United States from 1966 until 1972 as chief executive officer of ICI Americas Inc. He joined the parent company's board of directors in 1971 and was named deputy chairman in 1977. The Department of Industry reportedly approached him about a job in the public sector after he lost out in a race for the chairmanship of I.C.I. **********''One does not leave a company after 40 years without a lot of disappointment,'' Mr. Duncan said. He will become a director of Rolls-Royce in November and chairman in April. His new salary has not been disclosed, but it is expected to be less than his current annual pay, which exceeds $170,000. The present chairman, Lord McFadzean, earned just over $100,000 last year.  Daniel F. Cuff

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/30/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State George P. Shultz, putting the controversy over the pipeline issue with the European allies aside, has undertaken a discussion with them on overall East-West economic issues as the first step toward devising a more coordinated allied policy on trade with the Russians. **********United States and Western European officials said here yesterday that Mr. Shultz had been mostly listening to the Europeans, asking their attitude toward commerce with the Russians and toward the tightening of credits and technology sales to them. **********Mr. Shultz, who has been in New York for the United Nations General Assembly session since Sunday, is to address the world body today. He has already conferred privately with the foreign ministers of France, Britain and Italy, and the minister of state from West Germany, on East-West issues. Those four countries are the main suppliers of equipment for the construction of a natural gas pipeline from Siberia to Western Europe. **********The Reagan Administration, in retaliation for the imposition of martial law in Poland, has barred American companies from participating in the pipeline. It has angered the Europeans by trying to ban European affiliates from taking part and European companies from supplying components using American technology. Sanctions have been imposed against companies defying the Administration's actions. New Approach Sought **********John Hughes, Mr. Shultz's spokesman, said Monday that Mr. Shultz had agreed with his European counterparts that because the differences over the pipeline were so wide there was no point in discussing possible compromises. **********But American and West European officials said yesterday that Mr.  Shultz has made clear that in putting the pipeline issue aside, he was searching for a new approach to East-West trade that could avoid such rifts in the future. **********Mr. Hughes, who told reporters again yesterday that Mr. Shultz, in a meeting with Foreign Minister Emilio Colombo of Italy, had not discussed the pipeline dispute in detail, was asked why the issue was being avoided. **********''Well, I think basically that what is happening is a wider discussion of the overall East-West economic situation as it exists and how it might exist in the future, and a tendency to get away from the specifics in the pipeline dispute that has caused such controversy,'' he said. 'A Comparison of Notes' **********A senior West German official said that in Mr. Shultz's discussion on Monday with Minister of State Berndt von Staden, the Secretary had sought ''to get a feeling of what the Europeans think and how East-West economic relations are seen in the context of East-West relations as a whole.'' **********The Americans, he said, did not want to start the discussions ''on the decisive issue'' of the pipeline, but rather with what the French call 'a comparison of notes,' '' he said. **********''One day,'' the official said, ''we'll have to come to grips with the pipeline issue, but for the Secretary it is a first round. He wants to know what the Europeans are thinking.'' **********Foreign Secretary Francis Pym of Britain, who conferred with Mr.  Shultz on Tuesday, said at a news conference yesterday, ''We have to renew a debate on the ground rules over East-West trade.'' **********He said that ''we are trying to reconcile a difference that has been blown out of proportion by the press.'' ''What we need to do,'' he added, ''is establish a framework for East-West trade.'' Basic Difference Noted **********Mr. Shultz, in his two and a half months in office, has developed a reputation for taking his time before coming up with policy initiatives and for listening to many voices before making a decision. This was his approach leading to President Reagan's Middle East initiative and apparently is what is being done now over differences on East-West trade. **********Several Europeans said yesterday there is a basic difference with the Reagan Administration over trade with the Russians. The Europeans said they had told Mr. Shultz that they do not believe trade sanctions have that much impact on the Soviet Union and that while there was merit in barring technology with a military application they opposed the Reagan Administration's efforts to block the sale of advanced technology for use in the exploitation of natural gas and oilfields. **********Mr. Pym said that there had to be a debate not only on future credits and technological sales to the Russians, but on sales of food as well. The United States is a major seller of grain to the Russians, something that is pointed out repeatedly by Europeans who argue that this undercuts the Reagan Administration's arguments against the pipeline. ---- Baldrige Outlines Views By Reuters **********Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said yesterday that the Reagan Administration would not conduct business as usual with the Soviet Union despite pressure from Western Europe to lift the Siberian pipeline sanctions. But he indicated that the Administration might consider alternative approaches to penalize the Soviet Union for what Washington sees as its role in the declaration of martial law in Poland. **********Addressing the National Association of Export Companies in New York, he said the Administration would consider Western European suggestions ''if our European allies could get together with some unified approach that would be as effective as sanctions.'' **********''We will sit down at any time and talk about another approach besides sanctions,'' he said. ''But business as usual is not acceptable.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/11/busin.body_text: **********Since the disclosure recently that half of the voting control of the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation has been turned over by Marvin Davis, who purchased the company last June, to a little-known New York commodities trading concern, attention has focused on Marc Rich, the owner of that concern. But Mr. Rich is continuing to maintain his low profile, declining to respond to telephone calls. **********A report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, however, gave some details of the change in the ownership of Fox.  According to the 139-page document, Richco, a Netherlands Antilles subsidiary of Marc Rich & Company, will now have the same voting rights as Mr. Davis in electing directors to the Fox board. **********When the $722 million purchase of Fox and its transition to a private company occurred in June, Richco was identified as Mr.  Davis's equal partner. But at that time, Mr. Davis had all of the voting shares, while Richco's shares were nonvoting. **********Mr. Rich, 47, founded his commodities company in 1974 and most of its activities today are in oil - a commodity in which Mr. Davis, whom he has long known, also made his reputation. Mr. Rich had previously been associated with the Philipp Brothers Corporation, a major trading company, and started its spot oil trading unit. He left Philipp Brothers in the mid-1970's because of a salary dispute. **********The headquarters of Mr. Rich's firm are at 280 Park Avenue in Manhattan.

Hochstin, said that the firm was not party to the reorganization. The New York Stock Exchange said it is examining the condition of the firm. Chrysler plans to produce the engines in a joint venture with the Perkins Engine Group. (D1.) **********The Saturday Review may have to be closed on Monday, according to its owner. He said he is still seeking ways to keep the publication in business, however. The 58-year-old magazine has been losing $1 million a year for at least the past three years. (D3.) **********Crocker National is seeking an injunction against T.O.S.  Industries, which owes it $37.2 million and has filed for bankruptcy. (D3.) International **********European officials presented a formal protest to the U.S. against its ban on the sale of equipment for the Soviet pipeline project. The protest called the ban ''an unacceptable interference'' in Common Market affairs. Moscow, meanwhile, is pressuring European contractors by insisting it is ready to proceed without them. (Page A1.) **********Saudi officials are looking into the affairs of a money-changer who has apparently lost millions speculating in gold and silver. The case may lead to controls on money-changers, who have been expanding into virtual banks. (D1.) **********Citibank has paid nearly $6.9 million in back taxes to Switzerland and France because of disputes over the accounting of currency transactions there, the bank said. It also plans to pay $3.7 million to another European country, which it did not identify. (D7.) The Economy **********Tax negotiators broke a deadlock on welfare spending in the House-Senate conference on the bill to raise $98.9 billion in new revenue over the next three years. The committee completed approval of the spending portion of the measure, which would cut expenditures by $17.5 billion, and then took up the tax portion. (A1.) **********Business inventories grew 0.3 percent in June, reversing an improvement in May, the Commerce Department reported. The new figures put the June ratio of inventories to sales at 1.49, up from the 1.46 of May but still below the 1.52 of April. The F.C.C., whose reaction had been a matter of concern, welcomed the ruling. (D3.) Markets **********Interest rates plummeted as a rally in Treasury securities set the tone for an improvement in fixed-income markets. Yields on three- and six-month Treasury bills each fell about 50 basis points. Meanwhile, the revival of new corporate offerings continued to enjoy brisk demand. A key to the market's behavior, dealers said, was news that Lombard-Wall had filed for bankruptcy. (D1.) **********The stock market posted its eighth consecutive decline. The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 0.29 point, to 776.92. (D6.) Assets of the nation's money market funds rose by $3.7 billion in the week ended Aug. 11, to a record $220 billion. (D5.) The dollar fell, while gold prices rose $4.25 an ounce, to $337.25, in New York. (D10.) Corn and soybean futures prices were sharply down. (D10.) Today's Columns **********The President is letting Congress know his popularity can outweigh their fear of raising taxes in an election year. Budget-balancing is also popular; indeed, polls show 80 percent of the public want the budget balanced. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. (D2.) **********Following venture capitalists' activities might help investors discern the most promising areas of technology. Over the last decade, the Venture Capital Index has risen 383 percent. In that period, Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 7 percent. Market Place. (D6.)

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/09/busin.body_text: **********Hotel Talks Examine The Slump AFEW years ago, Stephen Brener, at the time executive vice p resident of Helmsley-Spear Hospitality Services Inc. raised the q uestion in a talk with colleagues at New York University's Real E state Institute of why local professionals did not hold regular l odging industry conferences. **********''There were the industry trade shows, of course,'' said Mr.  Brener, who now has his own consulting firm specializing in the lodging industry. ''But we realized that even though the hopitality industry is vital to the city's economy, we could not recall any major conferences or forums here for the deal makers in real estate: the developers, the brokers, the money men,'' he added in a recent interview in his office at 420 Lexington Avenue. **********The first conference was put together in 1979, and fewer than 100 persons showed up. But this week about 300 persons, from all parts of the country, attended the fourth annual Hospitality Industry Investment Conference, sponsored jointly by the Real Estate Institute, Stephen W. Brener Associates, Lodging Hospitality Magazine and Pannell, Kerr & Forester, the real estate accounting and research firm. **********The hotel and motel executives were drawn to the event, held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on Monday and Tuesday, to listen to, mingle with and pick up ideas from their colleagues as well as to make contacts with potential lenders or investors. **********''We consider this a working meeting providing important information and points of view for even the most experienced people in real estate,'' said Denis Phillips, dean of the School of Continuing Education at N.Y.U., who was an instrumental part in the formation of the university's Real Estate Institute. **********In characterizing the tone of the conference Mr. Brener said: ''Obviously we are in a recession and the hotel industry is feeling the squeeze. But despite the slowdown I think a lot of people have made it a point to be here to try to figure out what is going on and what they can do to make their business better.'' **********According to Mr. Brener's statistics, local hotels and motels reached a record high occupancy rate of 81 percent in 1979 and have suffered more than an eight percentage point drop since then. **********In the six sessions of the conference, participants dealt with such topics as alternative routes to financing, prospective institutional investment opportunities, the success of the unique-format hotels and motels, and the hospitality industry from the developers' point of view. **********As guides in their discussions, conference participants had such specialists as Gary L. Wilson, senior vice president of finance and development for Marriott Hotels; Jerrold Wexler, chairman of the Jupiter Corporation; Claude Ballard, a partner of Goldman, Sachs & Company, the investment house, and Charles E. Sayers Jr., vice president of real estate financing for the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. **********Because hotel and motel chains offering an alternative to the standard room-with-bath format have apparently avoided the downward trend, according to some industry analysts, the panel discussion on special formats attracted considerable attention. **********Stephen B. Oveson, president of the Hometels Management Company, based in Newport Beach, Calif., discussed the appeal to many travelers of the hometel, a special format that offers a suite complete with sleeping, entertainment and cooking facilities. **********Both Thomas J. Pritzker, president of the Hyatt Corporation, and Howard P. James, chairman and chief executive officer of the Sheraton Corporation, spoke in their keynote speeches about their companies' expansion programs for the rest of the decade. **********But mixed with the upbeat discussions of the lodging industry's most recent success stories were talks on the hard realities of raising capital in an atmosphere of tight money. **********''The idea of financing through alternative routes or in nontraditional ways is very much a part of the process of raising capital for projects,'' Eric Green of Pannell, Kerr, Forster, said in referring to the money squeeze.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/17/busin.main_headline: WRIGLEY REASSERTS ITSELF IN GUM MARKET
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/17/busin.print_headline: WRIGLEY REASSERTS ITSELF IN GUM MARKET
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/17/busin.body_text: **********The Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company is aggressively trying to re-establish itself as the nation's leading manufacturer of chewing gum. **********The Chicago-based company, having turned back a challenge from its competitors' sugarless and bubble gum products, is now intent on becoming a force in the market for liquid-center gums. **********Wrigley tried to do so once - and failed. The company introduced two liquid-filled chewing gum products several years ago, aimed at adults as a breath freshener, but they were withdrawn last year. **********Now Wrigley has brought out a new liquid-center bubble gum meant for children. Although the company contends that the new gum, called Tidal Wave, is completely different, and says that it will capture about 10 percent of the bubble gum market, some analysts are not enthusiastic about its prospects. Wrigley's Domination **********''The fact that the new one is a bubble gum and the other was a chewing gum won't make much difference,'' said Richard G. Elam, an investment analyst at Bacon, Whipple & Company, a Chicago brokerage firm. ''I'm afraid this product may meet the same fate as the first.'' **********Ever since William Wrigley Jr. started selling a spearmint-flavored gum in the late 1800's, Wrigley has had things pretty much its own way. For almost 80 years, the company sold only four kinds of gum - Doublemint, Spearmint, Juicy Fruit and P.K. -which were all introduced before 1915. P.K., the first sugar-coated gum, is sold almost exclusively for export. **********Wrigley controlled more than two-thirds of the total gum market until the 1970's, when its competitors -mainly Squibb's Bubble Yum and Care-Free sugarless gum (now owned by Nabisco Brands) and Warner-Lambert's Trident and Freshen-Up, the leading liquid-center chewing gum - mounted a serious challenge. Wrigley's market share declined to about 33 percent. **********But the company, which operates out of a white Renaissance-style landmark skyscraper, bounced right back. First, in 1974, it introduced Freedent, a special gum for denture wearers. Then it followed with Big Red, a cinnamon-flavored gum, two years later, and, in 1977, its first sugar-free gum. Finally, in 1979, the company took on Squibb's soft bubble gum product with the introduction of Hubba Bubba. Restructuring the Company **********To move these new products, Wrigley restructured its staid sales and marketing department. ''Our field force were still using pre-World War II techniques until we brought it up to date,'' said Claude Brooks, Wrigley's first vice president and corporate secretary. **********As a result, Wrigley's has reclaimed the top spot in the gum market, with a 44 percent market share. The company is No.1 in standard chewing gum; No.2 in bubble gum, behind Nabisco Brands, and No.2 in sugarless gum, behind Warner-Lambert. It hopes the resurgence in market share will end a two-year decline in its net income, which fell 7 percent last year, to $28.4 million, on sales of $607.8 million. **********The company reported a 13 percent increase in net income during the first quarter of this year, to $7.6 million, on sales of $137.3 million, compared with net income of $6.7 million, on sales of $148.9 million in the 1981 period. But the rise in net income resulted from accounting changes. Restating the figures based on prior accounting methods, Wrigley had a 13 percent drop in net income, to $5.6 million. **********The liquid-filled gum market has proved hard for Wrigley to crack.  The failure of its two previous entries resulted from weakness in demand for a liquid-center breath freshener, according to Mr. Brooks, who chewed more than a pack of the new gum during a recent interview.  Appealing to Children **********''We found that the gum appealed more to kids than to adults,'' he said. So Wrigley yanked the product off the market, modified it and reintroduced it as a bubble gum product for children. **********Repositioning products has worked for Wrigley before. When it introduced Big Red in direct competition with Warner-Lambert's Dentyne, sales began to lag after some initial success. Wrigley reintroduced the gum as a breath freshener, and its sales grew 20 percent a year. According to Mr. Brooks, the company expects the same thing for its liquid-center entry. **********''The demand for Tidal Wave is already ahead of production,'' he said.  Mr. Brooks said that the new gum was intended to capture 10 percent of the $500 million bubble gum market. But Warner-Lambert has introduced a similar liquid-center bubble gum product to complement its Freshen-Up and Chewels liquid-filled gums. **********A spokesman for the Warner-Lambert Company, Jack Sholl, declined to discuss the new product at length, but he did say that ''it's a successful product - the company is satisfied'' with its sales. **********Analysts expect the battle of the liquid-filled gums to intensify.  ''Wrigley is serious about this market,'' said Ronald L. Strauss, an analyst at William Blair & Company, a Chicago brokerage firm.  ''They learned a lot from their previous failure. We could see quite a battle.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/23/busin.body_text: **********Internorth Inc. of Omaha, a natural gas pipeline distributor, said it had increased its stake in the Bucyrus-Erie Company, a manufacturer of mining and construction equipment, to 9.5 percent of the 20.4 million common shares outstanding. https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/04/busin.body_text: **********After the Soviet Pipeline **********The initial impact of the Administration's decision to block construction of the Soviet pipeline and to deny high-technology licenses to foreign suppliers who trade with Moscow seems largely confined to the State Department. Experts say it will not be long, however, before the shock waves spread far beyond Foggy Bottom. **********American companies are likely to channel more research and development outside the United States, diffusing technology and making it easier for Moscow to acquire, said Harald B. Malmgren, an independent trade consultant. Reactions from Europe and elsewhere may also become more tangible, he said. **********Canada and France, which both oppose intensifying the economic cold war with Moscow, may ignore the United States position and become more flexible in their own dealings with Moscow. More Installment Debt **********Despite painfully high interest rates and continuing pessimism about the course of the economy, consumers are again inching out on the credit limb. Thanks largely to the rebate-inspired jump in auto sales, May's report on consumer debt, due Thursday from the Commerce Department, should show a rise from April levels, says Sandra Shaber, an economist at Chase Econometrics. And, while the stimulating impact of last week's tax cut is likely to mean more credit purchases in the second half, the growth is not apt to be as vigorous as in past recoveries, Mrs. Shaber said. Housing is almost sure to remain in the doldrums, dampening spending on household appliances and furnishings, traditional buy-now-pay-later purchases. Some consumers may decide to use their fatter paychecks to reduce their debt load, she said, before taking on new responsibilities. **********Mrs. Shaber forecasts that consumer credit this year will rise 8.6 percent above 1981 levels. That reflects a somewhat less hopeful view of the second half than Mrs. Shaber held in the winter. Then she predicted a a strong enough recovery to generate an 11 percent increase in consumer credit for 1982. The OPEC Roller Coaster **********The last four months have been difficult for the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. As members gather in Vienna this week, the problem they thought had been overcome last spring - squaring production with sagging demand - refuses to go away. **********With Nigeria, Libya and Iran producing above target levels, analysts say OPEC's output is exceeding its 17.5 million barrel-a-day ceiling by at least 1 million barrels. Unless further reductions are made, spot prices, which have begun to soften again, are likely to fall further from the $34 benchmark. Promises of lower production are apt to be made in Vienna, but analysts doubt they will be kept. **********Mounting debt and political differences with Saudi Arabia make it unlikely that Iran and Libya will cut production, said William Brown, director of energy studies at the Hudson Institute. And, while another sharp cut in Saudi production might correct the imbalance, that probably will not happen either. **********At this point, Mr. Brown said, only an early end to the inventory liquidation process or economic revival in major consuming countries can keep spot prices, now around $32, from falling further. Disconcerting Job Numbers **********An increasing number of analysts are proclaiming that the recession ended in May, but the first peek at conditions in June does little to support that notion. **********Although June's unemployment rate remained stuck at 9.5 percent, the jobless rate may not yet have reached its peak, said James Pihera, an economist at Georgia State University. Student joblessness recorded a surprisingly sharp drop last month. That trend is not likely to continue through the summer, Mr. Pihera said, and could push the overall jobless rate up to 9.8 percent in July and August. **********Other portions of the Labor Department report indicate the job markets have already deteriorated further. Overall employment and hours worked, two coincident indicators, showed sharp declines in June, Mr. Pihera said. That means that industrial production, which has declined in nine of the last ten months, probably fell again, too. **********To make matters worse, unemployment in the cyclical manufacturing and construction industries has risen further. If that continues, some analysts say it is more likely that the effects could spill over into the service sector, which thus far has remained relatively unaffected by the current downturn.  Kenneth N. Gilpin

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/05/busin.print_headline: SALES OF FLU DRUG BY DU PONT UNIT A 'DISAPPOINTMENT'
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/05/busin.body_text: **********On the surface, it would appear that Endo Laboratories, the pharmaceutical subsidiary of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, has everything going for it this year. **********The New England Journal of Medicine, in a recent issue, reported the results of a test that determined that Symmetrel, Endo's licensed antiviral drug, is 91 percent effective in preventing influenza. And the Center for Disease Control in Atlanta has predicted this winter's flu season will be heavier than last year's. **********But the 12-year-old Du Pont subsidiary has had favorable medical press and heavy flu outbreaks in the past, and sales of Symmetrel, the only available flu drug, are only slightly more than $10 million. **********''Although it's gotten good medical journal press, Symmetrel has been a disappointment in the marketplace,'' said James Arenson, an industry analyst with the brokerage firm of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. **********Endo, whose annual sales total about $100 million, represents only a small part of Du Pont, where sales in 1981 totaled $22.8 billion.  Indeed, Endo has been overshadowed by its sprawling corporate parent but, as pharmaceutical industry analysts suggest, it is also not performing very aggressively. **********Du Pont entered the pharmaceutical business in 1966, when its scientists developed Symmetrel. In 1969, the company purchased Endo Laboratories, a private Long Island drug concern, primarily for its marketing capabilities. It is interesting, then, that industry analysts cite marketing problems as a major factor in Symmetrel's low profile among the flu-catching public. Endo's Marketing Funds **********Mr. Arenson said that one of the problems has been the restrictive method with which the company finances promotion of the drug. Money for marketing comes directly from Endo's own budget and not from the parent company, which means Endo is left virtually on its own to market its products. **********Mr. Arenson also asserted that too much money is pumped into research and development at the expense of marketing. According to Hazen L. Richardson, general manager of Du Pont's biochemicals department, 40 percent of sales are used in research and development, compared with an industry average of 11.5 percent. And more emphasis on research is planned, Mr. Richardson said. **********''Endo does not have the marketing capabilities, but I don't know if that's the only thing holding them back,'' said Leslie Ravitz, an industry analyst with Salomon Brothers. **********Another problem may have been Symmetrel's restricted uses after it was introduced. It was approved by the F.D.A. in 1966 for prevention of Asian A-2 influenza virus. By 1976 it received a broader approval for use in preventing all influenza A viruses, which are the most common of all viruses. In November 1980, the drug was granted F.D.A.  approval for treatment, as well as prevention, of all influenza viruses. With each of these additional F.D.A. approvals, Endo's potential market for Symmetrel was expanded. **********Last year, Endo embarked on a marketing effort aimed at linking Symmetrel with relief from the flu. The company was host at a public health seminar for 7,500 public health officials last December at the National Institutes of Health in Washington. **********The marketing blitz, Endo's first ever, was apparently unnecessary, since last winter's flu season was among the lightest on record.  Still, Edwin E. Messikomer, president of Endo Laboratories and director of Du Pont's pharmaceutical operations, said he is pleased with Symmetrel's sales. ''They were right on forecast,'' he added.  '''m glad it's held up despite the weakened flu season.'' **********''To a degree, Symmetrel is discretionary,'' one industry analyst said. ''If you don't use it, you're still going to get over the flu.'' One problem with the drug is its side effects, and Endo scientists have developed another drug that does not produce as many side effects as Symmetrel. **********Some industry analysts indicate that Endo will not likely blossom until Du Pont acquires another pharmaceutical concern.  Mr. Messikomer said his company was ''evaluating new opportunities,'' both by developing its own products and by seeking new products to license or companies to acquire. **********In all, Mr. Richardson said there were 12 new products in varying stages of development at Endo, including a cardiovascular drug, which controls nervous system disorders, and an anti-arthritic. The antiarthritic, Tiflamizole, is currently in clinical testing and, according to Mr. Richardson, two to three years away from market.
