https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/17/busin.body_text: **********The stock of Crum & Forster soared $11.50 today, to $41, as rumors cirulated about an impending takeover of the large property and casualty insurance concern. **********Sears, Roebuck & Company, the Chicago-based retailer that has recently diversified into financial services, was mentioned as the likeliest suitor, but it denied the reports. **********Crum & Forster, which had earlier announced it was holding merger discussions with an unnamed company, refused today to identify the company or comment on the those talks. **********Some analysts have also said that Crum & Forster has been talking with the Transamerica Corporation and the American Can Company about a possible takeover of the company. **********But analysts seemed to agree that some deal will take place soon.  ''At least the market seems to think so, with the way Crum's stock has been acting,'' said one, who asked not to be identified. ''I think there will be a deal, because Crum's top people are ready to retire rich.'' **********On Wednesday, Crum & Forster's stock climbed $2.125 before it was halted shortly after 2 P.M. pending the announcement of the talks.  The New York Stock Exchange was reported to be investigating possible insider trading in the stock. **********Analysts tended to agree that the price tag for Crum & Forster is in the $1.2 billion to $1.7 billion range, or at least 1 1/2 to 2 times its book value. **********''American Can and Transamerica are just as likely to buy Crum & Forster as Sears,'' said Joseph Spivack, an analyst at Value Line Investments. ''American Can has been looking to expand into the property/casualty business, and Transamerica has been looking to increase its exposure in the property/casualty area.'' **********''Such an acquisition would make sense and a good fit for Transamerica,'' said Gerald E. Lewinsohn, vice president and insurance analyst at Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc.  ''Transamerica will definitely take a look, but won't chase Crum if Sears wants it bad enough.'' **********Crum & Forster is one of the largest property and casualty insurers in the nation, with more than a quarter of its business derived from writing workers compensation packages. Bruised by Recession **********Like many property and casualty insurance companies, Crum & Forster has been bruised by the recession, fierce market competition and underwriting losses. Its operating profits during the first half of this year fell 30 percent, to $64.8 million, from $92.1 million a year ago. **********While Crum & Forster disclosed that it was holding talks with a suitor, it also said that there is ''no assurance that a transaction will take place.'' The company reportedly held unsuccessful talks with CBS Inc. about a possible takeover three years ago. **********William C. McCuire, a spokesman for American Can, said that ''as a matter of policy we don't comment on our merger and acquisition activity while they are in the process, but it's public knowledge that we are interested in building our financial services sector.'' **********In May of this year, American Can agreed to acquire Transport Life Insurance Company for $152 million. Earlier, the company purchased Associated Madison Cos., an insurance holding company, for $127 million. The company has also been linked with takeover talks with the Penn Financial Corporation, a life insurance concern in Santa Monica, Calif. **********Transamerica, a San Francisco-based diversified holding companythat receives 64 percent of its revenues and 41 percent of its profits from its existing insurance operations, called the reports of its Crum & Forster takeover ''just rumors.'' **********''We often hold talks that never come to fruition,'' said William H. McCalve, a spokesman for Transamerica.  At Sears, Doug Fairweather, a spokesman for the retailer, said the company ''would neither confirm or deny the reports.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/18/busin.body_text: **********When the Manville Corporation, the nation's largest asbestos producer, decided three weeks ago to file for reorganization under Federal bankruptcy laws, it argued that the move to shield itself from asbestos litigation was partly the fault of the Government. **********''The Chapter 11 action might not have been necessary if the Government had accepted financial responsibility for its role in causing much of the disease,'' said John A. McKinney, chairman and chief executive officer. **********Mr. McKinney has made it clear that Manville's strategy involved increasing pressure on the Government to push the growing asbestos compensation problem out of the courts and to help pay the claims of tens of thousands of workers who have sued the company and others in the industry. ''I expect to emerge from this, some system in which the Federal Government pays its share,'' he said. **********Mr. McKinney's expectations, however, are not about to be realized soon. To start with, some of his basic assumptions are disputed by lawmakers. Some argue that Government is already paying its share, perhaps more, through workers' compensation, Medicaid and Social Security. Others say flatly that the Government is not to blame for the development of what medical experts have called the nation's worst occupational health disaster. **********The Background **********Asbestos is a mineral fiber that has been widely used in thousands of industrial and construction products over the past century because of its durability, resistance to flames and ability to insulate. **********Indications that breathing asbestos dust could cause asbestosis, a chronic lung disease, began to appear in the 1920's and 30's. The dust was later linked to cancer, which, like asbestosis, usually appeared three or four decades after exposure. **********Shipyard workers are the major source of the litigation that has sent Manville, UNR Resources and several smaller insulation makers into bankruptcy hearings. **********During World War II, workers in Navy and private shipyards often labored in thick clouds of asbestos dust as they raced to build or repair warships and freighters. Almost 56,000 workers were heavily exposed during the war, according to the study on which Manville based its decision to file for bankruptcy. **********During the war, the Government issued directives on permissible asbestos uses. But the record shows that guidelines on proper exposure and operating procedures were frequently ignored. **********In 1964, Dr. Irving Selikoff and a research team at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York published a study of asbestos disease in insulation workers indicating that the problem was far more serious and widespread than thought. In succeeding years, increasingly tough regulations on allowable exposure and labeling requirements were adopted by the Government, some despite industry objections. **********Today, there are an estimated 35,000 plaintiffs seeking compensation from 250 companies for asbestos-related diseases. About nine million Americans living today are thought to have been exposed to asbestos from 1940 to 1980. Estimates of total asbestos liability have ranged from $50 billion to $200 billion. For U.S Payments **********Proponents of increased Federal participation in compensating the asbestos plaintiffs argue on three basic grounds - legal responsibility, morality and practicality. **********So far, the Government has never been found liable for injury to anyone who worked with asbestos. Proponents of Federal participation in a compensation fund say, however, that the Government has preserved that record only by invoking sovereign immunity, which protects it against many actions to which private parties may be subject. They say the courts should remove this defense or support legal theories that get plaintiffs around it. **********The basis of the proponents' argument is the contention that Government knew everything the industry knew about the dangers of asbestos and thus was negligent in supervising shipyards. Moreover, they say, the Government, by specifying the use of asbestos in many jobs and by promulgating weak guidelines and regulations, contributed to the problems, and thus there should be a legal basis for shared liability. The Morality Argument **********More important, they say, the Government's role makes it morally responsible to support a compensation fund even if the cloak of sovereign immunity preserves it from liability. **********''I don't think there's a smoking gun, but the data in hand show the Government's pervasive involvement is enough,'' contended David Pullen, a Manville executive who is a spokesman for the Asbestos Compensation Coalition, an industry-sponsored lobbying group. Mr.  Pullen said that most of the persons exposed to asbestos could be regarded as war victims, to whom the Government owes support analagous to that received by veterans. **********Finally, proponents of Government compensation argue that as a practical matter, it will cost the Government less and compensate the plaintiffs better if all claims were consolidated in a federally directed and supported compensation plan. Against U.S. Payments **********Opponents of Federal contributions to a new compensation plan think the courts will continue to say there is no legal basis for suing the Government for asbestos-related diseases. And Government lawyers dispute the significance of many of the statements and actions cited as proof of pervasive Government involvement or negligence. **********Peter Nowinski, a Justice Department lawyer, added that available documents showed ''an earnest if not always successful effort at surveillance'' in shipyards and that industry was the source of the guidelines the Government set. **********Negligent or not, the Government contends it has compensated all of its employees to the limits required by law under the Federal Employment Compensation Act. As of last December, it faced 6,000 such claims and had paid $9 million on the small percentage that had been processed. The Government also paid the industry's contributions to state workers' compensation programs for those who worked under contract to it in private shipyards, in addition to supporting asbestos-afflicted persons in welfare and support programs. **********Representative George Miller, Democrat of California and sponsor of a bill that would set up a compensation fund supported by industry and insurers and cut off future litigation, said: ''There's no indication that the whole thing will fall apart without Government participation in the compensation fund.'' **********As for practicality, Mr. Miller and his colleagues argue that it would be more feasible politically and better financially for taxpayers to reform workers' compensation law than to ''socialize American industry's losses.'' The Outlook **********There seems to be a growing consensus among Congressmen most familiar with asbestos problems that a federally arranged substitute for litigation is needed for fair, efficient compensation of persons who contracted lung disease or cancer caused by asbestos inhalation.  But there is no vocal support for the position that the Government should participate in a compensation fund. **********''You could say that Manville's filing lent urgency to the matter, but it didn't make the issues clearer,'' said William Shore, legislative assistant to Senator Gary Hart, Democrat of Colorado, sponsor of the bill most favorable to the asbestos manufacturers. **********Senator Hart's bill would set up a commission to judge relative responsibility of various producers and users of asbestos, leaving open the question of whether the Government was partly to blame.  Analysts assume that it would result in some Government participation in the fund, although the bill itself is careful not to assume Government responsibility. **********Legislation introduced by Mr. Miller and the most recent version of a bill by Representative Millicent Fenwick, Republican of New Jersey, would move litigation out of the courts and into the workers' compensation arena, but would not provide for Government contributions to the fund. **********The Asbestos Compensation Coalition shows some optimism. ''We are gaining a momentum, although I can't name our supporters and I wouldn't call it a snowball,'' Mr. Pullen said. **********''There's a consensus that some legislated remedy is needed,'' Mr.  Shore said. ''That's progress, since Mr. Miller used to oppose that.  I'd be surprised if there isn't some middle ground with limited Government participation that he could live with.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/29/world.body_text: **********Japan today detailed the measures it would take to open its markets to more foreign goods. The measures are part of its response to increasing pressures from the United States and Western Europe, which are suffering high unemployment while running huge trade deficits with Japan. **********''Japan realizes that its prosperity depends upon the prosperity of the United States and Europe,'' said Masumi Esaki, a former Minister of International Trade and Industry and chairman of a special committee of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party charged with easing trade frictions. ''Therefore, we are determined to do all we can to maintain the free-trade system.'' **********The products most affected by the changes that will be made in regulations governing imports are cosmetics and pharmaceuticals, medical equipment, motor vehicles, electrical appliances and equipment, and sporting goods. Response to Pressure **********Japan's huge trade surpluses have aggravated unemployment in the West. Accordingly, the pressure on Japan to make its markets more accessible to Western goods - or face possible protectionist action against Japanese exports - has intensified in recent months. **********Japanese and Western government officials have expressed concern that moves toward protectionism could set off retaliatory actions by other nations, possibly resulting in a trade war. **********On Tuesday, the Government disclosed the broad outlines of the measures it said it would take to make exporting to Japan easier. It said that 67 nontariff barriers to the Japanese market would be eliminated or significantly reduced. These barriers essentially restrict imports by insisting upon certain levels of product quality and safety, as well as product testing. Some of the barriers prohibit the use of certain foreign-made goods, such as tennis balls and aluminum baseball bats. **********Today, at a quickly arranged news conference, the 67 areas marked for action were identified, from a list of 99 nontariff barriers that had been in the subject of complaints by all of Japan's trading partners. **********Of the remaining 32 complaints, Mr. Esaki said that 9 would b e studied furth er, 15 were based on misunderstandings by the foreign countries and 8 would not be changed, primarily because Japan considers tha t it already meets the international standards. **********The often-criticized nontariff barriers are viewed by the United States and the European Economic Community as evidence that Japan is a closed market, resistant to imports, yet exporting aggressively at the expense of industrial production and employment in other nations. **********Although Japan has reduced its tariffs, it has maintained a number of less visible impediments to imports, such as unusually strict health and safety standards and exhaustive te sting requirements for some products. **********The package of changes must be approved by the Cabinet on Saturday, but that is considered to be a formality.  The following are included in the list of promised changes: **********- Acceptance of animal test data generated abroad for medicine and cosmetics. **********- ''Simplification and rationalization'' of the documents that must be filed when declaring imports. **********- Acceptance of clinical data generated abroad for medicines and medical machines. **********- Expediting approval procedures for cosmetics. **********- Revision of standards for plywood imports. **********- Recognition of labeling in languages other than Japanese for household goods. **********- Relaxation of safety standards for electrical appliances. **********- Acceptance of foreign test data on automobiles, **********- Translation into English of the laws and regulations concerning import approval requirements for automobiles. **********- Issuance of certificates by domestic sports organizations on eligible foreign-made sporting goods. **********- Classifying American-made sake using a grading system comparable to that used by Japanese sake brewers. Quick Action Pledged **********Most of the changes would be put into effect by ministerial directives, rather than by the time-consuming redrafting of statutes. Mr. Esaki also promised that the changes would be made quickly, some immediately and others within weeks. **********Foreign business executives charge that, regardless of high-level Government directives, lower-level customs bureaucrats, who have long been taught to impede imports, are unlikely to change their practices. **********In response to such complaints, Mr. Esaki pledged that ''we will follow up to see if the new procedures really were implemented.'' Foreign Reaction Guarded **********Reaction to the liberalization package by foreign officials was guardedly optimistic. William G. Barraclough, economic and commercial affairs counselor at the United States Embassy in Tokyo, termed the measures ''significant.'' But he added that it was not yet clear that the Government steps alone would solve the problems of access to the Japanese market. **********The labyrinthine distribution system in Japan, based on generations-old social relationships, is often cited as a nongovernmental barrier to foreign products. **********Responding to a question, Mr. Esaki pledged that the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, through ''administrative guidance,'' would try to reduce the time required to bring a foreign car to market, and to insure that distributors make no more than ''normal profits.'' ---- U.S. Reaction Special to the New York Times **********WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 - Administration officials said today that they had not yet seen the details of the policy changes announced in Tokyo and would issue a formal reaction when the final package was conveyed to foreign governments. **********One top Reagan aide noted that the test would be whether there was a ''genuine opening'' of the Japanese market providing ''real opportunities which would lead to concrete improvements for American exporters.'' **********Lionel H. Olmer, Under Secretary of Commerce for international trade, called the measures ''potentially helpful.'' The United States had an $18 billion trade deficit with Japan in 1981, more th an twice the deficit of 1980.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/22/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Receiver of Delorean Outspoken Accountant
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/22/busin.body_text: **********Sir Kenneth Cork, who was appointed last Friday as the British Government's trouble-shooter in charge of the insolvency of DeLorean Motor Cars Ltd., remembers the first time that he was called upon to sort out a financial quagmire. It was in 1943, he recalled, when General Dwight D. Eisenhower told him that an officer's mess in Italy was in trouble. **********Sir Kenneth, who was then an enlisted man, but already a qualified accountant, successfully extricated the occupying powers from an overdrawn account at the Bank of Naples by some crafty financial maneuvering. ''But for three months, I was in fear of a court martial,'' he said. **********Widely known for his skills as a company liquidator, Sir Kenneth, 68, is now a senior partner in Britain's leading firm of accountants, W.H. Cork, Gully & Company. Although he has just become a joint receiver of DeLorean, which manufacturers a stainless steel sports car in Northern Ireland that is sold in America for $25,000, he has already spent three weeks racing between the United States, Belfast and his London headquarters, leading a Government investigation into the beleaguered company's prospects. **********A towering, bald and bespectacled man who was London's Lord Mayor in 1978, Sir Kenneth was knighted four years ago. He has been heavily involved with numerous financial, civic and artistic organizations in England, and is currently a director of nine companies. **********Known to speak his mind, Sir Kenneth is reported to have once criticized the Archbishop of Canterbury for the church's reticence in condemning greed and inflation. He has also frequently spoken out in favor of curtailing the number of personal bankruptcy procedures and helping unsecured trade creditors gain some proceeds from collapsed companies. As treasurer of the National Association of Youth Clubs, he once appealed to industry to take practical action to help unemployed youths. And recently he berated the Government for undersubsidizing the Royal Shakespeare Company, of which he is charman of the board of governors. **********Once describing himself as a ''funky sailor,'' Sir Kenneth, who gave up his 22-foot yacht for a catamaran, enjoys solo runs between England and France. He lives with his wife in the village of Great Missenden, northwest of London, and finds time occasionally to dabble in photography and painting.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/09/busin.body_text: **********Crude oil prices on the European spot market rose slightly yesterday in light trading, a development that traders attributed as much to reduced supplies for sale as to concern about the fighting in Lebanon. **********Traders said major varieties of crude oil rose about 35 cents a barrel on stable demand. **********The European spot market is generally considered a barometer of future oil prices. Oil traders said that they did not think the Middle East fighting posed an immediate threat to world oil supplies. But they said suppliers were concerned that the conflict could escalate and eventually result in a reduction of crude from the Arab world. **********On the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday, the price of futures contracts for home heating oil rose moderately in light trading.  Contracts for delivery in July rose 1.66 cents to close at 96.74 cents a gallon. On Monday, in a sharp reaction the the Middle East fighting, the heating oil futures contracts rose 3 1/2 cents a gallon.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/15/busin.body_text: **********Wall Street brokerage firms, with profits fattened by five months of some of the heaviest stock trading in history, are paying out large and, in some cases, record Christmas bonuses to their employees. **********Depressed earnings in the last two years had prompted some houses to drop the Christmas bonus, a tradition on Wall Street. But this year virtually every major brokerage house and investment banker is observing the practice, with bonuses that range from $400 to nearly 25 percent of an employee's annual salary, a spot-check showed. **********With daily trading volume frequently over 100 million shares since mid-August, the New York Stock Exchange said its members had earnings of $497 million in the third quarter, almost 10 times the $50 million they earned in the same period last year. **********As a result, there have been some sharp changes in previously austere bonus policies, the spot-check of more than a dozen firms showed. **********Dean Witter, for example, hadn't paid a bonus since 1978. But this month, the nation's second largest brokerage house is distributing Christmas checks that range up to $400 for its clerical workers and up to two weeks' pay for salaried employees who do not hold senior management positions. The firm, which informed its staff of the bonuses last Friday, said nearly 5,000 of its 12,000 employees will recieve the Christmas checks, with only senior executives and brokers on commission excluded from the bonuses. **********A Christmas bonus is ''the right thing to do this year,'' said Bob Anderson, Dean Witter's vice president for personnel, noting the brokerage fees that have been generated by the explosive trading volume. But there is ''certainly no assurance'' the practice will be repeated, he added. Dean Witter was acquired by Sears, Roebuck & Company last year. Brokers Are Excluded **********Merrill Lynch, the nation's largest brokerage house, paid bonuses yesterday to 18,500 of its 35,000 employees yesterday, with top salaried executives and brokers on commissions excluded. Those receiving the holiday checks, including secretaries, assistants and other salaried, nonmanagement workers, received an extra two weeks' pay if they had been with the firm all year. Smaller amounts, ranging down to $100, were paid to employees who joined the firm in 1982. **********Merrill Lynch also did not pay Christmas bonuses last year, when a weak market kept down earnings from stock brokerage, but it did pay the bonuses in 1980. **********Traditionally, some of the largest Christmas bonuses in the securities industry have gone to the employees of investment banking firms. John C. Whitehead, the senior partner of Goldman, Sachs & Company, said 2,000 of his firm's 3,000 employees would receive checks this year equaling 24 percent of their annual pay. The percentage is the largest ever paid by the company as a Christmas bonus. **********''We think bonuses are a useful tool that create teamwork,'' Mr.  Whitehead said. No Larger at Big Board **********At the stock exchanges themselves, there will be Christmas bonuses as usual this year, but the checks will be no larger than last year's at the New York Stock Exchange and less than last year's at the American Stock Exchange. **********The New York exchange said it would pay 1,700 of its 1,753 employees bonuses equal to 7.5 percent of annual salary. The Big Board has had the same Christmas bonus policy for more than five years.The American exchange said it would pay bonuses equal to 12.5 percent of annual pay, down from 15 percent last year and 14 percent in 1980. **********Like Merrill Lynch and Dean Witter, Prudential-Bache, another major brokerage, is reinstituting bonuses this year after suspending the practise in 1981. The company said its 3,600 clerical and administrative employees will receive between one and two weeks' additional pay, depending on length of employment. Based on Performance **********Salomon Brothers, the investment banking firm, paid a bonus to its employees on Sept. 30, the end of its fiscal year. The company said the amount of each bonus was based on an employee's individual performance. Mel Adams, a Salomon spokesman, declined to say how large the bonus checks were, although he said they were ''very generous.'' **********Morgan Stanley and Company, the big investment house, said it would pay a bonus to its employees this year, as it has in the past, but it declined to say how much. **********Prescott, Ball & Turben, a brokerage house, said its bonus schedule this year provides that salaried workers with two or more years of service receive about six weeks' bonus pay. Those with six to seven years' service in management positions will receive about 10 to 12 weeks' extra pay, the company said. **********Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb, the investment banking firm, said this year's bonuses were paid to salaried employees in September, the end of the company's fiscal year. The bonuses were described as setting a company record, but the company declined to disclose details. **********Drexel Burnham Lambert. another brokerage house, said that employees with one or two years' service would get four weeks' additional salary, while those with 10 years' service would receive a bonus of 12 to 13 weeks. Oppenheimer Plans Payment **********Oppenheimer & Company, another investment banking house, does not pay bonuses at Christmas time, but a spokesman said they would be distributed at the end of January. The amounts, he said, have not been determined. **********The First Boston Corporation was expected to announce today that it would pay a Christmas bonus to its employees. But the company refused to say how large that bonus would be. **********Mesirow and Company, a Chicago investment firm, said it was paying ''considerably higher'' Christmas bonuses than in the past. Richard Mesirow, a managing partner in the firm, said Mesirow has traditionally paid its employees bonus checks equal to two to four weeks of pay. This year, with ''more of an effort to evaluate people individually,'' he said, the size of the checks ''will fall into a wider range'' and some employees will receive bonus checks worth more than a month of their normal pay.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/18/world.main_headline: SYRIA, OFFICIALLY SILENT, SEEMS TO BE BACKING IRAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/18/world.print_headline: SYRIA, OFFICIALLY SILENT, SEEMS TO BE BACKING IRAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/18/world.body_text: **********Syria, which so far has remained silent on the Iranian invasion of Iraq, allowed hundreds of Iranian Revolutionary Guards to hold an anti-Iraqi demonstration here Friday. **********The guards marched through the Syrian capital chanting, ''After Baghdad: Beirut and Jerusalem!'' Brandishing huge posters of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the Iranian revolutionary leader, and of the Al Aksa Mosque in Jerusalem, the demonstrators ended their march at the Omayyad Mosque here. Prayers were then said for the success of the current Iranian offensive against Iran. **********Syria Advised Against Invasion **********The decision to allow the demonstration suggested that Syria was showing where its sympathies lie. But the protest march apparently caused some embarrassment here, since the Government of President Hafez al-Assad is said to have advised Iranian leaders against striking into the Iraq, ''a brother Arab country.'' **********At the same time, both Syria and Iran share a common goal - the ouster of Iraq's President, Saddam Hussein. Syria denounced Iraq for its invasion of Iran from the start of the war in September 1980, incurring disfavor among other Arab countries. Damascus is also said to have shipped considerable amounts of artillery and antiaircraft weapons to the Iranians. **********On the surface, Syrian-Iranian relations are close and friendly.  There have been recent visits to Damascus by Iran's Foreign Minister and Defense Minister, who held talks with President Assad over the crisis in Lebanon. **********Last month, at least two contingents of Iranian Revolutionary Guards arrived in Damascus to fight alongside Syrian and Palestinian forces in Lebanon. It is not publicly known how many Iranians actually got to the fighting lines, but the Israeli press reported that several hundred had infiltrated into west Beirut. Invasion Not Mentioned in Press **********The Government-controlled Syrian newspapers and broadcasting services have not mentioned the Iranian push into Iraq this week.  Sources close to the Syrian Government said the official reluctance to speak out was linked to the Lebanese situation. They said that if Syria denounced the attack on Iraq, it would anger Iran, which has given Damascus open support in Lebanon. But if Syria speaks out in favor of Iran, they said, it would win even greater hostility from other Arab nations at a time when Damascus feels a unified Arab stand is needed on the conflict in Lebanon. **********Syrian officials refuse to speculate even privately on the repercussions of an Iranian victory over Iraq. Those who do address the problem quickly point out that, unlike the situation in Iraq, which has a large Shiite Moslem population sympathetic to Ayatollah Khomeini, only 2 or 3 percent of Syria's nine million inhabitants are Shiites. **********These officials also say that the Moslem Brotherhood, the religious opposition to the Syrian regime, is composed of Sunni Arabs and has little in common with the Islamic fundamentalists in Iran. Problem for Syria Noted **********Middle East experts in Damascus say, however, that the Syrian regime is decidedly secular and would be uncomfortable with a radical Islamic regime in neighboring Iraq. **********Palestine Liberation Organization sources in Damascus refrained from commenting on developments in the Iranian-Iraqi war, saying they had observed a position of neutrality from the outset of the hostilities. **********Palestinians say, however, that they would be the losers in any shift of international attention away from the crisis in Beirut.  Syrian sources, meanwhile, firmly denied reports circulating in the United States that Syria had agreed to reverse its decision and accept some of the Palestinian guerrillas trapped in west Beirut.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/09/world.main_headline: ISRAEL SHUTS DOWN A UNIVERSITY IN WEST BANK
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/09/world.print_headline: ISRAEL SHUTS DOWN A UNIVERSITY IN WEST BANK
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/09/world.body_text: **********Israel ordered the largest Palestinian university in the West Bank closed for three months today, charging that its students had engaged in disruptive protests against the Israeli invasion of Lebanon. **********The closing of the University of Bir Zeit, which has 1,900 students, sparked a protest by 400 of them in nearby Ramallah.  Israeli troops fired bullets into the air and used tear gas and water hoses to disperse the demonstrators. Palestinian sources said 30 had been arrested. **********In Nablus, meanwhile, two lecturers and 32 students of Al Najah University were also arrested, Palestinian sources said. The arrests were reportedly made at army checkpoints near the gates of the university, where students have been prevented from attending classes. Closing Ordered by Sharon **********Israeli television said the order to close the University of Bir Zeit, a center of Palestinian activism, had been made by Defense Minister Ariel Sharon and that the Council of Jewish Settlements in the West Bank had asked him to close the campus entirely. **********It was the second West Bank university to be closed temporarily since the invasion of Lebanon began June 6. The Vatican-sponsored University of Bethlehem was shut June 11 after a student protest. It reopened on Monday. **********Bir Zeit University was closed on two other occasions during the last academic year, for a total of four months. According to Gabi Baramki, the acting president, the students had been quiet after the university reopened in April because they were eager to complete the second semester. **********Last week, however, Dr. Baramki said, tensions rose on campus after Israeli soldiers broke into a dormitory in Ramallah and marched about 40 students to military headquarters, forcing them to shout curses in the streets at the Palestine Liberation Organization. He said 100 students were arrested on Wednesday at army roadblocks that barred their entry to the campus. **********In other developments today, according to Palestinian sources, the Israelis arrested three employees of the city administration of Jenin, where the Mayor was dismissed Tuesday. The employees - Wafa Miri, Hakim Afif and Ahmad Dasouki - were reportedly accused of not cooperating with the Israeli-appointed replacement. **********In Gaza, Mayor Rashad ash-Shawwa said he had rejected an Israeli ultimatum that he resume full functioning of his municipality and refrain from issuing political statements.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/16/world.body_text: **********AROUND THE WORLD; Car Bomb West of Belfast Kills Child and Injures 10 **********BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 15 (Reuters) - A car bomb exploded today in Banbridge, killing a 9-year-old child and injuring 10 people, 5 of them seriously, the police said. **********They said the bomb was detonated without warning on a crowded main street in Banbridge, 30 miles west of Belfast. **********(The Associated Press reported that one of those injured was William Craig, a former Northern Ireland Home Affairs Minister.) **********Four other bomb blasts were reported in Northern Ireland within hours of one another. Republican sources here said the attacks appeared to have been an attempt by the Irish Republican Army to show that it was still active despite a series of arrests of suspected guerrillas. **********The authorities said the I.R.A. gave advance warning of the four blasts in which no one was reported hurt. They occurred in Belfast, Newry, Newtownstewart and Armagh.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/27/busin.body_text: **********Productivity of all private business in the United States, including farming, declined at an annual rate of nine-tenths of 1 percent in the first quarter, a slight improvement from the 1 percent rate of decline initially estimated, the Labor Department reported today. **********Productivity for nonfarm business is now estimated to have increased at a rate of five-tenths of 1 percent, rather than threetenths of 1 percent, the report said. **********The first-quarter showings, though hardly strong, were a distinct improvement over the last quarter of 1981, when productivity for all private business fell at a rate of 6.6 percent and productivity for nonfarm business declined at a rate of 6.9 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/05/world.main_headline: EGYPT MOVES TO GET BACK INTO ARAB FOLD
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/05/world.print_headline: EGYPT MOVES TO GET BACK INTO ARAB FOLD
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/05/world.body_text: **********Egypt's Ambassador to the United Nations flew to Kuwait today at the head of the first high-level Egyptian Government delegation to visit one of the Arab capitals that broke relations with Cairo in 1979. **********The delegation will attend a meeting of a 21-member preparatory commission making plans for a conference of nations that identify themselves as nonaligned. The conference is scheduled to be held in Baghdad in September. The commission will start meeting Monday for five days. **********Egypt is a founding member of the nonaligned movement together with India and Cuba, and it has observer status on the preparatory group.  With the April 25 deadline for Israel's withdrawal from Sinai only three weeks away, diplomats and officials in the Gulf countries had been speculating whether President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt would decide to send a prominent Government figure or an anonymous civil servant to Kuwait. Compromise Move by Egypt **********Mr. Mubarak's choice of Ahmed Esmat Abdel Meguid, Egypt's Ambassador to the United Nations, is seen as a compromise move that is apt to please the moderate Arabs without giving Israel cause for alarm. **********Although excluded from the formal meetings of the Arab caucus at the United Nations, Dr. Meguid is known to have been in frequent contact with most of the Arab delegates there. Egypt has a ''good'' Arab voting record at the United Nations, having sided with the Arabs on all mayor issues such as the annexation of Jerusalem and the Golan Heights and Israeli policy on the West Bank. **********Egypt sees the nonaligned movement as one of the best forums to better explain its position, and Mr. Mubarak is almost certain to attend the conference in Baghdad if it is held. **********In several interviews with Arab newspapers during recent weeks he has said that he sees no conflict between Egypt's ''special relationship'' with the United States and its membership in the nonaligned world. India also is a founding member of the nonaligned movement, and no one objects to its special relationship with the Soviet Union, he said. Talks on Iran-Iraq War **********To underline the importance of Dr. Meguid's mission, Mr. Mubarak received him here Saturday and Cairo newspapers printed pictures of the two men together with the announcement that the delegation was leaving for Kuwait. **********It is taken for granted that Dr. Meguid will meet separately with most of the Arab delegates. Egyptian officials have often said that the improvement of relations with the Arabs will come slowly and on a bilateral basis. **********Ostensibly the Kuwait meeting should deal with procedural questions only. But because of Iraq's recent military reverses, it is inevitable that the delegates will have to discuss the most fundamental question facing the Arab and Islamic worlds today, namely how to end the Iraq-Iran war. Egypt Strongly Pro-Iraq **********Egypt's position on the Iran-Iraq war is not far from that of Saudi Arabia and the other Gulf nations. Egyptian statements have been strongly pro-Iraq. Last year, under President Anwar el-Sadat, two major arms and ammunition shipments were sent to Iraq. Egyptian workers in Iraq have been hired by the Iraqi Army to serve with good pay in noncombatant functions. **********Egypt, like Saudi Arabia, would like to see the war brought quickly to an end without humiliation for President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.  Egypt, though further removed geographically, shares Saudi fears of Iranian military supremacy in the Gulf. More than Saudi Arabia, Egypt is vitally interested in preventing a cancellation of the Baghdad conference because of the war. **********Like Saudi Arabia and the other Gulf countries, Egypt sees Mr.  Hussein as a pragmatic leader with whom it would eventually be able to deal and who would counteract the hard-liners like Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya and Hafez al-Assad of Syria.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/29/world.body_text: **********President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq says that Pakistan's first general elections since 1977 could be held ''within two to three years.'' **********Less than a year ago, President Zia appeared to have dropped the idea of free national elections, after earlier pledging to hold them, on the ground that no honest and stable government could emerge from them. Instead, he announced that he was appointing a consultative assembly to advise him on the best time to call elections. **********President Zia, speaking in an interview at his home in Rawalpindi, said he now believes that conditions are evolving to the point where the poll will be held ''not in too near a future,'' but ''not in too distant a future,'' either. **********''It's very difficult to give a time frame,'' he said, but he added that ''within two to three years we should be able to hold a general election.'' **********General Zia is scheduled to make a good-will visit to the United States for about a week, beginning Dec. 6, at President Reagan's invitation. Sees No End to Afghan Problem **********In the interview, conducted in a sitting room of the President's private residence, General Zia also said that there was ''no solution in sight'' in the Soviet military intervention in Afghanistan. **********Pakistan has been conducting indirect, preliminary talks on the issue with the Soviet Union, under United Nations auspices. But General Zia said that as far as Pakistan was concerned, no political solution was possible unless all Soviet troops were withdrawn and Afghanistan regained its ''nonaligned status.'' **********He said also that while he hoped that the nearly three million Afghan refugees now living in Pakistan would eventually be able to return to their country, it would not be ''too difficult for Pakistan's 84 million people to absorb three million people'' if ''worse comes to worst'' and the refugees must stay. **********And the Pakistani leader, who came to power in a bloodless coup more than five and a half years ago, said that his meeting with Prime Minister Indira Gandhi in New Delhi earlier this month ''has certainly allowed us to be a little more optimistic'' about the prospects for ''a peaceful, irritant-free relationship'' with India, a neighbor with which it has fought three wars in 35 years. Agreed to Set Up Commission **********General Zia and Mrs. Gandhi met in New Delhi only briefly, while the general was on his way to visit a number of East Asian countries. They agreed to the early establishment of a commission to work out differences between the two countries. General Zia said at the time that the talks ''couldn't be better,'' that ''we had a heart-toheart exchange'' and that the exchange had ''paved the way for a better relationship.'' **********In elaborating on the meeting during the interview here, he was somewhat more restrained. He said he and Mrs. Gandhi had decided to build ''on the areas of agreement'' rather than dwell on areas of disagreement. **********''Otherwise,'' he said, ''you'll never get anywhere.'' He said some ''very thorny problems'' remained, including the unsettled territorial status of Kashmir. **********But he said Pakistan was determined to ''open up a new chapter'' in relations with India, and he hoped India would reciprocate warmly.  Asked whether he thought Mrs. Gandhi had also seemed to want such a new turning, he said, ''From our meeting I felt that she's responsive.'' **********In addressing the question of free elections, General Zia noted that the democratic tradition had never become firmly established in Pakistan. As the result of the second of the two national elections that Pakistan has held, in 1977, he said, the ''country was on the brink of civil war and we had to intervene in order to save it.'' 'No Ethics' in Pakistani Politics **********In Pakistani politics, he said, there has been no stability. ''The political parties have no political acumen as such,'' he said.  ''There is no ethics in politics in Pakistan. Pakistani politics means violence, Pakistani politics means character assassination and Pakistani politics means get hold of power and then use it best to your advantage. **********''Before I hold an election,'' he continued, ''I should be able to foresee some positive results of the election.'' He said that by ''positive results,'' he did not mean that ''people whose faces I like'' should be elected to national office, or that he or his party should be elected. **********''I have no party,'' he said. ''What I mean is that after the election, there should be a strong and stable government that has been returned to office by the people; not by coercion, not by enforcement and not by any underhanded means.'' **********General Zia, who has been trying to order Pakistani society according to Islamic principles, said that one of the Islamic principles of government is ''that you should select amongst yourself the best that you have,'' and that the best leaders should live according to Islamic values. **********Holding an election, he said, is a means of achieving an end, ''not an end by itself.'' ---- Opposition Politicians Arrested **********KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 28 (Reuters) - Two prominent opposition politicians were arrested today a few hours after the authorities expelled them from Pakistan's Punjab Province for three months, official sources said. **********The sources said Khwaja Khairuddin, secretary general of the Movement for Restoration of Democracy alliance of eight banned political parties, and the assistant secretary general, Mairaj Mohammad Khan, would be detained for one month in Sind Province.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/25/busin.main_headline: HIGH COURT TO RULE ON PATENT DAMAGES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/25/busin.print_headline: HIGH COURT TO RULE ON PATENT DAMAGES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/25/busin.body_text: **********The Supreme Court agreed today to decide how damages should be computed in cases of patent infringement.  The Justices agreed to hear an appeal by the General Motors Corporation, which was ordered by a Federal court to pay the Devex Corporation $19.8 million for infringing a patent on a method of manufacturing metal bumpers. **********More than half the total award, $11 million, was interest. G.M.  argued unsuccessfully before the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit that prejudgment interest should not be awarded in patent cases in the absence of a finding of bad faith or other exceptional circumstances. **********Called Useful Deterrent **********Another Federal appeals court, the Seventh Circuit, has adopted that standard, but the Third Circuit held that the award of interest as a normal procedure was a useful deterrent to keep a defendant in a patent suit from dragging it out. The Justices took the case today to resolve the conflict between the appeals courts. **********The case, General Motors v. Devex, No. 81-1661, is as notable for its long history as for the amount of money at stake. Devex filed the suit in 1956. The patent itself expired in 1969, and Devex won a judgment on the legal issue of patent infringement in 1972. The case has been before the Supreme Court twice before, with the Court refusing to hear earlier appeals. **********Devex filed its own appeal this time, arguing that it should have been awarded an extra $34 million, but the Justices turned down that case. **********Other action today included the following: Construction Industry **********In a case of some importance to labor relations in the construction industry, the Court ruled unanimously that Federal labor law permits, as part of a collective bargaining agreement between a contractor and a union, a ''subcontracting clause'' requiring the employer to subcontract only with subcontractors who themselves have labor agreements with particular unions. **********The question for the Court was whether such subcontracting clauses may validly apply only to particular construction sites at which both union and nonunion workers are employed, or whether the clauses are lawful without geographic limitation. **********The case, Woelke & Romero Framing v. National Labor Relations Board, No. 80-1798, was an appeal by a California contractor from a ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.  That court, upholding the legal interpretation by the labor board, ruled that the clauses were valid without limitation. The Supreme Court today, in an opinion by Associate Justice Thurgood Marshall, upheld that ruling. Mineral Rights **********The Court agreed to decide whether the Government retained rights to the commercial exploitation of gravel deposits on more than 70 million acres of Western land that was originally set aside for the Government under the Stock-Raising Homestead Act. **********The case, Watt v. Western Nuclear Inc., No. 81-1686, is an appeal by the Government from a ruling that the mineral rights that were protected by the act did not include gravel. The Government had attempted to stop Western Nuclear from operating a gravel pit on former Federal land in Wyoming. **********The Justice Department told the Supreme Court that the adverse ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit could throw into disarray the status of mineral rights in a geographic area the size of the state of Nevada.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/29/world.main_headline: IRAQ'S ARMY IS BELIEVED TO BE REELING
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/29/world.print_headline: IRAQ'S ARMY IS BELIEVED TO BE REELING
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/29/world.body_text: **********A few months ago, Iraq had an army of more than 210,000 men equipped with more than 2,300 tanks, 2,000 armored vehicles, 335 combat aircraft and many batteries of artillery. Much of this army was occupying a deep salient in Iranian territory. **********Now, military analysts here believe, Iraq's once large army numbers only about 150,000 men, with its generals executed by firing squads or in exile. Two of its four armored divisions have been reduced to the size of brigades, and only about 100 combat aircraft appear to be flyable. **********Since March, Iranian forces have dislodged Iraqi units from forward positions. In many cases, The Iranians have enveloped and captured almost the entire units. **********Implacably, if not with much textbook elegance, the Iranians continually maneuvered until they drove almost all Iraqi forces out of Iran this week, generating serious political alarm in Arab nations and among some officials of the Reagan Administration. Iraq Facing Morale Problems **********It is not yet clear that Iraq's armed forces have collapsed. But a United States official said today that ''there is no doubt they have suffered major losses in equipment and personnel and are facing morale problems.'' **********Few foreign analysts have much faith in the statistics issued by both sides since the Iraq-Iran war began in September 1980. But some of them believe that Iraq might have lost about 10,000 men - killed, wounded or captured -in a single battle. That would be a third of the 30,000 Iraqis who tried unsuccessfully earlier this week to hold the Iranian oil port of Khurramshahr. **********Some American officials and analysts outside the Government believe the rapid and serious Iraqi reversals were caused in part by an inflexible command structure. They said the inflexibility inhibited field commanders from using their intitiative to exploit opportunities early in the war or to sidestep disaster in recent weeks. **********The officials and analysts also cited superficial training, political meddling, unclear war aims and the absence of a plan to bring the war to a successful conclusion. **********Religion, another factor that has strongly influenced conflict in the Middle East for many centuries, may have also played a big role, according to some of the analysts. **********Iraq's problems, including the interference of civilian leaders in military affairs, once seemed mild compared with those of Iran, which was convulsed by a chaotic Islamic revolution. A Clumsy but Effective Force **********But the surviving cadre of Iranian professional military officers and the Islamic religious mullahs slowly found ways to work together effectively, if clumsily, according to the Western analysts. **********Iranian military officers were able to turn the Shiite religious fanaticism of the Moslem Revolutionary Guards into a valuable, if sometimes blunt, military asset. **********''In spite of its resupply problems, revolutionary turmoil, and the gradual reduction of its operational air strength to something like 70 to 100 fighters, Iran has forged a surprisingly effective military machine,'' Anthony H. Cordesman, a military and Middle East specialist, wrote in the June issue of Armed Forces Journal. **********In contrast, a variety of specialists said, Iraq's military organization has shown itself to be ''very, very inflexible - slow to move,'' in the words of one United States official. Soviet Military Influence **********The specialists attributed the inflexibility in part to Iraq's longtime military relationship with the Soviet Union. Soviet military doctrine emphasizes tight control of forward units by higher echelons of command and discourages small unit initiative. **********With the addition of political meddling by Baath Socialist Party officials, an American official said, ''tactical commanders were either not authorized to make quick decisions or, if authorized, were, in fact, reluctant to do so because of fear of subsequent punishment.'' **********Fearing accusations of cowardice, some Iraqi field commanders refused to move when under attack until it was too late to avoid capture, destruction or disorder, according to analysts. **********''They had ample firepower and manpower to prevent being overrun by Revolutionary Guards shouting Islamic slogans and charging them in a disorderly way,'' said a non-American expert. ''But in the crunch they clearly did not know how to employ those assets.'' A War of 'Amateur Armies' **********Several sources said they agreed in general with a remark in Mr.  Cordesman's article that ''both sides have shown that they are still amateur armies.'' **********Such analysis is not meant to slight the zeal of either side, but it helps to explain how Iran's strange new military organization, described as ''lashed up'' by one analyst, could prevail on a modern battlefield. **********The analysts said both sides fired many artillery shells but did not seem to have the communications, training or sophistication to apply artillery fire accurately to key targets. Tanks were used in large numbers, the sources said, but tank gunnery was very inaccurate. The use of fighter-bombers in close air support was unimpressive, one official said, although Mr. Corsesman wrote that armed helicopters were quite effective for both sides. **********The inability of Iraq to get the most out of its modern weapons permitted Iran's unorthodox mixture of militia zealots and professional soldiers to survive in what might have been a disastrous military environment. **********''In recent weeks the mullahs and the Revolutionary Guards in Iran showed they were willing to charge as assault infantry, and the Iranian armor and mechanized forces were happy to follow them,'' said one specialist. ''You can't exactly say that the professionals are commanding them. They are more or less pointing them in the right direction. But it has been working.'' **********Although some authorities are dubious, at least one Middle East analyst believes that the large number of Shiite enlisted men in the Iraqi Army were emotionally demoralized by the assaults from Iranian Shiites. The analyst said Shiites on both sides held ''a common belief in exactly the same slogans and that God decides battles.'' **********An American official said Iraqi commanders were apparently aware of possible demoralization. ''There is enough in the theory that, until they were needed, infantry units with high proportions of Shiites were deployed against Kurds and not against Iranians,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/18/busin.body_text: **********Despite fears that other creditors might be harmed, a Federal judge yesterday allowed the New York State Dormitory Authority to collect $38.5 million from Lombard-Wall Inc., the small Government securities firm that filed for bankruptcy last week. **********''I will sign this order despite the reservations I expressed,'' said Judge Edward J. Ryan after a long and stormy hearing in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan. ''This is not a precedent,'' he warned, saying he reserved the right to reverse the decision later. **********The judge acted after lawyers for a host of other creditors argued, in effect, that if the Authority was to receive funds from Lombard-Wall or Lombard-Wall Money Markets Inc., a subsidiary that also filed for bankruptcy, then they should, too. **********Bills Coming Due **********The Authority, which raises money for a number of colleges, hospitals and other institutions and invests idle money for some of them, had sought the cash to meet bills that were coming due. The money, the first dispensed by Lombard-Wall since it filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of Federal bankruptcy laws, was paid in the form of Treasury coupons that the Authority can cash. **********The Dormitory Authority, Lombard-Wall's largest unsecured creditor, has $250 million in secured debt and $52 million in unsecured debt with the little-known Government securities dealer. Lombard-Wall, in its trading activities, typically borrowed money for a fee from a party such as the Dormitory Authority and put up Government securities as collateral with the promise to buy them back at an amount slightly higher than the loan at a specified time. **********The aim of such an arrangement, called a repurchase agreement, is to provide the borrowing firm with money that it tries to invest at a higher return. Holding Off Creditors **********Saying that its assets must not be sold, Lombard-Wall has insisted that its creditors not be allowed to sell collateral they are holding; however, the Dormitory Authority said that it desperately needed the money and both sides brought an agreement to Judge Ryan for his approval yesterday afternoon. **********The judge at first had reservations, as did some of the 75 lawyers representing Lombard-Wall's creditors who packed the courtroom.  ''I am just apprehensive that anyone is going to get a leg up here by acting over-expeditiously,'' he said. **********But Henry Goodman, the attorney representing the Dormitory Authority, said it would be ''titanic and cataclysmic'' if the Dormitory Authority did not get the money. **********''It is cash needs, your honor, cash needs to meet contractor bills,'' Mr. Goodman told Judge Ryan.  ''Many of the other people here, too, would like immediately to have their affairs straightened out,'' the Judge responded. Firm's Chief Testifies **********The judge finally agreed to the order after Harold W. Kurtz, Lombard-Wall's president and chief executive, was brought into court to give sworn testimony that no one else had a claim on the securities. **********Nervously facing the room of lawyers, Mr. Kurtz said that his firm had paid cash for the coupons from United States Treasury securities that it proposed to turn over to the Dormitory Authority. According to Mr. Kurtz, his firm paid between $34 million and $35 million for the coupons and they now have a market value of $38.5 million. **********A repeat of the same scene is possible at another hearing scheduled for 11:30 A.M. today. A lawyer for the New York City Housing Development Corporation said that he had worked out a similar deal to recover $130 million from Lombard-Wall. **********Lombard-Wall, the third small government securities dealer to fail since May, said that its problems began with the failure of Drysdale Government Securities Inc. in that month. Comark Securities Inc., a West Coast firm, closed in June. **********Despite its willingness to help out the Dormitory Authority, Lombard-Wall obtained a temporary restraining order from Judge Ryan yesterday morning to prevent other creditors from selling their collateral. **********''We just have to stop disorderly liquidation if we can,'' Mr.  Kurtz said in a brief interview before taking the stand.  In its Chapter 11 filing, Lombard-Wall Inc. listed total assets of $2.059 billion and liabilities of $2.053 billion and said it owed $177.2 million to its 10 largest unsecured creditors. The first meeting of creditors is scheduled for Friday morning.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/31/world.main_headline: JAPANESE CABINET APPROVES BUDGET INCREASING ARMS OUTLAY 6.5%
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/31/world.print_headline: JAPANESE CABINET APPROVES BUDGET INCREASING ARMS OUTLAY 6.5%
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/31/world.body_text: **********ThePrime Minister and his Cabinet approved an austere budget today that covers the fiscal year beginning April 1.  It provides for cuts in allocations for education and many other services but, in response to American urging, would increase military spending. **********The proposed budget, amounting to $216.2 billion, would include $11.8 billion for the military, an increase of 6.5 percent. A senior official of the Japanese Defense Agency, Hirokazu Arai, said he felt the projected outlay was at the level of ''the minimum of resources'' needed to reach the goals of the military program for 1983-87, ''to purchase all the equipment we need within that period.'' **********(In Washington, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said Japan had made a ''reasonably significant effort,'' but added that it had not gone far enough toward matching its self-defense goals, United Press International reported. His criticism reflected the fact that the $11.8 billion projected for military spending would amount to less than 1 percent of Japan's gross national product.) **********The overall $216.2 billion budget for fiscal 1983, the first to be presented since Yasuhiro Nakasone became Prime Minister in November, was described as the most austere since 1955. It represents an increase of 1.4 percent over the 1982 budget and it reflects slumping tax revenues. Revenues for the 1983 fiscal year were expected to total $138.7 billion, as against $157.2 billion in 1982. The reason, officials said, is a lower than expected economic growth, now put at 3.4 percent for fiscal 1983. **********The budget proposal calls for a pay freeze for millions of Government officials, the 230,000 members of the defense forces, railwaymen and other public employees. However, there are plans for pay increases of 4.5 percent to be granted through a supplementary budget in the fall, retroactive to April 1. It is calculated that such pay increases would make the rise in defense spending 8.6 percent instead of the 6.5 percent mentioned in the budget proposal. 'Everybody Is Dissatisfied' **********Other austerity measures include reduced subsidies to agriculture, which is normally sacrosanct for political reasons. A Finance Ministry spokesman said at a briefing on the budget that ''everybody is dissatisfied.'' **********In January, the proposal is due to go to Parliament, where the ruling Liberal Democratic Party has a large majority. It is expected to be adopted in virtually its present form by spring. **********Prime Minister Nakasone went on television to appeal for public understanding of the budget. He compared the higher allocations to military spending to an insurance premium paid by a householder on what he described as ''a larger home,'' meaning, he said, that Japan has a bigger role to play in the world. **********''Our fiscal condition is very severe,'' said Shigeyoshi Genjida, an official at the Defense Agency.  ''These fiscal conditions forced our Government to make a real zero-sum budget,'' he said. ''This is reflected in a decrease on education, food control and local government. By accumulating these minuses, the defense budget was increased.'' **********The official said at a briefing that allocations for education and science were cut by nine-tenths of 1 percent, subsidies to farmers through food control accounts by 7.8 percent and payments to local government by 12.3 percent. Allocations for pensions were slightly cut and those for public works were to be held to the 1982 level. **********Mr. Arai, another Defense Agency official, said that the budget featured ''a marked shift of priority to defense.'' He added, ''This was a very bold step on the part of the Japanese Government, when other domestic programs were very sharply cut down.'' Down Payments of $100 Million **********Officials said that one illustration of Japan's seriousness over increasing military spending was the provision for ''future obligations'' in the military budget. These consist of down payments on American aircraft such as the F-15 fighter and the P-3C antisubmarine plane to be paid for over the next five years. **********The budget for 1983 provides for down payments on F-15's and P-3C's of just under $100 million, while the eventual cost of new military planes of this type will be over $1.4 billion, officials said. **********Some Japanese experts said the budget was too deflationary.  ''From an international viewpoint Japan is being asked to open its market and stimulate domestic demand,'' said Isamu Miyazaki, President of the Daiwa Research Institute and a former chief Government economic planner. ''It's very deflationary,'' he said.  ''Defense spending is not productive compared with public spending.'' **********Japan's fiscally conservative business community believes that the budget is, if anything, not taut enough.  ''This will mean a further continuation of a sizable deficit and that is a problem,'' said Masaya Miyoshi, an official at the Federation of Economic Organizations, the top businessmen's club.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/10/world.main_headline: ISRAELI BORDER AREAS SHELLED AFTER RAID ON PALESTINIANS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/10/world.print_headline: ISRAELI BORDER AREAS SHELLED AFTER RAID ON PALESTINIANS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/10/world.body_text: **********Some 100 rockets and artillery shells were fired into northern Israel today after Israeli air strikes against Palestinian bases, sending residents in the area running to their air raid shelters. **********There were no Israeli casualties reported. But the shelling, the first such attacks on Israeli territory since the cross-border ceasefire went into effect last July, appeared to hold the potential of provoking Israel into the extensive ground operation in southern Lebanon that has been under consideration during the last few months. **********Defense Minister Ariel Sharon, reportedly a strong advocate of a major assault to obliterate bases of the Palestine Liberation Organization across the border, has been restrained so far by Prime Minister Menachem Begin, for domestic and international political reasons. It is considered unlikely, however, that Mr. Begin will accept shelling attacks from Palestinians in southern Lebanon on northern Israeli towns and kibbutzim without a vigorous response. 4 Incidents Cited **********A military spokesman cited four incidents to justify today's air attacks: the planting of a mine, which wounded an Israeli soldier on patrol in south Lebanon; the planting of several antivehicle mines just inside Israeli territory near the Lebanese border two days ago; the laying of an explosive charge near a school in Ashkelon, south of Tel Aviv, and an incident this morning in which a bomb exploded in the back of a Jerusalem bus, injuring a woman and two children. **********The Israeli television broadcast a long film tonight on the bus attack, showing an eight-year-old girl in shock after being hit in the leg with shrapnel. All three were treated at a hospital and released. **********A military spokesman said that the air attacks were ordered by the Government ''after terrorist organizations had, during the past days, repeatedly and severely violated the cease-fire agreement.'' Syrians Did Not Attack **********A military communique identified the three targets in Lebanon as Mazraat al Wasitah, an operational base of the P.L.O.'s main arm, Al Fatah, containing bunkers, buildings and ammunition dumps three miles south of the Zahrani River estuary; Dahr Aqlin, a training base three miles south of Damur, and a gun position on the outskirts of Sidon, where two 100 millimeter artillery pieces, with a range of 14 miles, were located. The guns were out of range of the Israeli border. **********Although Israeli planes drew antiaircraft fire and Syrian MIG fighters were reported to have flown nearby, the Syrian pilots did not attack and all Israeli planes returned safely, according to the spokesman. **********After the attacks, the military issued a background paper asserting that ''Israel has demonstrated exceptional self-restraint in the wake of extensive P.L.O. cease-fire violations.'' Since July 24, the paper said, ''the terrorists perpetrated 130 attacks within Israeli territory, along Israel's borders, in Judea-Samaria and abroad.'' **********The last Israeli air attack took place April 21 in reaction to the killing of an Israeli soldier in southern Lebanon when his vehicle hit a mine. At the time, Israeli military commanders called it a warning action that would not be pursued if the P.L.O. returned to the cease-fire. No such pledges on the cease-fire were made today, however.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/25/busin.print_headline: IN EL PASO'S STORES, A NERVOUS QUIET
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/25/busin.body_text: **********The streets are very quiet here. It is the kind of quiet that makes for empty cash registers, bored salesmen and nervous shop owners. **********Depending on where their stores are situated, owners lost 30 percent to 70 percent of their customers when Mexico's President, Jose Lopez Portillo, imposed strict currency and import controls on Sept. 1. **********Businessmen here are dazed from the loss, and figure they can do little beyond cutting staff and hoping for a recovery in the Mexican economy that will bring back their customers from Juarez, just across the border. **********''Until now, this has been an international city,'' said Albert Schwartz, vice president of the Popular, a department store with three locations in town. ''It's tough.'' **********El Paso businessmen have always considered their proximity to the border an advantage because it expanded their own market of 500,000 people to 1.3 million. How the Cultures Mix **********South El Paso, the commercial neighborhood closest to the border, is almost an extension of Juarez. The Woolworth five and dime is a cinco y diez, the furniture store is a muebleria, and many of the sales clerks speak better Spanish than English. **********Even stores like J.C. Penney and Sears, which depend more on their American customers, have accepted pesos as eagerly as dollars.  ''For eight years we have taken pesos and it is hard for us to imagine not accepting them,'' Mr. Schwartz said. ''But if it seems to be a hopeless cause, then we will have to stop.'' **********At present, most of the stores, including Popular, Sears and Penney's, are trying to keep some Mexican clients and clear charge accounts by accepting pesos and reselling them to banks or private exchange companies. However, many are concerned that there will be such a large buildup of pesos on the American side of the border that they will have to stop. **********Only three banks in this city and a couple of private exchange companies are still accepting pesos, but the rates change daily.  Although the Mexican Government set the official rate at 70 pesos to the dollar, compared with 48 in February and 26 in January, the rate at the El Paso banks has ranged from 85 pesos to more than 100 pesos per dollar recently. **********The banks and exchange companies sell the pesos to tourists or residents who make purchases in Juarez and can get a better exchange rate in the United States. **********''We try to balance our accounts and not take in more pesos than we can sell, but yesterday we weren't selling dollars because we had an oversupply of pesos and it gets harder all the time to keep the account balanced,'' Donald C. Shuffstall, assistant vice president of the State National Bank, said one day earlier this month. ''We have to find a new market for pesos or we can't accept them.'' **********Since the banks and private exchange companies use different rates, stores find themselves competing not only on the price of cereal and milk but also on their exchange rates. Makeshift signs with 80 pesos, 90 pesos or 100 pesos are placed on storefronts all over El Paso. **********''I can resell my pesos for 90 to the dollar but the store next to me can resell his for 80 pesos to the dollar, so I had to drop my rate and I'm losing money,'' said the manager of one store in South El Paso. **********Businessmen here are closely following each proclamation from Mexico City to determine what it means for them. The day after the Mexican Government issued a 54-page report on the import restrictions earlier this month, businessmen packed a meeting hall at the Chamber of Commerce and tried to find leniency in the guidelines. There was not much to be found. **********Jeffrey Brannon, an economist from the University of Texas at El Paso, told the audience flatly: ''We all need to reorient ourselves.  Juarez will have to get basic supplies from Mexico, and El Paso will have to reorient their markets to other parts of Texas and New Mexico.'' **********''The whole thing hit us right between the eyes,'' said Sam Sayklay, the manager of Economy Cash and Carry, a grocery distributor that sells to companies that export to Mexico. ''We can't work with the peso rate changing every day.'' **********Jesus Gallardo, manager of the Woolworth's store, sat at the soda fountain and looked at his sales figures. ''What sales?'' he responded, when asked about the numbers. ''We never recovered from the first devaluation in February and sales last week were down by 49 percent.''
