https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/19/world.main_headline: SAHARAN REBELS WARN WASHINGTON THEY MAY TURN TO SOVIET FOR ARMS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/19/world.print_headline: SAHARAN REBELS WARN WASHINGTON THEY MAY TURN TO SOVIET FOR ARMS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/19/world.body_text: **********The Polisario Front, which has been fighting Morocco for for control of Western Sahara, has warned the United States that it might seek weapons from the Soviet Union if Washington continues to step up military assistance to Morocco. **********''The prospects of a military confrontation and an internationalization of the Sahara conflict have grown,'' said Mahmoud Abdel-Fattah, the front's chief permanent representative in Algiers. **********''The American involvement with Morocco is prejudicial for the equilibrium of Africa,'' Mr. Abdel-Fattah said. ''The Reagan Administration's military and economic assistance to Morocco is not only in support of King Hassan but directly against us. The United States, which calls itself the friend of Africa, appears to be implicated in an effort to destroy existing borders by helping Morocco swallow the Sahara.'' **********While it has long been known that the front's guerrillas received Soviet-made arms from Algeria and Libya, Mr. Abdel-Fattah's remarks in an interview here marked the first time that a senior Polisario Front policymaker has spoken openly about turning directly to the Soviet Union for military assistance. Report of Guerrilla Attack **********The interview, which was given at the front's sprawling complex of offices on Roosevelt Avenue here, came three days after the guerrillas reported a new attack by rebel forces guerrillas against Moroccan troops in southern Morocco. **********The guerrillas have contended that they killed more than 50 Moroccan soldiers in a number of locations in the area, but the Moroccan army has denied any such attack. **********Mr. Abdel-Fattah spoke as several African leaders were shuttling from capital to capital this week in search of ways to heal a major split within the Organization of African Unity, which admitted the Polisario Front as the organization's 51st member in February. **********Morocco and at least 19 other African countries have said they will boycott meetings of the organization where the front is seated, while supporters of the rebels, such as Algeria, have declared that their participation in O.A.U. meetings would be contingent on the seating of the guerrillas. New Attitude on O.A.U. Formula **********Mr. Abdel-Fattah left the impression during the interview that the front now viewed previous O.A.U. proposals -which have been accepted by Morocco in principle - for a cease-fire and a referendum to settle the seven-year-old war as inadequate. **********''The only way to end this war is through direct negotiations between the Polisario and Morocco,'' Mr. Abdel-Fattah, a slim, intense man who spoke in English and Arabic, said. ''There is no other way. We are ready to negotiate with Morocco any time. If there are no negotiations, there will be no cease-fire - and the war will continue. We want peace, and a just solution - but Morocco must talk directly with us.'' **********King Hassan has consistently refused such direct negotiations. He has said that the Western Sahara dispute will ultimately be resolved chiefly through talks between Morocco and the front's main supporter, Algeria. **********Mr. Abdel-Fattah scoffed at the King's position. ''If he wants to talk only with Algeria because they support us, does that mean we then should talk only with the United States because they finance and arm Morocco?'' he said, derisively. U.S. Promises of More Aid **********The Reagan Administration, Mr. Abdel-Fattah said, was unnecessarily inflaming the situation by its recent promises of more military and economic assistance to Morocco. **********''The danger of an internationalization of the conflict is daily increasing -and the United States has to accept a big responsibility in this,'' he added. ''The Moroccans don't need weapons, they need food. If Mr. Reagan is really concerned for King Hassan's crown, the best pressure he can apply is to get Hassan to stop the war, not continue it. But we say this quite clearly: the more weapons they give to Morocco, the more weapons we will need and the more we will seek those weapons from all those who will give them to us.'' **********''We have to defend ourselves,'' Mr. Abdel-Fattah continued. ''We cannot sit back and let the Reagan Administration help Morocco in slowly strangling us. The United States's increasing support to Morocco has consequences not only for the people of the Western Sahara but also for the security, peace and stability of this entire area. **********''If the Reagan Administration continues this kind of support to Morocco, our response will be to ask all those who can help us for more weapons - it's logical. The Soviet Union? My reply is, why not?''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/26/world.main_headline: POLISH POLICE CHIEF CAUTIONS ON MARCHES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/26/world.print_headline: POLISH POLICE CHIEF CAUTIONS ON MARCHES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/26/world.body_text: **********Poland's top security official said in a televised speech today that the authorities were equipped and ready to use force to put down anti-Government demonstrations planned for Tuesday. **********The official, Gen. Czeslaw Kiszczak, who is the Interior Minister, said the activists behind the demonstrations were being stirred up by the West and were bent on a confrontation with the martial-law regime. **********His speech, the first he has delivered directly to the nation, was regarded as the sternest warning so far against political marches on Aug. 31, the second anniversary of the agreement at Gdansk that created the Solidarity trade union, now suspended. **********Solidarity leaders have called for a two-week campaign of leaflet distribution and other protest actions, culminating in demonstrations in an attempt to force the regime to release internees and revive the union. **********The appeal has noticeably heightened tensions after a comparatively peaceful summer. This week, with heavy police patrols, attacks in the press on the West and a barrage of publicity about trials and raids on underground printing establishments, the Government is trying to overwhelm the mood of protest. 'Prophets of Confrontation' **********''The prophets of confrontation should abandon their actions while there is still time, while the road still remains open for a return to normal public life,'' General Kiszczak said, sitting before the cameras in military uniform. He is an alternate member of the party's Politburo and a member of the military council that was set up when martial law was declared Dec. 13. **********''No one, at home or abroad, should cherish illusions that it will be possible to organize street spectacles in Polish towns with impunity for the benefit of foreign TV stations,'' he said. **********''No one will be allowed to trample on the interests of the state and nation. If there have not been enough lessons so far, the provocateurs will be taught more. The authorities and law enforcement bodies have effective forces and the means to guarantee calm and security. Public order shall be maintained.'' **********Those preparing the marches, he said, are ''hypocritical'' in calling them peaceful.  ''Why, then, are crowbars, clubs, gasoline bombs, sharpened rods for puncturing tires and other tools and implements being readied?'' he said, adding that the organizers were also laying plans for first-aid centers to aid any victims in clashes with the police. Opposition to Protests Seen **********The general said most Poles opposed demonstrations that threatened to prolong martial law. Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, said in a speech last month that he hoped to lift martial law by the end of the year. **********General Kiszczak sounded the theme, which has dominated the Polish press, that ''subversive centers'' in the West, particularly in the United States, were trying to provoke trouble. He said demonstrations on Aug. 13 and 16 had been inspired by foreign broadcasts. **********Balancing the toughness of his warning somewhat, the general said the Government was still following a policy of socialist ''renewal,'' as reforms are called, and would follow a policy of dialogue wherever possible. **********''The authorities do not aim at increasing repression,'' he said.  ''We are looking for other methods.'' To this end, he said, discussions are being held in factories to counter propaganda from underground groups, and activists in hiding should feel free to give themselves up. **********''We are not passive in waiting for people to turn themselves in voluntarily,'' he said. ''We are extending our hand to those who do not have the courage to do it first.'' **********The impact of the speech was probably heightened by items on the news program before it. They included statements from a committee headed by Mieczyslaw Rakowski, a Deputy Prime Minister, that underground groups were being set back, and film clips of clandestine printing equipment that the police said was uncovered in Szczecin and elsewhere. The news also said persons arrested for organizing street marches earlier this month would be dealt with before military courts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/16/world.main_headline: POPE BIDS I.L.O. BUILD SOCIAL SOLIDARITY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/16/world.print_headline: POPE BIDS I.L.O. BUILD SOCIAL SOLIDARITY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/16/world.body_text: **********Pope John Paul II called here today for a ''new solidarity without frontiers'' based on the ''primacy of human work over the means of production.'' **********In an address to the International Labor Organization, a United Nations agency, the Polish-born Pope stressed that trade unions able to operate in ''full independence from the political authorities'' were essential for forming a ''society of solidarity.'' **********''The working man must assume responsibility for defending the truth, the true dignity of his work,'' he said. ''He must not be prevented from exercising that responsibility, though also bearing in mind the good of the community.'' **********The Pope appeared tired from his recent journeys to Britain and Argentina as he spoke before the nearly 2,000 government, trade union and management delegates who jointly represent their countries at the 149-member I.L.O. Solidarity Members in Gallery **********Several members of Poland's Solidarity trade union, suspended in December when the Government decreed martial law, were in the galleries of the conference hall of the Palace of Nations to hear John Paul speak. **********The address was the highlight of the Pope's one-day visit to Geneva at the invitation of the I.L.O. John Paul was greeted at the airport shortly before 9 A.M. by Fritz Honegger, the Swiss President. **********The Pope was not on an official visit to Switzerland, and he did not kneel and kiss the ground on arrival here, as he usually does on visits. **********Besides addressing the labor conference, John Paul visited the headquarters of the International Committee of the Red Cross and the complex of the 12-nation European Organization for Nuclear Research, which straddles Switzerland's frontier with France. **********The Pope had lunch with the local representatives of Roman Catholic agencies at St. Nicholas de Flue Church, as did Pope Paul VI in 1969 when he made a one-day visit to address the I.L.O. The organization was founded by the Versailles Treaty at the end of World War I to advance the cause of peace by promoting social justice for workers. Says a Public Mass **********John Paul's only contact with the local population was at the public mass he said in the large exposition hall adjoining the airport just before boarding his plane for the return flight to Rome. **********Francis Blanchard, I.L.O.'s director general, said in welcoming the Pope to the conference that John Paul knew the life of a worker because he had ''worked in a stone quarry and in a chemical factory as a manual laborer.'' **********The Pope spoke from the same podium from which Lech Walesa, the Solidarity leader who is now interned, addressed last year's conference as a Polish worker delegate. This year the Warsaw Government did not include any workers in its delegation, although I.L.O. rules call for one. **********At the outset of his speech the Pope recalled that the wounds he suffered in the attempt on his life in Rome last year had prevented him from addressing the 1981 conference as he had planned. **********John Paul urged that attention be focused on unemployment, with its ''harsh consequences for the workers which are too often overlooked.'' He urged that particular attention be given to the question of jobs lost because of the introduction of labor-saving technology ''without waiting for it to force itself upon our attention by the harm it causes.'' Says Work Enhances Dignity **********The guiding principle in dealing with unemployment problems, he said, ''should be that human work is both a right and an obligation for everyone, not only reflecting but enhancing the dignity of the human person.'' **********At the Red Cross headquarters, the Pope said the humanitarian agency and the Holy See were studying ways of closer ''collaboration on their activities in favor of peace.'' **********Speaking of the Geneva Conventions on the protection of war victims, John Paul said he would like to see added to them international agreements outlawing ''inhuman treatment and in particular torture.'' **********To the physics researchers at the nuclear center, the Pope said the church wanted the ''dialogue between science and faith, despite past tensions, to enter an always more positive phase and to be intensified at all levels. **********''The love of truth, sought with humility, is one of the great values capable of uniting men of different cultures,'' he said.  ''There is no truth that is not universal.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/09/busin.body_text: **********BETWEEN drags on a bottle of Coca-Cola, Bryan G. Dyson, president of Coca-Cola USA, yesterday announced the introduction of diet Coke, which he described as ''the most significant new product introduction'' in the history of the company. **********Although Coca-Cola has used it in ads, this is the first time the country's No.1 soft-drink company has put the name Coke on a product. And although he admits to the possibility that the new product might cannibalize some of the market for its Tab, which is already the leading diet cola, Mr. Dyson feels that it will create new drinkers in the category - men. **********Women have been the major users until now, making up the larger part of that 36 percent of the population that drinks low-calorie sodas with some frequency. **********All diet drinks constitute 13.8 percent of total annual soft-drink sales of more than six billion cases, according to John C. Maxwell Jr. of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc. He gives Tab 3.6 percent of the total; Diet Pepsi, 2.9 percent; Royal Crown Cola's Diet Rite, 0.6 percent, and Pepsi Light, 0.5 percent. **********Tab, Mr. Dyson said, has been positioned as a diet drink. Diet Coke (and the company is not capitalizing the D) is being positioned as a good-tasting cola that incidentally is low-calorie. **********Of course, Coke's ostensibly big news is a switch from recent industry pronouncements from the second-string competitors, Seven-Up and Pepsi-Cola, both of which have come in with caffeine-free colas.  Pepsi's announcement came as recently as Wednesday. **********Asked about his own company's intentions in the no-caffeine arena, Mr. Dyson responded that when Coke believes the time is right it will be there with such a product. **********Might he use the name Tab, as rumor has it? That is certainly one of the company's options, he said.  Although diet Coke is being sweetened with saccharin, the company's president said he did not rule out switching to either the new aspartame or cyclamates. **********Part of the advertising news here is that the campaign is not being done by Coca-Cola's regular agency, McCann-Erickson, but is handled instead by SSC& B, another of the Interpublic Group of Companies that, if Coke had its way, would still be secretly doing TV advertising for its Mello Yello beverage while McDonald & Little, Atlanta, continued as the publicly acknowledged agency of record. **********In any event, there was no SSC& B diet Coke advertising ready for yesterday's meeting, but there were tapes of the jingle, and those rousing jingles certainly have become the heart of the soft-drink industry's emotional advertising pitch. The line is: ''Introducing diet Coke - Just for the taste of it.'' **********The packaging, red on white rather than the traditional vice versa, was created by the Schechter Group. And instead of regular testmarketing, the product was given in-home trials under normal living conditions. **********Further defying soft-drink tradition, diet Coke will be introduced first into the New York market, which constitutes some 10 percent of the national population and is considered atypical of United States markets generally. The drink will be in seven markets with 15 percent of the population by September and, if schedules are kept, it will be virtually in national distribution early next year.  Meanwhile, as the product moves from market to market, the effectiveness of various advertising spending levels will be tested. **********Another expected question was how much Coke would be spending for advertising in light of reports that both Seven-Up and Pepsi would be spewing out as much as $100 million each on their introductions. **********While avoiding any precise figure, Mr. Dyson did say ''around $50 million-plus, and that is a very strong level to spend - spending twice that would be looking to advertising to do something extraordinary that the product can't accomplish itself.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/09/world.main_headline: SYRIANS VOWING TO HOLD TROOPS IN PRESENT LINES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/09/world.print_headline: SYRIANS VOWING TO HOLD TROOPS IN PRESENT LINES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/09/world.body_text: **********Syria said again today that it intended to maintin its military forces in their positions in Lebanon despite growing Israeli military and political pressure for them to withdraw. **********Officials here said that any withdrawal of Syrians from Lebanon would be out of the question. **********They affirmed that the troops had not pulled back from any forward positions in southern Lebanon since the start of the invasion on Sunday. **********The Syrians were reacting to reports from Jerusalem that Prime Minister Menachem Begin had added a demand for withdrawal of Syrians from Lebanon to his other conditions for an eventual Israeli withdrawal. **********Damascus has been stung by criticism from the extremist Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, that the Syrians avoided taking on the Israelis. **********Army communiques for the second day reported various clashes on the ground and in the air today and said that two Israeli planes had been downed by ground batteries. Israelis Inside Syrian Sphere **********Damascus pinpointed the presence of Israeli troops well inside the areas Syrians have regarded as their own military sphere since 1976, when a hypothetical red line was drawn across southern Lebanon with the help of American mediators. **********The line was specified at the time that Syrian forces first moved into Lebanon to stop fighting between Lebanese Christians and an alliance of Palestinians and Lebanese Moslems. At the request of American diplomats, the Syrians agreed to keep their forces to the north of the ''red line'' to avoid provoking an Israeli counterthrust. **********Syrian statements Monday and today appeared intended to create an impression that Syrians were intervening forcefully in the air and on the ground to protect the Lebanese and Palestinians and to insure peace in Lebanon, in keeping with the mandate of the Syrian-Arab peacekeeping force created at the end of the civil war.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/21/busin.body_text: **********The Mexican peso continued to recover lost ground against the dollar today as holders of dollars sought to profit from the artificially high exchange rate set when foreign currency operations resumed on Thursday. **********The dollar, which fell from 130 to 115 pesos during Thursday's trading, opened at 105 pesos and closed at 95 pesos today. The Mexican currency has lost 48 percent of its value on the open market since Aug. 5, when a two-tier exchange system was announced and the peso was allowed to float for most foreign exchange transactions. **********But despite profit-taking, foreign exchange markets remained relatively quiet today as both businessmen and financiers focused their attention on events in New York, where Finance Minister Jesus Silva Herzog was seeking a restructuring of Mexico's foreign debt in a meeting with the country's main creditors. **********''Until the financial rescue package is in place, it will be difficult to assess the immediate future,'' said one foreign banker, who asked to remain anonymous. ''But by putting an exorbitant price on the dollar yesterday, the Government has at least prevented a new run on the peso.'' Pressure to Unify Rates **********With three different exchange rates currently in operation, however, bankers expected that Mexico would be under growing pressure to unify the rates and lift all exchange controls as part of a planned credit agreement with the International Monetary Fund. A high-level mission from the I.M.F. was expected here shortly to start negotiations on a $4.1 billion, three-year loan. **********Apart from the open market rate, dollars are available at a preferential rate of 49 pesos for the payment of interest on foreign debts and crucial imports. But the third so-called Mex-dollar rate of 69.50 pesos, at which foreign currency deposits and investments must be converted into local currency, has caused the most controversy, since savers had banked on recovering dollars. **********The Government's announcement Thursday that it would liquidate an issue of special oil bonds that matures Monday at this ''Mex-dollar'' rate provoked particular anger and prompted a formal protest from Merrill Lynch, which had handled the bonds in the United States.  According to investment analysts, the issue is now worth $138 million - foreign exchange that, in current circumstances, Mexico is clearly unwilling to provide.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/14/world.main_headline: Khomeini Bloc Is Ahead In Iranian Voting
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/14/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Khomeini Bloc Is Ahead In Iranian Voting
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/14/world.body_text: **********Early results of elections for an assembly to choose Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's successor showed today that radical clergymen were leading the balloting in Teheran. **********Iran's national press agency said the President, Hojatolislam Ali Khamenei, and the Speaker of Parliament, Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, both favoring radical social and economic changes in Iran, were capturing a majority of the votes cast in the Iranian capital. **********The succession question has sharpened factional tensions between the radicals, who have the support of the Ayatollah, and the conservatives in Iran's clerical leadership, according to Iranian sources.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/20/busin.main_headline: Union Carbide Slumps 48.8%; Philip Morris Is Up 20.3%
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/20/busin.print_headline: Union Carbide Slumps 48.8%; Philip Morris Is Up 20.3%
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/20/busin.body_text: **********The Union Carbide Corporation reported yesterday that the impact of the recession on heavy industry had caused net income in the third quarter to plunge 48.8 percent, while sales dropped 10 percent. **********Warren M. Anderson, chairman and chief executive officer, said that the weakness in the economy continued to hurt many of the company's businesses, particularly those serving the steel, automobile and housing industries. He noted, however, that the corporation's consumer products businesses - particularly batteries -registered sales increases over the 1981 third quarter. **********The company, based in Danbury, Conn., said that net income in the latest quarter fell to $70.5 million, or $1.02 a share, from $137.8 million, or $2.02 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Sales fell to $2.16 billion, from $2.42 billion. **********Union Carbide said that domestic sales in the latest three months of $1.44 billion were 14 percent below the 1981 third quarter, while international sales were $716 million, or only 2 percent below last year's level. **********In Carbide's chemical business, sales dropped 17 percent, to $527 million, from $633 million, while metals and carbon sales showed the biggest decline of any segment, falling 30 percent, to $215 million, from $309 million. Philip Morris **********Philip Morris Inc. reported that record unit sales of cigarettes domestically helped buoy net income in the third quarter of 1982 by 20.3 percent as revenues advanced 7.5 percent. **********Philip Morris, the world's second-largest tobacco company after the British American Tobacco Company, said that net income in the latest quarter advanced to $250 million, or $1.99 a share, from $207.9 million, or $1.66 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Operating revenues increased to $3.14 billion, from $2.92 billion. **********''Their results were right on the nose so far as I am concerned,'' said John C. Maxwell Jr., tobacco analyst at Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb. ''There were two price increases late this year which amounted to some 15 percent between them and which will impact the fourth quarter. There also might be some inventory liquidation in the fourth quarter at both Philip Morris and in the industry as whole.'' **********George Weissman, chairman and chief executive of Philip Morris, said that the company posted record unit sales and revenues for the latest three months and that it was the 73d consecutive quarter that results exceeded the comparable period of the preceding year. **********''Third-quarter volume was particularly strong due in part to industrywide trade inventory accumulation,'' Mr. Weissman said. ''Our share of the U.S. cigarette market set new highs, both in the quarter and for the year to date, led by the continuing growth of Marlboro and the successful national introduction of Benson & Hedges 100's Deluxe Ultra Lights.'' Northwest Industries **********Northwest Industries, a manufacturing and consumer products company based in Chicago, said that net income in the third quarter plunged 90.7 percent, to $6.7 million, or 40 cents a share, from $72.4 million, or $2.35 a share, in the third quarter of 1981. Sales tumbled 44.9 percent, to $451.4 million, from $818.5 million. **********Northwest said that its largest operating company, the Lone Star Steel Company, suffered a sharp decline in sales and a modest loss in the third quarter. The poor showing, Northwest said, resulted from a ''continued and unprecedented decline in domestic oil and gas drilling activity, coupled with the high levels of inventories of oil-country tubular goods in the hands of distributors and end users.'' **********Ben W. Heineman, president of Northwest, said that the options for restructuring the company, as discussed in its 1980 annual report, had been partly exercised through the sale in January of its beverage operations to Beatrice Foods for $580 million. The company has also repurchased about one-third of its common stock, as part of the restructuring plan. Pfizer Inc. **********Pfizer Inc., a pharmaceuticals company, reported that net income in the latest three months more than quadrupled, to $71.5 million, or 91 cents a share, from $13.3 million, or 19 cents a share, in the third quarter of 1981. Sales increased 11 percent, to $909.6 million, from $819.1 million. **********In last year's third quarter, Pfizer said, there was a one-time after-tax loss of $45 million caused by the company's withdrawal from the diagnostic imaging business. Excluding the 1981 loss, latest-quarter results would have shown an increase of about 22.6 percent. **********Pfizer said that earnings continued to be hurt by the strength of the dollar abroad. Weyerhaeuser **********The Weyerhaeuser Company, the country's largest forest products concern, announced that net income in the third quarter dropped 38.1 percent, to $31 million, or 19 cents a share, from $50.1 million, or 34 cents a share, in the third quarter of 1981. Sales slipped 7.3 percent, to $1.02 billion, $1.10 billion. **********The Tacoma, Wash., company, attributed the decline in the thirdquarter results to depressed building materials markets, which have been hurt by weak home construction, and the worldwide recession, which has hurt export markets and domestic pulp, paper and packaging markets.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/26/world.main_headline: ISRAEL SEALS OFF VILLAGES OF STRIKING DRUSE IN GOLAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/26/world.print_headline: ISRAEL SEALS OFF VILLAGES OF STRIKING DRUSE IN GOLAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/26/world.body_text: **********Israeli troops today sealed off four Arab Druse villages in the Golan Heights where a general strike has been under way for 12 days over an issue related to Israel's annexation of the area. The military move followed the failure of a political attempt Wednesday night to settle the strike. **********The 13,000 inhabitants retained freedom of movement within their villages, but movement in and out was restricted. The Druse residents of the Golan Heights went on strike after four of their leaders were arrested two weeks ago and held on charges of inciting opposition to Israel's annexation of the area. **********A military source said tonight that Maj. Gen. Amir Drori had ordered the villages sealed off after receiving information that Palestinians from the WestBank and leftists from Israel were planning to infiltrate the area and bolster pro-Syrian residents favoring a continued strike to resist Druse who wanted it ended. Continued Protest Vowed **********Officially the military command here described the order as ''traffic restrictions to guarantee the region's security'' in the wake of recent developments in the Druse villages. **********At a meeting late Wednesday night in Majdel Shams, the largest of the Druse villages, Israeli officials rejected a demand by the strikers that the law extending Israeli law and administration to the Golan Heights be rescinded and that their four leaders be released.  The strikers responded by saying their protest action would go on. **********Meanwhile, Israeli journalists in the area complained of harassment at army checkpoints. The Israeli radio said that a cassette containing an interview with a local resident at an army checkpoint was confiscated by an army officer and that a reporter for the army radio station physically resisted an officer who tried to take away his equipment. Soldiers disconnected the wires of television equipment, it was stated. **********A protest was lodged with the Government press office. The army spokesman's office said the complaints were being investigated, but denied the commander had ordered force or violence against journalists.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/18/busin.body_text: **********WASHINGTON A report to Congress on automating the work in the Patent and Trademark Office, submitted this week by Commissioner Gerald J.  Mossinghoff, says the first stage will be completed by 1984. By then, the hand-done paperwork will be replaced, for one group of patents and all trademarks, by computer and electronic operations. **********Patent examinations currently involve a manual search through 24 million documents, and up to 7 percent of these may be missing. By 1990, when automation is complete, most paper files will be replaced by electronic data bases. Writtten exchanges with applicants and constituents will continue, but will be complemented by electronic communication. **********J. Howard Bryant has been appointed administrator for automation. A $2 million agreement has been made with the Mitre Corporation of McLean, Va., for the first year's service in engineering and other work. **********Mr. Mossinghoff says the first stage of the program will cost an estimated $29 million. The total program costs for the next eight years are estimated at $300 million, but he says the quality of operations and savings will ultimately pay for the entire system. **********Each year, the office processes more than 100,000 patent and 60,000 trademark applications and issues 65,000 patents and 40,000 trademarks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/06/world.main_headline: PANAMA PAPER SAYS CRACKDOWN WAS AIMED AT IT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/06/world.print_headline: PANAMA PAPER SAYS CRACKDOWN WAS AIMED AT IT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/06/world.body_text: **********The national guard's closing of the country's newspapers last week appears to be an effort aimed mainly at silencing the country's main opposition daily, the newspaper's publisher said today. **********The action came in the wake of the national guard's decision to topple President Aristides Royo and replace him with Vice President Ricardo de la Espriella. The order, issued by the national guard commander, Brig. Gen. Ruben Dario Paredes, said the papers were being closed to ''moralize'' the press and put an end to ''insults and verbal violence.'' **********But Roberto Eisenmann, the publisher of the main opposition paper, La Prensa, said: ''The suspension of all the press last week was simply to disguise the closure of La Prensa. Paredes threatened to close us and did.'' **********The fate of La Prensa in coming weeks will be an important indicator of Panama's likely political direction. The paper's survival will be evidence that, despite last week's shake-up, the country is continuing its gradual return to democracy, but its permanent closure - or the introduction of direct censorship - would badly bruise hope for free elections scheduled for 1984. Troops Raid Newspaper **********While other newspapers were simply informed of the suspension, heavily armed troops and policemen burst into La Prensa last Friday afternoon. Striking some secretaries with rubber hoses, they drove reporters and other employees out of the building. **********When soldiers finally withdrew from the daily Wednesday afternoon, editors found that corrosive acid had been poured into computers, electronic composers and even the printing presses. Drawers and cupboards had been forced open, files had been removed and some money had been stolen. Damage was estimated at about $150,000. **********Although much of the newspaper's equipment was made at least temporarily useless, editors and reporters worked throughout the day in the hope of producing a small eight-page issue Friday. **********''The important thing is that we come out with something,'' Mr.  Eisenmann said. ''Our readers need to know that we haven't been intimidated.'' Compensation Is Offered **********Significantly, President de la Espriella linked the credibility of his new civilian administraiton to the early re-opening of La Prensa, which he was eventually able to negotiate with the national guard.  And after La Prensa's installations were found to have been damaged, the Government offered to pay compensation to the newspaper. **********The foundation of La Prensa in August 1980 was itself evidence that, after dominating the country for 12 years, the national guard was willing to relax its control of news organizations and opposition parties. But the guard - and former President Royo - proved highly sensitive to criticism. **********La Prensa was conceived by a group of liberal businessmen and lawyers as an opposition organ, but ownership is shared by over 500 stockholders who represent a broad spectrum of democratic opinion and numerous different political parties. ''Our editorial line is simply to be democratic in an autocratic situation,'' Mr. Eisenmann said. **********In exposes, cartoons and a widely read satirical column, La Prensa constantly challenged the Royo Government and the national guard. And the daily's readers - its circulation stands at around 14,000 - frequently responded by providing reporters with secret information about corruption within the regime and the guard. Scandals Brought to Light **********Over the last two years, La Prensa has brought to light numerous scandals deeply embarrassing to the regime, including a major fraud in the Social Security Institute. It recently reported that the brother of a senior guard officer had, inexplicably, more than $4 million in his personal bank account and that bank officers were said to be involved in drug trafficking and arms smuggling. **********Officials frequently responded furiously. President Royo brought four criminal libel suits, one of which resulted in the daily's editor, Carlos Gonzalez de la Lastra, being sentenced to five months' imprisonment, a case still under appeal. Last fall, an armed band linked to the official Democratic Revolutionary Party entered the newspaper, firing shots and beating up employees. **********More recently, three newspapers owned by the Government began campaigns of personal insults against key figures of La Prensa, suggesting that Mr. Eisenmann was a contrabandist and that other editors were sexually depraved. After one report that linked the national guard to a trading company supposedly involved in dubious business practices, Mr. Eisenmann said, he was summoned by General Paredes and warned that the paper could be closed. **********When Panama's Supreme Court accepted La Prensa's request for an injunction ordering General Paredes to lift the suspension, however, the national guard chief said he had not issued the order but had merely ''suggested'' the closing to Mr. de la Espriella. As a result, the President was able Wednesday to order that La Prensa be returned to its owners. Paper Resume Publication **********Three other newspapers, La Estrella, the English-language Star and Ya, have resumed publication after accepting that censors be placed in their offices. On Wednesday, though, Justice Minister Justo Fidel Palacios said there would be no prior censorship and that the three Government-owned newspapers would be on the streets again Monday. **********''De la Espriella was very anxious not to start his Government with the stigma of censorship,'' a close friend of the President said.  ''Ironically, he needs a free press as much as the opposition if he's going to gather any power of his own.'' **********Today, General Paredes said he would send a commission to La Prensa to establish whether the damage to installations was ''selfsabotage.'' But if the national guard's responsibility is established, he said, it would pay compensation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/28/busin.print_headline: XEROX INCOME DECLINES 23.3%; RECESSION IS CITED
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/28/busin.body_text: **********The Xerox Corporation yesterday reported a 23.3 percent drop in its first-quarter net income that it said was caused by the recession.  Earnings fell to $109.5 million, or $1.29 a share, from a restated $142.7 million, or $1.69 a share, in the comparable 1981 period, the copier and computer maker said. **********First-quarter revenues were virtually unchanged at $2.051 billion, compared with $2.046 billion in the period a year earlier.  The world's largest maker of copiers, citing the recession as a major pressure on earnings, said that it had reduced its work force by 1,300 people, to 119,700, since the beginning of the year, continuing cutbacks that began in mid-1981 and bringing the total number of layoffs since that time to 3,300. **********C. Peter McColough, chairman and chief executive, and David T.  Kearns, president and chief operating officer, attributed the depressed earnings to several factors. Equipment Sales Down **********In a statement, the two officers said that the worldwide economic slowdown had forced sales of copiers and duplicators down. Sales of equipment declined 11.5 percent, to $230 million, from $260 million, and the mix of placements was weighted toward the smaller, less expensive machines than in the comparable 1981 period, the company said. **********The decline in the value of the dollar abroad, compared with the first quarter in 1981, and ''a substantial cost base impact from worldwide inflation'' also hurt earnings, Xerox said. **********Eugene G. Glazer, vice president of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said that he had expected Xerox's earnings to be down, ''but these were down more.'' **********''For the first time, the recession seems to be catching hold of Xerox,'' Mr. Glazer said. A major indication, he said, was that the number of copies made on all Xerox copiers grew by only 8 percent, down from a normal quarterly growth of 10 to 12 percent. 'Squeeze on Earnings' **********Another sign of the recession was the 12 percent decline in equipment sales, a first-time decline in that area for Xerox, Mr.  Glazer said. ''Their cost structure is rising while their revenues, because of the recession, did not rise,'' he said, ''and that put a squeeze on their earnings.'' **********Lesser factors, he added, were devaluation of the Mexican peso and competition in higher-end copiers from Eastman Kodak's Ektaprint series of copier duplicators. **********The restated earnings for the first quarter of 1981 reflected a new guideline of the Financial Accounting Standards Board. Xerox adopted Statement No. 52, aimed at reducing wide swings in earnings caused by fluctuating foreign exchange rates. The restatement lowered its per-share income by 17 cents, Xerox said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/11/world.main_headline: FRANCE UNDER SOCIALISTS EDGING CLOSER TO NATO
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/11/world.print_headline: FRANCE UNDER SOCIALISTS EDGING CLOSER TO NATO
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/11/world.body_text: **********President Francois Mitterrand's attendance at Wednesday's dinner of Atlantic alliance leaders and his decision to have Prime Minister Pierre Mauroy attend the meeting today appear to be signs that France is edging closer to the alliance, in the view of Western officials. **********Although Mr. Mitterrand's predecessor, Valery Giscard d'Estaing, attended similar dinners preceding summit sessions of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, he did so almost furtively, often announcing his presence at the last minute. Under President Giscard d'Estaing, France was usually represented by its Foreign Minister at formal alliance sessions. **********President Giscard d'Estaing's reticent attitude reflected the legacy of hostility to the alliance that he inherited from Gen.  Charles de Gaulle, who expelled its headquarters from France in 1966 and removed French forces from the joint military command. **********Luns Notes Change in Attitude **********Acknowledging that a change in French attitudes was under way, the alliance's secretary general, Joseph M.A.H. Luns, said at a news conference Wednesday that ''this President of France is more positive toward the alliance and more friendly to the U.S. than his predecessor ever was.'' **********''This is confirmed by what he is doing here,'' Mr. Luns went on.  ''And it confirms what we have felt about the new French Government from the beginning.'' **********Several earlier moves by President Mitterrand also suggested a change.Last month, he caught his allies by surprise when he invited the alliance foreign ministers to hold their annual spring meeting in Paris next year, for the first time since 1966. **********Another straw in the wind, diplomats noted, was the concern President Mitterrand showed over Western European defenses and his more hostile attitude toward the Soviet Union last year, when he supported plans to strengthen the nuclear forces of the alliance through the deploying new American missiles and criticized antinuclear protesters in West Germany and other countries. Giscard's Views Are Recalled **********This contrasted with what Prof. Dominique Moisi of France's Institute for International Affairs has characterized as ''the benign indifference'' exhibited by President Giscard d'Estaing toward the whole debate over nuclear defenses and the threat posed by the deployment of the Soviet Union's SS-20 missiles, which the new NATO missiles are supposed to counter. **********Various explanations are offered by Western diplomats and other students of French affairs for the shift in France's approach to the alliance under the Socialists and for its more belligerent attitude toward the Soviet Union. **********A political lifetime spent warring with the Communist Party is felt by many to have made Mr. Mitterrand mistrustful of the Communists.  And while his decision to bring Communists into the Government may have been a tactic designed to weaken the party, a stronger anti-Soviet stance in foreign policy helps make this more palatable to moderates at home. New Responsibilities Seen **********More important, in the view of Professor Moisi, is an awareness of ''France's new responsibilities'' forced on the Socialist leadership by the wave of pacifism in West Germany and other countries, doubts about the United States' military strength and resolve and the fact that military spending still commands universal support in France because of its military independence. **********But while France's political attitude toward the alliance and the Soviet Union may be shifting, Western experts remain uncertain just how far this change will be translated into new strategic doctrines, closer to those practiced by the rest of the alliance. **********Under President Giscard d'Estaing, France already seemed to have moved a long way from the classic Gaullist doctrine that most French forces must be kept back to defend France itself in case the rest of the alliance lost the ''forward battle'' for West Germany. If France's forces then failed to hold the Soviet armies at bay, France would threaten a strategic attack on Soviet cities, which it hoped would deter an invasion in the first place. Backing Up West Germany **********But despite a greater apparent willingness to commit French forces to a forward defense of the whole of Western Europe, Western analysts say the French Socialists are proving reluctant so far to make the concrete tactical changes necessary to give this shift of emphasis more credibility. **********France's conventional forces in West Germany remain huddled along the French frontier in the Black Forest with the headquarters at Baden-Baden. **********An even more important test of the Socialists' intentions, officials believe, is whether they will help deepen alliance defenses by allowing troops in West Germany to be resupplied from France in a war, even though this would involve France in the forward defense. **********United States military officials say that joint planning with the French is going better than it used to under President Giscard d'Estaing. But there is still no formal commitment by the Socialists to provide logistical support for a forward battle in West Germany.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/25/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; NEW DUTIES FOR INSILCO'S PRESIDENT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/25/busin.body_text: **********Donald J. Harper, 53, president of the Insilco Corporation, a conglomerate based in Meriden, Conn., has been elected to the additional post of chief executive officer, effective at the annual meeting in April. He will succeed Durand B. Blatz, 63, who will continue as chairman. **********Insilco was created in 1969 from the venerable International Silver Company, now one of its units.  ''A great deal of my time will be spent with the subsidiaries,'' Mr. Harper said in a telephone interview, referring to Insilco's sixteen operating companies in six industry segments. ''I want to make sure that we're allocating capital to growth opportunities, that the subsidiaries are motivated and that they understand the role they play as part of a diversified compa ny.'' **********Insilco's largest subsidiary is Times Fiber Communications, a wire and cable manufacturer in which it holds a majority interest and which accounted for abo ut 15 percent of the parent company's sales and earnings last year. Others include Rolodex, a manufacturer of secretarial s upplies; Taylor Publishing, a yearbook producer, and Miles Homes, a build-it-yourself housing company. **********Mr. Harper was previously with the Emerson Electric Company and had been president of its Fisher Radio Division when he joined Insilco in 1973 as vice president for operations. He became president of the International Silver subsidiary the following year, returning to Insilco in 1978 as senior vice prsident. Mr. Harper has been president and chief operating officer of the corporation for about two years. **********Mr. Blatz was associated with the George C. Lewis Company and the Avco Corporation before joining International Silver in 1957 as controller. Mr. Blatz was president of Internatinal Silver when Insilco was established. At that time he was named chairman, president and chief executive. **********Discussing Insilco's management methods, Mr. Harper said, ''We don't talk about autonomy and do something else. We really do it.  I'm going to be cementing these relationships.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/07/world.main_headline: ASSAD SAYS HE WILL SEEK MORE ARMS IN SOVIET
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/07/world.print_headline: ASSAD SAYS HE WILL SEEK MORE ARMS IN SOVIET
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/07/world.body_text: **********President Hafez el-Assad of Syria says that, on his next visit to the Soviet Union, the source of Syria's arms, he will seek to achieve a strategic balance with Israel, according to a French Arabic-language magazine. **********The magazine, Al Mostakbal of Paris, quoted Mr. Assad as having said that no date had been set for his trip to the Soviet Union, which has a treaty of friendship and cooperation with the Soviet Union. **********''The United States has no policy in the Middle East,'' the Syrian leader said. ''It only carries out Israel's policy in the region and this will eventually hurt American interests. The United States supplies Israel with the weapons it uses to occupy our land, while the Soviet Union supplies arms to help us defend ourselves. **********''We are determined to achieve a strategic balance with Israel in a way that would enable us to upgrade our defenses. I believe this will eventually materialize.'' U.S. Peace Role Is Doubted **********Mr. Assad said he doubted that the United States would be able to assume a ''more effective peace-making role'' after Israel's final withdrawal from Sinai last month. **********''The Arabs, who witness every day an American policy opposed to their interests and aspirations, cannot possibly go on offering services to the United States,'' he said, apparently alluding to the Persian Gulf oil producers, led by Saudi Arabia. **********''America supports Israel in every sphere and this American support makes our relations with the United States not good. It also renders America's role ineffective and incapable of bringing about an overall peace in the region.'' **********Mr. Assad, who maintains a working relationship with the Saudis despite ideological differences, said he would oppose Egypt's return to the Arab fold unless it renounced the Camp David accords. The Saudi press has been advocating a reconciliation with Egypt since the Sinai withdrawal.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/14/world.body_text: **********AMERICAN businessmen talk these days about new technology as the trump card in international competition. Confronted with a competitive onslaught based in part on advancing technology in Japan and, to a lesser extent, Western Europe, they are plunging resources into research and development. **********Consultants and academics are flooding business journals with reports on the strategic implications of technology and how to manage it. Still, although France, West Germany and Japan have joined the United States to make up what John Harris, president of the Technology Management Group at Booz-Allen & Hamilton, a consulting group, calls technology's ''big four,'' technology experts agree that over all, the United States has never lost the position it assumed during the 1940's as the world's leader in new technology. **********''Our stability, because of our size, is an advantage which is hard to beat,'' said Richard Foster, a principal at the consulting firm of McKinsey & Company. **********The United States' lead is clear in the fields of technology innovation generally considered crucial to its economic future, including biotechnology, most basic segments of electronics and sophisticated manufacturing processes. **********But some businessmen believe that the challenge is mounting rapidly. The Japanese have claimed technological supremacy in areas as varied as electronic memory devices, design and steelmaking. And Western Europeans have maintained their strength in traditional areas like chemicals and transport equipment, while achieving dominance in such less visible sectors as poultry processing equipment. **********Still, there is no widely accepted measure of technological strength, and first impressions can be deceiving. Japanese automobile technology, for instance, is not notably advanced. Thus, when Detroit shops abroad for new systems, as it is doing for fuelinjection devices for diesel engines, it is more likely to turn to such companies as Robert Bosch of West Germany or Lucas Industries of Britain than to Japan. **********Japan has pushed the application of new manufacturing technology, especially robotics and computer-driven industrial operations, further than its competitors. As a result, it has an advantage in terms of productivity and quality in the output of new cars, steel and a variety of consumer products. **********''They are certainly not ahead in technology in the sense of breakthroughs,'' James C. Abegglen, vice president of the Boston Consulting Group in the company's Tokyo office, commented recently.  ''They simply have the capacity to apply existing technology more quickly.'' **********Japan is well aware that its expertise in applying new technology would be far more formidable if it were more innovative. Spurred by the Japanese Government, Japanese industrialists are increasing efforts to innovate rather than license technology first developed abroad in such areas as electronics and biotechnology. **********''It would be wrong to make the Japanese out to be a powerhouse that will run us over,'' said Mr. Foster of McKinsey. ''They have to be selective.'' **********The Japanese impact in Western Europe has been strong in recent years precisely because of their selectivity, according to Ulrich Steger, the West German Social Democrat who is head of his party's committee in Parliament on economic and technological affairs. ''They are destroying complete branches of our industry not just bec ause of technology, but because of their carefully pl anned export strategy,''he said. **********The European reservoir of technological strength can be described as a patchwork quilt affected by historic strengths and Government policies. But European strength is evident in a number of areas, as is continued interest in new techn ology, according to Michael de Verteuil, man ager for research projects at the European Management Forum, of Gen eva, Switzerland. For instance, he said, in a recent study conduct ed by his organization, the United States was followed by Switzerlan d, West Germany, Britain and the Netherlands in researchand developme nt expenditures as a percentage of gross production for domestic cons umption. Japan was tied for sixth place with Sweden. **********Among European nations, West Germany is generally recognized for its strength in chemical technologies. Home of Bayer, BASF and Hoescht, three of the world's largest chemical companies, it has a long tradition of close cooperation between the industry and university researchers. It is also known for advances in heavy equipment design. **********France's first technological love has been vehicles. The nation has displayed an innovative if not always profitable interest in everything from technically sophisticated automobiles to supersonic aircraft. More recently, it has developed a state-of-the-art, highspeed train and spearheaded the success of Airbus Industrie, Europe's multinational answer to the American commercial aircraft industry. France has also teamed with West Germany to organize European nations behind a substantial space program. **********Britain remains a discouraging technological puzzle. Home of some the world's most respected research, it regularly innovates without engineering competitive products. The British, for example, invented the CAT scanner, a diagnostic device that allows doctors to avoid exploratory surgery in many cases by taking what amounts to a threedimensional X-ray, but American companies have taken over manufacturing and selling it. Similarly, British researchers discovered how to produce large quantities of pure antibodies by fusing antibody-producing cells to mouse tumor cells - a biotechnological breakthrough - but it was Americans who recognized the commercial value of the ''monoclonal antibody'' process and patented it. **********Experts note that national needs are relevant in measuring technological strength. Poor, developing nations may follow China, with its millions of small systems to convert animal and plant waste to fuel, in energy generation. **********Occasionally, special national needs create unexpected technological assets. South Africa, driven to develop energy independence because of international reluctance to trade with it in protest against apartheid, has become a world leader in synthetic fuel processes based on coal. And sun-drenched Israel, boycotted by the Arab oil producers, has become a leader in simple solar energy applications.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/16/world.main_headline: ARGENTINES PUT BLAME ON BRITISH FOR U.N. DELAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/16/world.print_headline: ARGENTINES PUT BLAME ON BRITISH FOR U.N. DELAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/16/world.body_text: **********Argentine officials said today that Britain was responsible for delaying negotiations on the Falkland Islands crisis but still expressed hope for a peaceful settlement. **********Foreign Minister Nicanor Costa Mendez told reporters late Friday night that the return to London of Sir Anthony Parsons, Britain's representative in the United Nations' mediation talks over the Falklands, proved that ''the responsibility for the delay or the prolongation of the negotiations is certainly not Argentina's, but Britain's.'' **********Foreign Ministry officials, repeating that opinion today, also voiced hope that the Ambassador's recall was a positive step that might lead to an accord within the British Government for a negotiated settlement of the crisis. **********Tonight as he left the Foreign Ministry after a day of meetings on the crisis, reporters asked Mr. Costa Mendez if he was optimistic.  ''That is a difficult assessment to make,'' he replied. ''I am confident in the negotiations.'' **********Two Pilots Killed **********The air force announced today that two Argentine pilots were killed in an attack on British ships Wednesday. That brings the number of announced Argentine dead to 63 and missing to 309 in combat with the task force that has massed in the South Atlantic to attempt to retake the British colony seized by Argentina April 2. **********Britain has announced 24 fatalities: 20 navy men killed in the attack on the destroyer Sheffield, one Harrier pilot shot down over Port Stanley, two Harrier pilots missing and presumed crashed and a helicopter pilot killed. **********Reflecting the general view in the Government here that a British invasion of the Falklands is imminent, President Leopoldo Galtieri said that with almost 400 Argentine lives already lost, most of them on the torpedoed cruiser General Belgrano, ''honor'' was at stake and the country was willing tto fight a bloody and prolonged war. **********''I am carrying on my shoulders the spilled blood of 400 Argentines,'' he said in an interview with Mexican television today.  ''The Argentine people, not me, I am sure, are ready for not only 400, but 4,000 or 40,000.'' **********The joint military command issued a communique saying that the search for a missing interisland transport ship, the Isla de los Estados, was continuing. British Reported an Attack **********The command announced Friday night that radio contact had been lost with the ship, which it said was carrying groceries, fuel and medicine among the islands. Military spokesmen did not deny that the transport might have been the ship that the British said they blew up Tuesday in the channel between the two main Falkland islands. **********An Argentine military spokesman said that he had no knowledge of any landing by British troops on Pebble Island in the Falkland group, but a communique issued by the joint military command said that Argentine forces ''repelled'' a bombardment by a single British ship on Pebble Island this morning. **********The sinking May 2 of the General Belgrano cost Argentina 20 confirmed dead and 301 lost at sea, according to the military command's final tally released late last night. **********President Galtieri's mention of the figure 400 today reflected the military's presumption that all the missing were dead. A total of 790 seamen from the ship were rescued, the command said. No Commandos on South Georgia **********Argentine military officials also acknowledged for the first time today that there were no commandos still holding out on South Georgia Island, which British forces recaptured April 26. The commandos were captured and were among the 149 repatriated Argentine marines who returned here Friday. **********In the interview today, President Galtieri again sidestepped a question on whether Argentina would turn to the Soviet Union for aid.  ''If Great Britain insists with its militaristic attitudes,'' he said, ''taking the conflict toward final consequences, we want Argentina and the world to know that just as we have been maintaining this situation in these past five or six weeks, we will continue to maintain five or six months, or five or six years.'' Negotiated Solution Favored **********General Galtieri underlined Argentina's position that it preferred a negotiated solution to war and that it would not break off the talks at the United Nations despite growing British military pressure. **********''In no way will Argentina be the one to cancel or cut this communication,'' he said. ''In the following days, it is probable that an approach toward the search for a solution may exist, but it is not definite.'' **********This was a slightly more positive assessment than one he gave for Peruvian television Friday night. He said then that ''there is a slow advance'' in the talks, but that the defined outlines of a solution were ''still not seen.'' **********Foreign Ministry officials said today that Mr. Costa Mendez would himself go to the United Nations once an agreement appeared at hand.  That he has not gone, they said, reflected the Argentine assessment of the distance between the two warring countries.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/24/busin.main_headline: ICAHN DRAWN BY DAN RIVER'S BOOK VALUE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/24/busin.print_headline: ICAHN DRAWN BY DAN RIVER'S BOOK VALUE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/24/busin.body_text: **********Dan River Inc. seems an unlikely company to be fighting a heated battle for control of its stock.  In the last decade, the large textile manufacturer has been a sluggish performer in an industry hit hard by rising imports, increasing competition and damaging price wars. Profits have tumbled since 1979, the company's best year, and long-term debt remains high. **********The future does not appear much brighter. Analysts predict Dan River's performance will be in line with the struggling industry's norm, at best, and say it will be some time before the company sees substantial improvement. ''Obviously,'' said one analyst, ''they have problems.'' **********Yet, Carl C. Icahn, the Wall Street financier, has spent the last two months and millions of dollars in a fierce bid to purchase as much as 50 percent of Dan River. And Dan River has taken a costly step to fight back. **********The primary attraction for Mr. Icahn lies far from Dan River's current operations or potential for earnings improvement, analysts say. Rather, the allure is more immediate: The company's book value is $35.11 a share, twice the current market price of its stock. The company's stock, which fetched as much as $23 a share last year, traded at $13 before the Icahn effort began. **********In Danville, Va., where Dan River is celebrating its centennial this year, the company line on its prospects differs from that of the analysts. Ineffective management, outmoded equipment and unprofitable plants are things of the past, executives say, pointing to extensive corporate restructuring this year and capital improvements totaling more than $250 million since the early 1970's. **********When the textile industry turns around early next year, said Thomas George, vice president for public relations, ''we think we'll be positioned to do very well.'' **********The numbers are not encouraging, however. After earning $22.2 million on sales of $579 million in 1979, Dan River posted profits of $19.6 million in 1980. Last year, earnings fell to $14.5 million while sales grew to $635 million. Analysts expect 1982 earnings to drop to between $3 million and $5 million. **********In fact, Dan River is performing below the norm in the struggling textile industry. While overall industry profits have dropped 40 percent so far this year, Dan River is down 76 percent, according to Edward F. Johnson, an analyst for E.F. Hutton. **********''Improvement in the textile environment, with consumer spending increases, will help,'' said Mr. Johnson, who forecasts earnings of about $9 million in 1983. ''But it's not as strong as Burlington or J.P. Stevens. We put it on the second tier.'' **********Dan River clearly has made attempts to turn the numbers around. It spent $157.5 million from 1977 to 1981 to modernize machinery at its 27 manufacturing facilities in five Southeastern states. Its president, Lester A. Hudson Jr., has said that capital spending would continue at a level approaching $40 million annually through 1987. (Because of the Icahn proceedings, Mr. Hudson and Dan River's chairman, David W. Johnston Jr., were unavailable for interviews this week.) **********In addition, unprofitable operations, like a texturizing plant in Mebane, N.C., and an industrial fabric facility in Cateechee, S.C., have been closed or sold. Investments have been concentrated in areas of strength - $20 million was spent, for example, to convert a South Carolina plant to expand denim production. **********''The company has decided to start making some very heavy bets on areas where they can be successful, such as denim and carpeting,'' said John S. Pickler, an analyst with Wheat First Securities. ''These are areas where they're as competitive as anyone in the industry, and I think that's a step in the right direction.'' **********Last June, Dan River announced a series of organizational changes intended, it said, to improve operating efficiency and ''eliminate staff and support function redundancy.'' **********Most important among the restructuring was the centralization of manufacturing and management in Danville, where the company was started. Since 1968, Dan River had maintained corporate offices both in Danville and in Greenville, S.C. - creating what many saw as damaging inefficiencies. The reorganization, which will be completed next year, is expected to save $4.5 million annually. **********Despite its present struggle, Dan River has its bright spots.  Production of died yarns, its oldest business, is still its strongest, accounting for more than 20 percent of total sales; the company says it produces 40 percent of colored-yarn fabric sales in the United States. The $59 million Floorcoverings division saw sales increase by 16 percent from 1980 to 1981. **********Still, analysts say the bottom line on Dan River is uninspiring.  Long-term debt, fed by expansion and a series of acquisitions in the 1960's and 1970's, topped $100 million last year, and more must still be spent. **********''The process is still going on,'' said E.F. Hutton's Mr. Johnson, predicting only gradual improvement over the next five years. dan river glance AT A GLANCE  Dan River Inc. Polcyn, a vice president at LTV, said late yesterday, ''We are no longer a part of the negotiations.'' **********Chrysler and the two other companies reportedly involved declined to comment on the matter.  The unit, which holds Army contracts to build the M60 and M1 tanks, is one of Chrysler's few profit-making subsidiaries, earning about $60 million a year in pretax profit. **********Chrysler had said it would sell the unit only if it urgently needed to raise cash. But last month, Chrysler said several companies had expressed interest, and it accepted bids.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/20/busin.body_text: **********Interest rates fell sharply. Optimism over a budget compromise, plus technical factors, indicate to traders and investors that rates will slide. But yields remain high: The 14 percent bonds due 2011 rose a point and a half, to 106 3/4, for a yield of 13.07 percent.  (Page D1.) **********Gold futures prices tumbled on rumors of a solution to the Falklands dispute, registering the largest one-day declines in six months. The reports were not confirmed, but the slide set off standing ''sell'' orders, aggravating the decline. Silver followed gold's descent. (D14.) In London, gold bullion fell $14.50 an ounce, to $348.25; in later trading in New York, the price declined to $340 bid. The dollar slumped as interest rates dropped. (D14.) **********Stock prices rose again, and trading picked up. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 2.66, to 846.08, mostly on the rumors that a peaceful solution was near on the Falklands and strong gains in the credit market. (D10.) Companies **********Eastman Kodak settled its last major antitrust suit pending when it agreed to pay GAF $9.5 million. GAF's amended suit had sought $750 million. As part of the settlement, Kodak agreed to drop a claim that GAF violated licensing agreements. (D1.) **********RKO lost an appeal to the Supreme Court to renew its license for WNAC-TV, a profitable television station in Boston. (D1.) The Court agreed to settle a dispute between users of first-class mail and of second-class mail about how postal rates should be set. (D21.) **********National Public Radio plans an information-distribution role in a joint venture with a private corporation. The network hopes to raise money to offset a loss of Federal money. (D4.) **********Chase Manhattan's operating net rose 58.1 percent, but Bank of America showed a rise of only 3.5 percent. (D8.) **********Profits climbed at Philip Morris and United Technologies in the first quarter, by 22.9 percent and 42.7 percent, respectively. But Goodrich posted a $18.4 million loss. (D7.) Tandy rose 30.1 percent, Honeywell, 6.1 percent and NCR, 10.9 percent. (D8.) **********Two bank holding companies in Pennsylvania are to merge, becoming one of the largest banking organizations in the country, with $10.2 billion in assets. https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/19/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; TROUBLE-SHOOTER GIVEN CHIEF'S POST AT MICRO Z
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/19/busin.body_text: **********Things have not been going well at the Micro Z Corporation, and its board of directors has hired Joffe Marketing International in an attempt to turn the company around. **********Louis H. Benzing, an executive vice president of Joffe, was named yesterday as president and chief executive officer of Micro Z. Mr.  Benzing, 55, succeeds Allan Klein, who has resigned as president but will remain the company's chief financial officer. **********''The company has gone through some hard times,'' said Mr. Benzing, who has been involved in a number of turnaround situations as a Joffe executive. Micro Z is seeking additional financing and plans to de-emphasize two of its products, he said. **********One is a sophisticated electronic cash register. ''The cash register industry is pretty crowded right now, and it's the better part of valor to bite the bullet,'' Mr. Benzing said. **********The other is a computerized system that can do all the accounting, reservations and other work for large hotels of 2,000 rooms.  ''There's not enough of these hotels going up, with the economy, and we're putting the product on the back burner,'' he said. **********At the same time, the company will stress two products.  One is a telephone device that reports on who made calls, for how long and so forth. It can be used to check on employees' use of phones and also by accountants, lawyers and others for proper billing of clients. **********The other is a call router system intended for use by hotels. It can send out calls from hotel rooms on cheaper routes, such as WATS lines. **********Micro Z, based in Monrovia, Calif., near Pasadena, expects to report a loss for the second and third quarters. In the first quarter, it had a loss of $1 million, in contrast to a $250,000 profit a year earlier. **********Mr. Benzing is a West Pointer who also holds a master's degree from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He is a former executive with the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation. **********''We will be here for two to four months,'' Mr. Benzing said. ''We will make the necessary adjustments. Then the company will have a permanent c.e.o. and will be on the road to recovery. We've done it several times.'' Daniel F. Cuff
