https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/28/busin.main_headline: IN THE SHADOWS OF MADISON AVENUE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/28/busin.print_headline: IN THE SHADOWS OF MADISON AVENUE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/28/busin.body_text: **********--------------------------------------------------------------------  Andrew Feinberg writes on advertising in New York. By ANDREW FEINBERG **********I t's a well-known practice on Madison Avenue. An advertising agency buys a television program and sells it to a station, not for cash, in some instances, but for air time for commercials. The time is then entered into what's called a time bank, usually in a computer. Then, from the time bank, the agency sells its clients the time for their commercials. **********The practice is known as bartering, and some barter deals are relatively straightforward. A variation called the tie-in barter, however, often finds the agency using its considerable leverage on the station to make the deal work. It might go something like this: Take the show and you'll get 40 percent of our business in your market. Reject it and you may suffer. Although agencies deny it, their critics say that their tactics are often coercive and unethical. **********The murky world of Madison Avenue's tie-in bartering was illuminated when the J. Walter Thompson agency disclosed this month that its syndication unit -the one that does the bartering - had overstated its revenues by $24.5 million over the last four years through what Thompson said were fictitious computer entries. **********The agency placed the head of its syndication and spot buying units, Marie Luisi, on an unpaid leave of absence, and it has written off $18 million in pretax earnings for the four years and lowered its 1981 fourth quarter pretax earnings estimate by $6.5 million. **********Thompson, which has the largest spot billings of any agency in the country - $301.1 million in 1981 - had more programs to barter than any other agency. Thus, its accounting scandal has raised many questions about how some agencies use tie-in barter and time-banking, which could cause major conflicts of interest. **********Generally, syndication refers to the sale of a television program.  The most prized and expensive syndicated properties are old episodes of hit shows (''M*A*S*H,'' ''All in the Family,'' etc.), and these are usually distributed by large syndicating companies, not agencies. **********Advertising agencies buy less desirable programs from producers, and they can then sell them outright to particular stations. But often these shows are given instead to the station in exchange for commercial time during the show, usually for a certain client interested in the property, or for commercial time to be used in the future. **********Roger Rice, president of the Television Bureau of Advertising, a sales and marketing organization that promotes television as an advertising medium, has been one of the leading critics of how agencies have used the practice in dealing with stations across the country. ''Tie-in barter is a shady, shoddy, seedy practice,'' he said. ''Station time should be bought on merit, not because of promises or threats.'' **********William T. Lifland, an antitrust expert at the law firm of Cahill Gordon & Reindel agrees with the general counsel of Ted Bates & Company, Elhanan C. Stone, that the law is murky on such a tie-in practice, and that it could be construed as a violation of the Sherman Antitrust Act. **********The chairman of the television advertising bureau, David E.  Henderson, said that six large agencies - J. Walter Thompson, Dancer Fitzgerald Sample, Grey Advertising, Ted Bates, Cunningham & Walsh and Doyle Dane Bernbach - were now involved in tie-in barter. Media executives at the first five agencies denied that they used the practice. Calls to the president of the New York office, media director and head of local broadcasting at Doyle Dane Bernbach were not returned. **********The denials by the agencies have been contradicted by TV station personnel, competing agencies, media buying services and syndicators. All, of course, have an interest seeing the agencies' bartering practices curtailed. **********However, television executives, too, are wary of discussing the subject publicly. Just 15 agencies control about 60 percent of the national advertising -or spot billings - placed on local stations in the United States, and the stations fear offending such important sources of their livelihood. But one who would discuss the issue is Larry Linehan, sales manager at WPIX-TV in New York. **********''Agencies often say to us, 'If you run this program, we'll give you X amount of dollars' '' he said. ''If I take the show I would expect preferential treatment. If I turned it down, I could have a problem. Sometimes I'll take the barter deal and not run the show, for instance with some of the programs that Dancer syndicates for General Mills. That's part of business. If it's good for WPIX, I'm in favor of it.'' **********MANY station officials, particularly those at top-rated stations, report little serious pressure. ''It's not that hard a sell,'' said Harold E. Protter, general manager of KPLR-TV in St. Louis. ''They tend to be people you've known for years. If you have a good working relationship with an agency, your share of business will probably increase.'' **********However, the sales manager of a Wisconsin station, who declined to be identified by name, is more concerned. ''The problem began eight or nine years ago and it's the bane of our existence,'' he said.  ''Historically, agencies offer you the dregs of the programming world - otherwise a full-time syndicator would pick the shows up. J.  Walter Thompson is the king of all this action. Sometimes we get hurt for turning down their shows.'' **********Fear of agency retaliation, although considerable, is not the only reason stations do not readily discuss tie-in barter. Mr. Rice says they cannot document such arrangements because the deals are never put in writing, and that some stations worry that they might be breaking the antitrust law. **********Several agency executives argue that the TV operators can play tough, too. ''Gimme a break!'' pleaded one top agency media director. ''When a station takes one of our syndicated programs, they often say, 'O.K., what will you give me?' And if you want to buy a good spot on a network, you usually have to take a package deal that includes some undesirable stuff.'' **********Syndication has grown dramatically since 1971, when the prime-time access rule, which turned an extra half-hour of time back to the local stations, helped create a need for programs. Agencies say their syndication activities have grown so that they can give clients more control over programming, combat the ever-rising cost of TV time, and, not incidentally, make more money for the agency. **********The ethics of syndication are not considered to be beyond reproach. An executive at a top-10 agency that syndicates programs said, ''I hear rumors about all kinds of scams and messes all the time.  Anything is possible. Kickbacks and bill-paddings and creative accounting are rumored constantly. That's why some agencies just choose to avoid it altogether.'' **********Walter Staab, president of the SFM Media Corporation, which buys advertising time and syndicates programs for advertisers, is a direct competitor of the top agencies. He maintains he is purer than most of them because his time-buying and syndication departments are told not to communicate with each other. **********''There has to be a Chinese wall within an organization between time-buyers and syndicators,'' he said. Many agencies say they have such a wall, but at Thompson the same person, Marie Luisi, was in charge of spot buying and syndication. **********Mr. Staab, who opposes time banks, unless separate banks are kept for each client, conceded the practice looked attractive in theory.  ''Many stations,'' he said, ''prefer to commit inventory rather than hard cash, especially since they are usually going to pay with some time they might be unable to sell. An agency, on the other hand, can get a 25 to 50 percent discount on the time it receives. Some of its clients, obviously, could realize significant savings when the agency sells them time at a cheaper rate. **********''But this time bank isn't worth anything unless it can be unloaded, and it has to be unloaded on the agency's clients, some of whom might find themselves on a station they should not be on.'' **********A media director at one of the country's top 15 agencies concurred. ''You should never own something you recommend that your client buy,'' he said. ''That's an obvious conflict of interest.'' **********Walter E. Reichel, senior vice president, executive director of media and programs for Ted Bates, said a wisely run time bank does not require an agency to ''unload'' time on anybody. **********Bates is now syndicating only one show, ''The Sonny and Cher Comedy Hour,'' which, through an arrangement with an independent syndicator, it generally sells to stations for a fixed-dollar amount of future time. By Mr. Reichel's accounting, Bates obtains commercial time via the time bank for about 60 percent of the going rate. The time is then charged to Bates's clients at 80 percent of the regular rate, and the remaining 20 percent goes for servicing, overhead and profit. **********Few stations offer much praise for the agencies' syndicated shows.  For a year, a show called ''The Phantom Wolf,'' obtained via barter, has been gathering dust on the shelf at WLWT-TV in Cincinnati, the stations says. A propitious day for airing has not yet dawned, and even Peggy Green, president of the Dancer Fitzgerald subsidiary that once syndicated the program, admits it is ''a turkey - it's a good show but very few stations seemed to want it.'' **********Many station sales managers say, however, that when such programs are not accepted, economic disaster does not necessarily ensue.  ''I've taken very few barter deals from agencies,'' said Stuart Tauber, general sales manager at WSBK-TV in Boston, ''but they can't take much business away from me because I'm a big sports station and they need to reach this audience. At most, I've lost a little.'' **********Virtually everybody in the advertising business admits that the line between vigorous negotiation and coercion can, at times, be hard to discern. ''We don't do tie-in barter,'' said John Williams, general manager of WPSD-TV in Paducah, Ky., ''but if we get an offer from a big agency, there is an unspoken aspect, an assumption on my part that if I cooperate with them I'll get a better share of their business.'' **********Ned Gelband, vice president media and programming at Jordan, Case & McGrath, doesn't think the Thompson scandal or directives from agency lawyers will diminish the tie-in practice. **********''It comes down to human nature,'' he said. ''Middle-management people can get a great sense of power from getting tough with stations, and by convincing the stations to take a show they can prove themselves to their boss, even if they eventually hurt their clients.''

A small number of Soviet women also were participating. **********Organized by Nordic Women for Peace, which also arranged last year's march, and by the Soviet Women's Committee and the Soviet Peace Committee, the march also will include men, a spokesman for the Scandinavian group said. **********The campaigners' route took them by boat from Stockholm to Helsinki. https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/24/world.body_text: **********The United States has decided to allow the families of American diplomats and other embassy workers to return to El Salvador at the end of this month. **********The State Department, noting a lessening of danger in San Salvador, the capital, said it would also stop granting the so-called hazardous duty pay that added 25 percent to the salaries, before taxes, of American workers at the embassy. **********But despite the decision to permit wives, husbands and children to return to this hot, high valley, life at the United States Embassy here is still far from normal. **********The diplomats and other workers, totaling nearly 100, still go to work in what looks more like a fortress than a diplomatic establishment. High walls and guard towers, built to fend off the rifle and rocket attacks of two and three years ago, surround it.  Guard outposts control the entire city block that the embassy occupies. To enter the building one passes heavy iron revolving doors normally used at prison entrances. **********Depending on their rank, diplomats use bodyguards or have guards stationed outside their homes. Many staff members are not permitted to drive their own cars to work; they are picked up by the armored embassy cars that run a shuttle service. Yet embassy workers feel they have made progress since the days when they were forbidden to go out at night, although they still need special permission to travel to other parts of the country. War Action Shifts **********The decision to allow dependents to return - two and a half years after they were barred - reflects the shifting of the war between the leftist guerrillas and the Salvadoran security forces from the capital to the northern and eastern provinces. **********''The situation has calmed down quite a bit in the city,'' an embassy spokesman said. ''The decision was made by the State Department on the basis of an embassy recommendation. The gist of it is that American personnel are no longer in special danger, or that there are actions specially directed against Americans.'' **********In recent months, urban violence has been reduced mainly to the burning of buses and cars. Bombs occasionally are set off in stores or telephone booths, usually at night when there are no crowds on the streets. Shots still ring out at night over the city, their sound bouncing off the surrounding mountains. **********Most reports of deaths come from the countryside and vary widely according to the source. The American Embassy reports that this month political killings of noncombatants have averaged close to 30 a week nationwide; the Salvadoran Human Rights Commission, an anti-Government monitoring group, reports that 54 civilians were killed in the first week of November, 76 in the second and 221 in the third. A commission spokesman said he was not yet able to provide an explanation for the sharp rise in reported deaths in the third week. **********In the last two years six Americans have been murdered and another, who disappeared from his hotel, is missing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/22/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; New Marine Bank Chief Foresees Expansion
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/22/busin.body_text: **********John R. Petty, 52, president of the Marine Midland Bank, has added the title of chief executive officer of the New York institution. He succeeds Edward W. Duffy, 55, who remains chairman of the bank, as well as chairman and chief executive officer of its holding company, Marine Midland Banks Inc. Mr. Petty is also president of the holding company, whose assets at the end of 1981 amounted to $18.9 billion. **********''Really what we're doing is positioning Marine for expansion in an environment of change,'' Mr. Petty said yesterday after the corporation's annual meeting. ''We have, through our holding company, made investments in two related banks in Philadelphia and Cleveland.  I am going to keep my eye on where most of our assets are presently, the Marine Midland Bank.'' **********Mr. Petty added that banking today ''has more than its share of uncertainty'' because of current regulatory and business conditions.  ''The market is dictating a change, but the regulators haven't responded,'' he said. ''We have to continue our services to our customers, but we have to be very prudent indeed that we create good assets, manage our expenses and control the balance sheet structure of the bank in a cautious manner.'' **********Mr. Petty started his career at the Chase Manhattan Bank in 1953.  He moved to the Treasury Department 13 years later and shortly afterward became Assistant Secretary for International Affairs. He was a partner of Lehman Brothers Inc. for more than four years before joining Marine Midland in 1976 as president of both the bank and the holding company. **********Mr. Duffy began with a predecessor of Marine Midland in 1952 and has headed the holding company since 1973. Three years later, when 10 subsidiary banks were merged into the Marine Midland Bank, which became the principal subsidiary of the holding company, he also became its chief executive. **********Although Marine has headquarters in both Buffalo and New York City, Mr. Petty spends most of his office hours in Manhattan. His home, however, is near Washington, where he moved after taking his Federal job and to which he commutes on weekends. ''Anyhow, there is seldom a time when I spend four nights in a row in the same city,'' he noted.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/21/busin.body_text: **********Plymouth may be doing well but its salesmen are finding it hard going these days. Working on commission, they have to try to get as much money as they can for each car because volume sales aren't there any more. **********At Elkins, if the gross profit on a sale is under $400, the salesman gets 25 percent of the gross. If he grosses $400 or more on a sale, he keeps 35 percent. Since fewer people are purchasing cars, said Sonny Dellinger, an Elkins salesmen, ''I go for the gross.  You've got to in times like these.'' **********Mr. Dellinger, who is 37 years old, came to Elkins a little more than a year and a half ago. ''This dealership is outside of the main automobile strip,'' he said from behind his desk in his office that faces the showroom. ''When a man comes here, he's definitely intersted in the product.'' **********He sold 134 cars last year, and salesmen at Elkins averaged about 100 sales, he said. Last year Mr. Dellinger earned $25,000 - his lowest salary since 1967. In 1977 he earned $38,000. He has a wife and three children, including a 21-month-old baby. **********Tom Stephenson, 57, has been with Elkins for just a little more than two years. With only a fifth-grade education he is the dealerships's ace salesman, and seems perpetually cheerful. **********The first new car he sold was a 1956 Ford, but for the last 25 years he has been with Chrysler. He sold 167 cars in 1981, the most sales in the dealership. Mr. Stephenson, who has a wife, six children and five grandchildren, earned approximately $30,000. In part he sells well, he said, because he is a ''Durham boy'' who has many friends and acquaintances. **********Gerald Pate, a salesman for seven years, had been working on his junked cars all morning, and he sat on his black vinyl easy chair, greasy hands folded. To his left was a television set with a pair of pliers for a tuning knob. He lives in a trailer in Zebulon, N.C., on an acre of land he bought from his mother. He is 39 and a bachelor. **********Mr. Pate said that he had averaged 60 sales prospects a month during the last four years. In the mid-to-late 70's he averaged 90 to 100 a month. Last year Mr. Pate earned $20,000. **********Mr. Pate walked behind his trailer to his shop where he refurbishes junked cars as a hobby. He pointed to a 1966 Imperial Le Baron.  ''That is the last great luxury car,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/03/world.main_headline: Israeli-Egyptian Talks Fail to Break Impasse
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/03/world.print_headline: Israeli-Egyptian Talks Fail to Break Impasse
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/03/world.body_text: **********A meeting between Israeli and Egyptian leaders failed today to resolve the two countries' differences over the site of future negotiations on Palestinian autonomy. **********The Egyptian Foreign Minister, Kamal Hassan Ali, met with Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel for nearly two hours after arriving on a hastily arranged visit to deliver a message from Hosni Mubarak, the Egyptian president. **********The two countries did not resume the negotiations on autonomy for Palestinians under Israeli occupation after Israel insisted that the talks be held here. Egypt maintains that the controversy over the status of Jerusalem is a major topic in the discussions. **********Asked after the meeting whether the two countries were near agreement on resuming the talks, Mr. Ali told reporters, ''Some more time is needed.'' **********He said he had also discussed the possibility of a meeting between Mr. Mubarak and Mr. Begin in the near future. A planned state visit by the Egyptian leader was postponed after he rejected Israel's demand that Jerusalem be included in his itinerary.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/12/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Israeli Troops in Sinai Level Illegal Settlement
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/12/world.body_text: **********Israeli troops leveled an illegal settlement in Sinai today after clearing it of squatters for a second time in eight days. The squatters, who were detained for questioning, are trying to block the return of the area to Egypt on April 25. **********An army spokesman said 30 people had been detained, half of them women. A spokesman for the squatters said those evicted were among 60 removed March 3 from the settlement, Hatzar Adar; they had returned by slipping around army roadblocks in the night. **********In another development, Druses on the Golan Heights, which was annexed by Israel in December, were notified that they had until April 1 to take out Israeli identification papers. The order came as as an anti-Israeli general strike by the Druses went into its 25th day. The 13,000 Druses, members of an Arabic-speaking sect that broke away from Islam, are Syrian citizens.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/05/world.body_text: **********The South African Government refused today to return the passport of Bishop Desmond M. Tutu, the general secretary of the South African Council of Churches. **********A spokesman gave no reason. **********The Government withdrew the passport of Bishop Tutu, a black activist, in April last year, also with no reason being given, and a Supreme Court application in March for its return was turned down. **********The Government gave him temporary travel documents for a trip to the United States last month. During that trip Bishop Tutu, an Anglican, conferred with African delegations to the United Nations in New York City. In August, he received an honorary doctorate of sacred theology from Columbia University. **********The withdrawal of Bishop Tutu's passport in 1981 touched off international protests.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/31/world.body_text: **********A Kuwaiti newspaper, quoting Jordanian sources, said a group of Syrian Army officers had failed in an attempt to overthrow President Hafez al-Assad. Syria denied the report. **********The newspaper, Al-Qabas, said Gen. Naji Jamil, a former Deputy Defense Minister, was executed as a conspirator.  It said as many as 150 army officers were arrested after the unsuccessful coup.  General Jamil was a key figure in Syria until he resigned in April 1978, citing health reasons. His position was taken over by Brig.  Sobhi Haddad. **********A Syrian spokesman in Damascus called the report ridiculous. ''It reflects the dreams of Syria's enemies,'' he said.  Syria has accused Jordan of aiding the fundamentalist Moslem Brotherhood in attacks on Mr. Assad's Soviet-backed regime.  In the past year, bombings and assassinations in Damascus have taken several hundred lives. Last year, tensions heightened when the two countries massed troops and armor along their common border.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/07/busin.main_headline: MESA'S BID IS TAKEN TO HOLDERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/07/busin.print_headline: MESA'S BID IS TAKEN TO HOLDERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/07/busin.body_text: **********The Mesa Petroleum Company, pressing its takeover bid for the Cities Service Company in spite of an outright rejection by the company's top management, disclosed last night that it was taking its offer directly to stockholders of Cities Service. **********The widely expected public bid - to start today without the endorsement of Cities Service officials - provides for Mesa to offer $45 a share for 12.1 million shares, or 15 percent, of Cities Service's shares outstanding. The offer is not conditioned on any minimum number of shares being submitted by shareholders. **********Although this is substantially less per share than Mesa had offered to the management of Cities Service, Mesa hopes that shareholders will respond with such enthusiasm that the Cities Service management would be persuaded to withdraw its opposition. **********Formal Reply Expected **********A lawyer representing Cities Service said late last night, ''My only comment is that I have no comment.'' He added that he had not yet been notified of the terms of the new Mesa offer. **********Charles J. Waidelich, chairman of the board at Cities Service, flatly rejected a $50-a-share bid for 51 percent of Mesa made last week, but Cities Service directors are expected to respond formally to the $50 offer at a special meeting tentatively set for tomorrow or Wednesday. **********Thus Mesa has two offers on the table, one of $50 a share for 51 percent of the company, as a first step in landing 100 percent of Cities Service, if Cities Service's management supports it, and one of $45 a share for 15 percent, if the company does not. **********Commenting on the $50 offer, T. Boone Pickens Jr., chairman of Mesa, said, ''Our proposal is still open and we hope that the board of directors of Cities Service will accept it.'' **********Mesa said that its own five-member board of directors had unanimously approved its offer to stockholders around 4 P.M.  yesterday in a conference held by telephone. **********Mesa had said earlier that it has sufficient financing for a $1.8 billion ''friendly'' bid for Cities Service. It added yesterday that it had arranged enough financing for the $555 million that it would need for its offer to shareholders, and that it reserved its right to purchase more shares if stockholders offered more than the 12.1 million sought. **********The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago and the Bank of Montreal, as widely reported, are to lead a group of banks extending slightly more than $1 billion in credit lines to Mesa. But only about $600 million can be spent for the Cities Service takeover bid. The rest is earmarked for other corporate needs. **********Other banks in the financing group are the First Interstate Bank of California, the Republic Bank of Dallas, the Texas Commerce Bank, the Mellon Bank, the First National Bank of Dallas, the Marine Midland Bank and the Mercantile Bank. **********In what appeared to be tacit acknowledgment that many bankers were reluctant to help finance Mesa unless it could work out a friendly deal, Mesa said that it intended to seek additional financing and, if it was successful, it might purchase more than the 15 percent of Cities Service it was seeking to purchase from shareholders. **********Mesa officials stressed, however, that there could be no assurance that it could get any additional financing. More Financing Sought **********The company said that it was attempting to arrange financing with unidentified banks, other lending institutions and ''independent entities'' that would purchase stock or other securities from Mesa and possibly swap them later for oil and gas properties or other assets of Mesa or Cities Service, if Mesa won 100 percent of Cities Service. **********Stressing that the offer made to Cities Service's board chairman remained open - $50 a share in cash for enough to give the company 51 percent and $50 in securities for the rest -Mesa said that it was ''prepared to agree'' that the securities it would issue would be valued at $50 by any Wall Street banker of mutual agreement.  Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette is representing Mesa, while the First Boston Corporation and Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb represent Cities Service. **********Mesa already owns 4.1 million shares of Cities Service, or slightly more than 5 percent. Thus, should it get the 15 percent it seeks, it would hold the 20 percent needed to show that much of Cities Service's earnings in its own earnings. Dome Device Used **********Using a device ''developed'' by Dome Petroleum Ltd. last summer, when Dome offered to pay $65 a share for a maximum 20 percent of Conoco Inc., Mesa will be able to assess how eager Cities Service stockholders are to sell their shares. **********In Dome's case, Conoco shareholders overwhelmed Dome with stock, showing they were overjoyed with the price offered. But since Dome bid for just 20 percent, it sent back the rest. Mesa, however, has allowed for a strong reception and may purchase more. Moreover, as with Conoco, if Cities Service's stockholders flood Mesa with stock, the company may have major difficulties in fending off Mesa as a suitor. **********Anticipating Mesa's move, Cities Service last Monday acted first by officially offering to purchase 37 million shares of Mesa, or 51 percent control, for $17 a share. By last Friday, Mesa stock stood at $18.625, ahead 37 1/2 cents. Cities Service, the most actively traded issue on the New York Stock Exchange, advanced more than $1, to $38, on a volume of more than a million shares, suggesting that some sort of Mesa offer had been anticipated.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/09/busin.body_text: **********Since last July, a shadowy group of speculators has spent as much as half a billion dollars buying up huge quantities of tin. Their evident attempt to corner the market has since raised the price of this normally plentiful metal more than 25 percent - to as much as $7.60 a pound in London yesterday -while the prices of other commodities have sagged under world recession. **********Commodity traders have been startled by such high prices at this time. Governments, manufacturers and the governors of world exchanges have been investigating the scheme, pooh-poohing it, taking steps to undercut it, asking how much more the speculators can spend and, generally, filling the narrow world of big-time tin with the shrewd and wild gossip that attends every such manipulation. **********On the floor of the London Metal Exchange, where much of the world's tin is traded, the prevailing rumor is that the Malaysian Government lies behind the gigantic purchases, which have amounted so far to 20,000 and perhaps even 30,000 tons of soft, shiny, useful, unglamorous tin. **********Since Malaysia is the world's largest producer of tin, that country, its accusers say, has the most to gain from higher prices.  The recent buying binge, moreover, began right after the world's tinconsuming nations killed a proposal last July to raise tin prices under the cur rent International Tin Agreement. No Threat to U.S. **********The squeeze, which appears to be legal, is not considered threatening to any vital American interest. Roy Markon, chief tin salesman for the General Services Administration in Washington, which stockpiles dozens of strategic materials, said that the Government agency's tin stockpile stands at almost 200,000 tons. It has been estimated, he said, that only 42,000 tons would be needed in a war lasting three years. **********Nor do world supplies appear threatened; tin is mined in Bolivia, Indonesia, Thailand and elsewhere in addition to Malaysia. Although world production has been dropping from a normal 200,000 tons and more, most analysts expect the economic slump to produce an even bigger surplus this year than last. **********Nor has the unexpected price rise yet devastated dealers caught on the wrong side of the market. The main reason, tin traders say, is that the London Metal Exchange last week eased its rules on how much a trader in tin futures would be permitted to lose when he must deliver tin when his contract to do so comes due at the end of this month. **********Still, attempts to corner basic commodities are hardly common.  There seems to be a plot afoot and there are certainly fortunes at stake. Memories of the Hunt brothers' attempt in 1980 to corner silver, and of another group to send up coffee prices have been revived together with the lessons of their failures. The jealousies of nations are also at work - of tin producers, in this case, versus industrialized consumers. Rumors of an OPEC-style tin cartel are being heard more and more. **********''Buyers don't know what to do because traders don't know what to do,'' said an irritated trader in New York City who buys tin on the international market and sells it to manufacturers. **********''It's costing us a hell of a lot of money,'' said a spokesman for United States Steel in Pittsburgh. Calling the squeeze ''galling,'' he estimated that U.S. Steel alone bought 4,000 tons of tin a year, nearly all of it for tinplate. **********''It's probably the Malaysians,'' runs the private opinion of more than one tin expert in the United States Government - although a diplomatic official at the State Department insisted, ''We have not seen anything that constitutes proof'' that the Malaysian Government itself is involved. Malaysia Denies It **********Perhaps the buyers are ''private individuals,'' said George Kam, who heads the Malaysian Tin Bureau in Washington. ''Perhaps Malaysian,'' he said, ''perhaps Indonesian, perhaps some Arabs, perhaps OPEC money -all that jazz. It's certainly not the Malaysian Government that's doing it.'' High officials in Kuala Lumpur, the capital of Malaysia, have likewise denied that their Government is involved. **********One curious rumor, an American official reported, is that someone wants to monetize tin. But why anyone would choose a metal whose uses have been shrinking is an enigma, he said. ''Consumption has been going down, not up,'' a New York tin dealer observed. **********''Also there's a rumor that it's a West Coast American company,'' a broker in London said. Still another theory is that the buyers just want to close the London market. **********''Whoever's doing this is playing with fire,'' warned the State Department official, who, like many others, chose to speak only privately about the issue. **********Mr. Kam predicted: ''Either A, they'll get burned, like the Hunt brothers in silver, or B - I don't know what.'' 'A One-Way Bet' **********Most analysts predict that the scheme will collapse. ''This thing can't stay up there for long,'' said a tin purchaser in industry. But no one is sure. ''Up to a point,'' an American official noted, ''the speculator has a one-way bet.'' **********A key figure in the smelter of speculation is said to be a broker named Marc Rich. Mr. Rich, who made a fortune in oil during the early 1970's and whose Marc Rich & Company operates in Switzerland, New York and elsewhere, reportedly began proposing a world-scale plan to raise tin prices early last year. **********A spokesman for his company in New York said yesterday that it had a policy against discussing business, and that Mr. Rich was ''almost impossible'' to reach. **********According to The Economist, the respected London news weekly, Mr.  Rich also sells tin in the United States for the world's largest tin producer, the Malaysian Mining Company - 55 percent of which is owned by the Malaysian Government. **********Three Malaysian directors of that company are reported to have set up a tin-buying company last June named Maminco, with a capital of $90 million. Where the money came from, or where much more tin-buying money h as com e from, is uncertain. The Economist has reported that the Governmen t-owned Bank Bumiputra of Malasia is intimately involved. PICK UP FIRST AND LAST ADD FIRST AND LAST ADD TIN **********Abdul Rahim Aki, who is head of Maminco and also deputy chairman of the Malaysian Mining Company, has denied that the private company is connected with the Government company. But interlocking directorates and other coincidences have persuaded many tin traders in Penang - Malaysia's spot market for tin - and in London and elsewhere that the Government backs the squeeze, and the Kuala Lumpur stock exchange is said to be investigating. The Heavy Buying Begins **********After last July's failed attempt by tin-producing nations to raise the official floor under the metal, prices on the Penang market shot up more than 20 percent in 10 days, one American official said. Soon afterward, metals dealers in London noticed that traders from Maclaine Watson & Company Ltd. - part of the Drexel Burnham Lambert group - were paying premium prices for three-month tin futures. **********''They started buying massively,'' a London metals trader said.  ''They bought and bought and bought. I don't know how much they bought before that in Penang.'' **********In October a meeting of the International Tin Council, which regulates prices on behalf of most producing and consuming nations, raised the price, but only slightly. Then suddenly, a few weeks later, the buyers changed tactics. **********On Nov. 26 they sold 10,000 tons worth of futures and bought 10,000 tons of metal. The switch depressed futures prices and sharply raised the price of physical tin. It made the metal costlier, in fact, than futures contracts for it - a phenomenon known in London as ''backwardation,'' since the costs of inventories normally keep tin prices the other way around. **********''Backwardation'' had startling results. The speculators were able to sell some of their physical hoard and buy up further contracts for future delivery. As for those who remained in the market in the hope that the speculation would collapse, some must now deliver physical tin on Feb. 25 and 26. Prices are exceptionally high, and much of the tin they will need is controlled by the shadowy buyers. Some Nervous Traders **********The market has thus remained tight and traders jumpy, and some relatively amateur speculators - in a tin market usually played by a few senior traders - are said to be in trouble. **********''The situation,'' one trader in London said, ''has been getting steadily worse.'' ''Forward business,'' added a New York tin buyer, ''has slowed down despite backwardation.'' Citing ''abnormalities'' in the market, the London Metal Exchange announced last week that a ''gentlemen's agreement'' had been reached to insure that the market remained ''orderly.'' **********Traditionally, contractual default on the exchange has been penalized by what one trader called ''horrible'' fines and other sanctions. ''Now,'' the trader said, sounding disappointed, ''if you default on the tin market you're only going to be fined 120 per ton per day.'' 'Sparks Will Fly' **********''I didn't think the London market would ever do that,'' the trader added, saying that quicker-witted dealers had already escaped undamaged. Despite the rule change, he said, ''The sparks will fly'' in London late this month. **********The United States has no domestic market in tin futures, but some Americans are obviously riveted on world developments.  Will the mystery buyers run out of money? It has been noted that they have been selling as well as buying tin, and an American official said that the price has not risen greatly since Jan 22. The price has hovered, in fact, just below the point at which the manager of the International Tin Council's buffer stock must start selling tin to ease the price. This stockpile is small by American standards -only a few thousand tons - but analysts wonder if the buyers would rather not be forced to buy it. **********From another office in Washington, Mr. Markon at the General Services Administration, when asked if he planned to flood the market with the 22,000 tons of tin that Congress has authorized him to sell, said with a laugh, ''I'm a salesman!'' He added, ''We've made $125 million since we started selling'' a year and a half ago. His earnings have come from the sale of more than 8,000 tons of tin, most of it offered since the buying spree began. The tin is now being offered to foreign as well as domestic buyers, a power granted by Congress in December. **********It is against the agency's legislated policy, Mr. Markon said, to buy and sell commodities in a way designed to manip ulate their prices. But h e is empowered to sell off surplus stocks ''in a prudentmanner.'' **********The metal that Mr. Markon has been selling has been stored, he said, in ''unwanted'' depots in Mechanicsburg, Pa., and elsewhere.  Some of the surplus tin is three decades old, and some traders have wondered about its quality. **********Next June 30, the current International Tin Agreement will expire.  The United States has announced that it will not enter the next agreement, and Government officials believe that an agreement without this country and perhaps some other consumers might vitiate the concept of a regulated market in tin. Large American tin buyers, such as the steel companies, believe with the Reagan Administration that a freer market in a plentiful commodity would help keep consumers' prices down. Speculation on Motives **********The mystery buyers may be fighting a long-term drop in prices as well as an immediate one, and the drama's main audience is trying to figure out how the squeeze might possibly succeed. **********''Maybe they're holding on until we're out of this recession,'' said a tin purchaser for a large American steel company. ''Then demand would shoot up and they'd be home free.'' **********United States officials, trying to determine what might happen if the mystery buyers have $1 billion to spend, note a possible chink in America's armor: an inability to sell huge amounts of tin quickly. **********If, they say, the mystery buyer is rich enough to purchase the 22,000 tons of tin that Congress has already authorized, and if the buyer could afford also to buy the International Tin Council's much smaller buffer stock, and if the buyer could also pick up enough of the world's surplus production to keep that source tight - then (assuming some other if's including an economic upturn) the tin king might somehow dispose of his hoard at a tremendous profit before Congress can authorize the sale of more tin. For in the past, officials note, a complexity of interests has kept Congress from acting swiftly on stockpiled commodities. **********In any case, one Government official warned, if recent history repeats itself even huge sales might not lower prices greatly. During the rapid rise in commodity prices around the time of the oil price increases of 1973-74, the General Services Administration sold nearly 44,000 tons of tin over two years.  Yet world tin prices did not collapse. If something similar happens this t ime, the tin-producing countries would make a killing on the heels o f the mystery buyer. **********If present prices drop, and if the next International Tin Agreement fails to raise the floor, tin producers are widely expected to revive an old idea of forming a cartel. **********The prospect elicits skepticism and distaste from tin consumers and American officials.  ''I think the Malaysians are talking a little too strongly now,'' said a major buyer and seller of tin in New York City. ''I don't know who they think they are. Tin is not oil.'' He meant that the commodity was not as irreplaceable as oil. Others, however, have noted that tin production is concentrated in a handful of countries, and that three-quarters of the non-Communist world's tin comes from Malaysia, Indonesia and Thailand -all members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations. **********Critics have also noted also, however, that although tin consumption is rising in both Communist and developing countries, important substitutes have been found in the industrialized West, which uses three-quarters of the world's tin and devotes most of that to tinplate and solder.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/20/world.main_headline: HOW ANDROPOV OILED THE ELECTION MACHINE THAT PROPELLED HIM TO THE TOP
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/20/world.print_headline: NOTES ON THE SOVIET UNION; HOW ANDROPOV OILED THE ELECTION MACHINE THAT PROPELLED HIM TO THE TOP
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/20/world.body_text: **********There was no campaign in any Western sense, no rallies and certainly no opportunity for the average Russian to make his weight felt. But Yuri V. Andropov had an election machine of a kind working for him long before the decision by the Communist Party's Central Committee last week to choose him as the party's new General Secretary. **********In some respects it was a more subtle machine than is customary in Soviet politics. As a former head of the K.G.B., the internal security and intelligence agency, Mr. Andropov probably had its backing, and that alone could be persuasive in a country where there are believed to be at least 100,000 K.G.B. men working on internal security alone. There are signs that he also had the backing of the 3.8-million-member armed forces, and there were large numbers of troops around the Central Committee building when the election occurred. **********But Mr. Andropov's loyalists also worked for him in other ways for months before Leonid I. Brezhnev's death but when it was alreay clear that the end was near. Officials with career links to the former K.G.B. head were to be found in the corners of diplomatic receptions and in quiet conversations over lunch praising his qualities. He was, they implied, the most capable man in the ruling Politburo, a modern man with a zeal for the efficiency that the Soviet Union so patently lacks. **********Little of this could be tested by Westerners, with whom the K.G.B.  chief has had little contact. Most diplomats were stuck with his biography, filled out by the relatively few major speeches he has given over the years and what could be divined from his 15-year stewardship of the K.G.B. The sotto voce assurances of Soviet officials here and in Western capitals thus formed an important influence on how Mr. Andropov was viewed. Account by a K.G.B. Defector **********Western accounts that Mr. Andropov speaks good English, likes whisky, plays tennis and appreciates Western culture were also based on Soviet sources - in this case officials, including a K.G.B. man, who defected to the United States. **********The K.G.B. man, Vladimir Sakharov, surfaced five months ago with his account of Mr. Andropov's penchant for Scotch and cognac, for Jacqueline Susann novels and for Glenn Miller records, asserting that he learned of them through his friendship with Mr. Andropov's son, Igor. **********The accounts may be true. One aspect, Mr. Andropov's English, is open to doubt, since he did not use it in his meeting with Vice President Bush on Monday, and even had written documents in English read to him by an interpreter. **********But the question that intrigues many Westerners here is whether the people who disseminated a more attractive image of the new Soviet party leader were consciously trying to offset his reputation as an unrelenting K.G.B. chief, and doing so in a way that they assumed would filter its way back into the Soviet bureaucracy. Knowing the U.S. **********It may seem fanciful that Western perceptions could influence the choice. But the Soviet leadership remains obsessed with the United States, and a man who seemed best equipped to deal with the adversary -by knowing American culture, among other things - might have an advantage. **********Since such things as a Politburo member's taste in liquor are not chronicled in Pravda, many in the Soviet bureaucracy learn about the top men through Western reporters, either in foreign publications that are a privilege of the elite or through Russian-language versions of such reports that are beamed back into the Soviet Union by Western radio stations. **********Only time will tell what difference, if any, Mr. Andropov's character makes. But the betting among Western diplomats who dealt with Mr. Brezhnev is that Mr. Andropov may prove even tougher. By this, they do not mean that he will favor armament over negotiations, but that in the talks that will inevitably occur he will prove shrewder, certainly more alert, than Mr. Brezhnev was in his declining years. As a new man in a potentially insecure job, he may have no other choice. A Farewell to Brezhnev **********To a Westerner, Mr. Brezhnev was not a sympathetic figure. He had traits that suggested an appealing degree of human weakness, such as his collection of Western sports cars and his habit, as Henry A.  Kissinger noted in his memoirs, of driving around his country retreats at breakneck speeds. He liked hunting boar and was vain about his prowess. He seemed to have a genuine affection for children. **********But he was also a man who presided over a system that was demoralizing to many Soviet citizens, and harshly repressive to the minority who dared to pose an open challenge. The repression was less severe than under Stalin, and nobody had to fear that he would be dragged out and shot. **********Living standards leaped up for millions during the Brezhnev years, and for this many were grateful. Yet Mr. Brezhnev changed nothing that was fundamental in the system, and as years wore by seemed in his stolid refusal to tackle bureaucratic strangulation and corruption in many ways to embody it. **********And yet when he died, and still more when he was buried, there was a mournfulness and a grandeur in the ceremonies that touched many Westerners whose attitude toward the Soviet leader was usually expressed in sardonic jokes. An Impressive Funeral **********Nobody who attended the lying-in-state could fail to be impressed by the scale of it, the mountains of wreaths and the unending line of mourners, the orchestra playing Beethoven, Mozart and Tchaikovsky, the immaculate army guards with their white belts and gleaming bayonets, the red, white and yellow sashes, many of them from party and Government bodies but many others from men and women who had grown up with Mr. Brezhnev, fought with him in the war or served with him in the provinces during his rise up the party ladder. **********Some Russians found the funeral lugubrious and overblown. But even cynics seemed to be touched by the grieving of his family. A woman most Soviet citizens barely glimpsed while Mr. Brezhnev was alive, his widow, Viktoriya, was suddenly exposed to television cameras, pulling away from the men who were Mr. Brezhnev's bodyguards to cast herself across the open coffin, caressing his forehead and hair; their daughter, Galina, reputed to be someone with a taste for diamonds and parties, was there, too, plainly ravaged. **********As a state ceremony, it had everything the Soviet system can muster. The tall, blond young men of the Rota Pochyotnogo Karaula, or Honor Guard Company, the elite unit that guards the mausoleum and performs other ceremonial duties, marched alongside the olive-green gun carriage into Red Square with a precision in their high-stepping gait and in the clockworklike swings of their arms that was daunting to anybody who ever tried to march in time. **********The army band that followed, playing Chopin's ''Funeral March'' over and over in a tempo that seemed sometimes almost to stop, missed not a step nor a note in the two hours that the funeral lasted. **********At the end, there were some slip-ups. The two attendants who slipped past the family and the members of the Politburo to lower the satin-covered coffin into the grave botched the job, with one of the boiler-suited workers lowering one of the sashes suspending the coffin so fast that it dropped several feet. As Mr. Andropov and others moved in to toss handfuls of earth onto the coffin, the workers could be seen on the television screen unceremoniously shoveling earth into the hole. A Quick Transition **********After 18 years it was over very fast. Mr. Brezhnev died at 8:30 A.M. on Wednesday, Nov. 10. He was replaced as party leader on Friday at noon, and by Monday at 12:45 P.M. he was buried. By Tuesday flags were back at full staff and Government offices were returning to their routines. In barely six days an era had ended and another one had begun, its first earmark an impatience to get on with work undone. **********Within hours of the burial Mr. Andropov had met with many foreign leaders, including Vice President Bush and Secretary of State George P. Shultz. The new party leader had held conversations of at least some substance on issues as diverse as nuclear weapons, Afghanistan, the Middle East and Poland. **********He had seemed to visitors to be plainly in command, notwithstanding reports that continued to circulate among some Soviet sources and their Western contacts of a power struggle in the two days that intervened between the death of Mr. Brezhnev and the appointment of Mr. Andropov. **********Only next week, when the Central Committee is expected to meet again and possibly make new appointments to the depleted ranks of the two key top party bodies, the Politburo and the Secretariat of the Central Committee, will it be possible to begin to gauge with any confidence the degree of the new leader's authority. But some things changed right away, as they do in almost any political system that revolves around one principal figure. Andropov's Primacy **********In the funeral procession, the Politburo members, in their snapbrim hats, awkwardly tailored overcoats and unpolished shoes could have been any collection of Soviet leaders over the last 30 years. They were mostly of pensionable age. But Mr. Andropov's primacy could not be mistaken. **********It was not only that he walked in the front row, with a stride that suggested pre-eminence. Not far behind him, and close to him throughout the day, was a man in civilian clothes with a small suitcase. It could have been a medical kit. Or it could have been the Soviet equivalent of the ''black box'' for conducting nuclear war that follows American Presidents wherever they go. The Bush Visit **********Although Vice President Bush was diverted from a visit to Africa on short notice, flying to Moscow on a 10-hour flight from Lagos, Nigeria, he was met at Sheremetyevo Airport by the cavalcade that follows the Vice President wherever he travels abroad. An Air Force C-141 Starlifter had preceded him with two bulletproof Lincoln Continentals and a retinue of Secret Service men who accompanied him even into the Kremlin and waited outside the modest room where he met Mr. Andropov. **********The United States had been asked to limit its funeral party to the bare minimum because of the large number of foreign dignitaries - 32 heads of state, 15 prime ministers, more foreign ministers than anyone could count - and the number was pared to exclude even Mr.  Kissinger, probably Mr. Brezhnev's closest contact among all highranking Western officials. Nonetheless, when the air crews, Secret Service men, chefs and chauffeurs were all counted, the party totaled more than 120. Some had to sleep in American diplomats' residences. **********The logistics were impressive. Mr. Bush's wife, Barbara, was met with a mink coat flown in from Washington to augment her African wardrobe. Mr. Bush had a statement on his meeting with Mr. Andropov ready within 20 minutes of returning to the American Embassy, a previously prepared text into which a single paragraph was dropped after Mr. Bush, Mr. Shultz and top officials huddled in the waiting room of the embassy clinic. The line, referring to the Kremlin talks as ''frank, cordial and substantive,'' was the best hint any reporters got immediately of what went on. **********For some in the embassy, one of the most impressive parts of Mr.  Bush's visit came afterward, when the Vice President moved to the embassy snack bar and spent half an hour circulating among embasy staff members and thanking them for making the visit go smoothly. ''I know how hard you worked,'' Mr. Bush said, recalling that he once headed the American diplomatic mission in China. ''We had Henry Kissinger coming in, and believe me, that was no vacation.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/06/busin.body_text: **********Italy is seeking to recover $6 million that it contends was diverted by Michele Sindona from two of his now-bankrupt Milan banks. Mr. Sindona is serving a 25-year sentence after having been convicted on charges relating to the 1974 failure of the Franklin National Bank in New York. **********The suit, filed last Thursday in United States District Court in Manhattan, named as defendents the Porcelain Company, a Manhattan company formerly called the Interlakes Realty Corporation, and three of its director-officers: Daniel A. Porco, of Manhattan, a longtime Sindona associate; William E. Colesar of Cape Coral, Fla., and Mary Bosiack of Valencia, Pa. **********The liquidators of the Milan banks said that in October 1971, $6 million was diverted by Mr. Sindona from the banks and channeled through Luxembourg to Interlakes Realty. They said $3.3 million was misappropriated from Banca Privata Finanziaria and $2.7 million from Banca Unione, which collapsed in 1974 shortly after they were merged. **********Italy has tried to have Mr. Sindona extradited on the ground that he caused the bankruptcies by stealing a total of about $225 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/16/busin.main_headline: Advertising; Challenges In Selling Car Import
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/16/busin.print_headline: Advertising; Challenges In Selling Car Import
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/16/busin.body_text: **********DURING its 32-year history, Cunningham & Walsh has done the advertising for the British Jaguar for 13 years and for American Motors for six. On Monday, it will begin to advertise three cars and trucks of Mitsubishi Motors of Japan, some of whose automobiles - but totally different lines - are already being sold by Chrysler. **********The selling by Chrysler is one hurdle for the agency. Then there is the fact that Mitsubishi is not such a familiar name. And, let's face it, an imported Japanese car is no novelty. Mitsubishi, in fact, will be the seventh. **********And, then, remember that Chrysler's four models are low-priced, and that the agency has to promote the new, higher-priced - $6,500 to $14,500 - Starion, Cordia and Tredia without denigrating the Chrysler products. **********Lotsa luck. **********''We're introducing a line of cars and trucks at a time when there might be an attitude that there are too many here already,'' said Anthony C. Chevins, undaunted agency president. **********And, while the introductory ad budget is impressive on a per-unit basis, its total figure, of probably near $10 million, is slightly more than a drop in the budget compared with all other automotive advertising spending. In the fourth quarter of last year, according to Leading National Advertisers, imported passenger cars had $81.6 million in advertising in all major media, excluding newspapers and spot radio, while the domestic makers had $138.5 million. **********''We had to be very creative, very exciting and very different,'' Mr. Chevins said, explaining that while all the work had been done in New York under Arthur R. Miranus, executive vice president and creative director, the servicing of the account would be handled by the agency's Los Angeles office. Mitsubishi Motor Sales of America, the advertiser, is based on the West Coast. **********C.& W., which has been the corporate agency for the Mitsubishi parent for two years, working only in print, has prepared a pool of TV commercials of 10-second, 30-second and 60-second length that will be backed by 80 percent of the budget, starting Monday. **********The first two weeks of television will be devoted to a 10-second spot that will seek to establish that Mitsubishi has its own dealer network and to promote the three-diamond logotype that Chrysler may not use outside its showrooms. **********For the next six weeks, 30-second and 60-second spots will show all items in the product line, and 30-second spots will be used to promote individual models and diesel turbo trucks on Oct. 18. **********The Monday start will be in 15 markets. Later the number will grow to 22 markets. Mitsubishi has 22 dealers whose total passenger sales are limited to 30,000 units for the year under a trade agreement between Japan and the United States. **********Mitsubishi has thoroughly researched its markets. It has decided which models its cars will most likely compete against and it knows in which markets its cars sell best. The use of commercials for different models in each market will be guided by that information. **********Two-page, four-color ads will begin to run in October in three news weeklies, and in Sports Illustrated, Road and Track, Sunset, Boating and Flying, Audio, Popular Photography, World Tennis, Stereo Review and Penthouse. **********That last magazine is an interesting choice since there will not be much of an auto advertising clutter problem. Detroit does not use the so-called skin books; neither Toyota or Datsun, which have in the past, have signed up for schedules. The only other Japanese cars in the book will be Isuzu and Subaru. **********The campaign is being aimed at 18-to 54-year-olds, but particularly at the 25-to-34 set.  An unusual facet of the media schedule is that in this age of cable, there is none. The reason is simple enough. The best potential Mitsubishi markets are those least penetrated by cable wires.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/17/busin.main_headline: STIHL: A WORLD WIDE FAMILY BUSINESS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/17/busin.print_headline: STIHL: A WORLD WIDE FAMILY BUSINESS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/17/busin.body_text: **********Andreas Stihl, founder of the world's largest chain saw manufacturer, did not want his daughter to go into the family business. Like most German men of his generation, Mr.  Stihl looked askance at women in business. **********That was in 1969. Judging by the scarcity of women executives in West Germany even today, this attitude seems to persist.  But Mr. Stihl's daughter, Eva Mayr-Stihl, overcame her father's misgivings. After studying languages and economics at Munich University, she joined the marketing department of the family enterprise, and now she is the company's executive vice president and chief financial officer. **********The Stihl Group, with sales of $355 million a year, has 5,300 employees and eight plants around the world. It revolutionized the lumber business, and more recently it helped generate a thriving market for do-it-yourself tools. 'Think About It Carefully' **********''My father was not enthusiastic about my joining the company,'' Mrs. Mayr-Stihl recalled during a recent conversation in her spacious office at Stihl headquarters, situated in a wooded valley just outside this southern German town. ''He told me to think about it carefully - that it wasn't just a pastime.'' **********Her father built the company's first electric chain saw in an old factory building near Stuttgart in 1926. A year later he introduced the gasoline-driven saw, a 140-pound heavyweight model that two men had to handle. The company's success followed, and lumbering was never the same again. **********Stihl saws were popular before World War II. They were shipped to the United States starting in 1930. But the company's really explosive growth came in the postwar years, when Stihl succeeded in reducing the saws' weight while maintaining their power. **********The first wave of steep oil price increases in the mid-1970's, a severe blow for many industrial concerns, caused Stihl's sales to boom because the demand for wood - as an alternative fuel to oil - skyrocketed, increasing the need for chain saws. **********At the same time, the Stihl Group, which until then had specialized in heavyweight saws for professional woodsmen, entered the new market for lightweight ''hobby saws.'' Stihl also expanded overseas. Plants Established Abroad **********In 1973, the year Andreas Stihl died, the company began assembling saws in Brazil, a promising market, to avoid tough import barriers. A year later a plant was opened in Virginia Beach, Va., to serve the United States. And in 1979 two more overseas plants - a chain factory in Switzerland and an assembly plant in Australia -joined the list. **********In 1975 Mrs. Mayr-Stihl took charge of the company's finances during a series of management shifts.  Analysts who follow the Stihl Group say she has skillfully handled its complicated operations. Her problem was to assure stable financing during a period of turbulent growth, with Stihl selling saws in about 130 countries and expanding production in four nations where monetary and credit conditions differed widely. **********While Stihl's American unit faced high interest rates and a volatile dollar, for example, the Brazilian subsidiary had to grapple with triple-digit inflation and a tangle of financing regulations. **********''I like to delegate authority,'' Mrs. Mayr-Stihl said. ''I have two good people - for finances and for cost accounting. And I never felt tempted to gamble on exchange rates. We had to let the overseas units do their financing locally.'' **********In addition to chain saws, which account for 85 percent of production, Stihl also makes brush cutters, hedge trimmers and disk cutters for masonry and metal. Hampered by Recession **********Stihl reported consolidated worldwide sales of $355 million for 1981, up 18.6 percent from the year before. But most of the gain, Mrs. Mayr-Stihl said, came from the surge in the value of the American dollar in relation to the West German mark. **********As a family-owned company, Stihl never announces its earnings, but the impact of the recession on the timber industry reduced last year's net income, Mrs. Mayr-Stihl acknowledged. **********Family members hold several positions at the company. The president is Hans Peter Stihl, Mrs. Mayr-Stihl's brother. Her husband, Robert Mayr, works in the marketing division, and a younger brother, Rudiger Stihl, heads the legal department. **********Mrs. Mayr-Stihl says the status of women in the West German business world is improving. ''It's a problem of generations,'' she declared. ''When I went to school, a third of the students were girls. Today it's about half and half. That will have an effect on careers.'' **********The German language, like English, was unprepared for sexual equality. There is no neutral form of address for women. In America the use of ''Ms.'' has been advocated, but the German approach is different. All women in business here, after they reach a certain maturity, are addressed as ''Frau'' (''Mrs.'') regardless of whether they are married or single. Outlook for the Company **********Despite growing competition, Mrs. Mayr-Stihl is optimistic about the company's future. ''The market shrank last year, but we were able to broaden our share,'' she said. ''And it's not because we're cheap. On the contrary. But we emphasize the product, distribution and service. We never went through mass merchandisers because we view a chain saw as a service-intensive product. We never speculated on quick sales. I think it's paying off.'' **********Most analysts say her optimism seems well founded. They cite Stihl's strong overseas production and distribution system and its reliance on heavy-duty chain saws used by professionals, which are more recession-resistant than light saws used by do-it-yourself hobbyists.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/02/world.main_headline: SUDANESE CALLS FOR ARAB MEETING, INCLUDING EGYPT, ON IRAN-IRAQ WAR
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/02/world.print_headline: SUDANESE CALLS FOR ARAB MEETING, INCLUDING EGYPT, ON IRAN-IRAQ WAR
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/02/world.body_text: **********President Gaafar al-Nimeiry of the Sudan called today for a conference of moderate Arab countries, including Egypt, to try to end the war between Iraq and Iran. **********Mr. Nimeiry made the proposal as he and President Hosni Mubarak met briefly with reporters after a long meeting.  ''We suggested an immediate Arab League meeting to be attended by Egypt,'' said Mr. Nimeiry, whose country was one of the three Arab countries not to break relations with Egypt when it signed the peace treaty with Israel. **********The Sudanese leader said he had had contacts with moderate Arab leaders ''but not the rejection states in order to meet and work collectively for ending'' the Persian Gulf war. **********Mr. Nimeiry said the so-called rejection states - Syria, Libya, Algeria, Southern Yemen and the Palestine Liberation Organization - should not be included in such a meeting ''because they do not work to save the Arab world but have their own objectives.'' **********''They seek to isolate Egypt,'' he said, ''and also to isolate Iraq, which is the second military power in the Arab world.'' Mr. Mubarak indicated that he approved such a meeting but did not say whether he would go himself. Mr. Mubarak has repeatedly said that he welcomed all overtures by Arab countries that broke ties with Egypt to resume relations but not at the expense of the peace treaty with Israel. **********Mr. Mubarak said, ''All the concerned countries should renounce their differences and care only for the public, not personal, interest or else the entire region will be endangered.'' **********Mr. Nimeiry said that in his contacts with Arab leaders, ''Some kings and presidents agreed with me about the importance of such a meeting.'' He did not identify any of them, and he indicated that a gathering had not been arranged yet when he said, ''The sooner we meet the better for all of us in order to stop the dangers facing this region.'' **********In the last few days, the Government-supervised Egyptian press has been full of stories, editorials and columns on recent developments in the gulf war. Many of the commentaries have conveyed a sense of anxiety that recent Iranian gains, might destabilize the Persian Gulf nations. **********Iraq initiated the break in diplomatic ties with Egypt. Despite this, Egypt has for the last year been providing Iraq with arms and ammunition. Some diplomats here feel that the Egyptians are going out of their way to sympathize with the fears of a spread of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's Islamic revolution. There is also a feeling here that an Iranian invasion of Iraq might incite Moslem fundamentalists in Egypt. **********''Yes, there is some fear of flying sparks,'' one Egyptian official said.  Others have indicated that the present turn in the gulf war might provide an opportunity for Egypt to return to a leadership role in the moderate Arab bloc. **********In an interview today in Al Ahram, Egypt's most influential newspaper, Mr. Mubarak said the war imperiled the entire region. He urged the United Nations to try to arrange a cease-fire. **********It is possible that Mr. Nimeiry might be a bridge between Egypt and the moderate Arab bloc. In any event, he was espousing his willingness to try when he told reporters today that had included Egypt in the Arab meeting because ''the past must be forgotten and we must deal with the dangers facing the Arab world.''
