https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/22/world.body_text: **********POLICEMAN IS KILLED IN PARIS BOMB BLAST **********PARIS, Aug. 21 (UPI) - A bomb planted beneath the car of an American diplomat exploded near the Eiffel Tower today, killing a police bomb-disposal specialist who had been trying to dismantle it.  Two other policemen were wounded, one critically. **********''The bomb was an apparatus meant to kill,'' Police Chief Jean Perier said as he surveyed the scene of the explosion, which occurred the instant the bomb was touched by the two-man disposal team. **********The bomb exploded on Avenue de la Bourdonnais near the Eiffel Tower, wrecking the car and shattering windows. American and other diplomats live on the avenue. **********The police and witnesses said one of the explosives specialists was trying to dismantle the bomb at the time of the blast. He was killed instantly, his body hurled 30 feet by the explosion. His partner's legs were torn off. A third policeman was wounded. Caller Blames Fugitive Terrorist **********In a telephone call to Agence France-Presse, a man identifying himself as Jean-Marc Rouillan, the fugitive leader of the terrorist group Direct Action, took responsibility for the bombing. But another caller later denied that the group was involved. **********Direct Action, an anarchist group that has taken responsibility for a rash of bombings against Jewish and Israeli targets, was outlawed Wednesday and 13 of its members were arrested. **********(According to Reuters, the French police said they were taking seriously a call from an extremist group, Lebanese Armed Revolutionary Factions, which in a telephone call to a Paris news organization took responsibility for the attack. The same group said it had been behind the murder in January of Charles Ray, a United States military attache.) France Plagued by Incidents **********For weeks France has been plagued by terrorism involving Corsican terrorists, Direct Action and unidentified gunmen. In the worst of the attacks, four gunmen, believed to be Arabs, killed 6 people and wounded 22 others at a Jewish-style restaurant in the city's old Jewish quarter. **********The police said the bomb that exploded today had been planted in a gutter beneath the car of the United States Embassy commercial counselor, Roderick Grant, but failed to detonate when the 55-yearold diplomat drove to work in the morning. **********A policeman on patrol spotted the package containing the bomb and a bomb disposal team was sent to the scene.  The critically wounded policeman was given emergency treatment in an ambulance parked near the site of the explosion.  A witness said the police sealed off the block after the bomb alert and were preparing to tow away parked vehicles when the explosion occurred. **********''I was about to back up my car at the request of police when a truck from the bomb department arrived,'' he said. ''Everything happened so quickly. Two police bomb experts got out of the little truck and bent over to grab a rope that stuck out from the drain of the gutter near two cars, an Austin and a Simca. One of them cut the rope and the explosion happened.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/25/world.main_headline: Spain's Governing Party Rules Out Early Election
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/25/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Spain's Governing Party Rules Out Early Election
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/25/world.body_text: **********Spain's governing center-right party said today that it did not plan to call for early national elections following the party's defeat in regional elections Sunday. **********The opposition Socialists won a majority in Sunday's elections to chose members of the new regional Parliament in Andalusia. **********Taking 52 percent of the vote, the Socialists, led by Felipe Gonzalez, an Andalusian lawyer, won 66 seats in the 109-member body - Spain's fourth regional legislature. **********Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo's Union of the Democratic Center won only 13 percent of the vote and only 15 seats.  The extreme-right Popular Alliance Party won 17 seats, and 17 percent of the vote. The rest of the seats were divided between the Communist Party and a regional socialist party.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/15/busin.body_text: **********The M-G-M/U.A. Entertainment Company said today that it had completed an agreement to consolidate $525 million in long-term debt with seven major banks. **********The debt agreement came two days after the company announced that David Begelman had left his posts as chairman and chief executive officer of its United Artists subsidiary. The company would not say whether he resigned or was dismissed, and Mr. Begelman has not commented publicly on his departure. **********Ralph W. Kuhns, vice president for entertainment company loans at the Bank of America, said the debt agreement had nothing to do with Mr. Begelman's departure. Bank of America is M-G-M/U.A.'s principal bank lender. The other banks participating in the new agreement are the Chemical Bank, Bankers Trust Company, Bank of New York, Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, Mellon Bank and Marine Midland Bank. **********M-G-M/U.A. has suffered through a series of box-office failures, including most of the 11 films that Mr. Begelman was responsible for as head of United Artists and as president of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer before it acquired United Artists last year. But two films released last month, ''Rocky III'' and ''Poltergeist,'' together have taken in more than $120 million. The company had a loss of $4.4 million in the fiscal third quarter, ended May 31 - its first unprofitable quarter in more than two years. **********Frank Rothman, chairman and chief executive officer of M-G-M/ U.A., said in a statement today that the bank credit would be used for film production and other purposes. **********The loan agreement, stretching over seven years, carries an interest rate one-half percentage point above the prime rate, now at 16 1/2 percent. M-G-M/U.A.'s total debt outstanding is about $670 million, with quarterly interest charges of about $26 million. The restructuring postponed repayment of most of this amount. **********The rest is largely accounted for by a $130 million promissory note at 12 percent held by the Transamerica Corporation. The note was issued last year when M-G-M acquired United Artists from Transamerica for $380 million. **********''This restructuring completes one of my major objectives,'' Mr.  Rothman said. Another goal, he added, is to reduce M-G-M/U.A.'s total debt. **********The company had been dealing with two separate banking groups since the acquisition of United Artists last year. Credit for M-G-M was led by Bank of America and for U.A. by Manufacturers Hanover. **********''It was very difficult to operate what was essentially one company on two separate lines of credit,'' Frank E. Rosenfelt, chairman and chief executive officer of the M-G-M film subsidiary, said in an interview. **********Six banks that had been lenders to United Artists did not take part in the new financing agreement, according to Mr. Kuhns. They are the Chase Manhattan Bank, Security Pacific National Bank, European American Bank, Irving Trust Company, Crocker National Bank and First National Bank of Chicago.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/18/world.main_headline: Deadline Passes in Abduction Of Honduran Chief's Daughter
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/18/world.print_headline: Deadline Passes in Abduction Of Honduran Chief's Daughter
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/18/world.body_text: **********The Guatemalan Government said tonight that it would not negotiate with ''terrorists,'' but did not say whether it would permit publication a manifesto demanded by the kidnappers of the daughter of the president of Honduras. **********The deadline for compliance passed late this evening with no word on the fate of the victim, Judith Xiomara Suazo Estrada, a 33-yearold physician who is a Guatemalan citizen. **********The Honduran Government said it was not negotiating with the abductors.  The kidnappers said the life of Miss Suazo Estrada ''will be in danger'' unless Guatemala agreed to publish a political manifesto in Mexican and Central American newspapers. **********Miss Suazo Estrada, daughter of President Roberto Suazo Cordova of Honduras, was kidnapped by armed men earlier this week as she was leaving a hospital here where she works.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/30/world.main_headline: Canada Gets Control Of Its Constitution
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/30/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Canada Gets Control Of Its Constitution
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/30/world.body_text: **********A bill to give Canada control over its own Constitution passed quietly into law today after Queen Elizabeth gave royal assent to the measure. **********The Canada Act ends Britain's power to amend the Canadian Constitution, more than a century after Canada gained its independence. The act, drafted in Ottawa, has been approved by all the Canadian provinces except Quebec. **********Queen Elizabeth will be in Canada from April 15 to April 18 to hand over the new Constitution.  The royal assent came after two months of debate in Parliament, largely concerned with worries about the rights of Canadian Indians.  Indian groups unsuccessfully fought the new law in British courts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/20/busin.body_text: **********The Northrop Corporation yesterday reported net earnings of $16.5 million for the third quarter, up sixfold from $2.5 million in the 1981 quarter. **********Per-share earnings rose to $1.10 from 17 cents. **********Sales totaled $705.1 million, up 34.5 percent from $524.2 million in the quarter last year. Northrop said the sales growth came from increased volume in its aircraft and electronics segments. **********The company said its spending on the F-5G Tigershark tactical fighter program rose to $47.8 million from $42 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/26/world.main_headline: PEKING TO SET UP PILOT PROGRAM TO REHABILITATE THE HANDICAPPED
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/26/world.print_headline: PEKING TO SET UP PILOT PROGRAM TO REHABILITATE THE HANDICAPPED
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/26/world.body_text: **********The Chinese Government plans to set up a pilot program in modern rehabilitation medicine after a lecture tour here by one of the world's leading specialists. **********Howard Rusk, an 81-year-old American physician who has pioneered rehabilitation techniques now used internationally, just completed a three-week visit in which he explained his philosophy and work to rapt audiences of doctors and medical workers in Peking, Xian, Changsha, Guilin, Hangzhou and Shanghai. **********The tour, made at the invitation of the Chinese Ministry of Public Health, took Dr. Rusk and his colleagues into three medical schools and about 40 hospitals. **********As his trip wound up in Shanghai, Dr. Rusk was informed by the Minister of Public Health that a program would be set up in Peking drawing upon the resources that he had developed at the Institute for Rehabilitation Medicine, which is affiliated with New York University. **********'This Really Has Great Potential' **********Dr. Rusk, who was interviewed by telephone in Shanghai, said that he had encountered ''very sympathetic and eager'' audiences at his lectures on rehabilitation of handicapped patients. **********''This thing has really caught fire over here,'' Dr. Rusk said. ''I have never been as excited about a mission as I have about this one.  This really has great potential.'' **********While the physician could not predict precisely how a modern rehabilitation program would benefit China, he observed that in the United States and some other countries, ''about 20 percent of the population have some type of problems that need some type of rehabilitation. It may be very modest or it may be very complicated.'' If this estimate holds true for China, up to 200 million people could be affected. **********Rehabilitation programs in China have tended to involve sanitariums, which are usually situated at mineral spas or similar therapeutic sites. In cities like Peking, handicapped people get around on hand-cranked tricycles. In the countryside, they are often limited to crutches or remain bedridden. **********''They have a physical therapy program, but the problem we had early on was to sell the philosophy of our program - that you have to treat the whole man,'' Dr. Rusk said. As an example, he told his Chinese audiences, over 80 percent of patients paralyzed from the neck down returned to gainful work after being treated at the Institute of Rehabilitation Medicine in New York. **********''Now they realize that in addition to their passive program, they need a dynamic program,'' Dr. Rusk said.  The World Rehabilitation Fund, over which Dr. Rusk presides, has trained specialists in over 100 countries. In the last 25 years, more than 3,000 physicians and 1,000 brace and limb makers have been trained. Impressed by Chinese Advances **********Dr. Rusk was impressed by some efforts he was introduced to in China. He talked of ''absolutely fascinating'' microsurgery being done in Shanghai to reattach severed limbs and extremities. ''The surgery is very meticulous and takes from eight to as high as 18 hours,'' he said. **********In addition to attending operations at which acupuncture was used as an anasthetic, Dr. Rusk witnessed demonstrations of myoelectric hands developed by biological engineers in Shanghai. ''I think they are the most advanced that I have seen anyplace,'' said Dr. Rusk of the artificial limbs, which are operated by brain waves through a computer. **********Dr. Rusk was invited to China after the World Rehabilitation Fund sponsored a year of training in New York for Wu Xiangguan, a Peking physician. Dr. Wu returned to tell the Minister of Public Health about the program. The mission to China included two other institute physicians, Mathew H.M. Lee and Sung J. Liao, as well as Dr. Rusk's granddaughter, Susan Sutphen, who just graduated from medical school. **********The Chinese have proposed translating Dr. Rusk's basic textbook into Chinese.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/25/world.body_text: **********The Soviet Union rebuked Portugal today for expelling two of its diplomats and said the action would have severe consequences on relations between the two countries. **********A Soviet Embassy statement said Portuguese charges that the mission's press section chie f and a commercial attache had violated their diploma tic status were without any foundation. **********The action naturally gravely prejudiced Soviet-Portuguese realations, a fact that the embassy can only regret, the statement said. **********The expulsion Friday followed a statement this month by Foreign Minister Andre Goncalves Pereira that Portugal was thinking of cutting the size of the Soviet Embassy in Lisbon as part of the West's response to the military crackdown in Poland.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/11/world.main_headline: 6 ISRAELI ARMY OFFICERS CONDEMN TROOP BEHAVIOR IN OCCUPIED AREAS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/11/world.print_headline: 6 ISRAELI ARMY OFFICERS CONDEMN TROOP BEHAVIOR IN OCCUPIED AREAS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/11/world.body_text: **********Six Israeli army officers who have faced rioting Arabs recently in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip held a news conference today to condemn the behavior of soldiers and to denounce a Government policy that they said had placed troops in a dangerous, dehumanizing situation. **********Arabs, they charged, are being regarded as objects, not as human beings. They are being arrested and punished randomly and collectively, regardless of their individual guilt or innocence, the officers said, and they are being victimized by Jewish settlers, who are inflaming the atmosphere and are going unpunished for their violence. **********The six officers, all reservists with combat experience, ranged in rank from lieutenant to major. They said they had been sent into tense situations with only vague orders, ill-trained troops and virtually no riot-control equipment - only their guns - to quell angry demonstrators who attacked them with stones and bottles. **********The news conference was held under the auspices of the Peace Now movement, which opposes the Government's policies in the territories. The movement was started by reserve Army officers several years ago to press for a more flexible Israeli position during peace talks with Egypt. Its last major demonstration, a protest in Tel Aviv March 27, drew as many as 25,000 supporters. 15 Arabs Killed by Gunfire **********Since the clashes in the occupied territories began in mid-March, 15 Arabs, most of them teen-agers, have been killed by soldiers' and settlers' gunfire. Estimates of the number wounded range from about 90, which is the army's figure, to nearly 200 listed by Palestinian journalists. Two Israeli soldiers have died, one from a knife attack on the West Bank and one from a hand grenade thrown in the Gaza Strip. **********The demonstrations were ignited by the dismissal of an elected mayor and town council on the West Bank that had refused to meet with the Israeli civilian administrator of the area, Menachem Milson. Mr.  Milson subsequently ordered the removal of two other elected mayors, and a fourth was dismissed by an army decree. **********The Israeli radio reported today that 25 members of Mr. Milson's senior staff had written a joint letter of protest about his methods and policies, arguing that he had undermined accomplishments made by the previous military government, that he had refused to consult with them and that he had taken actions behind their backs. Difficult Decision for Officers **********The army officers' news conference was probably without precedent in Israel, where the army has always been so integral to the fabric of the society that its strategies have usually commanded a loyalty as firm as loyalty to country. The officers said that it had been difficult for them to take the step, knowing, too, that they were treading at the edge of legality in revealing what they had seen of military activities. **********They had asked to meet with Defense Minister Ariel Sharon to discuss the problems privately, they said, but he refused. They met tonight with the army's chief legal officer to report details of incidents that they witheld from reporters. The army had no comment on the officers' allegations. **********Maj. Yuval Neryah, a tank officer who earned the highest decoration for bravery in the 1973 war, said that while he had fought in extremely hard battles, ''the number of difficult recollections I carry with me from them are modest compared to the feelings I've returned with from a month in reserve duty'' on the West Bank. 'The Soldiers Have No Defenses' **********''A group of soldiers, five, six or eight with a commander, are there, get into a situation where rocks are thrown at them, and the army today has nothing to offer us,'' he said. ''The soldiers have no defenses, and in the end, all we have is our weapons, our rifles.'' **********Despite standing orders to shoot at feet, he said, officers and their men ''panic, get excited, and then it's permitted to do almost anything.'' He contended that the past practice of conducting investigations into every incident of firing had been virtually abandoned. **********As a result, Major Neryah contended, fewer and fewer officers are willing to take the risks of withholding fire, and ''a situation develops where soldiers and officers lose their discipline, in essence become real victims of the Government's policy in the territories.'' **********''This is a process,'' he said, ''that in my estimation is harmful, first and foremost to ourselves, and to our soldiers, who we are trying to educate as we were taught, that you don't hurt unarmed people.'' Use of Untrained Troops Reported **********Rami Avni, an artillery lieutenant, charged that new troops not even finished with basic training and barely able to handle a rifle were sent into the midst of demonstrations. **********''So what do they do?'' the lieutenant said. ''I saw it with my own eyes. They take a platoon of trainees, and I was shocked, and they swoop down on demonstrators like animals tearing at prey. I've never seen such a thing. This is how we're educating our soldiers? Good God, what will become of us?'' **********The officers condemned the collective punishment and random arrests that they said had become routine. For example, if rocks are thrown, Major Neryah said, ''we go into the approximate area from which the rocks were thrown - and it's very difficult to pinpoint from exactly where - and act against civilians, local residents, part of whom, maybe even most of them, don't even know what happened.'' **********If a road to a Jewish settlement is blocked by rocks, and stones are thrown, said Lieut. Shuki Cohen, a tank officer, ''we get there, and we don't encounter the ones who made the provocations. **********''They have light feet and they take off to the hills,'' he went on. ''Are we supposed to spend the day running after them? So we come across the elderly, the women, small children, and they are punished. It's unbelievable. That's the policy.'' Mistreatment of Prisoners Cited **********Lieutenant Avni said that groups of prisoners - ''we don't know who's guilty and who's innocent'' - were brought to army barracks and were made to ''clean out bathrooms, the vehicles, they clean the pots in the kitchen - yes, the prisoners.'' **********Jewish settlers also came in for strong criticisms, especially from Lieutenant Cohen. They ''create an atmosphere and arouse anger, and are influencing events,'' he said. He condemned ''the way they relate to soldiers who are in fact defending them, their way of relating to the local Arabs in a debasing way, calling them 'dirty Arabs' and so forth, and this includes even the smallest children.'' **********''They think they can do anything they wish,'' he continued, ''and they act as they see fit. They run around armed - more than once they have shot out of buses when stones were thrown at them, without any relation to what was happening. I'm told that the settlements in the territories are supposed to in some way serve security interests. But my personal impressions are that the opposite is true.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/24/world.main_headline: British Defense Minister Is Visiting Falklands
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/24/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; British Defense Minister Is Visiting Falklands
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/24/world.body_text: **********The British Defense Secretary, John Nott, today became the first British Cabinet member to visit the Falkland Islands in 149 years of British rule. **********He is on a three-day tour of the islands and their British garrison during which he will attend the reburial of 14 soldiers who died recapturing the islands from Argentina. **********Mr. Nott will visit sites of crucial battles of the war, which began on April 2 and ended with Argentina's surrender on June 14.  Mr. Nott will have talks with the civilian and military authorities on the islands, claimed by Argentina since Britain occupied them in 1833.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/25/world.print_headline: 303 Indian Policemen Ousted After Outbreaks in Two Areas
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/25/world.body_text: **********Indian authorities announced the dismissal today of more than 300 policemen after police unrest last week in Bombay and the northern state of Haryana. **********Haryana's Chief Minister, Bhajan Lal, said that he had ousted 259 policemen, including union leaders, for taking part in demonstrations last week to back demands for better working conditions. **********In Bombay, where five people were killed during police riots, Police Commissioner J.F. Ribeiro said 44 men had been dismissed from the force. They were among a group of 63 policemen freed by a Bombay court yesterday after a judge ruled that they had not been formally presented with the reasons for their detention. Their arrest had helped touch off the Bombay police strike and subsequent riots.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/17/busin.main_headline: Stocks Off in Active Trading; Dow Slides 4.37, to 796.90
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/17/busin.print_headline: Stocks Off in Active Trading; Dow Slides 4.37, to 796.90
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/17/busin.body_text: **********The stock market ended moderately lower yesterday in accelerated trading, with the Dow Jones industrial average sinking below the 800 mark, its key support area. **********The Dow average, which was up almost 5 points early in the session, ended off 4.37 points, to 796.90, as selling pressure increased in the last hour of trading, mostly because of concern over high interest rates. **********Yesterday's Dow close was the lowest since June 10 when it finished at 795.57. Its lowest level this year was 795.47 on March 8.  Turnover on the Big Board yesterday soared to 56.3 million shares from 45 million on Tuesday. A big factor in the increased volume was a block of 5.25 million shares of U.S. Steel that traded at 18 1/4 and was crossed by Salomon Brothers. **********The block was the largest traded in the history of the exchange and was the third largest in dollar value. The previous largest block traded was 5.24 million shares of American Motors at a price of 7 1/4 on March 14, 1972. U.S. Steel's stock closed up 1/4, to 18 3/8, on a turnover of 5.9 million shares and topped the most active list for the second consecutive session. **********In the general market, declining stocks on the New York Stock Exchange outscored issues that rose in price by 820 to 620. Energy Group Is Weakest **********The weakest group was the energy stocks, which have been under pressure because of concern that the crisis in the Middle East will affect their oil supplies and because of the sharp drop in copper futures recently. Several of the oil companies own stakes in copper mining companies. **********''The turbulence in the market witnessed today will prevail over the near-term as interest rates continue to rise,'' commented Charles M. Lewis, vice president of Shearson/ American Express. **********Among the bigger losers in the energy category yesterday, Standard Oil (Ohio) tumbled 2 3/8 points, to 34; Pennzoil was off 2 1/8, to 30 3/4; Standard of California lost 1 7/8, to 30 1/8; Superior Oil, 1 3/4, to 24 7/8, and Union Oil, 1 3/4, to 33 1/2. **********Helene Curtis Industries lost 1 1/2 points and ended at 13. The company said it expects to report a loss for its first quarter ended May 31 because of its heavy advertising expenditures but anticipates a profit for the full year. **********Cummins Engine continued under pressure and fell 2 1/8, to 27. On Tuesday the stock dropped 3 1/8 points after forecasting a possible loss for the second and third quarters. **********The big gainer was Metromedia, which soared 6 points, to 217. On Monday the issue tumbled 7 points after the company signed a definitive agreement to acquire the Radiofone Corporation. **********Prices on the American Stock Exchange also declined, with the market-value index down 2.52, to 251.57. Mark Products, which has laid off about 25 percent of its work force since March because of a lack of demand for its energy equipment, eased 5/8, to 4 1/2. **********In the over-the-counter market, the Nasdaq composite index advanced 0.25, to 171.44. Forward Industries rose 7/8, to 3 1/2 bid, following a favorable report by an analyst concerning its earnings for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, 1983. **********Raypak Inc. was up 1 1/2 points, to 6, after the Micro-Z Corporation said it had agreed to acquire Raypak for an undisclosed amount of stock, cash and notes.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/16/world.main_headline: WALESA, AFTER LONG ISOLATION, WEIGHS FUTURE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/16/world.print_headline: WALESA, AFTER LONG ISOLATION, WEIGHS FUTURE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/16/world.body_text: **********Under a portrait of Pope John Paul II, Lech Walesa moved his arms, rolled his eyes, smoked, gestured, laughed and tossed his stocky body about as he was once again the center of journalistic attention after being locked away in a remote mountain hunting lodge for 11 months. **********''I will remain faithful to the August agreements,'' the leader of the now-outlawed Solidarity trade union told sucessive waves of foreign journalists this morning. He was referring to the 1980 agreement ending the strike at the Lenin Shipyard here that granted independent representation to workers and opened the way for Solidarity's formation. **********''I will be brave but prudent, very prudent,'' he declared.  It was, said those who know him well, vintage Walesa, a bravura performance, by turns politic, blustery, endearing, humorous and, at times, enigmatic in the extreme. **********But in the end, there were few clues to the next moves of the 39-year-old shipyard electrician who had become the symbol of the Polish uprising. As he himself said, the world that he had known had changed drastically under martial law and he had yet to get his bearings. **********''I have been 11 months in complete isolation, and I do not know what the situation is,'' he said. ''I have had plenty of time to think, but I must confront my theories with reality.'' **********Mr. Walesa arrived home late last night to a tumultuous welcome from a crowd of about 1,500 supporters waiting outside the drab, gray apartment block set in a row of identical, featureless buildings on the edge of this Baltic seaport. Over the next few days, sources close to the union said, he is expected to be meeting with his old comrades and advisers. **********Although he did not use the word ''Solidarity'' during his meeting with foreign reporters in his second-floor apartment, Mr. Walesa again and again employed two phrases. The first was that he would be ''faithful to August.'' The second was that while he wanted to work for a national agreement, it would not come ''with me on my knees.'' **********Asked if he still considered himself the leader of Solidarity, he replied: ''I have come from 11 months of isolation. I do not know what is happening.'' **********Mr. Walensa, who looked heavier than when last seen, thanked the journalists and said he wanted to meet with them again. ''Perhaps I will arrange something at Interpress,'' he said, referring to the Government agency where the official spokesman, Jerzy Urban, now presents the martial-law authorities' views each Tuesday. Willing to Meet Jaruzelski **********''What I am going to do, and how I am going to do it, I do not know,'' he said. ''I have to think it over seriously. I remain true to the spirit of the August agreements and I shall never deviate from them. '' **********He said he stood ready to meet with the martial-law ruler, Gen.  Wojciech Jaruzelski.  Speaking of the letter he sent General Jaruzelski last week, he said: **********''This is authentic. I have written this letter, and it has to be read very slowly, although it took me only a minute to write it. All that there is is necessary, and all of it has its sense. You also have to remember the date.'' **********He did not elaborate. The letter was written on Monday, Nov. 8, the day the Roman Catholic Primate, Archbishop Jozef Glemp, met with General Jaruzelski and a message was issued saying that the Pope could visit Poland next June. It was also two days before the date for a strike called by the underground Solidarity leadership, which failed to gain much support in the face of overwhelming Government power. **********Explaining his whereabouts in the more than 36 hours that elapsed between the announcement of his release and his arrival here, he said he had been taken on Saturday to Otwock, a Government house near Warsaw, where he stayed overnight, and then had been driven to Gdansk late Sunday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/28/world.main_headline: ONCE AGAIN A MEXICAN LEADER TILTS AT CORRUPTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/28/world.print_headline: ONCE AGAIN A MEXICAN LEADER TILTS AT CORRUPTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/28/world.body_text: **********Six years ago, while campaigning for office, President Jose Lopez Portillo described corruption as ''a cancer'' eating away at Mexican society and he renewed the pledge of many of his predecessors to attack the problem. **********But while some measures were taken and several former ministers were jailed for accepting illegal kickbacks, most businessmen and politicians now concede that the flood of petrodollars and the economic boom of recent years have enabled corruption to flourish as never before. **********Therefore when Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado tackled the issue at the start of his campaign for the presidential elections in July, he stirred little interest. As the candidate of the party that has ruled Mexico for the past 53 years, he was required to offer new promises that might revive the population's faith in the system, but public skepticism ran deep. **********Since then, however, Mr. de la Madrid has gone much further than form required, doggedly pursuing the topic and converting ''moral renovation'' into a central plank of his entire electoral platform.  And, in doing so, he has not only sent shudders of concern through a political system in which enrichment in office has become a norm, but he has also raised expectations that many Mexicans feel will be impossible to satisfy. 'A Clamor of the People' **********''Our actions will demonstrate that we're serious,'' Mr. de la Madrid said in a recent interview with a Mexican monthly, Contenido, ''and reality will defeat incredulity or irresponsibility. My words have not fallen into a vacuum. Moral renovation constitutes a veritable clamor of the people.'' **********Yet even he recognized that corruption is ''a profound cultural problem that permeates to the very root of Mexican culture'' and he stressed that the phenomenon was common to the private sector, the labor movement, the educational system and news organizations as well as to the Government. **********Most Mexicans would concede that corruption is an accepted part of daily life here, affecting them either as victims or beneficiaries.  But most would also argue that corruption has grown dramatically over the past decade, above all in the Government. ''It doesn't matter if they steal a bit,'' said a taxi driver who must pay daily bribes, or ''mordidas,'' to policemen for real or imaginary traffic violations, ''but they shouldn't steal so much.'' **********The ordinary Mexican's most frequent contact with corruption comes in his dealings with the police and with lower-level civil servants, who frequently demand a gratuity to complete the simplest bureaucratic procedure. But businessmen also complain that ''kickbacks'' are routinely paid on almost every contract granted by the Government. Corruption of Ministers Rumored **********Part of the disillusionment with the Lopez Portillo administration appears to stem from a widespread perception that it has failed to live up to its promise to control corruption. And while major scandals involving officials usually erupt only after they leave their posts, the rumor mill has long since identified key ministers and heads of state enterprises who are believed to have made vast fortunes over the past five years. **********A common practice has been for senior officials to own shares in companies that are major Government contractors, above all in public works or the oil industry. Frequently, though, extravagant displays of wealth - such as acquisition of a series of new homes in Mexico City, seaside resorts and the United States - are put down to ''inexplicable enrichment.'' **********A key role in Mexican society is also played by ''influence,'' the power and immunity enjoyed by friends and relatives of key officials. Mr. Lopez Portillo himself has been criticized for appointing his son, a sister and several cousins to important positions. And while the President won applause last year when he rejected the gift of a $2.4 million ranch that political friends had bought for his retirement, many Mexicans have been upset to discover that he is building a five-home complex for his family on a huge piece of land on the outskirts of the capital. **********At the same time, many Mexicans who complain about ''public immorality'' also benefit from the tradition of corruption. In the private sector, for example, tax evasion is widespread, while the payment of a bribe is somehow considered less venal than receipt of a bribe. Labor leaders are also frequently paid off by management to settle wage disputes, while most journalists receive regular payments from the Government that they regard as part of their salaries. Legal Loopholes a Target **********In face of this deeply entrenched custom, Mr. de la Madrid's strategy of ''moral renovation'' is therefore not one of wielding, in his words, ''an authoritarian garrote.'' Nor is it ''a vengeful program aimed at sowing fear and bitterness in the nation.'' Rather, he said, its objective is for ''public immorality to stop being a central problem of Mexico and the Mexicans.'' **********Direct sanctions, he believes, are less important than eliminating many of the administrative and legal loopholes and much of the excessive bureaucracy that encourage corruption. ''Regulations and bureaucracy at times make unnecessary, impractical, impossible and even absurd demands,'' he noted. ''I think we should eliminate the power of the authorities to make arbitrary decisions affecting the legitimate interests of individuals.'' **********But he also stressed the importance of modifying attitudes toward corruption through the educational system and the communications media. And while the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party still pays $70 a day to local reporters covering Mr. de la Madrid's campaign, he has pledged to eliminate the practice of having journalists on government payrolls. **********In his interview with Contenido's editor, Armando Ayala Anguiano, a longtime campaigner against corruption, Mr. de la Madrid noted that it was ''unacceptable'' for officials to receive presents. Asked pointedly whether he would appoint relatives to government posts, he stressed that family relationships or friendships would not affect his decisions. **********In a separate interview, Mr. de la Madrid disclosed plans to announce the salaries received by top officials, including the President, and to insist on public statements of assets when entering and leaving office. He also pledged to set an example. ''I can tell you quite frankly that I own the house I live in, the house I lived in when I got married where my mother now lives and a country house near Cuautla,'' he said. ''But I have no investment in shares or businesses whatsoever. I think that private business interests are totally incompatible with public service.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/20/world.body_text: **********India, the host country for the next summit meeting of the nations describing themselves as nonaligned, has announced that it is not inviting the Vietnamese-backed regime in Cambodia to the conference. **********The recently formed Cambodia coalition in exile, led by Prince Norodom Sihanouk, has also been excluded from the talks, due to take place in March. **********The moves are apparently aimed at containing divisions between supporters and critics of the Soviet Union.  Vietnam, Cuba and Afghanistan, among other Soviet allies, support Heng Samrin, who was placed in power by the Vietnamese in January 1979. India, the only nation outside the Soviet bloc to have extended full recognition to the Cambodian regime, has been criticized for its action by the non-Communist governments of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations. **********It is believed here that the conference will provide the Government of Indira Gandhi an opportunity to refurbish its nonaligned image, which was damaged after New Delhi recognized the Heng Samrin regime in Cambodia and failed to speak out strongly against the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan. Test for Mrs. Gandhi's Prestige **********The New Delhi conference is also perceived as a major test for Mrs. Gandhi's prestige and tact as a leader of the third world. Mrs.  Gandhi has recently been trying to change her pro-Soviet image by overtures to the West, especially to the United States, and by shoring up India's nonaligned position. **********India is due to take over as the head of the nonaligned movement after the March conference. Cuba has been head of the organization since the last summit meeting, which took place in 1979 in Havana. A meeting had been planned for Baghdad this fall, but the Iraqi Government, involved in a war with Iran, had to withdraw its invitation. **********The movement was founded in the 1950's by Jawaharlal Nehru, Mrs.  Gandhi's father; Egypt's Abdel Gamal Nasser, and Marshal Tito of Yugoslavia. It was originally meant to embrace those newly independent nations that wanted to stay out of the spheres of influence of the United States and the Soviet Union. Its membership amounts to 96 countries.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/08/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS CONDITIONS; DOLLAR HOLDS ITS OWN
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/08/busin.body_text: **********In spite of welcome declines in key short-term interest rates in the last four to six weeks, the dollar, which many analysts had expected to fall in value rather substantially in the wake of such reductions, has not done so. **********To be sure, the recent slide in rates has engendered a slight drop in the value of dollar, about 3 percent since early July, according to economists at Morgan Guaranty Trust Company. **********But in the face of cuts of more than 3 percentage points in rates like Federal funds and three-month Eurodollar certificates of deposit, some analysts are surprised that the dollar has not fallen further. **********''The dollar should have come down more than it has,'' said David Ernst, an economist at Evans Economics. ''But the basic factor is that the markets aren't sure domestic interest rates are going to stay down for very long; that is inhibiting the impulse to sell dollars.'' **********There are other explanations behind the dollar's soft landing.  Rates in key foreign countries have eased as United States rates have declined. As a result, while real interest rate differentials between American and foreign rates have narrowed slightly, they still favor the dollar. **********The largest declines abroad have come in Switzerland, Canada, France and Britain, where short-term rates are down by 1 to 2 percentage points from levels in late June or early July. By comparison, interest rates in West Germany and Japan have remained relatively stable. **********Another factor, in Mr. Ernst's view, is political. ''The crisis in Lebanon has kept the value of the dollar higher than it might otherwise have been,'' he said. ''The worse the situation there becomes, the less attractive the European currencies are.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/21/busin.body_text: **********Trans World Airlines announced that it had reached an agreement to sell 28 of its 707-131B aircraft for $28 million to the Boeing Military Airplane Company. **********Boeing will use the planes' engines and other systems to extend the life and efficiency of the military version of the 707 in fulfilling a contract with the Air Force. Because of the rise in fuel prices and the new 767 planes being built by Boeing, the plane is no longer considered efficient on commercial routes.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/14/busin.body_text: **********The Dow Jones industrial average rose 5.52 points, to 1,024.28 yesterday, after having fallen 38 points in the three previous sessions. Although issues that declined in price slightly outnumbered advancing stocks, investor sentiment was aided by a slight recovery in video game stocks. **********Turnover contracted to 63.1 million shares from Friday's 86.4 million.  Warner Communications, trading more than 2.4 million shares as the volume leader, rose 1 1/2, to 36 1/4. Last week, it plummeted 19 5/8 points after the company said that fourth-quarter profits would run below expectations, reflecting sales of its video game cartridges and coin-operated arcade games. In February, Warner's shares traded at a record price of 63 1/4 - up from 1 7/8 eight years earlier. **********Mattel, another major producer of video games, gained 1 5/8, to 18 3/8. Mattel tumbled 7 1/4 points on Friday, following the company's statement that it would show a loss for the final quarter. **********The chilling news from two of Wall Street's recent favorites had the effect of casting a pall upon the entire market late last week. Blue Chips Move Up **********However, a number of prominent blue chips - the stocks that have been favorites of institutional investors since midsummer - moved higher. Among components of the Dow industrials, there were gains of more than a point each in International Business Machines and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. **********Chrysler gained 1/4, to 14 1/2, after striking employees of the automobile maker in Canada approved a new contract.  Federal Express dropped 3 points, to 69 3/4. The company said it expects profits for the recently ended November quarter to at least equal, or exceed slightly, the profits a year earlier of 95 cents a share. Federal Express, which does not pay a cash dividend, has displayed strong earnings growth in recent years. **********Payless Cashways fell 2 1/2, to 43 1/2, after disclosing plans for a public offering of 700,000 shares. Proceeds will be used mainly for a proposed acquisition. **********Precious-metal stocks, reflecting higher prices for gold bullion, were strong. ASA Ltd. rose 2 5/8, to 65 5/8.  Brokerage issues generally moved ahead. Merrill Lynch gained 3/8, to 63. Meanwhile, a call option to buy Merrill's stock at a set price of 30 until the contract expires next month rose a point, to 33 5/8.  In early August, when the stock was trading at 21 1/4, this option sold at 7/8. **********U.S. Home fell 2 1/4, to 22 7/8. The decline was attributed partly to uncertainty about November's new-order rate for the home builder.  Shaklee Corporation dropped 2 3/4, to 37, in response to reports of a Federal Trade Commission investigation of a possible violation of a 1974 consent order. **********In over-the-counter trading, Reeves Communications plummeted 8 1/4 points, to 29 1/2. The company said it expects earnings for the current quarter and for the fiscal year ending next June 30 to run about the same as results a year earlier. The Nasdaq composite index dipped 0.52, to 233.33. **********On the American Stock Exchange, Bowne & Company dropped 1 1/8, to 16 1/4, responding to a published report that the company faces increased competition in the financial printing field. The Amex market value index gained 0.93, to 335.30.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/18/world.main_headline: London Fights Printing Of Book on Espionage
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/18/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; London Fights Printing Of Book on Espionage
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/18/world.body_text: **********The British Government's chief law officer said tonight that he had won a High Court order to stop publication of a new book about M.I.5, the country's intelligence agency. **********The Attorney General, Sir Michael Havers, declined to give the reasons for his action against the book, ''A Matter of Trust: M.I.5's Operations 1945-72,'' written by Nigel West. **********''I cannot comment because the matter is now before the court,'' Sir Michael said in a press statement. ''It is an interim injunction. A full hearing will decide whether or not it will be continued.'' **********Mr. West previously wrote a book on British security services from 1909 to 1945. He said then that he had helped to expose part of a spy network that included Anthony Blunt, a former art adviser to Queen Elizabeth who was recruited at Cambridge University to spy for Moscow. **********M.I.5 and past and present ministers have been embarrassed by a series of spy scandals and revelations since World War II.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/26/busin.body_text: **********LONG ago in the old country, in the village of Conglomera, an e ligible young man from the wealthy Shmendrix family approached the m atchmaker with a strangely honest request. **********''I want to marry Marrietta,'' Shmendrix announced. ''We're both rich and I'm lonely.'' The matchmaker put down her dress-for-success book and sighed.  ''Marrietta is a naughty girl,'' she said. ''She wants to stay a spinster.'' **********''This is a firm offer,'' Shmendrix said. ''Do your job.'' The matchmaker went to Marrietta. ''Have I got a match for you!  Handsome young Shmendrix, tenderly offering $48 a share for your hand.'' **********''I don't like him,'' the nubile maiden decided immediately. ''He's bossy. He wouldn't let me run my own house.'' ''He won't take no for an answer,'' the matchmaker pressed. ''He's already gone to your family. They'll make you do it. Be nice, go along.'' The matchmaker saw that the girl was seething, but what could the tempting target of takeover do? **********When the matchmaker got back to Shmendrix, the young man was in a frenzy. ''Fool!'' he cried, ''Marrietta went around behind your back and took a marriage contract to all my relatives. She'll marry me, all right, but I'll be henpecked and she'll be master of the house.'' **********The matchmaker blanched. ''Nobody has ever done such a thing to King Solomon brothers.'' Her eyes narrowed. ''I see in this deed the hand of Harry Grayshark.'' **********Now it was Shmendrix's turn to turn pale. ''Grayshark the gobbler, uniter of all technologies?'' The young man gulped. ''Matchmaker, the last time 'Jaws' Grayshark walked into a house, he threw the management out into a 10-foot snowdrift without earmuffs. And that was a friendly takeover.'' **********The matchmaker went directly to Grayshark. ''How could you do this thing? You're forcing the Shmendrix into having a unity day for all the cousins, they're taking ads, their tender is getting tough.  Young Shmendrix just voted himself a golden handshake in case he has to retire in a hurry. What's the big idea?'' **********''They were on my swallow list,'' Grayshark explained. He took out an envelope and made some notes on the back. ''But now I'm not so sure. With all the expenses of borrowing to buy each other out, the new family's debt might be half their total capital, and the interest may depress the amount the both of them could earn together. Let 'em cut each other up, and maybe I'll pick up the pieces.'' **********Back at Marrietta's house, the matchmaker pleaded in vain for the girl to forget the counterattack. ''With Shmendrix, you could maybe get along in time - but if you sell your soul to Grayshark, you'll both be out in the cold. And if you spend all this time in court before the wedding, can you imagine what the divorce will be like?'' **********Marrietta was adamant: ''Uncle Harry will help keep your young man in his place,'' adding darkly, ''And who is that blonde woman Shmendrix brings with him to meetings?'' THE matchmaker threw up her hands. When she returned to the S hmendrix house, she heard sounds of great festivity, with rice beingt hrown and cans tied on cars. **********''Welcome to the wedding!'' said young Shmendrix, ''I just married Alice Allied, who despises Harry Grayshark for preferring Haig & Haig Scotch to Hennessy Cognac. This is a real love match, perks all around, and it will enable me to keep Marrietta as a concubine and to do housework, no heavy lifting. We'll sell off a couple of Marrietta's fur coats to lower the debt. A happy ending.'' **********The matchmaker wasn't so sure. She hurried to the village pundit, a heavily bearded pauper wise in the ways of family finances.  ''I'm a matchmaker, not an antitrust lawyer, but somehow I get the feeling it's not right for everybody to be in everybody else's pocket this way,'' the matchmaker said. ''It's all getting out of hand. Do the business schools offer ethical guidance on this?'' **********''Wharton started to, but just merged with Stanford to avert a takeover by Harvard,'' reported the wise man.  ''My problem is a lack of heroes,'' explained the matchmaker. ''In the old days, the executive who built a better mousetrap, or created a new need and supplied it, or produced a product that took the world by storm - he was the hero, and an easy match to make.'' **********''And now?'' asked the wise man, moving to his telescope.  ''Today's business heroes are the assemblers of conglomerates who turn out puddings without themes,'' said the distraught matchmaker.  ''The purpose of matches should be to introduce real efficiencies, or to create little R.& D. children to go out and take care of the family later. Instead, the heroes you read about on the business pages are the men who wind up sitting on the largest pile of assets, with the most former cabinet officers on their boards of directors. I tell you, making matches for nonmanaging agglomerators is no fun.'' **********The wise man pressed his eye to the glass and took the long view.  ''Matchmaker, remember that hard times beget cannibalism, but good times ahead will churn up entrepreneurs. Families will soon be asking of all these brides and grooms, 'Are you doing this to profit the family, or sit atop an empire?' '' **********The matchmaker rolled her eyes and waited for some wisdom she could put to practical use in gaining perspective.  Suddenly the wise man tensed, turned from the telescope, and punched the printout button. ''Here it is,'' he said, tearing the sheet from the computer, ''the wisdom of the ages, from a poem of a hundred years ago, with the long view on all this financial Pacmania.'' **********The sheet read: Great fleas have litle fleas Upon their backs to bite 'em, And little fleas have lesser fleas, And so ad infinitum; And all the great fleas themselves In turn have greater fleas to go on, While these again have greater still, And greater still, And so on. **********---------------------------------------------------------------------  William Safire's column appears regularly on the Op-Ed page of The New York Times.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/15/world.body_text: **********BACK TO BASICS The Traditionalist Movement That Is Sweeping Grass-Roots America.  By Burton Yale Pines.  348 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $13.50. By ALAN BRINKLEY **********IN the heady days of the 1950's and the early 1960's, when American liberalism seemed securely enthroned, it was easy to dismiss the far right as the fading and obsolete remnant of a vanished past.  Its most prominent organizations, after all, were usually clumsy and embarrassing (witness the John Birch Society). Its leading publications were at best elegantly superficial (National Review) and at worst cranky and intemperate (Human Events). And its carping obsession with Communism was ill advised and politically crippling, for the liberals themselves had effectively pre-empted that issue. It did not seem presumptuous, therefore, when respected critics began to write smugly of the disappearance of a serious right, to celebrate what the historian Eric Goldman once called ''the arrival of a broad consensus in the thinking of Americans about the public issues of the day.'' **********But reports of the death of the American right were, as we now know, premature. Even 20 years ago conservatism remained a far more significant force than most liberals were willing to admit. And as reformers moved confidently to expand and transform the liberal state in the 1960's, the strength of the opposition grew rapidly. By the early 1970's the right had already --------------------------------------------------------------------- **********Alan Brinkley is associate professor of history at Harvard and the author of ''Voices of Protest: Huey Long, Father Coughlin, and the Great Depression.'' made a substantial comeback. And by 1980 with liberalism in almost total disarray, it was ready to seize at least partial control of the Government. **********The nature and significance of this right-wing revival is the subject of Burton Yale Pines's new book, an enthusiastic, even gloating, account of how the forces of ''traditionalism'' have swept through grass-roots America to transform the nation's politics. **********Since Mr. Pines spent most of a year traveling around the United States gathering material for his book, it is perhaps not surprising that the best parts of the book are not those that analyze the significance of the right-wing resurgence but those that describe how it has happened. And on that subject, he is often very good. The key to the conservative renaissance, he argues, is not so much the right's rising resentment as its ability to use modern political techniques to make that resentment felt. Corporate efforts to promote ''procapitalist'' values, parental attempts to purge progressive innovations from the schools and return to ''basics,'' the campaign by women to stop the Equal Rights Amendment and ''strengthen the family,'' the crusade by evangelicals to restore religious piety and fight the dreaded spread of ''secular humanism'' - all have relied on complex and sophisticated methods of organization, fund raising and promotion. Conservatives have, in other words, fused their fervent commitments with practical and effective efforts to increase their political influence - with what long-range results we can only guess. **********On the other hand, it is difficult to take seriously Mr. Pines's portrayal of the American left, which he caricatures in much the same crude way that liberals used to caricature the right. Liberalism has been, he suggests, a wild bacchanalian spree, marked by nihilism, hedonism and godlessness. Led by a powerful and conspiratorial ''new class'' of journalists, academics and other influence peddlers, liberals have worked to de- Continued on Page 26  stroy the foundations of American society - ''restricting freedom in the marketplace ... loosening social restraints,'' eroding the nation's defenses, all, it seems, out of sheer perversity. **********At the same time, Mr. Pines's picture of the right is offered in an almost embarrassingly obsequious tone. With breathless hyperbole, the former Time magazine writer (he now works at the Heritage Foundation, a conservative think tank) portrays the American right as rising up in moral anger to cast the traducers from their midst: ''Across the nation, in numbers beyond tallying, Americans have been mobilizing - some for more than a decade, others for just a few years - against liberalism and in support of traditional values.'' Before them the radicals and nihilists of the left have scattered in confused disarray. The nation is once again walking tall. (Lest anyone think otherwise, Mr. Pines includes numbing collections of statistics and polling data to support his claims.) **********HIS effort to define the broad common ground that will, he believes, unite the various right-wing constituencies into a strong and enduring coalition is particularly unconvincing. There are, he concedes, many distinct factions within conservative ranks, factions that often seem as bent on fighting each other as on combating the common enemy. But all such groups, Mr. Pines maintains, share certain basic values and commitments, even if they have not yet realized it.  All are defenders of what he calls ''traditionalism,'' the Burkean belief that ''history and tradition are better able than man to fashion man's institutions and norms, that reason has its limits and that today's generation has the solemn responsibility to convey unharmed to its heirs what it has inherited from its ancestors.'' Traditionalism, he suggests, is a unitary concept, embracing a single, coherent ideology. **********YET as his own reporting makes clear, even those who speak most fervently of their heritage often differ fundamentally over what that heritage is. To the ''Old Right'' - the defenders of corporate America and its interests -tradition dictates a firm commitment to capitalism and unfettered economic growth. To the ''New Right'' - a vaguely populist group more interested in cultural and moral issues -tradition means the defense of local values and institutions against the threats of centralized power, a concern that has produced animosity toward the business and financial establishment as often as it has toward the Government. And to the ''neoconservatives'' - intellectuals whose conversion to the right is of relatively recent vintage - the relevant tradition is that of the liberal Arcadia of midcentury, when basic decisions about the nation's course were entrusted to an educated, respected and supremely confident elite. To defenders of this establishment tradition, Jerry Falwell and Phyllis Schlafly are scarcely more appealing than Jerry Rubin and Bobby Seale. **********All conservative groups share a veneration of the nation's heritage. (So, for that matter, do most liberals.) All look askance at the recent performance of the Federal Government. (Many liberals do that too.) But Mr. Pines fails to explain how these very different concepts of what tradition is and what the Government should do to restore it are to be reconciled to produce a lasting ''traditionalist'' majority. **********Whatever one thinks of Mr. Pines's analytical efforts, however, it will be difficult to refute his broader conclusion. ''Liberalism,'' he claims, ''indeed seems like a dynasty fast losing the Mandate of Heaven. On the ascendancy is traditionalism, challenging liberalism on every major front and ending the liberal monopoly of the agendasetting process. On every critical public policy matter, liberals now must share the platform with traditionalists.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/27/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Nabisco to Sell Unit In $155 Million Deal
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/27/busin.body_text: **********Nabisco Brands Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to sell Julius Wile Sons & Company, its wine and spirits operation, to Whitbread & Company P.L.C., a London-based alcoholic beverage concern, for about $155 million. **********The move, analysts said, is part of Nabisco's plan to focus on its packaged foods business, where it is a market leader in cookies and crackers, and to divest itself of unrelated and typically slowergrowth operations. **********Since the merger of Nabisco and Standard Brands in July 1981, the company has divested itself of several units, including Chase & Sanborn, its coffee subsidiary, and it has leased its two corn wet milling plants. It is also trying to sell its pharmaceutical arm. **********''The company is in the process of divesting itself of a host of relatively low-return businesses, a process that should be completed by the end of 1982,'' Alan S. Greditor, food industry analyst with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., said. **********William Maguire, who follows Nabisco for Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, said that Nabisco's decision to sell Julius Wile made sense because ''the whole spirits industry is very slow growth for a long time, probably forever.'' **********Nabisco does not disclose its subsidiaries' revenues, but industry sources estimated Julius Wile's sales at $250 million last year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/22/busin.main_headline: Real Estate; Business Rent Curb Is Sought
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/22/busin.print_headline: Real Estate; Business Rent Curb Is Sought
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/22/busin.body_text: **********SMALL businesses throughout the city are threatened with large - and unaffordable - rent increases as their leases expire, according to city and state legislators and spokesmen for trade associations and merchant groups. As a result, these groups are calling for commercial rent controls. **********Faye Leeper and Santa Taylor, officers of two neighborhood merchant groups on the Upper West Side, which has experienced a residential and commercial revitalization in recent years, said that rent increases of 200 percent to 500 percent were now commonplace in the area. **********Emanuel Fuchs, chairman of the 400-member Retail Jewelers of Greater New York and chairman of the Small Business Task Force, a private group, said the increases were forcing many merchants to ''drain their already limited resources, and forcing others to go out of business completely.'' **********And William Seitz, president of the Neighborhood Cleaners Association, which has 1,000 members in New York City, said his group had received complaints of ''catastrophic'' rent increases from all over the city. **********''There's no question that landlords are entitled to increases,'' he said. ''But those increases should have some relationship to reasonableness and reality.'' **********Commercial rent regulation is the way to mitigate the problem, according to these and other merchants and several city and state legislators. **********A member of the City Council, Ruth Messinger, has introduced a bill that would limit rent increases on commercial establishments under 10,000 square feet to no more than 12 percent a year. The bill, first introduced two years ago, would apply to commercial spaces used for light manufacturing as well as for stores and offices. **********Under its provisions, a three-member Small Business and Commercial Protection Board, appointed by the Mayor and approved by the Council, would determine the precise amount of the yearly increase. The board would also rule on whether landlords deserved hardship exemptions and would penalize landlords who charged excessive rents. **********State Senator Franz S. Leichter and Assemblyman Richard N.  Gottfried, both of Manhattan, have introduced legislation in Albany that would authorize the City Council to establish a commercial rent regulation system. **********The measures, which even the supporters concede have no chance of passage this year, are vigorously opposed by the Koch administration and the real estate industry. **********''There is nothing the real estate industry sees more bright red about than this,'' said Richard Rosan, president of the Real Estate Board of Greater New York. ''I can't convey the depth of sentiment against it. Commercial rent control would be an absurdity. It would be absolutely disastrous and impossible to administer.'' **********Robert A. Kandel, commissioner of the city's Office of Economic Development, was more circumspect but equally opposed to the idea.  ''We believe the market ought to be allowed to function freely,'' he said. ''Certain areas are now hot. Revitalization is taking place. Property values are going up. Community life is energized, and city tax revenues are increased. This has great benefit to the neighborhood and to the entire city. Commercial rent control would be a disincentive to revitalization.'' **********Mr. Rosan noted that many expiring leases were negotiated 10 and 15 years ago. Thus the rents had long since declined in real value, he added, and only now are being raised to what the market will bear. **********Both men said they realized that some shop owners might be forced to move under the push of neighborhood revitalization. But they noted that when upgrading occurred in East Side areas many shops did not leave their neighborhoods but moved off the main thoroughfares to side streets with cheaper rents. **********Supporters of the legislation, like Mr. Fuchs of the retail jewelers group, contend, however, that the size of the increases will indeed drive out many small stores. **********He said that small merchants often could not move without great financial harm because they were dependent on a clientele that would not follow them. The problem is exacerbated, he added, because most of the viable commercial strips in the city are experiencing huge rent increases. **********However, George Sternlieb, director of the Rutgers University Center for Urban Studies, said he believed that commercial rent regulation was not necessary because the ''harsh reality of the retail market's condition'' would keep rents down. **********Mr. Sternlieb said that landlords of small businesses in most city neighborhoods who were seeking high rents were making a mistake.  ''The high visibility spots like Columbus Avenue are an old New York story,'' he said, ''but they aren't the whole of New York City.  There is a squeeze. There will be retailers who go to the wall. But there will also be landlords looking at empty stores.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/11/world.print_headline: BRAZILIAN SET FOR TICKLISH VISIT TO U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/11/world.body_text: **********The President of Brazil, Joao Baptista Figueiredo, begins a state visit to the United States on Tuesday that, in the words of a newspaper here, has suddenly become ''Malvinized.'' **********The crisis in the Falkland Islands, which Latin American nations, following the Argentine lead, call the Malvinas, has already prompted the Brazilians to cancel three social occasions associated with the trip and to reduce by a day President Figueiredo's stay in the country. **********Brazilian and American diplomats both say the clash in the South Atlantic and the future of American relations with Latin America will be a major topic of conversation when Mr. Figueiredo meets with President Reagan on Wednesday. **********Though it shares a 1,200-mile-long border with Argentina and Mr.  Figueiredo himself lived in Buenos Aires as a child, Brazil has not joined in the overt expressions of support for its neighbor that have emerged elsewhere on the continent. The Brazilians recognize the Argentine claim to sovereignty over the islands but argue that the matter should have been settled through negotiation. **********At the same time, they have inclined their policy toward the Argentines by selling them arms and small planes and by denouncing British armed attacks while remaining officially silent on Argentina's actions. **********Where other Latin American nations have viewed Washington's backing of Britain in terms of hemispheric betrayal, the Brazilians have cited the development more as a justification of their decision in the last decade to pursue an independent foreign policy. First Visit in 11 Years **********One indication of the distance that the Brazilians have put between themselves and the United States is that Mr. Figueiredo's visit to Washington is the first for a Brazilian head of state in 11 years.  General Figueiredo has made 10 state visits elsewhere since becoming President three years ago. He has been aided by the improved international image Brazil has earned since the military abandoned the more ruthless tactics by which it ruled the country in the 1970's. **********The army took power here in 1964, and Mr. Figueiredo is the fifth general to have served as President. He has become a popular leader, however, because of his liberalization program and because of a breezy style that contrasts with the starchy manner of some of his predecessors. **********The journey comes at a time when relations between the two countries have passed from a period of deep division to one of cordially discussed disagreements. **********Relations reached their lowest point during the Carter Administration when Brazil protested American criticisms of its human rights record and American attempts to abort its nuclear development agreement with West Germany. In 1977, Brazil canceled its military assistance accords with the United States. **********Today, the differences are more geopolitical and economic. Brazil does not share President Reagan's view that the Soviet Union is largely responsible for regional tensions, arguing instead that economic disparities between poor and rich nations are more to blame. **********Brazil is also wary of any arrangement that could jeopardize its growing political and economic influence in the developing world by casting it as an ally or representative of the United States. The United States would like Brazil to become more involved in Central America, to be more critical of the presence of Cuban troops and the influence of Communist governments in Africa and to help guarantee the security of the petroleum lanes.  But Brazil is more concerned about high interest rates and access to the American market.
